Neuromatch 3.0 Opening Session
 
Abstract
 
Welcome to Neuromatch Conference 3.0! This year has been full of challenges and new opportunities. The neuromatch team is excited to welcome you to the meeting and highlight some of our ideas and experiments toward making the future of neuroscience conferences as open, accessible, and exciting as possible.

Traditional talk
Watch now
Chaotic dynamics in a spatially distributed network generate population-wide shared variability
Noga Mosheiff
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Bard Ermentrout ; Chengcheng Huang

Neural activity in the cortex is highly variable in response to an identical stimulus. This variability is correlated among different neurons and has been found to be low dimensional. Cortical population recordings have also shown that shared variability decreases with the distance between a pair of neurons. Previously, Huang et al. demonstrated that spatiotemporal dynamics in spiking neural networks can give a rise to population-wide shared variability. In this work, we show that the population-wide shared variability can be internally generated in deterministic recurrent networks with chaotic rate dynamics. We analyzed the dynamical regimes of recurrent networks with excitatory and inhibitory populations, which are spatially distributed on a ring or a torus. We found that the networks have dynamical regimes of different regular solutions, depending on the temporal and spatial scales of inhibition, such as static bumps, bulk oscillations, traveling waves and alternating bumps. In particular, in a parameter regime where the excitatory projection width is close to the inhibitory projection width, the networks exhibit chaotic rate dynamics. The chaotic solutions contain low-frequency power in rate variability and have low-dimensional and distance-dependent correlations, in agreement with experimental findings. Further, we found that the parameter regime of chaos becomes larger when the networks are driven by correlated noisy inputs. The chaotic regime expands as the variance of the correlated noise component increases, while being insensitive to the variance of the independent noise components.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Significant Instances in Motor Gestures of Different Songbird Species
Javier Nahuel Lassa Oritiz
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Cecilia T. Herbert, Instituto de Física de Buenos Aires (IFIBA) CONICET Argentina; Gabriel B. Mindlin, Instituto de Física de Buenos Aires (IFIBA) CONICET Argentina; Ana Amador, Instituto de Física de Buenos Aires (IFIBA) CONICET Argentina

The nervous system representation of a motor program is an open problem for most behaviors. In birdsong production, it has been proposed that some special temporal instances, linked to significant aspects of the motor gestures used to generate the song, are preferentially represented in the cortex. We compute these temporal instances for two species, and report which of them is better suited to test the proposed coding (as well as alternative models) against data.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Comparative Study of Fruit Fly Brain Circuit Models with FlyBrainLab
Yiyin Zhou
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Aurel A. Lazar; Tingkai Liu; Mehmet Kerem Turkcan; Yiyin Zhou;

Comparison of circuit models, either among versions developed by one’s own, or among those published in literature, is the critical but often neglected step towards discovering the functional logic of brain circuits. Three types of comparisons are of particular interest. The first is, starting from a given dataset and after building a number of circuit models published in the literature, to analyze and compare them under the same evaluation criteria. The second is to automate the construction of executable circuits from datasets gathered by different labs and, to analyze, evaluate and compare the different circuit realizations. The third is to analyze, evaluate and compare brain circuits at different developmental stages.

We recently developed the FlyBrainLab interactive computing platform whose main capabilities include 1) 3D exploration and visualization of fruit fly brain data, 2) creation of executable circuits directly from the fly brain data explored in step 1), and 3) interactive exploration of the functional logic of the devised executable circuits. Consequently, FlyBrainLab automates and greatly simplifies the construction of and the comparison between executable fly brain circuits.

To demonstrate the comprehensive capabilities of the FlyBrainLab, we present, respectively, three comparative studies of fruit fly brain circuit models. In the first example, we compare three circuit models of the fruit fly central complex from the literature, all based on the FlyCircuit dataset. In the second example, we demonstrate the effect on modeling the Antenna and the Antennal Lobe circuits developed upon, respectively, the FlyCircuit and the Hemibrain datasets. In the third example, we investigate the differences in odorant encoding and processing in the Drosophila early olfactory system at two different developmental stages, the adult and larva, based on the Hemibrain dataset and the Larva L1EM dataset, respectively. Each example is supported by a FlyBrainLab Circuit Library developed to facilitate the exploration of the neural circuit/subsystem of interest.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Modeling the temporal dynamics of neurons in the IT cortex
Arefeh Farahmandi Najaf Abadi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ahmad Kalhor , School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, College of Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran ; Mohammad-Reza A. Dehaqani , 1- School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, College of Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran , 2- School of Cognitive Sciences, Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences, Tehran, Iran.

Understanding the neural mechanism of image processing in the visual brain is one of the main efforts in system neuroscience. The ventral stream is thought to function as a series of hierarchical stages that encode visual information increasingly in successive cortical areas. Recent electrophysiological studies have been suggested that the early and late phases of neural response encode multiple levels of hierarchical abstractions, i.e. an earlier representation of mid-level categories in the IT responses compared with superordinate-level and subordinate-level categories. However, the neural mechanism of this temporal category representation at multiple levels is poorly understood. To address this, we applied a combination of convolutional neural networks and a partial least squares regression (PLS) model to predict firing rates of IT neurons in response to the stimuli. To train a model, in the first phase, the feature vectors of images are extracted from a convolution neural network. Then, the feature vectors used as input to PLS regression to predict the dynamics of neural response. We found that the predicted firing rates are highly correlated with the neuron’s actual firing rates. Furthermore, the encoding of predicted neural responses illustrated an earlier representation of mid-level category representation. The suggested model proposes a neural mechanism for temporal dynamics of category representation in the IT cortex. Moreover, the trained model can be applied to extract informative feature vectors for machine vision applications.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The more the merrier: Investigation of the perception of nature inspired stimuli via in vivo 2Photon imaging and visual discrimination tasks.
Elisabeta Balla
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Elisabeta Balla, Department of Neurophysiology (Bio II) RWTH Aachen , Institute of Neuroscience and Medicine (INM-2) Forschungszentrum Jülich ;Christopher Wiesbrock, Department of Neurophysiology (Bio II) RWTH Aachen , RTG 2416 Multisenses Multiscales ; Jenice Linde , Department of Neurophysiology (Bio II) RWTH Aachen, RTG 2416 Multisenses Multiscales; Björn M. Kampa, Department of Neurophysiology (Bio II) RWTH Aachen, Institute of Neuroscience and Medicine (INM-2) Forschungszentrum Jülich, , RTG 2416 Multisenses Multiscales, JARA BRAIN

Contrary to bandwidth enriched naturalistic stimuli, standard simplistic visual stimuli such as sine-wave gratings are parametrically defined and lack variability. In view of highly developed visual systems, i.e., the primate visual system, it has been proposed that due to a divisive gain normalization, more information in a stimulus does not necessarily come with a functional advantage in terms of perception. This study aims to test the validity of this concept in mice in respect to their capability to discriminate between orientations and spatial frequencies with varying bandwidths. In a touchscreen chamber-based 2AFC task, two paradigms test for respectively spatial frequency discrimination performance with varying orientation bandwidths and the effect of different spatial frequency bandwidths on orientation discrimination. There was no clear significant influence of the spatial frequency bandwidth on orientation discrimination, whereas spatial frequency discrimination was significantly influenced by the orientation bandwidth. We can conclude that the proposed gain normalization seems to take place in terms of an orientation discrimination task, but not for a spatial frequency discrimination task. In order to address this question at the level of a large population of individual neurons, we used in vivo 2-photon calcium imaging in virally injected mice (pAAV.Syn.GCaMP6f.WPRE.SV40), expressing the activity dependent calcium indicator GCamP6f. Orientation and spatial frequency bandwidth enriched stimuli were presented at pseudo-random sequences. Significantly higher qualitative and quantitative responses resulted from the higher orientation bandwidths, whereas the same effect was not observed with the spatial frequency bandwidth increase.
Interactive talk
Watch now
PaSClass: A Machine Learning Pipeline to classify excitatory and inhibitory neurons of the rat Parasubiculum.
Alexandra Tzilivaki
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Rosanna P. Sammons ; Dietmar Schmitz

The parasubiculum (PaS) is a small brain region that belongs to the parahippocampal formation, lying between the presubiculum and the medial entorhinal cortex. PaS neurons are divided into 3 main classes: WFS1 positive excitatory neurons, Reelin positive interneurons, and parvalbumin (PV) interneurons. Using in vitro patch-clamp recordings, we analyzed the electrophysiological profile of more than 500 PaS neurons. Immunolabelling information was available only for ~50% of the dataset. Of this, the vast majority were WFS1+ positive neurons. A small proportion was Reelin-positive that exhibited similar electrophysiological properties to WFS1, while the least represented class was PV interneurons. For such a multiclass and imbalanced dataset with similar electrophysiological features for the WFS1 and Reelin classes, the commonly used threshold analyses or clustering approaches were inefficient to predict the class of the remaining neurons. Thus, we designed and developed a machine learning classification pipeline to predict the class of our PaS neurons. Firstly, we implemented and tested multiple classification algorithms, including Support Vector Classifier, Complement Naive Bayes Classifier, Logistic Regression, K-Nearest Neighbor classifier, Multilayer Perceptron Model (MLP), and the Random Forest Classifier (RF). Using exclusively the dataset where the immunolabelling information was available, we used stratification and cross-validation, to test the performance of the models. Appropriate class weights were added where applicable. RF and MLP yielded the highest accuracy scores across multiple trials. We continued by training and extensively testing the performance of our two best models, the RF and MLP. Finally, we used them to label the neurons lacking immunolabelling data. Tested models returned identical labels for 90% of the 244 cases. Cells with different predicted labels were excluded. The whole approach was performed using the open-access Python Sklearn package. We consider this pipeline as a new tool for predicting the staining of neurons when immunolabelling and morphological information is limited.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Inhibition of the Supplementary Motor Area Affects Distribution of Effort Over Time
Aviv Emanuel
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jasmine Herszage; Haggai Sharon; Nira Liberman; Nitzan Censor

In tasks that extend over time, people tend to exert much effort at the beginning and the end, but not in the middle, exhibiting the stuck-in-the-middle pattern (STIM). To date, little is known about the neural mechanisms underlying this effect. As the supplementary motor area (SMA) was previously implicated in coding prospective task-demands, we tested its role in producing the STIM pattern. Participants first underwent an SMA-localization session in which they tapped their fingers repeatedly while fMRI-scanned. In the next two sessions, before playing a 10-minute computer game that measured effort-engagement, participants underwent inhibitory 1-Hz repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation over the SMA, or over a control precuneus location. Three control experiments and a pretest confirmed that this task yields a STIM, which can be eliminated when the task lacks a salient end-point, or is too short. The results of the main experiment showed a more pronounced STIM following inhibitory SMA stimulation compared to control. A control analysis showed that overall level of effort was similar in both conditions, rendering alternative accounts in terms of motor inhibition unlikely. These findings are consistent with the possibility that the SMA may play a role in moment-to-moment coding of effort value, or in related sub-processes, which can cause effort to be distributed more equally over the course of a task.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Online Replication of Age Effects in Two Variants of the Mnemonic Similarity Task
Jack-Morgan Mizell
 
Abstract
 
Performance on The Mnemonic Similarity Task (MST) has been shown to be sensitive to age-related changes in medial temporal lobe function. The traditional MST has participants see a set of images during an encoding phase and then test their memory for these images in a test phase where participants must judge whether the images they are seeing are repetitions of previous images, similar images to those they saw, or completely new images. Age-related changes have been shown to relate to the ability to discriminate similar images (Lures) from previously seen images. This sensitivity has led to widespread use of the task, and several of its variants to probe age-related changes within the temporal lobes. However, whether these effects replicate in an online setting are currently unknown.

In this study we used two online versions of the MST-Objects version (MST-O) on an online sample of Older and Younger adults. Using both paradigms, we replicate previously reported age effects in the online setting. Specifically, and in line with lab-based studies, we see age-dependent effect on lure discrimination, while finding no such age effect on recognition abilities. Additionally, we were able to replicate a similarity-dependent effect on Lure Discrimination, where the more similar a Lure is to its original image, the less likely it is to be correctly identified, regardless of age group. We were also able to show that behavior in both tasks correlate across both online versions, showing that we are able to capture some meaningful individual differences. Both online versions of the MST-O captures similar behavior, and age-related differences to the lab-based experiments which opens up the potential for using the MST on larger and more diverse samples than are typically possible in lab-based experiments.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Peripheral cardiovascular hypersensitivity and blunted ventromedial prefrontal cortex reactivity in generalized anxiety disorder
Adam Teed he/him/his
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Maria Puhl, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Tulsa, Oklahoma; Rachel C. Lapidus, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Tulsa, Oklahoma, Department of Psychology, University of Tulsa, Tulsa, Oklahoma; Valerie Upshaw, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Tulsa, Oklahoma; Rayus T. Kuplicki, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Tulsa, Oklahoma; Jerzy Bodurka, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Stephenson School for Biomedical Engineering, University of Oklahoma, Norman, Oklahoma; Justin S. Feinstein, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Tulsa, Oklahoma, Oxley College of Health Sciences, University of Tulsa, Tulsa, Oklahoma; Wesley K. Thompson, University of California San Diego, San Diego, California; Martin P. Paulus, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Tulsa, Oklahoma, Oxley College of Health Sciences, University of Tulsa, Tulsa, Oklahoma; Sahib S. Khalsa, Laureate Institute for Brain Research, Tulsa, Oklahoma, Oxley College of Health Sciences, University of Tulsa, Tulsa, Oklahoma

Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is characterized by apprehensive expectation of aversive bodily states, yet the link between GAD and autonomic arousal is unclear. We investigated potential cardiorespiratory interoceptive dysfunction in GAD using peripheral adrenergic stimulation with the adrenaline analog isoproterenol (0.5, 2 mcg) and saline during BOLD fMRI. Infusions were randomized and double-blinded. GAD (n=29) and HC (n=29) females, matched for age and BMI, rated cardiorespiratory sensation intensity throughout infusions using a dial. Chronotropic dose 25 estimates, an indirect measure of beta-adrenergic receptor sensitivity, showed that GADs exhibited greater heart rate (HR) responses to isoproterenol than HCs (p=0.04, Cohen’s d=0.55). Linear mixed-effects (LME) models for HR revealed this effect to be driven by the 0.5 mcg dose (p=0.002). Sensation ratings were also amplified at this dose (p<0.01). GADs retrospectively reported heightened anxiety across doses (p≤0.005), and heightened heartbeat (p<0.001) and breathing (p≤0.001) intensity at 0.5 mcg. GADs showed significantly attenuated neural responses in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC) at 0.5 mcg relative to HCs (p<0.05 corrected). We corroborated these results in separate region-of-interest time-series analyses using multivariate Functional Principal Components Analysis (mFPCA), which characterizes the major modes of variation around smoothed mean trajectories. LMEs on coefficients obtained from the mFPCA showed time-course differences for GADs during the 0.5 mcg dose for HR (p=0.02), dial ratings (p=0.01), and BOLD responses from salience and default mode network regions, including the vmPFC (p=0.01). In summary, adrenergic stimulation in GAD females revealed evidence of autonomic hypersensitivity, which was accompanied by heightened cardiorespiratory interoception, anxiety, and attenuated neural responses in the vmPFC, a region important for self-referential processing and visceromotor control. Our results provide strong evidence that, in females, 1) GAD constitutes deficits in appraisal and regulation of sympathetic arousal, and 2) both autonomic and central nervous systems contribute to interoceptive pathophysiology in GAD.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Receptive field geometry shapes information content of the neural code
Alex Kunin
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Vladimir Itskov

A phenomenon observed in many neural populations, notably vertebrate retina, is the significance of weak pairwise correlations in shaping the collective behavior of the population. Models matching these second-order correlations but assuming no higher-order interactions successfully describe the distribution of population states and capture most of the information content of the neural code. We demonstrate that this phenomenon may largely be a consequence of receptive field geometry in the retina, and may extend to other populations of neurons which encode low-dimensional geometric information, such as place cells.

We show these maximum-entropy models accurately capture the information-theoretic content of the activity of mouse retinal ganglion cells. Moreover, such models successfully describe a population of model neurons with identical receptive fields, driven purely by feed-forward input. In contrast, cells with spatially-scrambled receptive fields retain the same pattern of pairwise correlations, but second-order models capture only a small fraction of the information content of the resulting code, suggesting the specific geometric structure of receptive fields plays a part. We explain these phenomena using the mathematical theory of convex geometry, notably a result known as Helly's theorem.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Grouped single-unit activity in a cortical avian nucleus supports a population model of birdsong production in Serinus canaria
Cecilia Herbert (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Santiago Boari, Dpto. de Física, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, Argentina and Instituto de Física de Buenos Aires, IFIBA-CONICET, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Gabriel B. Mindlin, Dpto. de Física, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, Argentina and Instituto de Física de Buenos Aires, IFIBA-CONICET, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Ana Amador, Dpto. de Física, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, Argentina and Instituto de Física de Buenos Aires, IFIBA-CONICET, Buenos Aires, Argentina

Birdsong requires fine coordination of the muscles in the vocal organ and respiratory system. The song system, which is the neural architecture dedicated to song production in oscine birds, poses a beautiful opportunity to model the activity of a circuit of interconnected neural nuclei for the production of complex behaviour.

Such a model has been developed previously by our laboratory. Our model makes specific predictions about the timing of population neural activity in different nuclei needed to produce song and can reproduce respiratory patterns observed in canary song phrases of different types.

In this work, the model was used to generate respiratory patterns that correspond to two types of phrases of canary song, given a proposed sparse activity in nucleus HVC (proper name), one of the nuclei involved. This telencephalic nucleus plays a key role in the production of motor commands, but the neural code it uses is still under debate.

We put our model to the test by recording extracellularly from nucleus HVC in singing canaries, isolating single-units that fire during particular phrase types and analyzing at which song instances these neurons fire.

We found that grouped activity across animals is in good correspondence to the population activity that can produce realistic respiratory patterns in our model for the two types of phrases studied. Furthermore, the experimental data show activity in additional song instances that will enrich further iterations of the model.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Variability and stability of folding patterns across cortical development and evolution
Katja Heuer
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Katja Heuer, Center for Research and Interdisciplinarity; Mathieu Santin, Institute for Brain and Spinal Cord; Marc Herbin, National Museum of Natural History; Roberto Toro, Institut Pasteur

Folding patterns are very characteristic of different species. Most quantification methods focus, however, on the estimation of the degree of folding – the description of their pattern remaining mostly qualitative. We developed a method to generate folding graphs which summarise the folding pattern of an individual brain. We illustrate the application of our method by computing folding graphs for several different mammalian species, as well as throughout their development.
We manually segmented the cerebrum and reconstructed 3D surfaces for all specimens. Based on mean curvature, we built gyral skeletons for each specimen and several developmental stages. The lines in the skeleton represent the axis of each gyrus, providing information about their orientation and width. We then simplify these lines into a graph and represent the folding pattern as an adjacency matrix where each cell corresponds to an encounter point between 2 or more gyri. We finally flatten the gyral skeletons.
Here, we will illustrate the flat skeletons for different primate species and developmental stages for several of the species. The complexity of the folding patterns increases rapidly with increasing brain volume leading to the development of a shared pattern which emerges even across different branches of the phylogenetic tree. Similarly, decreases in brain volume lead to a simplification of the folding pattern which occurs in a similar manner across different branches. A first comparison of folding patterns using graph edit distance leads to a clustering of species which reflects their brain volume more than a clade-specifc pattern.
Fold graphs can become a useful complement to estimations of the degree of folding, and provide a new perspective on the study of phylogenetic diversity.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Computation-Based Feature Representation of Body Expressions in the Human Brain
Marta Poyo Solanas
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Marta Poyo Solanas, Maastricht University; Maarten Vaessen, Maastricht University; Beatrice de Gelder, Maastricht University.

Research on body category representation, action and emotion has provided evidence that the brain is endowed with social perception skills. Yet, the actual visual processes that drive expression perception are still unknown. We went beyond research on high-level emotion representations to discover which mid-level body features drive automatic emotion perception.
We computed quantitative body features from angry, happy, fearful and neutral whole-body movements. These features represented kinematic (i.e. velocity, acceleration and vertical movement) and postural (i.e. symmetry, surface, the angles between body segments and limb contraction) aspects of affective body movements. Using representational similarity and multivoxel pattern analysis techniques, we investigated whether the (dis)similarity of body posture and kinematics between different emotional categories could explain neural responses to body expressions in and beyond body-selective regions.
Our results reveal six major findings. First, computationally defined features are systematically related to distributed brain areas. Second, postural rather than kinematic features reflect the affective category structure of body movements. Limb angles and limb contraction were particularly relevant for distinguishing fear from other body expressions and were represented in several regions including affective, action observation and motor preparation networks. Third, the posterior superior temporal sulcus differentiated fearful from other affective categories using limb contraction rather than kinematics, despite this area being known for its involvement in biological motion processing. Fourth, extrastriate and fusiform body area (EBA and FBA) also showed greater tuning to postural features. Although the pattern of feature representation in these areas was similar, the stimuli representation in EBA was very dissimilar to that of FBA, possibly reflecting their different roles in body processing. Fifth, kinematic and postural feature processing was not segregated into dorsal and ventral streams, with the exception of one feature: velocity. Finally, the brain representation of emotional categories showed a distributed pattern.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Spatial connectivity matches direction selectivity in visual cortex
L. Federico Rossi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kenneth D. Harris; Matteo Carandini

The selectivity of neuronal responses arises from the architecture of excitatory and inhibitory connections. In primary visual cortex, the selectivity of layer 2/3 neurons for stimulus orientation and direction is thought to arise from similarly-selective intracortical inputs. A neuron’s excitatory inputs, however, can have diverse stimulus preferences, and inhibitory inputs can be promiscuous and unselective. We revealed that excitatory and inhibitory intracortical connections to a layer 2/3 neuron accord with its selectivity by obeying precise spatial patterns. We used rabies tracing to label and functionally image the excitatory and inhibitory inputs to individual pyramidal neurons of mouse visual cortical layer 2/3. Presynaptic excitatory neurons spanned layers 2/3 and 4 and were distributed coaxial to the postsynaptic neuron’s preferred orientation, favouring the region opposite to its preferred direction. By contrast, presynaptic inhibitory neurons resided within layer 2/3 and favoured locations near the postsynaptic neuron and ahead of its preferred direction. The direction selectivity of a postsynaptic neuron was unrelated to the selectivity of presynaptic neurons but correlated with the spatial displacement between excitatory and inhibitory presynaptic ensembles. Similar asymmetric connectivity establishes direction selectivity in the retina, suggesting that this circuit motif might be canonical in sensory processing.
We are currently discovering similar patterns in the morphological reconstructions of the postsynaptic neurons, whose dendritic trees extended preferentially along the neurons’ preferred orientation. These results suggest a link between the dendritic architecture and the function of V1 neurons: by extending towards the appropriate inputs, dendrites may provide a morphological substrate for the emergence of visual selectivity.

 Interactive talk
Watch now
Fast-spiking interneurons support the development of symmetrical head-direction tuning curves
Pierre Orhan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Adrien Peyrache, Adrian Duszkiewicz

The postsubiculum (PoSub) is the cortical relay of the head-direction (HD) signal, projecting to the superficial layers of the medial entorhinal cortex, transferring HD inputs from the thalamus. Recent evidence from our laboratory suggests a topographical arrangement of the HD signal within the PoSub, as evidenced by symmetrical tuning of fast-spiking (FS) inhibitory neurons. Specifically, FS cells show a 1-, 2- or 3-fold symmetries in their tuning to HD. The origin of this arrangement is unknown. It could reflect topographical arrangement of local (<200 um) excitatory HD cells. Alternatively, it could result from a transformation of thalamic inputs directly by the inhibitory networks. To address this question, we have investigated the problem from a computational perspective. Here, we developed mechanistic, optimised, and random models to capture the emergence of the fast-spiking interneuron tuning curves based on thalamocortical and inter-inhibitory cell connectivity.
In a model of structured symmetric inputs to FS cells, constraining tuning curves variance to HD forces the density of each symmetry within the FS cell population to reflect exactly its contribution to input decoding. Conversely, the objective of recreating the inputs leads to a biologically plausible plasticity rule, assuming that (i) FS cells operate in a linear regime and (ii) connections between FS cells are plastic. Although the model accounts for tuning curve and fold distribution, the learning rule did not constraint the latter. Accordingly, a network with random connections that are optimized on the firing modulation of the FS cell tuning curves (range, mean and average but not symmetries) recapitulates the experimental data. Learning of a precise structure of thalamocortical connections seems therefore not necessary. We conclude that FS-FS connections and linear integration of thalamic inputs by FS cells are sufficient prerequisites for the emergence of spatially-symmetric responses in the brain’s navigation system.
Traditional talk
Watch now
M1 GABA relates to functional connectivity changes and retention in visuomotor adaptation
Caroline Nettekoven
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Caroline Nettekoven, Wellcome Centre for Integrative Neuroimaging, FMRIB, University of Oxford, UK ; Ned Jenkinson, School of Sport, Exercise and Rehabilitation Sciences, University of Birmingham, UK ; Charlotte Stagg, Wellcome Centre for Integrative Neuroimaging, FMRIB, University of Oxford, UK

Interacting with our ever-changing physical environment requires continual recalibration of the motor system. One mechanism by which this occurs is motor adaptation. Understanding how motor adaptation is implemented by the human brain, how different regions work in concert to retain adaptive movement accuracy, and how this function is linked to metabolic use of neurochemicals poses an important challenge in neuroscience. In humans, motor sequence learning is related to concentration of γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the primary motor cortex (M1). However, the role of M1 GABA in adaptation - where behaviour is acquired outside M1, but retained within M1 - is unclear. Here, we used an ultra-high field MR multimodal acquisition to address the hypothesis that M1 GABA and M1-Cerebellar functional connectivity would relate to retention of adaptation, but not acquisition of adaptation. As such, we demonstrate higher baseline M1 [GABA] relates to greater retention of adaptation but does not relate to adaptation-acquisition. This relationship is mediated by change in M1-Cerebellar functional connectivity: higher M1 [GABA] relates to a decrease in M1-Cerebellar connectivity, resulting in greater retention. These findings showed anatomical, neurochemical and behavioural specificity: As expected, no relationship was found between retention and a control metabolite, as well as retention and connectivity change between control regions and no relationship was found between M1 [GABA] and behaviour in a control condition. The implication of a mechanistic link from neurochemistry to retention significantly advances our understanding of population variability in retention behaviour and provides a crucial step towards developing therapeutic interventions to restore motor abilities.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Machine Learning and Mathematical Methods for the Brain Age Problem
Alessandro Maria Selvitella
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Justin Asher, Purdue University Fort Wayne; Khoa Tan Dang, Purdue University Fort Wayne; Peter Klopfenstein, Purdue University Fort Wayne; Maxwell Masters, Purdue University Fort Wayne; Jucoen Yeater, Purdue University Fort Wayne

Overall, the global population is aging and, as a result, there is an increasing frequency of age-related diseases. Researchers have tried to establish neuroanatomical biomarkers of aging and understand how the healthy adult brain changes with age. This is the Brain Age Problem (BAP). Our research concentrates on the use of brain biometrics, machine learning methods, and pure mathematics to improve the current answers to the Brain Age Problem (BAP). In this work, we derived the Normalized Stretching Ratio (NSR) given by (Thickness)^2/(Surface Area), which is a surrogate of the isoperimetric ratio that quantifies the stretching of a brain region. We used the NSRs of 68 brain regions as the predictors of a classification model on a freely available data set of young adults, collected by the Human Connectome Project. Our model does not sacrifice prediction accuracy when compared to a similar model on the raw data and so the dimensionality reduction provided by the NSRs yields a simpler explanation of the changes that occur in the brain. Our model reduces the gap between explainability and prediction accuracy by merging ideas from pure mathematical fields, such as differential geometry, machine learning, and neuroscience. This is joint work with my students Justin Asher, Khoa Tan Dang, Peter Klopfenstein, Maxwell Masters, and Jucoen Yeater.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Investigating How Aesthetic Preferences Change Over Time
Hassan Aleem
 
Abstract
 
Everyday experience suggests that our aesthetic preferences change throughout the course of our lives, sometimes quite abruptly. However, much of the existing research surrounding aesthetic preferences does not consider the impact of such changes. Understanding how and why our preferences may change over time is important not only for fields such as neuroaesthetics, marketing, and neuroeconomics, but for cognitive sciences overall. Here, we investigated how aesthetic preferences for different colored shirts, cars, and phone cases changed over a 4-week period. We measured changes in preferences for these three categories on a weekly basis. Our results showed that aesthetic preferences tended to drift further from their initial starting point as time went on. This effect was consistent for all three categories. We further found that aesthetic stability tended to increase as a function of age, but did not differ across sex. To our knowledge, this is the first study to investigate aesthetic preferences across multiple timepoints as well as categories. Our findings show that aesthetic preferences are not stable even at a weekly interval, stressing the importance of understanding how these changes may be reflected in existing experiments as well as in other domains of cognitive science.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Propagation and modulation of information in visual pathway
Chengcheng Huang (she)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Alexandre Pouget, University of Geneva; Brent Doiron, University of Chicago

How neuronal variability impacts sensory coding is a central question in systems neuroscience, often with complex and model dependent answers. Many studies explore population models with a parametric structure for response tuning and variability, preventing an analysis of how synaptic circuitry establish neural codes. We study stimulus coding in networks of spiking neuron models with spatially ordered excitatory and inhibitory connectivity. The wiring structure is capable of producing rich population-wide shared neuronal variability that agrees with many features of recorded cortical activity. While both the spatial scales of feedforward and recurrent projections strongly affect noise correlations, only recurrent projections, and in particular inhibitory projections, can introduce correlations that limit the stimulus information available to a decoder. Using a spatial neural field model we relate the recurrent circuit conditions for information limiting noise correlations to how recurrent excitation and inhibition can form spatio-temporal patterns of population-wide activity.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Motor unit firing frequencies are muscle dependent during static contraction: importance of axon distance?
Eric Kirk
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Eric A. Kirk, The University of Western Ontario; Charles L. Rice, The University of Western Ontario

The somatic nervous system innervates hundreds of different striated muscles, each comprised of a sub-population of motor units (MU). For any voluntary muscle contraction (to remain static or move the joint) MU activation is required that first involves MU recruitment (i.e. spatial control) and subsequent firing rate modulation (i.e. temporal control) to enable precision in producing tension at the tendon. Because contractile output is affected by structural (fibre type, innervation ration, etc.) as well as synaptic (intrinsic and extrinsic) properties, our aim was to understand which structural factor is most probable to affect the observation of different MU firing frequencies among muscles. Thus, we generated four hypotheses based on: fibre type, innervation type (brainstem vs. spinal), axon distance and anatomical location.
From an aggregated dataset containing MU firing rates from 15 different muscles and thousands of MU samples from male and female adult participants, post-hoc statistical comparisons were made based on the probability of an observed model (alternative) residing within a simulated distribution of model outputs (null distribution). For each hypothesis test, the simulated distribution was based on a fitted y-intercept with the addition of bootstrapping from studentized residuals of the observed model. We then performed 100 iterations of case bootstrapping for each hypothesis. Statistical significance was determined by a two-sided p-value calculation, where the observed slope coefficient (from the alternative) acted as the alpha value against the simulated distribution estimate.
Of the four hypotheses, axon distance to the muscle was the most probable hypothesis to reject the null estimate (q-value < 0.005). Therefore, axon distance as a factor to effect firing rates among muscles was least likely in our dataset to occur by chance, and we speculate that important axon-dependent structures related to internode length and maximum conduction velocity act as important limits on firing rate distributions.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Connectomes across development reveal principles of brain maturation in C. elegans
Daniel Witvliet
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ben Mulcahy; James K. Mitchell; Yaron Meirovitch; Daniel R. Berger; Yuelong Wu; Yufang Liu; Wan Xian Koh; Rajeev Parvathala; Douglas Holmyard; Richard L. Schalek; Nir Shavit; Andrew D. Chisholm; Jeff W. Lichtman; Aravinthan D.T. Samuel; Mei Zhen

From birth to adulthood, an animal’s nervous system changes as its body grows and its behaviours mature. However, the extent of circuit remodelling across the connectome is poorly understood. We used serial-section electron microscopy to reconstruct the brain of eight isogenic C. elegans individuals at different ages to learn how an entire wiring diagram changes with maturation. We found that the overall geometry of the nervous system is preserved from birth to adulthood, establishing a constant scaffold upon which synaptic change is built. We observed substantial connectivity differences among individuals that make each brain partly unique. We also observed developmental connectivity changes that are consistent between animals but different among neurons, altering the strengths of existing connections and creating additional connections. Collective synaptic changes alter information processing of the brain. Across maturation, the decision-making circuitry is maintained whereas sensory and motor pathways are substantially remodelled, and the brain becomes progressively more modular and feedforward. These synaptic changes reveal principles that underlie brain maturation.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Shared neural activity patterns between facial expression and shape recognition
Avisha She/Her
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Abhinav Singh, Integrated Science Education And Research Centre (ISERC),  Visva-Bharati University, Santiniketan; Hardik Bhatnagar; Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani; Alish Dipani, Birla Institute of Technology and Science, KK Birla Goa Campus; Anindita Bhattacharjee, Indian Institute of Technology, Banaras Hindu University; Nidhi Seethapathi, University of Pennsylvania

Facial expressions are among the most informative stimuli we perceive: Even a split-second impression of a person's face gives us an estimate of their mood and direction of attention. Existing neurological evidence strongly suggests the existence of machinery dedicated to processing facial expressions in the human brain. We consider an essential shape recognition process gates this facial expression processing machinery.
Therefore, here we propose a hypothesis that the facial expression recognition mechanism shares some shape recognition steps in the visual system in the cortical areas. We tested this hypothesis using the fMRI data from the Human Connectome Project of 339 subjects performing an emotion processing task. Similar to the Hariri emotion task paradigm, the subjects matched fearful or angry facial expressions with expressions on the bottom of the screen and also matched geometric shapes like longitudinal and latitudinal ellipses.
We separately analysed BOLD activations of the cortical surface regions of the two tasks using Multi-variate pattern analysis. We first selected the top 5% most active brain regions for both the tasks using ANOVA feature selection. These selected features using support vector machines linear kernel classified facial expressions recognition from resting-state with an accuracy of 83%. Similarly, for shape recognition, we got 81% accuracy. Further, the selected areas in ventral stream visual cortex like Posterior Inferior Temporal, Fusiform Face Complex, VMV3 in a ventromedial visual area, which best correlated with object recognition, showed a high correlation with facial expression recognition as well. The other cortical regions involving primary and early visual cortical sectors were also common to both the recognition tasks, but with varying degrees of activation. Thus, these results indicate that facial expression recognition and shape recognition have shared neural activity patterns.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Behavioral and neural bases of tactile shape discrimination learning in head-fixed mice
Jinho Kim
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jonathan Andrew Cheung; Andrew Erskine; Samuel Andrew Hires

Tactile three-dimensional shape recognition requires perception of object surface angles. We investigated how object surface angles are represented in the brain, how this representation is constructed from sensory inputs, and how it reorganizes across learning. Head-fixed mice learned to discriminate object angles by active exploration with one whisker. Calcium imaging of excitatory neurons in layers 2-4 of barrel cortex revealed maps of object-angle tuning before and after learning. Three-dimensional whisker tracking demonstrated that the sensory input components that best discriminate object angle (vertical bending and slide distance) also have the greatest influence on object-angle tuning of individual neurons. Despite high turnover in active ensemble membership across learning, both the population distribution of object-angle tuning preferences and individual preferences remained stable. Motor behavior and sensory inputs were not changed across learning, but population response from object-angle-tuned neurons better discriminated object angle after learning. These results show how discrimination training enhances stimulus selectivity in primary somatosensory cortex while maintaining perceptual stability.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
A Tale of Two Trees: Modeling Apical and Basal Tree Contribution to L2/3 V1 Pyramidal Cell Orientation Selectivity
Konstantinos-Evangelos Petousakis
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Konstantinos-Evangelos Petousakis, IMBB, FORTH and Department of Biology, University of Crete; Jiyoung Park, Department of Neuroscience, Baylor College of Medicine; Athanasia Papoutsi, IMBB, FORTH; Stelios Smirnakis, Department of Neuroscience, Baylor College of Medicine and Department of Neurology, Brigham and Women’s H. and JP VA H., Harvard Medical School; Panayiota Poirazi, IMBB, FORTH

Pyramidal neurons, a mainstay of cortical regions, receive a plethora of inputs from various areas onto morphologically distinct apical and basal trees. Both trees differentially contribute to the somatic response, thus defining distinct anatomical and possibly functional sub-units. To assess the latter, we modeled the complex response pattern of the L2/3 V1 pyramidal neuron to spatially tuned synaptic input. Our goal was to elucidate the contribution of each tree to the response pattern of the neuron. Towards this goal, we created a morphologically detailed computational model of a single cell, validated against electrophysiological data. We investigated the role of dendritic integration at the basal and apical trees, and its contribution in shaping cell responses. Results indicate that somatic action potentials are generated only when input coincides bilaterally, as unilateral stimuli are generally unable to evoke spiking activity at the soma. In addition, given equal synaptic drive, the responses of the neuron appear to be initiated by the apical tree, as its dendritic spiking activity temporally precedes somatic activity. Finally, basal tree activity, in the form of either depolarization or dendritic spiking, is essential for producing somatic activity, despite the fact that most somatic spikes are apically-driven. This model provides evidence for synergistic computations taking place in the basal and apical trees of the neuron, and emphasizes the role of predictive and attentional feedback input.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Hand Specificity And Interactions With Movement Planning In Cortical Oscillations
Gunnar Blohm
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Gunnar Blohm, Centre of Neuroscience Studies, Queen’s University, Kingston, Ontario, Canada; Douglas O. Cheyne, Program in Neurosciences and Mental Health, The Hospital for Sick Children Research Institute, Toronto, Ontario, Canada; J. Douglas Crawford, Centre for Vision Research, York University, Toronto, Ontario, Canada

To plan a reach or pointing movement, sensory information about the movement goal needs to be converted into a representation that specifies the desired movement with respect to the hand to be used. Here we use a pro/anti-pointing task that has been performed separately with the left and right hand and record MEG signals to investigate which brain areas in the reaching network reflect hand specificity. We also ask which of those areas are involved in computing a hand-specific movement plan as revealed by differences between both hands in the coding for the movement plan. We found eight areas that showed specific hand-related changes in oscillatory beta band power prior to movement onset: POJ, SPOC, IPL, SPL, VIP, S1, M1 and PMd. However, of those, only SPOC, IPL, VIP and M1 showed significant interactions between hand use and motor coding during movement planning, indicative of a hand-specific movement plan. Together with previous findings (Blohm, et al. 2019), we interpret these results as evidence for independent coding of the motor plan and hand use in areas POJ and PMd. In contrast, SPL and S1 seem to code for hand use, but might not represent an explicit motor plan. Finally, SPOC, IPL, VIP and M1 show evidence for a motor plan that is specific to the hand used.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Rhythmic Properties of Attention across Development
Ivette Planell-Mendez
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ivette Planell-Mendez, Princeton Neuroscience Institute, Princeton University; Myrthe J. Ottenhoff, Princeton Neuroscience Institute, Princeton University; Sabine Kastner, Princeton Neuroscience Institute, Princeton University

Classically, attention has been understood as a constant and continuous process. However, recent evidence suggests that attention alternates rapidly between states of enhanced and diminished perceptual sensitivity. This rhythmic property, which facilitates environmental sampling during the allocation of attention, allows attention to be flexibly applied to the most relevant target at any moment. Importantly, these dynamic attentional state alternations can be measured at the behavioral level. In adults, this rhythmicity occurs in the theta range (3-8 Hz). While adult and non-human primate studies have shaped our understanding of these dynamic properties of attention, little is known about this rhythmicity during development. In this study we aim to determine the developmental trajectory of rhythmic properties of attention at the behavioral level and hypothesize that it becomes more adult-like with age. A barrier to studying this in childhood has been that tasks for revealing the rhythmicity of attention are long and demanding. We’ve implemented a foveal task that is accessible for children, yet still captures this rhythmicity. During this task children fixate on a central point while a blue dot cloud followed by a red dot cloud appears on the screen. The appearance of the red cloud serves as a cue and is followed by a random cue-target interval that varies between 250-750ms after which time, one of the two clouds changes slightly in contrast. The ability to detect this contrast change depends on the phase of attention at the time it occurs, thereby allowing us to quantify the frequency at which attention is rhythmically oscillating. We are collecting data for ages 6-8 and 11-13, and have so far collected data from 11 children in the older group, to determine if there is a significant difference in peak frequency between these age groups. If so, we will include more ages to get a more holistic picture of the developmental trajectory of rhythmicity in attention.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Frequent nightmares and parasympathetic activity reflected in increased heart rate during sleep
Vivien Tomacsek
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Borbála Blaskovich, Max Planck Institute of Psychiatry, Germany; Anna Király, Eötvös Loránd University, Hungary; Richárd Reichardt, Budapest University of Technology and Economics, Hungary; Péter Simor, Eötvös Loránd University, Hungary

Nightmare Disorder, a parasomnia generally considered to be related to REM phase, is associated with vivid, emotionally dysphoric dreams commonly resulting in awakening and microarousals, experienced at least on a weekly basis. Poor subjective sleep quality is characterised by pathophysiological features such as abnormal arousal processes and sympathetic influences, which might lead to fragmented sleep. Dysfunctional parasympathetic regulation, especially before and during REM phases, brings about changes in the heart rate and its variability in subjects with Nightmare Disorder. We hypothesised that cardiac variability is attenuated in participants experiencing frequent nightmares as opposed to healthy control subjects during less deep sleep stages. Based on the second-nights’ polysomnographic recordings of 23 Nightmare Disordered (NM) and 29 control (CTL) subjects, we examined heart rate variability (HRV) during pre-REM, REM, post-REM and slow wave sleep periods, separately. In addition, two types of wakeful periods were also included in the analysis – besides resting state before sleep onset, ECG recordings of the participants during an emotional picture rating task were analysed. According to our results, a significant difference was found in the mean heart rate (HR) of the NM and CTL groups in the nocturnal segments but not during resting wakefulness before sleep onset, suggesting autonomic dysregulation, specifically during sleep in Nightmare Disorder. However, despite the accelerated heart rate in the NM subjects at night, they did not exhibit lower HRV. Our findings also show remarkable differences between the examined sleep stages regardless of the group, demonstrating major changes in the autonomic regulation throughout sleep. Regarding the emotional task, we also found a contrast between the NM and CTL subjects’ HR and HRV, which might indicate altered processes of emotion regulation in Nightmare Disorder.
