Panel on Future Opportunities in Neuroscience and Neurotechnologies with BRAIN Initiative Alliance Leadership
 
Abstract
 
Join a discussion on the future of neuroscience and neurotechnology funding with leadership from federal and non-government members of the BRAIN Initiative Alliance. Listen, learn, and engage with long-time collaborators in the U.S. BRAIN Initiative as they consider questions like:

- What might we expect for neuroscience funding in the coming years?
- What will the priorities be and will the focus of research opportunities shift?
- What is the long-term plan for government-supported projects like data archives?
- How might we support technology dissemination to the broader neuroscience community?

Panelists:

- Michelle Elekonich, Deputy Division Director, Division of Integrative Organismal Systems, Directorate for Biological Sciences, National Science Foundation

- David Markowitz, Program Manager, IARPA

- Caroline Montojo, Director, Life Sciences and Director, Brain Initiatives, The Kavli Foundation

- John Ngai, Director of NIH BRAIN Initiative, National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

- Alyssa Picchini Schaffer, Senior Scientist & Administrative Director, Neuroscience Collaborations, The Simons Foundation
Interactive talk
Watch now
Modulation of deep mesencephalic nucleus to locomotor control in walking monkey
Rui-Han Wei
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Erez Gugig, Johns Hopkins University;Oliver Stanley, Johns Hopkins University; Kathleen Cullen, Johns Hopkins University

The deep mesencephalic nucleus (DpMe), also termed the midbrain locomotor region (MLR), is a large area within the midbrain reticular which plays a key role in integrating and processing sensory, cognitive, and limbic inputs and in turn translating this information into a motor command adapted to our current environment. DpMe cells have been shown to respond to passive vestibular (rotational) stimuli, which suggests that this region plays an important role in vestibulo-motor control. However, DpMe responses to active movements, such as locomotion have not yet been characterized. Here we recorded continuous single unit extracellular activities from the DpMe in rhesus monkeys. First, we applied passive translations and rotation to characterize the vestibular responses of neurons in the DpMe. Head-mounted 3Dgyroscopes/3Daccelerometers were used to record the head motion, and neural sensitivities to passive vestibular modulation were computed. Second, we recorded from the same DPME neurons during head-fixed treadmill walking. Four high-speed cameras were used for motion recording synchronously. Deep-learning computer-vision toolbox (DeepLabCut) were used to extract the animals' 3D posture for gait analysis. We found that, when compared to resting activities, DpMe cells demonstrated a significant overall increase in activity during head-fixed treadmill walking. Notably, DpMe cells demonstrated phase-dependent modulation during walking, even in the absence of vestibular stimulation. Modulation patterns varied between DpMe cells- some cells demonstrated peak activity during swing phase, and others during stance. Taken together these results suggest that DpMe neurons play a critical role in processing multi-sensory input during the complex sensorimotor activities generated in everyday life, such as walking. In addition, our findings also advance our knowledge of the neural circuits that coordinate gait and balance and thus have important implications for the development of novel treatments and interventions.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Structures and functions of sleep circuits in the brain
Antoine Adamantidis
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Carolina Gutierrez Herrera; Mattia Aime; Markus Schmidt

Sleep is an essential biological need. Yet, its origin and functions are subject of intense experimental research (and debates). is My research interests aim at investigating the wiring, firing dynamics and plasticity of the neural circuits regulating brain states in normal and pathological states using in vitro and in vivo optogenetics combined to genetics and electophysiological, an now cell network imaging methods. These research goals have been driven by questions such as: What define a sleep/wake circuit? What are sleep oscillations good for? What is the neural coding of sleep and brain plasticity during sleep in health and diseases (narcolepsy, insomnia, stroke)?
My laboratory has identified hypothalamic cells controlling rapid-eye movement (REM) sleep and arousal, a septo-hippocampus circuit supporting theta rhythm generation and contextual memory consolidation during REM sleep and a thalamus sleep-wake switch. My current projects focuses on the orchestration of sleep oscillations (slow waves, spindles, theta, etc.) in space and time and their roles in brain plasticity after stroke, sleep-dependent memory consolidation, and maintenance of hypothalamic-based feeding (innate) behavior.
Traditional talk
Watch now
The generalized drift diffusion model enables high-throughput screening of perceptual decision-making strategies
Maxwell Shinn
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Maxwell Shinn, Norman Lam, Daeyeol Lee, Hyojung Seo, John D. Murray

Since the late 1970s, the drift-diffusion model (DDM) has been an important tool in the cognitive neuroscientist's toolbox, providing a way to quantify evidence accumulation during decision-making and link behavioral data to neural recordings. However, methodological challenges have limited the ability to expand the DDM to test new decision-making strategies. Specifically, the complexity of defining new models and the time required to fit them to data have prevented widespread exploration of variants on the DDM. Additionally, the DDM can only represent a limited set of experimental designs.

Here, we describe our recent work on the generalized drift-diffusion model (GDDM), a framework for building and fitting DDM extensions, and a software package (PyDDM) which implements the framework (Shinn et al., 2020, eLife). Our framework makes previously intractable high-throughput approaches possible with a 100-fold or more speedup compared to standard methods. It also makes it easy to reuse different aspects of these DDM extensions, facilitated by our growing online database of model mechanisms (https://pyddm.readthedocs.io/en/latest/cookbook/index.html) to promote reproducibility and open science.

Our framework allows experimentalists to fit models to more complex experimental paradigms, and theorists to conveniently formulate models and efficiently fit them with the latest methodology. We demonstrate this flexibility by analyzing a sophisticated decision-making task using a high-throughput approach to explore decision-making strategies. We presented monkeys with a perceptual decision-making task with noisy evidence extended over time that included both timing and reward manipulations. Our modeling approach discovered the key characteristics of decision-making strategies which can account for the reward and timing biases exhibited by the monkeys (Shinn et al., 2020, J Neurosci). Overall, we show that the GDDM in conjunction with PyDDM enables new possibilities for understanding decision-making.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Synaptic Dynamics as Convolutional Units
Julian Rossbroich
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Julian Rossbroich, Friedrich Miescher Institute for Biomedical Research; Daniel Trotter, University of Ottawa; Katalin Tóth, University of Ottawa; Richard Naud, University of Ottawa

Communication in the nervous system is largely based on temporal sequences of action potentials. A central feature of this communication is that the efficacy of action potentials is variable on short (10 ms - 10 s) time scales. These short-term plasticity (STP) dynamics differ markedly across connections and strongly regulate how action potentials are being communicated to postsynaptic partners.

Traditionally, STP dynamics are mathematically described by simple mechanistic models, such as the Tsodyks-Markram model, in which the parameters correspond to biophysical mechanisms. Optimizing the model parameters to best describe experimental data therefore yields an estimate of biophysical properties. However, such traditional models fail to capture the diversity of STP dynamics that are experimentally observed in response to complex stimulation patterns.

Here, we are willing to sacrifice some of the model’s biophysical interpretability in order to phenomenologically describe the large range of experimentally observed dynamics. To this end, we develop a flexible mathematical framework based on a linear-nonlinear operation. Despite its conceptual simplicity, the resulting Spike Response Plasticity (SRP) model is more adaptable than previous models. We show that the model captures short-term facilitation, short-term depression, biphasic plasticity, as well as supralinear facilitation and post-burst potentiation. Additionally, using standard gradient descent algorithms, model parameters can be inferred accurately with limited amount of experimental data.

Our model therefore provides a more flexible alternative to traditional mechanistic STP models. It can be used for large-scale characterization of synaptic dynamics and can easily be implemented in large-scale network models. Finally, our modeling framework makes explicit that synaptic processing bears algorithmic similarities with information processing in convolutional neural networks.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Memory suppression and fear extinction related to emotional cues
Olivia Cook
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
L. Knight, University of Louisville; B. E. Depue, University of Louisville

Background
Disparate research in animals and humans have shown reduced influence of fearful memory as an automatic process and a volitional process. It’s unclear whether volitional emotional memory suppression largely involves the same neural circuitry as automatic fear extinction.

Objective
To validate an examination of neural associations/dissociations between volitional memory suppression and fear extinction, we behaviorally tested both memory suppression and fear extinction. We aimed to identify what components of the memory are consciously reduced during suppression.

Methods
Participants (N=24) first learned 32 pairs of pictures: neutral human faces with either neutral images (NEU) or fearful scenes (NEG). Next, a neutral face would be shown and participants would be asked to either think about (THINK), suppress (NO THINK), or neither think about nor suppress (EXTINCT) the paired image; some faces weren’t shown (BASELINE). Participants then rated each face on how pleasant or unpleasant it made them feel and were asked to remember if the associated picture was negative or neutral.

Results
Within the ratings, there were significant main effects of Valence (p<.001), Condition (p<.001), and a significant interaction of Condition by Valence (p=.02). Think NEG showed that valence is lower than Baseline NEG (p = .012), while Extinction NEG showed that valence is higher than Baseline (p = .011).
Within the recall, there was a significant interaction of Condition by Valence (p=.02). NEG Think has the highest recall (92.71%) and there is a significant difference between NEG Think and NEG No Think (92.71 vs. 70.83%, p=.001) Additionally, NEG Think is significantly above baseline (p=.006), while NEG No Think is below baseline (although n.s., p=.38).

Conclusions
Think related to enhancement in memory recall and the most negative ratings of the paired neutral faces. No Think was associated with worsened recall, but valence ratings were right around baseline. Extinction did not alter memory, but valence became less negative.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Neuromodulation enhances plasticity in a rat model of cochlear implant use
Erin Glennon
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Angela Zhu, NYU School of Medicine; Mario Svirsky, NYU School of Medicine; and Robert C. Froemke, NYU School of Medicine

Rates of auditory perceptual learning with cochlear implants are highly variable across patients. Adaptation to cochlear implants is believed to require neuroplasticity within the central auditory system. However, mechanisms by which behavioral training enables plasticity and improves outcomes are poorly understood. Here we hypothesize that neural mechanisms promoting plasticity in the rat auditory system are key to optimizing cochlear implant usage. Specifically, we examined the effect of pairing locus coeruleus stimulation with an auditory stimulus on auditory learning when the animal has to relearn a tone identification task (self-initiated, go/no-go) using a cochlear implant. Initial training was done using acoustic stimuli in normal hearing animals. Animals were then bilaterally deafened, unilaterally cochlear-implanted, and retrained with the new target delivered by intracochlear electrical stimulation. Prior to daily behavioral training sessions, rats underwent 5-10 min pairing sessions either with optogenetic locus coeruleus or sham stimulation. Pairing accelerated learning with cochlear implants. We then conducted multi-unit recordings in the auditory cortex to assess responses to the cochlear implant. Animals that had been trained with the cochlear implant had increased activation of the cortex, and those that underwent pairing had a sharper representation of the target cochlear implant channel. We used fiber photometry to monitor activity of noradrenergic locus coeruleus neurons. During auditory learning, cochlear implanted animals display dynamic locus coeruleus activity, specifically during the acquisition of the meaning of reward relevant tones. These studies indicate that neuromodulation can play a powerful role in shaping outcomes with cochlear implant use and training.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Supralinear networks with short-term plasticity can account for transient neuronal dynamics in the olfactory system
Yue Kris Wu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Rainer W. Friedrich, Friedrich Miescher Institute for Biomedical Research; Friedemann Zenke, Friedrich Miescher Institute for Biomedical Research;

The olfactory system is widely believed to implement an autoassociative memory network capa- ble of generating similar representations in response to chemically distinct but functionally related odorants. Classic autoassociative memory models rely on strong recurrent excitatory connec- tions accompanied by attractor dynamics, which exhibit persistent activity even after removing the stimulus. However, multiple experimental studies in the mammalian piriform cortex and in the te- lencephalic area Dp of zebrafish have revealed that odor stimuli evoke transient responses with a precise excitation-inhibition balance. This balance implies that neural circuits may operate as inhibition-stabilized networks during stimulation. Here, we studied how transient responses can arise in networks with supralinear transfer functions by analyzing their behavior in response to external inputs. We found that transient responses can arise when network dynamics switch from stable to unstable by additional afferent inputs and are eventually re-stabilized through short-term plasticity mechanisms. We identified E onto I short-term plasticity as the most promising mech- anism in this process. By contrast, both spike-frequency adaptation and E onto E short-term plasticity were inconsistent with specific aspects of experimental data. In summary, we provide a modeling framework that accounts for transient neuronal dynamics in the olfactory system, which could be applied to other sensory systems.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
A Unilateral Cortical Resection of Both Visual Pathways Alters Action but not Perception
Zoha Ahmad
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Zoha Ahmad, York University; Marlene Behrmann, Carnegie Mellon University; Christina Patterson, University of Pittsburgh; Erez Freud, York University

Cortical resection, a treatment for humans with pharmaco-resistant epilepsy, provides a unique opportunity to advance our understanding of the nature and extent of cortical (re)organization. Previous studies have found that pediatric patients with resections of the ventral visual pathway still retain normal visuoperceptual abilities. It is not clear whether visuomotor computations, carried out by the dorsal pathway, follow a similar behavioral pattern. To address this outstanding issue, we examined visuomotor and visuoperceptual behaviors in a pediatric patient TC, who has a cortical resection that includes portions of the left ventral and dorsal pathways. TC used her right and left hands to estimate perceptually the width of blocks that varied in width and length (but not in overall size), and, in a separate condition, to grasp the same objects across their width. Consistent with previous studies, TC’s perceptual performance was comparable to that of controls. In contrast, TC was markedly impaired in her visuomotor sensitivity to object shape but only when she grasped the objects with her contralesional right (and not ipsilesional left) hand. These results provide novel evidence for a striking difference in the reorganization profiles of the two visual pathways. This difference might be attributed to a greater degree of hemispheric specialization of the dorsal pathway, or, alternatively, to differential maturation rates of the two pathways, such that the dorsal pathway maturation precedes that of the ventral pathway.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
A Novel Quantitative Method Assessing EEG Reactivity in Comatose Patients on ECMO
Yinuo Zeng
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Autumn Williams, Johns Hopkins University Department of Biomedical Engineering; Romergryko G. Geocadin, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine; Janaka Senarathna, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine; Nirma Carballido Martinez, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine; Jay Bronder, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine; Nitish Thakor, Johns Hopkins University Department of Biomedical Engineering; Eva K. Ritzl, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine; Sung-Min Cho, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine;

Objective:
Electroencephalogram (EEG) reactivity, defined as a change in EEG frequency or amplitude due to external stimulation, is used to assess responsiveness in comatose patients. We present a quantitative method to analyze EEG data from patients on extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) support.

Methods:
EEG was acquired from 22 ECMO patients using a standardized stimulation paradigm that included auditory, noxious touch, and nostril stimulation. Data were divided into 111 total epochs and assessed using two metrics: spectral power and permutation entropy. We classified epochs based on increase or decrease of each metric in response to stimulation and computed scores for each epoch, both overall and for each spectral sub-band. Scores were grouped and validated against visual analysis of raw EEG.

Results:
Variations were found to occur in all cerebral regions for both metrics. The mean overall scores for all types of stimulation for those patients identified by visual analysis as reactive were significantly higher than for those identified as unreactive: auditory (50.03 ± 46.11 vs 25.14 ± 12.27, p < 0.05), noxious touch (50.93 ± 33.32 vs 22.48 ± 11.45, p < 0.001), and nostril (48.64 ± 13.56 vs 19.61 ± 13.80, p < 0.01). Although nostril stimulation induced the largest difference on our metrics, it also resulted in the most epochs disqualified due to artifacts.

Conclusion:
Our findings provide preliminary support for the validity of a quantitative (rather than qualitative) EEG scoring system assessing the response to stimulation using our qEEG metrics. To our knowledge, this is the first study to apply qEEG methods in the assessment of EEG reactivity in patients on ECMO support. We anticipate that further validation of this quantitative method on larger patient populations will enable new avenues of investigation and test its prognostic value.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Mouse nucleus prepositus neurons encode eye movement during passive and active head movement
Hui Ho Chang
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Aamna Lawrence, Johns Hopkins University; Kathleen Cullen, Johns Hopkins University

The vestibular system plays a crucial role in our everyday life as it ensures gaze and postural stabilization and the sense of self-motion by detecting the head motion in space. Previous work done in rodents (i.e. mice and rats) has led to the view that the nucleus prepositus hypoglossi (NPH) and the supragenual nucleus (SGN) in brainstem relay vestibular information from the vestibular system to head direction (HD) network. However, the NPH has also been long-known to comprise the oculomotor integrator which plays an essential role in eye movement control by holding the eye at an eccentric position in orbit after the saccade. Further, a study in non-human primates (Dale & Cullen, 2013), established that neurons in the NPH predominantly encode eye-related rather than head-related movement signals during both passively-generated and voluntary head movements. To date, however, it remains unknown whether neurons in the NPH of rodents encode eye-related and/or head-related movement signals.

We hypothesized that NPH neurons in mouse, as in primate, preferentially encode eye-related signals during passive-generated and voluntary movement. Accordingly, we recorded the activity of NPH neurons with both with tungsten electrodes and/or 960 recording-site Neuropixel probes. Eye movement was simultaneously recorded with an AMR magnetic field sensor during behavioral protocols (Beraneck & Cullen 2007;Medrea & Cullen, 2013) designed to dissociate eye and head movement sensitivities (i.e., vestibular-ocular reflex (VOR), optokinetic reflex (OKR) and changes in static eye position). Our preliminary single unit recording indicated that neurons in the NPH of mice primarily output eye-related information during both passive and active head movement. Further, eye movement responses were nonlinear; modulation gain decreased with increasing eye velocity. Overall, our preliminary results suggest NPH neurons in mice mainly function to stabilize gaze, consistent with the non-human primate model.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Local coupling between sleep spindles and slow oscillations supports consolidation of visuomotor adaptation
Agustin Solano
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Agustín Solano, IFIBIO Houssay-University of Buenos Aires; Luis A. Riquelme, IFIBIO Houssay-University of Buenos Aires; Daniel Perez-Chada, IFIBIO Houssay-University of Buenos Aires; Valeria Della-Maggiore, IFIBIO Houssay-University of Buenos Aires

The last decade has seen remarkable progress in the identification of the neural signatures of sleep-dependent consolidation. Yet, with rare exceptions, most advances have emerged from the field of declarative memory. This imbalance may obey to the substantial evidence suggesting that only hippocampal dependent tasks benefit from sleep. Overnight reactivation of hippocampal memories appears to depend on the precise synchrony between slow oscillations (SO) and sleep spindles. Here, we sought to examine whether this coupling is also critical for the consolidation of human motor memories.
We hypothesized that if the level of coupling between SO and spindles is also critical for the consolidation of motor memories then it should predict long-term memory overnight. Given that the role of sleep in sensorimotor adaptation is somewhat controversial, in Experiment 1 (n = 46) we tested this hypothesis by manipulating the proximity between visuomotor adaptation (VMA) and sleep. This procedure has been implemented successfully for declarative memories. We found that sleeping immediately after learning increased memory retention by 35% compared to sleeping 14 hours later (p<0.05), an effect that persisted for at least two weeks. Next, in Experiment 2, we sought to identify the neural signatures supporting sleep consolidation of visuomotor adaptation. To this end, a new set of subjects (n = 10) were exposed to a VMA session or a control session in which no perturbation was applied (CTL), and went to sleep 10 min later. We found that adaptation to a visual rotation increased the density of spindles during NREM3 over the electrodes contralateral to the trained hand (p=0.05). This effect was mostly driven by the electrodes placed over the left sensorimotor cortex. Although visuomotor adaptation did not affect the density of SOs (p>0.05), it substantially modulated the spindle-SO coupling in an inter-hemispheric manner (p<0.001), suggesting it may rather increase the ability of slow oscillations to promote thalamic spindles. Critically, spindles associated with a SO predicted long-term memory overnight, whereas uncoupled spindles didn’t.
In conclusion, we have shown that sleep modulates the consolidation of visuomotor adaptation by increasing the level of coupling between spindles and slow oscillations in an inter-hemispheric manner during NREM3 sleep. Our findings provide compelling evidence for a role of the spindle-SO coupling in the stabilization of motor memories, and open the possibility of a common mechanism at the basis of procedural and declarative memory.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Attentional Sampling Strategies in Multi-Attribute Decision Making
Jacob Elsey
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jacob Elsey, Johns Hopkins University; Ernst Niebur, Johns Hopkins University; Veit Stuphorn, Johns Hopkins University

Many everyday decisions require us to consider multiple options, each comprised of a number of shared or different attributes. In such situations, optimal decisions require the simultaneous integration and comparison of a large amount of information. This complexity is thought to tax limited cognitive resources, requiring the use of attention to select a limited subset of information, upon which the decision is then based. To better understand the role of attention in decision making, subjects participated in multi-attribute decision making tasks in which we systematically varied the complexity of choices by increasing the number of options, or attributes, or both. Our task design uses eye position as an overt measure of attention while subjects choose between gambles that systematically cover the decision space. Each attribute's magnitude is masked by an opaque disk whose color indicates the attribute type. The attribute value is only revealed when the disk is actively fixated upon. Subjects freely inspect the attributes with no time constraint, before indicating their choice with a keypress. The resulting eye movements provide detailed temporal and spatial information about subjects' focus of attention during the attribute sampling process.

We find that human participants mainly deploy two strategies for sampling decision-related information. When only few options are available, participants most frequently use an exhaustive strategy to sample all attributes of each option independently, before examining the next one (2-Option, 2-Attribute: 68% of subjects, 2-Option, 4-Attribute: 66%). This is an effective strategy because all information is examined. However, when more options are available, participants most commonly employ a filtering strategy. They first compare their most important attribute (which differs between subjects) across all options to identify the one or two best ones, and then sample all attributes of those best options (4-Option, 2-Attribute: 75% of subjects, 4-Option, 4-Attribute: 68%). This strategy reduces the amount of information that needs to be processed but can lead to suboptimal choices. Importantly, which strategy is used depends on the number of options, but not the number of attributes. Thus, increasingly complex decision problems evoke strategic shifts in the direction of attention during the search for the preferred option. Because our new task design provides detailed information over the temporal order of sampling the attributes, it retains the ability to control task requirements typical for laboratory designs, while still capturing important aspects of real-world decision making in complex environments. Thus, this task allows us to explore the neuronal mechanisms underlying the different strategies.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Tracking fast and slow changes in synaptic weights from simultaneously observed pre- and postsynaptic spiking activity
Ganchao Wei
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ian Stevenson, Department of Psychological Sciences, University of Connecticut

Synapses change on multiple timescales, ranging from milliseconds to minutes, due to a combination of both short- and long-term plasticity. Here we develop an extension of the common Generalized Linear Model to infer both short- and long-term changes in the coupling between a pre- and post-synaptic neuron based on observed spiking activity. We model short-term synaptic plasticity using additive effects that depend on the presynaptic spike timing, and we model long-term changes in both synaptic weight and baseline firing rate using Point Process Adaptive Smoothing. Using simulations, we first show that this model can accurately recover time-varying synaptic weights 1) for both depressing and facilitating synapses, 2) with a variety of long-term changes (including realistic changes, such as due to STDP), 3) with a range of pre and post-synaptic firing rates, and 4) for both excitatory and inhibitory synapses. We also show the importance of tracking fast changes in synaptic weights, slow changes in synaptic weights, and unexplained variations in baseline firing simultaneously. Omitting any one of these factors can lead to spurious inferences for the others. Altogether, this model provides a flexible framework for tracking short- and long-term variation in spike transmission.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The Effects of Social Rewards on Incidental Episodic Memory
Gaia Molinaro
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Charlotte Russell, King's College London

Episodic memory is our memory for specific, personally experienced events. Although remembering the “what, where and when” of an instance may be highly beneficial, the brain’s memory capacity is limited and must therefore be selective. Rewards are important enhancers of episodic memory acquisition and storage. Among them, social rewards have been proposed as important drivers of motivated behaviour. Whether the benefits of social rewards on memory still operate on incidental (unplanned) memorization of neutral events has not been tested yet. In this study, we explored the effects of social rewards on memory for neutral scenes that were completely unrelated, except for proximity in time, to the sources of reward (here, the presentation of happy versus neutral faces). One day after the completion of an encoding task, participants were given a surprise memory test that assessed their recollection of spatial or temporal information related to such incidental scenes. Differences in memory for space versus time-related information were observed. Although participants were expected to have better memory for scenes that occurred after delivery of social rewards, this was not the case; possible explanations for this are discussed. However, strong interactions between the anticipated effect and participants’ mood were noted, and our initial hypothesis did hold true in a subset of participants who experienced exceptionally low mood on the day of encoding. These findings hint at the limitations of a reward-driven enhancement of incidental episodic memory and highlight the important role of mood in modulating the extent of such an effect.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Categorical representation by suppression or enhancement of auditory stimuli during perceptual learning
Kathleen Martin (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kathleen A Martin, New York University School of Medicine Skirball Institute of Biomolecular Medicine, New York University Center for Neural Science, New York University School of Medicine Neuroscience Institute; Colin Bredenberg, New York University Center for Neural Science; Eero Simoncelli, New York University Center for Neural Science; Cristina Savin, New York University Center for Neural Science; & Robert C Froemke, New York University School of Medicine Skirball Institute of Biomolecular Medicine, New York University Center for Neural Science, New York University School of Medicine Neuroscience Institute, Howard Hughes Medical Institute Faculty Scholar

Perceptual learning reliably enhances cortical representations of task-relevant stimuli in trained animals. However, these neural changes have predominantly been observed outside of behavioral context and regardless of learning rate. Our lab found that engagement in behavior alters auditory cortical responses via local inhibition and cholinergic signaling (Kuchibhotla et al., 2017). Here, we examined how sensory representations in both excitatory and inhibitory neurons change over auditory perceptual learning in mice on a two-alternative forced-choice (2AFC) task.

We performed simultaneous 2-photon imaging of excitatory and inhibitory neurons in auditory cortex throughout 2AFC auditory conditioning in head-fixed mice. To obtain water reward, animals learned to lick a left lick port for tones of a single, target frequency (11-16 kHz) and right for tones of all other frequencies. Discrimination between target (left) and surround (right) frequencies improved over 9-21 days. While animals were task-engaged, ~50% of stimulus-responsive excitatory neurons exhibited a categorical response, not encoding the frequency of the stimulus, but rather the behavioral choice on that trial. We observed two distinct population-level tuning in experienced animals; animals exhibited either a relative enhancement or suppression of the frequencies reported as target.

Using chronic two-photon imaging to track neurons longitudinally, we examined when these response profiles emerged during learning. We could detect whether an animal would likely exhibit enhancement or suppression as early as day 6 in behavioral learning. We developed a network model of excitatory and inhibitory neurons to explore what may account for these individual differences and how they arise over learning.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Dynamic filtering of habenulo-raphe inputs by a recurrent inhibitory serotonin network acting over behavioral timescales
Michael Lynn
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Michael Lynn, Department of Cellular and Molecular Medicine, University of Ottawa; Sean Geddes, Department of Cellular and Molecular Medicine, University of Ottawa; Mohamad Chahrour, Department of Cellular and Molecular Medicine, University of Ottawa; Sebastien Maillé, Department of Cellular and Molecular Medicine, University of Ottawa; Emerson Harkin, Department of Cellular and Molecular Medicine, University of Ottawa; Samir Haj-Dahmane, Research Institute on Addictions, University at Buffalo; Richard Naud, Department of Cellular and Molecular Medicine, University of Ottawa; Jean-Claude Béïque, Department of Cellular and Molecular Medicine, University of Ottawa

The habenulo-raphe pathway is believed to be implicated in orchestrating optimal behavioral responses to aversive, threatening or stressful environments. Here, we consider how long-range inputs from lateral habenula (LHb) influence circuit dynamics in the dorsal raphe nucleus (DRN) using electrophysiological, computational and behavioral strategies. We find that habenulo-raphe afferents triggered classical monosynaptic excitation of 5-HT neurons, as well as strong disynaptic inhibition whose induction was steeply frequency-dependent and which persisted for seconds. This novel inhibition was mediated by a GIRK conductance activated by 5-HT1A receptors. To determine the network motifs underlying this protracted inhibition, we undertook optogenetic and pharmacological manipulations in DRN. These experiments revealed, unexpectedly, that 5-HT neurons are organized in a recurrent inhibitory network, refuting the classical model of autocrine activation of 5-HT1A autoreceptors. Electrical stimulation approaches revealed that these inhibitory connections exhibited robust, dramatic short-term facilitation that we formalized with a linear-nonlinear plasticity model. To examine how this nonlinearity affects input-output transformation, we constructed an experimentally-constrained network model of DRN which incorporated the experimentally-fitted plasticity model at inhibitory connections. We find that excitatory inputs led to paradoxical inhibition of DRN at high frequencies, and that this polarity switch was dependent on plasticity dynamics and not on recurrent inhibition itself. To test the physiological relevance of this computation for processing threat information from the LHb, we developed a simple auditory classical conditioning paradigm and tested key predictions of our model through in vivo optogenetics. We uncovered a nonlinear transformation where stimulating the habenulo-raphe pathway at high-frequency, but not at low frequency, depressed goal-directed anticipatory licking behavior. We suggest that the computation sustained by this circuit motif in the DRN categorizes synaptic inputs to implement optimal adaption of behavioural policies in threatening environments.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Cerebral representation of two languages in the dog’s brain
Laura V. Cuaya (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Raúl Hernández-Pérez, Department of Ethology, Institute of Biology, Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary & MTA-ELTE ‘Lendület’ Neuroethology of Communication Research Group, Hungarian Academy of Sciences – Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary; Marianna Boros, Department of Ethology, Institute of Biology, Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary & MTA-ELTE ‘Lendület’ Neuroethology of Communication Research Group, Hungarian Academy of Sciences – Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary; Andrea Deme, Department of Applied Linguistics and Phonetics, Faculty of Humanities, Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary & MTA-ELTE “Lendület” Lingual Articulation Research Group, Budapest, Hungary; Attila Andics, Department of Ethology, Institute of Biology, Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary & MTA-ELTE ‘Lendület’ Neuroethology of Communication Research Group, Hungarian Academy of Sciences – Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary

Family dogs are exposed to a continuous flow of human speech throughout their lives. However, the extent of their abilities in speech perception is unknown. Our aims were to test the cerebral processing for speech detection and language discrimination in the dog auditory cortex. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) we studied awake and unrestrained dogs (n = 18). As speech stimuli, dogs heard fragments of speech in a familiar and an unfamiliar language, as control we scrambled the same stimuli. We hypothesized that if dogs can extract auditory regularities of speech, and of a familiar language, then the cerebral patterns in the auditory cortex would discriminate between speech and scrambled speech, and also between languages. Using multivoxel pattern analysis (MVPA) we found that the cerebral patterns of activity in the bilateral primary auditory regions discriminated between speech and scrambled speech, this means that the auditory primary cortex performed speech detection; and the secondary auditory regions (the right rostral Sylvian gyrus, the left rostral suprasylvian gyrus, and the left caudal ectosylvian gyrus) were related with language discrimination (i.e. the cerebral patterns of cerebral activity discriminated between familiar and unfamiliar language in the speech condition). No auditory region discriminated between languages based on scrambled speech, this suggests that language discrimination wasn’t based on speaker-related cues. Additionally, we didn’t find a significant effect of the familiarity of the language in the primary auditory cortex response, this could suggest either that speech detection is independent of experience or that dogs extrapolate the rules that they learned in a familiar language to a unfamiliar language. These findings corroborate recent evidence that speech processing is functionally organized in the dog auditory cortex. Our results demonstrate abilities in a non-primate species to extract auditory regularities of a familiar language without explicit training.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Human cortical ripples reflect a spectrum of synchronous spiking activity across spatial scale
Ai Phuong Tong
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ai Phuong S. Tong, NIH; Alex P. Vaz, NIH, Duke; Sara K. Inati, NIH; Kareem A. Zaghloul, NIH

Engagement of the medial temporal lobe (MTL) and neocortex in episodic memory is strongly associated with increases in high frequency activity (HFA). Recent evidence suggests that discrete HF oscillations termed ripples are linked to memory processes. While increases in HFA during successful memory retrieval has been widely observed, the dynamic changes within individual trials are less clear. We hypothesized that resolving increases in HFA in time can reveal discrete ripple events that reflect a spectrum of dynamic spiking activity coupled to low frequency (LF) oscillations. Twenty-one participants completed a paired-associates verbal memory task in which they studied word pairs and were later cued with a word from each pair while we recorded intracranial EEG (iEEG). Six of these participants had simultaneous microelectrode array recording of single-unit spiking activity. We extracted spectral power from the iEEG signal using Morlet wavelets between 1-200 Hz. We defined discrete HFA events as ripples when 80-120 Hz spectral power exceeded two SDs for a minimum of 25 ms. Ripples were detected from simultaneous macroscale iEEG and microscale local field potential (LFP) recordings. Synchrony of discrete events were measured using pairwise phase consistency (PPC). Increases in HFA during successful memory retrieval were correlated with ripples within trials (p<0.0001). Amplitude of iEEG ripples was correlated with amplitude, number, and synchrony of LFP ripples across MEA electrodes (p<0.05). Furthermore, amplitude of LFP ripples was correlated with spiking activity and number of spiking units (p<0.05). Spike-LFP PPC was significant between 4-8 Hz and 80-120 Hz during ripples in correct memory retrieval. LFP ripple-iEEG PPC was also significant between 4-8 Hz, suggesting that spiking activity during ripple events are coordinated by theta at the microscale and macroscale (p<0.001). Overall, our data suggest that successful memory retrieval exhibits discrete ripples across spatial scale that reflect a spectrum of synchronous spiking activity.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Prosthetic stimulation in the axis corresponding to support surface perturbation improves postural control in a BVL primate
Olivia Leavitt
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kathleen Cullen, Johns Hopkins Medicine

Bilateral vestibular loss (BVL) is a debilitating condition that can cause impairments in posture and balance. Studies in human subjects with profound BVL have proven useful in quantifying the contribution of vestibular sensation to posture. Generally, human studies involve the application of dynamic perturbations to support surface during stance. Analysis of the resultant upper body and head motion has demonstrated a shift from a platform-fixed to a head-fixed pattern of compensation around 0.5 Hz in normal subjects. In contrast, BVL subjects have difficulty with this platform-fixed compensation strategy.

Notably, vestibular prostheses are an emerging technology that improves outcomes in human BVL patients, however continued work in animal models is essential for understanding the current functional limitations of the technology. Accordingly, here we explored postural responses to platform tilts in a normal monkey vs. monkey with profound BVL. Both animals were trained to maintain a relaxed posture within a behavioral chamber mounted on a 6-dof hexapod motion platform. Dynamic perturbations were applied to animal’s support surface in roll and yaw (0.25-10 Hz, maximum velocity 5 deg/s). The BVL animal received vestibular stimulation with a biomimetic transfer function in either the horizontal or posterior semicircular canal. A wireless IMU was placed on the animal’s head, and center of pressure, and joint positions (DeepLabCut) were recorded. Analysis revealed that postural sway decreased from lower to higher frequencies, similar to the platform-fixed to head-fixed strategy shift observed in humans. Further, the BVL monkey demonstrated a relative increase in sway at lower frequencies, which was mitigated by posterior but not horizontal canal stimulation. These results suggest that profound BVL causes detectible impairments in postural compensation, which is partially corrected by a vestibular prosthesis, particularly at lower frequencies.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Auditory stimulation during REM sleep modulates cognitive performance.
Miguel Navarrete
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Miguel Navarrete, Cardiff University; Viviana Greco, Cardiff University; Penelope A. Lewis, Cardiff University

REM (rapid eye movement) and non-REM (NREM) periods are complementary processes constituting the human sleep. NREM has been found to be essential for declarative memory consolidation. There is no conclusive evidence for the cognitive functions of REM sleep although this stage has been associated to procedural memory and emotional arousal[1]. Recently, auditory stimulation during sleep has emerged as an useful method for manipulation of sleep processes, particularly during NREM[2]. Here, we studied the cognitive effects of auditory stimulation during REM. In two overnight conditions (stimulation vs no-stimulation) for 20 subjects, we studied the effect of auditory stimulation during REM. We recorded overnight polysomnography and short auditory clicks were applied locked to eye-movements in EOG during REM. Then, we evaluated changes of overnight performance for each subject in three cognitive tasks: psychomotor vigilance task (PVT), mirror tracing task (MTT) and visual discrimination task (VDT). Using linear random mixed effects analyses, we found that the stimulation increased sleep efficiency (p=0.048) as well as VDT performance (p=0.0092), but detrimental for MTT (p=0.019) and lessened but not significant for PVT (p=0.069). Likewise, the stimulation decreased the eye-movement density during REM (p=0.04) and induced a broadband beta rhythm (15-30Hz) for about 1s after stimulation. Then, followed by a decrease of theta after 0.75s of the stimulus. Interestingly, the induced beta increase was correlated to performance gain of VDT, whereas phasic REM was also correlated to VDT performance in both overnight conditions. Our findings indicate that acoustic stimulation provides means to modulate REM sleep. Furthermore, the divergent outcomes for cognitive performance suggest REM dynamics underpin different memory processes in different ways.

REFERENCES
1. Rasch B, Born J: In search of a role of REM sleep in memory formation. Neurobiol Learn Mem 2015, 122:1–3.
2. Ngo H-V V, Martinetz T, Born J, Mölle M: Auditory closed-loop stimulation of the sleep slow oscillation enhances memory. Neuron 2013, 78:545–53.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Value-based decision making in naturalistic vs laboratory settings
Angelo Pirrone
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Fernand Gobet, London School of Economics and Political Science

What defines a decision making experimental paradigm as “value-based”? We argue that a number of key features that characterise value-based decision making in naturalistic settings - the types of choices that our brains have evolved to optimise - are greatly overlooked in empirical research in decision making, especially in the experimental setup commonly used in value-based decision making research in laboratory settings, in both psychology and neuroscience. In this talk, we will present the naturalistic constraints that are common to virtually all value-based decisions outside of laboratory settings. Furthermore, we will discuss how failing to include such ecological constraints has important implications for our understanding of decision making. Finally, in view of these claims, we discuss possible new research questions for the future.
Traditional talk
Watch now
A calcium-based plasticity model predicts long-term potentiation and depression in the somatosensory cortex
Giuseppe Chindemi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Giuseppe Chindemi, UNIGE and BBP; Marwan Abdellah, BBP; Oren Amsalem, HUJI; Ruth Benavides-Piccione, UPM; Vincent Delattre, EPFL; Michael Doron, HUJI; Andras Ecker, BBP; James King, BBP; Pramod Kumbhar, BBP; Caitlin Monney, BBP; Rodrigo Perin, LNMC; Christian Rössert, BBP; Werner Van Geit, BBP; Javier DeFelipe, UPM; Michael Graupner, SPPIN; Idan Segev, HUJI; Henry Markram, BBP and LNMC; Eilif Muller, BBP and UM

Long-term plasticity of synapses between pyramidal cells (PCs) is considered one of the key mechanisms underlying learning and memory in the brain. However, potentiation and depression of synaptic responses have been experimentally tested for only a few of these connections in the neocortex. This gap poses a significant barrier for the study of learning mechanisms. Here we show that a calcium-based plasticity rule regulating layer 5 PC synapses holds also for several other pyramidal-to-pyramidal connections in a digital model of the somatosensory cortex. In particular, we show that differences in postsynaptic calcium dynamics are sufficient to explain the in vitro results on PC connections plasticity. We therefore propose that a common set of plasticity mechanisms is shared among PCs. Our results provide a piece of the puzzle towards understanding the role of the different PC types in neocortical learning.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Related Neural Networks Underlie Suppression of Emotion, Memory, Motor Processes as Identified by Data-Driven Analysis
Karisa Hunt (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Lindsay K. Knight, INSIGHTEC; Brendan E. Depue, University of Louisville

Goal-directed behavior benefits from self-regulation of cognitive and affective processes, such as emotional reactivity, memory retrieval, and prepotent motor response. Dysfunction in self-regulation is a common characteristic of many psychiatric disorders, such as PTSD and ADHD. This study sought to determine whether common neural regions are involved in the regulation of emotion, motor, and memory, and if a data-driven approach using independent components analysis (ICA) would successfully identify intrinsic connectivity networks (ICNs) that contribute to inhibitory regulation. Eighteen participants underwent neuroimaging while completing an emotion regulation (ER) task, a memory suppression (think/no-think; TNT) task, and a motor inhibition (stop signal; SS) task. In the ER task, participants were presented with negatively valenced pictures and instructed to either feel or inhibit their emotions. In the TNT task, participants received training to remember face-picture (cue-target) pairs. Participants were then presented with only the cue and told to either recall the picture or try to block its retrieval. In the SS task, participants were presented with either a stop- or go-signal and instructed to press a button only at the go-signal – not before the go-signal or at the stop-signal. ICA (CONN; MATLAB) was conducted on the neuroimaging data. Corresponding components were selected across task based on interrelated patterns of activation. Subsequently, ICNs were correlated with behavioral variables. ICA indicated a common medial prefrontal network, striatal network, and frontoparietal executive control network, as well as down-regulation in task-specific ROIs. These results illustrate that overlapping ICNs were exhibited across three distinct inhibitory regulation tasks as successfully identified through a data-driven approach (ICA).
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Prolactin-induced changes in the primary auditory cortex plasticity
Alba Cáceres Rodríguez
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Julio Esparza, Instituto Cajal; Eduardo Martin, Instituto Cajal

During pregnancy and lactation there are multiple adaptive changes in the mother’s brain that
are essential for the survival of the progeny. Clinical and experimental evidences indicate that
prolactin (PRL), present during lactation, can contribute to the development of these adaptive
modifications. While the importance of the endocrine system on the activity of neuronal
network in critical stages of life is well stablished, the role of PRL on the remodeling of the
auditory cortex (AC) in response to sound stimuli emitted by the pups during lactation is still
unknown. Therefore, the aim of this project is to study the modifications on neural activity of
the AC in a model of hyperprolactinemia. To reach this objective, we used electrophysiological
techniques with chronic electrode implants in the primary auditory cortex (A1) in order to record
auditory evoked potentials (AEPs). The recordings were conducted in awake animals treated
with domperidone (as the model of hyperprolactinemia) and in control animals treated with a
vehicle. For the auditory stimuli we used recordings of pup’s vocalizations during lactation
(wriggling calls), as well as trials of pure tones at different frequencies. Our data suggest that an
increase in serum levels of PRL modifies the AEPs registered in A1. Specifically, there is a loss of
the fundamental frequencies within 0.1-20 Hz band of the AEPs following stimulations with
pups’ vocalizations. This result suggests that PRL induces changes in mother’s auditory pathway
that may be relevant to the survival of the offspring.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Nonlinear stimulus representations in neural circuits with approximate excitatory-inhibitory balance
vicky zhu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Vicky Zhu, University of Notre Dame; Cody Baker, University of Notre Dame;Robert Rosenbaum, University of Notre Dame

Balanced excitation and inhibition is widely observed in cortex. How does this balance shape neural computations and stimulus representations? This question is often studied using computational models of neuronal networks in a dynamically balanced state. But balanced network models predict a linear relationship between stimuli and population responses. So how do cortical circuits implement nonlinear representations and computations? We show that every balanced network architecture admits stimuli that break the balanced state and these breaks in balance push the network into a “semi-balanced state” characterized by excess inhibition to some neurons, but an absence of excess excitation. The semi-balanced state produces nonlinear stimulus representations and nonlinear computations, is unavoidable in networks driven by multiple stimuli, is consistent with cortical recordings, and has a direct mathematical relationship to artificial neural networks. In addition, we study the synaptic plasticity and learnings in semi-balanced networks, and aim to build a more direct analogue between ANNs and neuronal networks in the cerebral cortex. This will open a highway of shared information between neuroscience and machine learning, resulting in rapid advances in each field.

Interactive talk
Watch now
Language networks reorganization in neurodegenerative disorders: behavioral, structural, and functional evidence from semantic variant of Primary Progressive Aphasia.
Valentina Borghesani
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Borghesani, V., UdeM; Lukic, S., UCSF; Hinkley, L.B.N., UCSF; Licata, A., UCSF; Bogley, R., UCSF; Weis, E., UCSF; Welch, A., UCSF; Mizuiri, D., UCSF; Miller, B., UCSF; Miller, Z., UCSF; Houde, J.F., UCSF; Nagarajan, S.S., UCSF; Gorno-Tempini, M.L. UCSF;

Primary Progressive Aphasia (PPA) is a clinical syndrome in which patients progressively lose speech and language abilities due to neurodegeneration of left-hemisphere language networks. Three variants are recognized, associated respectively with phonology and/or short-term verbal memory deficits (logopenic variant), grammar and/or speech-motor deficits (nonfluent variant), or semantic deficits (semantic variant, or svPPA). svPPA patients manifest a deep, generalized, loss of semantic knowledge and relatively focal anterior temporal (ATL) lobe atrophy.
Here, we capitalize on this unique clinical model and MEG recordings to investigate the spatiotemporal features of language networks and in particular the crucial role of the ATL in semantic processing.
First, we show that svPPA patients over-rely on dorsal, occipito-parietal brain regions during irregular word reading. This evidence corroborates a dual-route model where reading aloud is mediated by the interplay between a ventral lexico-semantic system and a dorsal sub-lexical/phonological one.
Second, we find that, during a semantic categorization task, svPPA patients show greater activation over bilateral occipital cortices and superior temporal gyrus, as well as inconsistent engagement of frontal regions. These findings indicate a pervasive reorganization of brain networks in response to ATL neurodegeneration: defective semantic representations are compensated via enhanced perceptual processing (in occipital regions) and semantic control (in the fronto-parietal network).
Finally, we demonstrate that the error patterns in an auditory verb generation task depend on the breakdown of different neurocognitive mechanisms across PPA variants. Specifically, svPPA patients produce the highest percentage of unrelated-verb responses and the highest number of light verbs, providing additional evidence of the critical role played by the ATL in semantic processing.
Taken together, our findings have important implications for clinical phenotyping and differential diagnosis of PPA variants, as well as for theoretical model of the neurobiology of language.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Effects of moderate prenatal alcohol exposure on long-term potentiation and rhythmic activity in the dentate gyrus.
Monica Goncalves-Garcia
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Savage DD, Department of Neurosciences - University of New Mexico; Hamilton DA, Department of Psychology - University of New Mexico

The hippocampus is susceptible to the effects of prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE) that can result in persistent cognitive impairments. Although there have been many investigations, deficits in synaptic plasticity remains poorly understood. Previous studies have identified deficits in long-term potentiation (LTP) in the perforant pathway to dentate gyrus synapses as a robust consequence of PAE. This study sought to investigate how PAE effects LTP in the dentate gyrus and how PAE influences continuous EEG signaling and time-frequency relationships in evoked responses after high-frequency stimulation (HFS). We utilized a rat model of moderate PAE (60 mg/dl peak blood alcohol content). Thirteen urethane-anesthetized adult male rats were implanted with monopolar electrodes in the dorsal dentate gyrus and in the entorhinal cortical perforant pathway. Evoked responses were recorded (1/30s) at 20KHz and continuous data were obtained at 1KHz throughout sessions. Synaptic potentiation was induced by 5 trains of HFS over 25ms with 30s inter-train intervals. PAE rats displayed reduced LTP of the fEPSP (p = 0.01). Data were analyzed using fast Fourier transformation (FFT) within the delta to gamma frequency bands, as well individual frequencies ranging from 1-16 Hz, including slow oscillatory activity (<1Hz) and rhythmic slow activity (3-15Hz). At baseline, the PAE group displayed a trend toward increased delta power (p = 0.055) and significantly increased 2-3Hz power (p = 0.042). There were no group differences following HFS or in relative power for any phase. Time frequency analyses performed on individual evoked responses revealed a greater increase in power associated with the fEPSP in SAC rats, whereas PAE displayed increased power in later portions of the evoked response that reflect feedback signaling from local interneurons. These observations suggest that deficits in LTP following PAE may be related to alterations in local inhibitory interneuron activity and rhythmic activity in the dentate gyrus.

Nanthia Suthana 		Keynote Event

BRAIN Initiative Alliance Tools, Tech, Theory, and Trainee Series: Tools (part 1)
 
Abstract
 
The BRAIN Initiative Alliance (http://www.braininitiative.org/) is hosting a virtual series in collaboration with Neuromatch 3.0 to highlight cutting-edge tools, technology, and theories emerging from the US BRAIN Initiative. The event is divided into three session to focus on 1) Tools (probes, optics, cellular, molecular), 2) Tech (software, hardware), and 3) Theory (modeling, computation), with trainees integrated in each session. Each session will include five brief talks/demos showcasing new tools, techniques, or theories from US BRAIN Initiative toolmakers followed by a moderated discussion with Q/A.

This is session 1/3, focused on Tools (probes, optics, cellular, molecular).

Moderator:
- Ute Hochgeschwender, MD (Central Michigan University)

Talks:
- "Idenification of lipid heterogeneity and diversity in the developing human brain"
Aparna Bhaduri, PhD (University of California San Francisco)

- "MR-active nanosensor: A tool to visualize biological condition/chemical"
Heather Clark, PhD (Northeastern University) and Hyewon Seo, PhD (Northeastern University)

- "Building a Toolbox of Enhancer-AAVs for Cell-Population Selective Gene Expression Across Species"
Boaz Levi, PhD (Allen Institute)

- "Free cloud platform for secure neuroscience data analysis"
Franco Pestilli, PhD (University of Texas Austin)

- "Neurotechnology design features' impact on identity and function of reactive astrocytes"
Ti'Air Riggins, MS (Michigan State University)
Keynote Event
Watch now
Daniel Colón-Ramos 		Keynote Event
Watch now
Symposium on Chronic Neural Interface Technology
 
Abstract
 
This symposium will feature three leading neural interface engineers that are creating next generation microelectrode array technologies for large-scale and long-term neural recording and stimulation in the brain, spinal cord, and peripheral nerve. Although metal microelectrodes are perhaps the oldest neural interface technology, they remain the most commonly used tool for measuring and stimulating neural activity in the brain, especially in applications that require realtime processing and control, such as brain-machine interfaces. Due to recent advances in materials and microfabrication methods, modern microelectrodes retain the same basic functionality of traditional microelectrodes but with several important new features, including ultrathin and compliant substrates that lead to reduced tissue damage and improved chronic stability. These devices provide hundreds of discrete channels for interfacing with the brain for long time spans, enabling new research paradigms for studying neural circuit function and creating promising new treatments for neurological disorders.

Speaker 1: Stephanie Lacour, Professor, EPFL Center for Neuroprosthetics
Talk title: Soft, microfabricated and multimodal neural interfaces

Speaker 2: Lan Luan, Assistant Professor, Rice University
Talk title: Ultra-flexible Neural Electrodes for Brain Disorders

Speaker 3: Cindy Chestek, Associate Professor, University of Michigan
Talk title: Neural Interfaces for Controlled Individuated Finger Movements

Moderator: Jordyn Ting, PhD student, University of Pittsburgh
Traditional talk
Watch now
Science fiction and folk knowledge of the brain: insights for science communicators
Kathryn O'Nell
 
Abstract
 
In science communication, one of the biggest challenges for scientists steeped in the vocabulary and assumptions of their field can be understanding exactly where expert and non-expert understandings of a particular topic differ. Luckily for neuroscientists, we have a particularly strong and underutilized tool in our belt for better understanding folk conceptions of the mind and brain: science fiction. Since the second century (and probably before) humans have been using speculative fiction to explore biological aspects of human identity. In this talk, I’ll review what classic and contemporary speculative fiction can tell us about the issues in neuroscientific research that loom largest in the public consciousness, like whether the brain is a computer, what aspects of human cognition are required for general artificial intelligence, how personal identity is preserved in an ever-changing biological system, and to what degree genetic factors control social outcomes. Then I’ll discuss how neuroscientists can use the conceptions of brain and mind that science fiction create and reveal as a starting point for communicating their research to non-expert audiences.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Architecture to learn untrained joints in macaques and other species
Benjamin Hayden
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Praneet Bala, Hyun Soo Park, Jan Zimmermann

Pose tracking of animals is of utmost importance in systems neuroscience and related fields like neuroethology. It is also of growing importance in fields that use behavioral assays in model organisms, such as addiction and mental health research. While off-the-shelf solutions exist for many laboratory animals, monkeys have proven especially challenging and require a bespoke solution. We recently developed a tracking system for rhesus macaques called OpenMonkeyStudio (Bala et al., 2020). Like other supervised approaches, our system makes use of machine learning based on carefully annotated example datasets. However, like other approaches, ours has a major limitation: it cannot generalize to new joints that were not explicitly trained through annotated examples. Here we describe two novel approaches that can do this. First, the prediction of novel 2D key points via 3D MLP augmentation and second, a 50-layer convolutional neural network (CNN) with point rendering supervision to perform full 3D segmentation of our macaque subjects. We then project the 3D voxel space into a mesh space using the marching cubes algorithm and overlay the 2D image textures. Our initial supervised training set used 13 joints; our new approach can track arbitrarily many, including a deformable mesh grid for the entire body of arbitrary density. For example, we demonstrate a version with 30,000 points on the subject’s body. One benefit of this approach is that we can perform high resolution head position and orientation tracking, thus giving us a rudimentary estimate of gaze direction. While our focus is on macaques, our approach can readily be applied to other species as well.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Mind-body relationships and neuroscientific frameworks: a pluralistic proposal based on cultural anthropology
Kamilya Salibayeva
 
Abstract
 
Mind/body dualism — or the question of the mind’s origins — is a problem central to the development of Western cognitive science. Can the mind be disentangled from the physical entity which exists in the time and space continuum that is associated with mental phenomena? The majority of Western thinkers have operated within this framework of discreteness and separability of notions related to the mind itself.
However, there is an alternative approach to the mind-body problem, based in the worldview of nomadic civilizations of Eurasia. A relatively unknown framework of thought is characteristic for people who practice transhumance — a type of pastoralist livestock herding in Eurasia. Transhumance remains well-preserved in the knowledge and language of ethnic groups of the region. Namely, it has an innate linguistic intractability: there is no separation of abstract notions (e.g., “mind” uses the same word as “consciousness”, “advice”, “memory”).
In my argument, I will refer to the historical discourse of censorship and colonialism, which hindered the spread and, perhaps, even the possibility of conceptualization of the nomadic world view. As such, I will briefly explore the syncretic relationships between Tengrism, Islam, and other frameworks of cosmological thought which, along with the nature of the nomadic lifestyle, inform the details of the cognitive framework.
After introducing the elements of nomadic civilization, I will provide a brief comparative analysis of the main Western schools of thought using the nomadic “structureless” frame of mind. Concise, yet informative, juxtapositions of views enable the differences to be seen in terms more closely approximated to the Western images of dualistic entities. Thus, my analysis provides a basis for traditionally omitted paradigms of philosophy, and may give rise to a new system of categorization of philosophical notions.
Traditional talk
Watch now
The inseparability of featural and configural visual processing in dyslexia
Bahareh Jozranjbar
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Árni Kristjánsson1, Department of Psychology, University of Iceland; Heida Maria Sigurdardottir, Department of Psychology, University of Iceland

While dyslexia is typically described as a phonological deficit, recent evidence suggests that ventral stream regions, important for visual categorization and object recognition, are hypoactive in dyslexic readers who might accordingly show visual recognition deficits. But what exactly these visual recognition problems are, is still unknown. If dyslexic readers‘ problems are visual, they could be restricted to visual word processing or they might generalize to other visual categories – all or only some, as face recognition is assumed to require domain-specific mechanisms. There are two different approaches to visual recognition; featural and configural processing. Featural processing is generally assumed to be important for word recognition while configural processing is often considered the hallmark of face processing. By manipulating featural and configural information in faces and houses, we investigated whether dyslexic readers are disadvantaged at recognizing certain object classes or utilizing particular visual processing mechanisms. We recruited 34 dyslexic readers and 34 matched typical readers. Dyslexic readers found it harder to recognize objects (houses), suggesting that visual problems in dyslexia are not completely domain-specific. Mean accuracy for faces was equivalent in the two groups, compatible with domain-specificity in face processing. However, univariate analyses of accuracy miss that even though no overall group differences were found for featural vs. configural accuracy, this does not mean that the tasks were solved using similar representations or the same underlying mechanisms. Representational similarity analysis (RSA), which originates in systems neuroscience, can provide a fuller description of the structure of information representation in each group. RSA on our behavioral data revealed that featural and configural processes were clearly separable in typical readers, while dyslexic readers appeared to rely on a single process. We speculate that reading deficits in some dyslexic readers reflect their reliance on a single process for object recognition.
 ... continues ... Traditional talk
Watch now
Mutliple bouts of high intensity exercise and its effect on resting state functional connectivity and implicit motor learning in healthy older adults
Brian Greeley
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Brian Greeley, University of British Columbia; Briana Chau, University of British Columbia; Christy C. Jones, University of British Columbia; Lara A. Boyd, University of British Columbia

Older adults show both age-related decreases in resting state functional connectivity and sensorimotor function. Aerobic exercise has emerged as a potential intervention that may mitigate or even reverse these age-related declines. However, studies that have touted the impact of exercise on resting state functional connectivity or motor learning have done so focusing on one of these two dependent measures alone. Here we sought to understand whether exercise influences both resting state functional connectivity, and motor acquisition and learning in the same population of older adults. Forty-two healthy older adults rested or completed high intensity aerobic exercise for 23 minutes, then immediately practiced a complex, implicit motor task with their non-dominant hand across five separate sessions. Participants were also scanned before the first and after the fifth day of practice, and returned 24-hours and 35-days following their fifth day of practice to complete short- and long-term retention tests of behavioural change. Independent component analysis revealed increased connectivity in the frontoparietal network, the dorsal attentional network, and the cerebellar network in the exercise group. Seed-based analysis revealed strengthened connectivity between the limbic system and right cerebellum, between right lobule 9 and the right middle temporal gyrus, and between right lobule 10 and bilateral middle temporal gyri. There were no group implicit motor learning differences during acquisition or at either retention test. Overall, these data suggest that either exercise alone, or exercise paired with a novel implicit motor learning task augment resting state functional connectivity but do not enhance behavioural change beyond that stimulated by skilled motor practice in older healthy adults.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Hand localization shifts after different types of visual error feedback in reaching
Jennifer Ruttle
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jennifer Ruttle, York University; Bernard M. 't Hart, York University; Denise Henriques, York University

Perturbed error feedback during reaching movements leads to adapted reaches, which involves at least two processes, as shown by a two-rate model (Smith et al., 2006). This model includes a fast and slow process, that respond differently to errors, and combine to change motor output, including those changes seen during rotated visual feedback training (McDougle et al., 2015). This model is specifically able to explain a rebound toward a previous performance when error feedback is removed. Adapting to rotated visual feedback also leads to shifted estimates of hand location, participants perceive their unseen hand as being closer to where they visually experienced the misaligned hand-cursor. Here we test how different types of feedback during training affect the rebound predicted by the two-rate model and shifts in proprioceptive-estimates of hand location. The feedback conditions include the typical continuous cursor feedback, and more “impoverished” conditions, terminal cursor feedback, and passive-exposure feedback. During rotated exposure feedback training, participants’ hands were moved by the robot with straight hand paths that perfectly countered any rotation, but with a normal error-clamp phase at the end. We find terminal cursor feedback produces a smaller rebound while the rebounds in the other conditions are indistinguishable. Regardless of the type of cursor feedback, perceived changes in hand location emerged very rapidly and with a similar time course throughout training across all three conditions. To further test the rapid changes in hand estimates, another group experienced a visuomotor rotation that changes every 12 trials. Participants attempted to learn each rotation with proprioceptive hand estimates again shifting quite rapidly following each change in rotation direction and size. However, the size of shift decrease slightly as training progressed, indicating a possible change in error sensitivity across time. These results underline the robustness and speed by which vision recalibrates proprioception.
