Black In Neuro: Screening of the film "Coded Bias"
 
Abstract
 
Black In Neuro will host a screening of the new film "Coded Bias"

RSVP to join us for a film on bias in artificial intelligence and the women data scientists and mathematicians fighting to expose its threat to civil liberties and democracy.

https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/neuromatch-conference-black-in-neuro-coded-bias-screening-event-tickets-126251394319

You will be sent a link to watch the film via email 10 minutes before the event start time.

Film Synopsis:
Coded Bias explores the fallout of MIT Media Lab researcher Joy Buolamwini’s startling discovery that facial recognition does not see dark-skinned faces accurately, and her subsequent journey to push for the first-ever US legislation to govern against bias in artificial intelligence. The documentary aims to shine a light on the threat artificial intelligence poses to civil rights and democracy.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Age-related double dissociation of fast and slow theta oscillations in children and adolescents
Lisa Johnson
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Qin Yin, Wayne State University; Lingfei Tang, Wayne State University; Eishi Asano, Wayne State University; Noa Ofen, Wayne State University

Neuronal oscillations are ubiquitous and associated with processes ranging from physiological to cognitive to pathological. These periodic rhythms change considerably during development, making understanding their development fundamental to understanding brain development. However, typical scalp EEG does not access medial brain areas directly and offers low spatial resolution of the lateral areas it does access. Noninvasive EEG therefore offers a limited window into brain development and, as we consider here, the development of cognitive processes such as declarative memory which rely on the medial temporal lobe (MTL) and its connections to specific lateral prefrontal (PFC) areas. To circumvent this issue, we capitalized on a unique opportunity to record EEG directly from the brains of pediatric neurosurgical patients undergoing invasive clinical monitoring for seizure management.

In this study, 21 children and adolescents (5.9-20.5 years) undergoing direct cortical monitoring (i.e., ECoG) attended to visual scenes in preparation for a memory recognition test. We isolated ECoG signals from 80 channels in MTL and 357 channels in PFC. We focused on theta rhythms, which are defined by a frequency of 3-8 Hz and consistently linked to memory processes in the MTL of adults as well as animal models. After disentangling oscillatory components from aperiodic 1/f activity, we detected at faster rhythm ~7 Hz which sped up with age and a slower rhythm ~3 Hz which slowed down with age. These results reveal that: (1) recent findings of fast and slow theta rhythms in the adult MTL extend to children; (2) both rhythms are also evident in PFC; and (3) development is associated with the functional differentiation of theta oscillations. Further analyses show that both theta oscillations support MTL-PFC functional connectivity patterns predictive of subsequent memory formation, suggesting that the functional differentiation of theta oscillations relates to the development of declarative memory.
Traditional talk
Watch now
The structure of life sciences academia
Alexey Guzey
 
Abstract
 
Academia has a public image that in a lot of ways has diverges with how it actually works, both presenting a better version of itself in some aspects and a worse version in others. In my talk I will discuss the observations I made and the patterns I noticed about the way life sciences academia (with the focus on neuroscience) works after 2 years of research and conversations with more than 100 people involved with life sciences academia. Topics I will cover include the sincerity and hypocrisy of academia; the relative rigidity of academic career paths; the funding asymmetry and the power asymmetry between the young and the old researchers; cooperation and competition in academia.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
LiftPose3D, a deep learning-based approach for transforming 2D to 3D pose in laboratory animals
Adam Gosztolai
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Semih Gunel, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne; Marco Pietro Abrate, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne; Daniel Morales, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne; Victor Lobato Rios, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne; Helge Rhodin, University of British Columbia; Pascal Fua, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne; Pavan Ramdya, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne

Markerless 3D pose estimation has become an indispensable tool for kinematic studies of laboratory animals. Most current methods recover 3D pose by multi-view triangulation of deep network-based 2D pose estimates. However, triangulation requires multiple, synchronised cameras per keypoint and elaborate calibration protocols that hinder its widespread adoption in laboratory studies. Here, we describe LiftPose3D, a deep network-based method that overcomes these barriers by reconstructing 3D poses from a single 2D camera view. We illustrate LiftPose3D’s versatility by applying it to multiple experimental systems using flies, mice, and macaque monkeys and in circumstances where 3D triangulation is impractical or impossible. Thus, LiftPose3D permits high-quality 3D pose estimation in the absence of complex camera arrays, tedious calibration procedures, and despite occluded keypoints in freely behaving animals.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Mathematics Ability vs. Mathematics Disability
Kevser Aktas
 
Abstract
 
In 1904, Spearman used the term general intelligence “g” as a measurement or success in a various form of cognitive tasks (Spearman, 1961). General intelligence is one of the most heritable behaviour traits, with heritability rising from 40% from childhood to 80% in adulthood (Kropnik et al., 2016). Mathematics ability(MA) is an important indicator of human intelligence (Chen et al., 2017). Basic arithmetic calculations and related numeracy skills are essential part of the normal brain operation (Docherty et al., 2010). The genetic complexities of MA might explain the fundamentals of general intelligence both at genetic and neurobiological level. On the other hand, American Psychiatric Association (1994) defines mathematics disability(MD) as receiving arithmetic scores at least 2 years below expected grade level. The studies show that 6% of school children face with MD. One of the well-known mathematical disorders as known dyscalculia is an important impairment that may cause severe problems in an individual’s life but with the help of better understanding of neurobiological and genetic aspects of the cases with proper arrangements in environmental factors would help to reduce the effects of the disorder. In the last two decades, rising interest on applications of neuroscience studies increased interventions of the studies in educational context. In this talk, I will present the genetic and neurobiological components of MA and MD as well as introducing Genome Wide Association Studies(GWAS) related to the research field. In addition, I will discuss the environmental factors that effect Mathematics ability and developmental disorders such as dyscalculia. The role of the society with some example of educational policies from the past, today’s applications and connection to genetics and neuroscience research will be explained. Finally, the future of the neuroscientific studies in educational setting will be discussed.
Traditional talk
Watch now
When the ventral visual stream is not enough: A deep learning account of medial temporal lobe involvement in perception
tyler bonnen
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Daniel L.K. Yamins, Stanford Universiry; Anthony D. Wagner, Stanford University

The medial temporal lobe (MTL) supports a constellation of memory-related behaviors. Its involvement in perceptual processing, however, has been subject to an enduring debate. This debate centers on perirhinal cortex (PRC), an MTL structure at the apex of the ventral visual stream (VVS), beset by decades of seemingly inconsistent experimental outcomes. We suggest that these apparent inconsistencies can be resolved by situating experimental behavior in relation to perceptual processing supported by the VVS. To evaluate this claim we leverage a deep learning approach that approximates visual behaviors supported by the VVS. We first apply this approach retroactively, modeling 29 published concurrent visual discrimination experiments: Excluding misclassified stimuli, there is a striking correspondence between a computational proxy for the VVS and PRC-lesioned behavior. Conversely, PRC-intact subjects outperform this model and PRC-lesioned subjects. We corroborate these results using novel, high-throughput psychophysics experiments: PRC-intact participants outperform a linear readout of electrophysiological recordings from the macaque VVS. Finally, in silico experiments suggest PRC enables out-of-distribution visual behaviors at rapid timescales: VVS-like models achieve PRC-dependent accuracy, but only with extensive training, while failing to generalize to out-of-sample stimuli. By situating these lesion, electrophysiological, and behavioral results within a shared computational framework, our work resolves decades of seemingly inconsistent experimental findings surrounding PRC involvement in perception. In doing so, we have identified biologically constraints that may inform future models of human-level visual behaviors.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Multinetwork Visuomotor Training To Synth-Music Investigated With Mobile Eeg
Rebecca Barnstaple
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Joseph FX DeSouza, York University; Lydia Jaufmann, Sein Jeung, Janna Protzak, Klaus Gramann, TU Berlin

We investigated the contribution of multinetwork training with music to neurorehabilitation. Previous studies showed that dance-based learning over 8-months produced BOLD signal changes in SMA using fMRI (Bar & DeSouza 2016) and resting state alpha power increases in frontal cortex post-dance in people with Parkinson’s disease compared to controls (Levkov et al 2014).
Our current project assesses the impact of motor learning while subjects (n=16) learn a 30-second choreography. Trials include watching VIDEO (4 times), watching LIVE performances of the choreography (6 times), moving with the teacher (LEARN; 6 to 20 times), imagining performing from a first-person perspective (IMAGINE; 6 times), and finally performing in space (PERFORM; 6 times). Sessions were recorded at the Berlin Mobile Brain/Body Imaging lab (BeMoBIL) which allows for acquisition of motion capture data synced with continuous recording of wireless mobile EEG (Brain Products ActiCap; 128 electrodes) in a dedicated 150 m2 lab space Movements are measured using 10 HTC Vive trackers running on Steam VR; music was rated for valence pre/post learning.
Preliminary results show a significant shift (p=.0009) in participants’ affective scoring of the music post-learning, suggesting that the experience of dance learning impacts perception of previously unfamiliar music. This is important, as music is a consistent factor in rehabilitation programs using dance; however, to this point, the effects of motor learning on affective music perception have not been studied in this context. Additionally, all participants reached our target of 80% or higher accuracy in reproducing the movement sequence within 20 LEARN trials, with expertise correlating to fewer trials. Next steps include frequency analysis of EEG data pre/post and during learning, along with movement analysis to determine the contribution of motor learning to observed brain-based changes.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Surprise signals in Frontal Eye Field
Michael Shteyn (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Carl R. Olson, Carnegie Mellon University

In classic learning theory, surprise is quantified by unsigned prediction error, which determines how much attention is captured by a particular event. Unlike signed reward prediction error, an unsigned prediction error increases with the improbability of an outcome, regardless of its valence. Neurons in the frontal eye field (FEF) are sensitive to reward amount and are involved in the allocation of attention but it is unknown how they respond to surprising outcomes. To address this, we trained monkeys in a Pavlovian paradigm requiring them to view two images in a probablistic sequence followed by delivery of a reward. The leading image, depending on its identity, predicted with high probability (p = 0.83) delivery of either a large or a small reward at the end of the trial. The trailing image indicated with certainty that the ensuing reward would be either large or small. The information conveyed by the trailing image usually confirmed, but occasionally violated, the prediction conveyed by the leading image. The key question of the study is whether a given trailing image would elicit differential activity depending on whether it confirmed or violated the expectation created by the leading image. We found that the strength of the response to the trailing image was indeed influenced by surprise. Neurons responded more strongly to a trailing image predicting large reward when the probability of large reward was low than when it was high. Similarly, neurons responded more strongly to a trailing image predicting small reward when the probability of small reward was low than when it was high. Further, we demonstrate that these results depend on presenting the cues in rather than opposite the response field. The results are consistent with the interpretation that cues signaling surprising outcomes capture spatial attention and, in so doing, recruit excitation of FEF neurons.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
EEG Delta Rhythms in Visual Association Cortices Mark Syntactic Constituents
M. Blake Rafferty
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Devin M. Casenhiser

Recent work has suggested that syntactic processes may be indexed neurologically via amplitude changes in EEG delta oscillations (1-4Hz). However, these observations have been primarily limited to the frequency domain, and little is known of how delta oscillations are modulated in real-time while syntactic processes are performed. In the present study, we used time-frequency analysis to characterize delta responses at constituent boundaries in sentences with a fixed grammatical pattern in contrast to lexically-matched scrambled lists with no obvious syntactic structure. We also sought to identify whether delta activity is modulated by lexico-semantic content. To do this, we included two additional sentence types: Jabberwocky sentences with identical morpho-syntax to grammatical sentence stimuli but where all content words were replaced by nonsense words and a scrambled version of these sentences. Analyses were conducted on the basis of structure (English + Nonsense sentences with grammar vs. English + Nonsense sentences scrambled) and lexico-semantic content (English with Grammar + English scrambled vs. Nonsense with Grammar + Nonsense scrambled). Results of time-frequency analysis revealed no effect of lexico-semantic content; however, higher delta power was observed at constituent boundaries for sentences with grammatical structure relative to word-lists. Post-hoc source analyses identified left-fusiform gyrus as the primary generator of this difference. The fusiform gyrus has been suggested as an interface between the sensory and conceptual systems in order to facilitate efficient visual processing, and as such, it is frequently activated during reading tasks like the one used in the present study. Considering this, we argue that delta oscillations emanating from the fusiform gyrus may reflect the integration of visual information with top-down knowledge of syntactic structure.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Violence, Neuroscience, and the Legal System
Jozsef Meszaros
 
Abstract
 
Long before then-President Barack Obama launched the BRAIN initiative, his predecessor George H.W. Bush designated the 1990's as a "Decade of the Brain". As neuroscientists, we can marvel at the tremendous breadth of discovery and innovation that has taken place within our field over these past three decades. But to what extent have the fruits of our labor been absorbed by the social and political systems which fostered them so closely? In a 2010 Supreme Court decision that forbid the lifetime imprisonment of juveniles for non-homicide crimes, the Court tipped its hat in the direction of developmental brain science. A handful of optimistic observers viewed the decision as heralding a new age of brain-based challenges to our conventional notions of criminal responsibility. Yet, this reality has yet to materialize and there is little to suggest that we can expect otherwise. In this talk, I will briefly discuss the short history of neuroscience and law. Then I will outline a few basic premises of how the legal system treats violent offenses. Finally, I will discuss work in which I have argued that neuroscience evidence of brain insults -- such as physical injury or lead intoxication -- should be used to reduce criminal responsibility for violent acts. Specifically, I will critically reflect on my previous scholarship pertaining to victims of battering relationships who are themselves accused of having participated in criminal conduct. A key question is: "Why should I be responsible for my brain's output if another person has disrupted its function in a way that made me more likely to be violent?" At the core of my argument is a concept of a malleable brain -- regardless of age -- and a notion of guilt that can be distributed to third-parties who disrupt that brain's ability to direct actions within the confines of the law.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
A functional hierarchy for choice in medial prefrontal cortex
David Maisson
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tyler Cash-Padgett, Maya Wang, Benjamin Hayden, Sarah Heilbronner, Jan Zimmermann

Hierarchical approaches to functional neuroanatomy propose that choice-relevant brain regions have overlapping functions and can be organized into a series that progressively transforms information about options into choices. Here, we examined responses of neurons in four regions of the medial prefrontal cortex as macaques performed two-option risky choices. All four regions encoded economic variables in similar proportions and showed putative signatures of key choice-related computations. We found evidence for a hierarchical organization proceeding from areas 14→25→32→24. Specifically, we found that decodability of eight distinct task variables increased along that path, consistent with the idea that hierarchically later regions make these variables more separable. We also found longer intrinsic timescales in the same series, further supporting the idea of a hierarchy. Together these results highlight the importance of the medial wall in choice, endorse a specific hierarchical organization, and argue against a modular functional neuroanatomy of choice.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Trajectories in Cognition Studies - a focus on embodiment and future frontiers
Anson Lim(he him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jesse Parent, Orthogonal Research and Education Lab

The study of cognition contains a vast set of tributaries flowing from "traditional" fields of cognitive science, particularly philosophy and general inquiries into the nature of the mind. What is missing following the last several decades of the cognitive revolution? In this talk, we look at relevant trajectories in the philosophy behind inquiries into cognitive capacity and functioning. In particular, we look at the concept of embodiment and how it shaped discourse, education, and analysis in studying cognition broadly, and in specific arenas such as cognitive neuroscience and computational cognitive science. We also provide guidelines for mapping out the frontier of cognitive studies, particularly examining further integration of embodied & developmental approaches from psychology and biology and their implications for artificial intelligence.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Visual ensemble representations emerge in Deep Neural Networks trained for object recognition
Siddharth Suresh
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Emily Ward, University of Wisconsin–Madison (grid.14003.36)

Humans are able to quickly pool information from across many individual objects to perceive ensemble properties, like the average size of objects, the color diversity of objects, or even the gender ratio in a group of faces. Such ensemble perception in humans is thought to occur extremely efficiently and automatically, but how it arises in the first place is unknown. Does ensemble perception arise because the human visual system must solve many different types of perceptual problems, or are ensemble properties represented even in a system with only the goal of recognizing individual objects? Here, we used an artificial visual system -- a deep neural network -- to determine whether the ensemble property of color diversity emerges in a network pre-trained to recognize natural objects (using ImageNet). We presented the network with new images that were completely different from its training set: images of letter arrays containing four colored consonants on a black background. The color of each letter within an array was drawn either from a broad sample of 19 colors (high color diversity) or a randomly selected range of six adjacent colors (low color diversity). The ensemble property of interest -- color diversity -- was therefore a summary statistic for the whole array and not recoverable from any individual element. We tested whether a ResNet50 neural network could distinguish high vs. low color diversity arrays by using the activations from different layers as input to a linear classifier (SVM). We found that the network was highly accurate at identifying color diversity, with deeper layers more accurate than earlier layers. This demonstrates the presence of ensemble representations for the first time in deep neural networks, and also suggests that ensemble perception of multiple objects can emerge even in a system only trained to recognize individual objects.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Priming Motor Learning through Exercise in those with Cerebellar Ataxia: A Pilot Study (PRIME-ATAXIA)
Chelsea Macpherson
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Chelsea E. Macpherson, PT, DPT, NCS (affiliation: Biobehavioral Sciences Department, EdD student in Motor Learning and Control, Teachers College, Columbia University, New York, New York, USA) ; Lori Quinn, PT, EdD (affiliation: Biobehavioral Sciences Department, EdD student in Motor Learning and Control, Teachers College, Columbia University, New York, New York, USA); Sheng-Han Kuo, MD (affiliation: Department of Neurology, Columbia University Medical Center, New York, New York, USA)

Keywords (separated by semicolons)
Cerebellar Ataxia; Motor Learning; Exercise; Neuroplasticity; Neurorehabilitation; Reliability; Feasibility

Background:
Impairments in gait and balance are hallmark symptoms for individuals with spinocerebellar Ataxias (SCAs) and they contribute to functional limitations including fall risk and loss of independent ambulation. Rehabilitation interventions hold great promise for improving physical function and delaying disease progression, however research specifically in SCA remains limited, especially so for remote or hybrid delivered interventions. Recent literature supports priming aerobic exercise can enhance task-specific motor performance in individuals with neurological disorders. Activation of neural circuitries following aerobic exercise may lead to downstream retention of cognitive and motor skills, and may provide a crucial link to enhancing motor performance and facilitating motor learning in individuals with SCAs. Exercise interventions are therefore optimally positioned as both a method to improve motor symptoms and slow disease progression, as well as to evaluate the responsiveness of outcome measures for use in a range of clinical trials. Establishing the feasibility of a remotely delivered motor-priming exercise intervention is crucial to support clinical trial readiness.

Aims:
1.To determine the reliability and responsiveness of a remotely-administered standardized clinical outcome battery in individuals with SCA.
2.To determine the feasibility of delivering a remotely-delivered 8-week high intensity exercise intervention in individuals with SCAs.

Methods:
The proposed aims will be nested in a single cohort study evaluating an 8-week remotely-delivered exercise intervention for individuals with genetically-confirmed SCAs (n=20). The intervention will be delivered twice a week for 8 weeks and consist of combined 30-minute high intensity interval training (HIIT) on a recumbent stationary cycle ergometer, followed immediately by intensive, individualized 20-minute balance training. A caregiver/support person will be required for engagement in intervention sessions. Participants and their caregiver/support person will be instructed in identifying a space at home to sufficiently and safely perform tests/interventions. Participants will use FitBit Wearable Activity Monitors with heart rate capabilities as a method to evaluate exercise intensity and duration. Remotely-administered standardized outcome battery will be conducted during two baseline assessments (1 week apart), mid-intervention (week 5) and post intervention (week 8) and will include the first 4-items of the Scale for Assessment and Rating of Ataxia (SARA), Cerebellar Cognitive Assessment Scale (CCAS), Neurologic Quality of Life (NeuroQOL), Timed Up and Go Test (TUG) and measures of postural sway through a smartphone app (Encephalog, Mon4t, LLC, Binyamina, Israel). To determine the test-retest reliability of the remotely-administered standardized clinical outcome battery, we will calculate intraclass correlation coefficients as well as minimal detectable change values. To determine the responsiveness of the outcome battery, we will calculate the effect estimates comparing baseline, mid-intervention and post intervention. To determine the feasibility of delivering a high intensity exercise intervention remotely, we will evaluate the safety, retention and adherence rates.

Results/Conclusion: Participants are currently being recruited for this study.

Clinical Implications: This project will provide knowledge on the feasibility of measuring clinical outcomes and delivering an exercise intervention remotely while additionally developing physiological and functional biomarkers for clinical trial readiness in SCA.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Direct brain recordings reveal occipital cortex involvement in memory development
Qin Yin
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Elizabeth L. Johnson, Wayne State University, University of California, Berkeley; Lingfei Tang, Wayne State University; Kurtis I. Auguste, University of California, San Francisco, Children’s Hospital and Research Center, Oakland; Robert T. Knight, University of California, Berkeley; Eishi Asano, Children’s Hospital of Michigan, Wayne State University; Noa Ofen, Wayne State University

Processing of low-level visual information shows robust developmental gains through childhood and adolescence. However, it is unknown whether low-level visual processing in the occipital cortex supports age-related gains in memory for complex visual stimuli. Here, we examined occipital alpha activity during visual scene encoding in 24 children and adolescents, aged 6.2–20.5 years, who performed a subsequent memory task while undergoing electrocorticographic recording. Scenes were classified as high- or low-complexity by the number of unique object categories depicted. We found that recognition of high-complexity, but not low-complexity, scenes increased with age. Age was associated with decreased alpha power and increased instantaneous alpha frequency during the encoding of subsequently recognized high- compared to low-complexity scenes. Critically, decreased alpha power predicted improved recognition of high-complexity scenes in adolescents. These findings demonstrate how the functional maturation of the occipital cortex supports the development of memory for complex visual scenes.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Systematic analysis of goal-related movements in alloparental mice during pup retrieval behavior
Keerthi Krishnan (She, Her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Parker Stevenson; Devin Casenhiser

Parenting is an ethologically relevant social behavior consisting of stereotypic behavioral components involving the care and nourishment of young. First-time rodent dams seek and gather wandering/scattered pups back to the nest (pup retrieval), an essential aspect of maternal care. Over the decades, qualitative observations of the behaving animal have been presented in quantitative discrete units. However, systematic analysis of the sequence of goal-related movements that comprise the entire behavior and which would be ultimately essential for understanding the contribution of specific neural circuits and brain regions, is usually not analyzed. Here, we present results from pup retrieval behaviors of alloparental female mice (Surrogates or Sur) of two genotypes; Mecp2-heterozygotes (Het), a female mouse model for a neuropsychiatric disorder called Rett Syndrome and their wild type (WT) siblings. Frame-by-frame analysis over different phases (habituation, isolation and retrieval) was performed manually using DataVyu software.
We previously showed that SurHet are inefficient at pup retrieval. Here, the sequence of pup retrieval crystallizes over time for SurWT, while it does not for SurHet. Day-by-day analysis shows dynamic changes in goal-related movements in individual animals in response to the same pup stimuli. SurHet behavior in different phases are similar to SurWT, suggesting that atypical dynamic patterns in SurHet behavior is dependent on context. Tactile sensory perception between adult and pups has been previously shown to be important for maternal behavior, by studies in the 1980s. Based on our results, we suggest that tactile stimulation of whiskers/face and somatosensation of the SurWT body may play essential roles in efficient pup retrieval, which might be adversely affected in SurHet. These results suggest atypical sensory processing in this female mouse model for Rett Syndrome.

Traditional talk
Watch now
A large-scale neural network training framework for generalized estimation of single-trial population dynamics
Andrew Sedler
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Mohammad Reza Keshtkaran (co-first author), Emory/Georgia Tech; Raeed H. Chowdhury, U of Pittsburgh; Raghav Tandon, Georgia Tech; Diya Basrai, UCSD; Sarah L. Nguyen, Georgia Tech; Hansem Sohn, MIT; Mehrdad Jazayeri, MIT; Lee E. Miller, Northwestern U; Chethan Pandarinath, Emory/Georgia Tech;

Large-scale recordings of neural activity are becoming ubiquitous, providing new opportunities to study network-level dynamics in diverse brain areas and during increasingly complex, natural behaviors. However, the sheer volume of data and its dynamical complexity are critical barriers to uncovering and interpreting these dynamics. Deep learning methods are a particularly promising approach due to their ability to uncover meaningful relationships from large, complex, and noisy datasets. One such method, latent factor analysis via dynamical systems (LFADS), uses recurrent neural networks to infer latent dynamics from high-D neural spiking data. When applied to motor cortical (M1) activity during stereotyped behaviors, LFADS substantially improved the ability to uncover dynamics and their relation to subjects’ behaviors on a moment-by-moment, millisecond timescale. However, applying LFADS to less-structured behaviors, or in brain areas that are not predominantly driven by intrinsic dynamics, is far more challenging. This is because LFADS, like many deep learning methods, requires careful hand-tuning of complex model hyperparameters (HPs) to achieve good performance. Here we demonstrate AutoLFADS, a large-scale, automated model tuning framework that can characterize dynamics in diverse brain areas without regard to behavior. AutoLFADS uses distributed computing to train dozens of models simultaneously while using evolutionary algorithms to optimally tune HPs in a completely unsupervised way. AutoLFADS required 10-fold less data to uncover dynamics from macaque M1/PMd, with better generalization to unseen behavioral conditions than previous LFADS models. We then tested data from the somatosensory and dorsomedial frontal cortices, areas with very different dynamics from M1/PMd. AutoLFADS produced estimates of population dynamics that were precisely linked to behavior without any prior knowledge of the areas’ dynamics, tasks, or subjects’ behaviors, outperforming any individually-trained LFADS model obtained through random HP searches.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Dopaminergic activation of prefrontal astrocytes requires both dopamine and adrenergic receptors
Silvia Pittolo
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sae Yokoyama, Department of Biochemistry & Biophysics, University of California, San Francisco; Michael Reitman, Department of Biochemistry & Biophysics, University of California, San Francisco; Kira Poskanzer, Department of Biochemistry & Biophysics, University of California, San Francisco & Kavli Institute for Fundamental Neuroscience

Cortical dopamine is crucial in many facets of behavior, including acute stress, depression and schizophrenia. Dopamine research has almost exclusively focused on neuronal signaling. However, astrocytes—which are organized in networks that tile the brain and express G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) for most neurotransmitters—are also well positioned to listen to and respond to dopamine signals. Here, we investigated the astrocytic response to dopamine in the prefrontal cortex (PFC), the main cortical recipient of dopaminergic inputs. First, using transgenic reporter lines, we found that prefrontal astrocytes in rodent PFC express both dopamine D1 and D2 receptors. Next, we expressed fluorescent reporters for GPCR second messengers in mouse prefrontal cortical slices. While inactivating neurons to isolate astrocyte-specific responses, we found that activation of dopamine receptors in astrocytes does not engage the canonical cyclic AMP signaling pathway downstream of dopamine receptors. In contrast, dopamine mobilized astrocytic calcium in both astrocyte somata and processes. To test which receptors mediate this calcium response, we used bath application of pharmacology, as well as one-photon uncaging of dopamine. These experiments revealed that dopamine recruits prefrontal astrocytes within seconds, and that antagonizing dopamine receptors only partially dampened the response of prefrontal astrocytes to dopamine, whereas the response was fully prevented by blocking adrenergic receptors. Lastly, we implanted GRIN lenses to image calcium dynamics in PFC astrocytes in vivo for the first time, and find that they exhibit different properties relative to locomotion than astrocytes in primary sensory cortices. Our finding that fast dopamine activation of prefrontal astrocytes requires both dopamine and adrenergic receptors is potentially relevant in the treatment of disorders such as schizophrenia and depression, where manipulation of more than one monoaminergic system is more beneficial than monotherapy. Together, our results suggest that astrocytes are important circuit components for dopamine signaling in PFC circuits.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Effects of memory for emotional valence and episodic detail on decision-making in aging
Michael Cohen
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Michael S. Cohen, University of Pennsylvania; Karolina M. Lempert, University of Pennsylvania; Kameron A. MacNear, University of Pennsylvania; Frances M. Reckers, University of Pennsylvania; Laura A. Zaneski, University of Pennsylvania; David A. Wolk, University of Pennsylvania; Joseph W. Kable, University of Pennsylvania

Objective: Older adults often show an increased vulnerability to fraud and frequently have decline in episodic memory. We examined how memory for a single prior experience influences older adults’ decision-making.

Methods: We presented older (n = 41) and middle-aged (n = 31) adult participants with pictures of social partners in a “dictator game”, or of houses in an analogous non-social task. Participants could gain $5 (high-reward) or $0 (low-reward) from each face or house. Each image was shown once. Minutes later, participants were asked to choose whether to play again with each person or house. After choices, memory for each face/house and for associated reward was tested. Neuroimaging data were collected from a subset (n = 11) of older adults. In a behavioral follow-up study (n = 137), collected online and sampled across the lifespan, we examined whether choices are driven by memory for reward valence (i.e., high vs. low reward) or specific episodic details. Here, rewards were varied in 10-cent increments within each valence (low: $0-$1.50; high: $3.60-$5.00), and the memory test included the exact value (e.g., $3.80), a same-valence incorrect lure (e.g., $4.30), and 2 opposite-valence values (e.g., $1.00).

Results: While older adults showed poorer associative memory overall, accuracy of confident responses was comparable across age groups. Confident memory for face/house-reward ($0 or $5) associations was related to subsequent choices in both age groups, as participants were much more likely to play again with faces or houses that they correctly believed were high vs. low value, though the effect was somewhat weaker in older adults. A preliminary analysis of fMRI data suggests that making adaptive choices (playing with rewarding partners or avoiding non-rewarding partners) was associated with increased BOLD signal in amygdala and hippocampus/parahippocampal cortex, relative to maladaptive choices. In the behavioral follow-up study, choices were consistent with memory responses even when the same-valence but incorrect lure was chosen. Memory for exact values was still above chance, however, and adaptive choices were even more likely when exact memory was available.

Conclusions: Older adults are capable of using explicit associative memory to guide decisions. However, across the lifespan, such decisions may rely largely on emotional valence memory (reliant on amygdala), which tends to be more preserved with age than episodic memory for details (e.g., Limbert et al., 2018). The latter appears to provide a further boost to decision-making, however, so age-related memory deficits could still lead to suboptimal choices.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Network-based R-statistics for longitudinal (unbalanced) samples: an R package
Zeus Gracia-Tabuenca
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sarael Alcauter, National Autonomous University of Mexico

The connectome models the brain as a set of interacting elements, allowing to characterize the brain from a systems perspective using network science. In particular, Zalesky et al. (2010) proposed Network-based Statistics (NBS) a mathematical approach that allows statistical inferences at the (sub-)network level, with a trade-off between false positive control and higher statistical power than mass univariate approaches (e.g. FDR). Nevertheless, NBS is based on general linear hypothesis testing (GLHT) which potentially limits its application to longitudinal samples, particularly, with an unbalanced sample, i.e., with a variable number of sessions per subject. We implemented a publicly available software R package, NBR (Network-Based R-statistics), that performs linear mixed-effects models (LME) in the NBS framework, allowing the exploration of unbalanced longitudinal samples.
We tested GLHT- and LME-NBS in the public dataset INDI-SLIM, which includes 333 participants (145 males; 17-28 y.o.) with two (n=212) or three (n=121) sessions each. All sessions include a resting-state fMRI scan and psychometric data. State anxiety scores and connectivity matrices between brain lobes were extracted. GLHT and LME tested the edgewise brain-behavior relationship for balanced (424 matrices) and unbalanced (787 matrices) samples, respectively.
The LME approach found a significant subnetwork, which includes the cingulum, frontal, parietal, occipital, and cerebellum (pFWE = 0.001), while GLHT found no significant results (pFWE = 0.355).
In summary, we developed an R package that implements LME for NBS. We showed that LME-NBS overpowers GLHT-NBS when dealing with unbalanced longitudinal samples. This is important given that missing data is very common in longitudinal samples, and balanced testing could dramatically undermine statistical power. Hence, considering the growth of longitudinal samples in neuroscience, we anticipate this method being potentially useful in the field.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Coordinate transform mechanisms mediating tactile motion representations on the hand
Himanshu Ahuja
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Himanshu Ahuja, Brain and Cognitive Science Department, University of Rochester; Ralf Haefner, Brain and Cognitive Science Department, University of Rochester; Greg De Angelis, Brain and Cognitive Science Department, University of Rochester; Manuel Gomez-Ramirez, Brain and Cognitive Science Department, University of Rochester;

Humans’ hand dexterity is largely facilitated by the brain’s ability to provide invariant object representations regardless of how fingers enclose the object. When an object slips between our fingers, it is perceived sliding down regardless of whether the hand is in a pronated vs. supinated position. Yet, the motion on the skin is completely reversed across both hand postures. This dichotomy indicates that tactile motion representations are remapped into a coordinate frame that is controlled, at least in part, by proprioception. A fundamental question that arises is whether tactile motion coordinate transforms are anchored on a skin- vs. ego-centric reference frame. In the skin-centric frame, the brain computes the object’s motion by combining cutaneous signals with the spatial position of the hand. In the World-centric frame, the brain uses the position of external cues (e.g., the object’s position relative to the floor) to derive the object’s motion irrespective of hand position. Top-down mechanisms may also allow switching between reference frames to provide invariant motion representations relative to hand movements vs. movements of external objects.
We conducted a series of human psychophysics experiments to study coordinate transform mechanisms in the somatosensory system. We designed a tactile stimulator that delivers cutaneous motion stimuli with the hand placed in different postures. Data show that humans can readily switch between Hand-centric and World-centric reference frames when judging the direction of tactile motion stimuli. Data also show that vision biases proprioceptive representations that control the coordinate transforms of cutaneous motion stimuli. Taken together, these data indicate that tactile motion representations are derived by integrating cutaneous, proprioceptive and visual-spatial signals, and that the haptics sensorimotor network can flexibly shift reference frames to accommodate for the current task demands.

Traditional talk
Watch now
Alteration of perineuronal net expression in the primary somatosensory cortex during maternal behavior
Dana Layo (she, her, hers)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Dana E. Layo, University of Tennessee Knoxville; Keerthi Krishnan, University of Tennessee Knoxville

Rett Syndrome (RTT) is a neurological disorder caused by mutations in MECP2, a gene expression regulator. RTT is hypothesized to be a sensory processing disorder, which could contribute to the higher-order cognition and social communication phenotypes. How MECP2 deficiency causes sensory processing issues is currently unknown. We use a female mouse model of RTT (Het) to study how MECP2 regulates the timing of experience-dependent plasticity during complex multisensory behaviors, such as the pup gathering paradigm. MECP2 is essential for regulating experience-dependent plasticity, as measured by perineuronal net (PNN) expression, in the auditory cortex during pup gathering. PNNs are extracellular matrix structures surrounding parvalbumin + GABAergic neurons in the cortex, and regulate their synaptic activity. Since efficient pup gathering behavior requires auditory, olfactory and somatosensory cues, we chose to look at PNN expression within the primary somatosensory cortex (SS1). We found that adult Hets perform the pup gathering behavior poorly and show an increase in PNN density within SS1 before (Naïve) and after (Sur) behavioral experience. This suggests that adult NaiveHets are unable to process tactile information causing their poor behavioral performance. By time course analysis, we found that adolescent Naïve Hets had similar PNN density to Naïve WT. Interestingly, adolescent SurHets still performed poorly in the pup gathering paradigm. Through whole brain immunohistochemical analysis of the SS1 in adolescent SurHets, we found 1) PNN density is increased in the SS1of SurHet in specific subregions and 2) the pattern of PNN density alterations in the adolescent and adult SS1 SurHet is different. This shows that, regardless of age, MECP2 is needed in SS1 to regulate the timing of PNN formation, during a complex sensory behavior. Overall, experience-dependent plasticity in the auditory and primary somatosensory cortex is dysregulated in the MECP2-Het mutant resulting in poor execution of a social communication paradigm.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Preferential subspace identification (PSID) for modeling behaviorally relevant neural dynamics
Omid Sani
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Hamidreza Abbaspourazad, University of Southern California; Yan Wong, New York University; Bijan Pesaran, New York University; Maryam Shanechi, University of Southern California

In addition to any specific behavior of interest, neural activity often relates to other brain functions as well as brain states with distributed representations such as thirst. Dissociating these behaviorally irrelevant neural dynamics from the behaviorally relevant ones is key in understanding how neural dynamics explain behavior. We develop a novel algorithm termed PSID for dissociating and modeling behaviorally relevant neural dynamics. PSID models the temporal structure of neural activity in terms of a latent brain state that dissociates the behaviorally relevant dynamics from other dynamics. First, with extensive numerical simulations, we show that PSID learns behaviorally relevant neural dynamics much more accurately, using orders of magnitude less training data and latent states with fewer dimensions. Next, we use PSID to study motor cortical dynamics in two non-human primates performing 3D reach-return movements toward targets while all joint angles in their upper-extremity were being tracked. PSID reveals that behaviorally relevant neural dynamics are markedly lower dimensional than implied by standard methods. In addition, PSID uncovers distinct rotational dynamics in neural activity during reach and return movements that are missed by standard methods and are significantly more predictive of behavior. Moreover, PSID learns more accurate behaviorally relevant dynamics from almost all recording channels and for almost all joints. Finally, to show that the benefit of PSID is due to its novel two-stage learning algorithm that considers both neural activity and behavior and can dissociate behaviorally relevant dynamics, we compare the results with example nonlinear modeling methods and find that PSID more accurately learns the behaviorally relevant neural dynamics. Taken together, PSID provides a new tool for studying and modeling behaviorally relevant neural dynamics that can otherwise be missed. PSID also serves as a dynamic dimension reduction method that can preserve behaviorally relevant neural dynamics. Finally, PSID can also be used to model shared dynamics between any two signals, e.g. neural activity in two brain regions.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Understanding muscarinic-mediated signaling in astrocytes using DREADDs for the control of neuroinflammation and cognition
Alycia Crooks
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
A. Hogan-Cann, Program in Neuroscience, Schulich School of Medicine & Dentistry, University of Western Ontario, London, ON and Translational Neuroscience Group, Robarts Research Institute, University of Western Ontario, London, ON; L. Saksida, Department of Physiology and Pharmacology, Schulich School of Medicine & Dentistry, University of Western Ontario, London, ON and Brain and Mind Institute, University of Western Ontario, London, ON; T. Bussey Department of Physiology and Pharmacology, Schulich School of Medicine & Dentistry, University of Western Ontario, London, ON and Brain and Mind Institute, University of Western Ontario, London, ON; M. Prado, Program in Neuroscience, Department of Physiology and Pharmacology, Department of Anatomy and Cell Biology, Schulich School of Medicine & Dentistry, University of Western Ontario, London, ON and Translational Neuroscience Group, Robarts Research Institute, University of Western Ontario, London, ON; V. Prado, Program in Neuroscience, Department of Physiology and Pharmacology, Department of Anatomy and Cell Biology, Schulich School of Medicine & Dentistry, University of Western Ontario, London, ON and Translational Neuroscience Group, Robarts Research Institute, University of Western Ontario, London, ON

In Alzheimer’s disease (AD), the loss of cholinergic neurons appears to drive degeneration in affected brain areas. Increasing evidence reinforces a strong relationship between cholinergic failure, neurodegeneration, and cognitive deficits in AD. With aging, glial cells release pro-inflammatory cytokines that contribute to age-related neurodegeneration and deficits in brain function. Astrocytes play important roles in cognition and modulation of neuroinflammation, but their role in AD remains unknown. Recent observations suggest that cholinergic signaling, via acetylcholine, regulates cognitive processing and hippocampal function, partially by signaling in astrocytes. Signaling via the Gq protein-coupled M3-muscarinic acetylcholine receptor (M3Gq), known to elevate intracellular Ca2+ concentration, to astrocytes can trigger the release of glial modulators favoring hippocampal plasticity. Conversely, Gi protein-coupled M4-muscarinic acetylcholine receptor (M4Gi) signaling in astrocytes impairs remote memory recall and decreases brain activity. We hypothesize that activating muscarinic receptors modulates astrocyte activity and leads to changes in neuroinflammation and cognition. Our objectives are to determine whether we can modulate muscarinic G-protein signaling specifically in astrocytes, to determine the baseline effect of astrocyte muscarinic signaling activation on behavior and cytokine expression and to determine if this signaling plays a role in AD. We generated mice expressing either Gq(hM3Dq) or Gi(hM4Di) Designer Receptors Exclusively Activated by Designer Drugs (DREADDs). These DREADDs are mutated receptors that longer respond to their endogenous ligand acetylcholine but are instead activated by Clozapine N-Oxide (CNO). We have confirmed that in both hM3Dq and hM4Di mice, DREADDs are expressed specifically in astrocytes. Activation of hM3Dq in cultured primary astrocytes, by CNO, increased intracellular Ca2+. Activation of global astrocyte Gi or Gq receptors do not show significant changes in motor activity or anxiety-like behavior. Future experiments will observe cognitive function tasks using touchscreen technology with acute and chronic activation of hM3Dq or hM4Di receptors and determine whether this signaling can regulate neuroinflammation.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Age and stimulus type influence the association between multi-voxel threat representations and explicit memory during generalization
Dana Glenn
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Dana E. Glenn, Department of Psychology, University of California, Riverside; Megan A. K. Peters, Department of Cognitive Sciences, University of California, Irvine; Daniel S. Pine, Emotion and Development Branch, National Institute of Mental Health; Kalina J. Michalska, Department of Psychology, University of California, Riverside

Aberrations in threat generalization may contribute to childhood anxiety. However, few studies have examined threat generalization across development and no developmental studies have compared generalization gradients for social vs nonsocial threat. We used representational similarity analysis and fMRI to assess developmental differences in the association between neural threat representations and explicit memory across social and non-social stimuli.
Twenty adults (Mage = 25.8) and 16 youth (Mage = 14.1) completed one social and one nonsocial threat conditioning and extinction-recall paradigm. During conditioning, the social paradigm paired a woman’s face with a scream and the nonsocial paradigm paired a colored bell with an aversive alarm. Three weeks later, during extinction recall, participants viewed the threat cue (CS+), safety cue (CS-), and generalization stimuli consisting of CS-/CS+ blends. Multi-voxel BOLD patterns were measured in five ROIs (vmPFC, dmPFC, anterior insula, dACC, amygdala) and representational dissimilarity matrices (RDMs) were created for each subject in each ROI and condition. Individuals’ RDMs were correlated with memory ratings matrices, averaged within each age group and paradigm.
A repeated-measures ANOVA revealed a Task x ROI x Age interaction, F(4,136) = 4.47, p = .002. Follow-up t-tests found a higher correlation between both youth and adults’ anterior insular activity patterns and memory ratings in the social than nonsocial task (ps < .002). Additionally, adults’ neural activity was more correlated with memory ratings for the social than nonsocial task in the dmPFC and vmPFC (ps < .004). Finally, youth’s dACC activity was more correlated with memory ratings for the social than nonsocial task, t(15) = 3.61, p = .003.
These findings indicate that salience of social threats may contribute to greater correspondence between neural activity and memory ratings across age groups. Further, whereas adults may rely on PFC to make categorical distinctions between threat and safety, adolescents may engage salience network structures.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
A common error creates competition between parallel sensorimotor learning systems
Scott Albert
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jihoon Jang; Adrian Haith; Gonzalo Lerner; Valeria Della-Maggiore; John W. Krakauer; Reza Shadmehr

During sensorimotor adaptation, the brain can rely on two separate learning systems: an intentional explicit system that responds to instructions, and an implicit system that is largely unconscious. However, it is unclear whether these putative systems learn independently from separate kinds of error, or compete to learn from the same error. Here, we mathematically express these two possibilities and consider their diverging predictions. When we test these predictions, we find that implicit and explicit systems share a common error; increases in explicit strategy siphon error away from the implicit system, thus impairing its learning. This negative interaction can mask changes in implicit learning such as savings and interference, that can be unveiled by suppressing explicit strategy. Together, the data suggest that in most cases, implicit and explicit systems are in competition to learn from a single error: task outcome. Cases that violate this rule suggest a second error source that also drives implicit adaptation, but leads to competition between two implicit learning modules. Altogether, the data show that patterns of implicit adaptation are shaped by competition between parallel learning systems.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Neural Signature of Subjective Confidence in Perceptual Decision Making
Wei Dou
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jason Samaha

Drift diffusion models propose that decisions are formed by continuously accumulating sensory information. Once the accumulated evidence reaches a boundary, a decision is made. Stronger evidence is accumulated faster and reaches the decision boundary quicker. According to some proposals, confidence in the accuracy of a decision depends on the same accumulated evidence underlying the choice. The central parietal positivity (CPP) component of the human event-related potential (ERP) has been demonstrated to encode accumulated evidence for a decision, like the ramping activity found in the parietal cortex of monkeys during evidence accumulation. As the buildup rate of the CPP indicates how quickly evidence is accumulated, it would be reasonable to expect that the CPP indexes confidence. In this study, we examined how evidence strength influences subjective reports of confidence in observers’ perceptual decisions and how the CPP changes with different levels of evidence strength and confidence. Electroencephalographic (EEG) recordings were measured while participants (n=25) performed a two-alternative dot-motion discrimination task with six motion coherence levels. Consistent with previous research, we found that the buildup rate of the CPP increased with stronger evidence and faster responses, indicating the build-to-bound dynamic of a decision variable. More interestingly, the buildup rate scaled with the confidence rating on the decision, suggesting that evidence accumulation in the brain (i.e. CPP) is tightly linked to the subjective perceptual experience of the sensory information favoring the decision. Further analysis showed that the response-aligned CPP ramped up faster for higher confidence when holding motion coherence constant. We conclude that, independent of the influence of objective evidence strength,
CPP reflects subjective confidence.
Traditional talk
Watch now
The Role of Methyl CpG Binding Protein 2 in Inhibitory Cortical Interneurons for Processing Ultrasonic Vocalizations
Deborah Rupert
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Stephen Shea, PhD

Background: Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) and Rett Syndrome (RTT) are characterized by impaired communication. RTT is a pervasive, neurodevelopmental disorder previously classified as an ASD and caused by loss of function mutations in the X-linked gene methyl CpG binding protein 2 (MeCP2)- a ubiquitously expressed transcription factor critical for maintaining mature neuronal synapses.

Objectives: Our goal is to determine the contribution of cell-type specific Mecp2 mutation to disruptions of auditory cortical circuitry and plasticity that degrade social vocal perception in a mouse model of Rett syndrome.

Methods: To achieve this goal, we will use a cell-type restricted Mecp2 mutant mouse model in combination with a behavioral paradigm that relies on vocal communication. We employ pup retrieval in response to ultrasonic vocalizations (USVs)- a natural, auditory-dependent, learned maternal behavior that we report to be impaired by Mecp2 mutation. USVs emitted by isolated infant pups are high-pitched distress calls that trigger a retrieval response in wild-type (WT) but not non-conditional, Mecp2 heterozygous females. Our previous work suggests that this difference is the result of impaired plasticity in the auditory cortex (ACtx) of Mecp2 mutant animals, a brain region required to detect and interpret vocalizations. ACtx inhibitory interneurons seem to be especially important for processing of socially relevant stimuli (e.g. USVs). Here we build on these findings by selectively inhibiting transcription of Mecp2 protein in specific subclasses of inhibitory interneurons (i.e. parvalbumin-, somatostatin-, and vasoactive intestinal peptide- positive populations) to determine which of these subclasses contributes most toward aberrant auditory processing in the context of our Rett mouse model.

Results: We examine the effects of restricted Mecp2 mutation in inhibitory interneuron subclasses on pup retrieval behavior and in vivo neural circuit activity in the ACtx in response to socially relevant auditory stimuli. We have found Mecp2 mutation restricted to the parvalbumin positive (PV+) cell type is sufficient for impairing pup retrieval behavior. Further, we have found ACtx neuronal activity in response to pup vocalizations are altered in “PV-Mecp2” mutants compared to WT controls similarly to findings from our cell-type non-specific model. These neuronal activity differences are specific to socially relevant sounds (i.e. USVs) as opposed to pure tones.

Conclusions: This work focuses on functional consequences of Mecp2 mutation to auditory processing circuitry that expands our understanding of the underlying etiology of RTT, identifies targets for ameliorating the downstream consequences, and informs pathophysiological mechanisms underlying neurodevelopmental disorders more broadly.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Representation learning for neural population activity with Neural Data Transformers
Joel Ye
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Chethan Pandarinath, Emory University and Georgia Institute of Technology

Neural populations are theorized to have an underlying dynamical structure which drives the evolution of population activity over time. This structure can be explicitly modeled with recurrent neural networks (RNNs), leading to state of the art modeling methods such as latent factor analysis via dynamical systems (LFADS).

However, explicitly modeling a recurrent state can require sequential processing of recorded activity, slowing real-time applications such as brain-computer interfaces or closed-loop control of network states. Here we introduce the Neural Data Transformer (NDT), a non-recurrent alternative. Its non-recurrence enables 3ms inference, comfortably within the loop time of real-time applications. In contrast, common LFADS inference times exceed 24 ms.

Though the NDT lacks an explicit dynamics model, it can still predict dynamical activity. We first evaluate the NDT on large synthetic datasets (i.e. an order of magnitude larger than real-world data) with autonomous dynamics of varying complexity. Here, the NDT accurately infers neural firing rates with performance that matches LFADS (i.e., within 1% R2). Further, we develop an NDT variant that better models non-autonomous dynamics. When tested on firing rate inference of synthetic data with unpredictable perturbations, the NDT achieves 0.73 R2, approaching the 0.83 R2 of LFADS. Finally, to test performance in smaller real-world datasets, we apply the NDT to motor cortical data from a monkey performing a reaching task. We show that the NDT uncovers representations that enable behavioral decoding within 15% of the performance achieved by LFADS, outperforming spike-smoothing.

Though the NDT’s speed and competent accuracy is already useful, the NDT is a forward-looking proposal. Transformers have attracted much attention in deep learning communities for their ability to scale to larger datasets and longer timescales than RNNs. We anticipate that new recording technologies, along with dataset standardization and aggregation, will further improve the NDT’s performance and applicability.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Chrna5 is essential for a rapid and protected response to optogenetic release of endogenous acetylcholine in prefrontal cortex
Sridevi Venkatesan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Evelyn K Lambe, Department of Physiology, University of Toronto

Optimal attention performance requires cholinergic modulation of corticothalamic neurons in the prefrontal cortex. These pyramidal cells express specialized nicotinic acetylcholine receptors containing the alpha5 subunit encoded by the Chrna5 gene. Disruption of this gene impairs attention, but the advantage alpha5 confers on endogenous cholinergic signaling is unknown. To ascertain this underlying mechanism, we used optogenetics to stimulate cholinergic afferents in prefrontal cortex brain slices from compound-transgenic wild-type and Chrna5 knock-out mice of both sexes. These electrophysiological experiments identify that Chrna5 is critical for the rapid onset of the postsynaptic cholinergic response. Loss of alpha5 slows cholinergic excitation and delays its peak, and these effects are observed in two different optogenetic mouse lines. Disruption of Chrna5 does not otherwise perturb the magnitude of the response, which remains strongly mediated by nicotinic receptors and tightly controlled by autoinhibition via muscarinic M2 recep- tors. However, when conditions are altered to promote sustained cholinergic receptor stimulation, it becomes evident that alpha5 also works to protect nicotinic responses against desensitization. Rescuing Chrna5 disruption thus presents the double challenge of improving the onset of nicotinic signaling without triggering desensitization. Here, we identify that an agonist for the unorthodox alpha4-alpha4 nicotinic binding site can allosterically enhance the cholinergic pathway considered vital for attention. Treatment with NS9283 restores the rapid onset of the postsynaptic cholinergic response without triggering desensitization. Together, this work demonstrates the advantages of speed and resilience that Chrna5 confers on endogenous cholinergic signaling, defining a critical window of interest for cue detection and attentional processing.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Reward-biased transitive inference task in rhesus macaques.
Allain-Thibeault FERHAT
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Allain-Thibeault Ferhat, Dept. of Neuroscience, Columbia University; Greg Jensen, ,Dept. of Neuroscience, Columbia University;Herbert Terrace, ,Dept. of Neuroscience, Columbia University; Vincent P. Ferrera,Dept. of Neuroscience, Columbia University;

If we know that person A is taller than person B, and B is taller than C, we can infer that A is taller than C. Such deduction is called a transitive inference (TI) and refers to the learning of novel relationships between pairs or groups of items that are implied by pairwise comparisons, whether they be verbal or non-verbal.
Numerous animal studies have revealed that all vertebrates tested to date display the ability to make transitive inferences. This ability is thought to be fundamental to understanding ordered sets such as social hierarchies. Consensus has not yet been reached whether TI task performance depends on model-free or model-based learning mechanisms, or a combination of both.
In traditional TI paradigms, subjects are presented a single list of ~7 items per session. Here, to test the mechanism behind TI task, we trained monkeys using two ordered lists of five items (images A to E) with reward disparity. Each training trial presented a pair of items and the earlier item (e.g. B from BC) was always the correct response. However, correct responses to List 1 were associated with 2 units of rewards, while List 2 was associated with 5 units of rewards. Once monkeys had learned both training lists (e.g. B1C1), they were tested with between-list adjacent (B1C2) and non-adjacent (B1D2) pairs. On the one hand, we found a powerful bias for items from List 2, consistent with a preference for items that had been paired with larger rewards during training. On the other hand, however, we also found that rewards did not entirely determine preference, with monkeys able to respond above chance overall, once the reward bias had been accounted for. This suggests that both model-based and model-free learning contribute to performance on TI tasks.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Classification of Successful Sensorimotor Adaptation in Locomotion
Carly Sombric
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Carly Sombric, University of Pittsburgh; Rayid Ghani, Carnegie Mellon University; Gelsy Torres-Oviedo, University of Pittsburgh

Introduction: Split-belt walking could serve as an intervention to correct hemiparetic gait due to brain lesions, such as stroke. However, not all participants respond similarly to the same split-belt protocol and it is unclear how to tailor the split-belt training for a given individual. Thus, there is a basic science and clinical interest to predict if a given protocol will be successful for a specific subject.

Methods: We applied classification algorithms on an assembled large dataset (N=690 samples) of split-belt experiments to identify subject demographics (e.g., age, BMI, etc.) and protocol details (e.g., length of training, walking speed, etc.) strongly influencing whether a specific protocol would result in “good” or “poor” sensorimotor adaptation for a given individual. A numerical approach was taken where many classifiers were trained and tested (e.g., logistic regression, random forest, etc.) on different subsets of the database with different model parameters. Performance metrics were computed (e.g., precision, recall, etc.) for each classifier type, subset of the data, and parameters for the classifier. For the performance metrics mentioned, a value closer to one indicates better classification performance than a value closer to zero.

Results: The best and most robust classifiers (e.g., consistent and high performance across different subsets of the data) had acceptably good performance as indicated by an average classification accuracy of 85% (average precision = 0.93, average recall = 0.81). Of the features used, baseline gait asymmetry (even for non-clinical subjects) and belt speed difference, rather than belt speed ratio, were identified as important for predicting a protocol’s success.

Conclusion: This work suggests that machine learning tools could be used to guide subject-specific rehabilitation interventions. The results of this work provide basic science and clinical insight into what aspects of split-belt gait training are important for different populations to successfully learn a new walking pattern.
