How thalamic network properties shape sensory development.
Matt Colonnese 		Keynote Event
Watch now
Elucidating brain mechanisms for the context-dependent control of vocal communication
Katie Tschida
Traditional talk
Watch now
A spatial developmental generative model of human brain structural connectivity
Stuart Oldham
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ben Fulcher, The University of Sydney; Kevin Aquino, Monash University; Aurina Arnatkevičiūtė, Monash University; Rosita Shishegar, Monash University; Alex Fornito, Monash University

The complex wiring of the human connectome is thought to support integrated brain function and adaptive behaviour. Yet the mechanisms leading to the emergence of this connectome topology are unknown. Generative network models have begun to shed light on these mechanisms by showing that stochastic wiring rules, subject to simple constraints based on a trade-off between the wiring cost and putative functional value of a connection, can reproduce many key topological features of empirical connectome data. However, recent evidence suggest that they may not accurately capture the way in which these properties are spatially embedded. One potential reason for this limitation is that current models assume a fixed geometry based on the adult brain, ignoring the major changes in shape and size that occur early in development, when connections form. Here, we propose a new generative network model that proposes a new cost-value trade-off formulation, and which can readily incorporate developmental changes in brain geometry, informed by structural MRIs obtained from a public database of foetal scans acquired from 21–38 weeks gestational age. Using a cross-validated procedure to fit these models to connectomes generated from 100 healthy adults with diffusion MRI, we show that our new model more accurately reproduces the topological properties of empirical data than existing models, but that developmental changes in brain shape and size do not lead to major gains in model fit. Critically, none of the models accurately capture the spatial embedding of network topology, being unable to reproduce the observed spatial topography of hubs. Our results suggest that generative models based on stochastic wiring rules can capture statistical properties of brain networks, but that they may be insufficient to comprehensively explain the way in which these properties are spatially embedded.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The Massive Report Paradigm: Assessing the richness of conscious visual experience
Regan Gallagher
 
Abstract
 
To most of us, our experience of the world seems extremely rich in detail. However, some researchers claim this feeling of richness is an illusion. We developed several tasks to estimate the richness of perceptual experiences based on information theory, in an approach we call the “Massive Report” paradigm. First, we simply showed participants (in lab N=10, in MTurk N>600) a brief glimpse (SOA=67, 133 or 267ms before being masked) of one natural scene picture (we used 580 images in total) and asked for 5 nouns/adjectives/verbs that describe the scene. Second, we compiled a large pool of descriptors for the set of images as potential “alternatives” and performed classical discrimination tasks with confidence ratings. The novelty of the paradigm is that we interrogated the phenomenology associated with a single image with a “massive” set of questions (between 20 and 80640 questions per image). The results of these experiments suggest that subjects can discriminate a huge repertoire of scene characteristics; in information theoretic terms, the bandwidth of differentiation measures at > 1500 bits per second (compared to previous estimates of <40 bits per second). Our results suggest that a moment of experience is much richer than previously considered.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Analyzing Network Connectivity in Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage with MRI
Casey Weiner
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Dr. Sarah Nelson, Johns Hopkins Hospital; Dr. Robert Stevens, Johns Hopkins Hospital

Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (aSAH) is a life-threatening form of stroke wherein an aneurysm ruptures, causing bleeding into the subarachnoid space, and for which prognosis is still difficult to predict. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can provide rich data on anatomical and physiological processes in the brain. In our project, we aim to compare the structural and functional connectomes of aSAH patients, generated from Diffusion Tensor Imaging (DTI) and functional MRI (fMRI), respectively, with those of healthy controls. We hypothesize that structural and functional connectivity, including networks that are necessary for consciousness and other critical processes of the brain, are altered in patients as compared to controls. Further, we hope to show that our DTI and fMRI data improve prognostication in aSAH.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The metaperceptual function: Exploring dissociations between confidence and task performance with type 2 psychometric curves
Olenka Graham Castaneda (she/hers)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Brian Maniscalco, Department of Cognitive Sciences, University of California Irvine; Olenka Graham Castaneda, Department of Cognitive Sciences, University of California Irvine; Brian Odegaard, Department of Psychology, University of Florida; Jorge Morales, Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences, Johns Hopkins University ; Sivananda Rajananda, Department of Bioengineering, University of California Riverside; Megan A. K. Peters, Department of Cognitive Sciences, University of California Irvine

Reports of confidence do not always correlate with perceptual accuracy. This dissociation suggests that distinct computational and neural processes underlie these functions. Recent investigations have therefore sought to experimentally isolate metacognitive processes by creating conditions where perceptual sensitivity is matched but confidence differs (“matched-performance / different-confidence”; MPDC). Although MPDC has been successfully implemented in recent studies, much remains unknown about its underlying causes or how to best induce these effects in experimental settings. Here we developed a principled approach to comprehensively characterizing MPDC effects through analyzing metaperceptual (i.e., type 2 psychometric) functions relating objective performance to subjective confidence across widely varying performance levels and experimental manipulations. We found that MPDC effect magnitude depends on stimulus properties, observers’ sensitivity level, and critically on trial type order (blocked or interleaved across stimulus property variations). Our findings provide the first comprehensive exploration of MPDC effects, offer a prescriptive guide to quantitative metaperceptual analysis, and suggest optimal experimental paradigms for experimentally isolating metacognition and awareness in future studies.
Traditional talk
Watch now
o8t Labs: An automated, machine-learning based approach to personalized brain mapping and functional connectomics.
Peter Nicholas
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Hugh Taylor, Omniscient Neurotechnology; Stephane Doyen, Omniscient Neurotechnology

With growing concern of a forthcoming reproducibility crisis in how MRI data is analyzed, it is paramount that a gold-standard of statistical practice is realized so that accurate comparisons can be made between studies investigating brain topology and function. Machine-learning models offer an easily accessible solution to generating reproducible and scalable data in the segmentation and statistical analysis of the brain’s complex neural structure.

“Connectomics” refers to the investigation of how brain networks communicate within and between one other, with the end goal of ascribing function and identifying irregularities in the wiring of healthy and pathological brain states, respectively.

To combat the challenges presented with the time taken and standardization steps required when processing large-scale data sets, we have developed a new multimodal image processing pipeline: o8t Labs. Labs utilizes machine-learning and cloud computing to offer a standardized and streamlined approach to performing structural and functional connectomic analyses.

Requiring an anatomical T1, resting-state fMRI and DTI image series, Labs first performs constrained spherical deconvolution (CSD) to generate a structural connectivity of the brains white matter tracts. Through the application of machine learning models, we are then able to re-parcellate regions derived from the HCP Atlas onto realigned resting-state image series, creating an individualized brain atlas for further analyses. Functional connectomic analysis is then performed, correlating BOLD signal change at rest between each parcellation of the loaded subject’s brain. These correlations are compared against a bank of 250 healthy controls to determine typical and atypical functional connectivity.

Multiple exports are currently available in Labs including processed image series, a structural atlas (delivered in NIFTI), as well as structural and functional connectivity matrices. The intention of these exports is for simplified re-integration into other analytic workflows.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Online assessments of Word-Predictability: a feasible alternative to in-lab research
Lena Peroni (She/Her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Bruno Bianchi, Laboratorio de Inteligencia Artificial Aplicada, Instituto de Ciencias de la Computación, FCEyN, UBA - CONICET; Diego E Shalom, Departamento de Física, FCEyN, UBA; Juan E Kamienkowski ,Laboratorio de Inteligencia Artificial Aplicada, Instituto de Ciencias de la Computación, FCEyN, UBA - CONICET,Departamento de Física, FCEyN, UBA

Recently, the use of web platforms for massive experiments has been rapidly growing. Online experiments allow to increase the number of participants to partake in the experiment, improving the quality of some measures. Also, using social media platforms one is able to reach people from several demographics making these results more diverse, and thus more representative. In order to understand how internal processes of the mind and external stimuli play together in the generation of action, reading may serve as an ideal paradigm since it requires language, reasoning and memory processes, to orchestrate the task. When we read printed text, we are continuously predicting upcoming words to integrate information and decide when and where we are going to move our eyes. The Predictability of each word can be estimated with a Cloze-Task Experiment. In it subjects have to read an incomplete text and guess the missing words given the preceding context. We studied whether online Cloze-Tasks could replicate in-lab ones, or even improve them as the sample size could be increased. In three experiments involving different corpora and online and in-lab setups, we observed that the online Cloze-Task replicates the results from the in-lab one and that the results were consistent between independent online experiments. Also, we showed that word-Predictability is highly dependent on large contexts, i.e. if the sentence is embedded in a story or not. Thus, online Cloze-Task could ease the collection for larger samples, generating robust and more precise measures.Recently, the use of web platforms for massive experiments has been rapidly growing. Online experiments allow to increase the number of participants to partake in the experiment, improving the quality of some measures. Also, using social media platforms one is able to reach people from several demographics making these results more diverse, and thus more representative. In order to understand how internal processes of the mind and external stimuli play together in the generation of action, reading may serve as an ideal paradigm since it requires language, reasoning and memory processes, to orchestrate the task. When we read printed text, we are continuously predicting upcoming words to integrate information and decide when and where we are going to move our eyes. The Predictability of each word can be estimated with a Cloze-Task Experiment. In it subjects have to read an incomplete text and guess the missing words given the preceding context. We studied whether online Cloze-Tasks could replicate in-lab ones, or even improve them as the sample size could be increased. In three experiments involving different corpora and online and in-lab setups, we observed that the online Cloze-Task replicates the results from the in-lab one and that the results were consistent between independent online experiments. Also, we showed that word-Predictability is highly dependent on large contexts, i.e. if the sentence is embedded in a story or not. Thus, online Cloze-Task could ease the collection for larger samples, generating robust and more precise measures.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Synaptic scaling requires a balance between stability, efficiency, and accuracy in realistic neuron morphologies
Adriano Bellotti
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Adriano Bellotti, University of Cambridge; Saeed Aljaberi, University of Cambridge; Fulvio Forni, University of Cambridge; Timothy O’Leary, University of Cambridge;

Synaptic scaling is a homeostatic normalization mechanism that preserves relative synaptic strengths by adjusting them with a common factor. This multiplicative change is believed to be critical, since synaptic strengths are involved in learning and memory retention. Further, this homeostatic process is thought to be crucial for neuronal stability, playing a stabilizing role in otherwise runaway Hebbian plasticity. Synaptic scaling requires a mechanism to sense total neuron activity and globally adjust synapses to achieve some activity set-point. This process is relatively slow, which places limits on its ability to stabilize network activity. We show that this slow response is inevitable in realistic neuronal morphologies. Furthermore, we reveal that global scaling can in fact be a source of instability unless responsiveness or scaling accuracy are sacrificed.

A neuron with tens of thousands of synapses must regulate its own excitability to compensate for changes in input. The time requirement for global feedback can introduce critical phase lags in a neuron’s response to perturbation. Realization of the phase lag instability requires a unified model of synaptic scaling, regulation, and transport. We present such a model with global and local feedback in realistic neuron morphologies. This combined model shows that neurons face a tradeoff between stability, accuracy, and efficiency. Global feedback is required for synaptic scaling but favors either system stability or efficiency. Large receptor pools improve scaling accuracy in large morphologies but worsen both stability and efficiency. Local feedback improves the stability-efficiency tradeoff at the cost of scaling accuracy. This project introduces unexplored constraints on neuron size, morphology, and synaptic scaling. We describe the interplay between global and local feedback mechanisms required to balance accurate synaptic scaling with neuron stability.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Genetic link between impaired homeostatic plasticity and neurodevelopmental disorders
Ozgur Genc
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Graeme Davis, UCSF; Stephan Sanders, UCSF; Joon An, Korea University; Richard Fetter, UCSF, Giulia Zunino, UCSF; Yelena Kulik, UCSF

Homeostatic plasticity is an evolutionarily conserved form of neuromodulation. It has been hypothesized that loss of homeostatic plasticity will make the nervous system more susceptible to disease. But, this has yet to be clearly demonstrated, particularly with respect to the homeostatic modulation of synaptic function in the central nervous system and brain disorders. To address this fundamental question, I use different model organisms (fly, mouse and IPSc-derived neurons) and combine genetic screening, electrophysiological and transcriptomic analysis methods. With this approach, I recently identified a novel class of autism-gene modifiers causing homeostatic plasticity to fail. This defines a model, where de novo risk mutations impair the robustness of neuronal activity when combined with the modifier mutations lurked in the genetic background. This validated approach helps us identify new genetic and molecular mechanisms, thereby providing a new framework for advancing our understanding of neurogenetic diseases.
It seems plausible that restoring the buffering capacity of homeostatic plasticity could be broadly relevant to the treatment of neurological disorders of any genetic origin. In the central nervous system, several neurological disorders such as Parkinson’s, manifest impaired neuronal function before the onset of the neuronal degeneration. Thus, this is an important stage when neurons cope with genetic and environmental insults by engaging homeostatic protective mechanisms, thereby maintaining the functional well-being. Using mammalian models, my current and future research aims to generate mechanistic insights on how homeostatic plasticity is compromised in neurological disorders including neurodegenerative diseases, stroke and neurovascular abnormalities. With this information, I hope to develop interventional strategies that will boost the homeostatic capacity of the brain to stabilize the neuron and circuit function.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Synaptic Scaling of Excitatory Post Synaptic firings in Hippocampal Neurons.
Yerram Pooja Chowdary
 
Abstract
 
Synaptic plasticity provides the basis for modeling of learning, memory, and development in neural circuits. Information is stored in neural circuits through long-standing changes in synaptic strengths. Most studies of information storage have focused on mechanisms such as long-term potentiation and depression (LTP and LTD), in which synaptic strength changes in a synapse-specific manner. In contrast, little attention has been paid to molecular mechanisms that regulate the local synaptic signaling, postsynaptic firing, or large-scale changes in network activity which are required to induce synaptic scaling. In cultures of dissociated rat hippocampal neurons persistent potentiation, and depression of glutamatergic synapses were induced by correlated spiking of postsynaptic neurons. Chronic blockade of hippocampal culture activity increased the amplitude of excitatory postsynaptic currents (EPSCs) without changing their kinetics. Conversely, blocking GABA (γ-aminobutyric acid) mediated inhibition initially raised firing rates, but over 48 hours ESPC amplitudes decreased and firing rates returned to close to control values. These changes were partly due to postsynaptic alterations in the response to glutamate and affected each synapse in proportion to its initial strength. Here, we selectively block postsynaptic firing in individual neurons while optically monitoring changes in synaptic strength. Such synaptic scaling may help to ensure that it is rapidly induced by a block of postsynaptic firing, but not by the local synaptic blockade. Hippocampal neurons thus homeostatically adjust synaptic strengths in response to changes in their own firing rate, a mechanism with the computational advantage of efficiently normalizing synaptic strengths without interfering with synapse-specific mechanisms of information storage.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Alcohol addiction and Co-Morbid Adult Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder their correlation with Cardiac, Autonomic and Cognitive behavioral Response
K Mrudula
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Mrudula, Dr. TN Sathyaprabha, Dr. Kaviraja Udupa, Dr. Arun Kandasamy, Dr. Jamuna Rajeshwaran

Background and Rationale: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a childhood
neurodevelopmental disorder which has a relation with development of substance use disorders in
adulthood. Physiological link and cognitive correlations between the two disorders may involves the
common network activities of the central autonomic network and frontal cortex. Hence there is a
need for further research on the correlation between the cardiac, cognitive and behavioral
parameters.
Materials and Methods: This is a pilot study which is a part of PhD Study titled “Evaluation of
Neurobiological correlates in men with co morbid alcohol use disorder and adult ADHD” and here are
preliminary results. 16 Study subjects (males and aged 18-50 years) admitted to deaddiction
department of NIMHANS were divided into 2 groups with 8 subjects in each group: Alcohol use
disorder (AUD) with/without comorbid Adult ADHD (AUD+AADHD) and compared with Healthy
controls from hospital staff and students of NIMHANS. Study groups were subjected to
Echocardiography, Conventional autonomic function tests, Pupillometry, Go No Go task, stop signal
task and paired pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation paradigms.
Results: AUD and AUD+AADHD groups showed moderate to severe cardiac autonomic dysfunction,
decreased values in parasympathetic activity, end systolic volume, decreased reaction time implying
more impulsivity. Increased sample size might provide some hints on the correlation links between
various neurobiological measures like cardiac Autonomic & Neurobehavioral dysfunction between
Alcohol addiction & Adult ADHD compared to healthy controls.
Conclusion: Our study demonstrates the importance of neurobiological measures that exist between
ADHD and substance use disorders and subsequent need of comprehensive study-based diagnosis for
improvement of their quality of life.
Keywords: ADHD, Alcohol, TMS, stop signal task, Go No Go task, Heart rate variability, Autonomic
functions.
Ethics statement: The experimental protocols were approved by the institutional human ethics
committee, NIMHANS, Bengaluru.
Acknowledgements: I thank NIMHANS institutional fellowship for providing me financial support for
conducting my research.
Conflicts of interest: No
Traditional talk
Watch now
Potentiation and Sequestration of Lipid Profile and Oxidative Stress in CdCl2 Mediated Neurotoxicity; Two Sides of Palm Oil Fractions
Patrick Ichipi-Ifukor
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Samuel Ogheneovo Asagba

Objective: This study was to determine if pretreatment with palm oil fractions could mitigate against sub-chronic cadmium mediated oxidative stress and lipid profile in the brain.
Design: The experimental study comprised six groups A-F. Rats in group A served as the normal control and received normal feed and water only, group B negative control received CdCl2 only. Test groups (C-F) received 5ml/Kg body weight of appropriate palm oil fractions: Crude Palm oil (CPO), Silica Gel Extract (SGE), Bleached Palm Oil (BPE), and Unsaponifiable Extract (UPE) from day 1-21 respectively. This was followed by sub-chronic exposure to 5mg/kg bodyweight CdCl2 through gavage to rats in groups B-F from day 22-43. Six rats from each group were sacrificed and the brain tissues excised for oxidative stress indices and lipid profile on days 29 and 43 of the experiment.
Results: Findings indicates significant rise of brain lipid peroxidation in experimental groups relative to control. Comparatively, CPO, SGE, and BPE increased brain MDA levels and reduced SOD and catalase enzyme activities compared to those that received only CdCl¬2. Sulphite oxidase enzyme was significantly reduced in test groups relative to control. Our study also demonstrated a significant increase in brain GSH in animals that received UPE compared to control. Brain lipid profile showed a significant rise in total cholesterol and LDL-cholesterol, a significant reduction in triglyceride and HDL-cholesterol in CdCl2, CPO, SGE, BPE groups. UPE mediated a reverse in the order of lipid profile observed in other palm oil fractions relative to control.
Conclusion: Palm oil fractions (CPO, SGE, and BPE) pre-administration potentiated brain oxidative stress indices, brain (total cholesterol, LDL-cholesterol) and reduced HDL-cholesterol and triglyceride in a sub-chronic CdCl2 toxicity. UPE, on the other hand, sequestered brain increase of total cholesterol and LDL-cholesterol while promoting activities of selected antioxidant defense markers in the brain.
