In parallel, more and more neuroscience-related data — and particularly metadata — are being made available under open licenses, which facilitates discoverability, reproducibility and reuse, as well as data integration.

Wikidata is a community-curated open knowledge base in which concepts covered in any Wikipedia — and beyond — can be described in a structured and FAIR fashion that can be mapped to RDF and queried using SPARQL as well as various other means. Its community of over 20,000 monthly contributors oversees a corpus of currently over 90 million 'items’ for concepts that are linked amongst each other, to external databases or to specific values via over 7000 'properties'. Items and properties have persistent unique identifiers, to which labels, descriptions and dedicated lexemes and their forms and senses can be attached in over 300 natural languages.

A range of open-source tools is available to interact with Wikidata — to enter information, curate and query it. In this presentation — which shall be available via https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.4064274 — we will outline a range of tools that allow to explore Wikidata content through frontends tailored to specific communities. Based on examples from the neurosciences, we will take a look at Scholia — available via https://scholia.toolforge.org/ — which allows to generate and explore Wikidata-based scholarly profiles of research topics, authors, institutions, funders and other parts of the research ecosystem, as well as of the world in which it is embedded.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Interhemispheric communication during haptic self-perception
Gaiqing Kong
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Gaiqing Kong, UCL Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience, UK; Miruna Nitu, UCL Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience, UK; Antonio Cataldo, Institute of Philosophy, University of London, UK; Hiroaki Gomi, NTT Communication Science Laboratories, Japan; Patrick Haggard, UCL Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience, UK.

When people move their finger across a planar surface, a slight resistance that decreases movement velocity is illusorily perceived as a bump on the surface. If the surface touched is one’s own skin, a bump should also increase the pressure from the finger to the skin surface. Participants made two movements of the right hand while holding a haptic force-control robot. Resistances were added to both, and participants judged “which movement felt more bumpy; first or second?”. The movements were transferred to a second, slave robot, delivering but task-irrelevant stroking touch to the left forearm. The slave robot briefly increased or decreased tactile pressure in synchrony with right hand velocity decrease, consistent with encountering bumps, or holes respectively (blocked factor), during self-touch. We investigated whether left tactile events changes would bias judgement of the bump size perceived with the right hand. Left tactile pressure increases and decreases both increased bump size perceived by the right hand. Tactile information was thus transferred inter-hemispherically, but the sign of tactile information was not respected. In experiment 2, randomising (rather than blocking) tactile pressure increases/decreases abolished these biases. Inter-hemispheric transfer during self-touch is based on consistent models of synchronized events, but omits geometric object information.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
The importance of BCL-XL in the onset of cognitive deficits associated to 22q11 deletion syndrome
Eva Cristina de Oliveira Figueiredo
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tamara Zehnder Dep. of Fundamental Neurosciences, UNIL, Lausanne, Switzerland; Anthony Laugeray, Dep. of Fundamental Neurosciences, UNIL, Lausanne, Switzerland; Denise Gastaldo, Dep. of Fundamental Neurosciences, UNIL, Lausanne, Switzerland; Tommy L. Lewis, Dep. of Neuroscience, Mortimer B. Zuckerman MBB inst.; Kavil Inst. For Brain Science, USA; Daniela Rossi, Maugeri Foundation, UNIPV, Pavia, Italy; Fulvio Magara, CPN, CHUV, Lausanne, Switzerland; Joseph Gogos, Dep. of Physiology and Cellular Biophysics, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, New York, USA; Claudia Bagni, Dep. of Fundamental Neurosciences, UNIL, Lausanne, Switzerland; Manuel Mameli, Dep. of Fundamental Neurosciences, UNIL, Lausanne, Switzerland; Franck Polleux, Dep. of Neuroscience, Mortimer B. Zuckerman MBB inst.; Kavil Inst. For Brain Science, USA; Paola Bezzi, Dep. of Fundamental Neurosciences, UNIL, Lausanne, Switzerland and Dep of Physiology and Pharmacology, Univ. La Sapienza, Rome, Italy

22q11 deletion syndrome (DS) is a syndrome characterized by structural abnormalities in dendrites maturation and spines formation and by behavioral and cognitive deficits (Karayiorgou et al., 2010). Among the genes deleted in the 22q11, six encode for mitochondrial proteins. Here, we examined mitochondrial genes expression in brain tissues of LgDel mice, a mouse model of 22q11DS (Meechan et al., 2009), and found that, among other mitochondrial-related genes, Bcl-Xl was specifically downregulated in cortical tissues and not in hippocampal tissues. We thus checked whether the decreased levels of Bcl-Xl could have a role in the neuroanatomical abnormalities associated to 22q11DS. At first, we analysed the mitochondrial distribution and the morphology of neurons in vivo by labelling single cells with a plasmid expressing a cytoplasmic fluorescent protein (mTAGBFP2) and a mitochondrial matrix-targeted fluorescent protein (mt-YFP) with IUE. Morphometric analysis of these parameters revealed remarkable differences between the LgDel and control mice. Then, we chronically treated LgDel mice with a biologically active peptide consisting of a domain of BCL-XL fused to the protein transduction domain of the HIV-TAT protein and found a significant rescue of mitochondrial phenotypes and a consistent improvement of the dendritic and spine abnormalities. Finally, the beneficial effect of TAT peptide was confirmed on cognitive deficits of LgDel mice.
Support contributed: SNFS NCCR “Synapsy” (51NF40-158776) and SNFS (26074366) to PB.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
A Bayesian map of the striatal microciruitry reveals different wiring processes for D1 and D2 spiny projection neurons
Francois Cinotti
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Mark Humphries, University of Nottingham

Serving as input region of the basal ganglia, a set of interconnected midbrain structures thought to determine action selection, the striatum is mainly made up of spiny projection neurons (SPNs) which fall into two main categories based on the expression of either D1-type dopamine receptors or D2-type dopamine receptors. These distinct neuronal populations project into two different pathways towards the globus pallidus, but also make lateral connections which could constitute feedback inhibition of the circuit. In addition, interneurons in the striatum also connect to these SPNs. This complex microcircuitry is often overlooked in models of the basal ganglia which typically adopt a simple feedforward view of striatal function, when in fact, the connections between SPNs in the striatum could be crucial in determining their output to the globus pallidus. Fortunately for modellers, experimental studies to characterize these connections have been conducted and it seems that D1 neurons make fewer connections than D2 neurons and prefer to connect to other D2 neurons. However, the robustness of these results is undermined by the fact that when reporting these findings, experimenters failed to provide an estimate of the measurement error. We take the opportunity of correcting this oversight to introduce a novel Bayesian approach for estimating and comparing probabilities of connection. This method allows us to easily combine different data sets from different studies, to plug in the results of previous experiments in the form of a Bayesian prior, and to easily compare connection probabilities visually. By applying this method to two previous experimental studies, we find that D1 neurons do indeed form fewer connections than D2 neurons, but that evidence for preferential targeting by D1 neurons of other D1 neurons is currently lacking. We then go on to propose a method for extracting the probability of connection given distance between neurons.
Traditional talk
Watch now
What is the cerebral cortex? A perspective from reptiles and amphibians
Maria Antonietta Tosches
 
Abstract
 
Vertebrates emerged more than 500 million years ago, and colonized water, land and air. Despite their diverse life histories, vertebrates share the same overall brain architecture, which is established during early embryonic development. Are correspondences, or homologies, extending beyond coarse brain regions, to the level of cell types and circuits? To address this question, we are studying cell types in the telencephalon, a brain region where the dramatic expansion of neuronal diversity in evolution is associated to morphological and functional novelties. We used single-cell transcriptomics to identify cell types in the simple three-layered cortex of reptiles, the sister group of mammals, and we are starting new work on an amphibian, the Spanish ribbed newt Pleurodeles waltl. Our quantitative comparison of single-cell transcriptomes across species sheds new light on the evolution of the mammalian six-layered neocortex. The transcriptomic signature of glutamatergic neurons in non-mammals suggests that mammalian neocortical layers are made of new cell types generated by diversification of ancestral gene-regulatory programs. By contrast, we find that the transcriptomes of cortical GABAergic neurons are conserved to an exquisite detail, suggesting that developmental or functional constraints shape the evolution of these cell types.
Interactive talk
Watch now
The hippocampus promotes formation of long-term memory for objects in rats by preventing sensory interference after learning
Isabelle Groves
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Daisy Arkell, University of Edinburgh, Centre for Discovery Brain Sciences and Simons Initiative for the Developing Brain; Emma Wood, University of Edinburgh, Centre for Discovery Brain Sciences and Simons Initiative for the Developing Brain; Oliver Hardt, McGill University, Patrick Wild Centre and Simons Initiative for the Developing Brain

Damage to the medial temporal lobe, notably the hippocampus, often leads to anterograde amnesia for declarative memories, but it remains unresolved how this deficit arises. Addressing this issue, we have proposed in our active decay theory that the hippocampus supports long-term memory formation by protecting against ongoing sensory stimulation which interferes with the stabilisation of newly formed content representations residing in extra-hippocampal areas. Efficient pattern separation within the hippocampus is predicted to promote resistance to interference and representation overlap. Thus, without a functioning hippocampus, ongoing sensory stimulation will lead to states of catastrophic interference in these brain regions, manifesting behaviourally as anterograde amnesia. Here, we report our results testing this hypothesis with an object recognition task in rats as a model for human declarative memories. Importantly, expression of long-term object recognition memory requires the perirhinal cortex, not the hippocampus in rats. We found (1) that inactivating hippocampus prior to object learning with intrahippocampal injections of GABAA and -B agonists (muscimol+baclofen) impaired object recognition tested 24 h after learning. (2) This deficit was absent when we placed rats into a highly familiar dark chamber right after object learning to reduce sensory stimulation during the memory stabilization period. Our findings support our theoretical model and suggest that anterograde amnesia due to hippocampal damage arises from heightened vulnerability to interference from ongoing sensory stimulation during phases of memory stabilization.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
De-noising EMG using dynamical systems models of muscle population activity
Lahiru Wimalasena
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jonas F. Braun, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, Technical University of Munich; Mohammad Reza Keshtkaran, Emory University and Georgia Tech; Juan Alvaro-Gallego, Imperial College of London, Northwestern University; Cristiano Alessandro, University of Pavia, Northwestern University; Matthew C. Tresch, Northwestern University; Lee E. Miller, Northwestern University; Chethan Pandarinath, Emory University and Georgia Tech

Precise coordination of the activity of groups of muscles is critical for motor function. However, a major barrier to understanding how the brain coordinates muscle activation is that recordings of electromyographic (EMG) activity from muscles are a noisy measure of muscle activation, making them difficult to evaluate on a moment-to-moment basis. The standard approach to processing EMG (i.e., rectification and smoothing) treats high frequency features in EMG signals as noise. Here, we describe dynamically-estimated EMG (deEMG), a method to de-noise EMG signals recorded simultaneously from multiple muscles. Our working model is that, during movement, the coordinated activity of muscles is the output of an underlying dynamical system, and that accurately modeling these dynamics using recurrent neural networks might substantially de-noise EMG, while preserving any complex, high-frequency components that are present in multiple muscles. We tested deEMG using intramuscular EMG recorded from 12 muscles from two model systems: (1) rat hindlimb muscles during locomotion and (2) monkey forearm muscles during an isometric center-out wrist force task. deEMG had significant advantages over standard smoothing. When applied to the rat data, the model’s nonlinear filtering properties produced single-trial representations of muscle activity that improved decoding of joint kinematics and preserved behaviorally-linked, high frequency EMG features that are suppressed by linear filters. Similarly, when applied to the monkey data, deEMG enabled more accurate prediction of measured forces and was substantially more informative about simultaneously-recorded motor cortical activity, suggesting that deEMG-inferred representations better reflect descending cortical commands. Additionally, deEMG revealed unexpected high frequency oscillations that correlated with oscillations in the recorded force data but were not apparent after standard smoothing. Ultimately, this method opens new avenues to studying the coordination of multiple muscles and their precise control by upstream brain areas.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Neuroscience education from home: Challenges and opportunities
Benjamin Silver
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Benjamin M. Silver, Department of Psychology, Columbia University; Diana H. Li, Zuckerman Institute, Columbia University; Alyssa Mayers, Zuckerman Institute, Columbia University; Paula L. Croxson, Zuckerman Institute, Columbia University

Despite the growing popularity of neuroscience, courses with significant neuroscience components are not part of most high school curricula. In addition, providing high school students with research experience can complement classroom learning, and is particularly helpful for underrepresented groups. The COVID-19 pandemic, and the transition to virtual learning that has accompanied it, presents unique challenges as well as opportunities for neuroscience education initiatives. At Columbia University’s Zuckerman Institute, our summer high school internship program, BRAINYAC (Brain Research Apprenticeships in New York at Columbia), was upended this past March by COVID-19, forcing us to migrate our teaching online and to assess the efficacy of the program in a virtual context. While the difficulties of virtual education are clear, virtual learning has also been touted as a solution to making quality education more accessible. As neuroscience researchers and educators, it is essential that we collectively take a critical look at our practices in this moment so we can continue to provide high school students with rigorous and engaging neuroscience curricula. In an interactive talk, we will discuss how we pivoted a hands-on, lab-based program to a purely virtual format that utilized both synchronous virtual teaching and asynchronous resources and projects focused on multimedia science communication, computational skills, and community building. We will also provide a forum for others who facilitate neuroscience education initiatives to share their own experiences. Some discussion points we will pose to others include the challenges faced in both the abrupt transition to online learning and online learning itself, as well as how virtual teaching presents an opportunity to make neuroscience education more engaging and accessible than it was before.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Emotional Metacognition: Stimulus Valence Modulates Cardiac Arousal and Metamemory
Sebastian Engen
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Nicolas Legrand; Camile Correa; Nanna Kildahl Mathiasen; Niia Nikolova; Francesca Fardo; Micah Allen

Emotion alters how we feel, see, and experience the world. In the domain of memory, the emotional valence and arousal of memorized stimuli can modulate both the acuity and content of episodic recall. However, no experiment has investigated whether arousal and valence also influence metacognition for memory (i.e., the process of self-monitoring memories). In a pre-registered study, we applied a novel psychophysiological design together with computational models of metacognition to assess the influence of stimulus valence and arousal on the sensitivity, bias, and efficiency of metamemory. To estimate the role of physiological arousal in mediating these effects, we recorded cardiac measures through pulse oximetry. We found that negative valence globally and substantially decreased both memory performance and subjective confidence, in particular for low-arousal words. Simultaneously, we found that emotional valence modulated both heart rate and heart-rate variability (HRV), indicating a robust effect of negative valence on physiological arousal during recognition memory. Exploratory trial-level analyses further revealed that subjective confidence was encoded in instantaneous heart-rate fluctuations, and that this relationship was modulated by emotional valence. Our results demonstrate that both recognition memory and metacognition are influenced by the emotional contents of encoded items and that this correlation is in part related to cardiac activity.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Role of long-range inhibitory neurons in cortical circuits
Jacob Ratliff
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Renata Batista-Brito

Background: Cortical activity is highly dependent on behavioral state of an animal with different states, such as sleep and wake, having profound impact on cognition and cortical processing. Despite its importance, the circuitry responsible for sensing behavioral state and modifying cortical states remains unknown. However, recent work suggests inhibitory neurons (INs) are likely involved in this regulation. While most inhibitory neurons are locally projecting, there is an IN subtype, defined by the co-expression of somatostatin (SST) and neuronal nitric oxide synthase (nNOS), that arborizes densely over large cortical areas. Here, we test the hypothesis that SST/nNOS cells play a crucial role in the generation of low frequency oscillations, a hallmark of multiple cortical states.

Results: Using a state-of-the-art set of intersectional genetic tools, we perform a variety of characterizations of SST/nNOS cells, to examine their afferent and efferent connectivity. We fluorescently label SST/nNOS cell processes using a membrane bound fluorophore to characterize output arborizations. We found that SST/nNOS cells have dense local connectivity and long-range projections in ipsi- and contralateral cortex. We also examine inputs to SST/nNOS cells utilizing monosynaptic rabies tracing finding rich local input from excitatory and inhibitory cells.
We compliment these experiments with in vivo extracellular electrophysiology paired with optogenetic manipulation of SST/nNOS cells in order to causally test the role of SST/nNOS cells towards network activity. Excitation of these cells preferentially induces low frequency oscillations while optogenetic inhibition specifically suppresses 1-3Hz oscillations. Similarly to endogenous oscillations, induced low frequency oscillations coincide with decreased gamma power, increased single unit phase locking to 1-3 Hz oscillations, and a current source density laminar profile characteristic of endogenous low frequency oscillations.

Conclusion: Together this set of experiments strongly suggest a role for SST/nNOS cells in the regulation of physiological low frequency oscillations across large cortical areas though the precise spatial scale is unknown.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Distinct prefrontal top-down circuits differentially modulate sensorimotor behavior
Rafiq Huda
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Rafiq Huda, Grayson O. Sipe, Vincent Breton-Provencher, K. Guadalupe Cruz, Gerald N. Pho, Elie Adam, Liadan M. Gunter, Austin Sullins, Ian R. Wickersham & Mriganka Sur

Sensorimotor behaviors require processing of behaviorally relevant sensory cues and the ability to select appropriate responses from a vast behavioral repertoire. Modulation by the prefrontal cortex (PFC) is thought to be key for both processes, but the precise role of specific circuits remains unclear. We examined the sensorimotor function of anatomically distinct outputs from a subdivision of the mouse PFC, the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC). Using a visually guided two-choice behavioral paradigm with multiple cue-response mappings, we dissociated the sensory and motor response components of sensorimotor control. Projection-specific two-photon calcium imaging and optogenetic manipulations show that ACC outputs to the superior colliculus, a key midbrain structure for response selection, principally coordinate specific motor responses. Importantly, ACC outputs exert control by reducing the innate response bias of the superior colliculus. In contrast, ACC outputs to the visual cortex facilitate sensory processing of visual cues. Our results ascribe motor and sensory roles to ACC projections to the superior colliculus and the visual cortex and demonstrate a circuit motif for PFC function wherein anatomically non-overlapping output pathways coordinate complementary but distinct aspects of visual sensorimotor behavior.
Traditional talk
Watch now
FootSim: Modeling tactile responses from the sole of the foot
Rodrigo Siqueira de Souza
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Rodrigo Kazu Siqueira, Department of Psychology & Sheffield Robotics, University of Sheffield, UK; Natalija Katic, University of Belgrade, Serbia; Leah R. Bent, Department of Human Health and Nutritional Sciences, University of Guelph, Ontario, Canada ; Nicholas D.J. Strzalkowski, Department of Biology, Mount Royal University, Calgary AB, Canada; Stanisa Raspopovic, Department of Health Sciences and Technology, ETH Zurich, Switzerland; Hannes P. Saal, Department of Psychology & Sheffield Robotics, University of Sheffield, UK

Cutaneous feedback from the foot sole is crucial for balance control and gait, but how relevant information is encoded in neural afferent populations during these behaviours is mostly unknown. Electrophysiological data can be obtained in humans but is limited to single afferents and passive stimulation. Here, we present a computational model that simulates neural spiking responses from a full population of mechanoreceptive afferents innervating the sole of the foot. Our work takes into account the unique mechanics of the skin tissue in the foot (including depth and hardness) and includes all afferent classes (both slowly and rapidly adapting) that signal skin indentation, slip, vibration, and stretch. Single-unit recordings of human afferent responses were used for validation and fitting of the model. We find that simulated afferent firing thresholds, as well as supra-threshold firing rates, match their empirical counterparts well. As a proof-of-concept, we then used the model to recreate neural population responses during walking, based on empirical data of the spatiotemporal pressure distribution on the foot sole. The model predicts sharp rises in neural activity during the initial contact phase as well as during lift-off and suggests that these are spatially constrained and differentially activate different receptor types. The model will help understand tactile feedback during gait and can be employed to reconstruct neural activity for use in prosthetic devices through direct neural interfaces with the lower limb nerves.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Development of Hearing in Neonatal Rats: Cortical Responses to Air- and Bone-Conducted Sound.
Roman Makarov
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Mikhail Sintsov, Laboratory of Neurobiology Kazan Federal University Kazan Russia; Guzel Valeeva, Laboratory of Neurobiology Kazan Federal University Kazan Russia; Pavel Starikov, MIPT The School of Electronics Photonics and Molecular Physics Moscow Russia; Dmitriy Negrov, MIPT The School of Electronics Photonics and Molecular Physics Moscow Russia; Roustem Khazipov, Laboratory of Neurobiology Kazan Federal University Kazan Russia and INMED INSERM UMR1249 Aix-Marseille University Marseille France;

In rats, sensitivity to environmental sounds emerges at around P11-13. However, morphological studies suggest that for a few days before that, the hearing function is constrained mainly by the immaturity of structures responsible for sound conduction. In accordance with that, it was shown that the bone-conducted (BC) sounds, which bypass the immature outer and middle ear, can evoke auditory brainstem responses already from P7. Whether these early responses reach the auditory cortex, and what are their spatio-temporal features remain largely unknown. Using epidural uECoG arrays and intracortical silicone probes, we showed that, starting from P8, responses evoked by the BC-sound involve thalamus-mediated activation of the auditory cortex. The evoked potentials had the initial positive and the following negative peaks, the latencies and amplitudes of which significantly changed with age. These responses largely overlapped with the responses evoked by electrical stimulation of the cochlea and the inferior colliculus as well as with the responses to normal intensity air-conducted sound (70 dB) after the onset of hearing (>P13). Topographic mapping revealed that BC-evoked responses co-localize with high-frequency sound representations in the auditory cortex. In addition, we showed that BC-evoked responses can be eliminated by bilateral cochlear ablation. We also found that similar cortical responses to the airborne stimuli of high intensity (>100 dB) can be evoked starting from P8, suggesting that the onset of sensory function highly depends on the sound conduction. Our main finding is that the earliest responses evoked by BC and high-intensity airborne stimuli reach the auditory cortex and undergo significant improvement over the second postnatal week. We suggest that this stimulus-evoked activity can potentially cooperate with spontaneous activity in the formation of auditory circuits during the pre-hearing period. Besides that, our study reveals remarkable similarities in the major developmental milestones of the auditory and visual systems.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Functional and Transcriptomic Diversity of Interneurons in the Hippocampal CA3 Region Probed by Patch-Seq
Daniel Müller-Komorowska (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Erick Martinez Chavez, Institute of Reconstructive Neurobiology, University of Bonn School of Medicine & University Hospital Bonn, Germany; Sandra Blaess, Institute of Reconstructive Neurobiology, University of Bonn School of Medicine & University Hospital Bonn, Bonn, Germany; Heinz Beck, Institute for Experimental Epileptology and Cognition Research, University of Bonn, Germany

Most mammalian brain regions contain diverse sets of GABAergic interneurons. These are essential in orchestrating the activity of principal neurons. Interneurons can be subclassified based on anatomical, physiological, and molecular features. In recent years, the advent of single-cell RNA-Seq has vastly expanded our knowledge of interneuron diversity regarding their transcriptional signatures. However, connecting transcriptomics with functional properties has remained challenging. The patch-seq technique quantifies electrical and transcriptomic features of the same single cell. While it lacks the high throughput of single-cell RNA-Seq, it permits direct correlation of molecular and functional properties.
We have used patch-seq in hippocampal CA3, a brain region involved in learning and memory, where GABAergic neurons are centrally involved in generating behaviorally relevant oscillations. We first measured the electrophysiological firing properties of CA3 interneurons and have subsequently sequenced the transcriptome from the same interneuron. We show that this approach can lead to the identification of novel interneuron types. We also discuss how this approach can be used to build more biologically realistic computational models of CA3. Ultimately this data could be used to model biologically plausible interneuron diversity and its functional roles.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Pattern Separation performance and hippocampal neurogenesis in aged female rats
Martina Canatelli Mallat
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Priscila Chiavellini, INIBIOLP; Marianne Lehmann, INIBIOLP; Rodolfo G. Goya, INIBIOLP; Gustavo R. Morel, INIBIOLP

Aging is associated with impaired performance in behavioral pattern separation (PS) tasks based on similarities in object features and in object location. Hippocampal dentate gyrus (DG) neurogenesis plays an important role in PS. In order to evaluate the effect of aging on discrimination of overlapping memories of object location or features, we assessed three groups of Sprague-Dawley rats: Young (Y, 4-5 mo., n=25), Middle-Aged (MA, 18 mo., n=32), and Senile (S, 28 mo., n=13). Spontaneous Location Recognition (SLR) and Spontaneous Object Recognition (SOR) were assessed in the three age groups. The testing chambers for SLR and SOR were black circular and white triangular arenas, respectively. Morphometric analysis revealed a significant age-related reduction in doublecortin (DCX) cell number and diameter in the DG. In the SLR, the discriminatory performance was markedly deteriorated in the MA and S rats as compared with Y rats. In the SOR, S rats presented deterioration in memory disambiguation but MA rats showed a preserved memory as compared with Y rats. Our findings reveal the existence of a significant vulnerability of DCX neurons to age in rats and deficient object location discrimination, likely related to deficient DG neurogenesis. Furthermore, the overlapping memories involving object location are more sensitive to age than overlapping memories involving features. A possible explanation for this observation is that the process of discriminating memories related to features is under the control of another pattern separator node, possibly the Prh, which is less affected by age. Our next goal is to study this region to evaluate the differences between the age groups in it.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Identifying Human Postural Dynamics and Control from Unperturbed Balance
Jongwoo Lee
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kuangen Zhang, University of British Columbia; Neville Hogan, Massachusetts Institute of Technology

Upright standing requires control of an inherently unstable multi-joint human body within a small base of support, despite biological motor and / or sensory noise which challenge balance. Without applying perturbations, system identification methods have been regarded as inadequate, because the relevant internal biological noise processes are not accessible to direct measurement. As a result, unperturbed balance studies have been limited to investigation of subjects' behavioral response patterns rather than possible underlying control strategies.
In this work, we present a mathematically rigorous system identification method that is applicable to study the dynamics and control of unperturbed balance. The method is derived from autocorrelation matrices with non-zero time lags and identifies the system matrix of a discrete-time dynamic system in the presence of unknown noise processes, without requiring any information about the strength of the noise.
Unlike reasonable `least-squares' approaches, the performance of the new method is consistent across a range of different combinations of internal and measurement noise strengths, even when measurement noise is substantial. We present a numerical example of a model that simulates human upright balancing and show that its dynamics can be identified accurately. With a biomechanically reasonable choice of state and input variables, a state feedback controller can also be identified.
Our numerical results indicate that the system identification method proposed in this work is applicable to real-world experimental data. Using this method, the dynamics and control of human quiet standing can be studied in depth without concern for adaptation or possible reflex responses evoked by external perturbations, or any need for expensive high-precision measurement equipment. This may enable diagnosis and treatment of individual subjects with impaired balance, and the development of safe and effective assistive and / or rehabilitative technologies.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Neuroscientific investigation of police perception, cognition, and behaviour
Paula Di Nota (she, her, hers)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Judith P. Andersen, University of Toronto

Police and other law enforcement personnel are tasked with serving and protecting our communities. As a result, officers are routinely exposed to uncertain, unpredictable, and potentially violent encounters. Resulting physiological stress responses have a pervasive influence on all aspects of police work and bear significant consequences on the health and safety of both officers and the public. An understanding of the neurophysiological mechanisms underlying these errors in perception, judgement, and behaviour is lacking in the response to countless examples of excessive use of force by police. Through our investigations of these mechanisms, we have contributed to a growing body of research that supports evidence-based use of force training and practices. In this interactive talk, we will begin by synthesizing the current state-of-the-art on neurophysiological investigations of perception, cognition, and behaviour among police populations. Relevant research topics include: situational awareness (i.e., sensory perception, attention, threat assessment, prediction); memory (i.e., encoding, consolidation, retrieval); decision-making (e.g., shoot/no-shoot); and skilled motor performance. We will also briefly discuss practical challenges to conducting empirical research in applied police settings, and the fine balance between maintaining experimental control and ecological validity. We invite feedback from attendees in a wide range of disciplines to stimulate an active yet focused discussion. Through this discourse, we hope to identify important gaps in knowledge, future areas of inquiry, and innovative methodological approaches. The insights yielded during this talk and from the research discussed will also highlight the broader impacts of applied neuroscientific police research on health, policy, and society.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Spatiotemporal Dynamics of Mesoscale activity in Sensory Cortex
Fatemeh Nematollahzadeh
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Mehdi Adibi, Sayed Jalal zahabi, Ehsan Yazdian

Synchrony in the activity of neuronal circuits is one of the topics of interest in modern systems neuroscience. The Spatiotemporal dynamics of the synchrony in the spontaneous activity at different scales may carry information about the organization, circuitry of neuronal populations as well as the local processes and function of these circuits.
Here, to quantify the extent to which the dynamics of synchronous spontaneous activity predicts the neuroanatomical structure, we recorded local field potentials (LFP) and spiking activity of cluster of neurons in the somatosensory cortex of anesthetized rats in using a 10x10 microelectrode array.
We did the experiments on the somatosensory cortex of awake and anesthetized rodents (rats and mice). We calculated different measures of within and cross-frequency coupling (in terms of phase-phase, phase-amplitude, amplitude-amplitude coupling) in frequency bands of interest (<0.1 Hz, δ, θ, α, β, γ) between pairs of electrodes. We observed a gradual decrease in the strength of coupling with the distance between electrodes, especially at higher frequencies. Specifically, while the decline was not so evident for <0.1 Hz and δ band, where the couplings varied insignificantly with distance, it became more profound for higher frequencies.
A multidimensional scaling analysis (MDS) on the strength of couplings revealed the spontaneous activity predicts the position of electrodes. Applying machine learning based on T-distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (t-SNE) lead to similar findings.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Cognitive switches and prefrontal gating of flexible sensory processing
Abhishek Banerjee
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Abhishek Banerjee, Newcastle University; Giuseppe Parente, University of Zurich; Jasper Teutsch, Newcastle University; Christopher Lewis, University of Zurich; Fritjof Helmchen, University of Zurich

Adaptive behaviour crucially depends on flexible decision-making, which in mammals relies on frontal cortex, specifically the orbitofrontal cortex (OFC). How OFC encodes decision variables and instructs sensory areas to guide adaptive behaviour are key open questions. Here we developed a reversal learning task for head-fixed mice, monitored the activity of lateral OFC neurons using two-photon calcium imaging, and investigated how OFC dynamically interacts with primary somatosensory cortex (S1). Mice learned to discriminate go/no-go tactile stimuli and adapt their behaviour upon reversal of stimulus–reward contingency (‘rule-switch’). Imaging individual neurons longitudinally across all behavioural phases revealed a distinct engagement of S1 and lateral OFC: whereas S1 neural activity reflected initial task learning, lateral OFC neurons saliently and transiently responded to the rule-switch. Lateral OFC to S1 projections feed this activity as value-prediction error back to S1. This top-down signal updated sensory representations in S1 by functionally remapping responses in a small outcome-selective neuronal subpopulation that was also sensitive to reward history. Functional remapping crucially depended on top-down feedback as chemogenetic silencing of lateral OFC neurons disrupted reversal learning as well as plasticity of S1 neurons. The dynamic interaction of lateral OFC with sensory cortex thus implements history-dependent, prediction error-based computations and plasticity essential for flexible decision-making.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Network Oscillations in Antidepressant Deep Brain Stimulation
Vineet Tiruvadi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Vineet Tiruvadi

Deep brain stimulation (DBS) has shown use in treating severe psychiatric depression but we don't know how it works when it works. Using modern neural recording interfaces we can study short- and long-term oscillatory changes in the brain related to DBS and to depression. I will present empirical work inferring depression severity from chronic neural oscillations and characterizing the immediate effects of DBS on whole-brain network oscillations. I'll then present a separate thread of computational work, consistent with empirical observations, that seeks to model antidepressant DBS as a control-affine system with both predictive and biophysical dynamics. This work provides a clearer view of how (and where) antidepressant DBS changes brain oscillations and sets a data-congruent foundation for more rational clinical improvements.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Hypothalamic Oxytocin Neurons Respond to Infant Vocalizations via Noncanonical Auditory Pathway
Silvana Valtcheva
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Silvana Valtcheva, Habon A. Issa, Robert C. Froemke

Mammalian babies are “sensory traps” for parents. Various sensory cues from the newborn are tremendously efficient in triggering parental responses in caregivers. We recently showed that core aspects of maternal behavior such as pup retrieval in response to infant vocalizations rely on active learning of auditory cues from pups facilitated by the neurohormone oxytocin (OT). Release of OT from the hypothalamus might thus help induce recognition of different infant cues but it is unknown what sensory stimuli can activate OT neurons.
I performed in vivo whole-cell and cell-attached recordings from optically-identified OT neurons in awake dams. I found that OT neurons, but not other hypothalamic cells, increased their firing rate after playback of pup distress vocalizations. Using anatomical tracing approaches and channelrhodopsin-assisted circuit mapping, I identified the projections and brain areas (including inferior colliculus, auditory cortex, and posterior intralaminar thalamus) relaying auditory information about social sounds to OT neurons. In hypothalamic brain slices, when optogenetically stimulating thalamic afferences to mimic high-frequency thalamic discharge, observed in vivo during pup calls playback, I found that thalamic activity led to long-term depression of synaptic inhibition in OT neurons. This was mediated by postsynaptic NMDARs-induced internalization of GABAARs. Therefore, persistent activation of OT neurons following pup calls in vivo is likely mediated by disinhibition. This gain modulation of OT neurons by infant cries, may be important for sustaining motivation. Using a genetically-encoded OT sensor, I demonstrated that pup calls were efficient in triggering OT release in downstream motivational areas. When thalamus projections to hypothalamus were inhibited with chemogenetics, dams exhibited longer latencies to retrieve crying pups, suggesting that the thalamus-hypothalamus noncanonical auditory pathway may be a specific circuit for the detection of social sounds, important for disinhibiting OT neurons, gating OT release in downstream brain areas, and speeding up maternal behavior.
Traditional talk
Watch now
In vivo Perturb-seq: study gene function at scale
Xin Jin
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Xin Jin, Society of Fellows, Harvard University; Sean K. Simmons, Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard; Ashwin S. Shetty, Department of Stem Cell and Regenerative Biology, Harvard University; Joshua Z. Levin, Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard; Aviv Regev, Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, MIT; Feng Zhang, Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, McGovern Institute of Brain Science, MIT; Paola Arlotta, Department of Stem Cell and Regenerative Biology, Harvard University

The number of disease risk genes and loci identified through human genetic studies far outstrips our capacity to systematically study their functions. I will discuss our attempt to develop a scalable genetic screen approach, in vivo Perturb-Seq, and apply this method to the functional evaluation of 35 autism spectrum disorder (ASD) de novo loss-of-function risk genes. Using CRISPR-Cas9, we introduced frameshift mutations in these risk genes in pools, within the developing mouse brain in utero, followed by single-cell RNA sequencing of perturbed cells in the postnatal brain. We identified cell type-specific and evolutionarily conserved gene modules from both neuronal and glial cell classes. Recurrent gene modules and cell types are affected across this cohort of perturbations, representing key cellular effects across sets of ASD/ND risk genes. In vivo Perturb-Seq pilots a systems genetics approach to investigate at scale how diverse mutations affect cell types and states in the developing brain, and can be used in various in vivo and in vitro model organisms and systems.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Mnemonic discrimination and integrity of the hippocampal complex in temporal lobe epilepsy
Alicia Comino (She/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Yasser Alemán-Gómez, Center for Psychiatric Neuroscience Department of Psychiatry Centre Hospitalier Universitaire Vaudois and University of Lausanne (Switzerland)/Department of Radiology Centre Hospitalier Universitaire Vaudois and University of Lausanne (Switzerland)/Medical Image Analysis Laboratory,Centre d’Imagerie BioMedicale Lausanne (Switzerland); Claudia Poch, Department of Basic Psychology University Complutense of Madrid (Spain)/Instituto Pluridisciplinar University Complutense of Madrid (Spain); Rafael Toledano, Epilepsy Unit Neurology Department Hospital Ruber Internacional, Madrid (Spain)/Epilepsy Unit Neurology Department University Hospital of Ramon y Cajal Madrid (Spain); Irene Garcia-Morales, Epilepsy Unit Neurology Department Hospital Ruber Internacional Madrid (Spain)/ Epilepsy Unit Neurology Department University Hospital of San Carlos Madrid (Spain); Ana Prieto, Department of Basic Psychology Autonoma University of Madrid (Spain); Nuria Garcia-Barragán, Epilepsy Unit Neurology Department University Hospital of San Carlos Madrid (Spain); Angel Aledo-Serrano, Epilepsy Unit Neurology Department Hospital Ruber Internacional Madrid (Spain); Antonio Gil-Nagel, Epilepsy Unit Neurology Department Hospital Ruber Internacional Madrid (Spain); Pablo Campo, Department of Basic Psychology Autonoma University of Madrid (Spain).

Pattern separation (PS) is a fundamental aspect of memory creation that defines the ability to transform similar memory representations into distinct ones, so they do not overlap when storing and retrieving them. Experimental evidence in animal models and the study of other human pathologies have demonstrated the role of the hippocampus in PS, in particular of the dentate gyrus (DG) and CA3. Patients with mesial temporal lobe epilepsy with hippocampal sclerosis (mTLE-HE) commonly report mnemonic deficits that have been associated with failures in PS. However, the link between these impairments and the integrity of the hippocampal subfields in these patients has not yet been determined. The aim of this project is to explore the association between the ability to perform mnemonic functions and the integrity of hippocampal CA1, CA3, DG in patients with unilateral mTLE-HE. To reach this goal we evaluated the memory of the patients with an improved object mnemonic similarity test. We then analyzed the hippocampal complex integrity with structural and microstructural diffusion data from high resolution 3T MRI. Our data indicate that patients with unilateral mTLE-HE present more difficulties in the mnemonic discrimination test that target PS, especially in conditions with higher interference. These specific mnemonic deficits would correlate with the integrity of white matter tracts in the subregions DG and CA3 contralateral to the seizure focus and therefore to the main sclerotic damage.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Finger stability in precision grips
Neelima Sharma (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Neelima Sharma, Yale University; Madhusudhan Venkadesan, Yale University

Stable precision grips underlie human hand dexterity. However, multi-link chains like our fingers are inherently prone to the mechanical instability of buckling, where the finger snaps into a hyper-extended posture when applying tip forces. How the neuromuscular control suppresses buckling instabilities in healthy fingers remains unknown. Using experiments and mathematical modeling, we show that human fingers maintain stability by using an open-loop strategy based on muscle stiffness, rather than sensorimotor feedback. In an experiment, we instructed people to maximize their index fingertip's forces in self-selected postures. The occasional buckling events were too fast for neural feedback control to stabilize, suggesting that stable finger postures rely on muscle stiffness. However, using a biomechanical model of the index finger activated by seven muscles, we found that muscle stiffness is also insufficient for stable grips at maximal forces unless we add extra stiffness to stabilize the finger joints. We tested this prediction in 23 subjects. Attaching a stiffening splint to the finger increased the maximal force by 69±14% and total muscle electromyography readings from two flexors by 85±23% compared to the finger without splint (mean±standard error). Therefore, people do not apply their true maximal force unless extra stiffness allows their muscles to apply higher force without compromising stability. We calculated the viable space of muscle activities that satisfy the finger's equilibrium and stability constraints using the biomechanical model. The viable activation patterns lie within a six-dimensional convex hyperplane that is embedded in the seven-dimensional space of normalized muscle activations. Within this viable space, muscle co-contraction could stabilize submaximal but not maximal forces. More stiffness aids stability but compromises compliance, essential for the adaptive grasping of complex objects geometries. Thus, we show how the interaction between finger mechanics and neural control of muscle stiffness affects hand function.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
A Neuroethics Framework for Global Brain Projects and Neurotechnology
Sinem Serap (she/her/hers)
 
Abstract
 
During the last two decades, with the development of technology, the small steps in brain science turned into the giant leap for mankind. Millions of bytes of data generated all over the world to break the brain’s code, to understand inner workings of brain function and hope to find treatments to cognitive diseases. Seven brain initiatives launched around the globe, but no single initiative was able to tackle those challenges. In December 2017, seven initiatives came together and formed International Brain Initiative to combine their effort and accelerate the progress of neurotechnological findings.
Implementing data sharing and standardization mechanism was one of the intents of the initiatives. Human body is known as the biggest data platform but human brain homes to most valuable data. All human behaviour could be understood under the illuminated light of this neurodata. Merging of brain initiatives also brings the question of who will capture this neurodata and how to maintain medical ethics.
Neuroethics could be classified under the umbrella of bioethics but it should also be diverse from the point that our minds are the true representatives of who we are. In this poster I will discuss the neuroethical standards that are proposed by brain initiatives so far and discuss the challenges in neuroethics from the window of neurotechnology and brain-computer interfaces. I aim to recommend some new insights for ethical principles for the effective protection of human subjects.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
I would have found it by now: Metacognitive contributions to search termination
Matan Mazor
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Stephen M. Fleming

When searching for a target object among distractors, a robust finding in cognitive science is that search time varies as a function of the number of distractors and their similarity to the target object. This is true not only for the time taken to say a target is present, but also for the time taken to terminate a search and conclude that a target object is absent. However, while models of visual search have successfully characterized contributions to target detection (such as salience or pop-out), the mechanisms underpinning when to terminate a search and conclude that a target is absent are poorly understood. In other words, when do people decide to give up and conclude that nothing is there? One hypothesis is that efficient search termination involves metacognitive knowledge such as the expected difficulty of the search, target salience, or fluctuations in one’s attentional state. By focusing on the first few trials in a visual search task in a large online sample, here we control participants’ ability to base their search termination on metacognitive knowledge before engaging with the task, and to directly measure the effect of experience on the shaping of this knowledge. In a first pilot experiment (N=181), we find a qualitative change in search termination efficiency before and after experiencing finding a target, in line with a metacognitive learning account.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Collective response of oscillating neuronal population to the applied perturbation: a computational framework
Faeze Aminmansoor
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Alireza Valizadeh, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences (IASBS)

Brain oscillations are hypothesized to modulate the inter-cortical communication and control the integration of information. The signal exchange in such processes relies on the response of the networks to the incoming inputs. Characterizing the network’s response with respect to the timing of input’s arrival, though, is crucial to assess the mechanism of cortical communication. In this study, we introduce a computational framework to investigate the collective response of a network regarding the perturbation phase at which it is received.


The role of inhibitory interneurons in generation of brain oscillations has firmly been established. Accordingly, we used a network of 500 inhibitory Integrate and Fire (IF) neurons and applied a brief perturbation to 10% of population at different phases of the LFP oscillation. The transient changes in the cycle period of subsequent oscillations as well as the change in their amplitudes are documented as a function of the perturbation phase. The resulted characteristic curve is called collective Phase (Amplitude) Response Curves (cPRC & cARC).


cPRC and cARC manifest, despite the fact that IF neuron models are type I and characterized by their phase only being advanced regardless of the phase of perturbation, a network consisting of IF neurons produces a delay in phase followed by an advance followed by a delay, depending on the timing of the perturbation. Furthermore, the amplitude of the subsequent cycle undergoes an increase-decrease-increase cycle of changes in its strength. The model then predicts that applying a perturbation at the early and very late phase of the oscillation gives rise to a transient reduction of LFP frequency while applying that at the middle period of oscillation induces a transient increment in that.


Our results suggest that the collective response of the oscillatory inhibitory networks are almost independent of the properties of the constituent neurons. As the collective response curve determine the efficacy of the communication and the signal exchange between the brain areas, this study can serve as an important step in understanding the mechanisms of inter-cortical communications.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The role of frontal cortex in multisensory decision-making
Philip Coen
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Philip Coen, University College London; Timothy P. Sit, University College London; Miles J. Wells, University College London; Matteo Carandini, University College London; Kenneth D. Harris, University College London

The ability to combine visual and auditory cues to localize objects in space is critical to many organisms, whether prey, predator, or pedestrian crossing the street. Recent studies have shown that the mouse frontal cortex plays a key role in transforming sensory stimuli into appropriate motor actions during decision-making tasks. However, real-world decisions are invariably multisensory. Where is the relevant multimodal information combined in the brain, and are separate modalities independently represented in frontal cortex?

To answer these questions, we trained mice to perform an audiovisual spatial task where animals turn a wheel to indicate whether a stimulus appeared on the left or right. The stimuli can be auditory, visual, or a combination of the two, presented in coherent or conflicting locations. We optogenetically inactivated different spots across dorsal cortex on individual trials while mice performed this task.

We found that auditory and visual primary sensory cortices were both required for the processing of modality-specific sensory information, and that the effect of inactivation in these regions was highly lateralized. Conversely, inactivation of secondary motor cortex (M2) had robust, modality-independent effects on behavior.

To determine whether frontal cortex contains separate representations of both modalities, or a modality-independent representation of the decision process, we recorded neural activity in M2 with Neuropixels probes in behaving mice. In preliminary analyses, we have observed a variety of response patterns, including neurons that are selective for both spatial location and stimulus modality. Overall, our results suggest a key role for M2 in multisensory decisions.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Active probing enhances the extraction of features for predicting seizures in a coupled neural mass model
Vinícius Carvalho
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Márcio F.D. Moraes, Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais; Sydney S. Cash, Massachusetts General Hospital; Eduardo Mazoni A.M. Mendes, Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais

Active probing stimuli may be used to uncover underlying system dynamics that would be otherwise unobservable with passive analysis. The use of such approaches could be a way to tackle the challenging and yet unsolved problem of reliably forecasting the occurrence of seizures. That is, electrographic responses to period stimuli could highlight neuronal excitability and synchrony changes involved in the transition from interictal to ictal activity. In this work, we evaluate this hypothesis in two coupled populations of a commonly used seizure-generating neural mass model. Features are extracted while system parameters are slowly shifted from normal towards ictal activity and different scenarios or model settings are evaluated: low-frequency stimuli are applied to the input of one or both populations, while increasing neuronal excitability gain, decreasing slow inhibitory gain, or increasing inter-population coupling. Results show that the use of probing stimuli provided predictive value, as similar feature changes were observed while model parameters were shifted towards ictal activity. Observed changes such as increased lag-1 autocorrelation and increased variance may be related to the phenomenon of critical slowing. These increased recovery times from perturbations could be indicators of the loss of the system’s resilience and are common hallmarks of impending critical transitions. Overall, our results indicate that low-frequency probing stimuli may play a role in uncovering some of the neuronal dynamics leading up to seizure states and assist in designing accurate and reliable seizure forecasting systems.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Rhythmic synchronous features in cortical neurons of songbirds
Santiago Boari (He/Him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Gabriel B. Mindlin, University of Buenos Aires; Ana Amador, University of Buenos Aires

How vocal communication signals are represented in the cortex is a major challenge for behavioral neuroscience. Beyond a descriptive code, it is relevant to unveil the dynamical mechanism responsible for the neural representation of auditory stimuli. In this work, we report evidence of synchronous neural activity in cortical neurons of canaries (Serinus canaria), in response to auditory playback of the bird’s own song. The rhythmic features of canary song allowed us to show that this synchronization was locked to syllabic repetition rates of song phrases. We recorded neurons in a brain region where sensorimotor integration occurs, showing that these neurons are activated at specific temporal instances during song playback.
Keynote Event
Watch now
Early sharp waves in the neonatal hippocampus
Roustem Khazipov 		Keynote Event
Watch now
Microglia modulate stable wakefulness via thalamic reticular nucleus
Qiaojie Xiong
 
Abstract
 
Microglia are involved with brain homeostasis and immunity, but their role in regulating vigilance remains unclear. We employed genetic, physiological, and metabolomic methods to examine microglial involvement in the regulation of wakefulness and sleep. Microglial depletion decreased stable nighttime wakefulness in mice by increasing transitions between wakefulness and non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. Metabolomic analysis revealed that the diurnal variation of the brain ceramide disappeared in microglia-depleted mice. Ceramide preferentially influenced microglia in the thalamic reticular nucleus (TRN), and local depletion of TRN microglia produced similar impaired wakefulness. Chemogenetic manipulations of anterior TRN neurons showed that they regulated transitions between wakefulness and NREM sleep. Their firing capacity was suppressed by both microglial depletion and added ceramide. In microglia-depleted mice, activating anterior TRN neurons or inhibiting ceramide production both restored stable wakefulness. These findings demonstrate that microglia can modulate stable wakefulness through anterior TRN neurons via ceramide signaling

Genevera Allen

Inhibitory circuits that gate synaptic enhancement in olfactory cortex
Anne-Marie Oswald

Abstract
 
Queer In Neuro will provide a casual open space for LGBTQIA+ researchers in neuro-related fields to 1) meet each other and discuss their personal experiences in science, and 2) brainstorm what they’d like to see from an organization that focuses on LGBTQIA+ experiences in neuroscience.  Traditional talk
Watch now
Developmental dynamics of bottom-up and top-down input integration onto L1 interneurons in the sensory cortex
Leena Ali Ibrahim
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Leena A Ibrahim, Harvard Medical School; Shuhan Huang, Harvard Medical School; Marian Fernandez-Otero, Harvard Medical School; , Emilia Favuzzi, Broad Institute; Bernardo Rudy, New York University; Gord Fishell, Harvard Medical School and Broad Institute

Information processing in a sensory cortex combines ‘bottom-up’ sensory experience, with feedback from higher cortical areas, modulation by subcortical systems, as well as cross-modal modulation by other sensory cortices. These projections jointly create an internal representation used to predict the incoming stimuli and reconcile it with expectation. How such representations emerge during development are not well understood. L1 interneurons (INs) are positioned at the nexus where top-down and bottom-up information converges and thus are likely playing a critical role in this modulation. They receive both strong cortico-cortical inputs from higher cortices, as well as bottom-up thalamic inputs and their inhibitory nature allows them to modulate sensory processing. Retrograde rabies tracing during early postnatal development within primary auditory (A1) and primary visual (V1) cortex, demonstrated that L1 INs receive strong first-order thalamic inputs during early sensory signaling. While these persist into adulthood, they become diminished. We hypothesize that the dominant bottom up input is important for establishing and refining long range top-down inputs (such as from the Anterior Cingulate Cortex, ACA, Premotor Cortex, M2 and Retrosplenial Cortex, RSP) onto L1 INs. Our in-vitro patch clamp data suggests that L1 interneurons in A1 and V1 receive functional inputs from the first-order thalamus; MGBv and dLGN respectively, and some of those inputs are mirrored in L4. By simultaneously providing L1 interneurons with both ascending sensory inputs, as well as cortico-cortical feedback inputs, accurate sensory processing and modulation in L2/3 can be established. Through this process the projections from the ACA/M2 which are initially abundant but weak are refined and strengthened. As this occurs precisely during the period when thalamic inputs are decreased, we posit that these two events are functionally coordinated. Additionally, our preliminary data suggests that sensory experience is necessary for the strengthening and refinement of these cortical top down inputs. We thus predict that bottom-up inputs to L1 interneurons during development are important for the establishment of cortico-cortical feedback circuitry.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Cerebellar nuclei evolved by repeatedly duplicating a conserved cell-type set
Justus Kebschull
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Justus M Kebschull, Stanford University; Noam Ringach, Stanford University; Ethan B Richman, Stanford University; Drew Friedmann, Stanford University; Sai Saroja Kolluru, Chan Zuckerberg Biohub; Robert C Jones, Stanford University; William E Allen, Harvard Univeristy; Ying Wang, UC Davis; Huaijun Zhou, UC Davis; Seung Woo Cho, Stanford University; Howard Y Chang, HHMI and Stanford University; Karl Deisseroth, HHMI and Stanford University; Stephen R Quake, Chan Zuckerberg Biohub and Stanford University; Liqun Luo, HHMI and Stanford University;

How have complex brain regions, circuits, and cell types evolved from simple origins? Here we investigate brain region evolution at cell-type resolution in the cerebellar nuclei, the output structures of the cerebellum. We applied single-nucleus RNA sequencing in chickens, mice, and humans, STARmap spatial transcriptomic analysis in chicken and mice, and whole-CNS projection mapping in mice. Our work revealed a conserved cell type set containing three classes of region-invariant inhibitory neurons and two classes of region-specific excitatory neurons. This cell type set forms an archetypal cerebellar nucleus that was repeatedly duplicated to create new regions. In excitatory neurons, duplication was accompanied by divergence in gene expression and shifts in projection patterns (neofunctionalization). By contrast, inhibitory neurons maintained their gene expression signatures (isofunctionalization). Interestingly, the excitatory cell class that preferentially funnels information to lateral frontal cortices in mice becomes predominant in the massively expanded human Lateral CN. Our data provide the first characterization of CN transcriptomic cell types in three species and suggest a model of brain region evolution by duplication and divergence of entire cell type sets.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Age-related Differences in Visual-Vestibular Integration over Time of Exposure in VR Simulated Driving Environments
Robert Nowosielski
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Robert J. Nowosielski, MSc, University of Toronto, Toronto Rehabilitation Institute, Toronto, ON; Bruce Haycock, PhD, University of Toronto, Toronto Rehabilitation Institute, Toronto, ON; Behrang Keshavarz, PhD; Ryerson University, Toronto Rehabilitation Institute, Toronto, ON; Jennifer Campos, PhD, University of Toronto, Toronto Rehabilitation Institute, Toronto, ON

Vestibular function is known to change with age, but the effects of these changes on functional behaviours requiring self-motion perception is largely unknown. Driving is a complex task that involves the use of vestibular inputs to guide self-motion perception and behaviours. However, the degree to which age-related changes in vestibular function affect driving performance has yet to be studied in an experimental setting. Driving simulators are an increasingly common tool for examining driving performance in a safe and controlled way, yet they differ widely in fidelity, including their motion capabilities. Using Toronto Rehabilitation Institute’s high-fidelity, full motion driving simulator, we measured the driving performance of older and younger drivers across three different physical motion conditions: no motion, rotational motion (yaw), and full motion (yaw, pitch, roll, and translational motion) using a between-subjects design (age x motion condition). We tested 34 younger adults aged 18 – 35 and 32 older adults aged 65+ using three, 15-minute driving scenarios for each motion condition. Driving performance was measured across 14 variables (e.g. speed variability, lane deviation). We hypothesized an additive and beneficial effect of motion (no motion to yaw, yaw to full motion) on driving performance (e.g. reduced speed variability, reduced lane deviations), with older adults benefiting more from additional motion components than younger adults. Our preliminary results demonstrate a more nuanced effect of motion, with older adults demonstrating a larger benefit from the addition of both yaw and full motion on driving performance, despite driving more poorly than younger adults overall. Furthermore, older adults demonstrated greater improvements in performance over drives than did younger adults. These findings suggest that age-related differences in how different motion types affect driving performance should not be viewed in terms of decrements in function, rather in unique perceptual and cognitive strategies in integrating multisensory information.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Amodal statistical completion of occluded objects
Thomas Cherian
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
SP Arun, Indian Institute of Science

It is well known that the visual system amodally completes occluded edges in a display. But real-world objects have more complex edges and yet, we have no trouble recognizing them even when they are occluded. Does our visual system extrapolate more complex types of information based on the statistics of the visible portion of an object? To answer this question, we performed a series of visual search experiments. We created occluded displays in which a shape was occluded in its top-left corner, and two alternative shapes whose contours were identical in the unoccluded portion but differed in the occluded portion such that one appeared to be the more likely object behind the occluder, and the other more unlikely. We then asked whether perceptual dissimilarities measured using visual search in the occluded conditions were correlated with the perceptual dissimilarities of the likely pairs or unlikely pairs. Across different sets of shapes organized on candidate features for perceptual completion (here: ‘numerosity’ of protrusions, ‘curvature’ between straight edges etc.), we observed that occluded dissimilarities were more correlated with the likely shape dissimilarities (r = 0.90, p < 0.0005 for ‘numerosity’ set and r = 0.89, p < 0.0005 for ‘curvature’ set’) compared to unlikely shape dissimilarities (r = 0.68, p < 0.0005 for ‘numerosity’ set and r = 0.80, p < 0.0005 for ‘curvature’ set’). Taken together, our results show that amodal completion is far more complex than is believed, in that it can not only extrapolate simple edges but use statistical properties to complete occluded portions of objects.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Exploring the relationship between functional ultrasound and neuronal activity
Anwar Nunez-Elizalde
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Michael Krumin, UCL; Charu B Reddy, UCL; Gabriel Montaldo, KU Leuven and NERF; Alan Urban, KU Leuven and NERF; Kenneth D Harris, UCL; Matteo Carandini, UCL

Functional ultrasound imaging (fUSi) is an appealing method for measuring blood-volume signals from the brain. However, the blood-volume signal measured by fUSi bears an unclear relationship to the underlying neuronal firing. Is this relationship linear, and stable across brain regions, subjects, and time?

To answer these questions, we performed simultaneous fUSi measurements and Neuropixels recordings in awake mice. Eight recording sessions were performed across four mice (~4 coronal slices per session). We inserted one or two Neuropixels probes per session, and related firing recorded from these probes to fUSi signals from the corresponding regions of interest (ROIs).

A linear model provided a good estimate of fUSi signals based on neuronal firing. We measured the multi-unit activity (MUA) from the Neuropixel probes and convolved it with a hemodynamic filter (4.2 s causal window). The filter was estimated using a linear regression model using half the data from one recording, and tested on the second half. Model predictions were accurate (r > 0.5). Furthermore, this model generalized across mice: it increased prediction accuracy relative to an instantaneous MUA model with no delay in all sessions in all three held-out mice. The hemodynamic filter resembled one measured optically, peaking ~1.5 s after neural activity (Pisauro, et al., J Neurosci 2013).

These results indicate that the relationship between neuronal firing and fUSi is stable and linear. Our current efforts aim to optimize the processing of fUSi signals so that they best capture variations in neuronal firing across both time and space.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Modeling Task Effects on Meaning Representation in the Brain via Zero-Shot MEG Prediction
Mariya Toneva
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Mariya Toneva, Carnegie Mellon University; Otilia Stretcu, Carnegie Mellon University; Barnabas Poczos, Carnegie Mellon University; Leila Wehbe, Carnegie Mellon University; Tom Mitchell, Carnegie Mellon University

How meaning is represented in the brain is still one of the big open questions in neuroscience. Does a word (e.g., bird) always have the same representation, or does the task under which the word is processed alter its representation (answering “can you eat it?” versus “can it fly?”)? The brain activity of subjects who read the same word while performing different semantic tasks has been shown to differ across tasks. However, it is still not understood how the task itself contributes to this difference. In the current work, we study Magnetoencephalography (MEG) brain recordings of participants tasked with answering questions about concrete nouns. We investigate the effect of the task (i.e. the question being asked) on the processing of the concrete noun by predicting the millisecond-resolution MEG recordings as a function of both the semantics of the noun and the task. Using this approach, we test several hypotheses about the task-stimulus interactions by comparing the zero-shot predictions made by these hypotheses for novel tasks and nouns not seen during training. We find that incorporating the task semantics significantly improves the prediction of MEG recordings, across participants. The improvement occurs 475 − 550ms after the participants first see the word, which corresponds to what is considered to be the ending time of semantic processing for a word. These results suggest that only the end of semantic processing of a word is task-dependent, and pose a challenge for future research to formulate new hypotheses for earlier task effects as a function of the task and stimuli.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Activation of 5-HT2A receptors reconfigures cortico-limbic functional connectivity in rats
Daniel Titheradge
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Daniel Titheradge, University of Bristol, School of Physiology, Pharmacology & Neuroscience, Faculty of Life Sciences, University Walk, Bristol BS8 1TD; Flavie Kersante, University of Bristol, School of Physiology, Pharmacology & Neuroscience, Faculty of Life Sciences, University Walk, Bristol BS8 1TD; Jesper L. Kristensen, University of Copenhagen, Department of Drug Design & Pharmacology, Universitetsparken 2 342, Copenhagen, Denmark; Martin Hansen, University of Copenhagen, Department of Drug Design & Pharmacology, Universitetsparken 2 342, Copenhagen, Denmark; Matt W. Jones, University of Bristol, School of Physiology, Pharmacology & Neuroscience, Faculty of Life Sciences, University Walk, Bristol BS8 1TD

5-HT2a receptor activation may contribute to the potential antidepressant effects of psychedelics. 5-HT2a agonists have been shown to induce High Frequency Oscillations (HFO, 125-145Hz) in diverse brain regions, but the mechanisms and relevance of these oscillations remain unclear. Here, we quantify the effects of a selective 5-HT2a agonist 25I-NBOH (25I) on functional connectivity in the cortico-limbic system of behaving rats.
5 adult male Wistar rats were implanted with local field potential recording electrodes in basolateral amygdala (BLA), dorsal hippocampus (dCA1), infralimbic (IL) and prelimbic (PrL) cortex. Baseline recordings in a familiar open field were followed by intraperitoneal injection of 25I (2mg/kg) or vehicle. LFP power, coherence and pairwise spectral multivariate granger causality (GC) were analysed for pre-injection, early post-injection (5-10 minutes) and late post-injection (35-40 minutes) periods.
25I reduced movement and increased the proportion of time spent at the open field perimeter. 25I induced reductions in broadband spectral power across all four regions, but increases in high-gamma (65-80Hz) in the BLA and HFO in BLA, IL and PRL. HFO peaks were most pronounced in IL. High-gamma and HFO coherence between IL, PRL and BLA increased; coherence between CA1 and other regions showed only a slight increase in the HFO range.
25I caused a marked increase in high-gamma GC from IL to BLA relative to pre-injection or vehicle, and a marked increase in HFO GC from IL to PRL. In the early post injection period, there was an increase in HFO GC from dCA1 to BLA.
Our data evidence a 5-HT2A receptor-mediated increase in functional connectivity between the prefrontal cortex and amygdala with an increase in “top down” control of the amygdala by the IL. These changes may contribute to the network basis of antidepressant effects of psychedelic drugs including psilocybin and ketamine.
Traditional talk
Watch now
A Bayesian filtering framework for neural and sensorimotor entrainment
Jonathan Cannon
 
Abstract
 
When presented with complex rhythmic auditory stimuli, most humans are able to track underlying temporal structure (e.g., a ``beat'') with overt movement or covertly while automatically and unconsciously adjusting for timing irregularities. We propose that the problem of overt and covert rhythm tracking is most naturally characterized as a problem of point process filtering: continuously estimating a hidden underlying phase based on the precise timing of temporally localized events that provide (incomplete) information about the phase. Here, we provide several mathematical framings of that problem at different levels of detail. We demonstrate that variational Bayesian solutions to this problem (specifically, point-process Kalman-Bucy filters) can be used to infer tempo as well as phase, and that they reproduce multiple characteristics of overt and covert human rhythm tracking including interval-dependent phase correction and the ``filled interval'' illusion. We point out that this approach to rhythm tracking fits nicely into the theory of predictive processing and active inference, and we discuss its plausibility in the human brain.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Exploring the role of oxytocin on rats' stress-related behaviours
Kate Zucconi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Janet Menard, Queen's University

Social contact is known to reduce or “buffer” rodents’ responses to acute stress. Although the mechanisms responsible for social buffering remain unclear, the neuropeptide oxytocin (OT) is thought to play a role. This possibility was explored in the current study. Rats were randomly assigned to either single- or paired-housing, then five weeks later they were tested in the elevated plus maze (EPM) and a modified version of the novelty-induced suppression of feeding test (NFST).
