Seven days later, their brains were harvested and processed for OT-labelling. Pair-housed rats displayed moderately higher open-arm exploration in the EPM and took significantly less time to initiate consumption of the snack in the NSFT. Furthermore, compared to single-housed rats, pair-housed rats had significantly more OT-ir cells in the ventral part of the paraventricular nucleus (PVN). The number of OT cells in the ventral PVN correlated negatively with their latencies to begin consuming the snack on Day 1 of the NSFT. Overall, these findings suggest that “social buffering” is mediated, at least in part, by social contact-induced remodelling of the OT system.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Cell-type specific nonlinearities in frontal-sensory integration in the parietal cortex
Gyorgy Lur
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Daniel Y. Rindner, UC Irvine

Top-down influences, including memory and attention, strongly affect sensory processing. Yet, synaptic interaction of cognitive and sensory information streams remains largely undescribed. Non-linear interactions have been frequently observed during multisensory processing, however, technical challenges so far prohibited the mechanistic exploration of how top-down and bottom-up afferents interact. Here, we employ a dual-color optogenetic strategy to determine the spatiotemporal features of multi-modal synaptic integration in the mouse posterior parietal cortex (PPC). We expressed a red light sensitive channelrhodopsin variant in the primary auditory cortex (A1) and a blue light sensitive opsin in the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC), a frontal region commonly associated with attention and working memory. This opsin combination allowed independent control of sensory and frontal inputs to the PPC. Using whole-cell patch clamp recordings in acute brain slices we show that the PPC receives direct, monosynaptic inputs from both A1 and ACC. Similarly to other cortical areas, layer 5 principal cells in the PPC show heterogeneity in their firing patterns. We found that two classes of pyramidal neurons, intrinsically bursting and regular spiking, have distinct patterns of frontal-sensory integration. Intrinsically bursting cells displayed a supralinear enhancement of coincident input from ACC and A1, an effect that diminished with increasing delays between inputs. Conversely, regular spiking cells showed maximal enhancement when afferents were activated with delay, and robust suppression of coincident inputs. Intriguingly, we also found that co-activating frontal and sensory inputs significantly enhanced sustained activity in the PPC microcircuit, indicating a potential role in working memory processes. Our data suggest that frontal-sensory integration has cell-type specificity in the PPC, and begins to unravel the circuit architecture of multi-modal integration.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Brain-wide mapping of neural activity evoked by different superior colliculus cell-types.
Arnau Sans Dublanc
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Arnau Sans-Dublanc1,2,3, Neuro-Electronics Research Flanders. Leuven, Belgium1. Department of Biology, KU Leuven. Leuven, Belgium2. VIB. Leuven, Belgium3; Anna Chrzanowska1,2,3; Katja Reinhard1,2,3; Dani Lemmon1,4, Faculty of Pharmaceutical, Biomedical and Veterinary Sciences, University of Antwerp. Antwerp, Belgium4; Gabriel Montaldo1,5 Imec, Leuven, Belgium5; Alan Urban1,2,3,6, Department of Neurosciences, KU Leuven. Leuven, Belgium6; and Karl Farrow1,2,3,5

Neuronal cell-types are arranged in brain-wide circuits to guide behavior. In mice, the superior colliculus is comprised of a set of cell-types that each innervate distinct downstream targets. Here we reveal the networks downstream of four collicular cell-types by combining functional ultrasound imaging (fUSi) with optogenetics to monitor whole-brain activity at a resolution of ~100 ‎μm. Each neuronal group activated distinct, partially overlapping sets of brain nuclei. This included regions not previously thought to mediate defensive behaviors. Electrophysiological recordings support the fUSi findings and show that neurons in the downstream nuclei preferentially respond to innately threatening visual stimuli. This work provides insight into the functional organization of the networks governing defensive behaviors and demonstrates an experimental approach to explore the whole-brain neuronal activity downstream of targeted cell-types.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Audio-visual training in older adults: 2-Interval-Forced Choice Task improves performance
Jessica O'Brien
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Annalisa Setti, University College Cork; Jason Chan, University College Cork

A growing interest in ameliorating multisensory perception deficits in older adults arises from recent evidence showing that impaired multisensory processing, particularly in the temporal domain, may be associated with cognitive and functional impairments. Older adults exhibit an extended temporal binding window (the timeframe during which the brain integrates inputs from different senses into a multisensory percept) which has been associated with mild cognitive impairment and falls-risk. Perceptual training has proved successful in improving multisensory temporal processing in young adults, but few studies have investigated this training approach in older adults. In the present study we used a simultaneity (or synchronicity) judgement task with feedback, to train the audio-visual abilities of community-dwelling, cognitively healthy older adults. We recruited 23 older adults (M = 74.17, SD = 6.23) and a group of 20 young adults (M = 24.20, SD = 4.23) who served as a comparison. Participants were tested before and after perceptual training using a 2-Interval Forced Choice Task (2-IFC); and the Sound-Induced Flash Illusion (SIFI). After three days of training, participants improved on the 2-IFC task, with a significant narrowing of the temporal window of integration found for both groups. Generalisation of training effects was not found, with no post-training differences in perceptual sensitivity to the SIFI for either group. These findings provide evidence perceptual narrowing can be achieved in older as well as younger adults after three days of perceptual training. This research contributes to mounting evidence that multisensory processing deficits in older adults’ can be modified through targeted perceptual training. Perceptual training could potentially represent a novel intervention avenue for populations whose impairments are associated with underlying multisensory processing difficulties (e.g. fall-prone older adults).
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Neural network models of object recognition can also account for visual search behavior
David Nicholson (he/him/they)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Astrid Prinz, Emory University

What limits our ability to find an object we are looking for? There are two competing families of models: one explains attentional limitations during visual search in terms of a serial processing computation, the other attributes them to noisy parallel processing. These models predict search behavior for the simplified stimuli often used in experiments, but it remains unclear how to extend them to account for search of complex natural scenes. Models exist for search of natural scenes, but they do not predict whether a given scene will limit search accuracy. Here we test an alternate hypothesis that could explain limitations across stimuli types: visual search is limited by an "untangling" computation, proposed to underlie object recognition. To test this hypothesis, we ask whether models of object recognition account for visual search behavior. The current best-in-class models are artificial neural networks (ANNs) that accurately predict both behavior and neural activity in the visual system during object recognition tasks. Unlike dominant search models, ANNs can provide predictions for any image. First we test ANN-based object recognition models with simplified stimuli typically used in studies of visual search. We find these models exhibit a hallmark effect of such studies: a drop in target detection accuracy as the number of distractors increases. Further experiments show this effect results from learned representations: networks that are not pre-trained for object recognition can achieve near perfect accuracy. Next we test these models with complex natural images, using a version of the Pascal VOC dataset where each image has a visual search difficulty score, derived from human reaction times. We find models exhibit a drop in accuracy as search difficulty score increases. We conclude that ANN-based object recognition models account for aspects of visual search behavior across stimuli types, and discuss how to extend these results.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Recording from the same cortical neurons over months with Neuropixels probes
Anna Lebedeva
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Nicholas Steinmetz, University of Washington; Marius Pachitariu, Janelia Research Campus; Jai Bhagat, UCL; Kenneth Harris, UCL; Matteo Carandini, UCL; Michael Okun, University of Leicester

For many studies, especially those focusing on learning and plasticity, it is important to track the activity of neurons over prolonged periods. Prolonged recordings can be achieved with two-photon imaging, but this method is difficult in deep brain structures and has limited temporal resolution. Here we asked whether neurons could be reliably tracked across recordings with Neuropixels probes, which allow access not only to the cortex but also to deep brain structures and can resolve individual spikes. We implanted mice with novel Neuropixels 2.0 probes that can have one shank or four shanks, and have more tightly spaced recording sites compared to commercially available Neuropixel 1.0 probes. We implanted the probes vertically through primary visual cortex and cemented them to the cranium. For recordings, mice were head-fixed in front of computer screens. Recordings were performed at regular intervals. Recordings yielded many neurons across >6 months, but there was substantial drift across sessions. To compensate for it, we used a modified version of Kilosort2 algorithm. To characterize the neurons, during each recording we presented a library of natural images. Many V1 neurons responded to these images and showed a pattern of preferences that constituted a unique signature. Using this signature we followed the activity of these neurons over the course of days, weeks and months. The ability to follow large populations of individual neurons over extended periods opens new possibilities in the study of learning and plasticity.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Neural similarity in BOLD response and multi-unit recordings
Sebastian Bobadilla-Suarez
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Marilena Lemonari, UCL; Scott L. Brincat, MIT; Markus Siegel, University of Tübingen; Earl K. Miller, MIT; Bradley C. Love, UCL and The Alan Turing Institute

One fundamental question is what makes two brain states similar. For example, what makes the activity in visual cortex elicited from viewing a robin similar to a sparrow? There are a number of possible ways to measure similarity, each of which makes certain conceptual commitments. In terms of information processing in the brain, interesting questions include whether notions of similarity are common across brain regions and tasks, as well as how attention can alter similarity representations. With multi-unit recordings, additional questions like the importance of spike timings can be considered. We evaluated which of several competing similarity measures best captured neural similarity. One technique uses a decoding approach to assess the information present in a brain region and the similarity measures that best correspond to the classifier’s confusion matrix are preferred. Across two published fMRI datasets, we found the preferred neural similarity measures were common across brain regions, but differed across tasks. In considering similarity spaces derived from monkey multi-unit recordings, we found that similarity measures that took into account spike timing information best recovered the representational spaces. In both fMRI and multi-unit data, we found that top-down attention, which highlighted task relevant stimulus attributes, had the effect of stretching neural representations along those axes to make stimuli differing on relevant attributes less similar. These effects were captured by a deep convolutional network front-end to a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network that tracked changes in task context and whose representations stretched in a task-driven manner that paralleled patterns of neural similarity changed with task context.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Analysing inter-regional neuronal connections at the single neuron-level
Sean Martin
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Shane O'Mara; John Aggleton

Recent improvements in in-vivo neuronal recording technologies allow large-scale recordings of individual neurons within and between multiple brain regions simultaneously. Such large-scale recordings potentially allow questions about brain network communication rules between neurons during behavioural tasks to be meaningfully addressed. However, analytic approaches to such datasets are currently lacking. We consider here the expected number of connections that might be recorded between neurons in these brain regions with current technology, to guide what the correct analytic approach to such recordings might be. We consider an ‘inductive’ argument, with multiple neurons in multiple brain regions and a simplified connection mapping between these neurons. Using the hyper-geometric distribution, we derive a probability distribution for the number connections recorded between the neurons of anatomically connected regions. This mathematically derived distribution is validated by Monte Carlo simulations of directed graphs. Our method is applied to simulated graphs with several neurons, based on counts in rat brain regions, and connection matrices from the Blue Brain project’s model of the mouse neocortex connectome. We conclude that the probability of simultaneously recording directly connected pairs of neurons in anatomically connected regions can approach zero, given current recording technology. Approaches summing neuronal activity over larger scales (such as local-field potentials) may offer considerable promise, especially if combined with other approaches (such opto- or chemogenetics), and simultaneously recorded neuronal activity.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Being in Sync: How Neural Entrainment Affects Attention and Conscious Experience
Gagana B
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Deepak Padamata; Mahdi Mahdavi;

Activation of attention-reward centres cause actual patterns of local field potentials across brain regions to become synchronised in their alpha, theta and gamma frequency bands but however, in recent years, research has been more focused on information filtering by partial synchronous spikes in neural populations. In this context, we further investigate the performance prediction estimates from neural synchronisation during the 2AFC task through analyses of power spectrums, time/frequency correlational metrics within and across brain regions, time lagged and phase based analysis of discrete brain wave structures and how these are can be reverse engineered to the respective brain state aka current conscious experience. Neural entrainment in turn has multitude of applications where (a) asychrony is attributed to Alzhimer's disease and Schizophrenia while (b) local network synchrony affects interpersonal communication (language understanding), learning experience (long-term working memory formation) and global fields or transient synchronous assemblies could underlie the basis of phenomenal consciousness where the NMDA-based plasticity, cortico-thalamic projections, and regular oscillatory waves knit with local diverse specialised brain module activity contributes to an integrated conscious experience. In this talk, we intend to explore discrete brain waves properties and associated mental states discussing the effect of synchronisation on consciousness while presenting our unique findings on mice models.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Transforming Sensory Cues into Aversive Emotion via Septal-Habenular Pathway
Guangwei Zhang
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Zhang, Guang Wei; Shen, Li; Zhong, Wen; Xiong, Ying; Zhang, Li I.; Tao, Huizhong W.

Emotions evoked by environmental cues are important for animal survival and life quality. However, neural circuits responsible for transforming sensory signals to aversive emotion and behavioral avoidance remain unclear. Here, we found that medial septum (MS) mediates aversion induced by both auditory and somatosensory stimuli. Ablation of glutamatergic or GABAergic MS neurons results in impaired or strengthened aversion, respectively. Optogenetic activation of the two cell types results in place avoidance and preference, respectively. Cell-type-specific screening reveals that glutamatergic MS projections to the lateral habenula (LHb) are responsible for the induction of aversion, which can be antagonized by GABAergic MS projections to LHb. Additionally, the sensory-induced place avoidance is facilitated by enhanced locomotion mediated by glutamatergic MS projections to the preoptic area. Thus, MS can transmit innately aversive signals via a bottom-up multimodal sensory pathway and produce concurrent emotional and motional effects, allowing animals to efficiently avoid unfavorable environments. Zhang et al. reveal a circuit for processing innately aversive sensory signals, with glutamatergic projections from MS to LHb and POA to generate the emotional and a motional effect, respectively. This role of MS in mediating aversion is previously unrecognized.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Brain-Wide Tracing of Inputs to the LP-ACC Reciprocal Circuit
Blake Zhou (they / them)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Yi-Ning Leow, MIT; Grayson O. Sipe, MIT; Ian R. Wickersham, MIT; Mriganka Sur, MIT

The rodent lateral posterior thalamus (LP) plays an important role in cortical communication through dense reciprocal connectivity with multiple cortical areas. A defining input to the medial subdivision of LP is the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC), which plays an integral role in top-down sensory processing and modulates visual selectivity via LP and the superior colliculus (SC). With broader receptive fields and feature tuning, LP is unlikely to provide precise visual encoding. Instead, LP likely provides ACC neurons with visual inputs filtered for behavioral context and convey top-down behavioral priorities from the ACC to other visual areas. To define the inputs that can ultimately shape this reciprocal interaction, we sought to map brain-wide monosynaptic inputs to the bottom-up LP-ACC and top-down ACC-LP circuits.

Brain-wide inputs to these two circuits differ significantly. Although LP activity is believed to be largely driven by cortical inputs, subcortical structures comprise more than half of input to LP-ACC, many possibly serving as inhibitory modulators. Cortical inputs to LP-ACC neurons largely originate from sensory and associative areas, with somatosensory and auditory inputs comparable to visual inputs. In contrast, most ACC-LP neurons receive inputs from frontal and sensorimotor cortical areas. Notably, both nodes of the reciprocal circuit receive extensive retrosplenial cortex (RSC) input and from higher visual areas AM & PM. Our data also show that SC is the largest single input to LP-ACC. Importantly, these originate from the intermediate and deep layers of the SC, which integrates multimodal information and orienting. This contrasts to posterior LP which receives SC input from superficial layers conveying visual information. This also points to LP as a potential node for SC feedback to the ACC.

Our brain-wide anatomical mapping of inputs to the reciprocal LP-ACC pathways provide a roadmap to understanding LP’s interaction with frontal areas for attentional control and visuomotor functions.

Support: NIH grant EY028219
 Traditional talk
Watch now
A cell-type specific understanding of innate defensive behaviors: the collicular perspective
Anna Chrzanowska
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Arnau Sans-Dublanc, NERF, KULeuven (Belgium); Katja Reinhard, NERF, KULeuven, VIB (Belgium); Dani Lemmon, NERF, University of Antwerp (Belgium); Gabriel Montaldo, NERF, imec (Belgium), Alan Urban, NERF, KULeuven, VIB (Belgium); Karl Farrow, NERF, KULeuven, VIB, imec

Animals’ behaviors are governed by distinct neuronal cell-types. In the superior colliculus of mice, there is evidence of a strong relationship between individual cell-types and orienting, hunting and defensive behaviors. Here we use this relationship to determine the contribution each collicular cell-type make on triggering behavior. We show that optogenetic activation of 4 different cell populations each evoked a distinct behavior, including freezing, stopping, hiding and orienting. Additionally, by combining optogenetics with functional ultrasound imaging (opto-fUSi) we mapped the neuronal activity in up to 264 brain regions and unraveled a few novel hubs engaged in defensive behaviors processing. Chemogenetic manipulation of one newly identified area, the posterior paralaminar nuclei of the thalamus (PPnT), revealed the role it plays in mediating habituation to repeated threat-like input from the superior colliculus. This study extends our understanding of how cell-types of the superior colliculus disseminate information across the brain to guide distinct behaviors.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Associations of pickleball-play with cognition among older adults: A longitudinal study
Abbie Hutton
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Inga Sogaard, Rui Ni

Inevitably, physical and cognitive abilities decline with age. The population of those over the age of 65 is currently doubling (Passel & Cohn, 2008). Contrary to aerobic exercises, open skill exercise has been shown to improve decision making, RT, and visual capabilities (Guo et al., 2016; Marks, 2006; Jafarzadehpur et al., 2012). Pickleball is rapidly growing and is recommended for older adults because of the court size, interaction, and is easy to learn, yet is moderate in intensity (Ryu et al., 2018). Pickleball can increase physical well-being and life satisfaction, but lacks research on cognition. We hypothesized that older adults who participate in pickleball will show improved cognition through perceptual learning.
A non-experimental, longitudinal study was used to compare 83 healthy older adults. Groups were based on exercise characteristics (advanced pickleball-AP, novice pickleball-NP, aerobic exercise, inactive). A battery of eight standard and cognitive assessments (Multiple object tracking, Useful Field of View, Flanker, N-back) were given.
UFOV. The aerobic and AP groups had quicker processing times. Older participants in the AP group had decreased processing times. As pickleball players age, it seems that the continuation of the sport can help maintain processing speed.
MOT. The aerobic group was more accurate. The reason we may not have found the pickleball groups performing like the aerobic group is that these visual functions may take consecutive years and multiple methods of exercising.
Flanker. The aerobic group had quicker RT. Playing pickleball more times a week can increase comfort level and familiarity with an unpredictable environment which could be why their RT was quicker.
N-back. In general, aerobic exercise can strengthen WM more than pickleball or that the N-back is not sensitive enough to assess changes in WM.
Open skilled exercise can potentially maintain and improve cognitive decline in older adults more than traditional aerobic exercise. As the population of older adults grows, it’s important to maximize their quality of life and a game of pickleball could be part of the solution.

Interactive talk
Watch now
Conserved core visual object recognition across simian primates: Marmoset image-by-image behavior mirrors that of humans and macaques
Alex Kell
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Alexander J.E. Kell, Columbia University; Sophie L. Bokor, Columbia University; You-Nah Jeon, Columbia University; Tahereh Toosi, Columbia University; Elias B. Issa, Columbia University

Introduced to the field decades ago, marmosets have become an increasingly popular model organism in neuroscience. Among the smallest simian primates, marmosets offer features typically associated with rodents in a species that is phylogenetically closer to humans—e.g., small size (~300 g), flat cortex, and relatively high fecundity. Marmosets may therefore mitigate traditional compromises between an animal model’s methodological tractability and its similarity to humans. Nonetheless, there remain serious concerns that, simian or not, marmosets’ perceptual and cognitive repertoire may be rather limited, particularly in higher-level perception and cognition. Here, we assessed the advanced perceptual abilities of the marmoset in a quintessential domain of systems neuroscience: vision. We quantitatively compared the behavior of three simian primates—marmosets, humans, and macaques—during core visual object recognition, the invariant identification of objects on natural backgrounds despite changes in object scale, position, and pose. We selected this behavior to benchmark the marmoset because it captures a crux problem in natural vision and is computationally challenging. We found that marmosets achieved impressively high performance on this core recognition task, and that their image-by-image behavior was remarkably human-like—indeed, nearly as human-like as was macaques’ (marmoset-human correlation, r = 0.73; macaque-human correlation, r = 0.77). Critically, these kinds of high-level visual behaviors did not seem to extend to rodents—we found that marmosets’ visual capabilities far outstripped those of rats on a simplified object recognition task. Thus, aspects of core high-level perception appear to be shared across simian primates, and marmosets may therefore offer a powerful platform for the study of capabilities conventionally considered to be the exclusive purview of larger primates.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Improving brain-machine interface robustness through deep learning-based manifold alignment
Brianna Karpowicz (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Lahiru Wimalasena, Emory University & Georgia Tech; Mohammad Reza Keshtkaran, Emory University & Georgia Tech; Yahia Ali, Emory University & Georgia Tech; Andrew Sedler, Georgia Tech; Ali Farschian, Northwestern University; Josie Walner, Northwestern University; Xuan Ma, Northwestern University; Ben Semel, Northwestern University; Kevin Bodkin, Northwestern University; Lee Miller, Northwestern University; Chethan Pandarinath, Emory University & Georgia Tech

Intracortical brain-computer interfaces (iBCIs) can restore voluntary movements to people with paralysis by translating brain activity directly into the motion of an external device. A major barrier to the long-term usage of iBCIs is the inability of the algorithms, or “decoders”, that do this translation to adapt to changes in the recorded neurons over time. These changes lead to degradation in decoding accuracy and necessitate periodic supervised decoder recalibration. An emerging approach to maintain decoder robustness consists in harnessing the stable relationship that exists between behavior and the latent manifold structure that underlies the activity of populations of neurons. One recent proof of concept (Degenhart et al., 2020) used an approach based on linear manifold discovery (Factor Analysis; FA). It achieved stable closed-loop BCI control over five days without recalibration. However, nonlinear manifold discovery methods produce estimates of manifold structure that are more informative about movement intention on a moment-by-moment basis. Thus, we aimed to develop a platform for nonlinear manifold alignment decoding (NoMAD) to achieve higher performing and stable BCIs.

NoMAD incorporates latent factor analysis via dynamical systems (LFADS), a deep learning approach that uncovers manifold structure by modeling the shared dynamics underlying population activity. NoMAD combines LFADS with unsupervised distribution alignment (Farshchian et al., 2019; Dyer et al., 2017) to produce consistent manifold estimates in the face of changing recorded neurons. We tested NoMAD in an offline analysis of motor cortical activity from a monkey performing an isometric wrist force task throughout 21 sessions spanning more than three months. NoMAD allowed stable, high performance decoding of the monkey’s force over all sessions without supervised recalibration. NoMAD’s force-decoding performance typically ranged from 0.85-0.90 R2, with all sessions exceeding 0.75. In comparison, FA-based stabilization achieved a median of only 0.45 R2, with significant performance fluctuations between sessions. Thus by combining accurate, nonlinear manifold discovery with the stability conferred by manifold alignment, NoMAD enables higher-performing and stable BCIs with greater suitability for real-world application.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Transferring generalized neural decoders across participants and recording modalities
Steven Peterson
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Steven M Peterson, University of Washington; Zoe Steine-Hanson, University of Washington; Nathan Davis, University of Washington; Rajesh P N Rao, University of Washington; Bingni W Brunton, University of Washington

Advances in neural decoding have enabled brain-computer interfaces to perform increasingly complex and clinically-relevant tasks. However, such decoders are often tailored to specific participants, days, and recording sites, limiting their practical long-term usage. Therefore, a fundamental challenge is to develop generalized neural decoders that can robustly train on pooled, multi-participant data and fine-tune to new participants. Here we introduce HTNet, a decoder architecture that fuses deep learning with neural signal processing insights. Specifically, HTNet augments a pre-existing convolutional neural network decoder with two innovations: (1) a Hilbert transform that computes spectral power at data-driven frequencies and (2) a layer that projects electrode-level data into predefined brain regions. This projection is critical for intracranial electrocorticography (ECoG), where electrode locations are not standardized and vary widely across participants. We trained HTNet to decode arm movements using pooled ECoG data from 11 of 12 participants, testing performance on unseen ECoG or scalp electroencephalography (EEG) participants; these pretrained models were later fine-tuned to each test participant. We show that HTNet significantly outperformed state-of-the-art decoder accuracies by 8.5% when tested on unseen ECoG participants and by 14.5% when tested on unseen participants that used a different recording modality (EEG). We then used transfer learning and fine-tuned these trained models to unseen participants, even when limited training data was available. Importantly, we fine-tuned trained HTNet decoders with as few as 50 events and still achieved decoding performance approaching that of randomly-initialized decoders trained on hundreds of events. Furthermore, we demonstrate that HTNet extracts interpretable, neurally-relevant features. By generalizing to new participants and recording modalities, robustly handling variations in electrode placement, and fine-tuning with minimal data, HTNet can be used across a broader range of neural decoding applications than current state-of-the-art decoders.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Mesoscale brain dynamics reorganizes and stabilizes during learning tactile discrimination task
Yaroslav Sych
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Aleksejs Fomins, University of Zurich; Leonardo Novelli, University of Zurich; Fritjof Helmchen, University of Zurich;

Adaptive behavior is coordinated by neuronal networks that are distributed across multiple brain regions. How cross-regional interactions reorganize during learning remains elusive. We applied multi-fiber photometry to chronically record simultaneous activity of 12-48 mouse brain regions while mice learned a tactile discrimination task. We found that with learning most regions shifted their peak activity from reward-related action to the reward-predicting stimulus. We corroborated this finding by functional connectivity estimation using transfer entropy, which revealed growth and stabilization of mesoscale networks encompassing basal ganglia, thalamus, cortex, and hippocampus, especially during stimulus presentation. The internal globus pallidus, ventromedial thalamus, and several regions in frontal cortex emerged as hub regions. Our results highlight the cooperative action of distributed brain regions to establish goal-oriented mesoscale network dynamics during learning.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Data-driven discovery of dynamical relationships within electroencephalographic spectra in sleep
Robert Law (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Shaun Purcell, Harvard Medical School

Sleep is a decidedly nonstationary and multiplex process, and its dynamics, as measured by electroencephalography, are marked by the coupled evolution of bandlimited activities. Many of these activities are tied to neurological processes involved in regeneration, learning and memory consolidation, and an open question in sleep epidemiology is how best to compactly quantify an individual's sleep dynamics in a data-driven manner, for demographic analysis.

To address this question, we first apply a “cool-start” nonnegative matrix factorization technique to separate epoch-level spectrograms into nonindependent, nonstationary time and frequency factors. The frequency factors recapitulate classical frequency bands with well-known demographic correlates, but they also admit variability in these bands across individuals. The temporal factors are found suitable for fitting systems of ordinary differential equations, which can compactly describe how the frequency factors evolve and influence one another.

We first apply this approach to data from the childhood adenotonsillectomy study (n=464), a publicly available sleep dataset. During the sleep onset period, highly significant linear differential interactions are found among individualized sigma, delta, and beta factors, essentially blindly confirming a previous model of those interactions. However, we find little evidence that sleep onset dynamics are trait-like in this sample. To conclude, we discuss several challenges in the method's implementation to sleep data at the epidemiological scale, as well as further potential applications to cross-species homology, sleep microarchitecture, and neural time-series outside sleep.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Animal-to-Animal Variability in Hippocampal Remapping
Honi Sanders (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Parsa Nilchian, Florida International University and MIT Summer Research Program; Samuel Gershman, Department of Psychology and Center for Brain Science -- Harvard University; Matthew Wilson, Picower Institute and Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences -- Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Honi Sanders, Center for Brains Minds and Machines and Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences-- Massachusetts Institute of Technology

Hippocampal place cells form a unique map for each environment, a phenomenon known as hippocampal remapping. What qualifies as a sufficiently different environment to give rise to a new hippocampal map is unclear, and different studies provide superficially conflicting results. In particular, many experiments have observed unexplained variability in remapping behavior between different animals.
Recent work has organized disparate phenomena associated with remapping by framing the context identification problem that the hippocampus is ostensibly solving as a hidden state inference problem. Lack of access to objective hidden state labels lead to an inherent ambiguity in identifying which experiences deserve unique maps. Animal variability can potentially be a result of different animals having characteristically different parameter settings in resolving this ambiguity.
We reanalyze a published data set collected from rats foraging in 11 different rooms, including a variety of types of repetitions of those rooms. We find that variability between these animals in remapping behavior is highly structured: different animals have characteristically different remapping behaviors across different types of repetitions of these rooms. For example, remapping between repetitions of an environment when the animal is not removed from a room correlate with remapping between repetitions of an environment much later in the day. We also find heterogeneity in remapping behavior across the place cell population within an animal. Overall, we find evidence that different animals have consistently different remapping responses to the same experiences, emphasizing the subjective nature of hippocampal remapping.
Special Event
Watch now
Black In Neuro: Neuroracism Panel Discussion
 
Abstract
 
Black In Neuro will lead a panel discussion as the first installment of a 2-part event on neuroracism.

The NeuroRacism panel will center discussions on how we in academia collect, use and interpret data about Black people. Panelists will highlight ongoing biases and anti-Black racism that is currently embedded in the practices of neuro-related research. We will explore what it means to think about data critically, from a social justice oriented lens, and to question the current status quo.

Participants are encouraged to revisit Black in Neuro’s NeuroRacism panel from this summer to gain further context and perspectives. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=inYtc5apSuk&t=1458s

Moderator: De-Shaine Murray

Panelist:
- Kafui Dzirasa, PhD

- Abeba Birhane, PhD Candidate

- Shalini Kantayya
Special Event
Watch now
Black In Neuro: Neuroracism Journal Club
 
Abstract
 
Black In Neuro will lead a journal club as the second installment of a 2-part event on neuroracism.

Thirty years ago, an international scientific project (the Human Genome project) set the goal to identify, map, and understand all of human DNA and genes. Since this project’s completion in 2003, there has been an increase of interest in precision medicine or treatment plans personalized for an individual based on their genetic make up, environment, and lifestyle. However, the human reference genome generated from the human genome project was primarily assembled from European ancestry and had a stark underrepresentation of African ancestry. In this journal club, we will meet with the authors of the 2020 CellPress Report, Missing in Action: African Ancestry in Brain Research. We will learn how underrepresentation of African ancestry in research is related to health disparities in diagnosis and treatment and discuss future steps to create inclusive science and medicine.

Moderator: Gwenaëlle Thomas

Panelists:
- Kafui Dzirasa, PhD

- Daniel Weinberger, PhD

- Alvin Hathaway, Sr., PhD
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Replay slows down with experience
Alice Berners-Lee (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ting Feng, Philips Research North America, Cambridge, MA; Delia Silva, 4 L.E.K. Life Sciences, Boston, MA; Xiaojing Wu, Comprehensive Epilepsy Ctr., NYU Langone Med. Ctr., New York, NY; Ellen Ambrose, Protenus, Baltimore, MD; Brad Pfeiffer, 7 Department of Neuroscience, UT Southwestern Medical Center, Dallas, TX; David Foster, University of California Berkeley

The hippocampus is implicated in memory formation, and neurons in the hippocampus take part in replay sequences, time-compressed reactivations of trajectories through space the animal has previously explored. These replay sequences have been proposed to be a form of memory for previously experienced places. I will present work exploring how these replays appear and change with experience. By recording from large ensembles of hippocampal neurons as rats explored novel and familiar linear tracks in various experiments, we found that hippocampal replays appear after a single experience and slow down with subsequent experience as greater detail is incorporated. We also investigated hover-and-jump dynamics within replays that are associated with the slow gamma (25-50Hz) oscillation in the LFP and found that replays slow down by adding more hover locations, corresponding to depiction of the behavioral trajectory with increased resolution. Thus, replays can reflect single experiences, and be rapidly modified by subsequent experience to incorporate more detail, consistent with their proposed role as a basic mechanism of hippocampally dependent memory.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Remembrance of things practiced: Fast and slow learning in cortical and subcortical pathways
James Murray
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
James M Murray, University of Oregon; G Sean Escola, Columbia University

The learning of motor skills unfolds over multiple timescales, with rapid initial gains in performance followed by a longer period in which the behavior becomes more refined, habitual, and automatized. While recent lesion and inactivation experiments have provided hints about how various brain areas might contribute to such learning, their precise roles and the neural mechanisms underlying them are not well understood. In this work, we propose neural- and circuit-level mechanisms by which motor cortex, thalamus, and striatum support motor learning. In this model, the combination of fast cortical learning and slow subcortical learning gives rise to a covert learning process through which control of behavior is gradually transferred from cortical to subcortical circuits, while protecting learned behaviors that are practiced repeatedly against overwriting by future learning. Together, these results point to a new computational role for thalamus in motor learning and, more broadly, provide a framework for understanding the neural basis of habit formation and the automatization of behavior through practice.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Batch Effects are Causal Effects: Applications in Human Functional Connectomes
Eric Bridgeford
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Eric W. Bridgeford, Johns Hopkins University; Michael Powell, Johns Hopkins University; Anton Alyakin, Johns Hopkins University; Brian Caffo, Johns Hopkins University; Joshua T. Vogelstein, Johns Hopkins University

Batch effects, accidental sources of variance across multiple experiments, present a substantial hurdle for statistical inference. These batch effects have been implicated in multiple widespread problems, including the reproducibility crisis. Typical batch mitigation strategies, which normalize each dataset individually, view batch mitigation fundamentally as a statistical problem. We turn this view on its head, and cast batch effects as a causal problem, namely, the experimental site causes additional sources of variation, over and above the sources of variation within site. We applied this strategy to 24 datasets in the “Consortium for Reliability and Reproducibility”. We illustrate that typical approaches amount to testing for independence, and therefore fail to address confounding variables. Such approaches are estimating the wrong estimand, and therefore, are invalid for quantifying batch effects when viewed from the causal perspective. Combining a causal view of batch mitigation with classical approaches (such as ComBat) yields satisfactory batch estimation and mitigation, while also preserving statistical patterns of interest. This framework can be applied to improve our understanding of the sources of batch effects, and enable more effective data aggregation strategies.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Playing magic tricks to deep neural networks untangles human deception
Regina Zaghi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Miguel Ángel Gea; Jordi Camí; Luis M. Martínez; Alex Gomez-Marin

Magicians have been in the business of hacking people’s minds for centuries. Some cognitive scientists, mainly those interested in attention and perception, have tried to explain why and how magic works, usually in laboratory conditions and using conventional psychophysical techniques and wisdom. Here we take a step in the opposite direction and ask not what neuroscience can do for magic but what magic can do for neuroscience in order to better understand human cognition. To that end, we studied the sleights of hand of a professional magician in the real world, upon several tricks where coins appear, disappear, multiply, and translocate. Using DeepLabCut, an AI-based pose-estimation system, we measured precisely the motor skills of the magician. We also trained the deep neural network to follow the coins, even when they were not visible. In other words, we transformed a tracking neural network into an artificial spectator. Can we fool it? Given that the neural network was trained by a human, what does it absorb and reflect about our own cognitive biases? The algorithm itself is indifferent to the speed of the magician’s performance and unaffected by change or inattentional blindness. However, just like a human spectator, the machine might still wrongly assume that a coin is in a closed fist, be uncertain, or even get “confused” when discovering it is not there. Overall, we find that the network possesses but also lacks some of the key human brain priors that grant illusionism its effectiveness. Our approach thus shows how it might be possible to use magic techniques to target the development of adversarial cognitive tricks at humans by choosing AI models that match human cognition as closely as possible. We can learn from what machines learn from us, creating a new powerful mirror to look into ourselves. 
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Contribution of descending modulation to load-dependant reduction of pain by working memory
Zoha Deldar
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Isabelle Blanchette; Mathieu Piché

Working memory (WM) engagement produces pain inhibition. However, it remains unclear whether higher WM load increases this effect. The aim of this study was to investigate the interaction between WM load and pain inhibition by WM and examine the contribution of descending inhibition. Thirty-eight healthy volunteers were assigned to one of two n-back groups for which WM load was different (2-back or 3-back). The experimental protocol comprised five counterbalanced conditions (0-back, n-back, pain, 0-back with pain, and n-back with pain). Pain and the nociceptive flexion reflex (NFR) were evoked by transcutaneous electrical stimulation of the sural nerve. Pain was significantly different between conditions, but not between n-back groups. Both the 0-back and n-back tasks reduced pain compared with pain alone, but the n-back task produced stronger pain inhibition compared with the 0-back task. NFR amplitude was significantly different between conditions but not between n-back groups. NFR was inhibited by the 0-back and n-back tasks, with no difference between the two tasks. These findings indicate that pain inhibition by WM is increased by WM load, but only to a certain point. NFR inhibition by WM suggests that inhibition of pain by WM depends, at least in part, on descending inhibition.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Examining the relationship between externalizing and internalizing behaviour and the cortico-amygdalar network in children with neurodevelopmental disorders: A multi-modal dimensional study
Hajer Nakua (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Hajer Nakua, Centre of Addiction and Mental Health, University of Toronto; Colin Hawco, Centre of Addiction and Mental Health, University of Toronto; Natalie Forde, Centre of Addiction and Mental Health, University of Toronto; Grace Jacobs, Centre of Addiction and Mental Health, University of Toronto; Michael Joseph, Centre of Addiction and Mental Health, University of Toronto; Aristotle Voineskos, Centre of Addiction and Mental Health, University of Toronto; Anne L. Wheeler, SickKids Hospital, University of Toronto; Meng-Chuan Lai, Centre of Addiction and Mental Health, University of Toronto; Peter Stazmari, Centre of Addiction and Mental Health, University of Toronto; Beth Kelley, Queens University; Xudong Liu, Queens University; Stelios Georgiades, McMaster University; Rob Nicolson, University of Western Ontario; Jennifer Crosbie, SickKids Hospital, University of Toronto; Russell Schachar, SickKids Hospital, University of Toronto; Evdokia Anagnostou, Holland Bloorview Kids Rehabilitation Hospital; Jason Lerch, SickKids Hospital, University of Toronto; Paul Arnold, Cumming School of Medicine, University of Calgary; Stephanie Ameis, Centre of Addiction and Mental Health, University of Toronto

Purpose: Children with neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs) including autism spectrum disorder (ASD), obsessive compulsive disorders (OCD) and attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) exhibit high rates of externalizing and internalizing behaviours. These behaviours have been linked to variation in cortico-amygdalar circuitry in typically developing children (TDC). Here, we examine whether cortico-amygdalar variation relates to internalizing and externalizing behaviours in children with different NDDs.
Methods: Using data from the Province of Ontario Neurodevelopmental Disorder (POND) Network, we analyzed T1 weighted, resting state fMRI and diffusion weighted data from a transdiagnostic sample of children and youth (ages 6-18 years, n=157-346) with a primary diagnosis of ASD, ADHD, or OCD, and TDC. Cross-sectional behavioral assessments from the parent-report Child Behavioral Checklist (CBCL) and multi-modal imaging were used. Associations between externalizing or internalizing behavior and cortico-amygdalar network connectivity indices (i.e. structural covariance, functional connectivity white matter connectivity) were examined using linear regressions, controlling for age, gender, and modality specific covariates.
Results: No significant associations (or diagnostic group-by-behavior interaction effects) were found between externalizing or internalizing behavior and any of the connectivity indices examined.
Conclusions: The null results of the current study do not provide evidence of a shared relationship between cortico-amygdalar network connectivity properties and externalizing or internalizing behavior across a transdiagnostic sample of children and youth. Using larger sample sizes, comprehensive behavioral batteries, and shifting the theoretical framework for examining brain-behavior relationships in transdiagnostic samples may be necessary for delineating such relationships.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Grip-specific dynamics are not shared between action and observation in the frontoparietal cortical grasping network
James Goodman
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
James Goodman, DPZ; Stefan Schaffelhofer, DPZ, cortEXplore; Hansjörg Scherberger, DPZ, University of Göttingen

Neurons in the frontoparietal cortical grasping network respond during both the execution and observation of action. This observation has been used to support numerous theories linking motor control and cognition but remains poorly understood at the population level. To address this, we use chronic multi-electrode arrays to record simultaneously from neuronal populations in the macaque primary motor (M1), premotor (F5), and posterior parietal (AIP) cortices as animals either grasp a variety of different objects or observe a human subject doing the same. We find a surprising lack of functional neuronal classes in any of these cortical areas: Instead, neurons in each area span a unimodal spectrum of sensitivities to observed action, with some neurons in F5 and AIP even preferentially active during observation. The lack of clear neuron classes suggests the link between action and observation may indeed be better understood in the framework of neural manifolds. Using demixed principal component analysis (dPCA), we find evidence for dimensions of neural activity shared between action and observation contexts, which decrease in prominence from AIP to F5 to M1. However, this activity does not include a shared representation of grip type, suggesting a lack of common representation of the specific details of the observed action. Linear classifiers confirm the lack of congruent grip representation across all dimensions of neural activity. Finally, we show that dynamical system models of the data fail to offer a unified explanation of the disparate representations of grip types across action and observation contexts. Activity during observation therefore lacks the precise grip-specific representations and dynamics seen during movement. This may reflect a non-specific mental rehearsal of movement that specifically avoids grip-potent neural dimensions to avoid making unwanted movements.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Obesity impairs cognitive function via metabolic syndrome and cerebrovascular disease: an SEM analysis in 15,000 adults from the UK Biobank
Filip Morys (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Mahsa Dadar, Laval University; Alain Dagher, McGill University

Chronic obesity is associated with several complications, including cognitive impairment and dementia. However, we have piecemeal knowledge of the mechanisms linking obesity to central nervous system damage. Candidate mechanisms are metabolic syndrome, consisting of inflammation, hypertension, dyslipidemia and insulin resistance. While there have been several neuroimaging studies linking adiposity to changes in brain morphometry, a comprehensive investigation of the relationship has so far not been done. Here we use structural equation modelling in 15,000 individuals from the UK Biobank to identify the causal chain linking adiposity to cognitive dysfunction. We found that body mass index and waist-to-hip ratio were positively related to higher plasma C-reactive protein, dyslipidemia, occurrence of hypertension and diabetes, all of which were in turn related to cerebrovascular disease as measured by volume of white matter hyperintensities on magnetic resonance imaging. White mater hyperintensities were associated with lower cortical thickness and volume and higher subcortical volumes, which were associated with cognitive deficits. We also observed that white matter dysconnectivity, as measured by fractional anisotropy and mean diffusivity, was a major cause of impaired cognition. Our results have clinical implications, supporting a role for the management of adiposity in the prevention of late-life dementia and cognitive decline.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
How mice recognize shapes: sensorimotor strategies and neuronal representations
Chris Rodgers
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Nogueira, Ramon; Pil, Christina; Greeman, Esther; Fusi, Stefano; Bruno, Randy

Humans and other animals can identify objects by active touch, requiring the coordination of exploratory motion and tactile sensation. Both the motor strategies and neural representations employed could depend on the subject’s goals. We developed a shape discrimination task that challenged head-fixed mice to discriminate concave from convex shapes. Behavioral decoding revealed that mice did this by comparing contacts across whiskers. In contrast, mice performing a shape detection task simply summed up contacts over whiskers. We recorded populations of neurons in the barrel cortex, which processes whisker input, to identify how it encoded the corresponding sensorimotor variables. Neurons across the cortical layers encoded touch, whisker motion, and task-related signals. Sensory representations were task-specific: during shape discrimination, neurons responded most robustly to behaviorally relevant whiskers, overriding somatotopy. Thus, sensory cortex can be dramatically reconfigured for the task at hand.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Offline memory replay in recurrent spiking neuronal networks
Aaron Milstein
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sarah Tran, Stanford University; Grace Ng, Stanford University; Ivan Soltesz, Stanford University

When foraging for food, rodents rapidly store memories of sequences of events including visual and sensory landmarks and behavioral choices, often based on a single experience. In parallel with behavioral learning, pyramidal neurons in the hippocampus rapidly acquire selectivity for "snippets of the animal's experience", including selectivity for spatial positions explored in the environment (a.k.a. "place fields”). We recently showed that a special event in the dendrites of pyramidal cells called a dendritic plateau potential can induce bidirectional synaptic plasticity to rapidly shift the location of a cell's place field in a single trial. Interestingly, this rapid plasticity also results in recruitment of these neurons to fire during hippocampal sharp wave/ripple events, which occur during "offline" resting periods, and often feature temporally compressed firing of neurons in the same sequential order that occurred during "online" exploration of the environment. Here we explore the circuit mechanisms of offline memory replay in a recurrent spiking neuronal network model. We tuned a simple network model with an architecture similar to hippocampal area CA3 to exhibit physiological levels of sparsity, selectivity, and rhythmicity, and found that this network can be cued by random input to emit sequences of neuronal firing resembling offline memory replay events.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The role of cingulate-motor circuits for organizing sequential choice actions
Daigo Takeuchi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Andrea Bari, RIKEN-MIT Center for Neural Circuit Genetics at the Picower Institute for Learning and Memory, MIT; Shruti Muralidhar, RIKEN-MIT Center for Neural Circuit Genetics at the Picower Institute for Learning and Memory, MIT; Dheeraj Roy, RIKEN-MIT Center for Neural Circuit Genetics at the Picower Institute for Learning and Memory, MIT; Heather A. Sullivan, McGovern Institute for Brain Research at MIT; Ian R. Wickersham, McGovern Institute for Brain Research at MIT; Susumu Tonegawa, RIKEN-MIT Center for Neural Circuit Genetics at the Picower Institute for Learning and Memory, MIT/Howard Hughes Medical Institute

Motor cortex underlies planning and the execution of complex voluntary movements. However, how motor circuits support an animal’s flexible updating of choice behaviors in the face of an abrupt change of rules remains poorly understood. Using the genetic rabies virus tracing method, we first searched for brain areas projecting to motor cortex in the rat and found that anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) is one of the major sources of projections to premotor cortex (M2 cortex) specifically. Based on this anatomical observation, we hypothesized that this cortico-cortical projection is involved in some cognitive-mnemonic aspect of animal’s planning and the execution of hierarchical (e.g., sequential) choice behaviors. To examine its potential role, we developed a behavioral task that we named conditional action sequence task (CAS -task) in which the rule dictating an animal’s response for reward is sustained within a block and is changed between consecutive blocks. Silencing excitatory neurons in ACC using an inhibitory DREADD virus disrupted an animal’s ability to flexibly adjust its choice responses following the rule switches in the task without affecting its performance in tone cue discrimination (sensory capability) or motor execution (motor capability). The same chemogenetic manipulation (silencing of excitatory neurons in ACC) altered physiological neural activity in motor cortex. Furthermore, chemogenetic inhibition at ACC terminals in M2 cortex using bilateral cannulas showed a disruption of the performance of sequential choice actions in the CAS -task. Together, these findings highlight a role of cingulate cortex and its projection to motor cortex in organizing and reorganizing hierarchical choice behaviors.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Bayesian inference of population prevalence
Robin Ince
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jim W. Kay, University of Glasgow; Philippe G. Schyns, University of Glasgow

Within neuroscience, psychology and neuroimaging, the most frequently used statistical approach is null-hypothesis significance testing (NHST) of the population mean. An alternative approach is to perform NHST within individual participants and then infer, from the proportion of participants showing an effect, the prevalence of that effect in the population. We propose a novel Bayesian method to estimate such population prevalence that offers several advantages over population mean NHST. This method provides a population-level inference that is currently missing from study designs with small participant numbers, such as in traditional psychophysics and in precision imaging. It delivers a quantitative estimate with associated uncertainty instead of reducing an experiment to a binary inference on a population mean. Bayesian prevalence is widely applicable to a broad range of studies in neuroscience, psychology and neuroimaging. Its emphasis on detecting effects within individual participants could also help address replicability issues in these fields.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Spatial Symmetry and its Relation to Grammatical Structures
Jeff Mitchell
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jeffrey S. Bowers, University of Bristol

Although there has been substantial debate over the merits of neural versus symbolic models of cognition, both approaches face a similar fundamental challenge. In each case, the set of functions available to the modeller includes every computable function, and so the fundamental question of which subset of these functions is cognitively relevant still needs to be answered, whichever toolkit is chosen. Within the symbolic approach, the Chomsky hierarchy provides an important example of possible constraints on the computational power of a formal grammar, in relation to human linguistic behaviour. In contrast, the most important constraint employed within the field of deep learning, has been the translational symmetry of image processing as implemented in convolutional networks.

Superficially at least, these appear to be two quite divergent means of limiting the space of functions, relating to the structure of space versus the syntax of natural languages. However, it is nonetheless possible to draw a connection between them. In particular, we show that imposing a convolutional structure on the memory cells of a recurrent network produces a stack like data structure, suitable for handling Context Free Grammars, the most common formalism applied to natural languages. Such an architecture reuses the symmetry under spatial translations employed within image processing applications as a method to obtain the uniformity across memory registers that is required for the same symbol to be represented at multiple locations.

Thus, despite their differences, neural and symbolic researchers have found their attention drawn to spaces of functions that share a common ingredient, in terms of translation invariance across a set of equivalent positions. More abstractly, we argue that symmetry has an important role to play in delimiting sets of interesting functions, that goes beyond just spatial translations and convolution.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Emergence of Non-Linear Mixed Selectivity in Prefrontal Cortex after Training
Wenhao Dang
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Russell J.Jaffe, Wake Forest School of Medicine;Xue-Lian Qi, Wake Forest School of Medicine; Christos Constantinidis, Wake Forest School of Medicine

Neurons in the prefrontal cortex (PFC) are typically activated by different cognitive tasks, and different context within a task. The selectivity of single neurons for the same stimulus dimension often changes depending on its context, a phenomenon known as nonlinear mixed selectivity (NMS). It has previously been hypothesized that nonlinear mixed selectivity (NMS) emerges as a result of training in Working Memory (WM). In this study, we tested this hypothesis by examining neuronal responses at different PFC areas, before and after monkeys were trained to perform different WM tasks involving visual stimuli location and/or shapes. We found that training induces a modest increase in the proportion of neurons with NMS only for spatial, but not shape feature working memory task, with area 9/46 undergoing the most significant change in NMS cell proportion. Furthermore, we also found that higher working memory task complexity, in the form of requiring to remember location and shape combinations, does not increase the degree of nonlinear mixed selectivity for stimulus shape with other task variables. Lastly, in contrast to previous finding, we saw little evidence that NMS is predictive of task performance. Our results thus provide new insights on the representation of stimuli and task information in neuronal populations in WM.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Oscillatory entrainment mechanisms and anticipatory predictive processes in autism spectrum disorder (ASD)
Shlomit Beker
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Shlomit Beker; John Foxe, Sophie Molholm

ASD is a neurodevelopmental condition that has striking effects on social communication. A less studied family of symptoms that defines it includes rigidity of routine, inflexibility of behavior and an intense desire for sameness. Studies have shown that sensory perception in this population is not flexibility adjusted to changes in the environment, and that their behavior is not influenced by prior knowledge or contextual cues. As of today, little is known about the neuronal substrates that are involved.
Using EEG on children with ASD, we found that neuronal oscillations are less in-synch with the visual periodic pictures, and show an altered anticipation for them, compared to controls. In a subsequent study on ASD adults, visual / auditory stimuli are presented in rhythmic patterns with different degrees of predictive value. Preliminary results show reduced entrainment to the central stimulation rhythm in the ASD group, in conditions where this rhythm is jittered.
We propose a neural account for the ASD phenomenology of rigidity and insistence on sameness, which could be crucial to the application of a behavioral training for children with ASD. Moreover, it can open a window for future investigation on the associated cellular and sub-cellular physiological mechanisms involved in it.

Interactive talk
Watch now
A Spiking Neural Network Model of the Motor Cortex
Lysea Munoz Haggie (she/her)
 
Abstract
 
How do networks of neurons in the motor cortex produce coordinated movements? Electrophysiological recordings in the motor areas show irregular spontaneous firing at rest and transient oscillations in neurons during movement preparation and onset. Excitatory and inhibitory activity must occur together in a balanced state to prevent chaotic dynamics. I have built a physiologically inspired, large scale spiking neural network model which replicates the spontaneous neural activity in the motor cortex using the Brian2 simulator toolbox and based on the work of Esser, et al., 2005.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Mathematical representation of neuron-glia networks.
Marco Peña-Garcia
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Nelson Castro, Instituto de Matemática Pura e Aplicada

Classical synapses are one-one. However, astrocytes play an active role in synapses, tripartite synapse. Besides, astrocytes are organized in networks, building a neuron-glia network. We propose three mathematical representations of a neuron-glia network: upsilon-family, upsilon-multiset, and upsilon-multidigraph. We represent synapses as graphs of a relation on a set of general neurons and define an upsilon-family as an indexed family of them. Then, we generate a multiset from upsilon-family to simplify it. Analogously to multidigraphs, we define isomorphism for upsilon-multisets. As a final simplification, we unnest the upsilon-multiset, getting the upsilon-multidigraph. Although upsilon-multidigraph has not multiple connections, we conjecture that it preserves isomorphism. From edges vertex of an upsilon-multidigraph, we generate a multi-topology of proper submultisets. Additionally, we create a network descriptor from a quasimetric defined over the vertex set of an upsilon-multidigraph. Finally, we roughly create a geometric realization of an upsilon-family in a three-dimensional Euclidean space. We concluded that neuron-glial network representations have a rich mathematical structure.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Cellular mechanisms of consciousness and dreaming
Jaan Aru
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Mototaka Suzuki, Humboldt University Berlin; Francesca Siclari, Centre Hospitalier Universitaire Vaudois Lausanne; William Phillips, University of Stirling; Johan F. Storm, University of Oslo; Matthew Larkum, Humboldt University Berlin

Recent breakthroughs in neurobiology indicate that the time is ripe to understand how cellular-level mechanisms are related to conscious experience. We propose that consciousness depends on the integration between two different parts of the cortical pyramidal neuron. In conscious states, these parts are coupled, thus enabling complex signal propagation and sustained dynamics within the thalamocortical system. When these parts of the pyramidal cell are functionally torn apart, such signal propagation is prohibited and consciousness breaks down. Hence, differences in global dynamics of large scale networks between conscious and unconscious states are controlled by local gates within pyramidal cells.

We further suggest that the hallmark of conscious processing is the flexible integration of bottom-up and top-down data streams enabled through dendritic integration on a cellular level. This cellular integration mechanism provides the foundation for Dendritic Information Theory (DIT). DIT offers a natural explanation for why conscious experience is modulated by context and prior knowledge.

We then explain how this mechanism can shed light on the neural mechanisms dreaming. We posit that during dreams neurons are in a state where they are driven top-down by the generative model. High acetylcholine and low noradrenaline put the pyramidal cells in a specific mode, where they are driven internally and activated through their apical dendrites. This could also be the neural mechanism for imagery and hallucinations.

Taken together, we propose a theory of how top-down and bottom-up information streams are combined on the cellular level. We think that besides illuminating the neural basis of consciousness and dreaming these ideas are relevant for figuring out the neural implementation of predictive processing and for developing novel AI algorithms.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Hippocampal replay alterations following moderate prenatal alcohol exposure
Ryan Harvey
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ryan E. Harvey, University of New Mexico; Laura E. Berkowitz, University of New Mexico; Benjamin J. Clark, University of New Mexico

Prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE) is among the most common developmental insults to the nervous system and is characterized by memory impairment. There is a need to identify physiological changes that help explain this memory impairment. Hippocampal sharp-wave ripples (SPW-Rs) and associated replay events are potential candidates as they are the electrophysiological signatures of memory reactivation and consolidation. Here, we tested the hypothesis that SPW-Rs and replay events are altered following PAE. To test this hypothesis, we recorded single-unit and local field potentials from hippocampal subregions CA1 & CA3 of moderate PAE & control rats while they made laps on a linear track and while at rest on a pedestal. Preliminary findings suggest that replay and SPW-Rs are altered following PAE. Specifically, replayed trajectories are truncated and SPW-R frequencies are slowed. The results from these experiments provide a novel framework for investigating hippocampal mechanisms of memory impairment associated with PAE and may also provide potential functional biomarkers following PAE.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Motor skill learning and execution in a distributed brain network
Steffen Wolff
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ashesh Dhawale, Harvard University; Raymond Ko, Harvard University; Bence Olveczky, Harvard University

The remarkable capacity of the brain to acquire and execute motor skills depends on a distributed motor network. While many components have been identified, less is known about their specific roles and interactions during skill learning and execution. Here we probe this network through the lens of complex, spatiotemporally precise motor sequences we train in rats. We focus on the basal ganglia and the contributions made by their main inputs, from motor cortex and thalamus, respectively. Using electrophysiological recordings, we find that the dorsolateral striatum (DLS), the main motor-related input nucleus of the basal ganglia, encodes the detailed kinematic structure of the learned motor sequences. We further show that a loss of the DLS renders animals unable to execute the learned idiosyncratic motor patterns, causing them to revert to simple species-typical behaviors. In addition, we find that not only the DLS, but also its motor cortical inputs are necessary for learning the skills we train. This very same pathway, however, becomes dispensable after the behaviors are acquired. In line with this, the loss of motor cortical inputs leaves the DLS activity encoding the kinematic structure of the behavior largely unaffected. In contrast, thalamic inputs to the DLS remain crucial for the generation of the learned skills and loss of these inputs disrupts performance akin to DLS lesions, causing a reversion to the same species-typical behavior. Together, our results suggest that the basal ganglia can play a role in the control of complex learned behaviors which goes beyond traditional models of basal ganglia function. They further suggest that motor cortex ‘tutors’ sub-cortical motor circuits during learning, potentially by guiding plasticity at thalamostriatal synapses. Such adaptive reprogramming of lower-level motor circuits may broaden their flexibility and allow them to store and generate complex learned motor skills.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Quantifying causality with quasi-experiments
Tony Liu (he/him)
 
Abstract
 
Causality is at the heart of many important questions in science, as the goal is often to either inform decision making or understand the underlying mechanisms of a system. Though causal ground truth is typically obtained through conducting experiments, experimentation can often be impractical or infeasible, and we would like to be able to obtain causality from observational data if possible. Econometrics has, over decades of focused work, developed a rich toolkit for estimating causal effects from non-experimental data exploiting (quasi) random variation in existing data, so-called quasi-experiments. Here we review such approaches and how they can be combined with machine learning to answer causal questions across domains such as medicine, society, and neuroscience.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Data-driven automatic exercise feedback
Nidhi Seethapathi (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Titipat Achakulvisut, University of Pennsylvania; Vanessa Moody, University of Pennsylvania; Irene Jeong, University of Pennsylvania; Konrad Kording, University of Pennsylvania

The current approach to correct a trainee’s exercise technique relies on expert feedback based on visual and qualitative assessment. Emerging computer vision-based pose estimation algorithms, built using neural networks, have extraordinary potential to automate and quantify the process of exercise training and injury prediction from videos. In this study, we build an automated pipeline with computer vision, machine learning and predictive modeling to translate weightlifting videos into insights and feedback without human overview. We first curated over 600 videos of people performing a deadlift from online forums along with natural language feedback provided by forum users in the form of over 1500 comments. Body pose information from these videos were obtained with the use of a computer vision-based pose estimation software called OpenPose. The pose data thus obtained was processed using dynamic time warping so as to align and normalize the videos with each other in time and space for ease of comparison. Using unsupervised machine learning in the form of principal component analysis and k-nearest neighbours clustering, we automatically classify well performed deadlifts from poorly performed ones. Further, we outline a procedure using natural language processing to create a virtual trainer who provides interpretable feedback by analyzing the nature of deviations in the movements of a given video from example expert movements. We envision the automated pipeline used here as being generalizable to other exercises thus, setting the stage for the use of artificial intelligence in exercise training and injury prediction.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Effects of procrastination on task shifting and prospective memory
Illia Kuznietsov
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Zhuravlova Olena, Zhuravlov Oleksandr, Kachynska Tetiana, Abramchuk Olha

Current studies of procrastination are focusing mainly on psychological aspects, while neurobiological side of this phenomenon remains poorly understood. So far, procrastination does not mean forgetting the tasks, but rather completing less important tasks first while postponing and keeping more important in mind, we hypothesize, that mechanisms of shifting between tasks and mechanisms of prospective memory will be more active in procrastinators in comparison with non-procrastinators. Based on this assumption we conducted an event-related potentials (ERP) study on subjects with different level of procrastination. Subjects were divided into 2 groups with high (8 subjects) and low (7 subjects) level of procrastination based on Pure procrastination scale test. ERPs were recorded during three experimental conditions: under the load of perceptual prospective memory, under the load of conceptual prospective memory and under task-shift paradigm. Responses and corresponding reaction time were recorded as well. Here we present the results of response analysis. No significant differences between studied groups were obtained for perceptual prospective memory task. During conceptual prospective memory task, the number of correct answers was significantly higher in procrastinators, than in non-procrastinators. Giving wrong answers, non-procrastinators had significantly higher reaction time, than procrastinators did. For task shift activity, reaction time was higher in procrastinators in shift condition. We suppose, that observed results show higher level of activation of conceptual prospective memory mechanisms in procrastinators, which should be reflected in the features of recorded ERPs.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Is left-behind a real reason for children’s social cognition deficit? An fNIRS study on the effect of social interaction on left-behind preschooler’s prefrontal activation
Keya Ding
 
Coauthors, Abstract
