Keya Ding, Key Laboratory of Child Development & Learning Science, Ministry of Education, School of Biological science and medical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing, China; Chuanjiang Li, Hangzhou College of Early Childhood Teacher's Education, Zhejiang Normal University, Hangzhou, China; Huibin Jia, School of Psychology, Henan University, Kaifeng, China; Mingming Zhang, School of Psychology, Shanghai Normal University, Shanghai, China; Dongchuan Yu, Key Laboratory of Child Development & Learning Science, Ministry of Education, School of Biological science and medical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing, China.

Parent out-migration has marked a common social issue in the rural area of China. Accumulated researches provided evidences that, early parent-child separation leads to the deficits in cognitive processes, education, emotion and health. However, the neural level of deficits of social cognition, which induced by parent-child separation in rural China is unclear. To evaluate these, we compared brain activation (the social interaction difference) and behavioral differences between 81 non /partially /completely left-behind children ages of 52-76 months (mean = 64.98 ± 6.321 months) in two joint attention tasks, i.e., IJA: initiating joint attention and RJA: response to joint attention, which was implemented with different interactive objects (teacher and stranger). Results demonstrated that higher prefrontal cortex (PFC) activation during joint attention tasks, higher activation in responding to stranger than teacher, especially in IJA, and the activation of joint attention positively associated with language score, cognitive flexibility and facial expression recognition. More importantly, partially-left-behind children evoked a higher brain activation in IJA tasks and presented a higher language level than completely/non-left-behind children. This study provided insight to neural basis in the development of left-behind children in rural China and revealed ‘Left-behind’ would not take the full responsibility of children’s social cognition deficits, family economic level and ‘left-behind’ together could contribute to the lower social cognition and brain development in children.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Auditory Corticothalamic Neurons are Recruited by Motor Preparatory Inputs
Kameron Clayton
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kameron Clayton, Harvard Medical School; Ross Williamson, University of Pittsburgh; Gen-ichi Tasaka, Hebrew University of Jerusalem; Adi Mizrahi, Hebrew University of Jerusalem; Troy Hackett, Vanderbilt University Medical Center; Daniel Polley, Harvard Medical School;

During active sensing, neural responses to sensory inputs directly generated by our own movements are suppressed. In the auditory cortex (ACtx), self-initiated movements elicit corollary discharge from secondary motor cortex (M2) that suppresses pyramidal neuron (PyrN) spiking via recruitment of local inhibitory neurons. Using single unit electrophysiology, we observed that ACtx layer (L)6 PyrNs were also activated hundreds of milliseconds prior to movement onset, at approximately the same time as fast spiking inhibitory neurons. Most L6 PyrNs were corticothalamic (CT) cells, which all expressed FoxP2, a protein marker enriched in brain areas that integrate sensory inputs to control vocal motor behaviors. Using a combination of two-photon calcium imaging and optogenetically targeted single unit recordings, we found that L6 CTs were strongly activated prior to orofacial movements, but not locomotion. The specific recruitment by facial movements suggests that L6 CTs may receive a different source of motor input, beyond M2. Monosynaptic rabies tracing revealed that L6 CTs received ten times more direct inputs from the basal ganglia than M2.
Our prior work found that optogenetic activation of L6 CTs reset the phase of low-frequency ACtx oscillations, modified sensory tuning in the thalamus and cortex, and switched perception into modes of enhanced detection or enhanced discrimination. Here, we show that preparatory facial movements can act like an optogenetic pulse, possibly priming cortical circuits for vocal feedback monitoring. These findings identify new pathways and local circuits for motor modulation of sound processing and suggest a new role for CT neurons in active sensing.
Traditional talk
Watch now
On the generation of theta rhythms and theta-gamma phase amplitude coupling.
Alexandra Chatzikalymniou
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Alexandra Chatzikalymniou, Krembil Research Institute, University Health Network, Toronto ON, CA, Department of Physiology, University of Toronto, Toronto ON, CA; Frances K Skinner, Krembil Research Institute, University Health Network, Toronto ON, CA, Department of Physiology, University of Toronto, Toronto ON, CA;

In the hippocampus, the 3-12 Hz local field potential (LFP) theta oscillation is a rhythm strongly correlated with spatial navigation, episodic memory and rapid-eye-movement (REM) sleep. As such, understanding the origin of this rhythm could shed light on the emergence of such cognitive phenomena. However, how the large variety of inhibitory and excitatory cell types form a theta-generating network remains unknown. We use a previously published full CA1 hippocampus model of unprecedented biological detail to understand the generation mechanism of theta rhythms. The model contains eight morphologically detailed interneuron types and pyramidal cells and is constructed based on experimentally derived connectivity. We find that a 400 μm thick, isolated segment (slice) of this hippocampus model, represents the minimum network that can generate theta rhythms. Guided explorations of this computationally tractable model reveal that theta rhythms are initiated by the pyramidal cells but are regularized by inhibitory inputs from parvalbumin positive fast-firing cells, supporting an “inhibition-based tuning” mechanism. We find a strong correlation between the net input current to the pyramidal cells and the resulting theta frequency, inferring that the intrinsic pyramidal cell properties are theta frequency controllers. We next investigate the control of external input drives to the theta rhythms of the segment model, including the recently discovered inputs from the subiculum. Finally, we leverage our insights to explain the termination mechanism of theta bursts and the theta/gamma phase-amplitude coupling in the original full CA1 model. As modern pharmacological approaches focus on cellular and subcellular targets, our models can be used to identify cellular-specific pathways underlying changes in LFP theta/gamma rhythms. In turn, this opens up avenues for clinical translation.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Aging affects attentional span and perception in the periphery
Julie Ouerfelli-Éthier
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Noémie Redureau, University of Montreal; Laure Pisella, ImpAct, INSERM UM1028, CNRS UMR 5292, University Claude Bernard Lyon 1; Aarlenne Z. Khan, University of Montreal

Aging has been associated with decline in perceptual and cognitive function, but the findings remain inconclusive. Here we tested how attentional window, i.e. how widely we can distribute our attention around a certain fixation location when searching for an item among distractors, changes with aging. Specifically, we investigated whether aging resulted in a decrease in attentional window during easy or parallel visual search (global processing). We also tested whether performance in visual search was related to perceptual visual function with a contrast detection task and two motion tasks (local and global motion perception) at two different eccentricities (5° and 10° eccentricity). We measured the size of the attentional window using different sized gaze-contingent visible windows in 12 younger adults and 11 older adults during a pop-out visual search task. Older adults showed a significantly smaller attentional window (M = 19.4°, SD = 3.3°) compared to younger adults (M = 23.2°, SD = 2.3°). They also had significantly higher contrast detection thresholds (M older = 9.3%, SD older = 5.1%; M younger = 4.5%, SD younger = 2.8%) and required longer durations to estimate global motion (M older = 442.8 ms, SD older = 214.2 ms; M younger = 181.4 ms, SD younger = 75.3 ms). In contrast, we found no difference in local motion perception thresholds between groups. Taken together, our results suggest interactions between attentional and perceptual deficits may explain impaired visual function in older adults.

The event is divided into three session to focus on 1) Tools (probes, optics, cellular, molecular), 2) Tech (software, hardware), and 3) Theory (modeling, computation), with trainees integrated in each session. Each session will include five brief talks/demos showcasing new tools, techniques, or theories from US BRAIN Initiative toolmakers followed by a moderated discussion with Q/A.

This is session 2/3, focused on Tech (software, hardware).

Novel functions of oligodendrocytes and myelin in axonal energy metabolism
Klaus Nave 		Keynote Event
Watch now
Neural and Biomechanical Correlates of Post-Stroke Gait Retraining
Trisha Kesar
Interactive talk
Watch now
Development of cortical projections to the brainstem vs. cervical spinal cord
Julia Kaiser
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Payal Patel; Jimena Perez-Tetuan; Nirupama Angira; Vibhu Sahni

For skilled motor control, corticospinal neurons (CSN) must make precise connections with segmentally appropriate targets – from rostral targets in the brainstem and cervical spinal cord for forelimb control, to caudal targets in thoracic and lumbar cord for trunk and hindlimb control. However, mechanisms controlling CSN axon targeting to specific spinal segments remained largely unknown. Previous work in the Sahni lab identified that CSN axons exhibit striking axon extension specificity at the transition between cervical and thoracic spinal segments. Crim1+ CSN axons extend past this transition zone into the thoracic and lumbar spinal cord, i.e. Crim1 expression prospectively delineates thoraco-lumbar projecting CSN (CSNTL). We hypothesized that there are likely additional transition zones that function in establishing segmentally specific CSN connectivity. We have investigated the early projection targeting specificity at one such transition zone – between the brainstem and cervical spinal cord. Indeed, we find that the majority of CSN axons (60-80%) do not extend further than the brainstem early in development (P0), establishing them as brainstem-projecting CSN (CSNB). A subset of these CSNB can be molecularly identified by the expression of Kelch Like 14 (Klhl14) a member of the BTB-Kelch superfamily of proteins. In future experiments, we will test whether Klhl14 is necessary and sufficient to limit CSN axon extension to the brainstem by loss- and gain-of-function experiments. Transcriptional profiling of CSNB at this likely critical, early developmental step will also likely enable identification of additional genes that potentially control CSN axonal targeting to the brainstem.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Symbolic methods for neural dynamics and emergent network behavior in a swim CPG
Krishna Pusuluri
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Huiwen Ju, Georgia State University; Andrey Shilnikov, Georgia State University

We present an approach based on the symbolic dynamics of voltage wave forms and parametric sweeps to study complex behaviors arising in models of individual neurons and rhythmic neural circuits. This method is employed for the bottom up reconstruction of a 4-cell circuit, modeled after the swim central pattern generator (CPG) of the sea slug Dendronotus Iris. We model the circuit under variations of intrinsic cell properties and external parameters that can be controlled in neurophysiological experiments, starting from individual cells and ascending upwards to pairs of half center oscillators, all the way up to the fully connected 4-cell circuit with multiple inhibitory, excitatory and electrical synapses. We analyze diverse activity types in isolated neurons such as tonic spiking, quiescence, or intrinsic bursting, and determine their bifurcation boundaries. We show how chaotic behavior can arise near activity transitions. Using an extended encoding scheme for coupled neurons, we demonstrate emergent network phenomena that can not be readily inferred from individual neuron properties. We demonstrate how a half-center oscillator (HCO), composed of two mutually inhibiting neurons, can produce anti-phase bursting oscillations, even when individual cells are not intrinsic bursters, as is seen through experimental neurophysiology. Through detailed parametric sweeps, we find appropriate model parameters to replicate experimentally determined CPG behavior, temporal characteristics and emergent 4-cell network bursting, where neither the individual cells nor the HCO pairs can themselves sustain bursting, without the synergistic interactions of excitation, inhibition and electric coupling in the full swim CPG circuit.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Presaccadic stimulus affects postsaccadic neural activity during realistic visual search
Atanas Stankov
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Atanas D Stankov, City College of New York; Jonathan Touryan, Army Research Lab; Stephen Gordon, Army Research Lab; Jason Ki, City College of New York; Lucas Parra, City College of New York;

Little is known about visual processing during realistic visual search in dynamic environments. Saccades during free viewing generate large neural responses, which have been linked to enhanced visual processing during the subsequent fixations. The content of fixation prior to a saccade is known to modulate post-saccading processing during free viewing of static images. But this phenomenon has not yet been established for more realistic dynamic visual stimuli. To emulate a natural setting, subjects were asked to detect visual targets that appear on the road while being driven through a 3D virtual town. We predicted that target- and saccade-evoked potentials are modulated by the visibility of those targets and their location in the visual field. Virtual “fog” reduced the visibility of targets, and decreased target- and saccade-evoked potentials, as expected. Saccade-evoked responses were stronger when saccades are prompted by a target appearing on the road as compared to spontaneous saccades. When targets appeared in peripheral vision, they elicited larger eye movements with a concomitant increase in saccade-evoked response. However, contrary to our expectations, targets elicited similar evoked responses regardless of where they appeared in the visual field. In conclusion, visibility of stimuli appearing before saccades affect post-saccadic processing. However, differences in neural responses to events occurring in foveal vs peripheral vision, could not be disentangled from differences in saccade behavior.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Cerebellar modulation of midbrain freezing-related circuitry
Christopher Vaaga (He/His)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Spencer T Brown, Northwestern University; Indira M Raman, Northwestern University

Innate defensive behaviors promote survival by allowing animals to detect and respond to threats within their environment, such as predators. Although innate, these defensive behaviors show a remarkable amount of flexibility and are subject to robust habituation, suggesting that the circuitry underlying defensive behaviors is subject to modulatory control. Using a combination of viral tracing and slice electrophysiology, we show that the cerebellum may provide one source of afferent modulatory influence within the periaqueductal gray by preferentially synapsing onto local dopaminergic neurons within the vlPAG. In turn, vlPAG dopamine neurons altered the relative strength of synaptically evoked inhibition and excitation onto transgenically identified freezing premotor neurons in the vlPAG. More specifically, activation of postsynaptic D2 receptors increased the strength of inhibition and decreased the strength of excitation. Such modulation is predicted to increase spike threshold and alter the gain of the input-output relationship, thereby changing the integrative properties of freezing premotor neurons. Together, these results suggest that locally released dopamine within the vlPAG modulates synaptic integration in freezing related neurons, which is controlled, at least in part, by input from the cerebellum.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Simulation-based inference of neural models from large-scale single-neuron electrophysiology
Joseph Nelson
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tom Chartrand

Mechanistic models are useful tools in neuroscience for testing whether proposed mechanisms are consistent with experimental data. Further, biophysically-detailed neural models can help infer parameters that are not easily measurable, such as ionic channel densities. Recent advances in likelihood-free statistical inference have given neuroscientists the opportunity to use both these biophysically-detailed models and statistical inference in their analyses. We test a new inference tool, which incorporates these recent advances, on the Allen Institute Cell Types Database. Sequential Neural Posterior Estimation (SNPE) is a tool for fast identification of model parameters consistent with both a chosen prior distribution and experimental data. SNPE trains an artificial neural network on synthetic data, using this trained network to estimate the posterior distribution of model parameters from experimental data. Previous studies have tested SNPE on a homogenous set of experimental protocols. For this study, we explore the viability of SNPE in a different context, by testing SNPE on a more diverse set of experiments. Our test dataset is derived from surgical samples from the human brain, with neurons tested adaptively at different current levels. To accommodate this diverse dataset, we use high-level features that generalize across experimental sweeps, rather than features from a particular neuron's voltage trace. We simulate two neural models, with parameters drawn from an informed prior distribution, and compute these high-level features from this synthetic data. With these synthetic features and SNPE, we conduct amortized simulation-based inference (SBI) on our dataset. We find that our amortized SBI across this dataset produces models inconsistent with the electrophysiological data, using both a reduced and conductance-based model. These inconsistent results show the difficulties of using SNPE in this new context, the sensitivity of SBI to feature selection, and the challenge of selecting a prior.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Is the brain macroscopically linear? A system identification of resting state dynamics
Erfan Nozari
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jennifer Stiso; Lorenzo Caciagli; Eli J. Cornblath; Xiaosong He; Maxwell A. Bertolero; Arun S. Mahadevan; George J. Pappas; and Danielle S. Bassett

A central challenge in the computational modeling of neural dynamics is the trade-off between accuracy and simplicity. At the level of individual neurons, nonlinear dynamics are both experimentally established and essential for neuronal functioning. One may therefore expect the collective dynamics of massive net- works of such neurons to only increase in their complexity, thereby supporting an expanded repertoire of nonlinear behaviors. An implicit assumption has thus formed that an “accurate” computational model of whole-brain dynamics must inevitably be nonlinear whereas linear models may provide a first-order approximation. To what extent this assumption holds, however, has remained an open question. Here, we provide a rigorous and data-driven answer at the level of whole-brain blood-oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) and macroscopic field potential dynamics by leveraging the theory of system identification. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and intracranial electroencephalography (iEEG), we model the spon- taneous, resting state activity of 700 subjects in the Human Connectome Project (HCP) and 122 subjects from the Restoring Active Memory (RAM) project using state-of-the-art linear and nonlinear model fam- ilies. We assess relative model fit using predictive power, computational complexity, and the extent of residual dynamics unexplained by the model. Contrary to our expectations, linear auto-regressive models achieve the best measures across all three metrics, eliminating the trade-off between accuracy and simplic- ity. To understand and explain this linearity, we highlight four properties of macroscopic neurodynamics which can counteract or mask microscopic nonlinear dynamics: averaging over space, averaging over time, observation noise, and limited data samples. Whereas the latter two are technological limitations and can improve in the future, the former two are inherent properties of aggregate macroscopic brain activity. Our results demonstrate the discounted potential of linear models in accurately capturing macroscopic brain dynamics. This, together with the unparalleled interpretability of linear models, can greatly facilitate our understanding of macroscopic neural dynamics, which in turn may facilitate the principled design of model-based interventions for the treatment of neuropsychiatric disorders.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Hippocampal Modulation of the Stress Response
Victoria Turner
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Mazen Kheirbek, UCSF

An essential adaptive function of the nervous system is to organize appropriate physiological and behavioral responses in the face of stressful situations. However, this process can become dysregulated in psychiatric disease. Characterizing the neural circuits that modify the adaptive stress response is essential to understand how the brain regulates responses to stressful stimuli and how that regulation can go awry.
Here we use optogenetics, DREADDs, and in vivo calcium imaging to investigate whether the hippocampus modulates hypothalamic CRH stress responses. Our results suggest how the ventral hippocampus (vHPC) exerts top-down control over the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus (PVN) to regulate responses to a stressful foot shock stimulus.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Multiplane Mesoscope reveals distinct cortical interactions following expectation violations
Farzaneh Najafi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Natalia Orlova*, Dmitri Tsyboulski*, Sam Seid, Sara Kivikas, India Kato, Marina Garrett, Doug Ollerenshaw, Shawn R. Olsen, Peter Groblewski, Peter Saggau#, Jérôme Lecoq#

Cortical columns interact through dynamic routing of neuronal activity. To monitor these interactions, we developed the Multiplane Mesoscope which allow simultaneous imaging of 8 cortical planes. The Multiplane Mesoscope allowed us to study cortical column interactions in excitatory and inhibitory subpopulations in behaving mice. We found that distinct cortical subnetworks represent expected and unexpected events, suggesting that expectation violations modify signal routing across cortical columns, and establishing the Multiplane Mesoscope as a unique platform to study signal routing.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Facilitation of transmission at axonal branch points by nodal GABA receptors: simulations with a reconstructed proprioceptive axon model
Noah Pardell
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jones KE, Neuroscience and Mental Health Institute, University of Alberta; Bennett DJ, Neuroscience and Mental Health Institute, University of Alberta

Large myelinated proprioceptive afferents branch profusely after entering the dorsal spinal cord en route to their postsynaptic targets in the intermediate and ventral lamina of the spinal cord. At each branch point there is a risk that the action potential will fail to propagate (branch point failure). Recent immunolabelling results have found that branch points are near nodes containing both voltage-gated Na+ channels and GABA_A receptors. Historically, GABA receptors on these sensory axons have been associated with presynaptic inhibition mediated by primary afferent depolarization. We used computer simulations of a previously reconstructed axon collateral branching pattern from a cat proprioceptive afferent to answer two questions: 1) how common is branch point failure, and 2) do GABA_A receptors increase the probability of failure?

The geometry, branching, and myelination pattern of the axon collateral generated large regions of the g_Na/g_K parameter space where action potentials failed to propagate. Branch point failure was a common feature in the absence of GABA_A receptor activation. Coincident activation of GABA_A receptors facilitated transmission of action potentials, rescuing branch point failure rather than exacerbating it. These results are consistent with the emerging idea that transmission along somatosensory axon collaterals in the spinal cord is primed by nodal GABA_A receptors.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Critical behavior in networks of inhibitory-excitatory spiking neurons with weak synaptic efficacy
Brandon Benson
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jonathan Kadmon, Stanford University; Surya Ganguli, Stanford University

Cortical circuits exhibit a rich dynamical behavior with irregular individual neuron firing rates, global oscillations, synchronization, scale-free fluctuations and high sensitivity to certain stimuli. While classical theories of inhibitory and excitatory (IE) neurons explain these behaviors, they require different synaptic properties. The coexistence of the observed behaviors suggests that the network may be operating at a near-critical regime. A recent study by Girardi-Schappo et. al. portrayed the phase space of IE neurons with binary activation, discrete-time dynamics, and stochastic threshold. The binary model presents qualitatively similar states to those of IE spiking neurons and the authors identified a critical point of the Direct Percolation (DP) universality class, namely a transition between an absorbing and an active network state often associated with a critical branching process. However, the existence and nature of the critical point in the case of more realistic spiking dynamics are still at question. In this work, we return the leaky iterate-and-fire (LIF) model, which was studies in the context of IE networks. We study its mean-field dynamics around the proposed critical point. When the total synaptic efficacy is of the order of the threshold -- a limit not previously studied -- stable activity with slow oscillations persists well into the unstable excitatory regime. This slow-oscillations phase is bounded by SNIC and Hopf bifurcation lines which meet at the proposed critical point. We find that along the Hopf bifurcation, the system exhibits scale-free avalanches with sub-critical scaling exponents that conform with in vivo cortical slice preparations. Importantly, we show that the microscopic dynamics cannot be understood as a critical-branching process. We further discuss our results in relation to sensitivity for perturbation, and to recent experiments of in vivo optogenetic perturbations in the visual cortex.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Are colour experiences equivalent across the visual field?
Ariel Zeleznikow-Johnston
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ariel Zeleznikow-Johnston, Monash University; Naotsugu Tsuchiya, Monash University

Perplexingly, our naïve impression of a vividly coloured experience across the visual field is challenged on empirical and theoretical grounds. Empirically, recent findings that subjects can be unaware of extensive desaturation of their peripheral vision demonstrates that our experiences have no guarantee of accuracy with respect to the external world (veridicality). Theoretically, objective verification of colour experience is hampered by claims that some subjective properties of experience are private and incommunicable. As a result, the connection between internal colour experience and external light properties seems arbitrary. This is epitomised by the "inverted qualia" argument, which posits the plausibility of different wavelength-experience mappings between individuals (e.g. colour inversion).

Here, we tested a reduced version of this claim by searching for evidence of colour inversion from central to peripheral vision within subjects. We sought to determine this by obtaining subjective similarity judgments between pairs of colours presented at varying eccentricities. We deemed colour experiences equivalent if stimuli presented at different eccentricities elicited equivalent similarity relationships. We tested for the possibility of inversion by seeing whether artificially swapping peripheral colour labels during analysis would decrease these correlations. Additionally, we investigated whether the presence/absence of accounting for cortical magnification by using stimuli scaled by eccentricity affected these similarity judgments.

Using dissimilarity analysis, we found that the similarity judgments between experiences induced by coloured stimuli were highly correlated regardless of the eccentricity of presentation. Our preliminary analysis suggests that swapping the colour labels (e.g. inversion) produced detectable decreases in correlations between central and peripheral dissimilarity judgments. Additionally, we found that similarity judgments between experiences induced by unscaled (but not scaled) stimuli decreased in correlation as stimulus size decreased.

These results do not support the possibility of colour inversion across the visual field and instead suggest the equivalence of central and peripheral colour experiences, irrespective of veridicality.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Quantification of active and passive defense responses in head-fixed mice.
Pia-Kelsey O'Neill
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jozsef Meszaros

Animals display a variety of defensive behaviors in response to aversive stimuli. The particular response that an animal selects may depend on the proximity of the threat, competing stimuli, or the animal's internal state. Responses to an aversive stimuli are diverse and dynamic, and capturing this complexity while also collecting neurophysiological data has been a challenge. In the virtual burrow assay, mice display both active and passive learned responses to odorants that have been associated with an aversive stimulus. As previously described, mice in this virtual burrow will actively ingress (entering the burrow enclosure) or passively tremble (leading to small oscillations in the burrow position). Here, we developed a method to compare and quantify ingresses and trembles. We observed tremble responses that consist of a 4-6Hz oscillation. These responses are more prominent during the presentation of aversive conditioned stimuli (both in duration and magnitude). Tremble, like ingress, undergoes extinction, but is not associated with ingress responses and thus seems to reflect a distinct behavioral response.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
When are open- and closed-loop control necessary for causal inference in neural circuits?
Adam Willats (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Adam Willats, Georgia Institute of Technology & Emory University; Matthew O'Shaughnessy, Georgia Institute of Technology; Kyle Johnsen, Georgia Institute of Technology & Emory University; Christopher Rozell, Georgia Institute of Technology

Many hypotheses about neural circuits are best stated in terms of causal relationships: “Activity in this region causes an observed change in that downstream region.” Furthermore, the development of effective therapeutic interventions requires knowledge of the causal relationship between potential therapies, markers of disease states, and patient outcomes. However, in experiments where interventions such as lesioning are unavailable, a key ambiguity remains as to whether activity is correlated across two populations because of a structural feedforward connection, or instead arises through recurrent connections or unseen, confounding common inputs. Closed-loop approaches appear to be a promising solution because they can hold regions constant, decoupling them from confounding feedback pathways while maintaining naturalistic activity levels.
However, despite the increasing interest in closed-loop control from the systems neuroscience community, it is still poorly understood in which settings these approaches are necessary, and how best to design interventions. What is needed is a characterization of how and when closed-loop control improves identification in representative simulations of neural circuits.
In this work we (1) summarize and integrate the existing understanding of network identification across several fields: systems neuroscience, control theory, and causal inference; (2) present a simplified approach for predicting whether two circuit hypotheses may be distinguished from data collected with passive, open-loop or closed-loop experiments; and (3) use a small network simulation of integrate and fire neurons to illustrate how network properties, including synaptic strength and internal time constants, impact how well the underlying causal structure of a circuit can be reconstructed.
While this work examines a simple set of circuits, we hope that it facilitates a broader discussion around how to design interventions, and how to understand the limits of causal identification across a broad range of neural systems.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Braisian Networks: A Bayesian-like Connectionist Model Displaying Flexible Learning and Network Wide Bursting.
Tsvi Achler
 
Abstract
 
Rigorous models of brain recognition (of how information is obtained, evaluated & stored) are essential to assess understanding, guide experiments and research strategies especially since understanding recognition is necessary for understanding most other brain functions. The most brain-like models are Bayesian Networks because they display logic and control through priors and likelihoods, but are neither connectionist (implementable with neurons) nor scalable because distributions must be calculated. Neural Networks are connectionist during recognition and scalable, but likelihoods and priors are not accessible and distributions are embedded into synaptic weights during learning through a complex rehearsal mechanism emulating shuffling casino card dealers. Unfortunately this rehearsal is difficult to model with neurons (thus not connectionist during learning) and the nuances of rehearsal for synaptic weight learning are commonly ignored in models, confounding understanding. Moreover neither of the above models shows brain phenomena such as Network-Wide Bursting (NWB). If real brains at a resting state are presented with a new or unexpected stimulus, neurons show a fast increase in activation (NWB of many neurons) followed by a slower inhibition, until the network settles again to a resting state. We introduce Braisian Networks with connectionist regulatory feedback connections that iterate during recognition and essentially estimate distributions. They allow flexible brain-like learning of likelihoods without rehearsal or distributions thus are connectionist both during learning and recognition. We demonstrate flexibility by learning common data sets in an order that is not suited for neural networks and the NWB phenomenon as a fundamental outcome of the network. Our goal is for neuroscientists to adopt more rigorous brain-like connectionist models both during recognition and learning to accelerate the field forward.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
A role of pannexin-1 channels in an experimental zebrafish model for Parkinson’s Disease
Georg S Zoidl
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Georg R. Zoidl, York University

Pannexins (Panx) are a group of channel proteins abundantly expressed in the central nervous system and many vertebrates' tissues. The channels play essential roles in transporting Ca2+ and ATP. Panx1 is implicated in epilepsy, stroke, trauma, inflammation, or pain. A role in Parkinson’s disease has been proposed, but evidence thus far is lacking. Here, the locomotor activity and visual-motor response of wild-type Tupfel longfin and panx1a knockout zebrafish larvae were tested after treatment with 1-methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine (MPTP). MPTP is known to induce Parkinson's disease-like effects in the zebrafish by blocking the Complex I in mitochondria. Short term treatment with MPTP caused a decrease in the movement of the larvae. Locomotor activity worsened after incubation with Panx1 inhibitors probenecid and mefloquine. The analysis of biomarker expression levels demonstrated the upregulation of genes in panx1a knockout larvae with known functions in mitochondrial health and dopamine synthesis. A transcriptome analysis authenticated a broad dysregulation of metabolic processes, such as those affecting mitochondrial health. It was concluded that panx1a channels play roles in maintaining metabolic homeostasis in the zebrafish. Loss-of-function contributes to the severity of outcomes in the MPTP model of Parkinson's disease.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Automated Neuron Tracing of Sparse Fluorescently Labeled Neurons
Thomas Athey
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jeremias Sulam, JHU; Joshua T. Vogelsetin, JHU; Daniel Tward, JHU; Ulrich Mueller, JHU; Michael I. Miller, JHU

Recent advances in brain clearing and imaging have made it possible to image entire mammalian brains at sub-micron resolution. These images offer the potential to assemble brain-wide atlases of neuron morphology, but manual neuron tracing remains a bottleneck. Here we present an automated tracing pipeline that leverages a hidden Markov model to allow tracers to intervene in the areas of least confidence, and utilizes dynamic programming to scale to large image data.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Microsurgical lesions identify segmentally distinct responses of axotomized corticospinal neurons
Carolin Ruven
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Vibhu Sahni, Ph.D.

It remains well established that the intrinsic ability of neurons for axon regeneration declines with age. Despite significant work, we still do not precisely know how and when do neurons lose this intrinsic ability during development. This is because conventional models of injury produce an injury response and disrupt potential guidance cues required for axon growth. Such models cannot therefore precisely delineate the intrinsic ability of neurons for axon regrowth. We aimed to investigate intrinsic ability of axonal regeneration during development, at a time when appropriate guidance cues are still expressed in their appropriate context. To this end, we have established a novel, reproducible, approach to transect developing corticospinal neuron (CSN) axons in the neonatal spinal cord. In this new approach, the corticospinal tract (CST) is injured using a beveled micropipette vibrating at ultrasonic frequency. This results in minimal glial scarring, inflammation and leaves the spinal environment largely unperturbed. This therefore enables a clear, unambiguous investigation of the intrinsic ability of axon regeneration through development. Our results surprisingly indicate that CSN axon regenerative ability is not lost uniformly across the different segments of the same axon. Specifically, CSN axons injured at postnatal day 7 (P7) at caudal thoracic T11 can fully regenerate and extend to lumbar segments. In striking contrast, CSN axons, when injured at high cervical C2, at an even earlier time, P4, completely fail to extend across this micro-lesion. This surprising finding indicates that CSN axons lose their regenerative ability at distinct times at distinct spinal segments. This new approach will now enable molecular delineation of specific mechanisms controlling the decline of CSN regenerative ability. Further, this also suggests that distinct therapeutic approaches will be required to target CST regeneration after spinal injuries at different spinal segmental levels. Finally, this novel microsurgical approach can now be used to specifically test whether candidate molecules can increase the intrinsic ability of CSN to extend axons after spinal cord injury.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Robustness and circuit dynamics of reciprocally inhibitory neurons to perturbation and modulation
Ekaterina Morozova
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Peter Newstein; Eve Marder

Essential rhythmic motor patterns are produced by central pattern generators (CPGs). Half-center oscillators (HCOs) are the building blocks of many CPG networks. They consist of two typically nonoscillotary neurons, or groups of neurons, connected by reciprocal inhibitory synapses. There are two fundamental mechanisms of antiphase oscillations in reciprocally inhibitory circuits: “release” and “escape”. We describe how dynamics of HCOs with “release” and “escape” mechanisms is modulated by their intrinsic properties, neurotransmitters and global perturbations, such as temperature.
One way of exploring how synaptic and intrinsic properties shape motor patterns is to control the parameters critical for production of neural output. Thus, we used the dynamic clamp to create HCO circuits of two pharmacologically isolated biological neurons from the stomatogastric ganglion of the crab. HCO circuits were formed by connecting two neurons with artificial reciprocal inhibitory synapses and adding hyperpolarization-activated inward currents.
HCOs with “release” and “escape” mechanisms produce alternating bursting for different sets of synaptic and H-conductances. These conductances must be tightly correlated to achieve robust bursting in “escape”, but not in “release” mode. H-current oppositely modulates the cycle frequency of HCOs with different mechanisms, decreasing the frequency in “release”, while increasing the frequency in “escape” mode.
CPGs must be robust to various perturbations. Temperature is a global perturbation that differentially affects all biological processes. We assessed the response of HCOs to temperature changes. Increase in temperature could switch the mechanism of oscillations from “escape” to “release” and, thus, alter the way circuits respond to external stimuli. HCOs with “release” mechanism are less robust to temperature increases.
Our results demonstrate that reciprocally inhibitory circuits with different underlying mechanisms of oscillations are distinctly modulated by the intrinsic conductances, neurotransmitters and external stimuli/ perturbations.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Spatial profiles of distractors modify saccade trajectories
Caroline Giuricich
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Robert Green, York University; Heather Jordan, York University; Mazyar Fallah, York University

Previous research has established how temporal factors and object similarity affect saccade trajectories to targets amongst distractors, but only in a specific spatial configuration. To better understand the spatial factors, we varied the egocentric distribution of targets and distractors while their similarity also varied. Participants had to search for the target out of two objects, both located at the same distance from a central fixation cross, with the distractor placed either clockwise or counterclockwise to the target. We measured the curvature of saccades made to the target using five metrics, analyzing the effects of similarity and angular distance. As the results demonstrated that saccades curve towards the distractor for shorter reaction times and away from the distractor for longer reaction times, we split the data accordingly. We find that as angular distance increases, the saccade curvature decreases. As well, for long reaction times only, as the target-distractor similarity decreases, the saccade curvature away from the distractor increases. These results suggest that visual object discrimination drives saccade trajectories but is also modulated by spatial and temporal factors.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Visual stimulus-specific habituation of innate defensive behaviour in mice
J. Alexander Heimel
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Azadeh Tafreshiha, Netherlands Institute for Neuroscience; Sven van den Burg, Netherlands Institute for Neuroscience; Kato Smits, Netherlands Institute for Neuroscience; Laila Blomer, Netherlands Institute for Neuroscience

Innate defensive responses such as freezing or escape are essential for animal survival. Mice show defensive behaviour to stimuli sweeping overhead, like a bird cruising the sky. Here, we found that mice reduced their defensive freezing after sessions with a stimulus passing overhead repeatedly. This habituation is stimulus-specific, as mice freeze again to a novel shape. This allows us to investigate the invariances in the mouse visual system. The mice generalize over retinotopic location and over size and shape, but distinguish objects when they differ in both size and shape. Innate visual defensive responses are thus strongly influenced by previous experience as mice learn to ignore specific stimuli. This form of learning occurs at the level of a location-independent representation.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Maximum Entropy Models for Connectivity Estimation in Neural Signals
Ali Haydaroglu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ali Haydaroglu, University College London; Taufik A. Valiante, University of Toronto

Maximum Entropy (ME) models, specifically the Ising model, have been proposed as estimators of connectivity in biological neural networks, although their efficacy for this purpose is not well characterized. Moreover, existing ME estimators are constrained to binary signals, which limit their application to non-spiking, continuous signals. This works proposes the Q-Potts model from statistical physics as an alternative Maximum Entropy-based connectivity estimation framework which enables the use of signals with Q discrete levels. A comparison between Potts estimators using a range of Q parameters is carried out. The methods are compared across several network topologies, including common-input networks which have been shown to cause systematic errors across connectivity inference methods. Simulated data is generated from the topologies using Multi-Variate Autoregressive (MVAR) Models and Dynamic Potts (DP) models. The Ising estimator, equivalent to a 2-Potts estimator, is shown to be a robust estimator of connectivity compared to higher-order Q-Potts estimator, even when data is generated with a model that matches the latter. When compared to widely used information-theoretic connectivity estimators, the Ising model performs at a similar level for data generated through MVAR models, and outperforms them in DP-generated models. While ME models remain susceptible to systematic errors in connectivity estimation, they are shown to be robust estimators of connectivity with some tolerance to model mismatch compared to other common methods. The possibility of hardware-accelerated inference for ME models make them a strong candidate for rapid online connectivity estimation for clinical purposes.

 Traditional talk
Watch now
Trajectory Prediction in a Biologically Inspired Network with a Strong Inductive Bias
William Chapman
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
G. William Chapman IV; Michael E. Hasselmo

Animals are able to track objects through a visual space and make predictions about future locations after relatively few observations, even when the dynamics governing the trajectory are relatively novel. In contrast, machine learning techniques typically generalize poorly when presented with dynamics which don't match the training data. Here we introduce a model architecture which attempts to bridge this gap, by incorporating principles of hierarchical predictive coding.

The essential component of this model is a predictive module which takes in two sequential observations, and outputs a prediction of the next observation of that same state space. Internally, each module has four layers: two inputs, a transformation layer that computes the difference between subsequent observations, and a prediction layer which takes in the more recent observation and the transition layer. These modules can operate on observations either directly from the target space, or the internal state from another predictive module. When training a network out of these modules, learning is on a per-module level based on its predicted value compared to the next observed input.

We tested generalization of the model by using two test datasets, and comparing to a standard LSTM. In-domain generalization was tested with datasets which matched the dynamics of the training set, but with unseen initial conditions. Out of domain generalization was tested using PDEs of the same order and dimensionality, but different parameterizations, as the training set.

We found that the models perform approximately the same for in-domain generalization with teacher forcing. For out of domain data, the predictive module network accumulates error at approximately half the rate as the LSTM model.

These results demonstrate how an appropriately structured network utilizing a single local loss-function can perform similarly to globally optimized models, while generalizing better.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Exploring the Role of the Endoplasmic Reticulum in Regulating Activity-Driven Intracellular Calcium Signaling in Drosophila Elementary Motion Detection
Vicky Mak
 
Abstract
 
Intracellular Ca2+ regulates several processes, including synaptic plasticity and neurotransmission. The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is a major neuronal Ca2+ reservoir. Although much is known about the molecular mechanisms underlying ER Ca2+ uptake and release, it is unclear how these dynamics contribute to neuronal activity in vivo. In this work, we investigated the role of the ER in intracellular Ca2+ signaling in Drosophila local motion detection. Cell-types within this circuit exhibit cytosolic Ca2+ response kinetics spanning various timescales. This cell-type-specific temporal filtering is critical for motion detection, but the cellular mechanisms underlying temporal filtering are unknown. Since ER Ca2+ handling can regulate cytosolic Ca2+, we hypothesized that the ER tunes cell-type-specific temporal filtering properties in motion detection. To test this, we measured stimulus-evoked ER and cytosolic Ca2+ signals in neurons in flies using two-photon microscopy. We found, first, that visual stimuli drive different ER Ca2+ signals depending on the cell-type and compartment. For example, within Mi1 neurons, dendrites exhibit slow, sustained (~1s) ER Ca2+ release, and axon terminals exhibit rapid, sustained (~100ms-1s) Ca2+ uptake. Thus, the ER acts as a Ca2+ source or sink during activation over different timescales. Second, we found that RNAi knockdown of ER Ca2+ efflux channel inositol trisphosphate receptor (IP3R) perturbs ER and cytosolic Ca2+ signaling. IP3R knockdown reduces ER Ca2+ uptake in Mi1 axons and Ca2+ release in dendrites, suggesting that homeostatic mechanisms reduce Ca2+ uptake when Ca2+ release is impaired. Finally, we found that reduced ER Ca2+ uptake in Mi1 axon terminals after IP3R knockdown is associated with more sustained cytosolic Ca2+ responses to visual stimuli, suggesting that ER Ca2+ handling regulates temporal filtering properties underlying motion detection. Altogether, we propose that the ER plays a critical role in regulating activity-driven intracellular Ca2+ signals in neurons in vivo, thereby tuning single-cell processing and circuit function.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Automatic tracking of mouse social posture dynamics by 3D videography, deep learning and GPU-accelerated robust optimization
Christiab Ebbesen
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Christian L. Ebbesen, New York University; Robert C. Froemke, New York University

Social interactions powerfully impact both the brain and the body, but high-resolution descriptions of these important physical interactions are lacking. Currently, most studies of social behavior rely on labor-intensive methods such as manual annotation of individual video frames. These methods are susceptible to experimenter bias and have limited throughput. To understand the neural circuits underlying social behavior, scalable and objective tracking methods are needed. We present a hardware/software system that combines 3D videography, deep learning, physical modeling and GPU-accelerated robust optimization. Our system is capable of fully automatic multi-animal tracking during naturalistic social interactions and allows for simultaneous electro-physiological recordings. We capture the posture dynamics of multiple unmarked mice with high spatial (∼2 mm) and temporal precision (60 frames/s). This method is based on inexpensive consumer cameras and is implemented in python, making our method cheap and straightforward to adopt and customize for studies of neurobiology and animal behavior.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Transmitter switching contributes to two environmental models of neurodevelopmental disorders
Swetha Godavarthi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Nicholas C Spitzer, University of California San Diego

Early environmental factors play a key role in emergence of neurodevelopmental disorders and cortical neurotransmitter imbalance is a convergent phenotype seen across different types of disorders. Neurotransmitter switching involves loss of one transmitter and gain of another often changing the sign of the synapse from excitatory to inhibitory or vice versa and altering behavior (Spitzer, 2017). We are testing the hypothesis that transmitter switching contributes to these disorders in mouse models. We treat pregnant females with either Poly Inosine:Cytosine (Poly I:C) or valproic acid (VPA) at embryonic day E12.5 and assess the progeny for molecular and behavioral changes.
Both treatments cause a transient decrease of 6000 GAD67+ neurons and an equal increase of vGluT1+ neurons in the mPFC at postnatal day (P)10 in experimental mice compared to controls that disappears by P90. These changes do not result from altered number of precursors or apoptosis and occur specifically in PV+ and CCK+ neurons. P90 animals demonstrate enhanced stereotypy and deficits in social interaction compared to controls.
Stereotaxic injection of P9 PV-Cre/CCK-Cre Poly I:C-treated mice with Cre-dependent HSV-GFP revealed vGluT1+GFP+ neurons in the neonatal mPFC at P13 demonstrating expression of vGluT1 in a subset of PV-Cre/CCK-Cre neurons, providing evidence for transmitter switching in single neurons.
To test the role of the transmitter switch in emergence of behavioral deficits, we stereotaxically injected P9 male and female PV-Cre/CCK-Cre mice with Cre-dependent HSV-GAD1-GFP. This restored GAD67+GFP+ neurons in PV and CCK cells in experimental mice and prevented gain of vGluT1 in GFP+ neurons by P13 unlike Poly I:C-treated controls injected with HSV-GFP. Restoring GAD67 also rescued altered behavior in P90 experimental male mice. Our results add to growing evidence that alteration in signaling in the nervous system during the early stages of its construction can be detrimental to the function of the mature brain.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Individual Differences in Anxious Temperament relate to Differences in Brain Morphometrics
Jessi M. Kane
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kane, J.M., Schagene, J.D. & Depue, B.E.

Anxiety disorders constitute the most prevalent subgroup of mental disorders in most western societies, with an estimated lifetime incidence of 33.7% in the US. Anxiety can be defined as a prolonged state of apprehension elicited by unpredictable threats, or threats that are spatially or temporally distant. The current study utilized structural images from three studies (N=75) to examine individual differences in different mood and anxiety socioemotional questionnaires (Beck Depression Inventory, Penn State Worry Questionnaire, State Trait Anxiety Inventory, Mood and Anxiety Symptom Questionnaire90, Ruminative Response Scale) and both cortical and subcortical brain metrics using surface-based morphometry. Cortical results indicated that increases in both the STAI and MASQ90 (general anxiety) related to increased grey matter area in the bilateral occipital pole (i.e., pericalcarine cortex, lingual gyrus). While subcortical results indicated that increased bilateral amygdala volume was related to increases in the STAI, MASQ90 (general anxiety) and RRS (rumination). Additionally, increases in bilateral nucleus accumbens volume was related to the positive affect dimension of the MASQ90. Results suggest that individual differences in anxious temperament, as measured by the STAI and MASQ90, may be related to increased visual cortex area, perhaps related to hypervigilance of the environment. Additionally, increased anxious temperament as measured by the STAI, MASQ90 and RRS, appear related to increased volume of the amygdala, again perhaps suggesting, increased threat processing due to hypervigilance. Finally, increased positive affect, as measured by the MASQ90, was related to increased nucleus accumbens volume, possibly indicating the role of dopaminergic ventral-striatal regions in positive mood.
Traditional talk
Watch now
A new non-Hominid primate network highlights the singularity of the human default mode network
Clément Garin
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Clément M.Garin, Department of Neurobiology and Anatomy, Wake Forest University School of Medicine, Winston-Salem, NC 27157; Christopher T. Whitlow, Department of Radiology, Wake Forest School of Medicine, Section of Neuroradiology, Winston-Salem, North Carolina, United States.; Finnegan J Calabro, Department of Psychiatry, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania; Department of Psychology, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Electronic address: lunab@upmc.edu.; Beatriz Luna, Department of Psychiatry, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania; Department of Psychology, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Electronic address: lunab@upmc.edu.; Marc Dhenain, Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS), Université Paris-Sud, Université Paris-Saclay UMR 9199, Neurodegenerative Diseases Laboratory, 18 Route du Panorama, F-92265 Fontenay-aux-Roses, France; Christos Constantinidis, Department of Neurobiology and Anatomy, Wake Forest University School of Medicine, Winston-Salem, NC 27157

The human default mode network (DMN) is particularly involved in high cognitive abilities such as self-directed thoughts. In humans, one of the typical functional features of this network includes a strong correlated activity between the posterior cingulate cortex (PCC) and the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC). Although these connections are generally assumed to be present in other primates, recent studies highlight poor connection between these two regions in marmosets but strong correlations between PCC and dorso-lateral prefrontal cortex (dlPFC; 8Ad). This disparity of the DMN connectivity has not yet been studied in other primates and no comparison was directly made with human data. Here, we aim to determine whether the humans DMN carries a connectivity pattern that distinguishes it from other primates. Moreover, we aim to identify the non-hominid primate network in which the mPFC is involved at rest.
In the current study, we compared the resting-state network functional organisation in humans, macaques, and mouse lemurs. We discovered a network involving mPFC that was highly similar in both non-hominid primates but was not identified in humans. We also detected a non-hominid primate “DMN-like” dissimilar to that of humans that did not involve mPFC but dlPFC regions such as 8Ad. We created a functional atlas for each species and compared the fingerprint pattern and connectivity magnitude between various clusters of interest. We found strong correlation between PCC and mPFC in humans but not in mouse lemurs and macaques. These findings diverge from the current literature that propose strong similarities between primates and human’s DMN. Altogether, our results suggest that high order networks in non-hominid primates display closer characteristics between themselves than to humans. These findings suggest that important events may have occurred during the hominid evolution. We propose that a reorganization/fusion of the fronto-temporal/parietal network is an element of the singularity of the human DMN.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Spatial and temporal cues of a stem cell direct the circuit partnership in Drosophila larval nerve cord
Yiwen Wang
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Yi-wen Wang, University of Chicago; Christopher C. Wreden, University of Chicago, Jake Henderson, University of Chicago, Maayan Levy-Bar, University of Chicago; Jason L Mac-Lean, University of Chicago; Ellie S Heckscher, University of Chicago

One of the long-lasting questions in the neuroscience field of is how circuits assemble starting from the level of neuronal stem cells. It is well-established that a small pool of stem cells generates widely diverse neurons through programs of gene expression—including spatial and temporal patterning. In contrast, how the spatial and temporal cues affect circuit assembly is poorly understood. This information will improve stem-cell based therapeutics for repair of damaged CNS tissue. In this study, we examine stem cell derived spatial and temporal cues in neurons that synapses with each other by determining their stem cell origin and neuronal birth timing. We use the Drosophila larval motor system as a model, focusing specifically on the neurons derived from neuronal stem cell NB3-3 and their presynaptic neurons. We applied electron microscopic connectome annotation of synaptic partnerships and advanced molecular genetic lineage tracing. Specifically, we characterize input connectivity for each neuron of NB3-3, and then determine stem cell origin and neuronal birth timing of both NB3-3 neurons and nerve cord interneurons that synapse onto NB3-3 neurons. The impact of this study is three fold. 1) It provides tools that will enable researchers to infer developmental origin of neurons in the Drosophila larval nerve cord. 2) It establishes NB3-3 as a powerful model system to study circuit assembly. 3) It suggests that the integration of spatial and temporal patterning information provides guidance for interneuron synaptic partnerships. Ultimately, our study revealed that the programs of gene expression known to promote neuronal diversity also regulate circuit wiring.

 Traditional talk
Watch now
Prefrontal and Parietal Neuronal Activity Mediates Working Memory Judgments
Sihai Li
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sihai Li, Department of Neurobiology & Anatomy, Wake Forest School of Medicine; Christos Constantinidis, Department of Neurobiology & Anatomy, Wake Forest School of Medicine; and Xue-Lian Qi, Department of Neurobiology & Anatomy, Wake Forest School of Medicine.

The dorsolateral prefrontal cortex plays a critical role in spatial working memory and its activity predicts behavioral responses in delayed response tasks. Here we addressed if this predictive ability extends to other working memory tasks, and if it is present in other brain areas. We trained monkeys to remember the location of a stimulus and determine whether a second stimulus appeared at the same location or not. Neurophysiological recordings were performed in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and posterior parietal cortex. We hypothesized that random drifts causing the peak activity of the network to move away from the first stimulus location and towards the location of the second stimulus would result in categorical errors. Indeed, for both areas, in non-matching trials, when the first stimulus appeared in a neuron’s preferred location, the neuron showed significantly higher firing rates in correct than in error trials, and vice versa, when the first stimulus appeared at a non-preferred location, activity in error trials was higher than in correct. The results indicate that the activity of both dlPFC and PPC neurons is predictive of categorical judgments of information maintained in working memory, and neuronal firing rate deviations are revealing of the contents of working memory.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Multiple sequential prediction errors during reward processing in the human brain
Colin Hoy
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Colin W. Hoy, UC Berkeley; Sheila C. Steiner, UC Berkeley; Robert T. Knight, UC Berkeley

Recent developments in reinforcement learning, cognitive control, and systems neuroscience highlight the complimentary roles in learning of valenced reward prediction errors (RPEs) and non-valenced salience prediction errors (PEs) driven by the magnitude of surprise. A core debate in reward learning focuses on whether valenced and non-valenced PEs can be isolated in the human electroencephalogram (EEG). Here, we combine behavioral modeling and single-trial EEG regression revealing a sequence of valenced and non-valenced PEs in an interval timing task dissociating outcome valence, magnitude, and probability. Multiple regression across temporal, spatial, and frequency dimensions revealed a spatio-tempo-spectral cascade from valenced RPE value represented by the feedback related negativity event-related potential (ERP) followed by non-valenced RPE magnitude and outcome probability effects indexed by subsequent P300 and late frontal positivity ERPs. The results show that learning is supported by a sequence of multiple PEs evident in the human EEG.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Epigenetic signature of FKBP5 is associated with structural changes in emotion regulatory brain circuits
Thomas Leon Kremer
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Thomas Leon Kremer, University Heidelberg; Urs Braun, University Heidelberg; Junfang Chen, University Heidelberg; Anais Harneit, University Heidelberg; Kristina Schwarz, University Heidelberg; Janina I. Schweiger, University Heidelberg; Markus Reichert, University Heidelberg; Emanuel Schwarz, University Heidelberg; Andreas Meyer-Lindenberg, University Heidelberg; Heike Tost, University Heidelberg

Disturbances in regulatory brain circuits involved in neural stress and emotion processing are commonly observed across many psychiatric disorders. Prominently, the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) and medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) serve as convergence sites for genetic and environmental risk factors. Epigenetic disinhibition of FKBP5, a regulator of the HPA-axis, might be a biological mechanism that translates environmental influences into altered brain function. Two specific DNA-Methylation (DNAm) loci have recently been identified as being particularly relevant for the epigenetic regulation of FKBP5. Here, we investigate the brain structural correlates of these epigenetic loci. In total 395 (194 women; age:28.12±10.45) healthy caucasian subjects underwent structural T1 MRI-Scans. Data was preprocessed using the CAT12 toolbox (in SPM12) following standard procedures. DNAm was assessed using the Illumina EPIC array and residualized for sex, age, cell composition, smoking and the first 10 PCs. The DNAm of the two loci of interest, cg20813374 and cg00130530, were averaged. Two General Linear Models on grey matter volume with (i) FKBP5 DNAm [n=395] and (ii) the trait version of the State and Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-T) [n=224] as predictors were build. Region-of-interest (ROI) analyses with ROI comprising ACC, mPFC, Hippocampus and Amygdala were conducted. FKBP5 DNAm was significantly associated with grey matter volume in the medial Orbitofrontal Cortex (T=4.37, p=.030 Family-wise error (FWE)-corrected in ROI). Within the FKBP5-dependent morphometric changes trait anxiety was negatively associated with perigenual ACC volume (T=-3.61, p=.044 FWE-corrected in ROI). We demonstrate that DNAm of key loci in FKBP5 and established risk markers for affective disorders converge on the same regions within a well-known brain circuits underlying neural stress processing, highlighting the importance of brain circuits in translating epigenetic into psychological risk.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
A 3D Parylene-based multi-electrode array for large-scale recordings from the rat hippocampus
Wenxuan Jiang
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Xuechun Wang, University of Southern California; Huijing Xu, University of Southern California; Ellis Meng, University of Southern California; Dong Song, University of Southern California

Large-scale monitoring of resolvable neuronal activities from multiple hippocampal sub-regions of behaving animals provides valuable insights into neurobiological mechanisms underlying learning and memory. However, current state-of-the-art probes such as microwire and silicon electrodes are much stiffer than brain tissue, which largely increases the chance of inflammation, and therefore makes it difficult to consistently record high-quality signals over long period of time. Parylene C is a promising alternative structural and insulation material for building neural probes with reduced mechanical mismatch between tissue and implants. In our previous work, a 64-channel Parylene-based multi-electrode array with 8 shanks was developed and applied to chronic recording of the hippocampus in behaving rats. In our current work, a novel 3D Parylene-based probe consisting of 16 (2x8) shanks with a 250um spacing was developed. Each shank contains 8 platinum electrodes and thereby has a total of 128 electrodes. To aid insertion, dissolvable polyethylene glycol (PEG) brace was employed to temporarily support the flexible probe. The 3D Parylene probe was implanted at 2.6mm posterior to the bregma and 2.4mm lateral to the midline at a depth of 4.4mm. 59 units of neuronal activities were recorded immediately after the implantation. 6 shanks recorded 8 units from CA1 while 9 shanks recorded 51 units from CA3. Histology showed that the shanks were straightly inserted within the 2.5mm depth and began to split after this depth, which was due to the different dissolving rates on the surface of the PEG block. This preliminary result demonstrated the feasibility of implanting 3D flexible polymer probe to deep brain structures for large-scale recordings. In the next step, different insertion methods will be investigated to ensure straight insertion of the probes. The large-scale 3D Parylene probe will be tested both acutely and chronically for recording from multiple hippocampal regions in behaving rats.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Neurotransmitter switches regulate motor learning and stress response
Huiquan Li
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Wuji Jiang, University of California, San Diego; Cong Chen, Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research, University of California San Diego; Don Cleveland, Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research, University of California San Diego; Nicholas C. Spitzer, University of California, San Diego

Neurotransmitter switching, involving the loss of one neurotransmitter and gain of another in the same neuron, is a form of plasticity that regulates E/I balance and behavior (Li & Spitzer, 2020; Spitzer, 2017). We have identified neurotransmitter switching and its behavioral consequences in both healthy and stressed brains during adulthood.
We find that one week of voluntary wheel running enhances the acquisition of motor skills in healthy adult mice. Running for one week also induces switching from acetylcholine to GABA expression in neurons in the midbrain pedunculopontine nucleus. Using viral vectors to override transmitter switching, either by expressing the enzymes for acetylcholine synthesis, or short hairpin RNAs interfering with the gain of enzymes for GABA synthesis, blocks the beneficial effect of running on motor skill learning (Li & Spitzer, 2020). These results show that neurotransmitter switching provides the basis by which sustained running benefits motor skill learning.
Under conditions of stress, we find that transmitter switching occurs following a traumatic fear experience. Two and four weeks after intense footshock stress, a subset of serotonergic neurons in the lateral wings of the dorsal raphe (lwDR) of adult mice have switched their co-transmitter from glutamate/vGluT3 (vesicular glutamate transporter type 3) to GABA/GAD67 (glutamic acid decarboxylase 67). At both time points, shocked mice show fear-related passive behaviors as they reduce exploration and increase freezing in a novel environment. We are now using Cre-dependent adeno-associated viruses (AAVs) to express vGluT3 or suppress expression of GAD1 that encodes GAD67 in serotonergic lwDR neurons and testing the impact on the stress-induced sustained fear responses.
Our studies suggest that neurotransmitter switching, as a form of brain plasticity, links prior experience to subsequent alterations of behavior. We expect this research to lead to new insights into development of therapeutic methods for treating movement disorders and mental illnesses.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Threat Neurocircuitry Predicts the Development of Anxiety and Depression Symptoms in a Longitudinal Study
Yujia Peng
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jeffrey D. Knotts, University of California, Los Angeles; Katherine S. Young, King’s College London; Susan Y. Bookheimer, University of California, Los Angeles; Robin Nusslock, Northwestern University; Richard E. Zinbarg, Northwestern University; Michelle G. Craske, University of California, Los Angeles

Dimensional models of anxiety and depression highlight symptom clusters that are thought to reflect disruptions in underlying functional processes. The current study investigates how longitudinal changes of symptom dimensions of anxiety and depression relate to threat neurocircuitry.

Participants aged 18-19 years (N=269, 183 female) were enrolled to ensure a range of scores on symptom measures related to threat and reward sensitivity. Subjects went through self-report measures of anxiety and depression at baseline, 12, 24, and 36 months. Symptom dimensions of general distress, fear, and anhedonic depression were estimated through a tri-level factorial model for each time point. Linear slopes were extracted for the change of symptom dimensions over time. Additionally, functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) scans were obtained while participants performed Pavlovian fear acquisition, extinction, and extinction recall tasks at both baseline and 36 months. Neural activity in brain regions related to neural threat circuitry (e.g. amygdala, hippocampus, anterior insula) were extracted.

Linear mixed models used to estimate relationships between the change of symptom dimensions over time and activation in neural threat circuitry revealed two major findings: (1) Neural threat reactivity during fear acquisition at baseline is positively associated with changes in fear symptoms over and above changes in general distress and anhedonia-apprehension, suggesting that greater sensitivity to fearful stimuli at baseline is associated with a greater increase in fear symptoms during the 3-year prospective period. (2) Neural responses to the extinguished stimulus during extinction recall at 36 months are negatively associated with changes in general distress, suggesting that greater increases in general distress over the 3 years are associated with deficits in extinction at 36 months. These findings show the promise of fMRI fear conditioning paradigms as a tool for classifying individuals into empirically established symptom profiles.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Cortical Attention and Default Mode Networks in Focused Attention Meditators Assessed with fMRI
Kathryn Devaney
 
Abstract
 
Meditation experience correlates with improved performance on behavioral assessments of attention, but the neural bases of this improvement are unknown. Two prominent, competing attention networks exist in the human cortex: a dorsal 'focused attention' network and a ventral 'circuit-breaker' network by which stimuli can capture attention. Additionally, a third network, the default mode network, demonstrates deactivation during demanding tasks. Here, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging to contrast cortical network activation between experienced vipassana meditators and controls. Participants performed two standard attention tasks during scanning: a sustained attention task and an attention-capture task. Meditators demonstrated increased magnitude of differential activation in the dorsal attention vs. default mode network in a sustained attention task, relative to controls. In contrast, attentional reorienting did not reveal behavioral or attention network differences between meditators and controls. These results demonstrate increased stability in sustained attention processes without an associated attentional capture cost in meditators.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Excitatory vestibular interneuron identity is spatiotemporally organized and develops independently of motoneurons in the larval zebrafish
Dena Goldblatt
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Marie R. Greaney, New York University; Basak Rosti, New York University; Venkatakaushik Voleti, Columbia University; Citlali Perez Campos, Columbia University; Kripa B. Patel, Columbia University; Wenze Li, Columbia University; Elizabeth M.C. Hillman, Columbia University; David Schoppik, New York University

Neural circuits must achieve precise wiring between distinct cell subtypes to produce appropriate behaviors. Identity specification and wiring precision in the circuit that stabilizes gaze is a particular case of this general developmental problem. Vertebrates stabilize gaze using excitatory vestibular interneurons that relay head and body destabilization to motoneurons that counter-rotate the eyes. Precise connectivity between directionally-sensitive interneuron subtypes and particular motoneurons is therefore crucial for behavior. The developmental mechanisms that specify excitatory vestibular interneuron identity and connectivity are unresolved, though previous work has suggested a role for spatiotemporal cues and/or motoneuron-derived factors. We tested these hypotheses in the tangential nucleus (TAN) of the larval zebrafish, which contains the excitatory vestibular interneurons necessary for vertical gaze stabilization. We first developed an assay using 2-photon and swept, confocally-aligned planar excitation (SCAPE) microscopy to rapidly and reliably define functional nose-up and nose-down vestibular interneuron subtypes. We used this assay to ask whether functional subtypes are spatiotemporally organized and discovered functional organization complementary to spatiotemporal development. Our results are the first demonstration of functional sub-organization within a vestibular nucleus and reflect a putative role for spatiotemporal factors in identity specification. Next, to investigate the requirement of motoneuron-derived signals for TAN identity specification, we used these functional assays to measure changes in TAN identity following constitutive motoneuron knockouts. Our results demonstrate that TAN functional identity and organization is preserved in the absence of motoneurons, arguing against a role for motoneuron-derived cues. Taken together, we predict that spatiotemporally-linked factors organize TAN subtypes into dorsoventral and rostrocaudal microdomains. We propose that functional identity acquisition and organization occurs in a motoneuron-independent manner.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Prefrontal neural activity underlying maturation of antisaccade task performance
Junda Zhu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Junda Zhu, Department of Neurobiology & Anatomy, Wake Forest School of Medicine; Xin Zhou, Department of Computer Science, Stanford University; Terrence R.
