Stanford, Department of Neurobiology & Anatomy, Wake Forest School of Medicine; Emilio Salinas, Department of Neurobiology & Anatomy, Wake Forest School of Medicine; Christos Constantinidis, Department of Neurobiology & Anatomy, Wake Forest School of Medicine

Executive function, including the ability to resist prepotent responses and plan appropriate actions matures relatively late in life, after adolescence. The antisaccade task is often used to evaluate response inhibition during development and adults are able to perform not only fewer incorrect choices but also faster appropriate actions. We investigated the neural basis of this ability by recording neural activity in the prefrontal cortex of monkeys as they transitioned from puberty into adulthood. Across both age groups, behavior followed a characteristic pattern as a function of cue viewing time, with most trials resulting in errors if they were initiated shortly after stimulus appearance. However, reaction times were not correlated with the neural responses to the visual stimulus but to the activity of motor and visuomotor neurons that appeared after the initial response to the stimulus. Our results reveal the mechanisms that govern reaction times in response inhibitions task and the nature of maturation that prefrontal cortex undergoes between puberty and adulthood.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Neural Fragility Of Intracranial Eeg Networks: Towards An Eeg Fingerprint For The Seizure Onset Zone
Adam Li
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Zachary Fitzgerald; Iahn Cajigas; Damian Brusko; Jonathan Jagid; Angel Claudio; Andres Kanner; Jennifer Hopp; Stephanie Chen; Jennifer Haagensen; Emily Johnson; William Anderson; Nathan Crone; Sara Inati; Kareem Zaghloul; Juan Bulacio; Jorge Gonzalez-Martinez; Sridevi V. Sarma

Over 15 million epilepsy patients worldwide do not respond to drugs. Successful surgical treatment requires complete removal, or disconnection of the seizure onset zone (SOZ), brain region(s) where seizures originate. Unfortunately, surgical success rates vary between 30%-70% because no clinically validated biological marker of the SOZ exists. We develop and retrospectively validate a new EEG marker -neural fragility. We validate this new marker in a retrospective analysis of 91 patients by using neural fragility of the annotated SOZ as a metric to predict surgical outcomes. Fragility predicts 43/47 surgical failures with an overall prediction accuracy of 76%, compared to the accuracy of clinicians being 48% (successful outcomes). In failed outcomes, we identify fragile regions that were untreated. When compared to 20 EEG features proposed as SOZ markers, fragility outperformed in predictive power and interpretability suggesting neural fragility as an EEG fingerprint of the SOZ.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Permutation-corrected independence testing for high-dimensional fMRI data
Ronan Perry
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ronan Perry, Johns Hopkins University; Loic Daumail, Lyon Neuroscience Research Center INSERM; Jelle Zorn, Lyon Neuroscience Research Center INSERM; Sebastien Czajko, Lyon Neuroscience Research Center INSERM; Daniel S. Margulies, Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS); Joshua T. Vogelstein, Johns Hopkins University; Antoine Lutz, Lyon Neuroscience Research Center INSERM

Making comparisons between populations of brain scans is a difficult task given the high dimensionality of functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data. Distance correlation statistics are well suited to performing 2-sample tests in the high-dimensional setting, which have a wide range of applications including such fMRI data. However, the common assumption of exchangeability among samples, or equivalence of distribution, under the 2-sample null distribution cannot be made if there are multiple subjects each with multiple scans, as is often the case. If naively performed, distance correlation can yield significant p-values solely due to these known, unaccounted for dependencies. We develop a multi-level generalization of distance correlation to k-sample testing which accounts for the presence of known dependencies by restricting the space of possible permutations. We evaluate this method on a novel data set of expert and novice meditators each with fMRI measurements during rest and during two different meditative states. The measurements are taken over cortical vertices and cortical gradients are extracted using diffusion map embeddings. The results show patterns of differentiability between certain pairs of states in certain levels of expertise and avoid false positives that would have been seen without appropriate corrections. The code is publicly available as part of the Python package hyppo.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Investigating the utility of neuropixel probes for studying the vestibular nuclei
Aamna Lawrence
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Hui Ho Vanessa Chang; Kathleen Cullen

Understanding neural circuits and how they generate behavior and perception critically depends on the accurate measurements of neuronal activity. Rapid progress in semiconductor technology has led to the development of high-definition silicon probes with many densely packed sites that provide high spatial resolution for electrical measurements. However, to date, no study has employed them in probing deep subcortical brain regions, like the brainstem. In our present study, we were, for the first time, able to successfully isolate single units in the vestibular nuclei using chronically-implanted Neuropixel IMEC 3B probes with 960 recording sites in head-restrained mice. The probe was positioned in the brain, such that there were approximately 112 recording sites in the medial vestibular nuclei. Spike sorting algorithms, namely, Kilosort2 and JRClust, were used for isolating the units. In total, we were able to isolate up to ten head movement-sensitive neurons by passively moving the head using the vestibular ocular reflex paradigm. The units showed robust head velocity sensitivity and no sensitivity for eye position and eye velocity during the static eye position and optokinetic reflex evoking paradigms, as inferred from their firing rates. The head velocity sensitivity (0.25 ± 0.12 (sp/s) / (deg/s)) and the baseline firing rate (18.56 ± 9.03 sp/s) of the neurons agreed with those reported by Beraneck and Cullen (2007) using tungsten microelectrodes. Moreover, our analysis of isolated units provided consistent results across both the above-mentioned spike sorting software. Overall, our results highlight the neuropixel probe’s success to investigate deep brain regions and simultaneously record many single units, thereby extending our ability to probe these circuits beyond the capabilities of the conventional tungsten and glass microelectrodes. The future direction of the study is to use the neuropixel probes for recording from head-free mice to understand the neuronal encoding of active movement in the vestibular nuclei.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Glutamate-to-GABA neurotransmitter switching induced by drugs of abuse and its impact on behavior
Marta Pratelli
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Nicholas C. Spitzer

Repeated exposure to drugs of abuse induces plastic changes in the brain that contribute to the appearance of drug-induced behavioral alterations. However, the relevance of some of these plastic changes and the extent of their behavioral impact have not yet been elucidated. An environmentally-induced form of neuroplasticity only beginning to be investigated in the context of drugs of abuse is neurotransmitter switching, which occurs when neurons lose expression of one transmitter and gain expression of another one, often switching the sign of the synapse and causing changes in behavior.
To determine whether exposure to drugs causes neurotransmitter switching, we chronically exposed mice to either phencyclidine (PCP) or methamphetamine. These two drugs have different targets and mechanisms of action in the brain, but produce similar behavioral alterations such as cognitive deficits, hyperlocomotion and locomotor sensitization.
We find that repeated administration of either PCP or methamphetamine induces a subset of excitatory glutamatergic neurons in the prelimbic cortex of adult mice to gain an inhibitory GABAergic phenotype, while losing the expression of the glutamatergic marker vesicular glutamate transporter 1. These changes occur in the same neurons as shown using transgenic mice in which glutamatergic neurons are permanently labelled by mCherry. To test the link between this neurotransmitter switch and drug-induced behavioral alterations we prevented the ability of glutamatergic neurons to gain GABA by injecting a Cre-dependent AAV expressing GAD1shRNA in the prelimbic cortex of vGluT1::Cre +/- mice prior to exposure to PCP. This treatment rescues PCP-induced cognitive deficits and locomotor sensitization, establishing a cause-and-effect relationship between the PCP-induced glutamate-to-GABA neurotransmitter switch and the behavioral alterations we have examined.
We are now investigating the role of brain activity in mediating this neurotransmitter switching, as well as analyzing the downstream targets of switching neurons and other switching events at the whole brain level using Clarity.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Lack of latent structure across levels of measurement of positive and negative valence processing in mood and anxiety disorders
JD Knotts
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
J.D. Knotts*, UCLA; Yujia Peng*, UCLA; Charles T. Taylor, UCSD; Michelle G. Craske, UCLA; Murray B. Stein, UCSD; Susan Bookheimer, UCLA; Katherine S. Young, King's College London; Alan N. Simmons, UCSD; Hung-Wen Yeh, Children’s Mercy Hospital, Kansas City, Missouri; Julian Ruiz, UCLA; Martin P. Paulus, UCSD; *equal contribution

The heterogeneous nature of mood and anxiety disorders has motivated the search for dimensionally based descriptions of psychopathology that can inform better classification and treatment approaches. Following the Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) approach, we sought to derive constructs assessing positive and negative valence domains that are observable in multiple levels of measurement, including self-report, behavioral, physiological, and neural circuit data..

Individuals with clinically impairing mood and anxiety symptoms were recruited largely from primary care clinics (N = 228). Participants completed comprehensive assessments from various domains to measure positive and negative valence processing. Behavioral assessments included emotional reactivity and distress tolerance tasks, during which skin conductance and heart rate were measured. Neuroimaging assessments included fear conditioning and the monetary incentive delay task. Symptomatic assessments included 16 questionnaires assessing various aspects of mood and anxiety symptoms and traits reflecting the negative and positive valence systems.

Group factor analysis (GFA) identified 15 latent variables explaining 26.6% of the variance across all tasks, none of which loaded across levels of measurement or tasks. Instead, variance was best explained by individual latent variables for each unit of analysis within each task. Further analyses suggest that some latent GFA variables are unrelated to the positive and negative valence systems.

The lack of latent structure across levels of measurement and tasks suggests that positive and negative valence processes operate relatively independently across self-report, behavioral, physiological, and neural circuits in clinical populations. While these findings suggest that dimensional approaches work well to reveal within-task features, they do not support the RDoC notion that cross-modality dimensions align in a way that illuminates psychopathology.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Atypical Functional Connectivity Between the Default, Dorsal Attention, and Frontoparietal Control Networks in Autism Spectrum Disorder
Braxton Hartman
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Naail Kahn, York University; W. Dale Stevens, York University; Alex Martin, NIMH

Autism spectrum disorders (ASD) are characterized by difficulties in social interaction and communication, as well as restricted and repetitive behaviours. Although widely accepted as being neurodevelopmental in nature, the specific abnormalities of brain function which underlie the disorder remain poorly understood. A growing number of studies have investigated the neuropathology of autism using functional connectivity MRI, which investigates the relations among large-scale, functionally specialized brain networks. Research with healthy adults has demonstrated that the antagonistic “default” and “dorsal attention” networks, which subserve internally and externally directed cognition, respectively, are modulated by a third “frontoparietal control” network, which flexibly couples with either the default or dorsal attention network depending upon locus of attention. We investigated resting-state functional connectivity within and between the default, dorsal attention and frontoparietal control networks in a group of 25 adult males with ASD and a control group matched on age, I.Q., and motion parameters. Differentiation of all three networks, reflecting the relative strength of functional connectivity within vs. between nodes of these networks, was reduced in the ASD group. In addition, the number of nodes exhibiting anticorrelation between the default and dorsal attention networks was significantly reduced in ASD. Region-of-interest analyses identified abnormal functional connectivity of the left frontal eye fields, which were hyperconnected to the medial prefrontal cortex and hypoconnected to the insula, which are thought to mediate context-memory binding and salient stimulus detection, respectively. Finally, graph theoretic analysis demonstrated an increase in betweenness-centrality of the left middle frontal gyrus (Brodmann Area 6), a crucial interconnector node, in the ASD group. These results provide evidence that the typical resting-state relationships among the default, dorsal attention, and frontoparietal control networks are altered in ASD.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Symmetric behavior from asymmetric wiring
Yangning Lu
 
Abstract
 
Caenorhabditis elegans maintains symmetric dorsal/ventral bending waves for locomotion in all developmental stages, during which its motor circuit undergoes significant rewiring. In adult, cholinergic motor neurons innervate and stimulate body wall muscles, and GABAergic motor neurons contra-laterally inhibit both sides. In the first larval (L1) stage however, a partial electron microscopy reconstruction suggests that cholinergic motor neurons only innervate dorsal muscles, and GABAergic motor neurons only innervate ventral muscles. How does such an asymmetric circuit produce symmetric output?

To answer this long-standing question, we undertook anatomical and functional analyses of the L1 larva motor circuit. We reconstructed the neural connectivity of a complete L1 larva by electron microscopy, from which we identified previously uncharacterized muscle innervating cells.

To elucidate the roles of these cells, we developed a novel all-optical manipulation methodology that allows bidirectional and systemic probing of neural circuits. We then combined calcium imaging, cellular ablation, chemogenetics, optogenetics, and all-optical interrogation to pinpoint mechanisms for symmetric muscle output. However, we found that the candidate cells identified from electron microscopy fail to explain output symmetry. Instead, we revealed that it is the excitatory premotor interneurons that provide extrasynaptic cholinergic activation to ventral muscles. Additionally, we found that ventral-innervating motor neurons provide extrasynaptic GABAergic relaxation to dorsal muscles. Thus, extrasynaptic pathways intricately compensate asymmetric synaptic wiring, allowing gait symmetry of newborn larvae.

These findings addressed the question of whether and how a neural circuit is able to operate symmetrically without structural symmetry. Our study highlighted the role of extrasynaptic transmission in regulating behavior, and demonstrated the dual role of both inter- and motor neurons in neuronal circuitry. It is possible that such mechanism is also utilized by other species to maintain stable behavioral output at different developmental stages, and beyond.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Dendritic and synaptic inhomogeneity patterns between pyramidals as a complementary mechanism for flexible coding in PFC.
Stefanos Stamatiades
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Stefanos Stefanou, IMBB,FORTH, Department of Biology, University of Crete, Heraklion, Crete; Athanasia Papoutsi, IMBB,FORTH; Panayiota Poirazi, IMBB,FORTH;

The Prefrontal Cortex (PFC) displays flexibility in decision making, compared to other cortical areas. Also, it contains non perfectly tuned neurons, responding in a variable way. Yet can robustly discriminate and maintain memoranda in working memory (WM). We investigate the effect of synaptic and dendritic mechanisms, in a PFC model network during a WM task simulation, to establish a link between these mechanisms and discrimination and maintenance of WM memoranda.
We propose the dendritic and synaptic inhomogeneity patterns between PFC pyramidals as a complementary mechanism for flexible coding in PFC, sufficient for performing stimulus dependent shifts of network activity, ultimately to be utilized downstream for different behavior. We do so by probing the spatial arrangement of synaptic inputs on a variable number of dendrites. Finally, we explore the structured, highly reciprocal PFC connectivity as an optimal neural connectivity substrate, best exploiting the dendritic and synaptic inhomogeneities for the above-mentioned computations.
Our results show that the combination of dendritic and synaptic inhomogeneities and structured, highly reciprocal connectivity can enable a single PFC recurrent network model to rapidly discriminate and maintain memoranda, despite the variable individual neuronal responses. We report that the network can rapidly shift between different transient, yet robustly discriminable activity trajectories, that are maintained during post-stimulus epoch. Also, we show that the above connectivity predicts the best PFC WM storage ability, compared with a non-optimal i.e. non-biologically correct network connectivity.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Data Quality metrics to improve EEG / ERP research - the Standardized Measurement Error SME
Andrew Stewart
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Prof Steven J Luck, UC Davis

Using EEG / ERP data allows non-invasive brain recording with high temporal precision.It is well understood that signal-to-noise ratio is key in EEG / ERP data. While removing periods with artifacts and “noisy” subjects should generally improve this signal-to-noise ratio, the nature of this improvement is often poorly quantified.

Despite this, there is no widely accepted metric of ERP data quality.

Here, we propose a concrete, reportable, auto-documented, heuristic approach for assessing data quality in averaged ERPs.

We build upon 'standard error' (SE) as a well understood measure, and formalize a specific procedure for applying SE to ERPs, called 'Standardized Measurement Error' (SME). We implement this by declaring, for a given analysis, the ERP score measure type (say, 'Mean Amplitude'), and the time window of interest (say, 300 to 400 ms). With that,

SME(score,time_period)= std_dev(score_value) / n_valid_epochs

A higher number indicates higher ‘spread’ or higher standard error, specifically at the score measure and time period of interest. We suggest that extensive use and reporting of SME would allow better calibration of researchers in assessing data quality. We include automatic calculation, saving, and parameter reporting of SME in our ERPLAB processing toolbox.

Preprint of paper at: https://psyarxiv.com/jc3sd/
ERPLAB v8 at: https://github.com/lucklab/erplab/releases
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Complexity and 1/f slope jointly reflect cortical states across different E/I balances
Vicente Medel
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Martín Irani, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile; Tomás Ossandón, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile; Gonzalo Boncompte, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile

Characterization of cortical states is essential for understanding brain functioning in the absence of external stimuli. The balance between excitation and inhibition and the number of non-redundant activity patterns, indexed by the 1/f slope and LZc respectively, distinguish cortical states. However, the relation between these two measures has not been characterized. Here we analyzed the relation between 1/f slope and LZc with two modeling approaches and in empirical human EEG and monkey ECoG data. We contrasted resting state with propofol anesthesia, which is known to modulate the excitation-inhibition balance. We found convergent results among all strategies employed, showing an inverse and not trivial monotonic relation between 1/f slope and complexity. This behavior was observed even when the signals’ spectral properties were heavily manipulated, consistent at ECoG and EEG scales. Models also showed that LZc was strongly dependent on 1/f slope but independent of the signal’s spectral power law’s offset. Our results show that, although these measures have very distinct mathematical origins, they are closely related. We hypothesize that differentially entropic regimes could underlie the link between the excitation-inhibition balance and the vastness of repertoire of cortical systems.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Chronic intermittent theta burst stimulation (iTBS) effects on adult hippocampal neurogenesis in males and females
Tianrui Zhang
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tian Rui Zhang; Baran Askari; Aydan Kesici; Evelyn Guilherme; Fidel Vila-Rodriguez; Jason Snyder

Intermittent theta burst stimulation (iTBS) is a promising form of non-invasive stimulation therapy for a variety of psychiatric illnesses. Currently iTBS is administered similarly across males and females, but it is not known whether iTBS’s mechanism of action is affected by patient sex. As hippocampal neurogenesis plays a critical role in stress adaptation and antidepressant course of action, we examined adult hippocampal neurogenesis in male and female mice following a chronic iTBS protocol similar to those used in the clinics. Although chronic iTBS does not exert dramatic effects on neurogenesis, we found that there is a trend for greater population of immature neurons after iTBS in males, but not females. Females do not respond to iTBS with respect to any hippocampal neurogenesis related measures. There is no effect on iTBS on survival of neurons born one week before stimulation for either sex. We also examined the morphology of new-born neurons and found that iTBS produced a trend for slight decrease in spines in stimulated animals compared to sham stimulated animals. New neurons generated in either sex have a normal morphology, similar to non-stimulated control animals, with the exception of females overall have lower total dendritic length compared to males. Otherwise, all comparisons between male and female new-born neurons are consistent with each other, indicating that baseline neurogenesis levels and new-born neuron morphological features are comparable between sexes. Our findings suggest that iTBS’s primary target on neuroplasticity may not be adult hippocampal neurogenesis, however there may be physiological differences of new-born neurons that are influenced by iTBS that remains to be further explored.

Network Activity in the Development of Inhibitory Circuits
Natalia De Marco 		Keynote Event

Multiple maps for navigation
Lisa Giocomo

Neuromatch Yoga
Ali Rigby
 
Abstract
 
Join in for very gentle stretching and meditation to settle your nervous system down before bed. Show some kindness to your body after being stationary all day. Let’s stretch and meditate together with support! No experience, special attire or props needed, and everything can be done seated in a chair if needed.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Neural bases of risky decisions involving nicotine vapor vs. monetary reward
Priyamvada Modak (she, her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Christian Hutslar, Indiana University; Rebecca Polk, Indiana University; Emily Atkinson, Indiana University; Jon Macy, Indiana University; Laurie Chassin, Arizona State University; Clark Presson, Arizona State University; Peter R. Finn, Indiana University; Joshua W Brown, Indiana University

Current studies of addiction involve decision making tasks with money or other non-drug rewards. However, previous research has shown that addiction changes response to drug vs non-drug rewards. Studies using drug reward have not given drugs as an instrumental reward directly in the MRI scanner. In this study, we looked at the neural representations of risk and reward associated with nicotine vs. money. We used a modified e-cigarette to deliver nicotine vapor to subjects with nicotine dependence inside the fMRI scanner. Our novel gambling task orthogonalized the gamble characteristics: variance in outcomes, probability of failure, and the expected value of the outcomes. This allowed us to evaluate their effects separately. The outcome in the case of a nicotine gamble was the duration of nicotine vapor inhalation and in the case of money gamble, it was the amount of money in dollars. We found an effect of greater nicotine reward anticipation in the cingulate gyrus and caudate. Regions in the motor cortex were active during nicotine inhalation, as was expected. The psychophysiological interaction analysis with these motor regions as seeds revealed increased functional connectivity with right middle temporal gyrus during inhalation. We also observed a striking reversal of effects in the cingulate cortex between money and nicotine rewards, in distinct but overlapping clusters. Activation was greater for monetary loss than win, but in contrast, activation was greater when subjects obtained nicotine than when they failed to obtain it. Activities correlating with the variance and probability of loss of a monetary gamble were found in various regions in the frontal cortex and temporal lobe. The results contribute to our knowledge of regions involved in decisions about nicotine when the nicotine reward could be realized immediately and provide insights into the limitations of non-drug rewards in studying addiction.
Interactive talk
Watch now
A zebrafish fmr1 mutant reveals early developmental changes in behavior and sensory coding
Shuyu Zhu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Michael McCullough, The University of Queensland; Zac Pujic, The University of Queensland; Jordan Sibberas, The University of Queensland; Biao Sun, The University of Queensland; Bianca Bucknall, The University of Queensland; Lilach Avitan, The University of Queensland; Geoffrey J Goodhill, The University of Queensland.

Fragile X syndrome (FXS) is the most common inherited form of autism spectrum disorders (ASDs), and is caused by a mutation of the fragile X mental retardation 1 (fmr1) gene. Some of the key characteristics of FXS include visual processing abnormalities, visual-motor function deficits and social deficits. However, little is known about the developmental trajectory of FXS, particularly early visual processing and its effect on visually driven behaviours. Utilizing the unique advantages of the zebrafish model system, here we used behavioural recordings of zebrafish hunting events combined with in vivo 2-photon calcium imaging of the optic tectum to assess functional changes between fmr1-/- and fmr1+/- larval zebrafish at 5, 9 and 14 days post-fertilisation (dpf). fmr1-/- fish showed early deficits in natural hunting behaviours, delayed development of neural coding in the optic tectum, and altered development trajectory in tectal network properties. However, these metrics improved in the fmr1/- fish when they were exposed to reduced sensory stimulation during development. We then assessed social behaviour at 28 dpf, and found that fmr1-/- fish displayed increased social preference compared to wild-type fish but slower reactions to conspecific movement. Together these results help reveal how fmr-/- changes the early development of vertebrate brain function, and how manipulating the environment could potentially help reduce these changes.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The neural dynamics underlying prioritisation of task-relevant information
Tijl Grootswagers
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tijl Grootswagers, Western Sydney University; Amanda K. Robinson, University of Sydney; Sophia M. Shatek, University of Sydney; Thomas A. Carlson, University of Sydney

The human brain prioritises relevant sensory information to perform different tasks. Enhancement of task-relevant information requires flexible allocation of attentional resources, but it is still a mystery how this is operationalised in the brain. We investigated how attentional mechanisms operate in situations where multiple stimuli are presented in the same location and at the same time. In two experiments, participants performed a challenging two-back task on different types of visual stimuli that were presented simultaneously and superimposed over each other. Using electroencephalography and multivariate decoding, we analysed the effect of attention on the neural coding of each individual stimulus. Whole brain neural responses contained considerable information about both the attended and unattended stimuli, even though they were presented simultaneously and represented in overlapping receptive fields. As expected, attention enhanced stimulus-related information contained in the neural responses, but this enhancement was evident earlier for stimuli that were presented at smaller sizes. Our results show that early neural responses to stimuli in fast-changing displays contain remarkable detail about the sensory environment but are also modulated by attention in a manner dependent on perceptual characteristics of the relevant stimuli. Stimuli, code, and data for this study can be found at https://osf.io/7zhwp/.
Interactive talk
Watch now
The Molecular Mechanisms of Ethanol Cognitive Neuroadaptations
Amanda Anqueira (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Alfredo Ghezzi, University of Puerto Rico at Río Piedras

Alcohol consumption is known to induce cognitive impairments mainly affecting executive functions, episodic memory, and other capacities related to brain function. Nevertheless, the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying such interactions is still unknown. Recent evidence has uncovered a similar interaction between ethanol exposure and cognitive function in the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, which opens the way for molecular studies in a genetically tractable model system. Using an olfactory conditioning assays where an odorant is used as a conditioned stimulus (CS) and is paired with a heat shock used as an unconditioned stimulus (US), it was shown that Drosophila larvae can learn to avoid the odor in future exposures. However, when the animals are exposed to a short acute dose of alcohol, they are no longer able to learn this association. Interestingly, larvae that have undergone prolonged chronic ethanol exposure seem to successfully avoid the odorant paired with the heat shock just as well as control ethanol-naive larvae, which is suggestive of ethanol-induced neuroadaptations. Our aim is to understand the genetic and cellular components responsible for this adaptation. For this, we employ RNA Sequencing technology to evaluate differences in gene expression in the brain of larvae chronically exposed to ethanol and in control larvae. Results from RNA sequencing suggest neuroadaptations are modulated by a diverse array of synaptic proteins within the larvae brain. With the knowledge obtained from this study, we could be able to understand ethanol’s effect on learning and memory and gain an insight into how addiction may be contributing to damages in this behavior.

 Interactive talk
Watch now
Characterizing Neuronal Activation of Melanotan II, a Novel Pharmaceutical Drug with the Potential to Enhance the Efficacy of Autism Therapy
Aashna Sahni
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Charles L. Ford, Anna A. McDonnough, Jamie LaPrairie, Larry J. Young


There is no effective pharmaceutical drug that can palliate the social deficits caused by autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Oxytocin (OT), a neuropeptide, promotes pro-social behaviors making it a potential candidate for pharmacological treatment. Melanotan II (MTII) is a compound of interest that evokes endogenous OT release in the paraventricular nucleus (PVN). Regions of the social salience network (SSN) coordinate to process social information. MTII primes PVN to release OT throughout the (SSN). MTII combined with social stimulus, increases OT releases throughout the SSN. MTII- induced pattern of brain activation was investigated across the SSN with social exposure. Twenty-four prairie voles received MTII doses ranging from 0.1 nmol to 1 pmol into lateral ventricles and were exposed to social or non-social stimuli. To observe activation, immunolabelling was performed to label for OT expression and c-FOS, an immediate early gene protein used as proxy for neuronal activation. Behavioral side effects were observed: stretching, spinning, scratching, grooming, and ambulating. Decrease in side effects was observed with decrease in dosage. To analyze c-FOS expression an online machine learning program, DeepFLaSH was used. Results suggested no behavioral difference between vehicle and 1 pmol group making it a viable dose for future experiments. However, a quantitative analysis of c-FOS expression suggested there was no significant difference in expression at different doses. We concluded the behavioral differences observed at different doses were not correlated with increased c-FOS expression in the PVN. In future, we will examine MTII-induced activation of c-FOS expression in other regions of the SSN.














Traditional talk
Watch now
Visual mismatch responses are a product of surprise, but not fulfilled expectations
Daniel Feuerriegel
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Daniel Feuerriegel, University of Melbourne; Jane Yook, University of Melbourne; Genevieve L. Quek, Radboud University; Hinze Hogendoorn, University of Melbourne; Stefan Bode, University of Melbourne

We are constantly forming expectations about our sensory environments. These expectations facilitate our decision-making and allow us to detect unusual events. Accordingly, studies using visual oddball designs have reported enhanced neural responses to surprising, compared to expected, images. Influential predictive processing models posit that these ‘mismatch effects’ arise from both suppression of responses to expected stimuli and enhanced responses to surprising stimuli. Existing studies have confirmed the role of surprise, but have confounded effects of fulfilled expectations with those of stimulus repetition, which mimic hypothesised expectation effects. We isolated and quantified effects of fulfilled expectations and surprise using a novel oddball design based on Fast Periodic Visual Stimulation (FPVS). This design controls for stimulus repetition effects while entraining participants’ expectations toward seeing specific images. We presented stimulation sequences consisting of the same face image presented at a rate of 6 Hz while recording EEG. Every 7th face was replaced by one of two different face identities, here termed the ‘oddball’ stimulus. The probability of a particular face image being the oddball ranged between 10% and 90% across sequences, in steps of 10%, including an ‘expectation neutral’ condition whereby Face A and B were each presented as 50% of oddball stimuli. Oddball-evoked ERPs were more negative between 200-300ms following surprising (10-40% probability) oddballs, compared to expected (60-90%) oddballs. However, expected oddball-evoked ERPs did not differ from neutral (50%) oddballs. Our findings indicate that visual mismatch responses reflect the detection of unusual events, but not the suppression of responses to expected inputs.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Neural correlates of computational complexity in a problem-solving task
Pablo Franco (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Peter Bossaerts, University of Melbourne; Carsten Murawski, University of Melbourne

Previous studies have characterised a cognitive control network that is modulated by cognitive load. However, these studies have mainly focused on perceptual tasks in which cognitive load can be characterised by the level of conflict or noise in the signal. It remains an open question how cognitive load of computational complex problems affects the cognitive control network. In these problems, cognitive load is arguably driven by a set of features related to the number of computation steps, computational time and memory used. Computational complexity theory has been suggested to provide a general theoretical framework that lends itself to characterising computational requirements of problem-solving. Previous work has shown that complexity affects human performance and time-on-task when solving problems; however, the neural underpinnings of this effect have not been examined. Here we study the effect of computational complexity on neural processes, and in particular, on the cognitive control network. We performed an ultra-high field fMRI study in which participants underwent scanning while solving instances of the knapsack problem, a canonical computational problem strongly associated with models of decision-making. Our behavioural results replicate previous findings on the effect of complexity on human performance. We also find that computational complexity correlates with activation in areas implicated in cognitive control, namely anterior insula (AI) and dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (dACC). Moreover, we find that activity in the angular gyrus (aG), a brain region implicated in numerical cognition, is also modulated by complexity. Overall, our results complement previous findings that use perceptual and probabilistic tasks to study cognitive control. Importantly, we find that computational complexity can be used to quantify cognitive load in problems that are fundamentally different to the ones explored up until now.
Interactive talk
Watch now
The auditory oddball test for larval zebrafish
Maya Wilde (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Rebecca Poulsen, Queensland Brain Institute; Ethan Scott, Queensland Brain Institute

The auditory oddball test is used clinically to evoke a phenomenon in EEG recordings known as mismatch negativity (MMN), in which the response to an unexpected sound (oddball) is greater than the response to an expected sound. This test is useful for investigating differences in auditory processing in developmental disorders such as autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The larval zebrafish is uniquely useful for non-invasive in vivo imaging of the whole brain at the cellular level. It therefore presents an opportunity to investigate MMN responses at the single-cell level. We used selective plane illumination microscopy to record fluorescent responses to auditory oddball stimulus trains in the brains of zebrafish larvae expressing GCamP6. Preliminary tests reveal certain populations of neurons do show elevated responses to oddball stimuli, and that pure tones are more effective for producing this effect than bands of white noise. Future tests will compare oddball responses between wildtype larvae and those carrying mutations associated with ASD.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Decoding explicit and implicit representations of food health and taste attributes in the human brain
Elektra Schubert
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Elektra Schubert, University of Melbourne; Daniel Rosenblatt, University of Melbourne; Djamila Eliby, University of Melbourne; Yoshihisa Kashima, University of Melbourne; Hinze Hogendoorn, University of Melbourne; Stefan Bode, University of Melbourne

Visual food cues are constantly encountered in everyday life and are closely related to dietary decisions. The processing of these cues involves two key attributes: taste and health. This study aimed to examine whether and when these attributes are represented in the brain during the viewing of food images a) while making explicit health/taste judgements, and b) while implicitly considering food attributes for consumption decisions. We used multivariate support vector regression to determine whether spatiotemporal patterns of event-related potentials occurring in the first 1200 ms after the presentation of a food image could predict ratings of tastiness and healthiness on a trial-by-trial basis. In Experiment 1, participants (N = 37) were directly instructed to rate the tastiness and healthiness of various food items. The results showed that taste and health ratings could both be predicted significantly above chance, with taste (530-640 ms, 680-770 ms, 820-980 ms) becoming decodable slightly earlier than health (640-710 ms). In Experiment 2, a different sample of participants (N = 89) rated how strongly they would like to consume various food items, with no explicit instruction to consider tastiness or healthiness. Using the same analysis approach, we found that taste (740-1190 ms) and health (530-830ms) ratings could again be predicted significantly above chance. We could also predict the decision strength (830-920 ms), which might reflect the integration of taste and health information for decision-making. Taken together, our results suggest that taste and health information is decodable from electroencephalography data during dietary decisions, even when participants are not explicitly instructed to consider these attributes. This finding provides an exciting path for future studies to investigate potential alterations of taste and health representations following interventions, such as health warning messages, aimed at improving dietary choices.
Interactive talk
Watch now
The surface geometry of cerebral cortex induces topological changes of cortical traveling waves
Kazuya Horibe
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ken-ichi Hironaka, Katsuyoshi Matsushita, Koichi Fujimoto

On the curved surfaces of living and nonliving materials, planar excitable wavefronts frequently exhibit a directional change and subsequently undergo a discontinuous (topological) change; i.e., a series of wavefront dynamics from collision, annihilation to splitting. Theoretical studies have shown that excitable planar stable waves change their topology significantly depending on the initial conditions on flat surfaces, whereas the directional change of the waves occurs based on the geometry of curved surfaces. However, it is not clear if the geometry of curved surfaces induces this topological change. In this study, we first demonstrated that the curved surface geometry induces bending, collision, and splitting of a planar stable wavefront by numerically solving an excitable reaction–diffusion equation on a bell-shaped surface. We determined two necessary conditions for inducing the topological change: the characteristic length of the curved surface (i.e., the height of the bell-shaped structure) should be greater than the width of the wave, and the ratio of the height to the width of the bell shape should be greater than a threshold. As for the geometrical mechanism of the latter, we found that a bifurcation of the geodesics on the curved surface provides the alternative minimal paths of the wavefront, which circumvent the surface region with a high local curvature, thereby resulting in the topological change. These conditions imply that the topological change of the wavefront can be predicted on the basis of the curved surfaces, whose structures are larger than the wave width.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Whether and how resource sharing resists scarcity : behavioral, neuroimaging, and endocrinological findings
Xiaoxuan Huang
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jie Liu, School of Psychology, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China; Ruolei Gu, 3. CAS Key Laboratory of Behavioral Science, Institute of Psychology, Beijing, China; Xiaoxuan Huang, 1. School of Psychology, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China; Yue-jia Luo, 1. School of Psychology, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China; Fang Cui, 1. School of Psychology, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen, China

Previous findings support that resource deprivation significantly activates a strong self-serving bias and promotes selfish preference in sharing decision making. However, a large number of studies have shown that uncommon sharing behavior could still be observed in the condition of resource scarcity. It’s unclear how resource sharing persists under shortage. In the present study, we suggested that empathy has accounted for the inconsistent and heterogeneous results in literatures of sharing decision. Here we combined a novel within-subject paradigm- participant who own resource decided whether and how to share their survival resources with the other participant who has no resource-with functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) and intranasal oxytocin to characterize the neural mechanisms underlying the processing of sharing behavior under resource scarcity. At the behavioral level, we found that people kept more resources for themselves under insufficient condition relative to sufficient condition. And the stability of sharing behavior was significantly correlated with the cognitive empathy(CE) score (r = -0.48, p < 0.01). At the neural level, we found activation in the left and right temporal-parietal junction (TPJ) were suppressed while the bilateral inferior occipital gyrus (IOG) were enhanced in insufficient condition comparing to sufficient condition. Psychophysiological Interactions (PPI) further suggested that the functional connectivity from lIOG to rTPJ was positively associated with the stability of sharing behavior. Oxytocin experiment provided evidence that high CE participants receiving oxytocin showed a lower changing rate than those receiving placebo while the low CE participants show no oxytocin effect. These findings suggest cognitive empathy trait and the lIOG-rTPJ neural connectivity play a crucial role in maintaining the stability of sharing behavior under scarcity, and oxytocin may strengthen the relationship between the two.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Neurocorrelates of Free Will Revisited
Paola Di Maio
 
Abstract
 

Neither science nor neuroscience explain free will. Some research shows humans have no free will, that it may be an illusion, [1], while other identifies networks of brain areas, including the pre-supplementary motor area, the anterior prefrontal cortex and the parietal cortex, that underlie voluntary action and cause distinctive conscious experience of intending to act and then controlling one's own actions, concluding that volition consists of a series of decisions regarding whether to act, what action to perform and when to perform it [2]
New findings identify networks of brain areas, including the pre-supplementary motor area, the anterior prefrontal cortex and the parietal cortex, that underlie voluntary action. These areas generate information for forthcoming actions, and also cause the distinctive conscious experience of intending to act and then controlling one's own actions.
The peak of evolution of human consciousness manifests at psychological and behavioural level with the ability to exercise conscious actions with less conditioning, particularly in the form of control over one's thoughts and emotions,
Such evolution of consciousness can be observed within certain network dynamics and could even visibly manifests in the morphology of the cortex,

The ability to make choices according to values and intents, and the awareness that animal instincts are determined by mechanical and biological responses to external stimuli, is what distinguishes human behaviour, develops awareness, consciousness and possibly drives evolution. This research revisits historical hypotheses based on recent findings, and proposes a novel interpretation of recent findings A theory of consciousness and free will as factors impacting consciousness and evolution is formulated.

[1] http://www.nature.com/news/2011/110831/full/477023a.html
[2]https://www.nature.com/articles/nrn2497#:~:text=Modern%20neuroscience%20rejects%20the%20traditional,open%20decisions%20between%20alternative%20actions.

[3] https://www.nature.com/articles/nrn2497)
Traditional talk
Watch now
On volition and consciousness in deliberate and arbitrary decisions
Uri Maoz
 
Abstract
 
The results of the Libet experiment have been interpreted as suggesting that the neural correlates of upcoming actions (and in particular the readiness potential) precede participants’ reported conscious awareness of the onset of their decision to move. Some have taken these results to mean that decisions are typically carried out unconsciously or even that consciousness plays no causal role in the formation of decisions. This, if true, may challenge some basic tenants of the notion that humans have free will and with it some key pillars of human social order—like moral and even criminal responsibility.

However, these dramatic consequences depend on the neural correlates of upcoming decisions being decodable on the fly—online and in real time. We demonstrate such an ability from intracranial recordings in humans. Further, that interpretation rests on the idea that these early, supposedly pre-conscious neural correlates of action reflect decisions rather than mere stochastic biases. But our reanalysis of single-unit recordings in monkeys challenges that interpretation. Further, the free-will debate centers more on deliberate decisions (e.g., which career path to pursue) than on arbitrary ones (e.g., which hand to raise for no reason or purpose). Deliberate decisions are, speculatively at least, more related to consciousness than arbitrary ones. So, we compared arbitrary and deliberate decisions with nearly identical perceptual inputs and motor outputs, on the same subjects, using a novel donation paradigm. We found the expected readiness potential for arbitrary decisions but not for deliberate ones, challenging the generalizability of the Libet results from arbitrary to deliberate decisions. Our results therefore pave the way for a role for consciousness in decisions, especially those that matter, as the neuroscience of volition moves beyond Libet.
Traditional talk
Watch now
What is it like to have a disorder of consciousness? Interpreting neural measures of conscious “level”
Jasmine Walter
 
Abstract
 
Disorders of consciousness (DOC) pose a significant clinical and ethical challenge because they allow for complex forms of conscious experience in patients where behavioural responses and communication are highly limited or non-existent. We currently know very little about what it is like to have a DOC, but richer information about the lived conscious experience of these patients could positively influence research and practice. For example, such knowledge may inform welfare-improving decisions about treatment, rehabilitation, social interaction and environmental enhancements for DOC patients. There has been considerable research into neuroscientific measures that could provide further insight by quantitatively assessing an unresponsive individual’s conscious “level” based on neural data. However, there is a growing consensus that consciousness is a multidimensional phenomenon and that unidimensional measures cannot capture all relevant kinds of variation in DOC consciousness. It remains unclear which dimensions of consciousness these unidimensional neural measures may reflect.
Given the paucity of subjective reports about DOC consciousness, I propose that to make progress on this question, we can investigate how neural measures behave in other conscious states where subjective reports are available (like sleep, psychedelic experiences, and anaesthesia). I survey such evidence for neural measures of consciousness and based on this, I argue that these measures may often be sensitive to particular features of consciousness, like sensory richness and unconstrained mental activity, but cannot be thought to index conscious level per se. These neural measures, if conceived of and applied as markers of specific conscious or neurocognitive properties, may offer significant insight into the subjective quality of DOC experience and as such may inform treatment and welfare related decisions for this patient group.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Cellular mechanisms for rapidly dynamic neural code in spatial navigation
Ching-Lung Hsu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Xinyu Zhao, Janelia Research Campus; Aaron Milstein, Neurosurgery Department, Stanford University School of Medicine; Nelson Spruston, Janelia Research Campus

Navigation usually involves complex tasks that require neural representation of environments, with the flexibility to respond to rapidly dynamic behavioral or cognitive variables. For instance, in the hippocampus, a brain area important for navigation, relatively small changes in cues can quickly modulate the neural representation of space. Besides, animals also learn to form such neural maps incorporated with task-relevant information. Remarkably, these processes can happen as promptly as in no more than a few seconds.

Dynamic hippocampal coding likely supports a hallmark complexity of spatial cognition, but the cellular mechanisms are poorly understood. In this talk, I will discuss our recent findings that the rapid and flexible formation and adaptation of place-dependent neural firing could be mediated by nonlinear subcellular integration or via synaptic plasticity, through experiments applying whole-cell patch-clamp recording to CA1 pyramidal neurons in acute hippocampal slices and in awake, behaving mice, as well as computational modeling. These results suggest a cellular and biophysical basis for neural computations fundamental to flexible and adaptive behavior.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Hippocampal astrocytes encode spatial information in their calcium dynamics during virtual navigation
Sebastiano Curreli
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jacopo Bonato, Neural Coding Laboratory Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia Genova and Rovereto Italy - Neural Computation Laboratory Center for Neuroscience and Cognitive Systems @UniTn - Department of Pharmacy and Biotechnology University of Bologna Italy; Sara Romanzi, Optical Approaches to Brain Function Laboratory Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia Genova Italy - Neural Coding Laboratory Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia Genova and Rovereto Italy; Stefano Panzeri, Neural Coding Laboratory Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia Genova and Rovereto Italy - Neural Computation Laboratory Center for Neuroscience and Cognitive Systems @UniTn Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia Rovereto Italy; Tommaso Fellin, Optical Approaches to Brain Function Laboratory Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia Genova Italy - Neural Coding Laboratory Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia Genova and Rovereto Italy;

Neuronal place cells encode spatial information through the modulation of their firing rate as a function of the animal’s position in the environment. This process is believed to provide a cellular substrate for spatial navigation. Growing evidence designate astrocytes, the most abundant non-neural cell type in the brain, as circuital elements involved in the processing of sensory information in several brain circuits. However, whether spatial information is exclusively encoded in neuronal hippocampal network or rather encoded in an extended circuit involving also astroglial elements is unknown. Here, we explore the hypothesis that astrocytes encode navigational information in their intracellular calcium dynamics, a major form of cellular signaling in this type of glial cell. To these aims, we trained head-tethered mice to navigate in a virtual linear track and we recorded calcium signals during virtual spatial navigation combining cell-specific expression of genetically encoded calcium indicators with two-photon functional imaging. We found that astrocytic calcium activity was significantly and reliably modulated by the animal’s spatial position in the virtual track. Calcium events accumulated at preferred locations of the virtual track and this phenomenon occurred in subcellular regions of the astrocyte, including the cell soma and proximal processes. Importantly, using a support vector machine classifier, we found that astrocytic calcium signals carried significant single-trial information about the animal’s spatial location. Taken together, these results demonstrate for the first time that non only neurons, but also astroglial networks, carry information about external variables important for performing complex cognitive tasks such as spatial navigation.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Hippocampal place cells encode global location but not changes in environmental connectivity in a 4-room navigation task
Eleonore Duvelle
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Roddy M Grieves, UCL London; Anyi Liu, UCL London; Selim Jedidi-Ayoub, UCL London; Joanna Holeniewska, UCL London; Adam Harris, University of Oxford; Nils Nyberg, UCL London; Francesco Donnarumma, Institute of Cognitive Sciences and Technologies Rome; Julie M. Lefort, UCL London; Kate J. Jeffery, UCL London; Christopher Summerfield, University of Oxford; Giovanni Pezzulo, Institute of Cognitive Sciences and Technologies Rome; Hugo J. Spiers, UCL London

Flexible navigation relies on a cognitive map of space, thought to be implemented by hippocampal place cells. In connected environments, optimal navigation requires keeping track of one’s location and of the available connections between subspaces. We examined whether the dorsal CA1 place cells of rats encode environmental connectivity in four geometrically-identical boxes arranged in a square. Rats moved between boxes by pushing saloon-type doors that could be locked in one or both directions. While rats demonstrated knowledge of environmental connectivity, their place cells did not respond to connectivity changes, nor did they represent doorways differently from other locations. Importantly, place cells represented location globally despite the repetitive geometry. These results suggest that CA1 place cells underlie a spatial map that does not explicitly include connectivity.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Coexistence of fast and slow gamma oscillations in one population of inhibitory spiking neurons
Hongjie Bi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Hongjie Bi, Université de Cergy-Pontoise, France, Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology, Japan; Marco Segneri, Université de Cergy-Pontoise, France; Matteo di Volo, Université de Cergy-Pontoise, Information et Complexité, France; Alessandro Torcini, Université de Cergy-Pontoise, France.

Oscillations are a hallmark of neural population activity in various brain regions with a spectrum covering a wide range of frequencies. Within this spectrum γ oscillations have received particular attention due to their ubiquitous nature and their correlation with higher brain functions. Recently, it has been reported that gamma oscillations in the hippocampus of behaving rodents are segregated in two distinct frequency bands: slow and fast. These two gamma rhythms correspond to different states of the network, but their origin has been not yet clarified. Here we show theoretically and numerically that a single inhibitory population can give rise to coexisting slow and fast gamma rhythms corresponding to collective oscillations of a balanced spiking network. The slow and fast gamma rhythms are generated via two different mechanisms: the fast one being driven by the coordinated tonic neural firing and the slow one by endogenous fluctuations due to irregular neural activity. We show that almost instantaneous stimulations can switch the collective gamma oscillations from slow to fast and vice versa. Furthermore, to draw a connection with the experimental observations, we consider the modulation of the gamma rhythms induced by a slower (theta) rhythm driving the network dynamics. In this context, depending on the strength of the forcing and the noise amplitude, we observe phase-amplitude and phase-phase coupling between the fast and slow γ oscillations and the theta forcing. Phase-phase coupling reveals on average different theta-phase preferences for the two coexisting γ rhythms joined to a wide cycle-to-cycle variability.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Prediction of Human Intelligence from Time-Resolved Brain Connectivity
Maren Wehrheim
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Maren Wehrheim, Department of Computer Science and Mathematics Goethe University Frankfurt am Main Germany; Joshua Faskowitz, Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences Indiana University Bloomington USA; Olaf Sporns, Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences Indiana University Bloomington USA; Christian J. Fiebach, Department of Psychology Goethe University Frankfurt am Main Germany, Brain Imaging Center Goethe University Frankfurt am Main Germany; Kirsten Hilger, Department of Psychology Goethe University Frankfurt am Main Germany, Julius Maximilian University Würzburg Germany; Matthias Kaschube, Department of Computer Science and Mathematics Goethe University Frankfurt am Main Germany, Frankfurt Institute for Advanced Studies Frankfurt am Main Germany;

Spontaneous interactions between brain regions contain pertinent information about the neural bases of human behavior and cognition. Previous studies predicting cognitive abilities like intelligence have mostly focused on time-averaged (static) brain connectivity, derived from resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Recent work decomposed dynamic brain connectivity into states of high and low co-fluctuation and demonstrated that only a small fraction of high co-fluctuation states is sufficient to approximate the general structure of the brain’s functional network architecture. Of note, such high co-fluctuation states have been shown to capture information that uniquely identifies individuals suggesting their relevance for stable individual differences in behavior and thought. Here, we use fMRI resting-state data (N = 281) to test whether the 5% of time points that index the moments of highest co-fluctuation can predict individual levels of general intelligence (WASI, Wechsler Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence). To this aim, we developed the Covariance Maximizing Eigenvector-Based Prediction framework (CMEP) that combines eigendecomposition-based feature construction with cross-validated ElasticNet prediction. The constructed features identify brain-wide patterns of network interactions reflecting a linear relationship between functional brain states and individual variations in intelligence. Surprisingly, functional connectivity reconstructed from highest co-fluctuation states could not reliably predict intelligence (correlation observed vs. predicted IQ scores: r = 0.14; p = 0.06). In contrast, functional connectivity reconstructed from the remaining 95% time points (excluding highest co-fluctuations) yields a significant prediction of intelligence (r = 0.38; p < 0.001). Finally, we reveal a different strategy for selecting critical time points and show that significant prediction of intelligence is indeed possible with only 5% resting-state fMRI data. The results are replicated in a completely independent sample (N = 831) and we conclude that the analysis of spontaneous brain network interactions may contribute to further understand individual differences of human cognition.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Predictive visual motion extrapolation emerges spontaneously and without supervision from a layered neural network with spike-timing-dependent plasticity
Hinze Hogendoorn
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Anthony N Burkitt, University of Melbourne

The fact that the transmission and processing of visual information in the brain takes time presents a problem for the accurate real-time localisation of a moving object. One way this problem might be solved is extrapolation: using an object’s past trajectory to predict its location in the present moment. Here, we investigate how a simulated in silico layered neural network might implement such extrapolation mechanisms, and how the necessary neural circuits might develop. We allowed an unsupervised hierarchical network of velocity-tuned neurons to learn its connectivity through spike-timing dependent plasticity. We show that the temporal contingencies between the different neural populations that are activated by an object as it moves causes the receptive fields of higher-level neurons to shift in the direction opposite to their preferred direction of motion. The result is that neural populations spontaneously start to represent moving objects as being further along their trajectory than where they were physically detected. Due to the inherent delays of neural transmission, this effectively compensates for (part of) those delays by bringing the represented position of a moving object closer to its instantaneous position in the world. Finally, we show that this model accurately predicts the pattern of perceptual mislocalisation that arises when human observers are required to localise a moving object relative to a flashed static object (the flash-lag effect).
Traditional talk
Watch now
Neural mechanisms of emotion regulation: A study with fMRI and dynamic causal modeling
Pablo Maturana
 
Abstract
 
How our brain regulate the emotions during a reapprasial task? To investigate mechanisms involved in this task we have selected a connectivity network consisting of three regions two prefrontal cortex area (vmPFC-dlPFC) and one limbic structures (amygdala). It was studied in two women populations healthy control and obeses. The results describe a neural mechanism for controlling emotion regulation during a task of reappraisal. We conducted Dynamic Causal Modeling (DCM) analysis, we used this approach to investigate the contribution the prefrontal cortex in the downregulated of the amygdala, finding that vmPFC and dlPFC in healthy control reduced negative emotional experience during cognitive reappraisal of aversive images, using the reappraisal task as modulatory factor in each of the connections of our model. DCM was recently supplemented with a hierarchical model over parameters, called the Parametric Empirical Bayes (PEB) framework which allows quantify the commonalities and differences across subjects which will allow us to make a comparison between two populations. The findings highlight are role of effective connectivity from vmPFC-dlPFC to amygdala in order to control emotions.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
EEG signals during relative depth judgments: Effect of image display techniques
Mehrdad Naderi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tatjana Pladere, University of Latvia; Gunta Krumina, University of Latvia

Different three-dimensional visualization technologies are developed to provide users with a high-quality experience. To identify the effect of new image display technique on user cognitive demands, one should assess depth perception and underlying neurophysiological processing of digital information. Whilst many fundamentally different three-dimensional image display techniques exist, the previous research has mainly focused on comparative assessment of brain activity in subjects viewing three-dimensional images and two-dimensional images leaving a gap in understanding the user cognitive demands associated with novel displays.
In this study, we aimed to identify and compare the effects of image display techniques on the relative depth judgements. The third dimension of image was generated in two ways – stereoscopic technique and volumetric technique. The visual stimulus contained four constant angular size circles, one of which was demonstrated closer to the subject. The subject’s task was to identify the closest circle. Electroencephalography was employed to record the brain activity during the visual task.
As a result, the relative depth judgments were fast and accurate for both image display techniques. The analysis of event related potentials showed a significant difference in late processing, but not in early processing. Specifically, the parietal lobe was more activated at 250-400 ms after the onset of three-dimensional visual stimulus comparing the stereoscopic visualization with volumetric visualization. Moreover, differences in the parietal lobe reflected in the event-related desynchronization of upper alpha oscillations. The considerably higher activity in the continuous waves of beta frequencies was observed in half of the participants. Based on the obtained results, we suggest that the depth perception and visual task completion might require a higher neural activity for the stereoscopic image viewing than for the volumetric image viewing.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Emergence of collective oscillations in balanced neural networks due to intrinsic fluctuations
Matteo Di Volo
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Di Volo Matteo, LPTM, University of Cergy Pontoise, Cergy, France; Torcini Alessandro, LPTM, University of Cergy Pontoise, Cergy, France

We report a transition from asynchronous to oscillatory behavior in balanced inhibitory sparse neuronal networks with instantaneous synapses. Collective oscillations emerge for sufficiently connected networks. Their origin is understood in terms of a recently developed mean-field model for sparse balanced neural networks. Collective oscillations are induced by irregular microscopic neural firing, due to balance. The same mechanism induces in balanced excitatory-inhibitory networks quasiperiodic collective oscillations.

di Volo, M., & Torcini, A. (2018). Physical review letters, 121(12), 128301.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The Fronto-Parietal Network Is Not a Flexible Hub During Naturalistic Cognition
Chiara Caldinelli
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Rhodri Cusack, Trinity College Dublin

It has been argued that the fronto-parietal network (FPN) is a flexible hub, in that it reconfigures its connectivity with other brain regions, to a greater extent than other networks. Cocuzza et al. (2019) and Cole et al. (2013) administered a set of difficult tasks during fMRI and found between-network variability in functional connectivity was larger for the FPN than for ten other networks. A limitation of this study is that the tasks were designed to be difficult and engage the FPN. It is unclear, therefore, whether the FPN is a flexible hub in general, or only in the context of challenging tasks. We therefore tested whether the FPN is a flexible hub during naturalistic cognition. In Experiment 1, we analysed data from 15 people watching a movie, Forrest Gump (www.studyforrest.org). We found that the variability in connectivity of the FPN was no different from other networks, providing no evidence that it acted as a flexible hub. As naturalistic movies do not have a regular block design over which to examine changes in connectivity, we investigated a range of temporal window sizes from 30-240 s. The results generalised across these. However, it is possible that Forrest Gump engaged the FPN less than everyday life, and the dataset only has 15 subjects. In Experiment 2, therefore we analysed a larger dataset (n=647, www.cam-can.org) of people watching a suspenseful clip known to strongly engage the FPN (Naci et al., 2014). Again, we found that the FPN was no more flexible than other networks. These results suggest that during naturalistic cognition, the FPN does not act as a flexible hub any more than other networks in the brain, suggesting it is not a trait of the FPN, but rather just a state during sets of difficult tasks.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Evaluating mechanisms of selective attention using a large-scale spiking visual system model: performance, processing and representational changes
Lynn Sörensen
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Lynn K. A. Sörensen, University of Amsterdam; Heleen A. Slagter, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam; Sander M. Bohté, Centrum Wiskunde & Informatica; H. Steven Scholte, University of Amsterdam

Spatial attention enhances the signal-to-noise ratio of visual information and improves perceptual sensitivity. Yet, the underlying mechanisms of selective attention are still contested: while some theories suggest an enhancement of the signal’s gain, others advocate for a reduction of noise. Comparing these two alternatives with computational models is often complicated by a lack of behaviour (performance, reaction times) or a missing link to neural measures (firing rates, population coding). Furthermore, it often remains unclear whether the proposed mechanisms can implement attentional selection in a model with complex sensory input and noisy processing. Here, we compare different attention mechanisms in a spiking Deep Convolutional Neural Network (sDCNN) performing a visual search task in complex real-world images with spatial cues. With this network, we can directly contrast effects of noise suppression (precision) and two different gain modulation mechanisms on model predictions. Like biological neurons, our sDCNN units have non-linear activation functions, which permits implementation of attentional gain either on a unit's input or on its outgoing connection. By virtue of communicating with spikes, our sDCNNs also face internal noise enabling us to implement a noise-based mechanism, termed precision. Across a variety of measures, such as performance, detection times and firing rates, we show that modulating the unit’s outgoing connection is most effective in selectively enhancing information processing by redistributing activity. For instance, models with gain-based mechanisms become faster at detecting a target object with a valid cue and slower with an invalid cue. In contrast, modulating precision did not produce reliable changes in performance. Leveraging representational similarity analysis, we show that gain mechanisms introduced additional target-related information based on the spatial cue. Our results mirror empirical findings and show that it is possible to adjudicate between attention mechanisms and to estimate their computational efficacy using more biologically realistic models and natural stimuli.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Disorder- and emotional context-specific neurofunctional alterations during inhibitory control in generalized anxiety disorder and major depressive disorder
Congcong Liu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Congcong Liu, Xiaolei Xu, Yuanshu Chen, Fei Xin, Benjamin Becker, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China

Background: Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) and Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) are highly debilitating and co-morbid disorders. Previous case control studies in either MDD or GAD patients suggest shared emotional and cognitive dysregulations, particularly exaggerated attention to negative information, yet partly separable alterations in cognitive control. However, common and disorder-specific alterations in the interaction between emotion and inhibitory control are poorly understood.
Method: In order to determine disorder-specific behavioral and neurofunctional alterations in this domain the present study examined emotional context-specific inhibitory control in unmedicated, treatment-naïve, first episode MDD (n = 37) and GAD (n = 35) patients and healthy controls (n = 35) by employing a validated affective go/no-go fMRI paradigm.
Result: On the behavioral level, we found evidence for supporting the disorder-specific alterations, such that MDD but not GAD patients exhibited impaired inhibitory control irrespective of emotional context (indexed through accuracy rates of no-go trials). On the neural level specifically MDD patients demonstrated attenuated recruitment of a broad bilateral network encompassing inferior/medial parietal and posterior frontal as well as mid-cingulate regions during cognitive control in the negative context (pFWE<.05, whole-brain). Further examination of disorder-specific alterations and potential compensatory recruitment on the neural level revealed that GAD patients exhibited a stronger engagement of the left DLPFC relative to MDD patients and that within the group of GAD patients better cognitive control in negative contexts associated with higher recruitment of this region (pFWE<.05, whole-brain), possibly reflecting a compensatory mechanism on the neural level that facilitates intact performance in GAD.
Conclusion: Findings from the present study suggest disorder- and emotional context-specific behavioral and neurofunctional deficits in inhibitory control in MDD in negative emotional contexts and may point to a depression-specific neuropathological mechanism. In contrast, GAD patients may maintain intact performance via compensatory recruitment of prefrontal regulatory regions.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Cortical responses to symmetry: Source localisation of the sustained-posterior negativity
John Tyson-Carr
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
John Tyson-Carr, Department of Psychological Sciences, University of Liverpool, Liverpool, UK; Marco Bertamini, Department of Psychological Sciences, University of Liverpool, Liverpool, UK; Giulia Rampone, Department of Psychological Sciences, University of Liverpool, Liverpool, UK; Alexis D. J. Makin, Department of Psychological Sciences, University of Liverpool, Liverpool, UK

Visual regularity activates a network of brain regions in the extrastriate cortex. Previous EEG studies have found that this response scales parametrically with proportion of symmetry in symmetry + noise displays. The parametric symmetry response happens in many tasks, but it is enhanced when the task requires active regularity discrimination. However, the origins and time course of this selective enhancement are unclear. Here we answered remaining questions with new source dipole analysis in a reanalysis of the data originally reported by Makin et al. (2020). As assumed, the parametric symmetry response found at the sensor level was generated by a pair of dipoles in the left and right extrastriate cortex, a finding comparable with previous fMRI research. This bilateral activity was itself enhanced during regularity discrimination, in accordance with original findings. However, we identified a third, and later, symmetry response in the posterior cingulate during regularity discrimination. The spatial distribution of this component was characterized by a strong positive potential over the vertex of the scalp at approximately 580 ms. Unlike the extrastriate response, this previously unknown activation only indexes strong, task relevant regularity signals. This clarifies the neural circuits which mediate the perceptual and cognitive aspects of symmetry discrimination.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Biophysically grounded mean-field models of neural populations under electrical stimulation
Caglar Cakan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Klaus Obermayer, Technische Universität Berlin

Electrical stimulation of neural systems is a key tool for understanding neural dynamics and ultimately for developing clinical treatments. Many applications of electrical stimulation affect large populations of neurons. However, computational models of large networks of spiking neurons are inherently hard to simulate and analyze.

We evaluate a reduced mean-field model of excitatory and inhibitory adaptive exponential integrate-and-fire (AdEx) neurons which can be used to efficiently study the effects of electrical stimulation on large neural populations.
