The rich dynamical properties of this basic cortical model are described in detail and validated using large network simulations. Bifurcation diagrams reflecting the network's state reveal asynchronous up- and down-states, bistable regimes, and oscillatory regions corresponding to fast excitation-inhibition and slow excitation-adaptation feedback loops. The biophysical parameters of the AdEx neuron can be coupled to an electric field with realistic field strengths which then can be propagated up to the population description.

We show how on the edge of bifurcation, direct electrical inputs cause network state transitions, such as turning on and off oscillations of the population rate. Oscillatory input can frequency-entrain and phase-lock endogenous oscillations. Relatively weak electric field strengths on the order of 1 V/m are able to produce these effects, indicating that field effects are strongly amplified in the network. The effects of time-varying external stimulation are well-predicted by the mean-field model, further underpinning the utility of low-dimensional neural mass models.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Predicting attentional engagement during narratives and its consequences for event memory
Hayoung Song
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Emily S. Finn, Dartmouth College; Monica D. Rosenberg, University of Chicago

As we comprehend narratives, our attentional engagement fluctuates over time. Despite theoretical conceptions of narrative engagement as emotion-laden attention (Bilandzic et al., 2019, Int. J. Commun.), little empirical work has characterized the cognitive and neural processes that comprise subjective engagement in naturalistic contexts or its consequences for memory. Here, we relate fluctuations in narrative engagement to patterns of brain coactivation, and test whether neural signatures of engagement predict later recall. First, in two behavioral experiments, participants rated how engaged they were as they watched an episode of the television show "Sherlock" (n=17) or listened to an audio-narrated story, "Paranoia" (n=21), by continuously adjusting a scale bar on a computer monitor. Self-reported engagement was synchronized across individuals, and the emotional content of the narratives was correlated with engagement when controlling for low-level stimulus features. We next analyzed functional MRI data collected as separate participants watched the same Sherlock episode (Chen et al., 2017, Nat. Neurosci.) or listened to the same story (Finn et al., 2018, Nat. Commun.). In these participants, group-average engagement drove neural synchrony, such that default mode network activity was more synchronized across individuals during more engaging moments of the narratives. Furthermore, time-resolved predictive modeling revealed that dynamic functional brain connectivity, but not BOLD activity patterns, predicted evolving states of engagement. Models not only predicted engagement of novel individuals within a single data set, but also generalized across completely independent samples. Finally, the same functional connections that predicted engagement overlapped with a validated neuromarker of sustained attention (Rosenberg et al., 2016, Nat. Neurosci.) and predicted post-scan free recall of the narratives, suggesting that engagement during memory encoding impacts subsequent event memory. Together, our findings reveal a robust and generalizable neural signature of engagement dynamics and elucidate relationships between narrative engagement, sustained attention, and event memory.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Motion extrapolation in the flash-lag effect depends on perceived, rather than physical speed
Jane Yook
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jane Yook, Melbourne School of Psychological Sciences, The University of Melbourne, Cognitive Neuroscience, Institute of Neuroscience and Medicine (INM-3), Forschungszentrum Jülich, Department of Psychology, Faculty of Human Sciences, University of Cologne; Lysha Lee, Melbourne School of Psychological Sciences, The University of Melbourne; Simone Vossel, Cognitive Neuroscience, Institute of Neuroscience and Medicine (INM-3), Forschungszentrum Jülich, Department of Psychology, Faculty of Human Sciences, University of Cologne; Ralph Weidner, Cognitive Neuroscience, Institute of Neuroscience and Medicine (INM-3), Forschungszentrum Jülich; Hinze Hogendoorn, Melbourne School of Psychological Sciences, The University of Melbourne

In the flash-lag effect (FLE), a flashed object in spatiotemporal alignment with a moving object is often misperceived as lagging behind the moving object. One proposed explanation for the illusion is based on predictive motion extrapolation and argues that the visual system constantly predicts the position for the moving object in the present moment, in order to compensate for the time required for neural transmission and processing. In this interpretation, the visual system uses an estimate of the object’s velocity to generate a prediction, which implies that the FLE should rely on an explicit neural representation of velocity. By contrast, alternative explanations of the FLE based on differential latencies or temporal averaging should not be dependent on such a representation of velocity. Here, we test the extrapolation hypothesis by investigating the effect of illusory changes in perceived speed on the magnitude of the FLE in two experiments. In Experiment 1, we manipulated perceived speed by adding temporal noise to a rotating wedge stimulus, and in Experiment 2 we manipulated perceived speed by changing the luminance contrast of the wedge. We show for both manipulations, differences in perceived speed corresponded to differences in FLE magnitude: both perceived speed and perceived flash-lag increased when the wedge contained dynamic noise relative to static noise, and when it was presented in low relative to high contrast. Moreover, this effect was consistent across two different textures. Our findings therefore indicate that the FLE depends on an explicit neural representation of velocity, consistent with the motion extrapolation hypothesis.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Too salty? Your amygdala-thalamus gain network may need to loosen up a bit.
Maria Veldhuizen (they)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Michael C. Farruggia, Department of Psychiatry, Yale School of Medicine, New Haven, Connecticut, US; Xiao Gao, Faculty of Psychology, Southwest University, Chongqing, China; Yuko Nakamura, The UTokyo Center for Integrative Science of Human Behavior, Tokyo, Japan; Barry G. Green, The John B. Pierce Laboratory, New Haven, Connecticut, US; Dana M. Small, Department of Psychiatry, Yale School of Medicine, New Haven, Connecticut , US

Peripheral sources of individual variation in taste intensity perception have been well described. The existence of a central source has been proposed but remains unexplored. Here we used functional magnetic resonance imaging in healthy human participants (20 women, 8 men) to evaluate the hypothesis that the amygdala exerts an inhibitory influence that affects the “gain” of the gustatory system during tasting. Consistent with the existence of a central gain mechanism (CGM), we found that central amygdala response was correlated with mean intensity ratings across multiple tastants. In addition, psychophysiological and dynamic causal modeling analyses revealed that the connection strength between inhibitory outputs from amygdala to medial dorsal and ventral posterior medial thalamus predicted individual differences in responsiveness to taste stimulation. These results imply that inhibitory inputs from the amygdala to the thalamus act as a CGM that influences taste intensity perception.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Divided attention in the tactile modality
Sharon Daniel
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Thomas Andrillon ; Naotsugu Tsuchiya ; Jeroen J. A. van Boxtel;

Most of our knowledge about the interplay between attention and consciousness comes from the
visual domain, which suggests that some stimuli can be consciously perceived in the near absence of
top-down attention, while other stimuli cannot. Here, we investigated whether tactile conscious
discrimination remains intact in the near absence of attention. We used the well-established dual-task
paradigm from the visual domain, in which participants are instructed to perform a central demanding
task while performing a secondary task in parallel. We compared the performance of a frequency
discrimination task in N=16 participants in three conditions with different attentional requirements but
identical input. Four fingers on one hand and 2 fingers on the other hand were stimulated with
vibrators. In the single-task, participants focused on one finger pair, while in the dual-task condition,
they focused on two finger pairs either on the same hand or across hands. Performance in the
dual-task was worse than in the single task. In contrast to previous visual experiments reported
improved performance when tasks were divided across hemifields compared to within a hemifield, we
did not find comparable result in the tactile modality. Specifically, we found that in the dual-task
conditions, performance was the same for same-hand and across-hands conditions. Our results
suggest that simple haptic tasks, such as frequency discrimination, cannot be performed in the near
absence of attention.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Machine Learning methods for predicting conversion from mild cognitive impairment to Alzheimer’s disease. A systematic review.
Sergio Grueso
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Raquel Viejo-Sobera, Universitat Oberta de Catalunya

Increase in life-span in our society is a double-edged sword that entails a growing number of patients with neurocognitive disorders, being Alzheimer’s disease (AD) the most prevalent. Advances in medical imaging and computational power, allow new methods to detect and hopefully prevent cognitive decline, especially in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI), a condition that might be considered a prodromal stage of AD. We conducted a systematic review following PRISMA guidelines of studies where Machine Learning (ML) was applied to neuroimaging data obtained from public databases in order to predict the progression from MCI to AD. We selected 30 studies and assessed their model performance based on its accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve, to determine which algorithms combined with which neuroimaging techniques achieved better predictions. Results show that the best method to detect group differences between healthy, MCI (progressive and stable), and AD subjects is using large samples with multimodal and multidimensional data (neuroimage, clinical, cognitive, biological, and behavioral data) combined with Deep Learning models (as compared with other ML models such as Random Forest or Support Vector Machine). Although performance of the different models still have room for improvement, the results are promising and this methodology has a great potential as a support tool for clinicians and professionals from health institutions.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Movement vigor in Rats
Thomas Morvan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Stefania Sarnio, INMED/IRPHE; Oceane Dauzere-Peres; Christophe Eloy, IRPHE, David Robbe, INMED

Choice between two actions (e.g. reaching for different rewards) can be used to assess internal motivation in animals as they will select the choice that has the higher subjective utility. Vigor of movement is a finer indicator that reflects continuous subjective utility.
The utility of a distant reward is dependent on its subjective reward, the amount of effort needed to reach it (movement cost) and temporal discounting (cost of time). High utility rewards make it worthwhile to expend more energy in order to reach it sooner, leading to an increase in movement vigor.
The goal of this project is to understand how rats balance reward, movement and temporal cost to maximize their reward rate.
We have developed an automated foraging task in which water-restricted rats have to run in a 120 x 15 cm enclosed corridor to get rewards (water). Water dispensers are located on each end of the apparatus and a drop of water is delivered each time the rat goes to the other side of the apparatus, forcing the rat to run back and forth to get subsequent rewards.
We are carefully manipulating the quantity of the reward (size of the water drops that they can get) and the cost (distance they have to run in order to get it), and are looking at the rat’s vigor of movement (speed as they run across the apparatus).
We show that rats elicit behaviors that are in line with an optimal control of effort expenditure and reward gain ratio: e.g., if we increase the quantity of reward on one side of the apparatus, they run faster towards the side where the reward is bigger.
We also started developing a reinforcement learning based mathematical model in which artificial rats are performing the same task, and elicit similar behavioral results.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Recognition of Harmonic Sound Sequences Investigated By Behavioral And Electrophysiological Studies
Filiz Tezcan Semerci
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Funda Yildirim

Consonance rating when listening to the two consecutively or simultaneously presented sounds is associated with the ratio of their fundamental frequencies. The simpler ratio is perceived as more consonant. Most of the previous studies investigated the neural mechanism of the harmony perception of simultaneously presented complex tones and emphasized the role of auditory system in subcortical level. However, there is still little known about harmony perception of sequentially presented pure tones and its relation to the short-term memory. Earlier studies which investigated the role of harmonic intervals on recognition performance mostly compared tonal and atonal melodies in Western music with both musicians and nonmusicians, and the results were contradictory (Dewar et al., 1977; Krumhansl, 1979; Schulze et al., 2011; Schulze et al., 2012). In those studies, melodies that were compared had different notes and contours. In this study, two melodies that consist of the same 10 tones were generated. Melodies had the same contour but differed order of tones, forming different harmonic relations between consecutive tones. Non-musician participants were asked to choose which melody (harmonic or inharmonic) was more consonant. The results showed that even though the ratings for in/harmonic melodies were not significantly different, it was easier for them to notice the same amount of frequency change in one note of the harmonic melody. An EEG experiment was conducted to test the working memory load hypothesis. The sustained anterior negativity (SAN) was compared as a measure of working memory load but amplitude of SAN did not reveal a significant difference. However, nonmatching stimulus elicited a P3b signal with higher amplitude for the harmonic condition. This result suggests that a higher level expectation occurs for harmonic condition since all the other parameters that affect P3b signal were well controlled in the experiment.
Interactive talk
Watch now
The assessment of visually guided reaching in Alzheimer's Disease and Mild Cognitive Impairment
Alex Mitchell
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Alexandra G. Mitchell, University of Edinburgh; Stephanie Rossit, University of East Anglia; Annie Warman, University of East Anglia; Suvankar Pal, University of Edinburgh; Michael Hornberger, University of East Anglia; Robert D. McIntosh, University of Edinburgh

The onset of cognitive problems associated with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) has recently been shown to be preceded by functional and structural changes in the posterior parietal cortex (PPC). The PPC is important for the visual guidance of actions, and focal damage to this region can cause gross spatial errors when reaching to objects in peripheral vision. Individuals with AD, and possibly pre-clinical AD, might therefore be predicted to show impairments of peripheral reaching, but no prior study has examined this. Our aim was to characterise peripheral reaching in patients with amnestic Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and typical AD, by comparison with age-matched controls (HC). A Peripheral Misreaching Index (PMI) was used to quantify differences in spatial accuracy between peripheral and free (central) reaching. Case-control analyses showed significant peripheral misreaching in a small subset of individuals with AD and MCI, but we found no overall differences between groups. Exploratory analyses revealed that reaching movements were slower and temporally extended in AD and MCI compared to HC, which is consistent with previous findings. Our findings show that, although gross spatial inaccuracy when reaching to peripheral targets is not prominent in AD or MCI, slowed visuomotor processing may be a characteristic feature of prodromal AD.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The Dorsal Striatum Energizes Motor Routines
Mostafa Safaie
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jurado-Parras; Sarno; Louis; Karoutchi; Berret; Robbe

The dorsal striatum (dS) has been implicated in both storing procedural memories and controlling movement kinematics. Since procedural memories are expressed through movements, the exact nature of the dS function has proven difficult to delineate. To alleviate this confound, we challenged rats in a series of complementary locomotion-based tasks. Surprisingly, dS lesions did not impair the ability to remember the procedure for successful completion of motor routines. However, the speed and initiation of the reward-oriented running phase of the routines were irreversibly altered by the dS lesion. Further behavioral analyses, combined with optimal control modeling indicated that these kinematic alterations were best explained by an increased sensitivity to the expended energy in the routines. Our work provides evidence for a fundamental role of the dS in modulating the kinematics of reward-oriented actions in order to optimize the energetic cost of moving.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Atypical pupillary response to novel auditory stimuli in children with autism spectrum disorder
Liu Yajie
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Yajie Liu, School of Psychological and Cognitive Sciences, Peking University, Beijing, China; Linlin Gong, School of Psychological and Cognitive Sciences, Peking University, Beijing, China; Sijia Zhao, Department of Experimental Psychology, University of Oxford, Oxford OX1 3PH, UK; Kunlin Wei, School of Psychological and Cognitive Sciences, Peking University, Beijing, China

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is characterized by impaired social interaction and interpersonal communication. Researchers have suggested that aberrant attentional function to exogenous stimuli contribute substantially to social deficits among individuals with ASD. The attentional function is modulated by locus coeruleus (LC) and its noradrenergic projections throughout the brain, and the LC activity has been shown abnormal among the ASD population. As an index of LC-NA activity, PDR provides a convenient and non-invasive measure for studying attentional deficits. However, previous research has focused on examining PDR when individuals with ASD process social stimuli (e.g., face pictures) or engage in complicated cognitive tasks. Here we used a simple auditory oddball task to test children with ASD and their age-matched typically-developed controls (TD group). Participants were required to listen to the stimuli without task responses while their PDR was continuously monitored. Compared to standard stimuli (pure-tone beeps), deviant stimuli induced phasic PDR in both groups. Social (laughter) and non-social (noise) deviants elicit similar PDR. Importantly, the ASD group exhibited significantly smaller PDR than the TD group. Controlling for age and IQ, we observed a strong negative relationship between PDR and ASD symptom severity across groups and a weak correlation within the ASD group. Our results suggest that aberrant attention function among individuals with ASD is not limited to social stimuli but probably include stimuli without social or affective content. Reduced LC-related responsivity to novel stimuli has important implications for affected attention orientating that has been proposed as a fundamental problem for social development in ASD.
Interactive talk
Watch now
AR spatial test for AD diagnosis
Rana Khoury
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sandy Rihana, USEK

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) has been around for more than a hundred years, and so far, there is still no cure. However, the disease can be slowed down significantly if detected in its early stages. The problem is that it can only be detected through expensive means like MRI and PET scanning. Therefore, there is an increasing need to find new methods for the diagnosis of Alzheimer’s in its presymptomatic phase. This presents some challenges because the disease is thought to start way before clinical symptoms emerge. We therefore propose a new generation of realistic cognitive tests that can target early cognitive deficits of dementia much better than conventional tests used in the clinic. In particular, we propose to use Augmented Reality (AR) which can open the door for much more flexibility in designing and monitoring these tasks remotely.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Super-resolution microscopy to investigate receptor-ribosome coupling as a mechanism to regulate local translation
Lucia Wunderlich
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Lucia CS Wunderlich, Max Koppers, Julie Qiaojin Lin, Christine E Holt, Clemens F Kaminski

Cell surface receptors regulate a variety of essential cellular processes, including mRNA translation, to enable the response to extracellular cues required for cellular survival. In addition to the long-known signalling pathways based on post-translational modifications of downstream targets and subsequent transcriptional activation, a different mechanism linking extracellular stimuli and translation has recently been discovered in neurons. This involves the release of ribosomes tethered to cell surface receptors upon axonal guidance cue stimulation, enabling local protein synthesis (LPS). This phenomenon allows rapid and local remodelling of the axonal proteome distant from the cell body, which is essential for axonal survival and neuronal circuit formation.
We use super-resolution microscopy to further investigate the mechanism of guidance cue-induced uncoupling of ribosomes from the guidance cue receptor deleted in colorectal cancer (DCC) during axonal development. Expansion microscopy and proximity-based methods are applied to the model system Xenopus laevis retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) to perform colocalization studies of receptors and different components of the translation machinery such as ribosomal proteins (RPs) and ribosome binding proteins (RBPs). Our results show a significant reduction of colocalizing ribosomes with DCC upon stimulation with the guidance cue Netrin-1, the ligand for DCC. Additionally, colocalization studies of different guidance cue receptors and RBPs confirmed a specific association of DCC with hnRNPa2b1. Together, these findings support a model of receptor specific association of ribosomes and RBPs, which enables selective mRNA translation.
Traditional talk
Watch now
How do the blind ‘see’? The role of spontaneous brain activity in self-generated perception
Avital Hahamy
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Meytal Wilf, MySpace Lab, Department of Clinical Neuroscience, Lausanne University Hospital, Lausanne, Switzerland; Boris Rosin, Department of Ophthalmology, Hadassah-Hebrew University Medical Center, Jerusalem 91120, Israel; Marlene Behrmann, Department of Psychology and Neuroscience Institute, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 15213, USA; Rafael Malach, Department of Neurobiology, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 7610001, Israel

Spontaneous brain activity has long been studied, but little is known about its behavioral implications. It has previously been hypothesized that spontaneous brain activity underlies unprompted (internally-generated) behavior. Here, we test whether spontaneous brain activity might underlie internally-generated vision. We test this hypothesis by studying the cortical visual system of five blind individuals who experience vivid visual hallucinations (Charles Bonnet Syndrome, CBS). Neural populations in the visual system of these individuals are deprived of external input, which may lead to their hyper-sensitization to spontaneous activity fluctuations. To test whether these spontaneous fluctuations can subserve visual hallucinations, the fMRI brain activity of CBS participants obtained while they reported their hallucinations (spontaneous internally-generated vision) was compared to the : 1) brain activity evoked by veridical vision (externally-triggered vision) in sighted controls who were presented with a visual simulation of the hallucinatory streams; and 2) brain activity of non-hallucinating blind controls during visual imagery (cued internally-generated vision). All conditions showed activity spanning large portions of the visual system. However, only the hallucination condition in the CBS participants demonstrated unique temporal dynamics, characterized by a build-up of neural activity prior to the reported onset of hallucinations. This build-up was most pronounced in early visual cortex and then decayed along the visual hierarchy. These results suggest that, in the absence of external visual input, a build-up of spontaneous fluctuations in early visual cortex may activate the visual hierarchy, thereby triggering the experience of vision.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Non-stimulated regions in early visual cortex encode the contents of conscious visual perception
Bianca van Kemenade
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Gregor Wilbertz, Department of Psychology, Freie Universität Berlin; Annalena Müller, Department of Experimental and Biological Psychology, University of Potsdam; Philipp Sterzer, Department of Psychiatry and Psychotherapy, Charité Campus Mitte, Berlin

Predictions shape our perception. The theory of predictive processing poses that our brains make sense of incoming sensory input by generating predictions, which are sent back from higher to lower levels of the processing hierarchy. These predictions are based on our internal model of the world and enable inferences about the hidden causes of the sensory input data. It has been proposed that conscious perception corresponds to the currently most probable internal model of the world. Accordingly, predictions influencing conscious perception should be fed back from higher to lower levels of the processing hierarchy. An elegant way to isolate effects of feedback signalling in the human brain is to measure neural activity in regions of retinotopic visual cortex that do not receive feedforward input. For example, previous fMRI studies have shown that non-stimulated parts of early visual cortex contain content-specific information from the surrounding visual context, most likely mediated by feedback signalling. Here, we asked whether the actual contents of conscious visual perception would also be reflected by neural signals in non-stimulated regions of early visual cortex. In our fMRI experiment, participants viewed large-field ambiguous visual motion stimuli that spared a subregion of the visual field. Using multi-voxel pattern analysis of fMRI signals, we could decode the participants’ reported perception not only from stimulated regions of early visual cortex, but also from non-stimulated subregions. These results indicate that early sensory cortices in the human brain receive predictive feedback signals that reflect the current contents of conscious perception.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Mistaking imagination for reality: mental imagery decreases perceptual detection threshold
Nadine Dijkstra
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Matan Mazor; Peter Kok; Stephen Fleming

Visual experiences can be triggered externally, by signals coming from the outside world during perception; or internally, by signals from memory during mental imagery. Imagery and perception activate similar neural codes in sensory areas, suggesting that they might sometimes be confused. In the current study, we investigated whether imagery influences perception by instructing participants to imagine gratings while externally detecting these same gratings at threshold. In a series of three experiments, we showed that imagery led to a more liberal criterion for reporting stimulus presence, and that this effect was both independent of expectation and stimulus-specific. Furthermore, participants with more vivid imagery were generally more likely to report the presence of external stimuli, independent of condition. The results can be explained as either a low-level sensory or a high-level decision-making effect. We discuss that the most likely explanation is that during imagery, internally generated sensory signals are sometimes confused for perception and suggest how the underlying mechanisms can be further characterized in future research. Our findings show that imagery and perception interact and emphasize that internally and externally generated signals are combined in complex ways to determine conscious perception.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Preparatory eye movements reveal prior knowledge and intended interaction in VR
Ashima Keshava
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ashima Keshava; Nina Gottschewsky; Farbod Nosrat Nezami; Peter König

Most studies on human cognitive behavior are performed in controlled laboratory settings, limiting the validity and understanding of cognition in more naturalistic settings. The study of eye-movements in naturalistic tasks has revealed that the eyes precede the hands during an action. However, it is unclear how anticipatory and task-oriented eye movements are affected by prior knowledge about objects. The present study aims to investigate eye movement behavior while interacting with familiar and unfamiliar objects in a virtual environment.
In this experiment, we study the gaze dynamics during interaction with 12 three-dimensional tool models in a virtual environment. We introduce a 2x2x2 factorial design with factors task, familiarity, and orientation. Participants were instructed to either lift or use a given familiar or unfamiliar tool. We presented the tools in two different orientations where the tool handle was presented either on the left or right side.
We used linear mixed models, with a random slope and intercept for subject and stimulus items, to model the odds of fixations on the tool effector before grasp initiation based on task, familiarity, and orientation. The results suggest that subjects fixate more on the tool effector when the tool is unfamiliar and during the use task. Also, during the lift task, fixations on the tool effector and handle were equally likely. Additionally, we did not find any effect of the orientation of the tool.
These findings suggest that the given task and the available knowledge about an object influence a person’s gaze control strategy during object interaction. Finally, the effect of prior knowledge and task type in a naturalistic setting lends further evidence towards eye movements predominantly driven by higher-level cognitive functions.
Interactive talk
Watch now
A New Computational Theory of Intelligence
Aman Patel (he/him)
 
Abstract
 
There is a large corpus of literature seeking to define “intelligence,” but many of these definitions focus on describing key features of intelligent systems, instead of the mechanisms that give rise to it. However, intelligence is such a nebulous concept that it might be best defined by how it works, rather than what it entails. In this paper, I synthesize insights from neuroscience, human development, and computer science to present a new mechanistic formulation of “intelligence”—as well as a new strategy for engineering it. The key hypothesis of this view is that all cognitive processes, including sensing, planning, logic, memory, and even consciousness, can be represented as information processing under a massively-parallel network of probabilistic circuits that model unknown processes. Each of these model-building circuits uses its input information, along with certain preset parameters, to attempt to produce the same output that the unknown process does. A complex network of such circuits may exhibit behavior that approaches what we typically consider to be “intelligent.”
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Pannexin1 Knockout Zebrafish as a Model for Seizure Investigation
Daria Taskina
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
D Taskina 1,2; PA Whyte-Fagundes 1,3; N Saffarian 1; C Zoidl 1 and GR Zoidl 1,2,3. 1. Biology, York University 2. Neuroscience Graduate Program, York University 3. Krembil Research Institute, Toronto

Many epileptic patients with recurrent seizures do not respond to medical interventions available on the market today. Evidence suggests that Pannexin1, an ATP-release membrane channel, plays a vital role in modifying neuronal excitability by altering the electrical and metabolic balances of the neural network.
Our research aims at evaluating whether Pannexin1 is a target for therapeutic intervention in epilepsy. A Pannexin1 knock-out zebrafish model was established to investigate the role of Pannexin1 in a seizure model in vivo. Additionally, we have employed probenecid, a known Pannexin1 channel blocker, to assess for the efficacy of pharmacological targeting. The resistance of the zebrafish to chemically induced seizures was investigated via their behavioural locomotor response, signs of stress on a molecular level, and in vivo electrophysiological recordings from the brain.
Our findings demonstrate that Pannexin1 channels contribute to the distortion of the electrochemical balance and aid in the propagation of seizures in vivo. Lack of Pannexin1, or pharmacological block of the channels, resulted in decreased seizure-related behaviour and electrophysiological ictal-like events, improved survival and reduced molecular stress responses.
Zebrafish are an appealing and multifaceted animal model for pre-clinical epilepsy studies; as they allow for high-throughput behavioural phenotyping and the examination of intact neuronal circuits. In future work we aim to incorporate Machine Learning in the analysis of zebrafish behaviour, thus automating the procedure, and unravelling novel patterns in phenotypic data.
Traditional talk
Watch now
MEG visual gamma oscillations reflect individual differences in sensory sensitivity
Viktoriya Manyukhina
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
E.N. Rostovtseva, Center for Neurocognitive Research (MEG Center) of MSUPE; A.O. Prokofiev, Center for Neurocognitive Research (MEG Center) of MSUPE; T.A. Stroganova, Center for Neurocognitive Research (MEG Center) of MSUPE; E.O. Orekhova, Center for Neurocognitive Research (MEG Center) of MSUPE

Visual gamma oscillations arise through interplay between excitatiory (E) and inhibitory (I) neurons in the brain and are characterized by high reliability and heritability. Therefore gamma oscillations in the visual cortex were proposed as a biomarker of E/I balance, which is related to neural processing and is disturbed in many psychiatric conditions. Little is known, however, about how gamma oscillations are related to individual differences in perception, and in particular, how it is related to sensitivity to sensory stimuli. In a recent magnetoencephalography (MEG) study in a sample of neurotypical males and in males with ASD we found that less efficient gamma response (GR) suppression in response to increase of motion of high-contrast gratings is associated with greater sensory sensitivity to stimuli in the everyday life. In this MEG study we replicated this result in a sample of neurotypical females. We found that efficacy of GR attenuation by visual stimuli of different intensity predicts individual differences in sensory sensitivity. This finding extends our previous result and demonstrates that the observed correlation is not sex-specific. Besides, this suggests that intensity-related changes in power of gamma oscillations may provide useful information about E/I balance in the visual cortex.
Interactive talk
Watch now
The classification system of hand motor-imagery EEG signals
Qiying Chang
 
Abstract
 
The classification system of hand motor-imagery EEG signals is generally used in intelligent rehabilitation robots for hand movement disorders caused by nerve injury during stroke. The intelligent rehabilitation device based on the brain-computer interface can effectively activate the damaged brain area from the perspective of rehabilitation medicine and improve the rehabilitation effect of the patient. However, due to the inherent differences between human brain signals, and the fact that most middle-aged and elderly patients suffer from imagination decline, the actual effect of most classification systems is poorer than expected, which limits the effectiveness of rehabilitation training.
The hand motor-imagery EEG signal classification system designed and implemented in this paper proposes a method to solve this personalized difference problem. Research details are as followed: 1) This paper studies and verifies the algorithm of signal preprocessing, feature extraction and classification. A set of methods with superior performance are applied to the system implementation; 2) A feature selection method based on classification effect is designed. This method is only based on the selection of channel and frequency features, which can effectively improve the generalization ability of the classification system; 3) The characteristics and classification effects of the data collected from different rehabilitation patterns are compared, and a combination of two rehabilitation patterns is applied to the classification system.
This system can achieve 88.4028% accuracy in 5×5 folds cross-validation on self-collected data. Compared with the existing EEG signal classification system, the result achieved by this system is quite good.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Evaluation of Anti-Parkinson’s activity of Herbomineral (Abhrak bhasma) on Rotenone induced Parkinson’s disease in Drosophila melanogaster.
Arun Shankar
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Arun Shankar Nair; Dr. Nirmala R. Rege; Dr. Snehalata Gajbhiye; Dr, Dinesh Uchil

Background and rationale: The study was designed to validate the claims in Ayurveda regarding the efficacy of Ayurvedic drugs in neurodegenerative disorders. It was decided to conduct an efficacy study of a herbomineral drug (Abhrak bhasma) on Parkinson’s disease induced chemically in Drosophila melanogaster (fly). Parkinson’s disease has symptom descriptions in Ayurveda and modern medicine. The latter offers only the symptomatic therapy by replacing dopamine, the neurotransmitter involved, but does not slow down or reverse the loss of dopaminergic neurons.
Methods: Rotenone, in a final concentration of 125 μM, was induced for inducing Parkinson’s disease in Drosophila melanogaster. Table concentration of bhasma samples were selected on the basis of viability assays carried out in our lab. The group serving as negative control will not have the study drugs in the cornmeal medium and the flies from positive control will be fed with L-dopa dissolved in the medium in the concentration of 1 mM. The flies in the bottle will be maintained for a period of 7 days at 25OC. On the 8th day, they will be subjected to climbing assay. The brain tissue of Drosophila melanogaster will be dissected and be subjected to biochemical estimations- Malondialdehyde, Glutathione, Protein estimation and Dopamine estimation.
Results: Climbing assays showed a significant reduction in the climbing/ motor ability between the contrel and disease control groups. There was a significant improvement in the climbing ability of flies fed with l-dopa and study drugs. Inflammatory markers and Dopamine levels were improved in the group fed with the drug.
Conclusion: Herbomineral (Abhrak bhasma) were found to be effective in reducing the rotenone induced dopaminergic loss of neurons.
Ethics statement: NA.
Acknowledgement:I would like to acknowledge SAIF dept., IIT Mumbai and our lab members for their support.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Eye movements in the formally blind
Paul Zerr
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
José Pablo Ossandón; Idris Shareef; Stefan Van der Stigchel; Ramesh Kekunnaya; Brigitte Röder

Sensitive periods have previously been identified for several human visual system functions. Yet, it is unknown to what degree the development of visually guided oculomotor control depends on early visual experience—for example, whether and to what degree humans whose sight was restored after a transient period of congenital visual deprivation are able to conduct visually guided eye movements. In the present study, we developed new calibration and analysis techniques for eye tracking data contaminated with pervasive nystagmus, which is typical for this population. We investigated visually guided eye movements in sight recovery individuals with long periods of visual pattern deprivation (3–36 years) following birth due to congenital, dense, total, bilateral cataracts. As controls we assessed (1) individuals with nystagmus due to causes other than cataracts, (2) individuals with developmental cataracts after cataract removal, and (3) individuals with normal vision. Congenital cataract reversal individuals were able to perform visually guided gaze shifts, even when their blindness had lasted for decades. The typical extensive nystagmus of this group distorted eye movement trajectories, but measures of latency and accuracy were as expected from their prevailing nystagmus—that is, not worse than in the nystagmus control group. To the best of our knowledge, the present quantitative study is the first to investigate the characteristics of oculomotor control in congenital cataract reversal individuals, and it indicates a remarkable effectiveness of visually guided eye movements despite long-lasting periods of visual deprivation.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Aristotle as a neuroscientist: The power of habit and the science of the science of metron
Christos Tsagkaris
 
Abstract
 
Both Aristotle and contemporary neuroscientists have investigated habit as an incremental component of memory. Many of Aristotle’s conclusions contradict with existing evidence. However, some of his observations may unlock current stalemates with regard to memory. The purpose of this work is to compare Aristotle’s observations with contemporary neuroscience in terms of habit and discuss their potential connection. While habit has been regarded for year as a non – semantic memory process, Aristotle has emphasized on the conscious and semantic dimension of repetition. Current evidence highlights the rational background of habit in line with Aristotle’s conclusions. The modern terms of up- and down regulation and withdrawal can be compared with the Aristotelian concepts of thymos and ethismos
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Serotonin functions as a bidirectional guidance cue regulating growth cone motility
Silvia Vicenzi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Lisa Foa ; Rob Gasperini

The neurotransmitter serotonin is implicated in a range of mental health disorders that are associated with altered neuronal connectivity during development. Remarkably, serotonin is synthesized and secreted in the embryonic brain prior to the formation of most synapses, thus before neural circuits become fully functional. This suggests serotonin could regulate neuronal connectivity through a process known as axon guidance, which enables neurons to form accurate connections. Growth cones, the leading tips of neurons, are guided in the developing brain by instructive molecules called guidance cues that enable neurons to reach and connect to their targets. We hypothesized that serotonin acts as a novel guidance cue, regulating growth cone motility and hence, axon guidance during early stages of brain circuit formation. Using a growth cone motility assay and a range of pharmacological tools, we found serotonin acts bimodally, attracting and repelling growth cones, through the binding to specific serotonin receptors 5HT2a and 5HT1b, respectively. Using high resolution imaging of growth cones exposed to microgradients of serotonin, we showed serotonin-induced bidirectional motility is underpinned by two distinct signalling mechanisms: 5-HT2a-induced attraction is mediated by calcium release, while 5-HT1b-induced repulsion is driven by cAMP signalling. Optogenetic manipulation of 5-HT2a signalling altered growth cone trajectories away from serotonin, further demonstrating the specificity of secreted serotonin as an axon guidance cue. Unravelling how serotonin functions to regulate the normal wiring of the brain will allow us to better understand how dysfunction in serotonin signalling during development could contribute to the onset of neurodevelopmental disorders.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Neural dynamics of stroboscopic stimulation at different stimulation frequencies
Ram Kumar Pari
 
Abstract
 
Stroboscopic stimulation has been previously shown to induce visual hallucinations and altered states of consciousness, state by entraining the brain to the driving frequency, similar to those reported under psychedelics; Although little systematic research exists on the effect of specific stimulation frequency on the experience. Previous studies have used different measures associated with consciousness, with psychedelics to quantify and measure such altered states of consciousness (ASC) produced and its effect on consciousness. The present study investigated the effects of different stroboscopic stimulation frequencies (3, 7, 8, 10, 13, 15, 19 Hz) on neural dynamics, using measures such as signal diversity (Lempel-Ziv complexity) and spectral power measured using EEG and attempted to relate these changes to self-reported changes in experiential content. The results indicated the stimulation frequencies within and near the alpha band (8 – 12 Hz) caused the greatest increase across all tested neural measures, with 8 Hz consistently displaying the most pronounced results, relative to baseline. All tested frequencies led to an increase in all experiential dimensions, relative to baseline and produced subjective visual and experiential effects similar to those associated with psychedelics. The results highlight the rich potential of using stroboscopic stimulation as a means of non-invasive neuromodulation.

Interactive talk
Watch now
Bi-directional tDCS produces anterior and posterior current flow in neighbouring cortical targets.
Jenny Lee
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jenny Lee, Department of Clinical and Movement Neurosciences, Queen Square Institute of Neurology, University College London; Carys Evans, Department of Clinical and Movement Neurosciences, Queen Square Institute of Neurology, University College London; Nick Ward, Department of Clinical and Movement Neurosciences, Queen Square Institute of Neurology, University College London; Sven Bestmann, 1Department of Clinical and Movement Neurosciences, Queen Square Institute of Neurology, University College London, Wellcome Trust Centre for Neuroimaging.

Introduction. Motor- and sensory-evoked potentials (MEPs and SEPs) are well-established biomarkers of the physiological effects of tDCS, and the primary motor (M1) and sensory (S1) cortices are positioned in close proximity on either bank of the central sulcus. De- or hyper-polarisation of neurons by tDCS is dependent on the orientation of current flow.

Conventional tDCS montages produce unidirectional current flow across M1 and S1. Since the principal axes of pyramidal neurons in the pre- and post-central gyral walls are predominantly oriented in opposite directions, conventional montages could produce orthogonal effects. Given the intimate connectivity between M1 and S1, this may contribute to variability in tDCS outcomes, and adds complexity to interpretation of observed biomarker changes.

Informed by current flow models, we propose a novel, bi-directional tDCS montage whereby current is directed to flow predominantly in the same direction along pyramidal neurons in M1 and S1, and therefore in opposite directions with respect to the whole head.

Objectives. To model a bi-directional tDCS montage which produces posterior-anterior (PA) current flow through M1 (PAM1) and anterior-posterior (AP) current flow through S1 (APS1). An ongoing physiological study will compare M1/S1 excitability changes after application of bi-directional and conventional tDCS.

Materials & Methods. E-field intensity and direction are modelled in MRI scans from the Human Connectome Project using Realistic Volumetric Approach to Simulate Transcranial Electric Stimulation (ROAST) and Freesurfer software.

Results. A custom HD-tDCS montage can produce uniformly polarizing current in M1 and S1. However, bi-directional current flow is achieved at the cost of E-field intensity at cortical targets. A conventional montage achieves desired E-field intensity at the cost of direction.

Summary and Outlook. Bi-directional tDCS can be achieved in neighbouring cortical regions. Model optimisation and physiological validation is ongoing, to improve E-field intensity and quantify the effects of bi-directional tDCS on cortical excitability.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
The dynamics of body category and emotion processing in high-level visual, prefrontal and parietal cortex.
Giuseppe Marrazzo
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Maarten J. Vaessen, Maastricth University; Beatrice de Gelder, Maastricth University, University College London;

Recent studies provided an increasingly detailed understanding of how visual objects like faces or bodies are categorized. What is less clear is how attributes like the emotional expression are represented, whether the coding of the expression is influenced by the task and influences the category representation. Using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and multivariate methods, we measured BOLD responses while participants viewed whole body expressions and performed an explicit (emotion) and implicit (shape) recognition task. Our results show that the type of task can be decoded in extrastriate body area (EBA), ventrolateral prefrontal cortex (VLPFC) and inferior parietal lobule (IPL) with higher activity for the explicit task condition in the first two areas and no evidence of emotion specificity processes in any of them. During the task of explicit recognition of the body expression, category representation would be strengthened while action related information would be suppressed. These results provide evidence that body representations in high level visual cortex and frontoparietal cortex are task sensitive and differentially contribute to expression representation based on their different anatomical connectivity.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Dynamic analysis of eye-head movements for estimating visuo-cognitive demands during driving
Laura Mikula (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sergio Mejía-Romero, Université de Montréal; Romain Chaumillon, Université de Montréal; Amigale Patoine, Université de Montréal; Eduardo Lugo, Université de Montréal; Delphine Bernardin Université de Montréal, Essilor International; Jocelyn Faubert Université de Montréal

Driving is a complex activity involving visuo-cognitive processes and failure to meet visual and/or cognitive needs can potentially affect drivers’ safety. Previous studies have shown that eye and head movements contribute to attention reallocation and they are both modulated by visuo-cognitive demands (Doshi et al., 2012; Fang et al., 2015). This study seeks to investigate the effect of visual degradation and increased cognitive demands on drivers’ eye-head movements and their ability to maneuver a vehicle in a driving simulator.
Twenty-one participants (21-34 years old) completed a driving task in which they were asked to maintain their speed constant while doing a concurrent visual task. Every participant performed the experiment with normal vision and with contact lenses inducing a visual degradation. Parameters such as speed and car lateral position were measured in the driving simulator; eye and head movements were recorded through motion capture. Visual exploration was analyzed using spatial and dynamic parameters.
Our results revealed that driving speed, but not car lateral position, was affected by visuo-cognitive demands (p < 0.05). Spatio-temporal parameters typically used to describe visual exploration (i.e. fixation duration, gaze position along horizontal and vertical axes) were not modulated by the visual degradation (all p > 0.05). In contrast, entropy showed that visual scanning was less explorative (p < 0.05) and participants recruited more head movements for horizontal gaze shifts (p = 0.03) when vision was degraded.
In conclusion, we showed that participants’ ability to maneuvering a vehicle while engaged in a secondary task remains relatively intact when vision is not optimal. We also provided evidence that eye-head movements and dynamic visual exploration are sensitive to the quality of vision and could be used as potential indicators of visuo-cognitive demands in more naturalistic tasks, such as driving.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Neuroscience Needs Philosophy to Understand Representations
Ben Baker
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ben Lansdell

Typical systems neuroscience experiments vary stimuli and correlate these with firing rates of recorded neurons. Such experiments are commonly taken to reveal that the neural activity is a representation of the stimulus. However, representation is a philosophical concept with a rich history. Within philosophy the concept of a representation goes far beyond correlation, typically implying semantically evaluable content and the possibility of misrepresentation. Here we summarize the standard investigative approach in neuroscience as well as the philosophical notion of representation as relates to understanding the mind. We point out how typical neuroscientific experiments stay well short of establishing what philosophers mean with representation. We then discuss approaches in neuroscience that rely on recording from much or all of an organism's nervous system, and approaches that use Deep Neural Nets to models intelligent behavior. We argue for a way that contemporary philosophy ought to be used to allow neuroscience to rework its approaches to meaningfully get at neural representations within these novel approaches.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Adult Zebrafish Possess Two Phenotypically and Functionally Distinct Microglial Populations
Shuting WU
 
Abstract
 
Microglia are the tissue-resident macrophages in the central nervous system and are critically involved in immune defense, neural development and function, and neuroinflammation. The versatility of microglia has long been attributed to heterogeneity. Recent studies revealed possible heterogeneity in human but not murine microglia, yet a firm demonstration linking microglial heterogeneity to functional phenotypes remains scarce. Here, we identified two distinct microglial populations in adult zebrafish that differ in morphology, distribution, development, and function. The predominant population – phagocytotic microglia, which expresses ccl34b.1, is broadly distributed, amoeboid in shape, highly mobile and phagocytotic. The other white matter-enriched ccl34b.1- population, termed regulatory microglia, possesses ramified protrusions but has limited mobility and phagocytosis capability. Their functional differences are further supported by distinct transcriptomes and responses to bacterial infection, where ccl34b.1+ microglia function in tissue clearance and ccl34b.1- microglia release immune regulators. Our study sheds light on the heterogeneity and functional diversification of microglia.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Study of states of consciousness under the effects of anesthetics through the use of information quantifiers
Nicolás Fuentes
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Nicolás Fuentes, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas, Físicas y Naturales. Universidad Nacional de Córdoba;Alexis García,Facultad de Ciencias Exactas, Físicas y Naturales (Universidad Nacional de Córdoba);Diego Mateos,Consejo Nacional de Investigaciones Científicas y Técnicas de Argentina (CONICET),Facultad de Ciencia y Tecnología. Universidad Autónoma de Entre Ríos (UADER),Instituto de Matemática aplicada del Litoral (IMAL-CONICET-UNC);Ana Carolina Maldonado,Centro de Investigación y Estudios de Matemática (CIEM-CONICET). FAMAF.Universidad Nacional de Córdoba

In the surgical practice it is of critical importance to know the state of consciousness that the patient has. Generally, this work is done by anaesthesiologists using visual inspection. To deal with this problem for some time, indices have been developed that allow to quantify the patient’s state of consciousness. However, these measures often have a great computational cost or needed expensive equipment. This generates the demand to develop new indexes, based on fast algorithms and open source. In this work we analyse electrocorticogram monkeys records under different anaesthesia using information quantifiers. The results showed that the use of these measures allows to detect the different states of consciousness of the monkeys. In addition, it could be seen that the effect of anaesthesia on brain dynamics varies depending on the anaesthetic used. These results show that these metrics could be used as indices of consciousness in patients under anesthesia.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Development of the Functional Assessment of Motor and Process Skills Scale among clients with Acquired Brain Injury
Stuti Chakraborty
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Reetha Janet Sureka; Abraham Peter J.; Samuel Kamalesh Kumar S.; Dr. Judy Ann John

BACKGROUND:. Occupational Therapy intervention aims to improve the client’s occupational performance, hence there is a need for occupational therapists to assess the client’s deficits in areas such as cognitive, motor or psychosocial ability. Current tools available for assessing such deficits are not performance based or specific to skills required for occupational performance.
AIM: To develop and validate a function-based assessment tool – the Functional Assessment of Motor and Process Skills Scale (FUMPS) in order to determine the specific deficits in motor and processing skills required for occupational performance, among clients with Acquired Brain Injury.
METHODS: The study consisted of 2 phases. The first phase involved tool development and obtaining expert panel’s opinion. The second phase consisted of standardization of the tool. For standardization, the tool was administered on 25 participants with acquired brain injury by two different raters and at two different points of time for finding the inter rater and test retest reliability. For finding concurrent validity, the tool was compared with COVS and MOCA scores of the participants.
RESULTS: FUMPS was found to have good correlation for inter rater reliability for both the motor and process skill components (motor skill - Cronbach’s alpha 0.98 , process skill – Cronbach’s alpha = 0.99) between two raters and was also statistically significant (P = 0.0 for both motor and process skill). It was also found to have good correlation for test retest reliability (motor skill – Cronbach’s alpha = 0.99, process skill – Cronbach’s alpha = 0.97) and was also statistically significant (P = 0.00 for both motor and process skill). While assessing concurrent validity, the tool was found to have good correlation with MOCA (Cronbach’s alpha = 0.83), moderate correlation with COVS (Cronbach’s alpha = 0.78) and was statistically significant (P = 0.00 for both).
CONCLUSION: From this study it can be concluded that the FUMPS is a reliable and valid measure for finding the specific motor and process skill deficits while performing functional tasks among persons with acquired brain injury.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Accuracy, Confidence and Decision-time of Perceptual Decisions in Discrete vs Continuous Environment
Zahra Azizi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Zahra Azizi, Institute for Cognitive Science Studies, Tehran, Iran; Reza Ebrahimpour, Cognitive Science Research lab., Department of Computer Engineering, Shahid Rajaee Teacher Training University, Tehran, Iran; Sajjad Zabbah, School of Cognitive Sciences, Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences (IPM), Tehran, Iran

In many cases, decisions require information integration from pieces of evidence with discrete time intervals. Yet, the neural mechanism underlying these decisions is uncertain.
This research has mainly concentrated on accuracy, confidence, and decision-time of double-pulse vs single-pulse stimulus. To inspect the concept, behavioral and electroencephalography (EEG) data have been analyzed.
Accordingly, we applied a perceptual decision-making experiment using Random Dot Motions (RDM) paradigm. Participants had to indicate the predominant direction of motion of a cloud of moving dots (left or right) by saccadic eye movement to the chosen target after receiving one or two pulses of 120 ms of information. Both direction and strength of the motion changed trial by trial. Moreover, the interval of two pulses is selected randomly from 0, 120, 360, and 1080 ms. Healthy adult subjects were tested and meanwhile, we used a 32-channel amplifier for the EEG signal recording. Here, we searched for the relation of accuracy, confidence, decision-time, and their ERP (Event-related potential) characterizations in a more real-life like decision-making.
Results from behavioral and the ERP have shown that participants develop similar behavior but with some differences in the discrete vs continuous environment. Subjects’ performance and confidence were independent of the intervals up 1 s. However, unlike the confidence, accuracy improved considerably in double-pulse trials. Moreover, when participants had better accuracy, their decision-time (the time between response cue and saccadic response) decreased. Interestingly, the decision-time of single-pulse trials was significantly longer compared to double-pulse trials. The grand-average ERP results showed a peak observed around 300 ms after the stimulus offset. This peak was identified to be related to decision-making and significantly increased in faster decisions.
To summarize, it seems, along with the continuous environment, accuracy, confidence, and decision-time could be tracked from ERPs component during decision-making in a discrete environment.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Are primates just big frogs? Forelimb force direction and amplitude are independently controlled by spinal motor modules
Amit Yaron (He\Him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Amit yaron NCNP; David Paul Kowalski, NCNP\Drexel ; Hiroaki Yaguchi, NCNP ; Tomohiko Takei, NCNP\Kyoto University; Kazuhiko Seki, NCNP

Modular organization of the spinal motor system is thought to reduce the cognitive complexity of
simultaneously controlling the large number of muscles and joints in the human body. Although modular
organization has been confirmed in the hindlimb control system of several animal species, it has yet to be
established in the forelimb motor system or in primates. Expanding upon experiments originally
performed in the frog lumbar spinal cord, we examined whether co-stimulation of two sites in the
macaque monkey cervical spinal cord results in motor activity that is a simple linear sum of the responses
evoked by stimulating each site individually. Similar to previous observations in the frog and rodent
hindlimb, our analysis revealed that in most cases (77% of all pairs), the directions of the force fields
elicited by co-stimulation were highly similar to those predicted by the simple linear sum of those elicited
by stimulating each site individually. A comparable simple summation of EMG output, especially in the
proximal muscles, suggested that this linear summation of force field direction was produced by a spinal
neural mechanism whereby the forelimb motor output recruited by co-stimulation was also summed
linearly. We further found that the force field magnitudes exhibited supra-linear (amplified) summation,
which was also observed in the EMG output of distal forelimb muscles, implying a novel feature of
primate forelimb control. Overall, our observations support the idea that complex movements in the
primate forelimb control system are made possible by flexibly combined spinal motor modules.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Dissecting Transient Burst Events
Catharina Zich
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Andrew J Quinn, University of Oxford; Lydia C Mardell, UCL; Nick S Ward, UCL; Sven Besmann, UCL

Neural activity recorded from the scalp [magneto-/electroencephalogram (M/EEG)], cortical surface [electrocorticogram (EcoG)], or inside the brain [local field potential (LFP)] is traditionally analysed by averaging tens to hundreds of trials. The trial-wise average of spectrograms commonly shows periods of sustained high or low spectral power. The underlying single trial activity may manifest as oscillations (i.e., sustained rhythmic fluctuations of synchronous spiking activity) or burst-like events. Burst-like events are intermittent, transient periods of synchronous spiking activity.
Events have a temporal, spectral, and spatial domain. However, most work so far has focussed on temporal event characteristics. Events are thereby compressed to a singular dimension, by reducing the spatial and spectral domains of their underlying signals. Domain reduction can have several un- wanted consequences. First, different domain reduction methods likely result in differences in event characteristics. Second, domain reduction can obscure interactions (e.g. temporal-spatial interaction also known as traveling wave) between domains, which may lead to ambiguous inferences and conclusions drawn from these analyses.
Considering all three domains will yield a more accurate description of individual event characteristics and their interactions. This is likely to underpin identification of more precise fingerprints of mechanisms underlying differences in population activity measures, such as spectral power. In turn, this can guide development of rational and mechanistically grounded treatments that target neurological and psychiatric conditions.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Neural data to visual masking in humans shows that deeper convolutional neural networks capture recurrent processes
Jessica Loke
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jessica Loke, University of Amsterdam; Noor Seijdel, University of Amsterdam; Lukas Snoek, University of Amsterdam; Ron van de Klundert, University of Amsterdam; Matthew van der Meer, University of Amsterdam; Eva Quispel, University of Amsterdam; Natalie Cappaert, University of Amsterdam; H. Steven Scholte, University of Amsterdam.

Recent studies have argued for a need to incorporate recurrent processing in the architecture of feedforward models (van Bergen and Kriegeskorte 2020; Kietzmann et al. 2019). Recurrent processing is a crucial feature in human visual processing that supports perceptual grouping (Roelfsema 2006), figure-ground segmentation (Supèr et al. 2001) and recognition under challenging conditions (Tang and Kreiman 2017; Spoerer et al. 2017; Rajaei et al. 2019). All of this suggests that current feedforward models are limited compared to their recurrence cousins. In this paper, we show how existing feedforward models exhibit operations similar to recurrent processing in the brain. Sixty-two human subjects and a family of ResNet models completed an object recognition task. The models varied in depth - ResNet-6, 10, 18, 34 - with their names indicating the number of layers. We found that the deeper networks (i.e. ResNet-34) performed more similarly to humans under normal circumstances; whereas, shallower networks perform more similarly to humans when recurrent processing is interfered with visual masking. By examining the human subjects’ electroencephalography (EEG) activity and activations in artificial networks, we observed two important findings. One, early differentiation in EEG signals is largely explained by image background and not object category. Image background, image complexity and object category interact: identical objects embedded in more complex backgrounds take longer to reach categorical perception. Two, ResNet models differ in how well they can explain neural data when recurrent processing is unhindered: deeper networks explain more variance as compared to shallower networks. But when recurrent processing is interfered, all networks explain the same amount of variance. Crucially, the difference in explained variance between unmasked and masked data only emerges at ~186ms - a latency beyond feedforward processes. This shows that networks of different depths differ in their abilities to model recurrent processing, showing that deeper networks model capture recurrent processing in humans.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Building a hierarchically controlled robot arm for real world behavior
Adam Matic (he, him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Alex Gomez-Marin

Motor control research often relies on computational modelling, aiming at plausible and biologically relevant results in simulated environments. In contrast, robotic approaches must work in the real world with delays, nonlinearities and noise - posing a greater challenge on the proposed architectures, and promising greater insight. Commercially available robots with pre-programmed control systems are an appropriate solution to perform certain tasks from the get-go. From a theoretical perspective, however, this can be limiting since alternative control architectures cannot be tested. Here we built a simple robot arm with two shoulder joints, elbow and wrist, from the ground up, 3D printed arm segments, DC motors as actuators; potentiometers, pressure and tilt sensors and a webcam for sensory input. We programmed the control architecture for visual and kinesthetic arm control on a PC and an Arduino-compatible microcontroller. The robot performed a planar reaching task and a tracking task following a continuously moving visual reference, while simultaneously maintaining constant pen pressure and angle of tilt. While modest in speed and precision, the robot arm successfully performed these tasks, showing biologically relevant movement features, such as bell-shaped speed profiles, isochronous rise times, and the emergence of the speed-curvature power law at high speeds. Next, we imposed movement constraints and perturbations such as inclining the writing surface, displacing the visual marker, blocking the wrist, and rotating the visual field. Without any learning algorithms or parameter adjustments, the robot performed successful reaching and tracking. In sum, while maintaining computational simplicity, the proposed architecture is capable of integrating several modalities of sensory information and coordinating multiple degrees of freedom in real-world tasks, demonstrating how some observed biological movement invariances might emerge not from a complex plan, but from the interaction of brain, body and environment
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Exploring Latent Structures of Cognitive Tasks Using PCA
Nora Bradford (She/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Davide Momi, University "G. d'Annunzio" of Chieti ; Nora Bradford, University of California, Irvine; Ladan Shahshahani, University of Western Ontario; Corey Richier, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign

Intro: It is established that aspects of cognition are overlapping in terms of their neural representation. We wanted to explore the latent structure across different cognitive tasks within the human connectome project (HCP) using PCA.
Methods: We applied PCA to task-evoked functional activity. The analytical pipeline was as follows: Time series for each task were extracted from the dataset. Each task was broken down into their separate sub-conditions (e.g., 0-back and 2-back working memory conditions.) Each condition for each task was then decomposed into a functional connectivity matrix. Finally, PCA was applied to each condition across each task.
Results: PCA components were extracted for each of the tasks in the HCP dataset. Initially, we examined how many components would best characterize the variability across tasks. Some tasks required many components to explain 95% of the variance (e.g., gambling, motor, emotion) whereas others required fewer (working memory, social) Across tasks, four components would be able to explain 95% of the variance.
Discussion: Our findings reveal that fewer components are needed to explain the variance in complex working memory and social tasks than in seemingly simpler tasks (e.g. motor). This may be due to the added noise of cognitive tasks, leading to a more distributed variance across components. It could also be due to mind-wandering during simpler tasks. In datasets like HCP which incorporate many types of tasks, PCA can be a helpful tool to project the functional connectivity patterns into spaces in which tasks are distinguishable. PCA is also a useful dimensionality reduction tool in fMRI data to reduce the size of the data without losing much of the variance within the dataset.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Developmental differences in white matter tracts between and within the dorsal and ventral streams
Sophia Vinci-Booher
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Vinci-Booher, S., Indiana University; Bullock, D., Indiana University; Caron, B., Indiana University; James, K.H., Indiana University; Pestilli, F. , Indiana University, University of Texas

A relatively unexplored group of white matter tracts that connect cortical regions associated with the ventral and dorsal visual streams have recently been described and made available for scientific investigation. We utilized diffusion MRI and reproducible, cloud-computing methods to characterize the development of these vertical white matter tracts in a cross-sectional sample of 24 children (5-8 years old) and 12 adults (18-22 years old). We then compared the development of these posterior vertical tracts to the development of horizontal tracts within the ventral and dorsal visual streams. Horizontal tracts within the ventral stream had FA that was more adult-like than horizontal tracts in the dorsal cortex, consistent with prior work. The development of the posterior vertical tracts was more similar to the development of the horizontal tracts in the ventral visual stream than tracts in the dorsal cortex, with higher FA values found in adults than in children. In one tract, the pArc, FA was predicted by performance on a perceptual matching task in the child sample. Our results suggest that posterior vertical tracts develop later than ventral stream tracts, but earlier than tracts in the dorsal cortex, and that the development of posterior vertical tracts may be related to the influence of perceptual processing on dorsally-mediated action in childhood.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Network principles predict motor cortex population activity across movement speeds
Shreya Saxena
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Abigail Russo, Princeton University; John Cunningham, Columbia University; Mark Churchland, Columbia University

Learned movements can be skillfully performed at different paces. What neural strategies produce this flexibility? Can they be predicted and understood by network modeling? We trained monkeys to perform a cycling task at different speeds, and trained artificial recurrent networks to generate the empirical muscle-activity patterns. Network solutions, combined with the principle that noise-robust dynamics require low trajectory tangling, yielded quantitative and qualitative predictions. To evaluate predictions, we recorded motor cortex population activity during the same task. Responses supported the hypothesis that the dominant neural signals reflect not muscle activity per se, but network-level strategies for generating muscle activity across speeds. Single-neuron responses were better described when regressed against network activity than when regressed against muscle activity. More deeply, population-level neural trajectories were structured differently from muscle trajectories. Neural trajectories had an organization that maintained low trajectory tangling within and across speeds, matching the structure of network solutions.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Automated Screening to Assist a Systematic Living Summary of Primary In Vivo Focal Cerebral Ischaemic Stroke Research
Emma Wilson
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Florenz Cruz, Charité-Universitätsmedizin Berlin; Joly Ghanawi, Independent Researcher; Jing Liao, University of Edinburgh; Sarah McCann, Charité-Universitätsmedizin Berlin; Malcolm Macleod, University of Edinburgh; Emily Sena, University of Edinburgh

Introduction: The failure to plan new research based on a systematic assessment of the existing literature is an important source of research waste. Systematic reviews of primary in vivo focal cerebral ischaemic stroke research have informed improvements in research quality and translation of findings to the clinic[1]. However, the process is time-consuming and, by completion, the results are often out of date. We aim to develop a workflow to automatically identify reports of this research to allow a systematic living summary of the literature[2].
Methods: We trained the machine-learning algorithm using a random sample of PubMed records from a search of terms relevant to focal cerebral ischaemia supplemented with relevant studies identified from previous systematic reviews[3]. In August 2020, we conducted a systematic search of PubMed and Embase and passed the unique studies through the algorithm to identify all primary in vivo focal cerebral ischaemic stroke research.
Results: Our random sample (N=4,000) identified 130 (3.3%) primary in vivo focal cerebral ischaemic stroke studies. We trained the machine-learning algorithm with 4,786 studies (4,000 random sample plus 786 identified from previous systematic reviews). The algorithm identified relevant studies with sensitivity at 95%, specificity at 98% and precision at 92%. Our systematic search of PubMed and Embase identified 752,494 unique studies duplicate removal. Of this, the algorithm identified 27,269 (3.6%) primary in vivo focal cerebral ischaemic stroke studies.
Conclusions: Automated screening of search results in systematic review will save substantial resources, especially where the yield of relevant studies is low. Preliminary machine-learning results suggest that this machine-learning algorithm is highly accurate in identifying primary in vivo focal cerebral ischaemic stroke research and could be used in an automated systematic living summary workflow curating such research.

References
[1] McCann et al. (2016) doi: 10.1007/s12975-016-0489-z
[2] Wilson et al. (2020) Retrieved from https://osf.io/ek6df/, Aug 2020
[3] CAMARADES Focal Ischaemic Stroke Database. Retrieved from https://camarades.shinyapps.io/SRMed/, Aug 2020
Traditional talk
Watch now
Evidence accumulation in the human brain using a novel continuous dot-motion task
Maria Ruesseler
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tom Marshall, Department of Experimental Psychology- University of Oxford; Lilian Weber, Department of Psychiatry - University of Oxford; Jill O'Reilly, Department of Experimental Psychology - University of Oxford; Laurence Hunt, Department of Psychiatry - University of Oxford,
