Special Event
Watch now
First-Gen In Neuro: Stories of Science From First-Generation Scholars
 
Abstract
 
Science is a winding road of obstacles, struggles, and detours. However, the vast majority of the science we see is presented in its most pristine form. We see the published paper, the perfectly curated powerpoint, the tenure announcement, the notice of award. Rarely do we hear about the journey. In this event, a series of incredibly successful first-generation scholars will tell their personal stories in science. These brief talks will focus on how they became scientists, how they navigated the unfamiliar territory of academia, and the barriers they faced along the way. This will be followed by a panel discussion and Q&A session. These stories will uplift early-career scientists and amplify a community of scholars struggling through a system that is not structured for their success.

Organizers:
- Daniel L. Gonzales, PhD (HHMI Hanna Gray Fellow, Purdue University_

- Caroline Palavicino-Maggio, PhD (Postdoctoral Researcher, Harvard Medical School)

Panelists:
- Steve Ramirez, Assistant Professor, Boston University (http://theramirezgroup.org/team/steve-ramirez)

- David Jentsch, Empire Innovation Professor of Psychology, Binghamton State University (https://sites.google.com/binghamton.edu/jentsch-laboratory)

- Michael Burton, Assistant Professor, UT Dallas (https://labs.utdallas.edu/niblab/)

- Robert Carrillo, Assistant Professor, University of Chicago (https://www.carrillolab.com/)

- Ellen Lumpkin, Professor, University of California, Berkeley (https://vcresearch.berkeley.edu/faculty/ellen-lumpkin)

- Diana Bautista, Professor, University of California, Berkeley (https://bautistalab.weebly.com/)
... continues ... Interactive talk
Watch now
Towards Machine to Brain Interfaces: Sensory Stimulation Enhances Sensorimotor Dynamic Functional Connectivity in Upper Limb Amputees
Keqin Ding
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Keqin Ding, Johns Hopkins School of Medicine; Andrei Dragomir, National University of Singapore; Rohit Bose, University of Pittsburgh; Luke E. Osborn, Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory; Manuel S. Seet, National University of Singapore; Anastasios Bezerianos, National University of Singapore; Nitish V. Thakor, Johns Hopkins School of Medicine

Recent development of sensory stimulation techniques demonstrates the ability to elicit touch-like phantom sensations in upper limb amputees. The cortical processing of this phantom sensation and the corresponding influences on sensorimotor functional connectivity have not been studied. We show the temporal dynamics of brain functional connectivity with and without sensory stimulation. Electroencephalogram (EEG) was recorded from 2 amputee participants and 3 able-bodied participants while they were performing hand movements with and without transcutaneous nerve stimulation. We applied dynamic functional connectivity (dFC) analysis, by modeling cortical signals as a series of functional networks along the temporal dimension. Results show that sensory stimulation enhances the speed of information transfer and number of connection paths between brain systems such as primary somatosensory (S1), primary motor, and higher order processing regions, all of which are involved in sensorimotor processing. The increased number in connection paths between S1 and motor systems is the most significant during the first 750 ms of the entire stimulation period. This is the first work to reveal dynamic communication between somatosensory, motor, and higher order processing regions in the cortex of amputees in response to sensory stimulation. This work provides insights into how multiple sensory modalities contribute to the motor cortex to generate motor actions. Topics for future research include investigating the functional connections from motor or multisensory processing systems to the somatosensory system in similar tasks, exploring the modular changes of large scale brain networks, and mapping the long term brain changes in amputee participants from immediate loss of sensory input to restoration through sensory feedback.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Relating the power law decay of power and eigenvalue spectra of neural population data
Brian Barry
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Bradley Voytek, University of California San Diego; Richard Gao, University of California San Diego

Neural data of all kinds exhibit 1/f-like statistics, which is often interpreted as evidence that the brain operates at the edge of criticality. Indeed, systems at criticality display scale-free temporal and spatial correlations, typically characterized by power law distributions of avalanche size and duration with related exponents. Previous works have demonstrated this in neural activity, and it is thought that long-range correlations across space and time maximize information processing. Alternatively, temporal and spatial correlation in neural population data can be characterized by the power spectrum and eigendecomposition (via PCA). It is well known that neural power spectra often follow a 1/f power law, where power decays as a function of frequency. More recently, it’s been shown that neural population activity resides on a low-dimensional manifold, and that the eigenvalue spectrum also follows a power law.

Here we investigate the relationship between the eigenvalue and power spectra – decompositions across space and time, respectively – in population spiking recordings and simulated data. We fit power law models to population power spectra and eigenspectra, and compute the correlation between their power law exponents as a function of population subsampling size, to find a subset size at which potential correlations between the exponents may arise. We find that space and time decompositions were correlated for select brain regions (e.g. V1, V2 and hippocampal formation) in some mice and no definitive subset size initiated inter-spectral correlations. In comparison, we simulate independent colored noise “recordings” with varying exponents, and find 1) their eigenvalue spectra spuriously also follow power law distributions, where 2) the decay exponents in time and space are closely related, despite being independently generated processes. This seems to arise naturally as a consequence of correlating any power law distributed processes. This suggests that low-dimensional (typically power law obeying) neural manifolds can arise purely as a result of the temporal statistics of potentially independent neuronal activity, thus calling for more robust measures of neural manifolds and criticality in the brain.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Impulse Inhibition in Frequent Cannabis Users
Assel Al-Bayati
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Holy Clayton, York University; Ryan Cortez, York University; Bernard Marius ’t Hart, York University; Denise Y. P. Henriques, York University

Since the legalization of recreational use of cannabis took effect in Canada, many questions have been brought forward regarding its immediate and sustained effect on daily tasks. For example, the long-term effect of cannabis is unclear on tasks that involve the inhibition of ingrained actions to avoid accidents, such as in driving or operating machinery. To investigate the effect of cannabis on various brain functions, we created a battery of cognitively demanding, visual-spatial and visual-motor tasks. Here, we discuss preliminary findings of one of the tasks in this battery: a speeded Go/No-Go task (80% go, 20% no-go) that measures the ability to inhibit motor impulses. Task performance is analyzed by comparing the proportion of false alarms on no-go trials as well as reaction times on hits and false alarms in frequent cannabis users (N=9) and non-users (N=63). Our findings indicate no difference in task performance on the speeded Go/No-Go task for frequent users of cannabis, versus non-users. These results may suggest the absence of a negative effect of cannabis on performance of impulse inhibition. However, these results are preliminary and are not conclusive on the impact of cannabis on cognition and motor performance.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
A miniature microscope for neuro + vascular imaging in freely moving animals
Janaka Senarathna
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Nitish V. Thakor; Arvind P. Pathak

Imaging multiple variables that characterize brain function in neuroscientific and preclinical animal models permits a better understanding of neurophysiology and its disruption in disease. However, multi-variable imaging systems need to acquire images with multiple contrasts, and therefore require inclusion of many optical components which make them large and stationary. Moreover, such systems are often custom designed, expensive, and restrict experimentation due to the need for anesthesia or animal head fixation. To overcome these challenges, we developed a portable, low-cost, miniature optical microscope capable of imaging three optical contrasts over a 3x3 mm2 field of view at 5 µm resolution. The microscope consists of a fluorescence (FL) channel for imaging neural activity (e.g. via GCaMP) or fluorescently tagged cells (e.g. 9L-GFP cancer cells); an intrinsic optical signal (IOS) channel for imaging hemoglobin absorption (i.e. cerebral blood volume); and a laser speckle contrast (LSC) channel for imaging perfusion (i.e. cerebral blood flow). Weighing 3g after strain relief, it can be used to conduct neuroimaging in freely behaving mice.

First we compared images acquired via the miniature microscope for each channel with those acquired from a non-miniaturized imaging system, and demonstrated a high degree of correlation. We then used it to interrogate neurovascular coupling in an awake mouse auditory cortex in relation to two distinct sound stimuli at 4 kHz and 24 kHz, and characterized the unique spatial and temporal relationship between neuronal, vasodilatory and blood flow responses to each stimuli. We also used our microscope to investigate in vivo the progression of a brain tumor throughout the tumor’s life-cycle and mapped the stages of angiogenesis and the establishment of patent blood flow within the tumor microenvironment.

We are working on the next generation of our microscope and looking for strategic partners to enable exciting discoveries in both basic neuroscience and preclinical research.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Sensory stimulation for improved phantom limb perception and control
Luke Osborn (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Keqin Ding, Johns Hopkins University; Mark Hays, Johns Hopkins University; Rohit Bose, University of Pittsburgh; Mark Iskarous, Johns Hopkins University; Andrei Dragomir, National University of Singapore; Zied Tayeb, Technical University of Munich; Gyorgy Levay, Infinite Biomedical Technologies; Christopher Hunt, Johns Hopkins University; Gordon Cheng, Technical University of Munich; Robert Armiger, Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory; Anastasios Bezerianos, National University of Singapore; Matthew Fifer, Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory; Nitish Thakor, Johns Hopkins University

A major challenge for controlling a prosthetic arm is communication between the device and the user’s phantom limb. The lack of sensory information to the phantom hand weakens the internal sensorimotor model that drives movement. We showed that targeted transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (tTENS) can be used to provide sensory stimulation and improve phantom limb perception and control. Transcutaneous nerve stimulation experiments were performed with four participants with arm amputation to map and understand their phantom limb perception. Results show that sensory stimulation improves the participants’ ability to perceive and move the phantom hand, which leads to improved movement decoding and functional prosthesis control. In an extended study with one participant, we found that sensory mapping remained stable over 2 years. Sensory stimulation improved within-day movement decoding while overall performance over 1 year remained stable. Using electroencephalogram (EEG) monitoring with two participants, we observed cortical correlates of sensorimotor integration and increased motor-related neural activity as a result of enhanced phantom limb perception. This work demonstrates the benefit of targeted nerve stimulation for improving phantom limb perception and control. Future directions include finding sensory stimulation strategies to optimally improve both short and long term prosthesis control improvements and investigating the effect of enhanced phantom perception on long term changes in motor-related neural activity.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Area-specific and frequency-dependent relationship between local field potentials and neural population dynamics
Cecilia Gallego Carracedo
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Matthew G. Perich, Raeed H. Chowdhury, Lee E. Miller, Juan A. Gallego

Local field potentials (LFPs) are generated by the summed synaptic input currents to local neurons. Many studies have shown that the activity of populations of cortical neurons is well described by low-dimensional, population-wide “latent dynamics”. Here we provide the first investigation of how much information is shared between these latent dynamics and the LFPs that ostensibly drive them.

We used microelectrode arrays to record LFPs and single neuron activity from premotor, primary motor and primary somatosensory cortex as monkeys performed an instructed delay reaching task. We calculated the latent dynamics from the single unit activity using principal component analysis. We computed the LFP power in eight standard frequency bands as well as the “local motor potential”, the moving average of the broadband LFP.

We first examined the relationship between each LFP band and the latent dynamics separately for each cortical area using canonical correlation analysis, a method that quantifies the correlation between the dynamics of two sets of signals. Although for all three areas the lowest and highest LFP frequency bands were strongly correlated with the latent dynamics, the LFP-to-latent dynamics correlations at mid-frequencies were quite variable across areas.

We obtained these results by focusing on one particular aspect of the behaviour: movement preparation for premotor cortex, and movement execution for primary motor and sensory cortices. We asked whether the area-specific relationships were preserved across these different aspects of the behaviour. We computed the canonical correlations between LFP and latent dynamics for both behavioural epochs, then compared the two sets of correlations. Remarkably, for both areas, these correlations were the same during movement planning and execution, and greatly exceeded the correlations observed when monkeys were not engaged in the task. Adopting a neural population view thus allows stable area-specific and frequency-dependent relationships between neural activity and LFPs to be identified.
Traditional talk
Watch now
The study of auditory-vocal load on drivers’ performance.
Seyedehsara hejazi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Masoumeh Korousharami, Mohamadsadegh Ghasemi

Recent years in all over the world, car accidents are account for many fatalities and deaths. There are several causes for car accidents such as driver distraction, sleepiness, fatigue and etc. In this paper, driver distraction is under focus. On the other hand, role of passengers is neglected in many studies, while in real situation passengers play significant role in drivers' distraction. In this research, conversations between passenger and driver are considered as auditory- vocal load as secondary tasks. Methodology: There are 20 healthy people young and experienced drivers (23-45 years old) participated in simulated driving experiment. Each of them passed pre-test (baseline driving) and four level of conversation including general, emotional, second language and problem solving in main experiment. Also DALI as a subjective teat carried out to reflect participant attitude toward the test. Results: Results demonstrated that speed and reaction time increased under emotional and problem solving conversations there was significant change in speed and reaction time. Conclusion: secondary auditory and vocal task may result in drivers’ distraction which can negatively affect driver performances.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Large-scale calcium imaging of spontaneous activity in larval zebrafish reveals signatures of criticality
Michael McCullough
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Robert Wong, University of Queensland, Queensland Brain Institute; Zac Pujic, University of Queensland, Queensland Brain Institute; Biao Sun, University of Queensland, Queensland Brain Institute; Geoffrey J Goodhill, University of Queensland, Queensland Brain Institute, School of Mathematics and Physics;

Neural networks in the brain may self-organise such that they operate near criticality, that is, poised on the boundary between phases of order and disorder. Models of neural networks tuned close to criticality are optimal in terms of dynamic range, information transmission, information storage and computational adaptability. Much of the experimental evidence for criticality in the brain has come from studies of neural spiking data recorded from tissue cultures or anaesthetised animals using microelectrode arrays, or from studies of mesoscopic-scale neural activity using magnetic resonance imaging or electroencephalograms. These approaches are inherently limited either by under-sampling of the neural population or by coarse spatial resolution.

In this study, we investigated neural criticality by utilising the unique properties of the larval zebrafish that enable whole-brain imaging of neural activity in vivo and without anaesthetic. We used 2-photon calcium imaging to observe truly spontaneous activity, and extracted neural activity data at single-cell resolution via state-of-the-art image segmentation. Our data comprise fluorescence time series for large populations of neurons from 3-dimensional volumetric recordings of spontaneous activity in the optic tectum and cerebellum of larval zebrafish with pan-neuronal expression of GCaMP6s (n=5; approx. 10000 neurons per fish). Neuronal avalanche statistics revealed power-law relationships and scale-invariant avalanche shape collapse which are consistent with crackling noise dynamics from a 3-dimensional random field Ising model. This result provides the first evidence of criticality in the brain from large-scale in vivo neural activity at single cell resolution. Our findings demonstrate the potential of larval zebrafish as a model for the investigation of critical phenomena in the context of neurodevelopmental disorders that may perturb the brain away from criticality.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Human neuromarkers of tactile perception: state of the art in methods and findings
Gianna Cannestro Cannestro (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
M. A. Abd, Ocean and Mechanical Engineering, Florida Atlantic University; E. Engeberg, Center for Complex Systems and Brain Sciences & Ocean and Mechanical Engineering, Florida Atlantic University; E. Tognoli, Center for Complex Systems and Brain Sciences, Florida Atlantic University

Tactile perception is a multifaceted sense with complicated convergent/divergent peripheral pathways. Its neuromarkers remain poorly understood, due to the sense’s inherent complexity and the confounding factor of intricate motor, cognitive and affective correlates. This gap hinders research evaluating interventions to restore touch in artificial hands. We inventorize state-of-the-art and recent innovations in control systems with soft and hard robotics that are poised to unlock more targeted non-invasive stimulations. We review neuromarkers observed for pressure, vibration, brushing, texture discrimination, pain, heat and cold, complemented with the covariates from movement, attention, working memory, multisensory and sensorimotor integration or competition (audition, vision) and affect. We analyze neural oscillations during sensory and (peripheral and central) electro-magnetic stimulation. This review matures a framework of reverse prediction, in which non-invasive observation of neural activity robustly and unobtrusively quantifies tactile perception.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Multiscale low-dimensional neural dynamics underlie naturalistic reach-and-grasp movements
Hamidreza Abbaspourazad
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Hamidreza Abbaspourazad, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Southern California; Mahdi Choudhary, Center for Neural Science, New York University; Yan T Wong, Department of Physiology, Electrical and Computer Systems Engineering, Monash University; Bijan Pesaran, Center for Neural Science, New York University; Maryam M Shanechi, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Neuroscience Graduate Program, University of Southern California

Studies of low-dimensional dynamics of neural population activity have largely focused on analyses of spiking activity of a population of neurons. However, motor function involves multiple spatiotemporal scales of brain activity ranging from small-scale processes measured by spiking activity to larger-scale brain network activity reflected in local field potentials (LFP). How low-dimensional dynamics of spiking and LFP activity relate to each other remains elusive to date. Further, for naturalistic reach-and-grasp movements, low-dimensional neural dynamics are relatively under-explored even for spiking population activity. We learn novel multiscale latent state-space models for spiking, LFP and combined spike-LFP activities recorded from non-human primates performing a naturalistic reach-and-grasp movement to diverse locations in 3D space and continuously in time without a trial structure. We partitioned the latent state into several dynamical modes, each characterized with a unique decay-frequency pair which described how fast neural dynamics decayed in time and with what frequency they ringed over time. We then quantified how predictive of behavior each mode was. In both spiking and LFP network activity, there existed a mode that was dominantly predictive of behavior compared to other modes. Interestingly, while spiking and LFP network activity displayed several distinct modes, this predictive mode was shared between them, i.e. had similar decay-frequency characteristics. This implied that the predictive mode was multiscale. Interestingly, the multiscale predictive mode was also shared across sessions and monkeys, but was not simply a replicate of modes in behavior. Finally, the multiscale predictive mode existed in both low-frequency and high-frequency LFP bands. Multiple convergent analysis showed that both the multiscale predictive mode’s decay and frequency explained naturalistic behavior. The predictive mode’s time-decay was ~1s, which was longer than all other modes, suggesting that naturalistic behavior relies on integrating multiscale neural dynamics over longer time-periods. In addition, its frequency was ~0.2 Hz, characterizing how fast the underlying neural dynamics tended to rotate in time. We propose that multiscale, low-dimensional motor cortical dynamics underlie naturalistic reach-and-grasp movements due to the prominent role of large-scale brain networks in these movements.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The effects of dopaminergic psychostimulants on complex problem solving
Elizabeth Bowman
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
David Coghill, University of Melbourne; Carsten Murawski, University of Melbourne; Peter Bossaerts, University of Melbourne

The role of dopaminergic systems in decision-making has been of increasing research interest in recent years. Medications that target these pathways are often used in disorders of attention, and are now also often diverted to non-medical, off-label, and illicit uses in the hope that they will enhance cognition and focus in healthy people. However, research to date reveals a mixed picture of efficacy in this aspect.

We completed a repeated-measures, double-blinded, placebo-controlled single dose trial (PECO: ACTRN12617001544369, U1111-1204-3404) to examine the actions of three indirect dopamine agonists on complex problem-solving performance of healthy adults. Forty participants received 15 mg dextroamphetamine, 30 mg methylphenidate, 200 mg modafinil, or placebo, counterbalanced across 4 testing sessions. In each session, participants completed 16 trials of the Knapsack Task (eight unique instances presented twice each). The Knapsack Task is a NP-hard combinatorial optimisation task, requiring the participant to explore different combinations of items to discover an optimal (maximal) value solution under a specified weight and time constraint.

Mixed-effects modelling of the knapsack decision sequence data revealed that participants took longer to submit solutions in the active drug conditions yet were less likely to find the optimal solution. Participants who performed below-average with placebo explored more solutions while in the active drug conditions, and above-average participants explored less. Closer inspection revealed that the drugs decreased productivity significantly and economically; productivity is the increase in value of the knapsack per item move per unit time. Initial choices, a good predictor of eventual performance in a trial, became more random under active drug conditions.

These findings suggest that dopaminergic stimulant medications may increase healthy adults’ motivation to spend more time and explore more combinations in pursuit of the solution to a computationally complex problem. However, this often results in decreased performance because exploration becomes more random.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Fully implantable wireless and battery-free neuromodulation tools
Philipp Gutruf
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Philipp Gutruf, University of Arizona

Recent advances in materials and optoelectronic concepts for the creation of soft electronics coupled with miniaturization of wireless energy harvesting schemes enable the creation of highly capable neuromodulation tools with sizes, shapes and physical properties matched to biological systems. This seamless integration enables a new class of implants with access to the central and peripheral nervous system and vital organs. Here we present a new class of tools that provide unparalleled capabilities to asses and modulate organ function and enable new experimental paradigms in a range of complex environments and contexts that cannot be explored with conventional technologies. The devices feature miniaturized form factor and technologies that are rapidly scalable to enable broad dissemination while still maintaining compatibility with noninvasive imaging technologies such as computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Specifically, we will highlight 1. Current advances in highly miniaturized wireless and battery free photometric recording devices that enable the study of neural dynamics in in ethnologically relevant environments even in young animal models unlocking new experimental paradigms to uncover the working principles of the developing brain. 2. Wireless battery-free and subdermally optogenetic stimulation tools that enable: neural activation in freely flying birds; transcranial optogenetic stimulation in mice without cranial surgery; long range neural activation in ethologically relevant environments. 3. Wireless battery free and subdermally implantable electrical interfaces to the spinal and muscular system. Combined these platforms for small animal models enable exploratory neuroscience with minimal impact on the test subject and quantitively expand experimental paradigms.

On the Causal Neural Substrates of Incidental Statistical Learning
Paul Dux 		Keynote Event

Panel on Translating Neurotechnology
 
Abstract
 
Nearly a decade ago, President Obama launched the US BRAIN initiative to advance technology and neuroscience research for understanding and treating disorders of the brain. Building on momentum that had been growing over the previous several decades, the BRAIN initiative cast a spotlight on the potential for neurotechnology to address some of society's greatest medical challenges, including Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, neuropsychiatric disorders, and many other brain diseases. The neural engineering community has responded forcefully to this call, creating several exciting new technologies that offer new important new capabilities for monitoring and regulating neural signaling throughout the nervous system. Some of these new technologies are now being transitioned into commercial products, which is a crucial step toward fulfilling the BRAIN vision. This panel includes four innovation leaders that are working to bring novel and potentially breakthrough neurotechnologies to the clinical market.

Speaker 1: Milton Morris, President & CEO of Neuspera Medical
Talk title: Translation of a Novel Mid-Field Powering Technology for Use with an Ultraminiaturized Implantable Neuromodulation Platform

Talk Title: Wireless and minimally invasive neurotherapeutic implants

Habenula as the experience-dependent controlling switchboard of behavior and attention in social conflict and learning

Interactive talk
Watch now
Segregation of current modules in modeling detailed single neuron models
Nathaniel Opsal (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Nate Opsal, University of Missouri; Pete Canfield, University of Missouri; Tyler Banks, University of Missouri; Satish S. Nair, University of Missouri

Biophysical conductance-based models of neuron can provide improved realism in network models to investigate neuronal oscillations. Such single cell models vary in morphological complexity from single compartment to ones that have over 1000 compartments. Computational overheads necessitate the use of reduced order single cells in large model neuronal networks. However, in such cases, it is important that the reduced order models selected retain the key biophysical properties of biological cells. We had previously hypothesized that in a single neuron, different sets of current modules might be responsible for maintaining neurocomputational properties such as resting potential, sub-threshold oscillations, and spiking behaviors. An approach termed the ‘segregation methods’ was designed using the hypothesis and tested successfully on several single cell models reported in the literature (Alturki et al., 2016).

Here we add to the segregation approach for designing current ‘modules’ by developing a new module to design bursts and other burst-like waveforms. We provide an example of a pyramidal neuron in the CA3 region of the hippocampus which is shown to respond to stimuli with a doublet at the start followed by tonic spiking, a characteristic neural signature. Furthermore, we investigate the functional significance of the doublet by embedding the single cell model into a previously developed hippocampal network model. We find that the doublet is critical for generating theta in the hippocampal model. A long-term goal is to develop a publicly accessible software tool that automates the process of designing a single cell using the segregation approach.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Expectations can boost the encoding of specific features of noisy speech
Andrew Corcoran (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Andrew Corcoran, Monash University; Ricardo Perera, Monash University; Matthieu Koroma, Ecole Normale Supérieure; Sid Kouider, Ecole Normale Supérieure; Jakob Hohwy, Monash University; Thomas Andrillon, Monash University

Expectations about our environment can help us extract meaningful signals from noisy sensory inputs. In some cases, our brain can even replace what is missing, a phenomenon called perceptual filling-in. However, it is still unclear whether perceptual filling-in changes the encoding of information or acts on post-encoding processes.

Here, we investigated auditory perceptual filling-in in 19 participants who listened to two categories of noisy speech: (1) noise vocoded speech (NVS), in which spectral features are replaced by amplitude-modulated band-limited noise, and (2) sine-wave speech (SWS), in which formants are replaced with sinusoids. Both SWS and NVS were created from intelligible speech. Participants were instructed to rate the clarity of NVS and SWS stimuli before and after seeing the original sentence (prior+), a different sentence (prior-), or nothing at all (prior0). High-density EEG was recorded throughout the task.

Displaying the correct (prior+) or incorrect (prior-) sentence induced a state of active listening, characterised by an increase in alpha oscillations. However, only the display of the original sentence (prior+) had a positive effect on clarity (perceptual insight). To investigate how expectations shaped sensory encoding, we used a technique designed to reconstruct auditory features (envelope, spectrogram, phonemes, etc) from the EEG recorded during sound presentation. Stimulus reconstruction was more efficient following the presentation of the correct (prior+) compared to the incorrect sentence (prior-). This increase in stimulus reconstruction was accompanied by a desynchronization within the theta band. These results suggest that perceptual filling-in directly acts on the encoding of auditory information, with the amplification of low-level features of auditory inputs such as the acoustic envelope.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Decoding Neural Activity into Language
伟 黄
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Wei Huang, MOE Key Lab for Neuroinformation, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, 610054, PR China; Hongmei Yan, MOE Key Lab for Neuroinformation, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, 610054, PR China; Kaiwen Cheng, MOE Key Lab for Neuroinformation, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, 610054, PR China; Chong Wang, MOE Key Lab for Neuroinformation, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, 610054, PR China; Jiyi Li, MOE Key Lab for Neuroinformation, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, 610054, PR China; Zhentao Zuo, State Key Laboratory of Brain and Cognitive Science, Beijing MR Center for Brain Research, Institute of Biophysics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100101, China; Chen Li, Department of Medical Information Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu 610065, China; Huafu Chen, MOE Key Lab for Neuroinformation, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, 610054, PR China;

Transforming neural activities into language is revolutionary for interpreting the formation of language from visual perception. If the neural signal of visual activities is regarded as a special kind of human biological language, it is quite feasible that we can apply the machine translation architecture in Artificial Intelligence (AI) to decode those neural signals. Therefore, a progressive transfer language decoding model was proposed to decode visual fMRI signals into phrases or sentences when natural images were being processed. The results of a similarity analysis showed that human natural language was successfully derived from visual neural activities. Additionally, by comparing the decoding effectivity of different visual areas in space, we found that higher visual areas usually had better performance. At the same time, we found that the contribution curve of visual response patterns in language decoding rose first and then gradually decreased at successively different time points. Our findings proved that the neural representations elicited in the visual cortex when visual scene tasks were being performed already contained semantic information that could be utilized to generate the human natural language. Our study will help in the application of language-based brain-machine interfaces, such as assisting aphasiacs in normal communication with others.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Cortical Endogenous Opioids and Repetitive Behaviors in Deer Mice
Farhan Augustine
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Shawn Doss, Johns Hopkins University; Harvey S. Singer, Kennedy Krieger Institute and Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine

Goal: Our research aims to understand the pathophysiologic mechanism(s) underlying human movement disorders.

Background: Repetitive movement disorders, such as tics and stereotypies, are common in the pediatric population. Although alterations in cortical-basal ganglia-thalamo-cortical circuits may be involved, there are numerous unanswered questions. Deer mice (Peromyscus maniculatus) provide a non-pharmacologically induced model for studying underlying mechanisms.

Methodology: Investigative approaches, to date, have included stereological studies designed to identify anatomical alterations in the cortex, striatum, and cerebellum, and techniques that quantify regional neurotransmitters (e.g., LC-MS and RNAscope).
Results: Stereological studies have identified a significant negative correlation between cell count in the ventral striatum and repetitive activity. Neurochemically, a significant negative correlation was observed between the repetitive activity of deer mice and the LC-MS/MS quantified endogenous opioids (leu-enkephalin (enk) and dynorphin-A (dyn-A) in the frontal cortex (FC) [Augustine et al. 2020]. Based on these findings, we have postulated that endogenous opioids in the cortex regulate the balance of activity within cortical-striatal pathways, either via goal-directed/habitual pathways, direct/indirect systems, or inhibitory circuits. For example, the FC originates habitual behaviors via cortical projections to striatal medium-spiny-neurons (MSNs) that participate in the DRD1-expressing (direct) and DRD2-expressing (indirect) motor pathways.

Current Studies: Studies in progress, using in-situ mRNA hybridization, are designed to examine the dopaminergic and endogenous opioid systems in the striatum and FC. To date, we have quantified the mRNA expression levels of DRD1/DRD2 and the mu, delta, and kappa opioid receptors (MOR, DOR, and KOR, respectively) in the FC and striatal regions. Preliminary data shows a negative correlation between the repetitive behavior activity and mRNA expression of dyn-A and enk in the FC, further supporting our initial report proposing a role for endogenous opioids as an underlying mechanism for repetitive behaviors.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Chronic Recording from Multiple Hippocampal Sub-Regions in Free Moving Rats with a Flexible Parylene-Based Multi-Electrodes Array
Huijing Xu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ahuva Hirschberg, USC; Wenxuan Jiang, USC; Kee Scholten, USC; Xuechun Wang, USC; Ellis Meng, USC; Dong Song, USC

Hippocampus is a subcortical brain structure that is essential for the formation of long-term memories. Obtaining stable, chronic recording of unitary activities from multiple sub-regions of the hippocampus in behaving animals is crucial for studying the biological basis of memoryformation and is also the foundation for developinghippocampal memory prosthesis. However, severe immune response caused by micro-motion between stiff implants and brain tissue often limits the lifetime of penetrating neural probes. To reduce the stiffness mismatch between recording devices and brain tissue, we developed and tested a flexible, Parylene-based multi-electrode array for recording from multiple sub-regions of the rat hippocampus and used this array to collect chronic neural activities from free moving rats. The 64 channels, Parylene multi-electrode array has eight shanks arranged in series with 250μmspacing. On each shank, eight recording electrodes were divided into two groups targeting at the CA3 and the CA1 sub-regions, respectively. The layout of recording sites is specially designed to conformto the curvature of the hippocampal cell body layers.Stereotactic surgery is conducted to chronically implant the flexible array. A dissolvable brace that temporarily reduces effective probe length is used to insert the bare array without buckling.Signals were monitored during the insertion and after recovery, while the animal is exploring freely in an open field. Eleven animals were implanted with the Parylene array. 70 out of 78(90%) implanted functional shanks recorded from at least one sub-region and 50% shanks recorded spike activities from both the CA1 and the CA3 sub-regionsduring the implantation. Insevenanimals, neural activities were monitored immediately post-implantation and on average 70.1±15.8 (23.9±14.2 CA1 and 46.3±13.0 CA3) units were identified from individual animals. After recovery, 90 units (11.3±3.1 per animal) with SNR greater than threewere recorded from eight animals over durationsranging fromthree weeks to eleven months. One Parylene array has recorded stable unitary activities for over 11 months.

Abstract
 
Neuromatch Movie Watch Party! Come have fun and relax with everyone over the time-travel classic, ‘Back to the Future.’ We will use the service Scener as a virtual movie theater to watch the film together using your Netflix account. Note that you must have an individual Netflix account to participate. Go to https://scener.com/ and create a free account before showtime.

We’ll be interacting in the chat while the movie airs, so join in with colleagues and friends from the past and make some future ones!
Interactive talk
Watch now
Automated estimation of morphology of a neocortical neuron using in vivo LFP data
Daniel Dopp
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ziao Chen; Drew B. Headley; Satish S. Nair

New technologies are beginning to provide neurophysiological data at increasing levels of precision and at multiple scales including at single neuron and network levels. In parallel, advances in machine learning-based algorithms and architectures have spurred the development of several automated neural parameter estimation schemes. As an example, statistical inference can be combined with machine learning schemes to provide principled approaches that can integrate multiple data sources to handle variability, quantify uncertainty and incorporate prior knowledge. A specific instance of such a hybrid scheme is sequential neural posterior estimation, which combines the advantages of statistical and mechanistic modeling (SNPE; Goncalves et al., 2020)

We use the approximate Bayesian computation inference algorithm SNPE to infer the morphological parameters of a single neuron from multi-electrode in vivo extracellular voltage recordings. In this inverse modeling scheme, we designed a generic biophysical single neuron model with stylized morphology that had adjustable parameters for the dimensions of the soma, basal and apical dendrites, and their locations and orientations relative to the multi-electrode probe. The model includes simplified biophysics and had a module to estimate extracellular potential at desired locations. We used the SNPE algorithm with the single cell model to infer the posterior distribution of the morphological parameters, given the in vivo extracellular spike waveform of a putative rodent neocortical cell near the electrode as the observed data. Such an approach provides estimation of the morphology that best matches the spatiotemporal profile of the extracellular action potential recorded on a multisite silicon probe (Neuropixel). The next step will involve inference of the parameters related to the biophysics of the neuron, and may need to be performed iteratively with the inference of morphology parameters. Our long-term goal is to develop a publicly accessible toolbox that automates the process of inferring neuronal morphology and parameters from in vivo extracellular voltages.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Ultra-sparse spike sequences for automatic recognition of auditory objects
Leonardo Tavares
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Dezhe Jin, Pennsylvania State University

In the last few years, Deep Learning has tremendously improved the performance of automatic speech recognition (ASR) systems. It has also been applied to related tasks, such as birdsong syllable recognition [2]. However, this success comes at the expense of large amounts of training data and computational power. When data is scarce, the performance tends to decrease rapidly. This hinders applications where high accuracy is required from a limited amount of labeled exemplars.

Here we explore a radically different approach to the task of auditory object recognition from continuous sound streams. Our approach is inspired by how the auditory system represents auditory objects. Namely, that neurons in high auditory areas fire sparsely and in patterns that correlate with specific auditory objects. In addition, these patterns are also seen to be robust against noise.

We train feature-detecting neurons that respond to acoustic structures within short-time windows of about 50 ms. Together, these neurons transform the sound input into a continuous stream of spikes. This spike representation is ultra-sparse and precisely timed. Auditory objects consisting of well defined spectrotemporal structures are then stored as templates of spike sequences. During testing, a template matching algorithm performs the search, discovery and classification of spike sequences in the continuous sound input.

Our contribution is two-fold. First, we demonstrate our approach in the task of segmenting and classifying Bengalese finch syllables from continuous birdsong recordings. We show that our system generalizes well even when only a few syllables are available for training. Second, we make available to the community a new open-source software for audio data annotation, which we call BASS. Our software is designed to allow users to quickly mark, compare and classify segments extracted from spectrograms. We find it particularly useful for manually annotating large sets of birdsong data.

[1] Tavares and Jin. Ultra-sparse spike sequences for automatic recognition of auditory objects. In preparation.
[2] Y. Cohen et. al. 2020. TweetyNet: A neural network that enables high-throughput, automated annotation of birdsong. bioRxiv doi: https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.08.28.272088
Interactive talk
Watch now
Seeing through the Mind’s Eye: Reconstruction of the visual stimuli using 3D Generative-Adversarial Modeling
Rishabh Chakrabarty
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kartik Viswanathan, International Institute Of Information Technology, Hyderabad; Avani Gupta, International Institute Of Information Technology, Hyderabad

A long-standing challenge in systems neuroscience is to understand how the brain processes visual stimuli and its internal representation in the brain. This enhances our understanding of how sensory information is encoded in the brain which in-turn offers insights into how the brain is processing information.

Reconstructing visual stimuli from fMRI signals is a complex problem. Previous neuroimaging studies have been focused on decoding orientation, position, object category, and reconstruction of the 2D image stimuli presented to the subject, however, such approaches fail to decode the spatial, temporal, and other information already encoded in the neuroimaging data.

Unsupervised learning techniques show promise in learning these complex representations between the visual stimuli and neuroimaging data.

Our self-supervised neural decoding pipeline initially converts the 2-dimensional stimuli to a 3D representation using three-dimensional generative adversarial networks, which is used as an input to train the Encoder(3D-to-fMRI) and Decoder(fMRI-to-3D) architecture using a supervised approach. We then use the pre-trained Encoder-Decoder architecture to perform unsupervised end-to-end training using these 3D reconstructions, and a similar unsupervised Decoder-Encoder training on unlabeled test fMRI data.

We perform 3D reconstruction of the 2D stimuli not because we believe that it is closer to the internal representation of how spatial information is encoded in the brain but to capture that information by training our Autoencoder using a 3D representation of the stimuli and the corresponding fMRI of the stimulus.

Breakthroughs in the neural decoding are needed for designing algorithms of brain–machine interface
and prosthetics it also facilitates the understanding of neurological disorders such as epilepsy, etc. Our approach is successfully able to untangle and extract spatial information from brain activity patterns. In the future, we plan on adding high-level perceptual criteria to improve reconstruction accuracy; enabling large-scale semantic classification and add layerwise loss to the architecture.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Personalized Brain State Targeting via Reinforcement Learning
Abhishek Naik
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Abhishek Naik, University of Alberta; Amritpal Singh, Maulana Azad Medical College; Koushani Biswas, NISER Bhubaneswar; Harini Sudha, IISER Pune; Matthew Schlegel, University of Alberta; Kyle E. Mathewson, University of Alberta

We propose a novel use of reinforcement learning as an active closed-loop assistive system that learns in real time to lead any brain state to a given goal state. Previous open- and closed-loop systems to manipulate brain states are generally passive in the sense that they are trained offline from data collected from a population but are not tailored or adapted for any individuals. Offline adaptation per individual if at all is very slow. Adaptation, and the speed of adaptation, is critical in most applications where manipulation of brain states is performed because poor initial performance and long training periods are barriers to BCI adaptation and success. Reinforcement learning is a sequential decision-making paradigm in which the system learns to map situations to optimal actions via trial-and-error interactions with the world to maximize a reward signal. Crucially, this reward signal is a form of evaluative feedback, for instance, proportional to how far the current state is from the goal state. This is in contrast to instructive feedback in the supervised learning paradigm, where the correct action is assumed known. We propose modeling brain state manipulation as a sequential decision-making problem, wherein a system takes real-time EEG data as input and uses audio-visual cues to start from any brain state and reach a physiologically-objective goal state such as a particular oscillation frequency or a deep-sleep state. We show a proof of concept example using a consumer-based EEG device. We believe such an active closed-loop system would have a large impact in assistive applications ranging from helping critically-ill patients fall asleep to helping everyday stressed-out individuals relax.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
3D markerless tracking for human movement science
Rachit Saluja
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Rachit Saluja*, University of Pennsylvania; Nidhi Seethapathi*, University of Pennsylvania; Konrad Kording, University of Pennsylvania;

Recent advances in computer vision have enabled tracking of 3D body pose in videos as they unfold over time. While movement science is quickly beginning to use 2D pose estimation, few studies use 3D computer vision algorithms with temporal tracking, in part because it is unclear which models would be appropriate for the movements that matter to movement science. Here, we compare state-of-the-art computer vision models on the types of movements (walking, running, reaching, jumping, interaction) and the types of metrics (3D velocity, acceleration, joint angles) important to movement science. We compare models that use different approaches such as GANs, sequence-to-sequence, heatmaps, and algebraic triangulation. Thus, we provide a pipeline for movement scientists to use these models on their video data and provide information necessary to choose between the models by testing them on the types of movements and metrics that are important for movement science.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Optimizing detailed L5 pyramidal tract cell models in the rodent motor cortex to predict in vivo microcircuit function
Ben Latimer
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Adin Aberbach, University of Missouri; Drew B. Headley, Rutgers University; Satish S. Nair, University of Missouri

Detailed biophysical modeling techniques are beginning to be used in conjunction with anatomical, biophysical, and extracellular multi-electrode recordings to shed light on cellular functioning in vivo (e.g., Egger et al., 2020). However, biophysical single cell models of neurons are typically constrained by in vitro data. These properties are impacted by factors such as cellular morphology, variations in extrinsic inputs received by up to 10K synapses, and the neuromodulatory state. In contrast, in vitro the synaptic inputs (random neurotransmitter release or pre-synaptic AP firing) that affect membrane potential and input resistance are much less pronounced. Thus, our picture of the cell’s in vivo characteristics is incomplete. We attempt to bridge this gap by developing a detailed biophysical model constrained by in vivo data.
We report the development of a morphologically realistic biophysical model of an L5 pyramidal tract neuron in the rodent primary motor cortex with active channels in the dendrites, including Nat, Ca, SK, Im, Ih, and a dense Ca2+ rich region at the base of the apical tuft. The model is used to conduct parametric studies to probe the effect that synaptic conductances, afferent firing rates, coherence of afferent spike times, and dendritic attenuation have on the baseline firing rate of the neuron. The single cell model will then be inserted into a network model of the motor cortex for investigating computations in motor cortex circuits during a voluntary reaching task.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Neural correlates of auditory categorization in the supplementary motor area
Isaac Morán
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jonathan Melchor, UNAM; Javier Pérez, INR; Tonatiuh Figueroa, UNAM; Luis Lemus, UNAM

Grouping naturalistic auditory stimuli into discrete categories is fundamental for speech recognition in humans and social communication across various species. It has been noted that supplementary motor area (SMA) is part of a circuit that links auditory information into motor commands. We investigated whether SMA is involved in the processing of the categorization of auditory stimuli. We train nonhuman primates in a task of categorizing naturalistic auditory stimuli. Our results demonstrate that SMA, both at the level of single neurons and at the population level, shows a categorical coding related to both auditory signals as well as the motor choices of the subjects. Our results demonstrate that SMA integrates sensory information and links it to categorical processing.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Horizontal connections for enhancing machine visual grouping
Vijay Veerabadran
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Virginia R. de Sa, University of California San Diego

Evidence from biological vision supports the hypothesis that horizontal interactions in the early visual cortex facilitate low-level grouping. We explore whether such recurrent nonlinear horizontal connections enhance the grouping abilities of deep convolutional networks (DCNs) optimized to solve contour integration problems. We introduce V1Net -- a bio-inspired recurrent unit implementing linear and nonlinear excitatory-inhibitory (E-I) lateral connections; spatial convolutional layers in DCNs can be substituted with V1Net to create a V1Net-DCN. We compare the performance of a shallow V1Net-DCN against 15 carefully selected feedforward and recurrent neural architectures (including state-of-the-art DCNs) on the MarkedLong and Pathfinder challenges -- two synthetic image classification tasks based on low-level grouping with 1 million images each. Our results demonstrate that a compact 3-layer V1Net-DCN matches or outperforms the test accuracy and sample efficiency of all comparison models with varied capacity and architectural diversity. Our experiments are suggestive of the importance of implementing recurrent long-range E-I horizontal connections to enhance the low-level grouping abilities of feedforward deep learning models. Our ablation studies highlight interesting differences in the relative importance of linear and nonlinear horizontal connections. In the future, we are interested in exploring whether this enhanced grouping utility of V1Net translates to more data efficient image segmentation methods.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Comparing 7T sequences to image human basal ganglia activity during performance on a visual cueing task
Kelly Garner
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Christopher Nolan, University of Queensland; Ole Jensen, University of Birmingham; Markus Barth, University of Queensland; Marta Garrido, University of Melbourne

Although it is well established that expectations influence visual selection, our mapping of the neurophysiological infrastructure that instantiates this influence remains incomplete. Two known influences on visual selection; probabilistic and value-based learning, have been associated with the function of the human basal ganglia, yet the sensitivity of these nuclei to visual selection demands remains unknown. Imaging the activity of the basal-ganglia is a challenge, as the iron-rich nuclei suffer signal loss when using conventional imaging sequences. We therefore sought to determine which echo-planar imaging (EPI) parameters yield the best signal in the basal ganglia when participants perform a visual cueing task that pits spatial probabilities against reward incentives in relation to upcoming visual targets. We compared three sequences designed for use with 7T Magnetic Resonance Imaging, that sought to balance high spatial and temporal resolution with full brain coverage, varying in slice acceleration factors and echo times. Importantly, we compared the contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR) between sequences when both spatial probabilities and incentive-values influenced upcoming target discrimination performance, and when comparing the hand of response, which is in-line with the typical contrast used to determine optimal parameters for imaging the basal ganglia. We find that the sequence that provides the best CNR under varying visual selection manipulations is not the same as that found for the motoric contrast. Therefore, optimal imaging parameters for the basal ganglia during experiments that assess visual and cognitive manipulations may differ from the optimal parameters for imaging motoric-related activity.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Plasticity Underlying Contextual Fear Memory in the Schaffer Collateral Synapse
Kiara Vega Bellido (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kiara S Vega Bellido, Baylor College of Medicine

The hippocampus (HPC) is a key structure for the formation and storage of episodic memory. It is reasoned that place cells in subregions CA3 and CA1 of the hippocampus, which exhibit robust location-specific firing, likely encode the contextual aspect of an episodic memory. Contextual Fear Memory (CFM) in rodents is a hippocampal-dependent example of episodic memory where a specific context is associated with an aversive experience. CA1 place cells receive spatial information from CA3 through Schaffer Collateral (SC) synapses5 and encode the context associated with CFM; in the case of the Inhibitory-Avoidance task on a linear track, this context is identified as the shock zone (SZ). We propose the synapses feeding into the place cells encoding the SZ are thus recruited to the CFM engram6 and participate in the different stages of CFM: acquisition, retrieval, and sleep-mediated consolidation. We hypothesize this recruitment of CA1 place cells to the memory engram occurs through long-term potentiation of SZ-encoding synapses. In vivo evidence of the synapse-specific modifications which recruit CA1 place cells to the CFM engram and mediate their activity during the different stages of CFM is fundamental to the neurophysiological understanding of episodic memory. This study aims to provide such evidence by measuring synaptic efficacy by concurrently stimulating Schaffer collaterals and recording responses in CA1 during CFM acquisition, retrieval, and sleep-mediated consolidation, and identify the plasticity recruiting CA1 place cells to the CFM engram through this key synaptic pathway.

Traditional talk
Watch now
Wandering minds, sleepy brains: lapses of attention and local sleep in wakefulness.
Thomas Andrillon
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Angus Burns, Monash University; Teigane MacKay, Monash University; Jennifer Windt, Monash University; Naotsugu Tsuchiya, Monash University

Attentional lapses are ubiquitous and can negatively impact performance. They correlate with mind wandering, or thoughts that are unrelated to ongoing tasks and environmental demands. In other cases, the stream of consciousness itself comes to a halt and the mind goes blank. What happens in the brain that leads to these mental states? To understand the neural mechanisms underlying attentional lapses, we cross-analyzed the behavior, subjective experience and neural activity of healthy participants performing a task. Random interruptions prompted participants to indicate whether they were task-focused, mind-wandering or mind-blanking. High-density electroencephalography revealed the occurrence of spatially and temporally localized sleep-like patterns of neural activity. This “local sleep” accompanied behavioral markers of lapses and preceded reports of mind wandering and mind blanking. Furthermore, the location of local sleep distinguished sluggish versus impulsive behaviors, mind wandering versus mind blanking. Despite contrasting cognitive profiles, attentional lapses could share a common physiological origin: the appearance of local islets of sleep within the awake brain.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Vagolytic effect of Zolpidem on Sleep-dependent Memory: A Trade-off between Working Memory and Long-term Memory
Pin-Chun Chen
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Hamid Niknazar, University of California Irvine; Lauren N. Whitehurst, University of California San Francisco; Sara C. Mednick, University of California Irvine

Sleep benefits learning, including long-term memory (LTM) and working memory (WM). However, it’s unclear whether sleep features of central nervous system (CNS) and autonomic nervous system (ANS) causally interplay in supporting different types of sleep-dependent cognitive enhancement. Here, we used Zolpidem to manipulate spindles (measured by sigma power) and vagal activity (measured by high-frequency HRV; HF) and investigated the trade-off between improvement in LTM and WM performance. We used a double-blind, placebo-controlled within-subjects design (N=38; Mage = 20.85 ± 2.97 years, 19 Females) to test if Zolpidem increases performance on a word paired-associates task by boosting spindles, while decrease performance on the operation-span WM task by suppressing vagal tone, during the night of sleep. We explored the impact of Zolpidem on ANS profiles during sleep and showed that Zolpidem increased heart rate and decreased vagal activity during sleep, suggesting a vagolytic effect. Also, Zolpidem increased LTM retention but decreased overnight WM improvement, compared to Placebo. We found a positive correlation between WM improvement and vagal activity, while a negative correlation between LTM retention and vagal activity, suggested a functional role of vagal activity on WM and LTM. Using effective connectivity, we showed that Zolpidem increased the causal effect of sigma on HF. Such causal information flow was correlated with the difference between overnight LTM and WM changes: the more sigma’s causal effect over HF, the more hippocampal-dependent sleep benefits (LTM) than the prefrontal-dependent task (WM). These findings suggested a causal role of vagal activity on sleep-dependent cognition, and an antagonist role of spindles and vagal activity, which implicates a trade-off between LTM and WM processing during sleep.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Local sleep in the waking brain impairs attention: A pharmacological study
Elaine Rose Pinggal (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Paul M. Dockree, Trinity College; Jessica J. Barnes, The University of Queensland; Natasha Matthews, The University of Queensland; Angela J. Dean, The University of Queensland; Rafael Abe, Monash University; L. Sanjay Nandam, The University of Queensland; Simon P. Kelly, University College Dublin; Redmond G. O’Connell, Monash University; Mark A. Bellgrove, Monash University; Thomas Andrillon, Monash University

Local sleep (LS) describes dissociative states in which parts of a globally awake brain show
sleep-like activity. LS has been associated with deficits in sustained attention (SA) but the
causal involvement of LS in attentional lapses remain unclear. This study aimed at addressing
this knowledge gap by directly manipulating LS and SA through pharmacological means. In a
double-blind, randomised-control trial, 32 participants received methylphenidate,
atomoxetine, citalopram or placebo during four separate experimental sessions. During each
session, electroencephalography measured LS whilst participants completed a visual SA task.
Methylphenidate, which increases wake-promoting noradrenaline and dopamine, decreased
LS and improved performance (lower reaction time (RT), and less misses). Atomoxetine,
which increases noradrenaline, decreased LS but increased RT. Conversely, citalopram,
which increases sleep-promoting serotonin, increased LS and RT. Mediation analysis
confirmed the causal relationship of LS on SA. These results suggest that LS could represent
a mechanism for the effect of fatigue on attention.
Keynote Event
Watch now
The cellular changes occurring in early Alzheimer’s disease
Bart de Strooper 		Keynote Event
Watch now
Engagement of active dendritic integration in neuronal circuit computations
Stephen Williams
Interactive talk
Watch now
Are age-related changes in internal model function linked to poorer somatosensory function?
Jean-Jacques (JJ) Orban de Xivry
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Orban de Xivry JJ, KU Leuven; Vandevoorde K, KU Leuven, Parthasharathy M, KU Leuven

Motor functions are thought to be decreasing with age. Yet, in two different motor paradigms linked to internal model function, we observed that the performance of the older participants was "better" than that of younger participants. In a force matching task involving the arm, participants were asked to reproduce a force by applying a force with one arm onto the other arm. In this case, the reproduced force is higher in older participants than in younger participants. This overshoot in force is linked to the fact that an internal model predicts the movement of our own arm and hence the intensity of the sensation of the internally-generated force is decreased (Parthasharathy, Mantini and Orban de Xivry, 2020; Wolpe et al. 2016).

Similarly, in the task-irrelevant clamped feedback task (Morehead et al. 2017), participants are asked to bring their invisible hand to a target but the cursor trajectory is deviated on the left or right of the target by a constant angle. That is, the cursor direction is made fully independent from the hand direction while the velocity of hand and cursor are matched. When the perturbation is introduced, implicit motor adaptation occurs because of the introduced sensory prediction error (the difference between the expected and actual cursor direction). As a result, the hand direction drifts opposite to the cursor unbeknownst to the participant. This drift is larger in older participants (Vandevoorde and Orban de Xivry, 2019).

In both cases, the increased response from older participants could be linked to their age-related deficits in somatosensory function. In the force-matching task, the overshoot in force is thought to be the result of the balance between sensory information and internal model output. Given the accepted age-related deficits in somatosensory function (e.g. proprioception), the large overshoot in older people might be due to their poorer somatosensory function. In the motor adaptation task, proprioception would ensure that the hand does not drift too far away from where the participants think the hand is going.

Yet, across several experiments with both tasks, we failed to find any link between somatosensory function and the performance in the force-matching task (Parthasharathy, Mantini and Orban de Xivry, 2020) or the motor adaptation tasks (Vandevoorde and Orban de Xivry, in preparation). This interactive presentation will be centered on the discussion of why elderly participans are "better" at these tasks.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Can perfect accumulator assumption explain the integration of facial features during a perceptual decision making task?
hadiseh hajimohammadi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Reza Ebrahimpour, Cognitive Science Research lab., Department of Computer Engineering, Shahid Rajaee Teacher Training University, Tehran, Iran; Sajjad Zabbah, School of Cognitive Sciences, Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences (IPM), Tehran, Iran

This study aims to investigate the integration of evidence in informative facial features during a perceptual decision making task. We hypothesize that the perfect accumulator assumption might explain the integration of the facial information. Having developed a customized algorithm, neutral faces have been geometrically morphed together such that -100 represents prototype one, +100 prototype two and zero the middle face between the two faces. The trials are designed in a way that stimuli either have three informative features (eyes, mouth, nose simultaneously) or only one informative feature (eyes, mouth, nose individually) fluctuating in time and combined with a mask throughout the trial. Eight human subjects (four women) participate in this face discrimination task after getting familiar with the pure faces with no mask and passing the train phase. The participants invited to the main phase of the experiment are instructed to maintain their gaze on the red fixation point in the center of the screen and report if the stimuli displayed on the left side of the fixation point is more similar to the first prototype or the second one. Using the logistic regression model on the probability of correct in different morph levels, it reveals that the subjects are not biased toward any of the choices. Having calculated the evidence contained in each one-informative feature trials and using the perfect accumulator assumption, we compute the expected accuracy for combining the evidence from one-informative feature trials. We show that expected accuracy calculated from the combination of one-informative feature trials are significantly smaller than the accuracy gained from the three informative features trials. Rejecting the initial hypothesis, the finding suggests that the integration of facial feature information can be more than the sum of individual information of each informative feature.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
When differences matter: rTMS/fMRI reveals how differences in dispositional empathy translate to distinct neural underpinnings of self-other distinction in empathy
Henryk Bukowski
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Henryk Bukowski, Social, Cognitive and Affective Neuroscience Unit, Department of Basic Psychological Research and Research Methods, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; Martin Tik, 2MR Center of Excellence, Center for Medical Physics and Biomedical Engineering, Medical University of Vienna, Austria; Giorgia Silani, Department of Applied Psychology: Health, Development, Enhancement and Intervention, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; Christian Ruff, Zurich Center for Neuroeconomics (ZNE), Department of Economics, University of Zurich, Zurich, Switzerland; Christian Windischberger, MR Center of Excellence, Center for Medical Physics and Biomedical Engineering, Medical University of Vienna, Austria; Claus Lamm, Social, Cognitive and Affective Neuroscience Unit, Department of Basic Psychological Research and Research Methods, University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria;

Self-Other distinction is crucial for empathy, since it prevents the confusion of self-experienced emotions with those of others. We aimed to extend our understanding of the neurocognitive mechanisms of self-other distinction. Thirty-one female participants underwent continuous theta burst transcranial magnetic stimulation (cTBS) targeting the supramarginal gyrus (rSMG), a sub-region of the temporoparietal junction previously shown to be involved in self-other distinction, and the vertex, a cortical control site. Right after stimulation they completed a visuo-tactile empathy task in an MRI scanner. Self-Other distinction performance was assessed by differences in emotion judgments and brain activity between conditions differing in the requirement for self-other distinction. Effects of rSMG-cTBS (compared to vertex cTBS) on self-other distinction depended on dispositional empathic understanding: It decreased self-other distinction in participants with lower dispositional empathic understanding but increased it in participants with higher empathic understanding. On the neural level, this inverse relationship between disposition and self-other distinction performance translated into a reduction or an increase of cTBS-induced rSMG activity, in persons with lower and higher dispositional empathy, respectively. Moreover, the distinct activations of rSMG activity were associated with two anatomically and functionally distinct networks. These findings open up novel perspectives on the causal role of rSMG in self-other distinction and empathy. They also suggest that considering individual differences may yield novel insights into how brain stimulation affects higher-level affect and cognition, and its neural correlates.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Investigating activity-dependent processes in cortical neuronal assembly and in developmental epileptic encephalopathy
Sara Mancinelli
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Filippo Mirabella, IRCCS Humanitas Clinical and Research Center, Via Manzoni 56, 20089 Rozzano - Milan, Italy; Monica Tambalo, IRCCS Humanitas Clinical and Research Center, Via Manzoni 56, 20089 Rozzano - Milan, Italy; Rosalba Olga Proce, IRCCS Humanitas Clinical and Research Center, Via Manzoni 56, 20089 Rozzano - Milan, Italy; Christel Depienne, University Hospital Essen, Institute of Human Genetics, Hufelandstrasse 55, 45147, UK Essen, Germany; Roberto Rusconi, Humanitas University, Department of Biomedical Sciences, Via Rita Levi Montalcini 4, 20090 - Pieve Emanuele-Milan, Italy; Davide Pozzi, Humanitas University, Department of Biomedical Sciences, Via Rita Levi Montalcini 4, 20090 - Pieve Emanuele-Milan, Italy; Simona Lodato, Humanitas University, Department of Biomedical Sciences, Via Rita Levi Montalcini 4, 20090 - Pieve Emanuele-Milan, Italy.

The cerebral cortex contains an extraordinary diversity of excitatory projection neuron (PN) and inhibitory interneurons (IN), wired together to form complex circuits. Spatiotemporally coordinated events involving the execution of intrinsic molecular programs and activity-dependent processes contribute to cortical development, and alterations of these delicate processes have been associated to neurological/neurodevelopmental disorders. Despite the recent groundbreaking discovery of spontaneous activity in the embryonic brain, it is still unclear whether early activity contributes to shape subtype-specific neuronal identity. Trough in utero genetic perturbation and pharmacological inhibition of selected ion channels, known to control excitability, we aim at identify the activity-regulated processes controlling the development of different cortical PN classes and their wiring. Our project aims at dissecting the contribution of activity-dependent processes in the acquisition of subtype specific features of developing cortical neurons, trough in vivo genetic manipulation of distinct channels known to be regulator of neuronal excitability and/or associated with developmental epileptic encephalopathy. We are currently combining RNA sequencing technology and in utero experimental activity perturbations, to identify coupled activity and molecular modules involved in cerebral cortex development and disease.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Ventral Tegmental Area projecting dopaminergic neurons, as a neural substrate for flexible adaptation of goal directed behaviors
Javier Vázquez
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Pierre Trifilieff, University of Bordeaux; Andrea Contini, University of Bordeaux

Several psychiatric conditions such as drug addiction or schizophrenia are marked by an impairment in the ability to optimally acquire and/or express goal-directed actions. Such alterations in executive control have been associated with a dysfunction of the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC), possibly linked to an alteration of dopamine (DA) transmission. However, preclinical data regarding the implication of DA signalling in executive control remain controversial. Here, we used a chemogenetic approach to selectively and reversibly inhibit DA neurons of the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and assess the effect on distinct components of goal-directed behavior using the outcome devaluation task that allows assessing the ability of animals to flexibly adapt goal-directed actions.
We found that while inhibition of VTA-DA neurons during outcome devaluation had no effect, the same manipulation during reversal of the instrumental contingencies resulted in a deficit in a subsequent outcome devaluation test. Our data provide clear evidence regarding the implication of VTA-DA transmission in the capacity to flexibly adapt goal-directed behaviors. These findings support the idea that alteration of VTA-DA transmission could participate to the aetiology of cognitive symptoms in psychiatric disorders.
Interactive talk
Watch now
A reach trajectory can be learnt using binary reward feedback
Katinka van der Kooij
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
van Mastrigt, N.M.; Smeets, J.B.J.

Binary reward feedback on movement success is sufficient for learning some simple sensorimotor mappings in a reaching task, but not for some tasks in which multiple kinematic factors contribute to performance. The critical condition for learning in more complex tasks remains unclear. Here, we investigate whether reward-based motor learning is possible in a multi-dimensional trajectory matching task and whether simplifying the task by providing feedback on one factor at a time (‘factorized feedback’) can improve learning. In two experiments, participants performed a trajectory matching task in which learning was measured as a reduction in the error. In Experiment 1, participants matched a straight trajectory slanted in depth. We factorized the task by providing feedback on the slant error, the length error, or on their composite. In Experiment 2, participants matched a curved trajectory, also slanted in depth. In this experiment, we factorized the feedback by providing feedback on the slant error, the curvature error, or on the integral difference between the matched and target trajectory. In both experiments, participants learnt the multidimensional task: they reduced errors in the matched trajectory. There was no evidence that the factorization of feedback improved learning. We conclude that multiple kinematic factors can be learnt in parallel.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
How trial correlations and feedback shape sequential decision-making
Khanh Nguyen
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kresimir Josic, University of Houston; Zachary Kilpatrick, University of Colorado Boulder
