To make the best decisions, organisms must flexibly accumulate information, accounting for what is relevant, and ignoring what is not. However, many decision-making studies focus on sequences of independent trials in which the evidence gathered to make a choice and the resulting actions are irrelevant to future decisions. An important and naturalistic aspect of such experiments is a probabilistic schedule of rewards, in which sometimes correct responses are not rewarded and sometimes incorrect responses are. For example, birds may correctly identify a fruitful tree but have difficulty harvesting the fruit. Normative theory has been developed for such tasks when reward is the sole evidence (e.g., two-armed bandit tasks), but less is known about how an observer should integrate probabilistic rewards that are interspersed with noisy evidence to inform their decisions in correlated trials. To understand decision-making under more natural conditions, we propose and analyze models of ideal observers who accumulate evidence to freely make choices across a sequence of correlated trials and receive uncertain feedback. We extend drift-diffusion models to obtain the normative form of evidence accumulation in a series of trials with the correct choice evolving as a two-state Markov process. We analyze three different feedback cases: no trial-to-trial feedback, probabilistic trial-to-trial feedback, and probabilistic reward as feedback. Ideal observers integrate noisy evidence within a trial until reaching a decision threshold and bias their initial belief depending on the evidence accumulated and feedback received on previous trials. Ideal observers optimize their reward rate across trials by adjusting their sequence of decision thresholds to deliberate longer on early decisions and respond more quickly in later trials. We show how conflicts between feedback and accumulated evidence are resolved, and under which conditions one of them dominates. Our findings are consistent with experimentally observed response trends.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
This is built to last: Delta and Theta changes in resting-state EEG activity after regulating emotions
Gaia Lapomarda
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Stefania Valer, University of Trento; Remo Job, University of Trento; Alessandro Grecucci, University of Trento

Over the past years, EEG has been used to characterize cortical responses associated with emotion regulation. One limitation of the previous experiments is that they focused on task-related activity, without exploring the possibility that regulating emotions can leave a trace in the brain, by affecting its oscillatory activity at rest. The relevance of this point is to understand whether the effect of regulation lasts and alters brain activity, or it vanishes soon after the application.
33 volunteers took part in the study. Five minutes of electrical brain activity at rest were recorded before and after 1) one session in which participants perceived and regulated (through distancing) their emotions (Regulation session, ReS) and 2) another session in which they only perceived emotions (Attend session, AtS). The order of the two sessions was randomized. We used 160 visual stimuli, both neutral and negative, taken from the International Affective Picture System to elicit emotions. Subjective ratings of valence and arousal of stimuli were also recorded using the Self-Assessment Manikin procedure, as a manipulation check of effective regulation.
Behavioral results showed the efficacy of the regulation strategy, with significant differences in the arousal and valence ratings, respectively reduced and increased in the ReS compared to the AtS. Cluster-based permutation analysis on EEG data at rest revealed a significant increase in delta and theta activity after ReS compared to the AtS. These findings suggest that regulating emotions affects baseline activity of the brain. Specifically, distancing produces increased activity in delta and theta frequencies after the regulation session. In line with previous findings, we argue that an increase in these frequencies may be considered as a signature of emotion regulation processes.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Astrocytic mitochondria regulates astrocytes morphogenesis and supports synaptogenesis
Tamara Zehnder
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tamara Zehnder, Department of Fundamental Neurosciences, Faculty of Biology and Medicine, University of Lausanne, Rue du Bugnon 9, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland; Francesco Petrelli, Tamara Zehnder1, 1. Department of Fundamental Neurosciences, Faculty of Biology and Medicine, University of Lausanne, Rue du Bugnon 9, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland; Jennifer Romanos, Institute of Pharmacology and Toxicology, University of Zurich, CH-8057 Zurich, Switzerland; Eva C. De Oliveira Figueiredo, Department of Fundamental Neurosciences, Faculty of Biology and Medicine, University of Lausanne, Rue du Bugnon 9, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland; Tommy L. Lewis, Aging & Metabolism Program, Oklahoma Medical Research Foundation, Oklahoma City, OK 73104, USA; Nicole Déglon, Department of Clinical Neurosciences, Laboratory of Neurotherapies and Neuromodulation (LNTM), Lausanne University Hospital (CHUV) and University of Lausanne, CH-1011 Lausanne, Switzerland; Neurosciences Research Center (CRN), Laboratory of Neurotherapies and Neuromodulation (LNTM), Lausanne University Hospital and University of Lausanne, CH-1011 Lausanne, Switzerland; Franck Polleux, Department of Neuroscience, Columbia University, New York, NY 10032, USA, Mortimer B. Zuckermand Mind Brain Behavior Institute, New York, NY 10032, USA; Mirko Santello, Institute of Pharmacology and Toxicology, University of Zurich, CH-8057 Zurich, Switzerland; Paola Bezzi, Department of Fundamental Neurosciences, Faculty of Biology and Medicine, University of Lausanne, Rue du Bugnon 9, CH-1005 Lausanne, Switzerland

The mechanisms controlling the postnatal maturation of astrocytes play a crucial role in ensuring a correct synaptogenesis. Here we explore the functional significance of mitochondrial activity for post-natal maturation of astrocytes in vitro and in vivo. We show that postnatal morphogenesis of astrocytes is critically dependent on the transient up-regulation of metabolic regulator PPARγ co-activator 1α (PGC-1α) which is required for determining the highly interconnected functional network of mitochondria and then for providing an efficient bioenergetic supply in the developing astrocytes. The integrity of the elongated mitochondrial network depends on the metabotropic glutamate receptor 5 (mGluR5) via a direct modulation of PGC-1α. We also report that perturbation of mitochondria network and function by ablation of the PGC-1α or of the mGluR5 in the developing astrocytes leads to a delayed morphogenesis of astrocytes and an impairment in the formation and function of neighbouring synapses, whereas genetic re-expression of PGC-1α in astrocytes restores mitochondrial functions and ameliorates both astroglial and neuronal defects. Together with the finding of the development-associated enhancement of mitochondrial function in astrocytes, our results uncover mitochondria activity as a novel mechanism controlling astrocyte morphogenesis and supporting synaptogenesis, thus identifying the mitochondrial function of the developing astrocytes as potential target to ameliorate the formation and function of synapses. Support contributed: Swiss National Foundation NCCR “Synapsy” (51NF40-158776) and “Transcure” (51NF6240-16) to PB, SNFS (26074366) to PB.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Vagus nerve stimulation induces widespread cortical and behavioral activation
Lindsay Collins
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Laura Boddington, David McCormick

Vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) is currently used to manage a variety of neurological disorders, although the mechanisms underlying therapeutic benefits are unclear. We hypothesized that VNS may activate widespread regions of the brain via neuromodulatory projections and ultimately alter cortical and behavioral state. We tested this prediction in mice surgically implanted with a vagus nerve cuff electrode. Pupillometry and behavioral analysis in awake head-fixed mice demonstrated that VNS dose-dependently induces a change in behavioral state. Widefield calcium imaging of excitatory neurons revealed that VNS activates multiple regions of the cortex, including motor, somatosensory, retrosplenial, visual, and auditory cortical areas. Widespread cortical activation evoked by VNS was maintained under light isoflurane anesthesia, indicating that VNS activates the cortex above and beyond that resulting from VNS-induced motor activity. Two-photon calcium imaging and multiunit recordings of excitatory cortical neurons confirmed that VNS excites layer 2/3 cells in both awake and anesthetized states. The vagus nerve innervates the noradrenergic locus coeruleus which sends broad neuromodulatory projections throughout the brain including the cortex and the cholinergic basal forebrain. Noradrenaline and acetylcholine are both heavily implicated in modulation of cortical and behavioral state, so we predicted that the observed effects of VNS on cortical excitation and arousal state may occur via activation of these neuromodulatory pathways. Using 2-photon calcium imaging of cortical axons we demonstrated that VNS activates both noradrenergic and cholinergic cells. Together, our results support a model of VNS in which stimulation results in activation of broadly projecting neuromodulatory systems, a widespread increase in cortical excitation, and an increase in arousal state.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Sensorimotor adaptation by task-irrelevant feedback
Kunlin Wei
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kunlin Wei, Yajie Liu, Wanyin Jiang, Yuqing Bi

Learning by doing is the first tenet of sensorimotor learning. Some motor learning methods, e.g., observational learning, circumvent physical practice of actions, but they still demand deliberate mental simulation of to-be-learned actions with the aid of task-relevant feedback. Here we demonstrate that people can obtain long-term learning in a sensorimotor adaptation task based on task-irrelevant feedback. Participants were required to control a hand-cursor to reach to a target while ignoring a directionally-deviated cursor (the double cursor) moving simultaneously with the hand. Participants were able to suppress this task-irrelevant cursor's influence and perform the task without any sign of implicit learning or adaptive strategy. However, in delayed retention tests, they adapted significantly faster to a standard visuomotor rotation perturbation than naïve controls. Participants also showed this saving effect if the double cursor moved in the opposite direction of the visuomotor rotation in the retention test, if it moved with a random direction, or if it moved in mirror-symmetrical directions (mirror reaching is widely regarded as a skill acquisition task). Thus, given that the effect is direction-invariant and across-task, it appears that participants abstract the spatial relationship of visuomotor rotation from the double cursor. They did not show any implicit learning or explicit strategy initially, and their savings was supported only by the faster formation of explicit motor strategies. Furthermore, we found no saving effect if the double cursor was not directionally deviated but amplitude scaled to the actual hand movement, further collaborating that people deduce an angular concept from the task-irrelevant feedback. Hence, sensorimotor adaptation can be facilitated without deliberate practice and without overt behavioral measures such as explicit strategy or aftereffect. While sensorimotor adaptation is widely considered as a combination of explicit strategy and implicit adaptation, our findings suggest that the motor concept, perhaps a third component, might affect adaptation.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Flexible operation of serial dependence in perceptual decision-making
Huihui Zhang
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Xing Tian, Division of Arts and Sciences, New York University Shanghai, NYU-ECNU Institute of Brain and Cognitive Science, New York University Shanghai, Shanghai, PRC; David Alais, The University of Sydney, School of Psychology, NSW 2006, Australia

Perceptual decision-making can be biased towards recent choices. In many cases, the recent past information stored in working memory is structured (e.g., a continuous attribute with a categorical behavioral-relevant choice). How exactly these information affects the dynamic decision process still remains unclear. We examined this ?attractive? serial dependence using a categorization task with auditory stimuli that vary along two attribute dimensions: gender (male to female, 5 levels) and syllable (?ba? to ?da?, 5 levels). We found that categorization of both gender and syllable exhibited a positive serial dependence on previous choices. However, the underlying dynamic process differed between the attributes. For gender, the amplitude of serial dependence was modulated by the similarity between previous and current stimuli, with participants more likely to follow their previous choice if the previous and current sounds were similar (and they responded more quickly in this case). For syllable, the dependence on previous choice did not depend on similarity between successive stimuli. With the drift-diffusion model, we further showed that in gender categorization, the past history (percept and choice) influenced the evidence accumulation, but in syllable categorization, the past choice mainly biased the starting point of accumulation. Next, participants were asked to rate how much the stimulus sounded male/female and ?ba?/?da?. We found that ratings of gender varied continuously along the male/female dimension but ratings of ?ba?/?da? showed a bimodal distribution. Our results suggest that during the categorization task, the continuous percept and categorical choice of gender are possibly both stored in working memory, but for syllable, perception is same as decision, both categorical. The different structures of recent past information may result in the different operations of serial dependence in perceptual decision-making.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Do neural responses to heartbeats distinguish self and other in an emotional perspective taking task?
Tahnée Engelen
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Anne Buot, École Normale Supérieure; Julie Grèzes, École Normale Supérieure; Catherine Tallon-Baudry, École Normale Supérieure;

On a daily basis, we share in each other's joy and frustrations, yet despite the contagious nature of emotions, we are perfectly capable of dissociating our own emotional state to that of someone else. Such a differentiation between self and other might seem trivial, but becomes more puzzling considering that many physiological responses and neural activations are shared between experiencing and observing of emotions. One proposed mechanism in which our sense of self might be anchored is the neural monitoring of heartbeats. The debate on how our emotional experiences are shaped by bodily signals, in particular cardiac signals, is long-standing, yet this relationship has been mostly explored in how emotions might change cardiac activity. Here, we propose a new avenue of research; how is the neural monitoring of heartbeats related to our emotional experience, and more specifically, does the neural monitoring of heartbeats help differentiate self from other in emotion? To explore this question, participants engaged in an emotional perspective taking task while their brain activity was measured using EEG, and several peripheral physiological measures were recorded (cardiac activity, facial EMG, and Skin Conductance Responses (SCR)). While participants prepared to rate a naturalistic image for either their own emotion or the emotion depicted in the image, Heartbeat Evoked Responses (HER) significantly differed between the self and other condition. Additionally, during exploration of the image, a self-other difference in SCR was found, as well as an interaction for the valence of the image and self-other condition in the facial zygomatic muscle. Observed self-other HER differences were localized to frontal and occipital sources, which correlated with subjective ratings of the images, as well as empathic traits, but not with the effects observed in physiological responses. Our results show that the HER can perform a role in self-other distinction in emotional contexts.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Effects of the stress hormone cortisol on spontaneous activity in the larval zebrafish tectum
Elina Jacobs (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Matthew J. Harvey, Kings College London; Martin Meyer, Kings College London

Early life stress can have lifelong negative health consequences, but we still lack an understanding of the mechanisms that cause this. In the brain, exposure to stress during development is known to affect neural plasticity and excitability in the limbic system. The limbic system in turn is intimately interconnected with sensorimotor systems, which represent key stages in receiving information about the world and coordinating behavioural responses to environmental stimuli including stressors. Yet, how stress affects sensorimotor systems remains largely unknown. Here we used the optic tectum of the larval zebrafish as a model to investigate how exposure to the stress hormone cortisol affects processing in a visual circuit. Specifically, we hypothesized that cortisol would have an effect on tectal physiology and that we would observe differences in tectal population dynamics. We employed two-photon calcium imaging to probe single-cell resolution changes in activity during spontaneous (stimulus free) tectal activity before and after addition of cortisol. We applied machine learning approaches to characterise the dynamics before and after cortisol. Preliminary results suggest that cortisol significantly alters the population dynamics in the larval tectum. These results suggest that the larval zebrafish is a promising model for investigating the effects of stress on sensorimotor physiology and development.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Influence of dopamine signalling and oxidative metabolism on fluorescent advanced glycation end products formation in Drosophila melanogaster
Ana Filošević Vujnović
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Katarina Jović, Faculty of Health and Medical Sciences, University of Surrey, Guildford, Surrey, United Kingdom, Emanuel Pištan, High school Andrija Mohorovičić, Rijeka, Croatia, Rozi Andretić Waldowski, Department of Biotechnology, University of Rijeka, Rijeka, Croatia

Dopamine (DA) is one of the major monoamines in the central nervus system. Disfunction in the DA synthesis, transport or signaling can lead to pathophysiological conditions associated with aging and neurodegeneration. DA influences glucose release, and high levels of free glucose can induce non-enzymatic glycation and covalent bonding of intra- and extra-cellular proteins resulting in the fluorescent Advanced Glycation End products (fAGEs).
Our objectives were to investigate if DA could impact fAGEs formation in vitro, and in vivo. We have adapted a method for in vitro hydrothermal synthesis and semi-quantification of fAGEs. DA and its precursor L-DOPA inhibited fAGEs synthesis in vitro, as did the known plant flavonoid and antioxidant, quercetin (QUE). For in vivo study we used Drosophila melanogaster and have shown that increasing DA pools by feeding flies L-DOPA, or reducing DA pools by feeding 3-iodo tyrosine (3IY) did not influence fAGEs formation. The effect of manipulating DA transport and signalling on fAGEs formation was tested using mutant in dopamine transporter (DAT), fumin, and mutant in dopamine D1-type receptor dumb. Both, fumin and dumb had increased fAGEs formation. To test the influence of extracellular DA on fAGEs we fed wt flies cocaine (COC), a known DAT inhibitor, which increases DA in the synaptic cleft, and methamphetamine (METH) which increases DA efflux. COC and METH both increased fAGEs compared to control flies, and METH feeding led to higher fAGEs amount compared to COC. We hypothesized that oxidative metabolism of free cytosolic DA in METH treated flies could be one of the reasons for increased fAGEs. To test this we fed flies with combination of METH and QUE and have shown reduction in fAGEs.
Results from this study suggest that increase in fAGEs is associated with the impairment of DA transport and its oxidative metabolism. Since detection of fAGEs is easy and non-invasive method that can be performed on skin tissue in humans, our finding supports the use of fAGEs testing in the context of neurodegenerative diseases.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Fingolimod (FTY720) improves the functional recovery and myelin preservation of the optic pathway in focal demyelination model of rat optic chiasm
mona hashemian
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Maryam Ghasemi-Kasman, Cellular and Molecular Biology Research Center, Health Research Institute, Babol University of Medical Sciences, Babol, Iran ; Hadi Parsian, Department of Clinical Biochemistry, Faculty of Medicine, Babol University of Medical Sciences, Babol, Iran ; Farzin Sadeghi, Department of Medical Microbiology, Faculty of Medicine, Babol University of Medical Sciences, Babol, Iran

It has been shown that fingolimod (FTY720) possesses beneficial effects on remyelination in the central nervous system (CNS). In this study, the effects of FTY720 and sodium valproate (VPA) as histone deacetylase inhibitor (HDAC) on the conductivity of visual signals, extent of demyelination area, glial activation, and expression levels of HDAC1and S1PR1 have been evaluated in the optic chiasm of lysolecithin (LPC)-induced demyelination model. In order to produce this demyelination model, LPC (1%, 2 μL) was injected into the rat optic chiasm. Latency of visual waves was measured by visual evoked potential (VEP) recording. The extent of demyelination area and level of glial activation were assessed using immunostaining. Gene expression analysis was performed to evaluate the expression levels of HDAC1, S1PR1, Olig2, and MBP in the optic chiasm. Analysis of electrophysiological data showed that LPC administration increased the latency of visual signals. FTY720 improved the functional recovery of the visual pathway and reduced the level of glial activation in the optic chiasm. FTY720 enhanced myelin repair and up-regulated the expression levels of Olig2 and MBP. Additionally, the expression levels of HDAC1 and S1PR1 were significantly reduced in animals treated with FTY720. In contrast to FTY720 treated animals, administration of VPA could not significantly improve the functional recovery of optic pathway following LPC injection. Cumulatively, the results of the present study demonstrate that FTY720 application improves the functional recovery of the optic pathway by reducing demyelination levels, amelioration of glial activation, and down-regulating of S1PR1 and HDAC1.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Cardiac signals modulate visual awareness
Viviana Leupin (Her/She)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Viviana Leupin, Joanna Moret, Juliane Britz

We can investigate neural correlates of consciousness by measuring the brain response to different perceptual outcomes of the same stimulus (e.g., sensory threshold stimuli perceived in 50% of trials). Differences in perceptual awareness can arise from i) evoked brain responses for different perceptual outcomes and ii) from the pre-stimulus differences in brain activity. Cyclic variations of bodily signals can also influence perceptual awareness: baroreceptor activity during the systolic phase interferes with sensory stimulus processing, and the pre-stimulus response of the brain to the heartbeat (HEP) differs for stimuli subsequently seen or not. We presented subjects with near-threshold stimuli (Gabors overlaid with random-dot-noise) and compared i) the event related potentials (ERPs) and ii) the HEP for the same stimuli when consciously seen and not. ERPs for seen and unseen differed as a function of cardiac phase: early sensory potentials (P1) were modulated during systole, while later cognitive potentials (VAN) were modulated during diastole. The HEP amplitude, topographic and source space differences indicated that the default-mode-network is recruited for subsequently unseen stimuli and that the saliency-network is recruited for subsequently seen stimuli. Taken together, we show that the cardiac phase and the brain response to the heartbeat can influence conscious awareness at the visual threshold.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Cortico-cerebellar networks as decoupled neural interfaces
Joseph Pemberton
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ellen Boven; Rui Ponte Costa; Richard Apps

The brain solves the credit assignment problem remarkably well. For credit to be correctly assigned across multiple cortical areas a given area should, in principle, wait for others to finish their computation. How the brain deals with this locking problem has remained unclear. Deep learning methods suffer from similar locking constraints both on the forward and backward phase. Recently, decoupled neural interfaces (DNI) were introduced as a solution to the forward and backward locking problems.
Here we propose that a specialised brain region, the cerebellum, helps the cerebral cortex solve the locking problem closely matching the computations and architecture of DNI. In particular, we propose that classical cerebellar forward and inverse models are equivalent to solving the backward and forward locking problems, respectively. We tested the cortico-cerebellar-DNI (CC-DNI) model in a range of sensorimotor and cognitive tasks that have been shown to be cerebellar-dependent. First, we show that the CC-DNI unlocking mechanisms can facilitate learning in a simple target reaching task. Next, by building on the sequential MNIST task we demonstrate that these results generalise to more complex sensorimotor tasks. Our cortico-cerebellar model readily applies to a wider range of modalities, to demonstrate this we tested the model in a cognitive task, caption generation. Models without the cerebellar-DNI component exhibit deficits similar to what has been observed in cerebellar patients in both motor and cognitive tasks. Finally, we introduce a CC-DNI model with highly sparse connectivity as observed in the cerebellum, which substantially reduces the number of parameters while improving learning through decorrelation.
Overall, our work offers a novel perspective on the cerebellum as a brain-wide decoupling machine for efficient credit assignment and opens a new avenue of research between deep learning and neuroscience.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Modulating RPTPσ promotes functional recovery in experimental models of multiple sclerosis
Smaranda Badea
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Li Rong, School of Biomedical Sciences, LKS Faculty of Medicine, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Rong Liu, School of Biomedical Sciences, LKS Faculty of Medicine, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Haitao Sun 2 Department of Neurosurgery, Zhujiang Hospital, Southern Medical University, Guangzhou, China; Jiandong Huang, State Key Laboratory of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong and School of Biomedical Sciences, LKS Faculty of Medicine, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Wutian Wu, Joint Laboratory for Brain Function and Health (BFAH), Jinan University and The University of Hong Kong, Guangzhou, China and Re-Stem Biotechnology Co. Ltd., Jiangsu, China

Changes in chondroitin sulphate proteoglycans (CSPGs) following neural injury or as part of a neurodegenerative process lead to the inhibition of myelin repair. In Multiple sclerosis, CSPGs are deposited at the border of active and expanding demyelinating lesions and may create a barrier for regeneration and contribute to neurodegeneration. CSPG inhibition of axonal regeneration is partially mediated by the protein tyrosine phosphatase sigma (PTPσ) receptor. PTPσ is also the main player of CSPG inhibition of oligodendrocyte (OL) outgrowth and myelination. Intracellular sigma peptide (ISP) binds to PTPσ and relieves CSPG-mediated inhibition and has been used to promote regeneration after spinal cord injury. Identification of PTPσ as a functional receptor for CSPGs presents a promising avenue of investigation to rescue OL activity and promote recovery in demyelinating lesions.

Here we show that ISP treatment can improve functional recovery in animal models of multiple sclerosis and highlight cellular changes involved in the process. The EAE mice treated with ISP significantly recovered hindlimb function, and showed considerably reduced neuroinflammation and immune infiltration, smaller demyelinating lesion sites, and significantly more neurofilament sparing. After systemic demyelination, mice that received ISP showed motor and cognitive improvements that correlated with increased remyelination and decreased neuroinflammation. We further demonstrate that delaying ISP administration by two weeks in a chronic disease model leads to a lesser degree of functional and histological improvements while still significantly improving the condition, highlighting the importance of modulating CSPG signalling at an incipient stage of the disease. In vitro, astrocytes, microglia and OPCs exposed to CSPGs showed inhibitory responses that were ameliorated by ISP addition . Overall, our results suggest an exciting avenue for regeneration by targeting RPTPσ, supporting further consideration for therapeutic usage.

 Traditional talk
Watch now
The development of the brain circuitry of conscious awareness in infancy
Huiqing Hu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Rhodri Cusack, Trinity College Institute of Neuroscience, School of Psychology, Trinity College Dublin, Dublin, Ireland; Lorina Naci, Trinity College Institute of Neuroscience, School of Psychology, Trinity College Dublin, Dublin, Ireland; Global Brain Health Institute, Trinity College Dublin, Dublin, Ireland.

One of the great frontiers of consciousness science is understanding how early consciousness arises in the development of the human infant. The reciprocal relationship between the default mode network (DMN) and dorsal attention network (DAN)/executive control network (ECN) has been suggested as a key feature of the brain mechanisms of conscious awareness. Nevertheless, it is poorly understood whether this relationship is present in new-born infants, or indeed whether DMN, DAN and ECN are developed at birth. We used resting-state fMRI data collected from preterm infants before (gestational age at 34.2 ± 2.0 weeks, N = 73) or at term-equivalent age (TEA, 40.9 ± 2.1 weeks, N = 73), and term infants (41.2 ± 1.7 weeks, N = 282) from the developing Human Connectome Project (dHCP), and adults (22–36 years, N = 176) from the Human Connectome Project 1200, as a reference group to investigate these questions. We calculated the within- and between-network functional connectivity (FC) in DMN, DAN and ECN and captured their internal structure using hierarchical clustering analysis for each group. We found: 1) Infants did not exhibit higher within- relative to between-network FC in DMN and DAN until TEA, suggesting that these networks are underdeveloped before TEA. 2) The three networks were already developed in infants born at TEA. However, they were less cohesive and more atypical in their nodal structure than the adult networks. 3) Infants did not show lower FC in the DMN-DAN pairing relative to other pairings until TEA, suggesting the third trimester is a key period of the development of this reciprocal relationship. 4) Birth at or prior to TEA differentially impacted to the development of these networks and their relationship. Our study sheds light on the development of the brain circuitry that supports conscious awareness in infancy.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Overcompensation of lens-accommodation in case of Convergence Insufficiency- A theoretical Model 
Akshara Vaithiswari Gopiswaminathan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ashwin Badrinath Pothiadia Irungovel, SUNY College of Optometry ; Bradly Alicea, Orthogonal Research and Education Laboratory

In this submission, I will present the theoretical computational model of a Non- Strabismic Binocular Vision Anomaly- an Adaptive Accommodation excess in case of Convergence Insufficiency (CI). Normally when a person perceives a target, ciliary and extraocular muscles are managed by the oculomotor nerve to clear the blur. The blur and disparity are corrected by altering the accommodation and vergence, respectively.
CI is characterized by an inability to maintain binocularity while working at distances closer to the body, experienced usually as intermittent double-vision when focusing at a target. People with CI often complain of the inability to concentrate while doing near work and complain of headaches, double- vision, and strain - caused due to the fatigue of the extraocular and ciliary muscles. The neural feedback system of accommodation and vergence are co-dependent, in that they are connected via a closed-loop pathway. Physiologically, this is evident in the form of an ”Accommodation Triad” which consists of Accommodation, Convergence, and Pupil constriction. The accommodation triad describes an exceptional adaptation acquired as neural feedback in some subjects (despite fatigue) as an excess of accommodation to compensate for CI. I will present the neural mechanism and the theoretical computational model of this adaptive process.
Traditional talk
Watch now
The Role of Genetic Polymorphisms in a Mouse Model of Traumatic Brain Injury and Personalized Treatment Approaches
Anna Giarratana (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Shavonne Teng, Sahithi Reddi, Cynthia Zheng, Smita Thakker-Varia, Janet Alder; Rutgers University

Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) is a serious and potentially life threatening problem. Clinicians have long noticed that certain patients recover better after TBI and we seek to identify genetic differences underlying these differences. This knowledge can be used to explore personalized approaches to treatment.

We investigated cellular and behavioral outcomes in genetically engineered mice with the BDNF Val66Met and ApoE4 polymorphism following repeated, mild TBI (rmTBI). We have found that injured Val66Met and ApoE4 carriers have a larger injury volume as assessed by MRI relative to injured Val66Val and ApoE3 carriers. We have shown that injured Val66Met carriers have increased levels of neurodegeneration, apoptosis, p-tau, activated microglia, and gliosis in the cortex and/or hippocampus at 1 and/or 21 days post injury (DPI) and that injured ApoE4 carriers have increased levels of neurodegeneration, apoptosis, activated microglia, and p-tau in the cortex and/or hippocampus at 1 and/or 21 DPI. We have also found that injured Val66Val mice have significantly more total BDNF at 21 DPI in the cortex, while ApoE3 injured mice have more total BDNF at 1 and 21 DPI in both the cortex and the hippocampus.

Therefore, we have concluded that Val66Met and ApoE4 are risk factors for poor outcomes after rmTBI. For personalized treatments, in the Val66Met injured mice we used an AAV-BDNF virus to overexpress wildtype BDNF, while in the ApoE4 injured mice we used Bryostatin-1, a PKCε activator that has previously been shown to increase BDNF levels. AAV-BDNF treatment in Val66Met injured mice reduces astrogliosis and activated microglia at 21 DPI and increases learning and memory. Bryostatin-1 treatment in the ApoE4 injured mice reduces neurodegeneration and activated microglia at 1 DPI and improves recovery in learning and memory. This study highlights the role that personalized therapeutics may be able to play in recovery for susceptible individuals.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Effects of practice of meditation on Brain EEG dynamics
Saketh Malipeddi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Prof. Bindu M. Kutty; Dr. John P John; Prof. Seema Mehrotra

Background: Humanity is going through unprecedented challenges. Chronic lifestyle diseases and mental health issues have skyrocketed in the last few decades, posing a significant threat to human well-being. Ancient Indian mind and body practices like Yoga and meditation prove beneficial in these times.

Aims: To assess the effects of the practice of Isha Yoga on the Brain using EEG

Methods: EEG data was acquired using a 128-channel Geodesic EEG system, in 7 advanced meditators, 5 novice meditators, and 6 controls (those with no previous history of any meditation). EEG data was recorded in all the three groups for 62 minutes (4 mins rest – 30 mins cognitive task – 4 mins rest – 6 mins of Pranayama – 14 mins of meditation – 4 mins of rest). EEG data preprocessing was done using Makoto’s PREP pipeline in EEGLAB v13.4.4b and MATLAB version R2017a.

Results: There was a statistically significant difference (p < 0.05 with FDR correction) in power spectral plots between the three groups: For Pranayama at 6 – 8 Hz (frontal mid-line and occipital regions) and 30 – 40 Hz (fronto-parietal and occipital regions); For Meditation at 6 – 8 Hz (occipital regions) and 30 – 40 Hz (Frontal and occipital regions)

Conclusion: Advanced practitioners of Isha Yoga had an increased frontal mid-line theta power (indicating greater parasympathetic activation and calmness) and an increased gamma wave power (indicating brain-wide synchronization and a high degree of attentional control). The results indicate that the long-term practice of Isha Yoga leads to greater well-being and higher cognitive control.

 Traditional talk
Watch now
The interhemispheric interactions in cortical plasticity
Jan Jablonka
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jan A. Jablonka, Robert Bińkowski, Elżbieta Fuszara, Maria Sadowska, Władek Sredniawa, Aleksandra Szlachcic, Paulina Urban, Ewa Kublik

The two hemispheres of the brain are commonly treated as independent structures when peripheral or cortical manipulations are applied to one of them. The contralateral hemisphere is often used as a within-animal control of plastic changes induced onto the other side of the brain. This ensures uniform conditions for producing experimental and control data, but it may overlook possible interhemispheric interactions. We provide, for the first time, direct proof that cortical, experience-dependent plasticity is not a unilateral, independent process.
We mapped metabolic brain activity in rats with 2-[14C] deoxyglucose (2DG) following experience-dependent plasticity induction after a month of unilateral (left), partial whiskers deprivation (only row B was left). This resulted in ~45% widening of the cortical sensory representation of the spared whiskers in the right, contralateral barrel field (BF). We show that the width of 2DG visualized representation is less than 20% when only contralateral stimulation of the spared row of whiskers is applied in immobilized animals. This means that cortical map remodeling, which is induced by experience-dependent plasticity mechanisms, depends partially on the contralateral hemisphere. The response, which is observed by 2DG brain mapping in the partially deprived BF after standard synchronous bilateral whiskers stimulation, is therefore the outcome of at least two separately activated plasticity mechanisms (center cerround in 2DG visualised representation). A focus on the integrated nature of cortical plasticity, which is the outcome of the emergent interactions between deprived and non-deprived areas in both hemispheres may have important implications for learning and rehabilitation.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Regression-based EEG analysis reveals temporally scaled signals during interval timing
Cameron Hassall (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jack Harley, University of Oxford; Nils Kolling, University of Oxford; Laurence Hunt, University of Oxford

The ability to act and perceive over different timescales is critical in our lives, yet the neural basis of flexible timing remains poorly understood. Recently animal work suggests that flexible timing is achieved via temporal scaling within medial frontal cortex, where a common neuronal response is stretched or compressed across the length of the produced interval. Our goal was to determine whether such scaling could be found non-invasively at the scalp using electroencephalography (EEG). A traditional EEG analysis can only capture fixed-time components because it assumes that neural activity occurs at fixed-time latencies. To capture scaled-time activity, we developed a regression-based approach to unmix fixed-time and scaled-time components within the EEG. After validating the approach using simulated data, we conducted two interval timing experiments. In one task, human participants learned to produce either a short, medium, or long interval. In a second task, they judged the accuracy of a computer-produced interval. In both tasks, we observed a scaled-time component that was distinct from the preceding and following fixed-time components. Interestingly, the earlier in time that the scaled-time component peaked, the faster the participant responded. These results suggest that temporal scaling is a feature of human interval timing and may provide a general method for recovering temporally scaled signals associated with other cognitive processes known to unfold over varying timescales.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Neural representations of social placebo effect
Xinyuan Yan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Yina Ma, Beijing Normal University

Abstract
Knowing the efficacy of administrated treatment is critical for inducing placebo effect. For example, giving treatment with full information could enable better therapeutic effect than just administrating treatment in hidden way. Even fake pill with “effective” descriptions would produce therapeutic-like effects. One fascinating question would be: how human brain could encode and represent treatment-related information to generate placebo responses? In the current study, we answered this question within the framework of social placebo effect (SPE), a latest placebo effect that can facilitate social functioning. Specifically, we examined the spontaneous representation and information-based representation by adopting resting-state and concepts representation task. Behavioral measurement was also adopted to confirm the placebo responses. We found that the spontaneous representation for treatment information has enhanced functional connectivity within social brain network, as well as between vmPFC and superior frontal gyrus. Further, in concepts representation task, treatment’s efficacy was represented in vmPFC, left middle frontal, right lateral orbitofrontal cortex with more distinct and finer-grained pattern in placebo condition. Finally, combing neural indices and behavioral indices, participants in placebo condition can be discriminated from control condition with a classification accuracy of 89%. Our study revealed the potential neural mechanisms for explaining why giving treatment information would induce placebo effect in multiple perspectives. These findings may further contribute to the way to manipulate effectiveness of treatment in clinical practice.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Spectral features of an oddball task across modalities
Priyanka Ghosh
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Arpan Banerjee, National Brain Research Center

P300 complex is associated with cognitive processes such as attention and mem-
ory.An oddball paradigm in which,a deviant stimulus is infrequently presented
amidst a sequence of standard repetitive stimuli,typically exhibits a positive
peak in the event related potential recording via electroencephalogram(EEG)
at a latency of around 300ms from the onset of the stimulus.This study explores
the spectral features of the P3 complex ERP and the underlying cortical areas
involved in its generation,across unimodal and multimodal using 2 stimuli odd-
ball paradigms.Further,we extrapolate to study the spectral changes acquired
through 2 stimuli oddball paradigm,in which both the stimuli are of a different
modalities.Consequently,we compare our empirical results and try to answer
whether the P3 complex is modality specific and how does it vary spectrally
and spatially(underlying cortical generators).
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The subjective understanding of actions and emotions in the brain involves the interplay of the semantic network and the action observation network
Minye Zhan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Minye Zhan, NeuroSpin; Rainer Goebel, Maastricht University; Beatrice de Gelder, Maastricht University;

How brain areas interact to understand other people’s bodily actions and emotions is still poorly understood. Apart from the involvement of the action observation network and areas related to human body perception, evidence of other brain areas’ involvement is still scarce. In this high-resolution 7T fMRI study with representational similarity analysis (RSA), we examined the representational geometry of participants’ subjective understandings of whole body images, using a large set of exemplars of bodily actions and emotions. Besides using conventional univariate/multivariate analysis, we obtained subjective reports of the perceived actions and emotions from the participants, and mapped these individual reports to a common high-dimensional space using pre-trained word embeddings. The representations for perceived action and emotion were high dimensional, both correlated to but not reducible to the predefined action and emotion categories. The perceived emotion representations further contained dimensions for the valence, and for fear and sad expressions. With searchlight RSA, we found that the left middle superior temporal sulcus (L mSTS) and left dorsal premotor cortex (L PMd) respectively corresponded to these behavioral representations. Further with task-residual functional connectivity and hierarchical clustering, we found that areas in the action observation network and the semantic/default-mode network were functionally connected to these two seed regions, and showed the most similar representations to them. Our study provides direct evidence of the concurrent involvement of both networks in action and emotion understanding.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Analysis of EEG event-durations
Benedikt Ehinger
 
Abstract
 
Many EEG studies are analyzed using event-related potentials (ERP). But often, the experiments contains events of variable duration (e.g. reaction times, fixation durations, stimulus durations, movements). Due to a lack of analysis tools or plain unawareness, such durations are rarely modelled and typically a single ERP is calculated for all durations. This can lead to nonsensical, missleading or otherwise biased results, especially if event durations differ between conditions.

Using regression methods, I investigated this problem on real and simulated datasets. In the simulations, I systematically explore the effects of the ERP's waveform, different duration distributions, and noise, on multiple ways to model duration. Because varying event-durations co-ocur often with temporal overlap between events, I also investigate the influence of overlap and deconvolution based overlap-correction.

I conclude, that modelling event durations as a binned or linear predictor is not recommended. Non-linear effects can capture some of the patterns and are a promising candidate for further study.

This work is especially important for complex experiments for instance in virtual-reality or mobile EEG settings which naturally allow for eye-movements.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Investigating The role of cognitive systems in moral judgments according to social intuitionism and dual-process theory
Adib Valibeygi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Adib Valibeygi, Fasa Neuroscience Circle (FNC), Student research committee, Fasa University of Medical Sciences, Fasa, Iran Mehrnaz Hosseinzadeh, Fasa Neuroscience Circle (FNC), Student research committee, Fasa University of Medical Sciences, Fasa, Iran Fatemeh Saadat, Fasa Neuroscience Circle (FNC), Student research committee, Fasa University of Medical Sciences, Fasa, Iran Hadis Jalalinezhad, Fasa Neuroscience Circle (FNC), Student research committee, Fasa University of Medical Sciences, Fasa, Iran Laaya Rezaian, Fasa Neuroscience Circle (FNC), Student research committee, Fasa University of Medical Sciences, Fasa, Iran Elma Azhdehakosh, Fasa Neuroscience Circle (FNC), Student research committee, Fasa University of Medical Sciences, Fasa, Iran Guyonne Rogier, Department of dynamic and clinical psychology, Spienza University of Rome, Rome, Italy

Emotionally demanding decision-making situations, with conflicting utilitarian and deontological consideration, would make moral dilemmas the most challenging decision-making scenarios. According to dual-process theory, the fast intuitive and slow rational systems contribute to decision makings. But the extent that each system imparts in making judgments remains unknown. As social intuitionism theory considers the role of deliberation just in post-hoc justifications. In the present study, we hypothesized that usually slow thinking is preceded by fast intuitive thinking unless the individuals are asked to provide reasons when making judgments.
sample of 57 (female= 30, age (19-27), undergraduate students at Fasa University of Medical Sciences) participates voluntarily in the study. Participants were randomly assigned to two groups. and were presented with six classic scenarios representing moral and reasoning dilemmas and were ask to judge the righteous of the action. Groups were different in concurrency of judgment and providing explanations, as group one, were asked to simultaneously judge actions and provide explanations; but group two weren't informed the need for explaining. Then participants in either group were asked about their subjective inference of the judgments. Next, they had the chance to revise decisions. After this, all participants were asked to provide demographic data, and answers to Beck's Depression Inventory, and Yale-Brown Obsessive-Compulsive Scale.
The results indicate that the initial judgments were not affected by the grouping, and insufficient (p=0.06) to show group one tends more to revise their judgments. Also, revisions mostly happen in those scenarios subjects regards themselves emotional. Subjective inferences of judgments show a positive association of confident with being rational, and satisfaction, challenging with being annoyed and emotional. Female individuals tend more to revise but other variables such as obsession, and depression didn’t affect the judgments.
The study had limitations due to small sample size and lack of normalization. We didn't significantly show that the need for writing explanation would effectively induce the utilization of system two.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Dynamics of history-dependent perceptual judgment
Iacopo Hachen
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sebastian Reinartz, International School for Advanced Studies; Romain Brasselet, International School for Advanced Studies; Alisea Stroligo, International School for Advanced Studies; Mathew Diamond, International School for Advanced Studies

Perception is not the mere encoding of instantaneous physical features. A main determinant of perceptual choices is the pre-existing state of the subject as shaped by recent events. In other words, perceptual systems exhibit the important feature of being history-dependent. In a recent study (https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.07.12.199489v1), we focused on the role of stimulus history and its updating dynamics. We trained rats to classify whisker-mediated vibrations according to their mean speed, assigning each stimulus to one of two possible categories, “strong” or “weak”. Rats showed a response bias that was inversely correlated to stimulus values received in the preceding trials, but not dependent on previous choices or rewards. Specifically, receiving a high-speed stimulus led to a lower probability of classifying upcoming stimuli as “strong”, and vice versa, an effect which lasted for several trials. Surprisingly, the repulsive bias in a given trial n, following a stimulus in trial n-1, increased with the time interval between the two. The same key results were obtained by testing human subjects in an analogous tactile discrimination task. We modeled subjects’ perceptual judgments as the result of a history-dependent shift in decision criterion applied to sensory input, outperforming an ideal observer model based on current sensory information only. We also discuss mechanistic hypotheses concerning the neuronal correlates of this phenomenon, that we are currently investigating.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Hippocampal representations emerge when training recurrent neural networks on a memory dependent maze navigation task
Justin Jude
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Matthias Hennig, University of Edinburgh

Can neural networks learn goal-directed behaviour using similar strategies the brain uses to combine the relationships between the current state of the organism and the consequences of future actions? Recent work has shown that recurrent neural networks trained on goal based tasks can develop representations resembling those found in the brain, entorhinal cortex grid cells, for instance. Here we explore the evolution of the dynamics of their internal representations and compare this with experimental data. We observe that once a recurrent network is trained to learn the structure of its environment solely based on sensory prediction, an attractor based landscape forms in the network's representation, which parallels hippocampal place cells in structure and function. Next, we extend the predictive objective to include Q-learning for a reward task, where rewarding actions are dependent on delayed cue modulation. Mirroring experimental findings in hippocampus recordings in rodents performing the same task, this training paradigm causes nonlocal neural activity to sweep forward in space at decision points, anticipating the future path to a rewarded location. Moreover, prevalent choice and cue-selective neurons form in this network, again recapitulating experimental findings. Together, these results indicate that combining predictive, unsupervised learning of the structure of an environment with reinforcement learning can help understand the formation of hippocampus-like representations containing both spatial and task-relevant information.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Volumetric analysis reveals bilateral cerebellar atrophy in Rasmussen encephalitis
Johannes Reiter
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Bastian David, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn, Venusberg-Campus 1, 53127 Bonn, Germany; Selma Enders, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn, Venusberg-Campus 1, 53127 Bonn, Germany; Conrad Prillwitz, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn, Venusberg-Campus 1, 53127 Bonn, Germany; Bernd Weber, Institute of Experimental Epileptology and Cognition Research, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany; Christian Elger, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn, Venusberg-Campus 1, 53127 Bonn, Germany; Rainer Surges, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn, Venusberg-Campus 1, 53127 Bonn, Germany; Theodor Rüber, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn, Venusberg-Campus 1, 53127 Bonn, Germany, Epilepsy Center Frankfurt Rhine-Main, Department of Neurology, Goethe University Frankfurt, Frankfurt am Main, Germany, Center for Personalized Translational Epilepsy Research (CePTER), Goethe-University Frankfurt, Frankfurt am Main, Germany

Background: Rasmussen encephalitis (RE) is a rare autoimmune disease affecting one single cerebral hemisphere, leading to neuroinflammation, epileptic seizures and, finally, atrophy.
Besides primary atrophy localized within the ipsilesional cerebral hemisphere, recent studies have uncovered volumetric changes occurring within the contralesional hemisphere, which are conceptualized as secondary changes. Primary and secondary changes show a striking inhomogeneous distribution and severity pattern among patients, raising questions about the underlying mechanisms.

Aims: This study aims to uncover atrophic changes being present within the cerebellum of RE patients and sets them in relation to atrophy patterns of the cerebral cortex.

Methods: In a cross-sectional manner 57 patients (37 female, mean age=22+/-16y) diagnosed with RE were tested against 57 matched healthy controls. Using a surface-based approach morphometric measures of the cerebral cortex were examined. Depending on the visual appearance of cerebral atrophy, hypothetical groups of predominantly affected regions were formed. Cerebellar atrophy was studied by performing a Voxel-based-Morphometry and related to the groups of different regional cerebral affection.

Results: The cerebral cortex of the ipsilesional hemisphere showed widespread atrophy, particularly located around the sylvian fissure (fwe-corrp<0.01). The VBM of the cerebellum revealed bihemispheric atrophy most pronounced in both cerebellar tonsils and the contralesional posterior lobe (tfce-corrp<0.01). While significant atrophy was observed in patients with occipital, temporal and insular cerebral atrophy focus, patients with a frontal disease focus or a diffuse atrophy distribution did not show significant cerebellar atrophy compared to controls.

Conclusion: Supporting previous studies, atrophy within the ipsilesional cerebral hemisphere showed a transsylvian predilection site. Surprisingly, both cerebellar hemispheres showed significant atrophy, even though the primary pathology is thought to be restricted to one cerebral hemisphere. Crossed cerebellar atrophy might explain degeneration observed on the contralesional cerebellar hemisphere, while excitotoxicity, antiepileptic drugs or even the primary disease might be causes for bilateral neuronal degeneration.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Alpha-beta oscillations in the human substantia nigra signal the anticipation of appetitive and aversive social feedback: evidence from intracranial recordings
Alexandra Sobczak
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Alexandra Sobczak, Institute of Psychology I, University of Lübeck, Ratzeburger Allee 160, 23562 Lübeck, Germany; Eva M. Bauch, Faculty of Life Sciences, University of Applied Sciences and Medical University, Am Kaiserkai 1, 20457 Hamburg; Kai Heimrath, Departments of Neurology and Stereotactic Neurosurgery, Otto-von-Guericke University, Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany; Norbert Brüggemann, Klinik für Neurologie, University of Lübeck, Ratzeburger Allee 160, 23562 Lübeck, Germany; Christina Lohse, Klinik für Neurologie, University of Lübeck, Ratzeburger Allee 160, 23562 Lübeck, Germany; Hermann Hinrichs, Departments of Neurology and Stereotactic Neurosurgery, Otto-von-Guericke University, Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany; Friedhelm C. Schmitt, Departments of Neurology and Stereotactic Neurosurgery, Otto-von-Guericke University, Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany; Jürgen Voges, Departments of Neurology and Stereotactic Neurosurgery, Otto-von-Guericke University, Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany; Hans-Jochen Heinze, Departments of Neurology and Stereotactic Neurosurgery, Otto-von-Guericke University, Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany, Department of Behavioral Neurology, Leibniz Institute for Neurobiology. Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany; Tino Zaehle, Departments of Neurology and Stereotactic Neurosurgery, Otto-von-Guericke University, Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany, Department of Behavioral Neurology, Leibniz Institute for Neurobiology. Leipziger Straße 44, 39120 Magdeburg, Germany; Nico Bunzeck, Institute of Psychology I, University of Lübeck, Ratzeburger Allee 160, 23562 Lübeck, Germany

The substantia nigra/ventral tegmental area (SN/VTA) is well known for its involvement in reward anticipation and prediction error signaling. Moreover, recent work in animals shows that the SN/VTA does not only process rewarding but also aversive events. However, direct evidence from human subjects, which often learn through social interactions, is sparse. Therefore, we used intracranial electroencephalography recordings (iEEG) from SN dopamine (DA) neurons in Parkinson’s Disease (PD) patients (n=12, intraoperative, off medication) in combination with a social incentive delay task (SID) including photos of either neutral, approving or disapproving faces. At the behavioral level, patients’ response times did not differ between conditions. Healthy controls (young adults n=51; older adults n=52) and a slightly larger control group of PD patients (n = 19, on and off medication) exposed faster responses when anticipating positive and negative versus neutral feedback. Finally, time-frequency analysis revealed an effect within the alpha-beta range (8-20 Hz) from 300-600 ms after cue onset. Specifically, alpha-beta power significantly increased for positive vs neutral and negative vs neutral cues, but there was no significant difference between positive vs negative cues. As such, our findings provide new evidence for a role of the SN in processing appetitive and aversive social information via specific oscillatory mechanisms in the alpha-beta range.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Melanopsin-mediated regulation of pupil size in natural vision
Rafael Lazar
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Dr Manuel Spitschan

In humans, steady-state pupil size is largely determined by the activity of the intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells (ipRGCs) expressing the short-wavelength-sensitive photopigment melanopsin (λmax = 480 nm). From well-controlled laboratory studies employing parametric stimuli, we know that radiance drives the size of the pupil, with higher melanopic radiance associated with smaller pupil size, but at present there is no established data set for variations in pupil size in real-world light exposure. Here, we demonstrate a novel method to assess the light input regulating steady-state pupil size under dynamic, real-world conditions. We integrated a wearable infrared video-based eye tracker (Pupil Labs GmbH) with a small-scale spectroradiometer (Ocean Insight Inc.). Both devices were attached to a bespoke 3D-printed adjustable head mount and connected to a miniature, battery-driven control computer (Raspberry Pi), enabling simultaneous sampling of pupil size and spectral irradiance at 10-sec intervals. We measured natural variation in pupil size across two protocols, in which healthy, young participants (n=7; age: 20-30 years) moved in and between indoor and outdoor environments varying in light conditions and engaged in a range of everyday tasks. We successfully measured variation in pupil size as a function of near-corneal melanopic irradiance in the real world, yielding distinct dose-response curves for each participant. Under these uncontrolled conditions, data retention was reasonably high (~65% data retained; total number of usable spectrum and pupil size pairs: 6620). In line with the sluggish properties of melanopsin signalling, pupil size was more accurately predicted by integrating preceding melanopic irradiance values (60-sec window) than the simultaneous samples. In summary, we demonstrate a robust paradigm for conducting ambulatory research measuring melanopsin-mediated physiological signals in humans outside of the laboratory.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
“Metacogmission”: measuring metacognition across the lifespan and over two cognitive domains via an engaging gamified task
Andrew McWilliams
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Hannah Bibby, Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience, University College London, London, UK; Nikolaus Steinbeis, Department of Clinical, Educational and Health Psychology, University College London, London, UK; Stephen M. Fleming, Metacognition Group, Wellcome Centre for Human Neuroimaging and Department of Experimental Psychology, University College London, London, UK.

Background:
Metacognition – or “thinking about your own thinking” – is of increasing interest to cognitive neuroscientists, as a concept with translational potential to real world problems including theories of mental illness, insight into mental health and the capacity for authentic decision-making. Open questions remain about how metacognition develops and functions. There is conflicting evidence about whether metacognition improves or decays with age, and whether it generalises across multiple cognitive domains. Measurement of metacognition has often been limited by confounding effects of an individual’s task performance levels and of their general propensity to be self-confident. Models derived from Type 2 signal-detection theory circumvent these issues by returning a metacognitive “efficiency” parameter, quantifying sensitivity of confidence ratings given a certain level of task performance. However, fitting these models requires high numbers of trials to generate robust parameters, making tasks difficult to use for people who have low concentration or motivation.

Methods:
Working with a technology firm and a mental health service user advisory group, we developed Metacogmission – a gamified metacognitive task. After trialling at 2 public engagement events with over 400 people, we here report a cross-sectional observational study of >300 online volunteers (18 to 83 years), measuring metacognition for memory and visual perception. We use Bayesian modelling to derive metacognitive efficiency (meta-d’/d’), charting metacognition through the lifespan across two domains.

Results and conclusions:
Metacogmission was acceptable and fun, showing potential for use with clinical groups. Meta-d’ model fits, as assessed with MCMC convergence diagnostics, were robust, returning parameters comparable to those from more extensive laboratory tasks. Preliminary results indicate that as people age, performance on the first order cognitive tasks was preserved, although raw confidence (“bias”) decreased to middle age. Metacognitive efficiency remained largely stable with age, and was correlated across cognitive domains, consistent with a degree of domain-generality for metacognition.
Interactive talk
Watch now
The effect of expertise upon behavioral, neural, and computational representational space
Hans Op de Beeck
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Stefanie, Duyck; Chiu-Yueh Chen; Farah, Martens;

When people become an expert in a particular domain, they process objects of expertise in a different manner. Previous neuroimaging studies have demonstrated how this expertise alters brain activity by comparing objects of expertise with other objects (e.g., Gauthier et al., 2000, Nature Neuroscience; Harel et al., 2010, Cerebral Cortex). However, everyone knows whether an image depicts a bird or a car. In contrast, only a bird expert can tell apart a great-tailed from a boat-tailed grackle. Here we focus upon the neural basis of expertise at this detailed level by comparing the similarities and differences of the representational spaces of birds between 20 ornithologists and 20 control participants. We scanned subjects with functional magnetic resonance imaging while presenting images of 24 different bird types. The image set was organized in 8 triplets, which each contained two birds that belonged to the same species but were visually different (e.g. male and female) and one bird that resembled one of the other two birds but belonged to a different species. As such, the triplets dissociated species-level semantics from visual similarity. Behaviorally, ornithologists showed more within-group consistency in subjective similarity ratings compared to controls. In addition, the ornithologists showed a sensitivity to the dissociation between species and visual appearance when rating semantic similarity. A neural representational similarity analysis analyzed the multi-voxel patterns in low-level visual cortex (LVC), high-level visual cortex (HVC), and prefrontal cortex (PFC). In PFC, the neural patterns distinguished bird types more reliably in ornithologists than in controls. In addition, the similarity structure of the neural patterns was more shared between ornithologists than between controls, in particular in HVC and in PFC, and more correlated with behavioral similarity. These high-level behavioral and neural representations were also correlated with the representational spaces in deep artificial neural networks. Overall, our findings suggest that expertise has a large impact upon the behavioral and neural representational space of objects of expertise.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Myelination of parvalbumin interneurons shapes the function of cortical sensory inhibitory circuits and mouse whisker-mediated behaviour
Najate Benamer
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Najate Benamer, Marie Vidal, Maddalena Balia, María Cecilia Angulo Institut of Psychiatry and Neurosciences of Paris (IPNP), INSERM U1266, Paris, France

Oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs) represent the only non-neuronal cells that receive bona fide synapses from neurons. In the developing somatosensory cortex, we previously showed that OPCs are highly innervated by fast-spiking parvalbumin-expressing (PV) interneurons (Orduz et al., 2015, eLife; Orduz*, Benamer* et al., 2019, Nat Commun). Interestingly, the PV interneuron subtype represents the largest proportion of myelinated GABAergic neurons in the cerebral cortex. Despite several studies on neuron-OPC synapses, the function of these synapses remains poorly understood. In a recent work, we genetically inactivated γ2-mediated GABAergic synaptic signaling of OPCs to disturb PV interneuron-OPC synapses. We found that PV interneuron-OPC synapses does not highly affect OPC proliferation, oligodendrocyte differentiation and the developmental myelination pattern of the somatosensory cortex (Balia et al., 2017, Glia). Nonetheless, it has remained unclear whether neuron-OPC synapses could guide the correct myelination of the presynaptic neuron, impacting its function in neuronal circuits.
Here, we demonstrate that the disruption of GABAergic synaptic signaling of OPCs prior to myelination onset resulted in severe PV interneuron myelination defects characterized by longer internodes and nodes and proximal axon malformation. Consequently, high-frequency PV interneuron discharges as well as PV interneuron-dependent postsynaptic latencies and strengths of excitatory neurons were reduced during postnatal cortical development. These dysfunctions generated a strong excitation-inhibition imbalance that was correlated with whisker-dependent texture discrimination impairments. We concluded that, during cortical development, the inactivation of γ2-mediated OPC synapses have profound consequences in the myelination of PV interneurons, affecting the function of mature cortical inhibitory circuits. Our data reveal that PV interneuron-OPC synaptic activity during postnatal development constitute a key step in the construction of cortical circuits involved in rapid and strong inhibition during sensory processing (Benamer et al., 2020, Nat Commun, In Press).
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Resting State fMRI Connectivity in Schizophrenia, Bipolar Disorder, and Healthy Controls
Daniel Brown
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Daniel Brown, University of Oslo, Haakon Engen, NORMENT

Working Abstract:

Ongoing thought patterns, emerging from a collection of dynamically-connected neural systems, represent rich data that may contain valuable biomarkers for healthy vs. abnormal human cognition. In the distinction between neurotypical and abnormal brain function, connectivity analyses of resting-state fMRI data (rsfMRI) provide non-invasive biobehavioral estimations of functional connectonomics, which can then be aggregated for comparisons across demographic and diagnostic variables. The development and maturation of these computational connectivity analyses is promising for translational neuroscience, as a diagnostic tool to predict outcomes and optimize treatment selection, as well as for basic research, to advance the understanding of both healthy brain function and the evolving conceptualization of some mental disorders as heterogeneous “circuitopathies”, with distinct subtypes differentiated by individual circuits of disfunction.
In our current research, we investigate models of resting-state connectivity in fMRI data of schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and healthy controls (SZ, BP, HC; respectively), using Dynamic Graphical Models (DGMs). These multilinear models allow the estimation of directed connectivity, such that parent-child node connections are reported. Our data has been previously collected as part of research at the Norwegian Centre for Mental Disorders Research (NORMENT). At this stage in the research, we are using a DGM to investigate group differences between the SZ, BP, and HC groups.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Integration of information in the perceptual decision making task
Dominik Krzeminski
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jiaxiang Zhang

Perceptual decision making describes a process of deciding between available options based on the information from their senses. Recently, progress has been made to relate this behaviour to neural data. A number of computational models have been proposed to explain various aspects of the perceptual decision. Typically, those studies consider only a single dimensional binary decision. The multi-attribute decision-making research often focuses on multi-modal stimuli, ie. with different accumulation rates between attributes. Moreover, the evidence from animal studies shows that the brain tends to sum reward predictions from multiple cues. The details of the combination of evidence have not been studied in details in the perceptual decision paradigm, especially among the human subjects. In this study, we test whether the human brain combines the input from two information sources linearly (additively). We modify the classical random dots motion discrimination task by adding an additional axis of dots movement. We show that there are significant differences in terms of accuracy and reaction time between decisions made from the same amount of information provided by a single and two axes. In the congruent condition the accuracy and reaction times were lower when participants had to combine the data, but for the incongruent condition, participants were faster (but less accurate) when exposed to two axes. The angle between the access did not have a significant effect on analysed behaviour.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Mice learn multi-step routes by memorizing subgoal locations
Philip Shamash
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Phillip Shamash, UCL; Sarah Olesen, UCL; Panagiota Iordanidou, UCL; Dario Campagner, UCL; Banerjee Nabhojit, UCL; Tiago Branco, UCL

Animals must rapidly gather spatial information about new environments so that they can quickly reach food or safety even when direct paths are unavailable. The behavioral strategies used to implement multi-step routes to goals in naturalistic settings are unknown. Here we show that mice spontaneously learn a subgoal memory strategy while escaping to shelter or seeking food in an obstructed environment. We first investigated how mice navigate to shelter in response to threats when the direct path is blocked by a wall. Initially, mice ran straight toward the shelter and circumvented the obstacle using sensory cues. Over the course of 20 minutes, however, they switched to a spatial memory strategy to execute spatially efficient paths. Efficient escape routes were not learned by reinforcing egocentric actions or by constructing an unbiased internal map during exploration. Instead, mice used a hybrid strategy: they memorized specific subgoal locations encountered during previous running movements toward the obstacle. We then found that the same behavioral strategy is also used in a reward-seeking task. These results show that spontaneous memorization of local subgoals is a fundamental strategy by which rodents execute efficient multi-step routes to goals in novel environments.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
BrainPrint captures stage-specific lateral shape asymmetry in autoimmune limbic encephalitis
Antonia Harms
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tobias Bauer, Department of Epileptology, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany;Leon Ernst,Department of Epileptology, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany; Bastian David,Department of Epileptology, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany; Bernd Weber,2Institute of Experimental Epileptology and Cognition Research, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany; Albert J. Becker,3Department of Neuropathology, Section for Translational Epilepsy Research, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany;Christian E. Elger,1Department of Epileptology, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany; Martin Reuter,Martinos Center for Biomedical Imaging, Radiology, MGH / Harvard Medical School, Boston, USA, German Center for Neurodegenerative Diseases (DZNE), Bonn, Germany; Rainer Surges,Department of Epileptology, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany; Theodor Rüber,Department of Epileptology, University of Bonn Medical Center, Bonn, Germany,Epilepsy Center Frankfurt Rhine-Main, Department of Neurology, Goethe University Frankfurt, Frankfurt am Main, Germany,Center for Personalized Translational Epilepsy Research (CePTER), Goethe-University Frankfurt, Frankfurt am Main, Germany;

Limbic Encephalitis (LE) is an autoimmune disease often associated with temporal lobe epilepsy. It is categorized by serological subgroups, that differ in clinical progress, therapy and prognosis.

Our aim is to develop accurate imaging biomarkers for clinical and scientific implementation.

We investigate lateral shape asymmetry of an ensemble of 10 cortical and subcortical structures, by applying BrainPrint, a surface-based method that uses Eigenvalues of the Laplace-Beltrami operator on triangular (boundary) and tetrahedral (volumetric) meshes as shape descriptors. The intraindividual lateral shape asymmetry of each structure is calculated as the Euclidean distance between the shape descriptors.

We are comparing lateral shape asymmetry of patients with antibodies against the glutamic acid decarboxylase 65 (GAD, n=34), leucine-rich glioma-inactivated protein 1 (LGI1, n=15), contactin-associated protein-like 2 (CASPR2, n=9) to age-matched healthy controls (HC, n=41). We divide the sero-groups by disease stage (time between first LE-associated symptoms and date of MRI) into an early stage (below or equal 24 months) and a chronic stage (above 24 months).

We find significant difference in the amygdala volume between the LGI1 patients of the acute group and the HC. Regarding the shape-asymmetry we find differences for the amygdala (LGI1 early), the hippocampus (CASPR2 early, LGI1 chronic), the caudate nucleus (CASPR2 early), the thalamus (GAD and LGI1 early and chronic) and the striatum (GAD, LGI1, CASPR2 chronic).

Our findings mirror the higher sensitivity of shape information as compared to volumetry. Since we already identified sero-specific features in volume differences in earlier studies, we now expect to refine those findings by adding information about shape. Our aim is to develop a decision tree classifier, so that in future MR-imaging analysis will contribute accurately to diagnosis, prognosis and description of progress of LE.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Oscillatory activity in the STN under PD: do we need to account for aperiodic broadband signal/activity and how it affects our data?
