Elena Belova
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ulia Semenova, Semenov Institute for Chemical Physics, Anna Gamaleya, Burdenko Neurosurgery Institute, Alexey Tomskiy, Burdenko Neurosurgery Institute, Alexey Sedov, Semenov Institute of Chemical Physics

Oscillatory activity in the basal ganglia is under extensive research as it may contribute to motor dysfunction in Parkinson’s disease (PD). Most of the studies deal with local field potentials (LFPs), which are thought to reflect activity of neuronal populations in the vicinity of the macroelectrode recording contact. The power of oscillations may be assessed using power spectral density estimates in the range of interest. However, every spectra has aperiodic broadband component (commonly viewed as noise) that is usually not taken into account. Recent research (Gao et al., 2017) has suggested that this aperiodic signal may reflect the balance between the excitatory and inhibitory (E/I) projections. Besides, the slope of aperiodic component may affect the amplitude of oscillatory peaks and skew the perceived power of oscillations when measured without slope extraction. We aimed to compare the power of LFP oscillations in several bands using the conventional method and the method accounting for aperiodic component. LFP spectra were recorded in the subthalamic nucleus of parkinsonian patients undergoing DBS surgeries in 2017-2020 in Burdenko Neurosurgery Institute. We performed LFP recordings at rest and during voluntary movement (i.e. fist contraction). We searched for the association between oscillatory activity in several frequency bands and motor signs of PD and their sensitivity to motor tests using both methods. Here we provide the evidence supporting the idea that aperiodic broadband component in LFP spectra may carry meaningful information about E/I balance, though this aperiodic signal does not affect significantly the associations found for LFP oscillations and motor function in PD.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Retinal inputs to human neuroendocrine and circadian physiology
Manuel Spitschan
 
Abstract
 
In addition to canonical visual functions, light exposure profoundly affects physiology and behaviour through its effects on circadian, neuroendocrine and neurocognitive functions. This is largely mediated by the melanopsin-containing intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells (ipRGCs). However, ipRGCs also receive cone-rod input, making the signal driving the non-visual effects of light complex. Here, I will discuss two lines of my work investigating how the different photoreceptors in the retina impact human neuroendocrine and circadian physiology. First, I will describe a recent study examining the role of S cones in melatonin suppression by evening light, employing the method of silent substitution to generate spectral light stimuli that differ by almost two orders of magnitude in S cone activation with minimal change in the activation of the L and M cones, melanopsin and rods. Second, I will describe a recent field study with congenital achromats, who do not have a functional cone system, examining the regularity of their rest-activity cycles using actimetry, and the melatonin phase angles of circadian entrainment.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Connectome based model predicts individual differences in inattentive and hyperactive symptoms of ADHD.
Jee Won Yoon
 
Abstract
 
Background: Studies have persistently investigated brain regions in ADHD patients that show abnormalities compared to normal controls. However, due to diverse cognitive dysfunctions and related neural correlates in ADHD, results are non-converging showing lack of reliability. To resolve this problem computational models have been developed incorporating related brain regions and investigating relationships with relevant behaviors or symptoms with increased robustness. Yet, few models predict each subjects’ primary symptoms of ADHD which takes individuality into account.
Methods: Using resting state brain scans of 299 children with and without ADHD, we constructed a model by using CPM(Connectome based Predictive Modeling) to predict individual differences in inattentive and hyperactive symptom severity. In addition, we generalized each of these two models to other neuropsychological test batteries to identify shared components.
Results: Using leave-one-subject-out CPM, both inattentive and hyperactive models showed significant predictive power with generalization to novel individuals. We found predictive functional networks of inattentive and hyperactive phenotype that appear in widespread patterns across the whole-brain. Among 4 sets of neuropsychological tests, both inattentive and hyperactive model generalized to ATA-vision and Stroop tests. This indicates that primary symptoms of ADHD that are reflected in selected functional brain features involve cognitive measurements of these two neuropsychological tests.
Conclusions: Functional connections of an individual contain information about two primary symptoms or phenotypes of ADHD and share components with cognitive measures from certain types of neuropsychological test batteries which are ATA-vision and Stroop test.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Object Categorization and Response Bias Flexibly Change Depending on Cross-Spatial Scale Coherence and Task Demands
Miguel G.E. Santo
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Miguel G. E. Santo; Johan Wagemans

Categorization of visual stimuli at different levels of abstraction relies on the encoding of relevant diagnostic features present at different spatial scales. We used the Eidolon Factory (Koenderink et al., 2017), an image-manipulation algorithm based on the scale-space representation of the early visual cortex that introduces random disarray fields across spatial scales. When the disarray is incoherent, edges become fuzzy and less defined; when it is coherent, the coarser scales dictate where the finer scales end up, leading to warping of the local structure of the image. With this method, we asked: is the brain using the global shape or is it detecting some salient feature to resolve a recognizable object? And, how is the correlational structure of different spatial scales interacting with the task demands? Images of animal faces, human faces and everyday objects were disarrayed coherently or incoherently to create a family of 50 eidolons per image with increasing disarray. Participants (N=217) viewed each family of eidolons in a smooth sequence from maximum disarray to none and performed a category verification task either at the superordinate (any face type) or basic (human face only) levels at different levels of uncertainty. In the first response, they used their gut feeling to respond, for the second response they had to be sure of their decision. When participants used their gut feeling to respond, we observed a basic-level advantage, but not an effect of the type of disarray. When they were sure of their response, we observed a superordinate advantage and stronger disarray effects in the coherent stimulus. Furthermore, participants changed their decision criterion depending on the abstraction level of the task. These results suggest that the visual system flexibly adjusts to the relevant perceptual information depending on task context and that it does not strictly adhere to feedforward processing.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Deletion of beta2-containing nicotinic receptors in striatal neurons leads to behavioral alterations and increased striatal activity
Helena Janickova
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Alice Abbondanza, Institute of Physiology of the Czech Academy of Sciences, Prague, Czech Republic; Martin Modrak, Institute of Microbiology of the Czech Academy of Sciences, Prague, Czech Republic; Jan Elias, Czech Centre for Phenogenomics, Institute of Molecular Genetics of the Czech Academy of Sciences, Vestec, Czech Republic; Trisha Dhabalia, Institute of Physiology of the Czech Academy of Sciences, Prague, Czech Republic;

Nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) are relatively less expressed by striatal neurons comparing to other brain regions and their expression by individual types of striatal neurons as well as their functional significance is rather elusive. According to the traditional view supported mainly by electrophysiological data, nAChRs are mainly expressed by striatal interneurons while the expression by striatal principal neurons (commonly referred to as medium spiny neurons, MSNs) is very low. Striatal interneurons represent only approximately 5 % of neurons in the striatum and they consist of a group of cholinergic interneurons (CINs) and several different types of GABAergic interneurons (GABAINs). In our study, we reviewed previously published single cell RNA sequencing data1 to investigate the pattern of beta2-containing nAChRs (beta2* nAChRs) expression by striatal neurons. Furthermore, we performed deletion of beta2* nAChRs in striatal neurons to test the effect of the deletion on behavior and neuronal activity. By examining the previously published data, we found no difference in the RNA expression level between striatal interneurons and MSNs. In contrast, the non-specific deletion of beta2* nAChRs in striatal neurons led to increased neuronal activity evaluated by Fos immunofluorescence, both at baseline and after induction with amphetamine. This suggests that the deletion mainly affected inhibitory GABAINs leading to increased MSNs' activity. In addition, mice with the beta2* nAChRs deletion in striatal neurons showed alterations in social preference test and increased anxiety together with mild cognitive alterations and hyperactivity. This behavioral phenotype is less prominent but generally in agreement with the phenotype observed in global beta2-KO mice2.
References:
1. Munoz-Manchado AB. et al., Cell Rep. 8, (2018)
2. Granon S. et al., Proc Natl Acad Sci USA. 16, (2003)
Interactive talk
Watch now
Investigating Intero- and Exteroceptive Predictive Processes in Major Depressive Disorder
Dipanjan Ray
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Moumita Das, Basque Center for Applied Mathematics

The association between depression and derangement of sensory processing is well known. However, our understanding of the neural processes underlying sensory perception, both intero- and exteroception, is undergoing a rapid change. Predictive coding, for example, is a theoretical framework that proposes that the brain constantly generates hypotheses that predict sensory input at varying levels of abstraction and minimizes prediction errors either by updating its prior hypotheses (perceptual inference) or by modifying sensory input through action (active inference). In other words, (i) both bottom up and top down information flow among hierarchical cortical regions play important role in sensory processing and (ii) sensory and motor processes are highly entangled. In the current study, we investigate whether and how depression alters top-down and bottom-up information flow in the sensory (and motor) cortex. We implement effective connectivity analysis among the brain regions involved in intero- and exteroception as well as motor processing employing Dynamic Causal Modelling on resting state fMRI data from 62 individuals diagnosed with major depressive disorder (MDD) and 62 age and sex matched healthy controls. We find alteration in effective connectivity in MDD patients in areas involved in exteroception and motor processing (e.g., V1→FP1, MC→V1, VLPFC→SMA, SMA→V1) but not in areas involved in interoception. The implications of these findings for the pathophysiology of depression is discussed.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Control over sampling boosts numerical evidence processing in decisions from experience
Stefan Appelhoff
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ralph Hertwig, Max Planck Institute for Human Development; Bernhard Spitzer, Max Planck Institute for Human Development

Humans routinely sample information about alternatives before committing to a choice. However, the level of control over the sampling can differ: In some situations, the decision maker can decide what to sample (e.g., from which alternative) and/or how much (when to stop sampling), while in other settings, the provision of decision information is determined by external sources. Behavioral studies indicate that self-controlled sampling can modulate accuracy and recency biases in decisions from sequential numerical samples. However, the neurocognitive underpinnings of these behavioral effects are poorly understood.

Here, we recorded EEG while human participants accumulated numerical evidence about two choice alternatives (two-armed bandits). Before commiting to a choice, participants were free to decide from which alternatives to sample (partial control) or, additionally, when to stop sampling (full control). In matched baseline conditions, sample presentation was entirely pre-determined (no control; yoked conditions).

Behaviorally, we found heightened choice accuracy under full control, but not under partial control, compared to yoked baseline conditions. Unlike in previous work, recency biases were invariantly evident in all conditions under study. Turning to the EEG data, early visual responses (P1/N1) to the number samples did not differ between conditions. However, multivariate analyses revealed that the neural encoding of numerical information (cardinality, approx. 290-600 ms after sample onset), was enhanced under full control, mirroring the pattern in behavioral accuracy. Interestingly, this enhancement of numerical processing was not limited to late samples near the time of stopping, but was evident early on in the sample sequence. Consistently, we found a steeper ramping-up of late parietal signals throughout sequential evidence accumulation under full control.

Together, our findings indicate that control over sampling, and in particular over stopping, can enhance the encoding of numerical information in decisions from experience. The results replicate and extend previous findings of a neural numberline in multivariate EEG signals, and help understand the benefit of self-directed information search in human decision making.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Effects of Traumatic Brain Injury on the structure of BA4a and BA4p
Isabella Kaczmarczyk
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Nikhil Sharma, University College London, Francesco Grillo, University College London

Introduction: ALS is a universally fatal neurodegenerative disorder with no effective treatment. Recent reports (NEJM) suggest that subjects with traumatic brain injury (TBI) are 4 times more likely to develop ALS than non-TBI subjects. It is not clear why TBI should increase the incidence of ALS. The cortico-motoneurones - which originate in the posterior part of the motor cortex (BA4p) - have long been implicated in ALS. It is conceivable that TBI selectively damages BA4p that predisposes individuals to ALS. We hypothesised that subjects with TBI would have low grey matter density in the left BA4p compared to BA4a in TBI patients versus non-TBI.

Methods: We used the open ADNI-DOD data set (https://ida.loni.usc.edu/login.jsp?project=ADNIDOD). Vietnam War Veterans (mean age = 68.8, ADNI-DOD) with a history of war-related TBI (n=55) and those without TBI (n=34) were included in the study. We initially explored the parcellation of the motor cortex into BA4a and BA4p regions from Freesurfer (5.3.0). 

Results: Our preliminary results show the total BA4 thickness in the left hemisphere was smaller, but does not show a significant decrease in thickness (t = 0.731, p-value = 0.4667) in TBI versus nTBI. The cortical thickness in the LH BA4p seem to show more thinning however this was not statistically significant compared to the LH BA4a or to control regions, in the initial sMRI analysis (BA4p, t = 1.2546, p-value = 0.2136; BA4a, t = 1.2546, p-value = 0.9503)

Conclusions: We report that the structures of the subdivisions of BA4 are differentially affected by TBI, implicating that the BA4p structure may be more critical in the development of motor neurone disease. 
Results are preliminary-Future work will refine this further by examining the subdivision of the motor cortex using other imaging modalities suggest at fMRI & DTI. 
 Traditional talk
Watch now
A Multiscale Cortico-Basal Ganglia Model for Arm Reaching Task in Normal and Parkinsonian Conditions
Sandeep Sathyanandan Nair
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sandeep Sathyanandan Nair, Indian Institute of Technology Madras; Vignayanandam R. Muddapu, Indian Institute of Technology Madras; V. Srinivasa Chakravarthy,Indian Institute of Technology Madras

A major underlying cause of Parkinson's disease (PD) is the idiopathic loss of dopaminergic neurons in Substantia Nigra pars compacta (SNc). Dopamine deficiency due to the loss of SNc neurons manifests in cardinal symptoms of PD, including tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural imbalance. To investigate the PD condition in detail and manage its symptoms, it is important to have an integrated multiscale computational model that can replicate the symptoms at the behavioral level by evoking some of the underlying mechanisms that contribute to the pathology. In line with this, we developed a multiscale integrated model of cortico-basal ganglia motor circuitry for arm reaching task incorporating a detailed biophysical model of SNc dopaminergic neuron. Computational models of the basal ganglia tend to take a dichotomous approach, describing exclusively at a detailed biophysical level or at abstract information processing level using concepts from Reinforcement Learning (RL), without working out the relationship between the two levels. In our model, we replace the abstract representations of reward with the realistic variable of extracellular dopamine released by a network of SNc cells and incorporate it with the RL-based behavioral model, which simulates the reaching task. Our results showed that as SNc cell loss increases, the success rate in reaching the target decreased, while the average reaching time increased. In addition, the biophysical model of SNc allows us to explore an important hypothesis related to the cause of PD - the link between cellular energy deficiency and the death of dopaminergic cells. The RL-based behavioral component of the model gives us the flexibility to simulate the various PD symptoms e.g. tremor and bradykinesia. We conclude that our model presents a realistic and efficient way of simulating arm reaching task in normal and Parkinsonian conditions, thereby allowing us to understand how neurochemical dysfunction leads to behavioral abnormalities.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The effect of familiar size on size perception.
Jeroen Smeets
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Pauline Weijs, Eli Brenner

When interacting with the world around us, we use retinal size information to judge the distance of objects. It is known that this judgment is influenced by familiar size: a soccer ball looks farther away than a tennis ball if their images are equally large on the retina. On the other hand, when we lift a tennis ball and a soccer ball of the same weight, the soccer ball will not feel heavier, but lighter. So, familiarity has opposite effects on perceptual judgments of distance and weight. The effect of familiar properties on perception can thus be in two directions: assimilation or contrast. We here investigate how familiar size influences judgments about the size of images of objects that are presented on a computer screen. The images were about 5 cm in diameter, presented simultaneously 15 cm apart. Seventy participants had to indicate which of two objects appeared larger on the screen in a 2-alternative forced-choice discrimination task. The objects could be balls (tennis or soccer) or coins (10 eurocent or 2 euro). Participants also compared the images of the balls with a grey disk. The average precision of the size comparison was 3.5%, irrespective of the objects. We found that familiar size did indeed bias size perception: the size of the soccer ball was over-estimated by about 5% (assimilation). This overestimation varied considerably between participants. The bias in the comparison between the two balls was equal to the sum of the biases in the comparisons with the grey disk. The bias for the coins was smaller and in the opposite direction (contrast). We conclude that a depicted object’s familiar size can influence the perceived size of its image, but whether it is assimilation or contrast differs between experiments.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Systematic review and meta-analysis of the calibration of confidence judgments in individuals with schizophrenia
Martin Rouy
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Pauline Saliou, Université Grenoble Alpes, CNRS, LPNC UMR 5105, Grenoble, France; Ladislas Nalborczyk, GIPSA-lab, CNRS, Grenoble, France; Michael Pereira, Université Grenoble Alpes, CNRS, LPNC UMR 5105, Grenoble; Paul Roux, Université Versailles Saint-Quentin-En-Yvelines, Centre Hospitalier de Versailles; Nathan Faivre, Université Grenoble Alpes, CNRS, LPNC UMR 5105

Background: Metacognitive deficits are well-documented in schizophrenia as a decreased capacity to adjust confidence to first-order performance in a given cognitive task. However, because metacognitive ability directly depends on first-order performance, the observed metacognitive deficits may partly be driven by lower first-order performance. Thus, we hypothesized that studies controlling for first-order performance find smaller metacognitive deficits in schizophrenia.
Method: We conducted a meta-analysis of 43 studies comparing the calibration of confidence in 1458 individuals with schizophrenia compared to 1337 matched controls with a Bayesian model. Subgroup analyses and meta-regressions were performed to explore how metacognitive deficits depend on task performance, cognitive domains, clinical severity, and treatment dosage.
Results: We found a smaller metacognitive deficit in schizophrenia among studies equating first-order performance between groups. Plus, the metacognitive deficit in non-controlled studies was correlated with first-order performance. No correlations were found between metacognitive deficit and clinical features of schizophrenia.
Conclusion: We provided evidence that the metacognitive deficit in schizophrenia is inflated due to non-equated first-order performance. Thus, efforts should be made to develop experimental protocols accounting for lower first-order performance in schizophrenia.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
The time-course of prediction formation and revision in human visual motion processing
Tessel Blom
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Stefan Bode, University of Melbourne; Hinze Hogendoorn, University of Melbourne

Establishing the real-time position of a moving object poses a challenge to the visual system due to neural processing delays. While sensory information is travelling through the visual hierarchy, the object continues moving and information about its position becomes outdated. By extrapolating the position of a moving object along its trajectory, predictive mechanisms might effectively decrease the processing time associated with these objects.
Here, we use time-resolved decoding of electroencephalographic (EEG) data from an apparent motion paradigm to demonstrate the interaction of two separate predictive mechanisms. First, we reveal predictive latency advantages for position representations as soon as the second object in an apparent motion sequence – even before the stimulus contains any physical motion energy. This is consistent with the existence of omni-directional, within-layer waves of sub-threshold activity that bring neurons coding for adjacent positions closer to their firing threshold, thereby reducing the processing time of the second stimulus in one of those positions. Second, we show that an additional direction-specific latency advantage emerges from the third sequence position onward, once the direction of the apparent motion stimulus is uniquely determined. Because the receptive fields of early visual areas are too small to encompass sequential apparent motion positions (as evidenced by the lack of latency modulation for the second stimulus position), this latency advantage most likely arises from descending predictions from higher to lower visual areas through feedback connections. Finally, we reveal that the same predictive activation that facilitates the processing of the object in its expected position needs to be overcome when the object’s trajectory unexpectedly reverses, causing an additional latency disadvantage for stimuli that violate predictions. Altogether, our results suggest that two complementary mechanisms interact to form and revise predictions in visual motion processing, modulating the latencies of neural position representations at different levels of visual processing.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The Psychophysics of Non-neuronal Cognition
Bradly Alicea
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Bradly Alicea, OpenWorm Foundation; Jesse Parent; Richard Gordon; Akshara Gopi; Thomas Harbich

Non-neuronal cognition can be used to explain what appear to be neural behaviors in cellular-level systems. Examples include cellular decision-making (Perkins and Swain, 2009), information processing in regenerative processes (Baluska and Levin, 2016), and active perception among filopodia (Aspalter et.al, 2020). We characterize movement among colonies of the diatom genus Bacillaria as a collective pattern generator (CoPG). The CoPG is similar to a central pattern generator (CPG) found in insect nervous systems. Collective pattern generators are produced by the stretching motions produced by the actin filaments of two neighboring cells. These synchronized movements propagate down the colony in an undulating, accordion -like manner. While we can utilize a neural model to characterize the behavior of this type of multicellular colony, psychophysical models are used to characterize pseudo-neuronal behaviors.

We will use a database of images and movies of Bacillaria movement (Alicea et.al, 2019) to capture measurements of colony movement and to train a generative model of movement dynamics. Using these data and a model, we can then establish an input/output curve that determines how much input results in a corresponding degree of output. From these input/output curves, we can derive just-noticeable differences and signal detection measurements. To model the movements that lead to statistical regularities, we propose a connectionist model in which nodes (neuronal units) can act as neuronal oscillators. Collectively, these nodes form the components of a CoPG. Meanwhile, connectivity is determined by the relative degree of synchronization between neighboring cells.

References
Alicea, B., Gordon, R., Harbich, T., Singh, U., Singh, A., and Varma, V. (2019). Towards a Digital Diatom: image processing and deep learning analysis of Bacillaria paradoxa dynamic morphology. bioRxiv, doi:10.1101/2019.12.21.885897.

Aspalter, I.M. et.al (2020). Active Perception during Angiogenesis: filopodia speed up Notch selection of tip cells in silico and in vivo. bioRxiv, doi:10.1101/2020.08.22.261263.

Baluska, F. and Levin, M. (2016). On Having No Head: cognition throughout Biological Systems. Frontiers in Psychology, 7, 902.

Perkins, T.J. and Swain, P.S. (2009). Strategies for cellular decision-making. Molecular Systems Biology, 5, 326.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Selective impacts of sleep deprivation on brain and behavior
marco bigica (mr)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Chunxiang Jiang, Cardiff University Brain Research Imaging Centre, Cardiff University, Cardiff, UK and Paul C. Lauterbur Research Center for Biomedical Imaging, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shenzhen, China; Ilenia D'Onofrio, Cardiff University Brain Research Imaging Centre, Cardiff University, Cardiff, UK; Zhishan Liu, Cardiff University Brain Research Imaging Centre, Cardiff University, Cardiff, UK; Chen Song, Cardiff University Brain Research Imaging Centre, Cardiff University, Cardiff, UK and Department of Psychiatry, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, USA

Sleep is essential to brain functioning and lack of sleep greatly impairs behavior, yet the mechanisms underlying the detrimental effects of sleep deprivation remain largely unclear. Here we investigate how sleep deprivation influences the structure of neural connections and the function of neural communications that, in turn, lead to the behavioral impairments.

Using a combination of quantitative structural MRI, multi-compartment diffusion MRI, resting-state functional MRI, task functional MRI, behavioral testing and physiological monitoring, we traced the changes in brain structural indices (axon density, axon diameter, myelination), functional indices (signal propagation speed, signal-to-noise ratio, coding accuracy), behavioral indices (perception, decision making, introspection, attention, vigilance, action, emotion) and physiological indices (pupillary light reflex, resting heart rate, resting breathing pattern), across 36 hours of sleep deprivation and one night of recovery sleep, in 14 healthy young adults.

Analysis of behavioral data revealed that the time course of performance detriment is largely dissociable between behavioral domains. The detriment was first observed in vigilance and mood ratings, followed by perceptual decision making and introspection. By contrast, visual spatial attention and perception remain relatively unaffected by sleep deprivation. The heterogeneous changes in behavioral performances hint towards a stronger impact of sleep deprivation on prefrontal cortex than on parietal-occipital cortex, which we are currently testing via analysis of brain structural and functional data.
Interactive talk
Watch now
What is the nature of representation in the tool-selective areas in the parietal cortex? Effects of category, shape, and spatial frequency
Chenxi He
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Olivia S. Cheung, New York University Abu Dhabi

When we perceive an object (e.g., a hammer), much information about the object is processed (e.g., its shape, kind, or function). To what extent such information is processed in the category-selective regions? We have previously shown that tool-selective regions in the occipitotemporal cortex primarily contain categorical information about tools, compared with visual information (e.g., shape or spatial frequency, He et al., 2020). Here we examined the extent these information may be represented in other tool-selective regions, particularly in the parietal cortex. Using fMRI, tool-selective regions in left superior and inferior parietal lobules (SPL/IPL) were defined in a separate localizer with images of animals and tools with naturally variable image statistics. We then tested the nature of representations in these regions with images of animals and tools that were either round or elongated, and either in low or high spatial frequencies (LSF/HSF). Importantly, the images of the two categories shared comparable gist statistics, minimizing low- or mid-level visual differences across the two categories. Using representational similarity analysis (RSA), a model of tool category (tools were correlated with each other and not correlated with animals, and animals were not correlated with each other) and a model of HSF were most correlated with the neural patterns in SPL, whereas an interaction model of elongation and HSF was most correlated to the neural patterns in IPL. Functional connectivity analysis further suggested that the tool representation in SPL might be related to the stronger connectivity between tool-selective left medial fusiform gyrus and SPL, compared with IPL, and that the elongation representation in IPL might be related to the stronger connectivity between tool-selective left premotor region and IPL, compared with SPL. Together, these results revealed how different aspects of information are represented in various regions in the tool-selective network to support recognition and potential action planning.
Traditional talk
Watch now
DystoniaNet: A Deep Learning Platform to Diagnose Dystonia from Raw Structural MRI
Davide Valeriani
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kristina Simonyan

Dystonia is a neurological disorder of heterogeneous pathophysiology, which causes involuntary muscle contractions leading to abnormal movements and postures. As the third most common movement disorder after essential tremor and Parkinson’s disease, its diagnosis is remarkably challenging due to the absence of a biomarker or "gold standard" diagnostic test. This leads to a low agreement between clinicians, with up to 50% of cases being misdiagnosed and diagnostic delays extending up to 10.1 years. We developed a deep-learning algorithmic platform, DystoniaNet, to automatically identify and validate a microstructural neural network biomarker for dystonia diagnosis from raw structural brain MRIs of 612 subjects, including 392 patients with three different forms of isolated focal dystonia and 220 healthy controls. DystoniaNet was specifically designed to estimate its uncertainty and refer uncertain cases to further examination. Moreover, its streamlined architecture makes it more computationally efficient than other popular deep learning platform, such as AlexNet. In our dataset, DystoniaNet identified clusters in corpus callosum, anterior and posterior thalamic radiations, inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus, and inferior temporal and superior orbital gyri as the biomarker components. These regions are known to contribute to abnormal inter-hemispheric information transfer, sensorimotor processing, and executive control of motor commands in dystonia pathophysiology. DystoniaNet used this biomarker to achieve an overall accuracy of 98.8% in diagnosing dystonia, referring only 3.5% of cases to further examination. The diagnostic decision by DystoniaNet was computed in 0.36 s per subject. DystoniaNet significantly outperformed shallow machine-learning algorithms in benchmark comparisons, showing nearly a 20% increase in its diagnostic performance. The DystoniaNet platform showed substantial improvement over the current 34% agreement rate on dystonia diagnosis between clinicians. In summary, DystoniaNet leverages deep learning to deliver highly accurate, timely, interpretable, and generalizable dystonia diagnosis, hence contributing to enhance clinical decision-making of this disorder.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Reconsolidation of a threat memory in humans: A highly demanding working memory task interfere the re-stabilization and its biases processing towards threat.
Soledad Picco
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Fernandez Rodrigo, IFIBYNE -CONICET - UBA; Pedreira M. Eugenia, IFIBYNE - UBA - CONICET

Consolidated memories can be reactivated into a labile state by the presentation of a reminder. The reactivation of the memory trace is followed by a process of re-stabilization known as reconsolidation. In most of reconsolidation studies, a second task, with similar characteristics to those of the target memory, is used as an amnesic agent.
Anxiety manifest as a persistent and generalized defensive system, activated when predicted aversive events are perceived as a threat and uncertain. In laboratory, threat conditioning has been taken as the paradigm for assessing fear memories and anxiety related disorders. In the framework of the reconsolidation the idea that this process would allow to modify this type of maladaptive memories has been proposed.
Here we aim to interfere the re-stabilization of an implicit aversive memory in humans using a high demanding working memory task, which aimed to overload this transient memory system. To reach such goal, we designed a 3 day protocol, and compared a trained threat conditioning group, that 24hs later had or not a reminder, or a fake working memory task; 48hs after, all 3 groups performed an extinction follow by a reinstatement and several tasks targeting cognitive bias towards threat. We revealed that the memory reconsolidation interference is effective for the implicit memory retention but not for the declarative memory. Finally, we showed how the interference reduced biased processing towards threat.


Interactive talk
Watch now
Neural flexibility and the propensity to change opinions following online media consumption
Kristen Flaherty
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kristen Flaherty, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD, Northeastern University, Boston, MA; Italo’Ivo Pinto, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD; Aditi Periyannan, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD, Tufts University, Medford, MA; Amir Meghdadi, University of California, Santa Barbara, Santa Barbara, CA, Advanced Brain Monitoring, Carlsbad, CA; Christian Richard, Advanced Brain Monitoring, Carlsbad, CA; Chris Berka, Advanced Brain Monitoring, Carlsbad, CA; Kanika Bansal, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD, Department of Biomedical Engineering, Columbia University, New York, NY; Javier Garcia, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD

Digital persuasive media have a profound effect on decision-making. Recent communication neuroscience research shows a significant relationship between frontal brain regional activity and opinion change. Despite these findings, the neural dynamics that give rise to this relationship and the extent to which these effects extend beyond the laboratory are largely unexplored. Here, we utilize a network science approach -- dynamic community detection -- to extract brain network dynamics, and extend this method to data that mirrors neural activity of digital media consumers today. We investigate the dynamic coactivity of neural correlates of opinion change, as prompted by consumption of online persuasive media. Electroencephalographic (EEG) activity was collected from 240 healthy and diverse participants while interacting with biased content in a social media environment. Before and after interacting with the platform, participants were asked their opinions on vaccinations, capital punishment, corporate investment practices and politics. After calculating opinion change scores, we estimated the statistical relationship of the bandpassed EEG data (delta: 1-3Hz, theta: 4-7Hz, alpha: 8-12 Hz, beta: 13-25Hz, gamma: 30-40Hz) between electrodes with a weighted phase-lag index (wPLI). These connectivity matrices were then subjected to the dynamic community detection algorithm to extract network metrics that quantify the propensity of “nodes” (electrodes, here) to change their network affiliation across time. We show that network flexibility and promiscuity of frontal nodes, specifically within gamma and alpha bands, during engagement with persuasive digital content, are significantly associated with opinion change. These results indicate that coactivation of the frontal brain region with other network communities explains, in part, an individual’s likelihood to alter their position on a sensitive issue. Our results highlight the importance of neural coordination in our decision making process and provide support of the importance of frontal regions in shaping our opinions, not only in the laboratory, but also in a real-world scenario.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Citric Acid Water as an Alternative to Water Restriction for High-Yield Mouse Behavior
Inês Laranjeira
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Anne E Urai, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY, USA; Valeria Aguillon-Rodriguez, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY, USA; Inês C Laranjeira, Champalimaud Centre for the Unknown, Lisbon, Portugal; Fanny Cazettes, Champalimaud Centre for the Unknown, Lisbon, Portugal; The International Brain Laboratory; Zachary F Mainen, Champalimaud Centre for the Unknown, Lisbon, Portugal; Anne K Churchland, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY, USA.

Powerful neural measurement and perturbation tools have positioned mice as an ideal species for probing the neural circuit mechanisms of cognition. Crucial to this success is the ability to motivate animals to perform specific behaviors. One successful strategy is to restrict their water intake, rewarding them with water during a behavioral task. However, water restriction requires rigorous monitoring of animals’ health and hydration status, and can be challenging for some mice.
We present an alternative that allows mice more control over their water intake: free home-cage access to water, made slightly sour by a small amount of citric acid (CA). In a previous study, rats with free access to CA water readily performed a behavioral task for water rewards, although completing fewer trials than under water restriction (Reinagel, 2018). We here extend this approach to mice and confirm its robustness across multiple laboratories.
Mice reduced their intake of CA water while maintaining healthy weights. Continuous home-cage access to CA water only subtly impacted their willingness to perform a decision-making task, in which they were rewarded with sweetened water. When free CA water was used instead of water restriction only on weekends, learning and decision-making behavior were unaffected. CA water is thus a promising alternative to water restriction, allowing animals more control over their water intake without interfering with behavioral performance.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Computational investigation of optimal sub-goal settings under myopic planning horizons
Pranav Mahajan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Pranav Mahajan, BITS Pilani University - K. K. Birla Goa Campus

Humans have been known to break down their final goals into smaller sub-goals which involve planning upto a limited number of steps ahead in time. This is mainly driven due to inability to precisely plan much later into the future and thus a study of optimal sub-goal settings under myopic planning horizons is of interest to us. We computationally study the behaviour of three different myopic planning agents in the game of Tower of Hanoi, which has a long history of being used in neuropsychological studies. Our motivation for using the Tower of Hanoi puzzle for our simulations, is that it captures the conditional dependence in tasks and its effect in overall planning, which we observe very often in daily planning, for example, the progress in other tasks are dependent on partial completion of few tasks termed as “blockers”. The three myopic planning agents used in our study are as follows: (1) Agent A plans “h” steps ahead, and then chooses the plan for which the state after “h” steps is most similar to the final goal. (2) Agent B first sets the subgoal to move the largest misplaced disk to its target location and then plans “h” steps ahead to try to find a way to accomplish that subgoal. It then repeats its cycle of goal-setting, planning, and plan execution until all disks are in their target locations. (3) Agent C is identical to Agent B except that it sets its subgoal by resolving to move a randomly selected disk to its target location. We discuss the convergence of these agents on varying planning horizons “h” on two different final goals: (a) a tower in a random location, (b) another randomly chosen configuration. Our results show that Agent B outperforms other agents in both the final goals and is conjectured to achieve the final goal with a sufficiently long planning horizon h>2(n-1), where n is the number of disks. This directly translates to our understanding that taking the “blocker” task to completion, upon which other tasks are conditionally dependent, is an optimal goal setting in a myopic planning horizon. Currently, the agents assume complete knowledge of all the possible states after “h” steps via the discrete Sierpinski Gasket. In future works, we can decay this model predictive power with the planning horizon “h” and validating this work with data from a randomized controlled trial with human participants.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
The left temporoparietal junction causally supports goal emulation in observational learning
Lei Zhang (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Lei Zhang, University of Vienna; Farid I. Kandil, University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf; Claus C. Hilgetag, University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf; Jan Gläscher, University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf

Humans learn from their own trial-and-error experience and observing others by inferring their goals. Previous studies have established a comprehensive neurocomputational account of the integration between directly earning and observational learning. Crucially, these studies have identified that bilateral temporoparietal junction (TPJ) is functionally associated with goal emulation. However, the causal role of bilateral TPJ in such processes remains unclear. Here, employing continuous theta-burst stimulation (cTBS) over bilateral TPJ as well as vertex, we tested how the TPJ supports goal emulation in a probabilistic reversal learning task (N = 31). Participants on each trial were first required to choose between two stimuli, after they have seen the choices from four other co-players, they had the opportunity to adjust their choices. A probabilistic reward was then delivered given their second choice. Notably, participants were instructed that they would play this game with four “intelligent computers,” and choices from those computers were in fact generated from our computational algorithm model (reported elsewhere), such that they matched with actual human behavior. To increase ecological validity, we used human faces to indicate each computer. Behavioral results indicate that disrupting activity in the left TPJ resulted in reduced choice switch probability and longer response time when confronted with opposing social information, as opposed to the right TPJ and vertex conditions. In addition, choice accuracy was declined when participants actually switched their choices in the left TPJ condition. No significant difference was observed between trials across stimulation sites. Computational modeling with the hierarchical Bayesian approach suggests that the corresponding parameter quantifying social information significantly decreased in the left TPJ condition, as compared to the right TPJ and vertex conditions. Together, our results provide evidence for the causal role of left TPJ in supporting goal emulation in human observational learning.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Gender (im)balance in citation practices in cognitive neuroscience
Jacqueline Fulvio
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ileri Akinnola, University of Maryland - Baltimore County; Bradley Postle, University of Wisconsin-Madison

It has recently been reported that in five broad-scope neuroscience journals, citation rates for papers first- and/or last-authored by women are lower than would be expected if gender was not a factor in citation choices (Dworkin et al., 2020). Given the important implications that such underrepresentation may have on the careers of women researchers, it is important to determine whether this same trend is true in subdisciplines of the field, where interventions might be more targeted. Here, we report the results of an extension of the analyses carried out by Dworkin et al. (2020) to citation patterns in the Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience (JoCN). Specifically, we asked whether the degree to which the categorical authorship-gender balance of articles cited in JoCN from 2009-2020 reflected the gender balance of the journal’s authorship during that time frame. First, we determined that the gender balance of JoCN authorship was stable during the time frame considered, with women-led authorship (i.e., with a woman in the first and/or last author position (“W∪W”)) considerably more prevalent in JoCN compared to the five broad-scope neuroscience journals considered previously (59.2% W∪W at JoCN vs. 46.7% W∪W at the “Big 5”). Next, we determined that the reference sections of papers published in JoCN during this time span included W∪W papers at a level considerably lower than the 59.2% that would be expected if gender were not a factor in making citation choices. Furthermore, this pattern of citation imbalances is characteristic of the reference sections in all author-gender groups (i.e., “MM,” “MW,” “WM,” and “WW”), thereby implicating systemic factors. These results contribute to the growing body of evidence that intentional action is needed to address inequities in the way that we carry out and communicate our science.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Neural Data Analysis Pipelines for Extracting Information From C. elegans Microscopy Data
Amin Nejatbakhsh
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Erdem Varol, Columbia University; Eviatar Yemini, Columbia University; Vivek Venkatachalam, Northeastern University; Albert Lin, Harvard University; Aravi Samuel, Harvard University; Oliver Hobert, Columbia University; Liam Paninski, Columbia University

C. elegans is a well-known model organism that has been widely used in neuroscience research to address variety of question ranging from developmental genetics to circuit-level neural dynamics. However, a significant analysis bottleneck remains the processing and the normalizing of the signal observed in highly variable microscopy data across the population of animals. Moreover, online experimental design is a critical scientific paradigm which necessitates the development of automated and scalable tools for analyzing a stream of data.

Motivated by these applications and recent advances in the field of computer vision and statistics we have developed automated and semi-automated pipelines for extracting information from C. elegans microscopy videos. On Monday, I will be presenting a summary of our progress divided in the following categories:

0) probabilistic inference for constructing a statistical atlas.
1) point set registration for aligning the atlas to an image.
2) permutation inference for probabilistic neuron assignments.
3) optimal transport for probabilistic segmentation and tracking.
4) matrix factorization for demixing calcium signals from deforming videos.

Categorizing the analysis techniques as a pipeline of atlas building, registration, segmentation and signal extraction is general and can be applied to virtually every single animal model and emerging imaging modality.
Interactive talk
Watch now
The visual world in the dog brain
Raul Hernández (He/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Laura V. Cuaya; Eduardo Rojas; Eszter Farkas; Attila Andics

To create representations of the environment, the visual pathway processes stimulus features in increasingly complex stages, from low-level feature detection to high-level object recognition. In primates, the occipital lobe performs the first feature detection steps, while computations required for object recognition take place in the inferior-temporal cortex, a region characterized for having neurons selective towards particular stimulus categories. In dogs, there is conflicting evidence that nevertheless points towards an organization similar to the one found in primates. Our aim was to describe regions in the dog cortex that process visual stimuli similarly to certain primate brain regions, including both low-level feature detection and high-level category selectivity. We hypothesized similarity between the patterns of activity in the dog occipital cortex and a model of the primary visual cortex (V1 model), and between the patterns of activity in the dog temporo-occipital cortex and a model of semantic organization (Category model). We acquired functional magnetic resonance images while the participants (13 humans, 10 dogs) observed the videos of cars, cats, dogs, and humans. Using representational similarity analysis, we compared the activity patterns of different regions of the human and dog cortex with the two models (i.e. V1 model and Category model). We found a significant correlation between the V1 model and the patterns of activity of a bilateral cluster involving the left parahippocampal gyrus in dogs and a bilateral cluster involving the right intracalcarine cortex in humans. In turn, the Category model correlated with the patterns of activity of a cluster involving the left suprasylvian gyrus in dogs, and a bilateral cluster involving the lateral occipital complex in humans. The finding of comparable cluster locations in the cortex of the two species suggests a similar functional organization for visual object recognition in the human and the dog brain.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Vox2Vox: 3D-GAN for Brain Tumour Segmentation
Marco Domenico Cirillo
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
David Abramian, Department of Biomedical Engineering at Linköping University, Center for Medical Image Science and Visualization at Linköping University; Anders Eklund, Department of Biomedical Engineering at Linköping University, Center for Medical Image Science and Visualization at Linköping University

Gliomas are the most common primary brain malignancies, with different degrees of aggressiveness, variable prognosis and various heterogeneous histological sub-regions, i.e., peritumoral edema, necrotic core, enhancing and non-enhancing tumor core. The treatment depends on the location and size of the tumour(s). Although both these brain tumour types can easily be detected using multi-modal MRI, to extract them using image segmentation is a challenging task. To perform manual segmentation can take 20 - 60 minutes for a single subject, and automatic brain tumor segmentation can save a lot of time for neuro radiologists. Hence, using the data provided by the BraTS Challenge 2020, we propose a 3D volume-to-volume Generative Adversarial Network for segmentation of brain tumours. The model, called Vox2Vox, generates realistic segmentation outputs from multi-channel 3D MR images, detecting the whole, core and enhancing tumor with median values of 93.39\%, 92.50\%, and 87.16\% as dice scores and 2.44mm, 2.23mm, and 1.73mm for Hausdorff distance 95 percentile for the training dataset, and 91.75\%, 88.13\%, and 85.87\% and 3.0mm, 3.74mm, and 2.23mm for the validation dataset, after ensembling 10 Vox2Vox models obtained with a 10-fold cross-validation. We decided to report median metric values because in these way dataset outliers are not taken into consideration, showing in this way a properer model performance on these two datasets.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Can we strategically reallocate memory resources?
Yin-ting Lin
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Daryl Fougnie, New York University Abu Dhabi

We can selectively prioritize information during perception. In working memory, information can be similarly prioritized by a retro-cue. This is thought to occur due to reallocation of resources to prioritized items. Here we tested this by employing a working memory task with unequal item rewards to create uneven distribution of resources. Retro-cues then indicated which of three items could be dropped from memory. If reallocation occurs, then we should observe a larger benefit in memory when a high reward item versus a low reward item becomes irrelevant, since high reward items tie up more resources. We found that participants use both reward value and cue information to perform the task. There is better performance for items with higher reward values, F(2,90) = 10.85, p < .001, and for valid versus neutral cues, F(1,45) = 16.38, p < .001. However, our results show that removing a well-encoded item does not benefit performance more, t(45) = 0.05, p = .959 (JZS Bayes Factor = 6.245683). These findings challenge the dominant view that retro-cue benefits reflect reallocation of memory resources from removed items. Our results are more consistent with a benefit to cued items (such as retrieval protection or a general strengthening) that is independent of the memory strength of the de-prioritized item.

Interactive talk
Watch now
Conflict detection in a sequential decision task is associated with increased cortico-subthalamic coherence and prolonged subthalamic oscillatory response in the beta band
Zita Patai
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Zita Eva Patai, Tom Foltynie, Patricia Limousin, Harith Akram, Ludvic Zrinzo, Rafal Bogacz*, Vladimir Litvak*

Making accurate decisions often involves the integration of current and past evidence. Here we examine the neural correlates of conflict and evidence integration during sequential decision making. Patients implanted with deep-brain stimulation (DBS) electrodes and age-matched healthy controls performed an expanded judgement task, in which they were free to choose how many cues to sample. Behaviourally, we found that while patients sampled numerically more cues, they were less able to integrate evidence and showed suboptimal performance. Using recordings of Magnetoencephalography (MEG) and local field potentials (in patients) in subthalamic nucleus (STN), we found that beta oscillations signalled conflict between cues within a sequence. Following cues that differed from previous cues, beta power in the STN and cortex first decreased and then increased. Importantly, the conflict signal in the STN outlasted the cortical one, carrying over to the next cue in the sequence. Furthermore, premotor cortico-subthalamic beta coherence increased during the initial power decrease. These results extend our understanding of cortico-subcortical dynamics of conflict processing, and do so in a context where evidence must be accumulated in discrete steps, much like in real life, leading to a more nuanced picture of conflict monitoring systems in the brain and potential changes due to disease.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Non-corrupting decision-making feedback to area MT
Yuan Zhao
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Yuan Zhao, Department of Neurobiology and Behavior, Stony Brook University; Jacob L. Yates, Brain and Cognitive Science, University of Rochester; Aaron J. Levi, Center for Perceptual Systems, Departments of Neuroscience & Psychology,The University of Texas at Austin; Alexander C. Huk, Center for Perceptual Systems, Departments of Neuroscience & Psychology, The University of Texas at Austin; Il Memming Park, Department of Neurobiology and Behavior, Stony Brook University

In sensorimotor decision-making, internal representation of sensory stimuli is utilized for the generation of appropriate behavior for the context. For stimuli near perceptual threshold, the trial-by-trial activity of single neurons in many sensory areas is correlated with the animal's perceptual report. This correlation between variability in sensory neurons and perceptual decisions has often been attributed to feedforward readout of the neural activity by the downstream decision-making circuits. However the interpretation is quite ambiguous and the correlation could also originate via feedback from decision-making mechanisms downstream of the sensory representation. Its meaning can be better understood in the light of population-wide correlations among sensory neurons.
The middle temporal (MT) area contains both sensory and choice information and is known to be the key sensory area for visual motion perception. Using a statistical nonlinear dimensionality reduction technique on single-trial ensemble recordings during perceptual-decision-making, we extracted low-dimensional latent factors that captured the population-wide fluctuations and dissected the particular contributions of sensory-driven versus choice-correlated activity in the low-dimensional population code.
We found that the latent factors strongly encoded the direction of the stimulus in a single dimension with a temporal signature similar to that of single MT neurons. If the downstream circuit were optimally utilizing this information, choice-correlated signals should be aligned with this stimulus encoding dimension. Thus the decision-making process may be corrupting the sensory representation. Surprisingly, we found that the sensory stimuli and choice variables are separate at the population level contradicting the optimal readout view. This misaligned choice information allows the feedforward sensory information to coexist with the decision-making process. The time course of these signals suggest that this misaligned contribution likely is feedback from the downstream areas.
This new insight postulates how neural systems can maintain a mixed representation while allowing learning and adaptation.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Gaze Behavior changes following motor learning in a gait training task
Alex Cates
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Keith Gordon, Northwestern University

Vision plays a vital role in motor task execution and motor planning. During walking, where an individual looks and the distribution of their fixation locations provides insight into the preferred motor control strategies. Fixation distributions are well characterized in healthy adults and show consistent differences among individuals with gait deficits (who emphasize fixations involved in motor execution) and elite athletes (who emphasize fixations involved in motor planning). However, how individuals change their gaze distribution and the relationship to motor performance, is not understood. The present study examines how healthy young adults shift their gaze behavior during a locomotor learning task. Participants completed a treadmill-based sequence stepping task where they had to continuously step onto projected targets. The targets appeared in a repeating 6-step sequence of different step lengths which participants implicitly learned over multiple trial blocks. We hypothesized that participants would shift their gaze location forward (e.g. 2-3 steps ahead), emphasizing motor planning, as they learned the sequence. Our results did not support this hypothesis. With practice participants did learn the 6 step sequence and reduce their step error, however their gaze shifted closer to their feet, with participants spending more time fixating on the current target and immediate step path. This finding suggests that participants emphasized motor execution over motor planning while learning the task. Possible explanations for this result include a change in confidence, as awareness of their step errors may change step performance, or a change in information value, such that by learning the sequence, participants did not need visual information to plan their steps and could focus on optimizing stepping execution. Future studies should expand on these results with more complex stepping sequences, by artificially challenging participants’ confidence, and by disrupting visual informational value to see if gaze can be shifted in the opposite direction.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
A confirmation bias on how humans actively sample sensory information
Ankani Chattoraj
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ankani Chattoraj*, University of Rochester; Sabyasachi Shivkumar*, University of Rochester; Ra Yong Soo, University of Rochester; Katherine Moon, University of Rochester; Ralf Haefner, University of Rochester

We interpret visual scenes by making eye-movements to different locations to accumulate evidence. Recent work (Yang et al. 2016) showed that humans make goal driven eye-movements in a gaze contingent paradigm of a visual categorization task so as to maximize information about the correct category. Other studies investigating temporal integration of information in the absence of eye-movement have shown that humans are often biased to overweigh early evidence (“primacy effect”, Nienborg et al. 2009, Kiani et al 2008, Lange et al. 2020). We recently showed that a perceptual confirmation bias drives this effect and arises from approximate online inference in a hierarchical model in which expectations influence sensory inferences (Lange et al. 2020). In this study, we investigated whether similar biases exist due to biased eye-movements. Are saccades to peripheral stimuli biased by existing beliefs about the correct category?
To test this hypotheses, we designed two 2AFC experiments. In Experiment 1, the subject first fixated on a band passed gabor stimulus either oriented +45 degrees or -45 degrees while two or three stimuli (fixed per trial, random across trials) appeared in the periphery and the subject had to saccade to one of them. After three such saccades, the subject had to report the orientation in majority. In Experiment 2, a subject saw 18 black horizontal/vertical ellipses on a gray background and made eye-movements freely for 1.5 secs before choosing the orientation in majority.

In both experiments we found evidence that subjects are biased to saccade to targets that confirm their belief about the correct category. The pattern of subject responses can be explained by an approximate inference model of information maximization (extending Yang et al. 2016).
 Interactive talk
Watch now
A systematic review of stakeholder perspectives on cognitive effects of brain stimulation
Garrett Flynn
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Miranda Zhang, Flintridge Preparatory School, La Cañada Flintridge, CA, USA; Kevin Rao, La Salle High School, Pasadena, CA, USA; Eran Klein, Center for Neurotechnology and Department of Philosophy, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, Department of Neurology, Oregon Health and Science University, Portland, OR; Dong Song, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, USA;

Whether implemented in deep brain stimulation (DBS) devices, transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) systems, or bidirectional brain-machine interfaces (BMIs), targeted electrical stimulation of the brain is an emerging technology for the treatment of neurological and psychiatric conditions. Despite the promise of neurostimulation, there is an accumulating body of literature on side effects, mostly on motor, psychiatric or psychosocial effects. Cognitive side effects of neurostimulation have been relatively understudied and underreported by patients, caregivers, and healthcare providers (Mehanna, Bajwa, Fernandez, & Shukla, 2017). Several neuroethics scholars have advocated for complementing clinical measures with qualitative methods that characterize complex, context-specific changes in language, memory, and other cognitive processes following brain stimulation (Shook, Galvagni, & Giordano, 2014). Additionally, there is increasing scientific and medical interest in the use of brain stimulation techniques to treat disorders of cognition, such as dementia (Hampson et al., 2018). Reviews of brain-computer interface (BCI) studies using social research methods have proven useful to guide future qualitative research (Kögel, Jox, & Friedrich, 2020; Kögel, Schmid, Jox, & Friedrich, 2019). However, qualitative brain stimulation studies where neural activity is directly modulated to affect cognition have not been the focus of these reviews.
We conducted a systematic review of literature on stakeholder perspectives on cognitive effects of neurostimulation. A PubMed database search of qualitative studies on brain stimulation yielded 34 unique datasets from 41 publications that include quoted responses to open-ended interview or survey questions. Of these 34 datasets, 14 (41%) had at least one associated publication addressing actual or expected cognitive effects. Patient-reported cognitive effects were logged in 7 (50%) of the 14 datasets, yet only one (14%) of these seven datasets indicated that patients were asked about cognitive effects. On the other hand, 5 (36%) of the 14 datasets logged provider-reported cognitive effects and four (80%) out of these 5 datasets asked providers about expectations or views of cognitive enhancement. Similarly, quoted providers mention that brain stimulation worsens, restores, and enhances cognition with equal frequency while patients describe that brain stimulation actually worsens cognition slightly more than it restores. Our findings suggest that previous qualitative studies on brain stimulation lack focused attention to cognitive changes—specifically patient-reported cognitive impairment. As such, future studies of neurostimulation should aim to more consistently and rigorously evaluate cognitive effects. Researchers and clinicians involved in existing studies may also benefit from development of qualitative tools that assess cognitive effects on device users.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Multi-animal pose estimation with DeepLabCut
Jessy Lauer (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Alexander Mathis, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology; Mackenzie Mathis, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology

Many experiments in biology require measuring interactions between multiple individuals. Nonetheless, whereas deep learning powered pose estimation recently showed remarkable performance on single animal, the solution to the multi-animal problem is far from trivial. Detected body parts must first be connected and associated with animals, which is a costly combinatorial task. Animals’ motion must then be tracked frame by frame, and the resulting trajectories stitched together to ensure dynamic feasibility and disambiguate overlaps and identity switches. Here we introduce DeepLabCut 2.2, a framework built onto the open-source pose estimation toolbox DeepLabCut to address the multi-animal scenario. We discuss our implementation of bottom-up animal assembly and robust motion trackers, as well as our novel solution to tracklet stitching and identity prediction directly from an image. We will demonstrate its utility on a collection of behaviors (from fish to mice). Taken together, DeepLabCut 2.2 thus provides users with an efficient solution to the multi-animal problem that is seamlessly integrated into the existing workflow and user interface, and requires just as little (if any) programming experience.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Representation of Spatial Frequencies in Neural Populations of Human Temporal Cortex
Hojjat Azimi Asrari
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Mohammad Rabiei Ghahfarokhi, School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran; Niloufar Shahdoust, School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran; Farideh Shakerian, Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, Cell Science Research Center, Royan Institute for Stem Cell Biology and Technology, ACECR, Tehran, Iran, Department of Physiology, Faculty of Medical Sciences, Tarbiat Modares University, Tehran, Iran; Mohammad-Reza A. Dehaqani, School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran, School of Cognitive Sciences, Institute for Research in Fundamental Sciences, Tehran, Iran

Multiple brain areas in temporal lobe, associated with human vision, represent the visual stimuli and regulate object recognition. Moreover, EEG and fMRI studies suggest that brain visual representation of low versus high spatial frequency is significantly noticeable. Recently, SEEGs (stereo-electro-encephalography electrodes), a technique used for invasive recording of brain activity via three dimensional recordings, have been standing out for its clinical applications in seizure surgeries. The high quality of recoding in SEEGs data gives the opportunity to combine Long Time Monitoring (LTM) with controlled stimulus presentation and investigate the neural representation of objects in human brain. Although, massive body of non-invasive imaging studies have been addressed the neural representation of objects in human brain, the neural representation of spatial filtered objects in human brain using intra-cortical recording is poorly understood.
During LTM, a pharmacologically intractable epileptic patient with implanted SEEGs participated in a face and non-face detection visual task. Electrodes were implanted in the right hippocampus, right and left supplementary motor area, right pre-supplementary motor area, and right anterior cingulate gyrus to evaluate an anatomo-electro-clinical correlate in the generation and propagation of seizures. The stimulus set is comprised of 155 grayscale images including 73 animates (face and non-face) and 82 inanimates at different level of frequencies to probe the selectivity of neural population across the five areas of the brain implanted by electrodes.
Our results support the existence of distinct neural representation of different spatial frequencies for face and non-face stimuli within temporal lobe of human brain. Furthermore, the interaction of category representation and spatial frequencies suggests a major role of spatial dynamics in face and object processing across ventral visual stream at human brain.
Our findings provide insight into the fine-grained functional architecture within the human brain pertaining to spatial dynamics in face and object processing.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
A deep generative modelling approach to detect epileptogenic lesions
Bastian David (He/Him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Leonie Henschel, German Center for Neurodegenerative Diseases (DZNE); Sailesh Conjeti, German Center for Neurodegenerative Diseases (DZNE); Fabiane Schuch, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn; Bernd Weber, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn; Elke Hatingen, Department of Neuroradiology, Goethe University Frankfurt; Christian Elger, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn; Martin Reuter, German Center for Neurodegenerative Diseases (DZNE), Martinos Center for Biomedical Imaging, Radiology, MGH / Harvard Medical School; Rainer Surges, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn; Theodor Rüber, Department of Epileptology, University Hospital Bonn, Epilepsy Center Frankfurt Rhine-Main, Department of Neurology, Goethe University Frankfurt, Center for Personalized Translational Epilepsy Research (CePTER), Goethe- University Frankfurt

Purpose: Focal cortical dysplasias (FCDs) may be easily overlooked in conventional visual assessment of MRI. Automated approaches have been proven useful for the detection of FCDs and their use may enhance the postoperative outcome. However, as even most elaborate approaches do not yield satisfactory sensitivity, the development of novel approaches is warranted on clinical grounds. MRI features of FCD type IIb include cortical T2-signal hyperintensities but have sparse correlates in T1-weighted MR-volumes. We here describe an approach leveraging on this apparent difference in MR-modalities and the power of conditional generative adversarial networks (cGAN) in modality synthesis, by creating a difference image between the real FLAIR and a T1-based synthetic FLAIR mimicking healthy brain structures. We show that the integration of this information in a convolutional neural network (CNN) supports the automatized detection of FCDs.

Methods: We retrospectively collected and manually labelled T1w and FLAIR images of 42 patients (18 females; age=38.8±11.4 y) with an FCD type IIb. T1w images served as input for our cGAN, pre-trained on 80 datasets of healthy controls (37 females; age=44.8±10.6 y), to synthesize artificial FLAIR images. Real and synthetic FLAIR images were in turn subtracted. T1w, FLAIR and the difference images were passed to a multi-scale 3D CNN. Specificity was assessed on a separate cohort of 56 mesial temporal lobe epilepsy patients (35 females; age=39.2±11.5).

Results: The cGAN showed robust generation of synthetic FLAIR images on non-lesional brains (SSIM±σ = 0.92±0.04). Employing a five-fold cross-validation scheme, our CNN-classifier reached a sensitivity of 92.9% (39/42 FCDs detected), while maintaining a high specificity of 96.4% (54/56 true negatives).

Conclusion: Our combined deep learning approach using a cGAN for modality synthesis followed by a CNN outperforms current state-of-the-art methods. Moreover, it is conceivable that our approach may generalize to any other pathology imaged with complementary imaging modalities.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Enhanced or impoverished recruitment of top-down attentional control of inhibition in test anxiety
Hua Wei
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Hua Wei,Southeast University; Renlai Zhou,Southeast University

Existing evidence shows that test anxiety impairs individuals’ inhibition. However, controversy exits as to whether a high test anxiety (HTA) individual, when completing an experimental task, increases or decreases top-down attentional control resources to maintain (high) task performance. To fill the gap, the present study examined whether a HTA individual will increase or decrease recruitment of top-down attentional control resources to complete inhibition task. In this flanker task experiment, individuals were confronted with a threat or no threat context in combination with a low or a high working memory load. Electroencephalography (EEG) data were collected and the Event Related Potential (ERP) N2 measured top-down attentional control resource allocation. The EEG results showed three crucial significant differences: in comparison to low test anxiety (LTA) individuals: (1) in a no threat and low working memory load condition, HTA individuals had larger incongruent N2 amplitudes; (2) in a no threat and high working memory load condition, HTA individuals had larger incongruent and congruent N2 amplitudes; and (3) in a threat and high working memory load condition, HTA individuals had smaller incongruent N2 amplitudes. This significance pattern: (1) clarifies the neural mechanism underlying the frontal lobe’s involvement in the processing of an inhibition task; (2) supports the idea that, in order to maintain (high) task performance, HTA individuals tend to engage in enhanced recruitment of top-down attentional control of inhibition; but also shows that (3) in case of a threat coinciding with a high working memory load, HTA individuals fail to employ this compensatory strategy as they display impoverished top-down attentional control of inhibition.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Neural processes underlying contextual influences on decisions
Aditi Periyannan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Italo’Ivo Pinto, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD; Kristen Flaherty, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD, Northeastern University, Boston, MA; Amir Meghdadi, University of California, Santa Barbara, Santa Barbara, CA, Advanced Brain Monitoring, Carlsbad, CA; Christian Richard, Advanced Brain Monitoring, Carlsbad, CA; Chris Berka, Advanced Brain Monitoring, Carlsbad, CA; Kanika Bansal, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD, Department of Biomedical Engineering, Columbia University, New York, NY; Javier Garcia, US CCDC Army Research Laboratory, Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD

Our everyday social interactions affect not only our own decision making process and actions, but also the spread and evolution of information. As social interactions become increasingly online through social media, information consumed through this medium shapes how we think. We examined the neural underpinnings guiding the impact of information and context (e.g., social vs cyber) on decision making, where information credibility varies greatly. In this study, 240 healthy participants answered a questionnaire surrounding a variety of current issues (e.g., vaccinations, capital punishment, etc.) at three points in the study: (1) before interacting with a simulated social media environment that presented news articles including real and fake information, (2) following the social media platform interaction, and (3) after talking to other participants in a group. Electroencephalography (EEG) was measured during interactions with the social media platform.
