Participants were then scored based on how much they changed their opinion and categorized as “cyber influenced”, “socially influenced”, both, or neither, in order to evaluate the hypothesis that variability in opinions is linked to variability in neural behavior. Neural variability was analyzed using two methods: (1) traditional power analysis and (2) connectivity strength using a network approach that measures statistical relationships among nodes (EEG electrodes). Results show the respective neural pathways of information processing via digital interaction and in-person social interaction were not statistically different, suggesting that similar neural processes may serve both types of decisions to change their opinion, regardless of context. We further investigated this finding using more sensitive approaches to aggregate network changes, differentiating individuals that are more susceptible to information presented through a social media platform. Our results suggest different scales of neural processing underlying decision making are at play when individuals are presented with a variety of reliable and unreliable information in different contexts.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Standardized and reproducible measurement of decision-making in mice
Guido Meijer
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
The International Brain Laboratory; Valeria Aguillon-Rodriguez; Dora E. Angelaki; Hannah M. Bayer; Niccolò Bonacchi; Matteo Carandini; Fanny Cazettes; Gaelle A. Chapuis; Anne K. Churchland; Yang Dan; Eric E. J. Dewitt; Mayo Faulkner; Hamish Forrest; Laura M. Haetzel; Michael Hausser; Sonja B. Hofer; Fei Hu; Anup Khanal; Christopher S. Krasniak; Inês Laranjeira; Zachary F. Mainen; Guido T. Meijer; Nathaniel J. Miska; Thomas D. Mrsic-Flogel; Masayoshi Murakami; Jean-Paul Noel; Alejandro Pan-Vazquez; Cyrille Rossant; Joshua I. Sanders; Karolina Z. Socha; Rebecca Terry; Anne E. Urai; Hernando M. Vergara; Miles J. Wells; Christian J. Wilson; Ilana B. Witten; Lauren E. Wool; Anthony Zador

Progress in science requires standardized assays whose results can be readily shared, compared, and reproduced across laboratories. Reproducibility, however, has been a concern in neuroscience, particularly for measurements of mouse behavior. We show that a standardized task to probe decision-making in mice produces reproducible results across multiple laboratories. We designed a task for head-fixed mice that combines established assays of perceptual and value-based decision making, and we standardized training protocol and experimental hardware, software, and procedures. We trained 140 mice across seven laboratories in three countries, and we collected 5 million mouse choices into a publicly available database. Learning speed was variable across mice and laboratories, but once training was complete there were no significant differences in behavior across laboratories. Mice in different laboratories adopted similar reliance on visual stimuli, on past successes and failures, and on estimates of stimulus prior probability to guide their choices. These results reveal that a complex mouse behavior can be successfully reproduced across multiple laboratories. They establish a standard for reproducible rodent behavior, and provide an unprecedented dataset and open-access tools to study decision-making in mice. More generally, they indicate a path towards achieving reproducibility in neuroscience through collaborative open-science approaches.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
The spatial extent of the tilt aftereffect
Busra Tugce Gurbuz
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Huseyin Boyaci, Bilkent University, National Magnetic Resonance Research Center (UMRAM)

The tilt aftereffect (TAE) is observed when the perceived tilt of oriented contour changes due to adaptation to another orientated contour. So far, the TAE has generally assumed as a local aftereffect observed only at the adapted location. Here, we challenged this main assumption and investigated how the TAE spreads across different spatial locations.
Using a peripheral adapter, we measured the TAE magnitude at 15 peripheral locations while participants were fixating on a central fixation point. Adapter grating was always presented at the same spatial location with 10.5° eccentricity to the central fixation point. In contrast, test gratings were presented randomly at 15 test locations within the same visual hemifield, including the adapter location, and two 1-up-1-down staircases determined their orientations. Participants indicated the test gratings' perceived tilt by pressing the right or left arrow key on a keyboard. The control condition was identical to the experimental condition except for adaptation. The subjective verticality (SV) of the test grating was determined by fitting a logistic regression function to the data. The TAE magnitude was calculated by subtracting the control condition's SV from the experimental condition's SV.
We found that the TAE is a non-local aftereffect that spreads across the whole visual hemifield (N=19, p<0.05) except one location (down-row, 2.5° eccentricity, p=0.472). To explain the computational mechanisms underlying this spread, we simulated a population of orientation-tuned neurons with different receptive fields (RFs). Based on the gain-reduction model of adaptation, we hypothesized that adaptation would decrease tuning-curves' and RFs’ sensitivity and trained our model with human data to explore how this reduction happens. Our trained-model could predict human data with 70% accuracy and provide supporting evidence for the gain-reduction model.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Face processing in ecologically valid scenes: Characterizing fixation related ERPs under free-viewing conditions
Anna Lisa Gert
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Benedikt V. Ehinger, Stuttgart University; Silja Timm, Osnabrück University; Peter König*, Osnabrück University; Tim C. Kietzmann, Donders Institute for Brain, Cognition and Behaviour

Classically, the physiological mechanisms of face perception are studied under restricted, lab-based conditions. Specifically, visual stimuli are passively presented, no eye movements are allowed, and the timing is under the control of the experimenter, not the participant. While this approach yields high experimental control over factors influencing the signal of interest, it lacks natural validity. Here, we investigate whether we can replicate the N170, a face-sensitive ERP observed in classic experiments, in a free-viewing paradigm using natural scenes.
First, we use a passive control-condition to replicate the classical N170 findings. The same participants then view images taken from a head-camera in a local shopping center under free-viewing conditions. We model our data using the unfold toolbox, which also corrects for overlap effects and co-varying non-linear dependencies on different eye movement parameters. Additionally, we extend the analysis beyond classically electrode sites and time windows by employing TFCE.
In the classic setup, we replicate the face-object N170 contrast. In the free-viewing condition, we find a similar effect, but additionally, the amplitude of the P100 is also increased when a face is fixated. Underlining the usefulness of the more natural free-viewing approach the N170 face-effect correlates between the passive and active condition (r=0.78), and the variability within the subjects is decreased under free-viewing conditions. Interestingly, when looking at fERPs assigned by the category of the previous fixation, we find more positive fERPs for fixations originating from a face, even before fixation onset. This indicates an adaptation effect when moving from one to the next fixation. This effect becomes even stronger for two consecutive fixations within a face.

In summary, we demonstrate the feasibility of an ecologically valid study of face processing, uncovering neural aspects previously remaining unnoticed.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Erasing Fear: Challenges for Decoded Neurofeedback
Jorge Morales
 
Abstract
 
Neural interventions in humans are either anatomically specific but invasive (e.g. ablations of cortical tissue), or non-invasive but with anatomical limited resolution (e.g. TMS). Most of these interventions are functionally non-specific. Decoded Neurofeedback (DecNef) is different: by leveraging fMRI and machine learning, DecNef creates non-invasive, functionally targeted interventions of neural activity. Aided by external reward, subjects unconsciously self-regulate targeted multi-variate patterns of their own BOLD-activity. Subjects self-activate patterns of neural activity indistinguishable from patterns corresponding to seeing images of some target stimulus type (e.g. spiders). Through trial and error and a sophisticated online readout of their neural activity paired with a reward system, subjects learn to create “spider” activity patterns in the absence of spiders. The clinical applications are promising. A popular treatment of phobias and post-traumatic stress disorder is exposure therapy, but it takes an enormous toll on patients who have to endure being exposed to their source of fear and trauma. With DecNef, because patients are unaware of the target, they can be *unconsciously* “exposed” to patterns of neural activity similar to those of their feared target effectively reducing their phobic symptoms without undergoing the emotional labor. Despite its promise for cognitive neuroscience and for the clinic, DecNef’s mechanisms of action remain poorly understood. This raises theoretical questions about our understanding of neural representations and neural intervention that I’ll discuss in this talk:

(1) What is the status of the neural representations targeted by DecNef?

(2) What kind of voxel-to-neural activity mapping can allow its impressive yet mysterious functional-specificity?

(3) Because of its underdetermined and potentially long-lasting effects (up to two months), can harmful or undesirable patterns of activity be activated unbeknownst to subjects. Could new phobias be instilled, precious memories altered or erased, undesired associations created?
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Zebrafish exhibit visual attentional pop-out effects in their behavior
Sarah Stednitz, she/her/hers
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sarah Stednitz, MPI Biological Cybernetics; Jennifer Li, MPI Biological Cybernetics; Drew Robson, MPI Biological Cybernetics; Zhaoping Li, MPI Biological Cybernetics

Sensory inputs drive our interactions with the world, but the raw sensory inputs contain far more data than could be fully processed by our brain, which is constrained by limited resources. To overcome this processing bottleneck, the brain has evolved attentional selectional mechanisms to select only a fraction of the sensory inputs for deeper processing, and for survival this selection is often rapid and exogenously driven (“bottom-up”) so that it does not require any higher-order (“top-down”) cognitive guidance. Such attentional selection for visual inputs has been studied extensively in mammals, particularly in humans. To study the underlying neural mechanism for bottom-up visual selection, the zebrafish (Danio rerio) is perhaps an ideal model system. They rely on visual input for many behaviors early in development, possess evolutionarily conserved brain regions including a large optic tectum associated with attentional selection, and are amenable to live imaging using genetically encoded fluorescent indicators of neuronal activity. However, bottom-up visual attentional selection behavior has not yet been well characterized in zebrafish. A hallmark of the bottom-up visual selection is pop-out, when a uniquely featured visual item in a background of uniformly featured items, e.g., a red dot among green dots, elicits a rapid orienting behavior. Such orienting can be by gaze shifts (often in humans), and/or by turning of head, limb, tentacles, and body. We first demonstrate the pop-out effect in zebrafish using colored dot stimuli, and measure the orienting responses by shifts in the animal’s body orientation. We characterize the orientation response in relation to the sensory inputs, in particular the colors and spatial configurations of the dots. Our findings suggest conserved mechanisms of visual attention across evolution, and lay the groundwork for imaging studies to describe the underlying neuronal computations.

Black In Neuro Mentorship Workshops: Getting the most out of your mentor-mentee relationship (Trainee workshop)
 
Abstract
 
Note: zoom links for this event will not be posted until shortly before the session. Please refresh the website right before the meeting for the current link.

In this interactive workshop, we will examine the concept of “mentoring up”. Through discussion and case study analysis we will outline effective strategies trainees can use to strategically find and maintain strong mentoring relationships and build communication skills as a means to enhance self-advocacy in your research training and beyond.

Leaders:
- Paige Cooper, PhD

- Johnna Frierson, PhD

 Traditional talk
Watch now
Neural dynamics underlying the coding of location and running speed in the medial entorhinal cortex
Holger Dannenberg
 
Abstract
 
Memory-guided navigation and path integration require accurate coding of location and running speed. In mammals, path integration relies on memory circuits in the medial entorhinal cortex (MEC), where grid cells are proposed to provide a metric for space. The linear and positive modulation of firing rates observed in MEC speed cells has been proposed to provide a running speed signal for updating grid cell firing and supporting path integration.
In the first part of my talk, I will demonstrate that rate coding of running speed by speed cells in the MEC differs across time scales and works best at seconds-long time scales. I will further present data that such a slow and linear rate code is insufficient for accurate real-time coding of running speed as required by current computational models of grid cell firing and path integration.
Spatially periodic grid cell firing in the MEC relies on inputs from the medial septum. The second part of my talk will examine the role of medial septum inputs for theta oscillatory activity and speed cell firing in the MEC.
The last part of my talk will examine the time course of changes in spatiotemporal accuracy of grid cell firing after transitions between light and dark conditions. Data will show that slow changes in grid cell stability on a time scale of tens of seconds are accompanied by slow changes in the local field potential theta frequency vs. running speed relationship, a proposed oscillatory speed signal. Furthermore, darkness results in large changes in the firing rates of many neurons including speed cells that explain the observed changes in the slopes of speed tuning curves. In summary, data suggest that the representation of space by grid cells in the MEC may be a function of velocity signals integrated over past time.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Representing Fly Behavior with Recurrent Neural Networks
Ishan Saran
 
Abstract
 
Behavior is a complex process that operates across many time and length
scales, in many different contexts, and differentially to a variety of external
and internal stimuli. The necessity to quantify behavior in a precise and
meaningful manner, however, is growing as the advent of new technologies -
optogenetics, connectomics, optical imaging techniques - in the world of
neuroscience has led to an explosion of assembling and analyzing large swaths
of neural data. Here we investigate recurrent neural networks (RNNs) as a
model of the underlying dynamics of Drosophila melanogaster and find the
behavioral representation it constructs similar to representations built from the
previously published results of postural time series. This is a markedly different
result from that of RNNs applied to rat models and we investigate the
implications.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Sleep does not facilitate human fear memory consolidation
Yuri Pavlov
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Yuri G. Pavlov, University of Tuebingen; Boris Kotchoubey, Univesity of Tuebingen

Introduction
The positive effects of sleep on the consolidation of declarative memories are generally well known. The role of sleep in consolidation of fear memories has not received as much attention. Moreover, only a few studies in humans have used physiological indices of conditioning, and none used central physiological measures. In the current study we investigated how sleep affects (1) consolidation of fear memories on behavioral level and (2) central measures of fear conditioned response by means of EEG.
Methods
In our experiment event-related brain potentials (ERP) were recorded during a fear conditioning procedure presented twice, before and after sleep or control intervention in 18 healthy young individuals. The procedure involved pairing of a neutral tone (CS+) with a highly unpleasant sound (UCS+). As a control, another neutral tone (CS-) was paired with a neutral (for some subjects slightly pleasant) sound (UCS-). The two sessions of conditioning were separated by approximately 2.5 hours when: on one experimental day subjects watched a silent movie for 2h (wake intervention); on another day the participants had 2h sleep opportunity (sleep intervention). The two days were separated by at least two weeks and counterbalanced in respect to the stimulus mapping.
Results
In EEG differential conditioning manifested itself in the contingent negative variance (CNV)-like slow ERP component. Both period of sleep and wakefulness resulted in increased amplitude of the CNV to CS+ (main effect of contingency F(1,17) = 17.6, p < 0.001) without a significant difference between the type of intervention. The same effect was obtained on the behavioral level, with Valence ratings of CS+ were more negative as compared to CS- (F(1,17) = 14.9, p < 0.001). The intervention (sleep/wake) followed by a block of extinction learning. Relearning of fear after the extinction elicited stronger differential response in CNV (main effect of Time (before-after comparison) F(1,17) = 6.5, p = .02) but not in the behavioral ratings (F(1,17) = 0.66, p = .426).
Conclusions
The data indicate that fear memories are consolidated with the course of time with no beneficial effect of sleep or a period of wakefulness.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Social gradients: Cross-sectional and longitudinal evidence of differential functional embedding and plasticity of the social brain
Sofie Valk
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Philipp Kanske, TU Dresden, Germany; Bo-yong Park, MNI, Canada; Seok-Jun Hong, Sungkyunkwan University, South Korea; Anne Böckler-Raettig, University of Hannover, Germany; Fynn-Mathis Trautwein, University of Freiburg, Germany; Boris C. Bernhardt*, MNI, Canada; Tania Singer*, Social neuroscience lab, Germany

Social interaction is key to human survival and has been proposed to be linked to the organization of the cerebral cortex. In a sample of healthy adults (N=332) we determined that task-based networks implicated in attention, empathy, and ToM-processing are topologically ordered along a social gradient from internal to external cognitive functions and have differentiable behavioral, functional, and genetic associations. We found domain-specific change in functional topology following a mental training intervention addressing attention and interoception, socio-affective skills, and socio-cognitive skills respectively. Attention-based practice resulted in segregation of cortical association networks, whereas socio-cognitive training resulted in their integration, reflecting a dissociation between cognitive quiescence and active thought. Socio-affective training had balancing effects on functional network organization, related to the regulating function of emotion. Together, our results show that social interaction involves a modifiable balance of network integration and segregation embedded along a social gradient from external to internal cognitive functions.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Mental compression of spatial sequences in human working memory using numerical and geometrical primitives
Fosca Al Roumi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sébastien Marti, Liping Wang, Marie Amalric, Stanislas Dehaene

How does the human brain store sequences of spatial locations? The standard view is that each consecutive item occupies a distinct slot in working memory. Instead, we formulate and test the alternative hypothesis that the human brain compresses the whole sequence using an abstract, language-like code that captures the numerical and geometrical regularities of the sequence at multiple nested levels. We exposed participants to spatial sequences of fixed length but variable regularity, and asked them to remember the sequence in order to detect deviants, while their brain activity was recorded using magneto-encephalography. Using multivariate decoders, each successive location could be decoded from brain signals, and upcoming locations could be decoded prior to their actual onset. Crucially, sequences with lower complexity, defined as the minimal description length provided by the formal language, and whose memory representation was therefore predicted to be more compressed, led to lower error rates and to increased anticipations. Furthermore, neural codes specific to the numerical and geometrical primitives of the postulated language could be detected, both in isolation and within the sequences. These results suggest that the human brain detects sequence regularities at multiple nested levels and uses them to compress long sequences in working memory.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The time course of decision-making: contribution of the electrophysiological version of the monetary incentive delay (e-MID) task
Inês Macedo
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Carina Fernandes; Helena Garcez; Ana R. Gonçalves; Fernando Barbosa; João Marques-Teixeira

The Monetary Incentive Delay (MID) task is a popular tool for studying the different stages of economic decision-making. During this task, participants are presented with a cue that signals possible gains/losses. This cue is followed by target detection, which requires a button press to win/avoid losses. Then, feedback reveals the success/failure of the performance. The MID task has been extensively used to investigate neural activity associated with different stages of decision-making. Specifically, the cues elicit affective processes of gain/loss anticipation (anticipation processes), which induce positive/negative arousal, and motivate approach/avoidance behaviors. The output of this process is integrated (integration processes) with further evaluative considerations, feeding in motivation processes that promote subsequent motor actions and decisions. Also, the delivery of the results elicits neural activity associated with the processing of gains and losses. This study exploits the temporal resolution of EEG to identify the neural correlates associated with these processes. To this purpose, 28 healthy younger adults performed a version of the MID task adapted to an ERP technique. The anticipation processes were analyzed through the cue-P3, which is correlated with the engagement of proactive cognitive control that increases in function of the reinforcement amount. The integration processes were analyzed through the Contingent Negative Variation (CNV) elicited by the cue, which is associated with the engagement of effortful processes to future motor responses. The motivation processes beyond motor choice were analyzed through the Lateralized Readiness Potential (LRP) and the target-P3. The LRP reflects the voluntary motor response after the decision threshold, while the target-P3 is elicited by the target and is modulated by the task-relevance and motivated attention. Finally, the feedback processes were analyzed through the frontocentral feedback-related negativity (FRN) and the feedback-P3. These ERPs were elicited by gain, loss and neutral gamble, and were compared in a within-subjects design.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Temporally precise cholinergic signaling in the basal forebrain reflects reward-seeking and reinforcement during olfactory behavior.
Liz Hanson
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Elizabeth Hanson, Baylor College of Medicine; Katie Brandel-Ankrapp, Baylor College of Medicine; Benjamin Arenkiel, Baylor College of Medicine

Sensory perception underlies how we internalize and interact with the world around us. In order to adapt to changing circumstances and interpret signals in a variety of contexts, sensation needs to be reliable, but perception of sensory input needs to be flexible. An important mediator of this flexibility is top-down regulation from cholinergic and GABAergic projection neurons in the basal forebrain. Basal forebrain projection neurons serve as pacemakers and gatekeepers for downstream neural networks, modulating circuit activity across neuronal populations in the cortex and hippocampus. This top-down control is necessary for sensory cue detection, learning, and memory, and is disproportionately disrupted in neurodegenerative diseases with symptoms of cognitive decline. Intriguingly, cholinergic signaling acts locally within the basal forebrain to sculpt the activity of basal forebrain output neurons. To determine how local cholinergic signaling impacts the basal forebrain output pathways that participate in top-down regulation, we sought to better define the dynamics of cholinergic signaling within the basal forebrain during motivated behavior and learning. Here we utilize fiber photometry and the genetically encoded acetylcholine indicator GAChR2.0 to determine temporal patterns of cholinergic signaling in the basal forebrain during olfactory-guided, motivated behaviors and learning. We show that cholinergic signaling reliably increases during reward seeking behaviors, but also reveal that cholinergic signaling in the basal forebrain is strongly suppressed by reward delivery in a Go/ No Go olfactory-cued discrimination learning task. Intriguingly, the observed transient reduction in cholinergic tone is mirrored by a suppression in basal forebrain GABAergic neuronal activity. Together, these results suggest that cholinergic tone in the basal forebrain changes rapidly to reflect engagement in goal-directed behavior, incorporate feedback signals, and impact basal forebrain circuit activity.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Leveraging spatial connectivity for more efficient planning in naturalistic scenarios
German Espinosa
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
German Espinosa, Malcolm A. MacIver

The brute-force approach to planning, where the number of possible futures grows exponentially with the number of possible moves per step, fails to be tractable when the number of steps is large. There are methods to subsample the tree of possibilities to make the calculation tractable in such cases. These include Monte-Carlo tree search and variants like UCB1. In this talk, we present the results of a different strategy motivated by recent work in our group that indicates where plan-based action selection is most useful. Consider a discretized space being planned over, with some cells containing barriers/occlusions/gateways, and other cells being open. Rather than each possible position in a space being considered during planning, the agent plans over locations in the space where there is a transition in the graph connectivity. In the real world these transitions include barriers, corridors, gateways, and bottlenecks where the prey can hide. These locations are where the largest potential reward value changes happen. To bridge between these locations during plan execution, shortest path trajectories are calculated. This method enables planning a number of steps ahead that is several orders of magnitude larger than planning where every location of the space is considered. We present results in an idealized predator-prey scenario where we show that this method provides similar survival rates for the prey as UCB1 but with far fewer compute steps. In future work we will be deploying this method for guiding mobile robots that are interacting with animals in real time.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Posner cueing specifically modulates attention, but not expectation: Behavioral and neural evidence
Sricharan Sunder (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kavya Rajendran, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore; Devarajan Sridharan, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore

Attention and expectation are cognitive processes that help us navigate our environment efficiently. Each can modulate observers’ perceptual sensitivity (d’), decisional criteria (c), or both. Standard “attention” tasks involving probabilistic attention cues (e.g Posner cueing task), are hypothesized to conflate the effects of these two processes on behavior.

We tested this hypothesis by having the same set of n=19 subjects perform two tasks: a standard Posner cueing task (two-alternative detection/2-ADC task) and a two-alternative forced-choice (2-AFC) task. We replicated a previous study (Wyart et al, PNAS, 2012, DOI:10.1073/pnas.1120118109) in which subjects performed an detection 2-AFC task with independent probability (expectation) and relevance (attention) cues. Our task overcame key limitations of this previous study, and confirmed that signal probability modulated criteria alone whereas relevance modulated d’ alone.

Next, the same subjects who performed the 2-AFC task also performed a 2-ADC (Posner cueing) task with spatial probabilistic cues. Subjects were cued to the most probable location of an upcoming target event (change in orientation) and indicated whether they perceived the change at the cued location, at the uncued location, or not at all. In this task, probabilistic cueing modulated both d’ and criteria.

Nevertheless, only d’ modulations (difference in d’ between cued and uncued locations) were correlated across subjects between the 2-ADC and 2-AFC tasks (r=0.63, p<0.01, n=19 subjects) whereas criterion modulations were uncorrelated (r=-0.13, p=0.56). In addition, relevance cues (but not probability cues) in the 2-AFC task, and Posner cues in the 2-ADC task systematically modulated the power of EEG steady state visually evoked potentials (SSVEPs) and alpha-band oscillations.

Our results provide direct behavioral and neural evidence indicating that probabilistic cues, such as Posner cues, serve as attention, rather than expectation, cues.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Spatial theta-phase coding in the lateral septum: a theory of allocentric feedback during navigation
Joseph Monaco
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
H. T. Blair, UCLA; Kechen Zhang, Johns Hopkins University

During spatial navigation, the frequency and timing of spikes from spatial neurons including place cells in hippocampus and grid cells in medial entorhinal cortex are temporally organized by continuous theta oscillations (6–11 Hz). The theta rhythm is regulated by subcortical structures including the medial septum, but it is unclear how spatial information from place cells may reciprocally organize subcortical theta-rhythmic activity. Here we recorded single-unit spiking from a constellation of subcortical and hippocampal sites to study spatial modulation of rhythmic spike timing in rats freely exploring an open environment. Our analysis revealed a novel class of neurons that we termed 'phaser cells,' characterized by a symmetric coupling between firing rate and spike theta-phase. Phaser cells encoded space by assigning distinct phases to allocentric isocontour levels of each cell's spatial firing pattern. In our dataset, phaser cells were predominantly located in the lateral septum, but also the hippocampus, anteroventral thalamus, lateral hypothalamus, and nucleus accumbens. Unlike the unidirectional late-to-early phase precession of place cells, bidirectional phase modulation acted to return phaser cells to the same theta-phase along a given spatial isocontour, including cells that characteristically shifted to later phases at higher firing rates. Our dynamical models of intrinsic theta-bursting neurons demonstrated that experience-independent temporal coding mechanisms can qualitatively explain (1) the spatial rate-phase relationships of phaser cells and (2) the observed temporal segregation of phaser cells according to phase-shift direction. In open-field phaser cell simulations, competitive learning embedded phase-code entrainment maps into the weights of downstream targets, including path integration networks. Bayesian phase decoding revealed error correction capable of resetting path integration at subsecond timescales. Our findings suggest that phaser cells may instantiate a subcortical theta-rhythmic loop of spatial feedback. We outline a framework in which location-dependent synchrony reconciles internal idiothetic processes with the allothetic reference points of sensory experience.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Probabilistic Information Processing in Humans and Recurrent Neural Networks
Nuttida Rungratsameetaweemana
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Robert Kim, Salk Institute for Biological Studies; Terrence J. Sejnowski, Salk Institute for Biological Studies

In nature, sensory inputs are often highly structured, and statistical regularities of these signals can be extracted to form expectations about future sensori-motor associations, thereby facilitating optimal behavior. To date, the circuit mechanisms that underlie these probabilistic computations are not well understood. Through human electrophysiolgical experiment and a recurrent neural network (RNN) model, the present study investigates how the brain extracts, processes, and utilizes probabilistic structures of sensory signals to guide behavior. To achieve this goal, we first constructed and trained a biophysically constrained RNN model to perform a probabilistic decision-making task similar to the paradigm used in the human data. Specifically, the training environment was probabilistic such that one stimulus was more probable than the others. We show that both humans and the RNN model successfully extract information about stimulus probability and integrate this knowledge into their decisions and task strategy in a new environment. Specifically, performance of both humans and the RNN model varied with the degree to which the stimulus probability of the new environment matched the formed expectations. In both humans and RNNs, this expectation effect was more prominent when the strength of sensory evidence was low. These findings suggest that both humans and our RNN model placed more emphasis on prior expectations (top-down signals) when the available sensory information (bottom-up signals) was limited. Finally, by dissecting the trained RNN model, we demonstrate how competitive inhibition and recurrent excitation form the basis for neural circuitry optimized to perform probabilistic information processing.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
The effects of wearing an Eye Mask on cognitive functions and sleep architecture
Viviana Greco
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Greco Viviana, Cardiff University Brain Research Imaging Centre; Andrews Ralph, University of Sussex, Brighton; Smith Elena, University of Cologne, Germany; Bergamo Damiana, University of Padua, Italy; Cuccio Paola, University of Padua, Italy; Lewis Penelope, Cardiff University Brain Research Imaging Centre.

Study Objectives: In this study, we aimed to explore whether wearing an eye mask while sleeping, therefore minimizing light exposure, would affect the quality and the macrostructure of sleep, and improve cognitive performance.
Methods: Ninety-five healthy participants were tested in a within-subject design. In counterbalanced order, ambient light was blocked during sleep with an eye mask for one week during the summer months (experimental condition) or not-blocked (control condition). After five habituation nights, participants were tested on three cognitive tasks: word pairs memory, Psychomotor vigilance task (PVT), and motor-skill learning (MSL) on two consecutive days. Overnight consolidation was also examined on word pairs and MSL.
On the last testing days of both weeks, participant wore a wearable EEG devise in order to measure sleep architecture.
Results: Our analysis revealed superior word pairs encoding in the blocked light condition (p= 0.024). We also found faster performance on the second day of PVT in the blocked light condition (p= 0.002). The eye mask didn’t provide a better performance on MSL (Blocked-light: p< 0.001 vs. No blocked-light: p< 0.001) or overnight consolidation of word pairs (p=0.363).
The blocking light exposure increased the percentage of time spent in NREM stage 2 (p=0.023) and REM sleep (p=0.025).
Conclusion: We conclude that wearing an eye mask during the summer do not only contributes to optimize learning ability and vigilance, but also provides beneficial effect in terms on sleep quality and sleep architecture. No effect was found on motor performance on a finger-tapping task.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Hyperscanning: A Valid Method to Study Neural Inter-brain Underpinnings of Social Interaction
Artur Czeszumski
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sara Eustergerling, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany; Anne Lang, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany; David Menrath, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany; Michael Gerstenberger, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany; Susanne Schuberth, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany; Felix Schreiber, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany; Zadkiel Zuluaga Rendon, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany; Peter König, Institute of Cognitive Science, Universität Osnabrück, Osnabrück, Germany, Institut für Neurophysiologie und Pathophysiologie, Universitätsklinikum Hamburg-Eppendorf, Hamburg, Germany;

Social interactions are a crucial part of human life. Understanding the neural underpinnings of social interactions is a challenging task that the hyperscanning method has been trying to tackle over the last two decades. Here, we review the existing literature and evaluate the current state of the hyperscanning method. We review the type of methods (fMRI, M/EEG, and fNIRS) that are used to measure brain activity from more than one participant simultaneously and weigh their pros and cons for hyperscanning. Further, we discuss different types of analyses that are used to estimate brain networks and synchronization. Lastly, we present results of hyperscanning studies in the context of different cognitive functions and their relations to social interactions. All in all, we aim to comprehensively present methods, analyses, and results from the last 20 years of hyperscanning research.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Decoding stimuli in a Visual Working Memory Task
Nikolaos Chrysanthidis
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Nikolaos Chrysanthidis, Department of Computational Science and Technology, Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, 10044, Sweden; Hande Tunbak, The Wolfson Institute for Biomedical Research, Rockefeller Building,University Street, University College London, United Kingdom; Keerthi Krishnan, Department of Biochemistry and Cellular and Molecular Biology, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37996;

Decoding information from fMRI data has been shown to be informative in a range of vision, language and motor tasks. More specifically, differences in neuronal activity in task-related brain areas (e.g. prefrontal cortex) and specific phases of information processing are predictive of correct/incorrect recall in related working memory tasks. Subtraction analyses have demonstrated that activation differs depending on the presented stimuli, suggesting that we can also decode stimulus information from the Blood-Oxygen-Level-Dependent signal. In this study, we analyse the published Human Connectome Project (HCP) dataset, which studies brain connectivity in healthy adults. We focus on the Working Memory N-back task, with the specific contrasts: a high working memory load (“2-back”) versus a low working memory load (“0-back”). The already published results showed robust mixed-effects group-level activation in dorsal frontal-parietal and cingulate areas which are linked with working memory. Here we further extend the existing analysis by using non-linear models trained with parcels from different brain areas collectively to predict the type of stimulus. Furthermore, we investigate the role of certain brain areas in distinguishing stimuli by comparing specific parcels. Our analysis shows a close relationship between participants performances and categories of stimuli explained by response times. Our study also reveals that different types of stimuli have distinct brain signatures and a simple SVM classifier with a non-linear kernel can successfully decode stimuli with high accuracy in both Working Memory tasks. Finally, we train a GLM with samples from different brains areas and report that decoding stimuli success rate varies significantly, suggesting that some brain areas are more crucial in decoding stimuli in a working memory task, i.e. Secondary Visual Cortex, 96%(±0.01). *This study was conducted under the umbrella of NMA Summer School - Summer 2020
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Task state reactivation during aversive learning and avoidance
Toby Wise
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Yunzhe Liu;Fatima Chowdhury;Raymond J Dolan

Many symptoms of mood and anxiety disorders are associated with simulation of potential aversive outcomes. However, the fundamental computational and neural mechanisms that might support this phenomenon remain unknown. In this study, we sought to identify neural mechanisms supporting task state reactivation as a potential mechanism that might underlie these symptoms. Subjects completed an task that involved navigating through a maze of unique task states during MEG scanning. Critically, some states were probabilistically associated with electric shock, and subjects were required to use their knowledge of the task state space to successfully avoid shock. Behaviourally, subjects used model-based inference to successfully avoid shock, and at a neural level this was linked to reactivation of subsequently chosen goal states during planning. Following outcome receipt, we observed reactivation of the unchosen goal state, potentially facilitating counterfactual updating. Finally, we found that reactivation strength was linked to activity in the medial temporal lobe, suggesting that regions such as the hippocampus might support this process. These results indicate that the brain simulates potential outcomes of hypothetical actions during avoidance, providing a candidate mechanism in which dysfunction might lead to symptoms of mood and anxiety disorders.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Neural measures of subsequent memory reflect endogenous variability in cognitive function
Christoph Weidemann
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Christoph T. Weidemann, Swansea University & Columbia University; Michael J. Kahana, University of Pennsylvania

Human cognition exhibits a striking degree of variability: Sometimes we rapidly forge new associations whereas at other times new information simply does not stick. Correlations between neural activity during encoding and subsequent retrieval performance have implicated such "subsequent memory effects" (SMEs) as important for understanding the neural basis of memory formation. Uncontrolled variability in external factors that also predict memory performance, however, confounds the interpretation of these effects. By controlling
for a comprehensive set of external variables, we investigated the extent to which neural correlates of successful memory encoding
reflect variability in endogenous brain states. We show that external variables that reliably predict memory performance have relatively
small effects on electroencephalographic (EEG) correlates of successful memory encoding. Instead, the brain activity that is
diagnostic of successful encoding primarily reflects fluctuations in endogenous neural activity. These findings link neural activity during learning to endogenous states that drive variability in human cognition.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Tuning movement to optimize information harvesting
Malcolm MacIver
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Chen Chen, Northwestern University; Todd D. Murphy, Northwestern University

Information about potential fitness enhancers is dispersed in space, which provides a logic to the heterotroph strategy of moving to acquire resources. But how ought animals move to optimally acquire information? Current work on Lévy-flight like trajectories may apply to the context of acquiring resources that are far outside the range of sensory systems, but are not predictive when resources are in range. Entropy minimization approaches like infotaxis provide predictions for how animals ought to move when targets are in sensory range, but these do not agree well with measured trajectories. We present a new approach, energy-constrained proportional betting, and show that it generates trajectories that agree well with measured trajectories of animals localizing targets across four species spanning insects, fish, and mammals. In addition to predicting sense organ movements, the method also performs well for prescribing sensor locations in mobile robots in weak and noisy signal conditions.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
pMA as a model to study the somatotopy of the interhemispheric interaction
Kseniia Kozlova
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kseniia Kozlova 1, Maria Mitina1, Pavel Novikov1, Vadim Nikulin1,2 and Maria Nazarova1,3, 1 Higher School of Economics, Moscow, Russia; 2 Max Planck Institute, Leipzig, Germany , 3 Federal State Budgetary Institution «Federal center of brain and neurotechnologies» of the Ministry of Health of the Russian Federation

Physiological mirror activity (pMA) is an involuntary muscle activity in one limb muscles that happens when muscles of the opposite limb are strongly contracted. This phenomenon reflects the interhemispheric balance in the motor system. We hypothesize that pMA may serve as a model for studying the somatotopy of the interhemispheric interactions. We assume that pMA would be more prominent in the homologue muscles of the opposite hand compared to non-homologue muscles.
We obtained the preliminary results from 11 healthy right handed participants (7 females, 19 to 28 y.o.). Surface EMG was recorded from the abductor pollicis brevis, first dorsal interosseous, abductor digiti minimi from both hands. Extensor carpi ulnaris and flexor carpi ulnaris were used as control muscles. Subjects performed three motor tasks (thumb abduction, index finger extension, little finger abduction) in a pseudo-random order with their right hand while pMA was measured in the left.

We observed pMA in the left hand muscles in 9 out of 12 participants with presence of < 50% of the trials. pMA tended to increase with the repetitions in the experiment course. Average pick-to-pick amplitude of pMA was 150 μV, while pMA latency varied between 50ms to 4500 ms. With regard to the pMA somatotopy, the phenomenon was more prominent in homologues muscles than in non-homologues ones.

One of the obstacles we faced was that in some subjects in the active hand the isolated isometric contraction of one muscle without other co-located muscles was not possible. Further analysis, relating to demixing of EMG signal from the closely located muscles,
will be developed and performed.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Sampling-like representation of prospective locations during hippocampal theta sequences.
Balázs Ujfalussy
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Gergő Orbán, Computational Systems Neuroscience Lab, Wigner Research Center for Physics, Budapest, Hungary

Predicting the possible future consequences of actions is necessary for efficient planning. In volatile or partially observed environments animals can capitalise on representing the uncertainty associated with those predictions. Representation of and computations with uncertainty has recently gained support in a wide range of cognitive phenomena but whether and how uncertainty is represented in navigation and planning has remained elusive. Here we investigated the neuronal representation emerging in a goal-oriented spatial navigation task in a neuron population recorded from the hippocampus, a region widely implicated in model-based planning.

During exploratory behavior the hippocampal population activity repeatedly outlines the trajectory of the animal starting from its recent past towards its possible future positions within each theta cycle (theta sequences). Critically, during a single cycle the uncertainty is expected to increase systematically, thus providing an opportunity to identify how it is encoded in the population activity. We contrasted 4 alternative models: (a) encoding only the most likely trajectory (no uncertainty encoded); (b) encoding the uncertainty by sampling from the distribution of possible trajectories (uncertainty encoded across theta cycles); (c) representing uncertainty via the standard probabilistic population coding (PPC) or (d) via distributed distributional code (DDC).

By decoding hippocampal spikes falling into different phases of the theta oscillation, we confirmed that the location encoded by the activity sweeps ahead of the animal at late theta phases. Consistent with the representation of increased uncertainty, we observed that place fields were largest when estimated from late phase spikes. The population activity typically encoded single locations instead of full distributions with the firing rate being the highest when encoding future locations ruling out distributional population codes (PPC and DDC). Finally, we found that the variability between subsequent theta cycles is larger than that expected from encoding the most likely trajectory, and is consistent with sampling from hypothetical future trajectories.

Our analysis, being the first to directly contrast alternative frameworks of probabilistic computations, also demonstrates that activity in the hippocampus represents uncertainty and therefore is well equipped to contribute to optimal planning.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
PsychRNN: An Accessible and Flexible Python Package for Training Recurrent Neural Network Models on Cognitive Tasks
Jasmine Stone
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Daniel Ehrlich*, Yale University; Jasmine Stone*, Yale University, University of Cambridge; David Brandfonbrener, Yale University, New York University ; Alex Atanasov, Yale University, Harvard University ; John Murray, Yale University (* indicates equal contribution)

Task-trained artificial recurrent neural networks (RNNs) provide a computational modeling framework of increasing interest and application in computational, systems, and cognitive neuroscience. RNNs can be trained, using deep learning methods, to perform cognitive tasks used in animal and human experiments, and can be studied to investigate potential neural representations and circuit mechanisms underlying cognitive computations and behavior. Widespread application of these approaches within neuroscience has been limited by technical barriers in use of deep learning software packages to train network models. Here we introduce PsychRNN, an accessible, flexible, and extensible Python package for training RNNs on cognitive tasks. Our package is designed for accessibility, for researchers to define tasks and train RNN models using only Python and NumPy without requiring knowledge of deep learning software. The training backend is based on TensorFlow and is readily extensible for researchers with TensorFlow knowledge to develop projects with additional customization. PsychRNN implements a number of specialized features to support applications in systems and cognitive neuroscience. Users can impose neurobiologically relevant constraints on synaptic connectivity patterns. Furthermore, specification of cognitive tasks has a modular structure, which facilitates parametric variation of task demands to examine their impact on model solutions. PsychRNN also enables task shaping during training, or curriculum learning, in which tasks are adjusted in closed-loop based on performance. Shaping is ubiquitous in training of animals in cognitive tasks, and PsychRNN allows investigation of how shaping trajectories impact learning and model solutions. Overall, the PsychRNN framework facilitates application of trained RNNs in neuroscience research.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Closed-Loop Acoustic Neurostimulation during Sleep: Targeting theta waves
João Patriota
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
João Patriota ; Elsa Juan; Illia Korjoukov; Umberto Olcese; Lucia Talamini

Recently there has been an increasing interest in the potential applications of closed loop neuro-stimulation. Most studies are focused on targeting slow waves during NREM sleep, to improve memory consolidation. REM sleep plays a crucial role in emotional processing, which is essential for mental health. Theta is a hallmark of REM sleep, therefore detecting and manipulating theta waves could pave the way towards targeted interventions in clinical and sub-clinical populations. We present the first results on the development of an algorithm able to detect and target precise phases of theta (4-8 Hz), which could be used to further address how targeting can play a role on memory reactivation and memory consolidation.
Data of nine participants that underwent a night of polysomnography and EEG recordings in the lab. Ten minutes of recorded REM epochs from each subject were used to run the closed-loop acoustic stimulation (CLAS) system, targeting the 0-degree phase of theta.
Targeting procedure involves an oscillatory phase prediction algorithm, based on non-linear sine fitting on the most recent data segment of unfiltered EEG signal. The criteria for stimulus release are: 1) The fitted sine is in a frequency range of interest, 2) The fitting error is below a given threshold & 3) The prediction is within a delimited future time window. The algorithm is implemented within EventIDE software (Okazolab). This method has been applied to the slow oscillation frequency range.
Across all participants we achieved a mean target phase of 10.85 degrees (3.58 median), standard deviation of 56.74 degrees and made, on average, 163.78 predictions for each separate REM epoch.

These results on offline simulations suggest that it is possible to target specific phases of theta oscillations in a closed loop setup. This brings possibilities of a different tool for non-invasive intervention on processes that happen during sleep.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Neural and genetic bases for human ability traits
Camila Pinto
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jannis Bielefeld, Department of Physiology, Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine; Rami Jabakhanji, Department of Physiology, Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine;Diane Reckziegel,Department of Physiology, Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine; James W Griffith, Department of Medical Social Sciences, Feinberg School of Medicine, Northwestern University; Apkar Vania Apkarian, Department of Physiology, Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, & Center for Translational Pain Research, Feinberg School of Medicine, Northwestern & Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, Feinberg School of Medicine, Northwestern University & Department of Anesthesiology, Feinberg School of Medicine, Northwestern University.

The understanding of human ability, including behavioral and neurological function, is still underexplored. Current attempts are often narrowly defined and lack a comprehensive basis. However, a better definition of a basis for human ability would be invaluable since neuropsychiatric disease diagnoses and symptom severity are commonly related to such differences in performance. Here, we use the framework of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) Toolbox, which provides a unified assessment of neurologic and behavioral function to identify four underlying ability traits within the NIH Toolbox normative data (n = 1369): 1: Motor-endurance, 2: Emotional processing, 3: Executive and cognitive function, and 4: Social interaction. Using the Human Connectome Project young adult dataset (n = 778) we showed that two traits, Motor-endurance and Executive and cognitive function were reliably associated with specific brain functional networks (r^2=0.305±0.021). Moreover, we showed the biological nature of these ability traits by calculating their heritability (31% and 49% respectively) from twin data.
Therefore, we characterize human ability using the NIH Toolbox as a framework. Looking forward, this framework allows us to determine connections between the trait space and clinical outcomes in different neurophysiological conditions, such as chronic pain.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Behavioral models of visual working memory do not generalize to the whole-report paradigm
Ben Cuthbert (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Dominic Standage, Queen's University, Martin Paré, Queen's University, Gunnar Blohm, Queen's University

Many prominent behavioral models of visual working memory have been both motivated and validated by results from "single-report" change-detection and delayed estimation tasks. Recently, a new "whole-report" paradigm was introduced to address shortcomings with these canonical tasks, and to support claims about fundamental properties of visual working memory. However, it is unclear how well results from the relatively complex whole-report paradigm generalize to simpler tasks (and vice versa). Here, we use an existing whole-report dataset to show that participant responses exhibit statistical dependencies between simultaneously-presented stimuli that cannot be accounted for by an entire class of models that assumes independent encoding. We then fit several hierarchical encoding models (proposed to capture dependencies between stimuli) to the data, and find that this model class is also unable to account for whole-report behavior. Finally, we compare response distributions between stimulus types, and find that the dependencies exhibited when reporting hue are not present when reporting orientation, despite very similar overall task performance. Rather than proposing a model to capture behavior across all task paradigms, we suggest that this failure to generalize is the result of model mis-specification. We argue that some visual working memory models would be better conceptualized as models of change-detection or delayed estimation performance, and that more care should be taken when integrating results across stimulus modalities and behavioral paradigms into a single, unified theory.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Reward modulates cortical representations of action
Tyler Adkins
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tyler Adkins, University of Michigan Department of Psychology; Taraz Lee, University of Michigan Department of Psychology.

People are capable of rapid improvements in action performance when they are presented with large prospective incentive cues. The neural mechanism by which this performance enhancement occurs remains unclear. We investigated this phenomenon by offering prospective offers of monetary reward to human participants, contingent on their successful production of sequential actions. We found that people executed cued actions more quickly and accurately when they were offered large rewards. Reward offers were associated with elevated activity throughout the brain and fine-grained patterns in these regions encoded information about future action. Follow-up analyses provided evidence that action-coding in action preparation regions of the frontal lobe enhanced by reward and related to subsequent performance. This work sheds light on the neurocognitive mechanisms underlying the incentive-motivated performance of action, suggesting that it may depend critically on the fidelity of prospective action representations in the frontal lobe.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
A Neural Coactivity Code for Dynamic Memory
Mohamady El-Gaby
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Hayley M Reeve; Vítor Lopes-dos-Santos; Natalia Campo-Urriza; Pavel V Perestenko; Alexander Morley; Lauren Strickland; István P Lukács; Ole Paulsen; David Dupret

Information is encoded in the combined activity of multiple neurons. Notably, millisecond-timescale coactivity provides fundamental building blocks for some neural codes. Such short-timescale coactivity binds neurons with related tuning to external variables, giving rise to population-based representations congruent with those of their participating neurons. Alternatively, groups of neurons that are not individually tuned to a given variable may nevertheless encode such a variable as a function of their coactivity. While this type of emergent coding has been described for physically well-defined variables such as specific sensory inputs and actions, its possible cognitive function has not been explored. Here we show that coactivity-based representations provide a neural code for dynamic memories, where animals rapidly learn and flexibly retrieve short-lived behavioural contingencies every day. We trained mice to discriminate two new behavioural contingencies each day, while monitoring and manipulating neural ensembles in the hippocampal CA1. We found that short-timescale coactivity contained robust contingency information. Unlike coactivity patterns encoding space, which comprised neurons with overlapping place fields, coactivity-based contingency discrimination was unrelated to the tuning of individual neurons but instead an emergent property of their combined activity. Such millisecond, but not longer, timescale coactivity was flexibly reinstated to predict trial-by-trial memory performance. Moreover, optogenetic suppression of synaptic inputs from the upstream CA3 region selectively during learning impaired coactivity-based contingency information in CA1 and subsequent dynamic memory retrieval. These findings show that short-timescale coactivity stitches together individually untuned neurons to represent abstract, task-relevant variables in support of dynamic memory retrieval. Millisecond coactivity-based representations may preferentially exhibit the rapid dynamics needed to mnemonically process short-lived cognitive variables.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Synapse size as a gate between stable and switch-like behaviour
Monika Jozsa
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tihol Ivanov Donchev, University of Cambridge; Rodolphe Sepulchre, University of Cambridge;  Timothy O'Leary, University of Cambridge

Synapses comprise a small cellular compartment known as the postsynaptic density, which is the site of a number of extensively characterised biochemical processes involved in neuronal communication, learning and memory storage. Many biomolecular systems operate in the small system size regime, where the number of interacting molecules is in the tens or hundreds. In this regime, the inherent randomness of chemical reactions has an overall larger effect which raises the question of how synapses can signal reliably and store information over extended periods.

An important consequence of randomness in biochemical systems is that in the small system size regime, they can have multiple modes even if they only have a single mode in the large system size regime, that is, in the mass-action (deterministic) limit. This raises the possibility that compartmentalization can be exploited by biological systems to realise switch-like computations.

We illustrate this on a well-known test system, the toggle switch. The toggle switch is a continuous-time birth-death process describing the volume of two chemical species that mutually inhibit each other. This process possesses a single stable equilibrium in the mass action limit and exhibits bimodality for small system sizes. We explore a new heuristic approach to predicting the emergence of multimodality in nonlinear biochemical reactions in the small system size regime. In generic examples we show that there is a critical system size that separates unimodal and multi-modal behaviour that can be estimated by using linear noise approximation.

By considering the system size as a time-dependent control variable, our results support that system size may drive biochemical systems between stable uni-modal and switch-like multi-modal behaviour. Crucially, synapses are observed to increase in volume when potentiated, raising the possibility that system size may be exploited by synapses to achieve reliable switches despite the randomness in the underlying biochemical components.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Mechanical modifications to carbon fiber electrodes increase recording yield in brain and enable interfacing with peripheral structures
Elissa Welle (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Paras Patel, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan; Ahmad Jiman, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan; Elizabeth Bottorff, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan; Tim Bruns, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan; Cynthia Chestek, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan, Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, University of Michigan

Carbon fiber electrodes may enable better long-term brain and nerve interfaces by minimizing the tissue response commonly seen with silicon-based electrodes. Our recent modifications to a carbon fiber electrode surface using a laser or blowtorch has increased the recording yield and adaptability of the arrays in the brain and nerve, respectively. Past carbon fiber electrode arrays in the brain exhibited both high fidelity single unit recordings and a healthy neuronal population immediately adjacent to the recording site. We recently showed that using a 532nm laser instead of traditional microsurgical scissors for the creation of the electrode site increased the recording yield to 84% after 7 days and 71% after 63 days of chronic implant with PEDOT:pTS coating (N=45 fibers) (Welle et al., 2020), compared to a ~30% recording yield for scissor cut fibers. The laser cut electrodes created a consistent, sustainable 257 ± 13.8-µm2 electrode with low 1kHz impedance (19 ± 4kΩ with PEDOT:pTS) and low fiber-to-fiber variability. To enable peripheral nerve interfacing, where the insertion problem is more difficult, we used a 3mm butane flame to create sharpened carbon fiber electrodes that successfully inserted through the epineurium of nerve and dorsal root ganglion without a shuttle. The sharpened carbon fibers were on average 224µm in length with 147µm of exposed carbon and a tip angle of 72 degrees (N=24 fibers). We recorded spontaneous neural activity from rat cervical vagus nerve (Jiman et al., 2020) and feline dorsal root ganglion structures. Discernible single units were detected in physiologically relevant experiments, such as brushing and bladder filling. This work suggests that carbon fiber may be a viable material for higher channel count arrays for the peripheral nervous system.
... continues ... Interactive talk
Watch now
A motor adaptation paradigm to strengthen implicit learning
Shanaathanan Modchalingam
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Shanaathanan Modchalingam, York University; Marco Ciccone, York University; Bernard Marius ’t Hart, York University; Denise Henriques, York University

When our intended movements have unintended outcomes, the human motor system can quickly adapt future movements. Motor output is modified in a way such that motor errors, that is, the difference between the expected and the perceived consequences of any motor output, are reduced. Both explicit and implicit neural processes play key roles in adaptation. Explicit processes, such as the effortful use of conscious strategies to counter a perturbation, can be quickly employed and allow for flexibility in rapidly changing conditions. Implicit processes on the other hand, such as the unconscious updating of internal models, supposedly arise slowly but do allow for reliable, persistent changes in the motor system. When adapting reaching movements, implicit components of adaptation have been demonstrated to have an upper boundary in the amount by which they alter future movements, regardless of the size of the experienced perturbation [1]; that is, they are thought to be limited in scope. Here, we allow participants to adapt to small, consistent errors, and when they have done so, introduce further small errors. Consequently, we show that the proposed upper boundary on implicit adaptation can be overcome. We also show that the additional implicit learning observed is not caused by simply gradually increasing the perturbation to prevent explicit strategies. This suggests that while additional implicit adaptation is difficult to achieve during tasks with large, salient errors, and in tasks with slowly introduced errors, it may be achievable by evoking multiple distinct error correction steps.

1. Bond KM, Taylor JA. Flexible explicit but rigid implicit learning in a visuomotor adaptation task. J Neurophysiol. 2015; doi:10.1152/jn.00009.2015
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Weak signatures of audiovisual integration in mouse visual cortex
Célian Bimbard
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Timothy Sit, UCL; Anna Lebedeva, UCL; Philip Coen, UCL; Kenneth Harris, UCL; Matteo Carandini, UCL

Sensory cortices are increasingly thought to encode multisensory information. For instance, mouse primary visual cortex appears to be influenced by auditory inputs, which have been suggested to provide global inhibition or loudness and frequency specific information. However, sounds can also evoke behavioral responses. Such behavioral responses are now known to elicit neural activity across the brain. Thus, a potential confound between acoustic-related and movement-related activity could exist in multisensory studies.

To investigate this issue, we measured the neuronal responses to natural movies and natural sounds in primary visual cortex (V1) using chronically implanted Neuropixels probes, thus recording the activity of hundreds of units.

First, we replicated previous results showing that sounds could evoke neural activity in V1. Sound-evoked responses were weak compared to video-evoked responses, but we could still significantly decode sound identity from population activity. Second, we observe that mice showed stereotypical, unsolicited behaviors in response to the sounds (from startling to more complex behaviors). Third, we show that removing movement-related activity from V1 population activity drastically reduced the responses to sounds. We conclude that a significant part of sound-evoked responses in V1 comes from indirect behavioral responses. Analysis of changes in behavioral states is thus required for a careful characterization of auditory inputs to other sensory areas.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Science Management
Tanya Brown
 
Abstract
 
The landscape of scientific research is changing. Today’s researchers need to participate in large-scale collaborations, obtain competitive funding, share and manage big data, publish and undertake knowledge translation activities, all while conducting ground-breaking science and act as their own PR agent, in order to be successful. As per these increasing demands, Science Management is now a vital piece of the environment in order for the growing multidisciplinary needs of scientific research be met with efficacy. Moreover, this topic is relevant across the career spectrum – whether you’re a young investigator or an established senior scientist, adopting Science Management will help optimize your approach and workflow for greater discovery. My goal is to motivate my colleagues and field counterparts to regard Science Management as an essential component to their research workflow and begin to integrate formalized project management into regular practise.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Tools for efficient 3D cell and projection analysis and atlas registration of whole mouse spinal cord.
Felix Fiederling
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Luke A. Hammond, Columbia University; Carol A. Mason, Columbia University; Jane Dodd, Columbia University

The spinal cord (SC) contains a remarkable and complex variety of interconnected cells that relay and process somatosensory information and execute movement. Classic research on the embryonic and adult SC has identified major classes of neurons, based on embryonic markers, morphology and position within the SC. But recent advances in transcriptional profiling have revealed that the extent of spinal cell diversity far exceeds previous assumptions.

To achieve better characterization of spinal cell types and the detailed connectivity between cells that form functional circuits, it is necessary to map the spatial relations of neurons and projections. To date, however, unbiased approaches to map positional information in the context of the whole SC are severely limited by a lack of tools for efficient data collection and analysis. Moreover, the absence of a standardized 3D reference atlas for the mouse SC complicates anatomical mapping of data and comparison between samples and results across the field.

Here we present tools for practicable analysis of labelled cells and projections in whole mouse SC in the context of a novel 3D anatomical atlas. We have designed soluble, 3D-printed, ‘Spine Racks’ that guide oriented and parallel embedding of serial tissue segments of the entire SC within a single block for synchronous cryo-sectioning. Spine Racks precisely position tissue pieces within each block section array, permitting automated imaging of slides and rostro-caudal sorting of section images. Additionally, we have developed “SpinalJ”, a user-friendly plugIn for ImageJ, to register section images and to map the reconstructed data to a prototype 3D reference atlas. SpinalJ further combines various tools for manual and automated cell and projection analysis, as well as for data visualization.

Together, these tools capacitate high-throughput comparative analyses of neurons and their projections in whole SC.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Cell-Autonomous and Non-Autonomous Mechanisms Controlling Projection Neuron Migration
Andi Hansen
 
Abstract
 
Concerted radial migration of newly born cortical projection neurons, from their birthplace to their final target lamina, is a key step in the assembly of the cerebral cortex. The cellular and molecular mechanisms regulating the specific sequential steps of radial neuronal migration in vivo are however still unclear. Recent evidence suggests that distinct signaling cues act cell-autonomously but differentially at particular steps during the overall migration process. Functional MADM (Mosaic Analysis with Double Markers) analyses in comparison to global knockout also indicate a significant degree of non-cell-autonomous and/or community effects in the control of cortical neuron migration. Non-cell-autonomous effects may differentially affect cortical neuron migration in distinct compartments and thus regulate critical steps in the migration process. It is therefore not only essential to determine the nature of the interplay of cellautonomous and non-cell-autonomous mechanisms but also how they control cortical neuronal migration. Here we established a MADM-based experimental strategy for the analysis of cell-autonomous versus nonautonomous gene function and/or community effects. We pursued subtractive phenotypic analysis of genetic mosaics (wild-type/heterozygote background) with conditional and/or global knockout (mutant background), both coupled with sparse fluorescent MADM-labeling of homozygous mutant neurons, to trace the sequential steps of migration in 4D. Using these experimental paradigms we define so far unknown cell-autonomous functions of candidate signaling pathways intersecting with non-cell-autonomous effects to coordinate radial neuron migration.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
DNA Methylation Underlies Sexual Differentiation of Cell Type in the Brain
Laura Cortes (She/Her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Carla Cisternas, Georgia State; Damian Mason, Georgia State; Iagn Kenji Cabahug, Georgia State; Nancy Forger, Georgia State

Most animals display sex-specific behaviors, such as mating, aggression and parental care, that are important for the continuation of the species. These behaviors are controlled by sexually dimorphic groups of neurons that are defined by their gene expression (i.e., neurochemical phenotype) in certain brain areas. Within several hypothalamic regions, for example, females have more neurons that express estrogen receptor alpha (ER𝛼) and kisspeptin than do males. Little is known regarding the biological processes that cause these sex differences to develop, but our research suggests that epigenetic mechanisms play a role. Expression of epigenetic enzymes that place and remove methyl marks is highest during the first week of life in the hypothalamus and differs by sex. This suggests that DNA methylation is a critical mechanism underlying sex differences in brain development. In addition, we find that inhibiting DNA methylation neonatally by injecting zebularine into the cerebral ventricles abolishes sex differences in the number of ER𝛼 cells at weaning in three hypothalamic areas: the preoptic area (POA), ventromedial hypothalamus (VMH), and arcuate nucleus (ARC). Interestingly, however, zebularine disrupts sex differences differently in each brain area. In the POA and VMH, zebularine treatment increases ER𝛼 labeling in males to female-like levels, while in the ARC, zebularine decreases ER𝛼 labeling in females to male-like levels. Effects of zebularine on kisspeptin also differs by region: in the anteroventral periventricular region, kisspeptin cell number is unaffected by inhibition of DNA methylation, but kisspeptin labeling in the ARC is reduced in females after zebularine treatment. Finally, we recently tested the role of demethylating enzymes on sex differences in neurochemical phenotype. We find that early-life knock-down of Tet2 and Tet3 feminizes (i.e., increases) ER𝛼 labeling in the ARC of males. Thus, both DNA methylation and demethylation early in life sculpt sex differences in cell type in the hypothalamus.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
How the Mind Creates Structure: Hierarchical Learning of Complex Action Sequences
Maria Eckstein
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Anne CE Collins

Humans have the astonishing ability to learn from small amounts of data in reward-sparse environments, and to efficiently create multi-step goal-directed action plans. How humans aquire the representations that support this ability has fascinated researchers in psychology and artiﬁcial intelligence for decades. We investigate the contributions of two mechanisms: curiosity, the intrinsic motivation to explore the effects actions have on the environment; and hierarchical structure, the representation of goals and actions across multiple levels of abstraction.
To test this hypothesis, we asked 60 undergraduate participants (49 females) to participate in a task in which they operated a star-making machine using their computer keyboard, with the goal of collecting as many stars as possible.
Participants needed to learn four 4-key sequences that led to 4 different stars. Each 4-key sequence was made up of two successive 2-key sequences.
