The 2-key sequences were one of four possible shared across stars, and their successful execution was signaled visually (triggering curiosity), but not rewarded. We asked whether participants learned and employed this underlying structure to obtain stars. Indeed, response time (RT) patterns revealed a strong segmentation of participants’ 4-key sequences into two 2-key sequences, with markedly speeded RTs on actions 2 and 4 of the sequence, compared to actions 1 and 3. This suggests that participants learned the 2-key sequences and used them as a basis to explore 4-key sequences. The strength of RT segmentation was related to performance, such that high levels of segmentation—suggesting exploration in the space of 2-key sequences—was related to faster learning. After learning, participants underwent an unsignaled transfer block, in which either 2-key sequences were modified by exchanging component keys (low-level transfer), or 4-key sequences were modified by exchanging component 2-key sequences (high-level transfer). Participants showed faster relearning after high-level than low-level transfer, suggesting that high-level policies were more malleable and low-level policies were more automated.
This research sheds light on the cognitive processes involved in representation learning for decision making. Faced with the natural world’s combinatorial explosion of possibilities, humans might bootstrap learning by shifting the level of exploration from basic actions to compound action sequences, which are themselves learned through curiosity.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Predictive mechanisms are involved in perceptual stability across saccades
Anne-Sophie Laurin
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Anne-Sophie Laurin, University of Montreal, Department of Psychology; Maxime Bleau, University of Montreal, School of Optometry; Jessica Gedjakouchian, University of Montreal, School of Optometry; Romain Fournet, University of Montreal, School of Optometry; Laure Pisella, ImpAct, INSERM UM1028, CNRS UMR 5292, University Claude Bernard Lyon 1; Aarlenne Zein Khan, University of Montreal, School of Optometry.

It has been suggested that perceptual stability across saccades relies on predictive mechanisms. Specifically, predictions of what should occur after the saccade modulate our perception of the visual scene once the saccade has been executed.
To investigate this, we measured how perceptual discrimination of a visual target at a peripheral location before saccading to it, is influenced by changes in the visual scene after the saccade. Participants’ task was to discriminate a symbol at a peripheral location, before saccading to it. We manipulated information in the visual scene after the saccade in various ways (removal, change in identity or shifts). Because changes after the saccade were irrelevant to the task, we hypothesized that changes in discrimination performance, if any, could only be attributable to disrupted comparisons between our pre-saccadic expectation and our post-saccadic perception of the visual scene. We observed that the disappearance of the saccade goal target, without the disappearance of the surrounding stimuli, reduced the discrimination performance compared to baseline. Importantly, discrimination performance remained unchanged when the entire visual scene, including or excluding the saccade goal target, was removed. These results support the idea that discrimination decreases are not due to abrupt changes affecting memory of the target. It also suggests that removal of the visual scene does not disrupt predictive mechanisms, likely because changes are correctly attributed to the external world.
We also observed that shifts in the position of the saccade goal target after the saccade disrupted discrimination performance to a much greater degree when the position shifted outside the distribution of saccade endpoints both parallel and perpendicular to the target. This supports the notion of predictive mechanisms taking saccade-related motor noise into account when comparing pre- and post- visual target information, thus involved in the perception of a visual scene across saccades.
Traditional talk
Watch now
A Quantification of Dendritic and dendritic spine morphology in Cyclooxygenase - 2 – Knockin Mice
Ashby Kissoondoyal
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ravneet Rai-Bhogal; Crawford Dorota, York University

Background: ProstaglandinE2 (PGE2) is a lipid signaling molecule involved in normal neurodevelopment. Abnormal PGE2 signalling due to genetic or environmental causes has been linked to autism spectrum disorders (ASD). Previously our lab demonstrated that disrupting the function of COX2, the rate-limiting enzyme of PGE2 production affects the expression of developmental genes important in synaptic transmission and dendritic spine formation in males. Further, Ptgs2 Y385F knockin (COX2-KI) animals demonstrate autism-like behaviours, including impairments in social interaction and motor strength, and repetitive and anxious behaviors. Our Objective was to examine the effect of abnormal PGE2 signalling on the morphology of cerebellar dendritic spines.
Methods: We examined GOLGI-COX stained cerebellums of COX2-KI and Wild-type B6.129S6(FVB)-Ptgs2tm1.1Fun/J (WT) mice at postnatal day 25 (PN25). We measured dendrite length, branching, and thickness, the proportion of dendrites forming axonal loops, and dendritic spine density and morphology. Measurements were compared between and within conditions (COX2-KI and WT) and sex.
Results: COX2-KI mice had greater dendritic arborization within 40µm of the soma than WT mice. Dendrite thickness was greater in WT Females than WT Males. In contrast COX2-KI Males had thicker dendrites than COX2-KI Females. Compared to WT mice, the odds of observing axonal loops was higher in COX2-KI mice. While dendritic spine density was greater in WT Males compared to WT Females, there was no significant difference between COX2-KI Males and Females. Examining dendritic spine morphology, WT Males were less likely to have immature (stubby and filopodia) spine shapes compared to mature (mushroom) shapes, whereas WT females were more likely to have immature (stubby and thin) shapes. Showing the opposite trend, COX2-KI Males and Females were more likely to have immature (stubby and thin) shapes, and mature (mushroom) shapes respectively. These findings show that PGE2 signalling disruptions in the COX2-KI result in sex-dependent abnormalities in cerebellar neuronal development.
Interactive talk
Watch now
The different mechanisms that distinguish motor skill acquisition from adaptation
Raphael Gastrock
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Bernard Marius 't Hart, York University; Denise Y. P. Henriques, York University

As people move within an environment, changes in circumstances may lead to movement errors. To produce correct movements, these errors must be processed regardless of whether people are acquiring a new motor skill (de novo learning) or adapting a well-known movement (motor adaptation). However, these two types of learning should develop differently and switching between response mappings in de novo learning should not lead to reach aftereffects typically observed after adaptation. Here, we conducted two experiments that differentiate de novo learning from adaptation and explore the mechanisms of de novo learning further. In experiment 1 (N = 16), we distinguished the two motor learning types by having each participant train with two perturbations in counterbalanced order: a 30-degree visuomotor rotation and a reversal of cursor feedback in the opposite direction of a mirror axis. Importantly, we matched the movements required to reach the targets in both tasks. We found no order effects, suggesting that learning for one perturbation does not affect the other. Although participants countered for both perturbations by the end of only 90 training trials, learning for the rotation task was more gradual while variability in learning was greater for the mirror task. Participants generally took longer to initiate and execute reaching movements in the mirror task. Moreover, participants only exhibited reach aftereffects after completing the rotation task. In experiment 2 (N = 116), we developed an online version of the mirror task, with target locations placed farther from the mirror axis than in experiment 1. Asymptotic learning of participants differed depending on target location, but reach aftereffects were also not observed. These results highlight the development of de novo learning and how it is distinct from adaptation. As such, our future work will investigate both behavioural and neural processes underlying these different types of motor learning.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Efficient coding in auditory cortex determines target detection behavior
Chris Angeloni
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Chris Angeloni, University of Pennsylvania; Wiktor Mlynarski, IST Austria; Katherine Wood, University of Pennsylvania; Linda Garami, University of Pennsylvania; Anne Hermundstadt, Janelia HHMI; Maria Geffen, University of Pennsylvania

Sensory systems are composed of neurons with limited dynamic range, but are required to accurately represent a world in which the dynamic range of incoming stimuli can vary wildly. To efficiently encode acoustic environments with different dynamic ranges (referred to here as contrast), neurons in auditory cortex (AC) adapt the gain of their response function to effectively match their dynamic range to that of the environment. However, it is not known whether these widespread changes in neural sensitivity have an impact on auditory percepts. To test this, we trained mice to detect auditory targets in backgrounds of different contrasts, and find that, 1) target detection and sensitivity were improved in low contrast, and, 2) the time-course of target detectability varied depending on contrast, decreasing rapidly after a transition to high contrast, and increasing at a slower rate after a transition to low contrast. These patterns of target detectability are recapitulated in populations of AC neurons simultaneously recorded with behavior and the magnitude of gain modulation in cortical neurons predicts behavioral performance of individual mice. Consistent with these results, a normative model in which neurons efficiently adapt their gain to optimize stimulus reconstruction also exhibits detection performance in line with our behavioral and neural results. Together, these results demonstrate that efficient neural codes in auditory cortex directly influence behavioral percepts.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Teaching causality to neuroscientists
Ari Benjamin
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ari Benjamin, University of Pennsylvania; Tony Liu, University of Pennsylvania; Sofia Triantafillou, University of Pittsburgh; Eleanor Batty, Harvard University; Madineh Sarvestani, Max Planck Florida Institute; Konrad Kording, University of Pennsylvania;

The standard curriculum for neuroscientists does not include a formal definition of causality, or any formal treatment of what methods exist to estimate a causal effect. Since a great number of neuroscientific questions are causal in nature – including questions of mediation, of connection, and of mechanism – we developed a fast, one-day curriculum to provide neuroscientists a working concept of how causality can be treated formally. In the third week of Neuromatch Academy, we presented these materials in an interactive problem-solving format, interspersed with video instruction, to over 1,700 students. Students from around the globe worked through this curriculum in live video conferencing in groups of around 10, each guided by a teaching assistant. After conclusion of the academy, we evaluated the success of these materials and their presentation with surveys provided to students and teachers. This talk will present our educational goals and approaches in consideration of what was most and least successful. The full academy curriculum is published online and openly available for re-use.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Parallel ascending spinal pathways for affective touch and pain
Seungwon (Sebastian) Choi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Junichi Hachisuka, University of Pittsburgh; Matthew A. Brett, Harvard Medical School; Alexandra Magee, Harvard Medical School; H. Richard Koerber, University of Pittsburgh; Sarah E. Ross, University of Pittsburgh; David D. Ginty, Harvard Medical School

Each day we experience myriad somatosensory stimuli: hugs from loved ones, warm showers, a mosquito bite, and sore muscles after a workout. These tactile, thermal, itch, and nociceptive signals are detected by peripheral sensory neuron terminals distributed throughout our body, propagated into the spinal cord, and then transmitted to the brain through ascending spinal pathways. Primary sensory neurons that detect a wide range of somatosensory stimuli have been identified and characterized. In contrast, very little is known about how peripheral signals are integrated and processed within the spinal cord and conveyed to the brain to generate somatosensory perception and behavioral responses. We tackled this question by developing new mouse genetic tools to define projection neuron (PN) subsets of the anterolateral pathway, a major ascending spinal cord pathway, and combining these new tools with advanced anatomical, physiological, and behavioral approaches. We found that Gpr83+ PNs, a newly identified subset of spinal cord output neurons, and Tacr1+ PNs are largely non-overlapping populations that innervate distinct sets of subnuclei within the lateral parabrachial nucleus (PBNL) of the pons in a zonally segregated manner. In addition, Gpr83+ PNs are highly sensitive to cutaneous mechanical stimuli, receive strong synaptic inputs from primary mechanosensory neurons, and convey tactile information bilaterally to the PBNL in a non-topographically organized manner. Remarkably, Gpr83+ mechanosensory limb of the anterolateral pathway controls behaviors associated with different hedonic values (appetitive or aversive) in a scalable manner. This is the first study to identify a dedicated spinal cord output pathway that conveys affective touch signals to the brain and to define parallel ascending circuit modules that cooperate to convey tactile, thermal and noxious cutaneous signals from the spinal cord to the brain. This study has also revealed exciting new therapeutic opportunities for developing treatments for neurological disorders associated with pain and affective touch.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The organization and developmental establishment of cortical interneuron presynaptic circuits
Gabrielle Pouchelon
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Gabrielle Pouchelon, Harvard Medical School, Department of Neurobiology, Broad Institute, Stanley Center for Psychiatric Research; Yannick Bollmann, Aix Marseille University, INSERM, INMED, Turing Center for Living Systems; Elaine Fisher, Harvard Medical School, Department of Neurobiology, Broad Institute, Stanley Center for Psychiatric Research; Chimuanya K Agba, Harvard Medical School, Department of Neurobiology, Broad Institute, Stanley Center for Psychiatric Research; Qing Xu, Center for Genomics & Systems Biology, New York University; Kimberly D Ritola, Janelia Research Campus, Howard Hughes Medical Institute; Andrea Mirow, Harvard Medical School, Department of Neurobiology, Broad Institute, Stanley Center for Psychiatric Research; Seyhun Kim, Harvard Medical School, Department of Neurobiology, Broad Institute, Stanley Center for Psychiatric Research; Rosa Cossart, Aix Marseille University, INSERM, INMED, Turing Center for Living Systems; Gord Fishell, Harvard Medical School, Department of Neurobiology, Broad Institute, Stanley Center for Psychiatric Research.

Sensory and cognitive functions are processed in discrete cortical areas and depend upon the integration of long range cortical and subcortical inputs. PV and SST inhibitory interneurons (cINs) gate these inputs and failure to do so properly is implicated in many neurodevelopmental disorders. The logic by which these interneuron populations are integrated into cortical circuits and how these vary across sensory versus associative cortical areas is unknown. To answer this question, we began by surveying the breadth of afferents impinging upon PV and SST cINs within distinct cortical areas. In contrast to the characterized thalamic and cortical canonical circuits, we found that the afferents to PV and SST cINs receive similar projections within areal location. However, the identity of the thalamic and cortical neuron is variable according to the cell-types they project to. During development, cell-type specific circuits are specialized via areal-specific progression, regression and transitory connectivity. Remarkably the organization of thalamocortical afferents to SST and PV cINs reach their mature specificity through distinct mechanisms. While thalamocortical afferents to PV IN are regulated by sensory experience, projections to SST IN developed through postsynaptic mGluR1 receptor activation. Altogether, these data provide a comprehensive map of cIN afferents within different functional cortical areas and reveal the region-specific logic by which PV and SST cIN circuits are established.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Perinatal vasopressin surge may be neuroprotective with implications for neurodevelopment
Jennifer Gray
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Yarely C. Hoffiz, Ph.D.; Alexandra Castillo-Ruiz, Ph.D.; Taylor A. Hite; Nancy G. Forger, Ph.D.

A striking surge in vasopressin (VP) accompanies birth in humans, but the neural underpinnings and function of this surge remain unknown. In the current study, first sought to determine whether there is a similar surge in mice by measuring plasma levels of copeptin (a proxy for VP) following either a vaginal or C-sectioned birth. We found that neonates experience a ≥ 50-fold elevation in peripheral copeptin levels compared to adult mice, and that these levels are significantly higher in mice born vaginally compared to those born by C-section. We also found that VP mRNA expression in the hypothalamus significantly increases during the days prior to birth, and that hypothalamic VP neurons are activated at birth based on cFos labeling. Additionally, we observed significantly decreased plasma osmolality at 1 and 3 hours following a vaginal, but not C-section birth, indicating a transient increase in water retention following a vaginal birth. Importantly, our lab has previously shown that neuronal cell death is significantly decreased at 3 hours following a vaginal, but not C-section birth, in several brain regions. We then established a detailed time course of cell death, showing a significant drop in cell death at 3 hours in the PVN, BNSTl, and LS. To test whether perinatal VP release may be neuroprotective, we performed intracerebroventricular injections of VP in C-sectioned mice 3 hours after birth. We observed a significant reduction in cell death in the PVN and AHA in C-sectioned mice that received VP compared to control. Overall, these data suggest that there is a surge in both central and peripheral VP which may be neuroprotective during early brain development.
Traditional talk
Watch now
How representations adapt: the role of structure in model-based planning
Leonie Glitz (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Garrett, N.*; Jüchems, K.; Summerfield, C.;

Updating a model of the world that is used for planning faces a trade-off between computational efficiency (generalisation across different contexts) on the one hand and context-specific encoding on the other. Humans are exceptionally good at navigating this trade-off, though the neural implementation of this balance remains elusive. We developed a two-stage sequential learning task which allowed us to probe human state transition probability learning across two sets of contexts. One set (dependent blocks) involved two contexts with identical transition probabilities whereas the other set (independent blocks) consisted of two contexts with uncorrelated transition probabilities. We find that participants collapse across contexts in the dependent but not the independent set of contexts, using information from both contexts to inform choices when adaptive, which is confirmed by our computational modelling. Comparing the neural (fMRI) encoding of model-derived state transition functions and updating between the two contexts in each set allowed us to investigate where in the brain this selective combination or separation of representations is implemented. Using representational similarity analysis, we find that the pattern of neural activity associated with using and updating transition functions is more similar between contexts in dependent than in independent blocks in parts of the hippocampal formation (including parts of amygdala and entorhinal cortex). This suggests that, in line with recent theoretical proposals, the hippocampus and surrounding structures may be the parts of the brain that allow for an adaptive degree of generalisation and separation of environmental information, enabling us to both plan and learn from experience.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Global visual salience of competing stimuli
Alex Hernandez-Garcia
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Alex Hernandez-Garcia, University of Osnabrück; Ricardo Ramos Gameiro, University of Osnabrück; Alessandro Grillini, University Medical Center Groningen; Peter König, University of Osnabrück

Current computational models of visual salience accurately predict the distribution of fixations on isolated visual stimuli. It is not known, however, whether the global salience of a stimulus, that is, its effectiveness in the competition for attention with other stimuli, is a function of the local salience or an independent measure. Further, do task and familiarity with the competing images influence eye movements? Here, we investigated the direction of the first saccade to characterize and analyze the global visual salience of competing stimuli. Participants freely observed pairs of images while eye movements were recorded. The pairs balanced the combinations of new and already seen images, as well as task and task-free trials. Then, we trained a logistic regression model that accurately predicted the location—left or right image—of the first fixation for each stimulus pair, accounting too for the influence of task, familiarity, and lateral bias. The coefficients of the model provided a reliable measure of global salience, which we contrasted with two distinct local salience models, GBVS and Deep Gaze. The lack of correlation of the behavioral data with the former and the small correlation with the latter indicate that global salience cannot be explained by the feature-driven local salience of images. Further, the influence of task and familiarity was rather small, and we reproduced the previously reported left-sided bias. Summarized, we showed that natural stimuli have an intrinsic global salience related to the human initial gaze direction, independent of the local salience and little influenced by task and familiarity.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Cortical representations of conspecific sex shape social behavior
Shan Huang
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Shan Huang; Lyle Kingsbury Lyle; Tara Raam; Letizia Ye; Don Wei; Rongfeng Hu; Li Ye; Weizhe Hong

A central question related to virtually all social decisions is how animals integrate sex-specific cues from conspecifics. Using microendoscopic calcium imaging in mice, we find that sex information is represented in the dorsal medial prefrontal cortex (dmPFC) across excitatory and inhibitory neurons. These cells form a distributed code that differentiates the sex of conspecifics and is strengthened with social experience. While males and females both represent sex in the dmPFC, male mice show stronger encoding of female cues, and the relative strength of these sex representations predicts sex preference behavior. Using activity-dependent optogenetic manipulations of natively active ensembles, we further show that these specific representations modulate preference behavior toward males and females. Together, these results define a functional role for native representations of sex in shaping social behavior, and reveal a neural mechanism underlying male- vs. female-directed sociality.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Aiming evokes explicit motor adaptation
Marius 't Hart
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Urooj Taqvi, York University; Raphael Q. Gastrock, York University; Jennifer Ruttle, York University; Shanaathanan Modchalingam, York University; Denise Y.P. Henriques York University;

In recent years it has become exceedingly clear that explicit learning plays an important role in motor adaptation. The most used method to measure explicit adaptation is aiming: participants are asked to indicate what angle, relative to the target, they will aim at for their next reach. While useful and straightforward, this method may also reveal the nature of the manipulation to participants, by forcing them to consider reach direction on every trial. This may evoke explicit adaptation where normally there wouldn’t be any. To test this we had three groups of participants adapt to a 30° rotation. These were an instructed group (N=24) who were explained the manipulation and given a strategy to counter it, an aiming group (N=24) who pointed an arrow at where they said they would aim their reach on the next trial (without landmarks or reminder instructions) and a control group (N=24) who neither received instructions nor did aiming. Except for an initial benefit of instructions, each group adapted similarly. In all three groups we measured explicit and implicit contributions at the end of adaptation by asking people to either include (explicit+implicit) or exclude (implicit only) whatever strategy they thought they had. As expected, there was no difference between these two measures in the control group indicating fully implicit adaptation. The two measures differed in the instructed group, indicating partially explicit adaptation. The distribution of differences was uni-modal in these two groups, but in the aiming group, the distribution was bi-modal, with one peak around zero, akin to the control group, and one peak lined up with the peak of the instructed group. This shows that in about one third of participants aiming has the same effect as an instruction, so that aiming not only measures, but also causes explicit adaptation.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Amplified representation of sound termination in the auditory cortex and its behavioral relevance
Magdalena Solyga
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tania Rinaldi Barkat, Brain & Sound Lab, Department of Biomedicine, Basel University, 4056 Basel, Switzerland

Offset responses in auditory processing appear after a sound terminates. In the peripheral auditory system, neuronal circuits within the cochlear and superior paraolivary nuclei play a central role in generating offset responses. In the central auditory system, a recent study showed that neurons in the anterior auditory field (AAF) have significantly stronger responses to sound termination than those in the primary auditory cortex. The mechanisms that generate and drive offset responses within AAF as well as their behavioural relevance remain unknown.
To understand the role of AAF offset responses in sound perception, we asked whether detecting the end of a sound would be influenced by them. Using optogenetics, we showed that preventing AAF offset responses decreases the mouse performance to detect sound termination.
Next, we combined electrophysiological recordings in auditory cortex and thalamus of awake mice with antidromic stimulation to better understand how cortical offset responses occur. We found that more than 80% of AAF inputs come from onset-offset responsive thalamic cells, indicating that a big portion of information on sound termination in AAF is inherited from the preceding nuclei. However, our results also demonstrate that cortical offset responses are amplified in comparison to the thalamic ones.
Overall, our results reveal the importance of cortical offset responses in coding and perceiving sound termination. They might play a crucial role for advanced processing such as detecting changes within temporally discontinuous sounds.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
“I listen for your voice”: The Influence of art/design on parental stress, experience and engagement in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit
Laurena Clark
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Laurena Clark, York University; David Scadding, York University; Dr. Upali Nanda, University of Michigan; Dr. Joseph DeSouza, York University

Current research indicates a strong correlation between parental involvement in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU), and better health outcomes for babies. Healthcare Interior Designers are responsible for designing spaces that not only meet all current standards and best practices, but also consider the experiences of the people who inhabit these spaces. With the focus of healthcare design shifting towards an evidence-based approach, there is opportunity to expand the current body of knowledge with further research, to help guide the design of facilities and have a positive impact on the health and wellbeing of patients, visitors and staff. My thesis focuses on the idea of integrating environmental graphic art installations in the NICU to provide a medium through which messages can be communicated to parents to support, educate and encourage them to spend more time with their babies, potentially leading to better health outcomes. Research will incorporate findings from Contemporary Western Art/Architectural History, specifically looking at art in hospitals, Environmental Psychology to investigate how we are affected by the built environments that surrounds us, and Visual Communication to understand how text, image and content can be used to convey a message with the goal of affecting human behaviour. This is a unique and exciting research opportunity that extends across disciplines, where a gap in the research exists. If this contribution bridges the gap, there is the potential to have significant impact on the health and wellbeing of people in the NICU.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Spinal inhibitory Ptf1a-derived neurons prevent self-generated itch
Augusto Escalante
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ruediger Klein

Chronic itch represents an incapacitating burden on patients suffering from a wide spectrum of diseases. Despite recent advances in our understanding of the cells and circuits implicated in the processing of itch information, chronic itch often presents itself without an apparent cause. Here, we identify a spinal subpopulation of inhibitory neurons defined by the expression of Ptf1a, involved in gating mechanosensory information self-generated during movement. These neurons receive tactile and motor input and establish presynaptic inhibitory contacts on mechanosensory afferents. Loss of Ptf1a neurons leads to increased hairy skin sensitivity and chronic itch, partially mediated by the classic itch pathway involving gastrin releasing peptide receptor (GRPR) spinal neurons. Conversely, chemogenetic activation of GRPR neurons elicits itch which is suppressed by concomitant activation of Ptf1a neurons. These findings shed new light on the circuit mechanisms implicated in chronic itch and open novel targets for therapy developments.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Disruption of neonatal Purkinje cell function underlies injury-related learning deficits
Aaron Sathyanesan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Aaron Sathyanesan, Children's National Research Institute, Washington DC; Panagiotis Kratimenos, Children's National Research Institute, Washington DC; Vittorio Gallo, Children's National Research Institute, Washington DC

It is hypothesized that perinatal cerebellar injury leads to long-term functional deficits due to circuit dysmaturation. Using a novel integration of GCaMP6f fiber photometry with automated measurement of cerebellar behavior using the ErasmusLadder, we causally link cerebellar injury to altered Purkinje cell responses during maladaptive behavior. Inhibition of Purkinje cells is sufficient to phenocopy the effects of perinatal cerebellar injury. Our results uncover a direct link between perinatal cerebellar injury and activity-dependent maturation of cerebellar cortex.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Endothelin-1 signaling maintains glial progenitor proliferation in the postnatal subventricular zone
Katrina Adams
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Giulia Riparini, University of Urbino "Carlo Bo", Italy; Payal Banerjee, Children's National Hospital, USA; Marjolein Breur, VU University Medical Center, The Netherlands; Marianna Bugiani, VU University Medical Center, The Netherlands; Vittorio Gallo, Children's National Hospital, USA.

Signaling molecules that regulate neurodevelopmental processes in the early postnatal subventricular zone (SVZ) are critical for proper brain development yet remain poorly characterized. Here, we report that Endothelin-1 (ET-1), a molecular component of the postnatal SVZ, promotes radial glial cell maintenance and proliferation in an autocrine manner via Notch signaling. Loss of ET-1 signaling increases neurogenesis and reduces oligodendrocyte progenitor cell proliferation (OPC) in the developing SVZ, thereby altering cellular output of the stem cell niche. We also show that ET-1 is required for increased neural stem cell and OPC proliferation in the adult mouse SVZ following demyelination. Lastly, high levels of ET-1 in the SVZ of patients with Cathepsin A-related arteriopathy with strokes and leukoencephalopathy correlate with an increased number of SVZ OPCs, suggesting ET-1's role as a regulator of glial progenitor proliferation may be conserved in humans. ET-1 signaling therefore presents a potential new therapeutic target for promoting SVZ-mediated cellular repair.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Transferring structural knowledge across cognitive maps in humans and models
Shirley Mark
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Rani Moran;Thomas Parr; Steve Kennerley; Tim Behrens

Relations between task elements often follow hidden underlying structural forms such as periodicities or hierarchies, whose inferences fosters performance. However, transferring structural knowledge to novel environments requires flexible representations that are generalizable over particularities of the current environment, such as its stimuli and size. We suggest that humans represent structural forms as abstract basis sets and that in novel tasks, the structural form is inferred and the relevant basis set is transferred. Using a computational model, we show that such representation allows inference of the underlying structural form, important task states, effective behavioural policies and the existence of unobserved state-trajectories. In two experiments, participants learned three abstract graphs during two successive days. We tested how structural knowledge acquired on Day-1 affected Day-2 performance. In line with our model, participants who had a correct structural prior were able to infer the existence of unobserved state-trajectories and appropriate behavioural policies.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Saccade-related potentials during task-related refixation behaviour
Radha Nila Meghanathan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Cees van Leeuwen, Laboratory for Perceptual Dynamics, Brain & Cognition Research Unit, University of Leuven, Leuven, Belgium & Center for Cognitive Science, University of Kaiserslautern, Kaiserslautern, Germany; Marcello Giannini, Laboratory for Perceptual Dynamics, Brain & Cognition Research Unit, University of Leuven, Leuven, Belgium; Andrey R. Nikolaev, Department of Psychology, Lund University, Lund, Sweden & Laboratory for Perceptual Dynamics, Brain & Cognition Research Unit, University of Leuven, Leuven, Belgium

When a saccade is planned, attention shifts to the subsequent fixation location before the saccade is executed. In a free viewing task, this attention shift is biased by higher-order processes related to the task. We used EEG to study the dependence of pre-saccadic attention shifts on task-related processes. The EEG activity in the interval preceding a saccade is known as the saccade-related potential (SRP). We studied SRPs in a visual search task requiring memorization of multiple targets for subsequent change detection. Such a complex task naturally leads to refixations, i.e. the eyes returning to previously visited locations, depending on the task-relevance of the fixated item. We compared SRPs between first fixations and refixations for task-relevant (target) and task-irrelevant (distractor) items. Both task-relevance and type of fixation (first fixation vs refixation) affect working memory load, which biases pre-saccadic attention. Fixations on targets load working memory with both identity and location information, whereas fixations on distractors load working memory only with identity information. Higher working memory load is also observed in our task during first fixations, which are made for memorization of a new target in comparison to refixations, which are made for rehearsal of previously fixated items. First fixations had longer durations than refixations indicating a difference in pre-saccadic attention. Consistent with this finding, we observed an effect of both task-relevance and fixation type on the SRP in the interval preceding the saccade away from a target but we found no such effect for distractors. Higher SRP amplitudes were seen in the occipital region for first fixations than refixations with the opposite effect in the frontal region. Our results provide neurophysiological evidence for the effect of task-relevance and working memory load refixation on saccade planning.
Traditional talk
Watch now
The impact of advanced age on Mu Opioid Receptor signaling in the midbrain periaqueductal gray: implications on analgesia
Evan Fullerton
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Evan F. Fullerton*; Myurajan Rubaharan; Mary C. Karom; Anne Z. Murphy, PhD

Chronic pain is exceedingly prevalent in individuals over 65 years of age, but is under-managed in this population. The present studies investigated the impact of advanced age on morphine modulation of persistent inflammatory pain in male and female rats. The impact of age, sex, and pain on μ-opioid receptor (MOR) expression and binding in the ventrolateral PAG (vlPAG), a critical region in the modulation of pain, was examined using immunohistochemistry and receptor autoradiography. Additionally, we used radioligand binding assays and GTPyS assays to assess the impact of age, sex, and pain on MOR availability and affinity, and MOR induced G-protein activation. Intraplantar administration of Complete Freund's adjuvant (CFA) induced comparable levels of edema and hyperalgesia in adult (2-3mos) and aged (16-18mos) male and female rats. Morphine potency was highest in adult males, with a two-fold decrease in morphine effective concentration (EC50) observed in aged versus adult males (10.22mg/kg versus 5.19mg/kg). Adult and aged female rats also exhibited significantly higher EC50 values (10.69 mg/kg and 9.00 mg/kg, respectively) compared to adult males. The upward shift in EC50 from adult to aged males was paralleled by a reduction in vlPAG MOR expression and binding. Further, females and aged males exhibited reduced vlPAG MOR binding potential (radioligand binding assay) and reduced G-protein activation efficiency (GTPyS assay) compared to adult males. The observed age-related reductions in morphine potency, vlPAG MOR expression, MOR agonist binding, and opioid induced G-protein activation have significant implications in pain management in the aged population. Our novel findings elucidate the mechanisms responsible for reduced morphine potency in aged animals and identify potential therapeutic targets to improve pain management in the elderly.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Instantaneous Modulation of Gamma Rhythm by the difference of Time Constants of Inhibitory/Excitatory synapses
Nosratullah Mohammadi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Nosratullah Mohammadi, Alireza Valizadeh

The human brain and all other mammal brains have a distinguished gamma activity during tasks that underlie higher cognitive functions such as awareness, learning, memory, and decision making. Although numerous studies tried to clarify a mechanistic explanation of generation and modulation of brain rhythms, yet many aspects are not still well-known. In this computational study, we simulated a network of excitatory and inhibitory neurons which generates rhythmic activities in a range of slow oscillations (1-20 Hz) as well as a faster oscillation in the range (30-100 Hz). We verified a noticeable correlation between synaptic decay time constant and amplitude-frequency correlation in cycle-by-cycle population activity. Our results showed that the greater the difference of time decay of inhibitory synapses compared to that of excitatory synapses, the stronger the amplitude-frequency correlation of population activity. We also observed a change in the correlation sign of the phase of slower oscillation with the amplitude of faster oscillation depending on the difference between the decay time of excitatory synapses compared to inhibitory synapses. These results indicate that the difference between the decay time of excitatory and inhibitory synapses plays an important role in tuning of oscillatory activity of the cortical circuits.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Statistical Methods for Multiscale Comparative Connectomics
Vivek Gopalakrishnan (he/him/his)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Vivek Gopalakrishnan, JHU; Jaewon Chung, JHU; Eric Bridgeford, JHU; Jesús Arroyo, JHU; Benjamin D. Pedigo, JHU; Carey E. Priebe, JHU; Joshua T. Vogelstein, JHU;

A connectome is a map of the structural and/or functional connections in the brain. This information-rich representation has the potential to transform our understanding of the relationship between patterns in brain connectivity and neurological processes, disorders, and diseases. However, existing computational techniques used to analyze connectomes are often insufficient for interrogating multi-subject connectomics datasets. Several methods are either solely designed to analyze single connectomes, or leverage heuristic graph invariants that ignore the complete topology of connections between brain regions. To enable more rigorous comparative connectomics analysis, we introduce robust and interpretable statistical methods motivated by recent theoretical advances in random graph models. These methods enable simultaneous analysis of multiple connectomes across different scales of network topology, facilitating the discovery of hierarchical brain structures that vary in relation with phenotypic profiles. We validated these methods through extensive simulation studies, as well as synthetic and real-data experiments. Using a set of high-resolution connectomes obtained from genetically distinct mouse strains (including the BTBR mouse — a standard model of autism — and three behavioral wild-types), we show that these methods uncover valuable latent information in multi-subject connectomics data and yield novel insights into the connective correlates of neurological phenotypes.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Optical Stimulation and Recording Acquisition Software
Jeremy Forest
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jeremy Forest, Alexander Reyes

Electrophysiological recordings have traditionally been used in neuroscience to document the activities of neurons. In the last decade, optical imaging techniques have emerged as a viable alternative for examining dynamics of populations of neurons. The most recent development is a construct that permits not only recording at very high spatial, voltage, and temporal resolution but also stimulation of individual neurons completely with optical means. Thus, it is possible to record intracellular events completely non-invasively.
This technique however requires several pieces of equipment, which includes a high frame rate camera, an infrared laser, a digital light processor, movable microscope stages, and data storage devices. To precisely coordinate these hardware, we developed a software that runs on a Python platform using a modular MVC (Model-View-Controller) approach and based on the PyQT framework. The software is an efficient cost-free alternative to expensive commercial frameworks and is an open source tool that can be readily modified by the scientific community to suit their needs.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Contrast between biological and artificial neural network
krishna katyal he/him
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
bradly alicea, orthogonal lab,usa

This talk will be about the differences between ANNs and BNNs. Artificial Neural Network (ANN) is a computing system whose fundamental composition is analogous to biological neural networks. Where a node acts as soma, input acts as dendrites, weights or Interconnections acts as the synapse and the output acts as axon.Despite ANNs being a manifestation of the BNNs there exist a lot of differences.
The primary difference between ANNs and BNNs is different topologies: Instead of a network with asynchronous computing nodes, the ANNs compute one by one. Recurrent feedbacks are simulated in Long short-term memory (LSTM) networks and Recurrent neural networks but general neural networks compute the state & weights of a layer of the neural network then use the result to compute the next layer while in backpropagation the weights are improvised. Layers aren’t connected to non-neighbouring layers .IN BNNs the neurons can fire asynchronously parallelly, having dense neurons hubs and a large amount of lesser connected ones, partially following the power law (for the large values of k, the fraction P(k) of nodes in the network having k connections to other nodes as P(k) ~ k -z where z generally lies from 2 to 3, although may lie outside these bounds ). Due to their topology the BNNs are better at fault and ambiguity tolerant as there is no central part, they can heal and are self-regenerated to some extent.The size of ANNs and BNNs also vary,there are 10 11 neurons in the brain whereas computational considerations limited ANNs nowadays to 10 5 neurons. As far as the energy consumption is concerned the human brain has nearly 20 watts of power consumption whereas a GPU (graphics processing unit) used for training artificial neural networks consumes somewhere from 150 to 250 watts, Human brain is highly efficient in comparison to the GPUs.Different between the ANNs and BNNs are (but not limited to) topologies,fault tolerance,size and energy consumption prominent differences between the BNNs and ANNs
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Expectation, In and Of Choice
Brandon Caie
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Brandon Caie, Queen's University; Paul Schrater, University of Minnesota, Aarlenne Khan, Universite de Montreal; Gunnar Blohm, Queen's University

Expectations guide choice. Scientists repeat the sensory conditions in which a choice is made so as to statistically sample an underlying expectation. The statistics of a process can be deduced in this manner if it is ergodic, that is if a collection of samples at one time captures the dynamics of the process at all times. Popular models of choice treat expectation as ergodic within a trial, subject to change between trials. We analyzed the temporal dynamics of expectation in a free choice saccade task, and found that expectations evolved within as well as between trials. We embedded reinforcement learning into an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) process to model expectation as a continuous dynamic. The OU process reaches a steady-state at a predicted time of choice, rather than at true sensory onset, accounting for empirical history effects in anticipatory behaviour. The model suggests that expectations should be understood as a predictive dynamic interacting with an environment, rather than a stationary parameter locked to choice onset. We provide normative arguments for the cost and benefit of different reinforcement strategies in this model.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Chronic imaging of local populations in auditory cortex reveals ongoing recombination of neuronal ensembles representing sensory stimuli
Dominik Aschauer (he)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Bastian Eppler, FIAS Frankfurt; Matthias Kaschube, FIAS Frankfurt; Simon Rumpel, JGU Mainz

Neuronal ensembles are believed to form essential functional units within neural networks. How structurally and functionally stable are such ensembles? This question is of particular interest in light of evidence that synaptic connections show substantial remodeling on the time scale of days. At the same time, the perception of external stimuli has to be highly reliable, while allowing for flexible integration of novel experiences to form associations to already known stimuli.
Using chronic imaging of local population activity in mouse auditory cortex, we show that neuronal responses to short sounds typically cluster into a near discrete set of response modes. Moreover, we find that response modes show significant remodeling over several days. We identify a set of elementary operations capturing the dynamics of sensory representations, which involve changes in the set of stimuli driving particular response modes as well as their formation and elimination.
We demonstrate that stable encoding of external stimuli is maintained in activity patterns of local populations despite ongoing remodeling of sensory representations. Training a decoder based on logistic regression using information on a single time point either from single cell activity or from response mode patterns, respectively, is sufficient to decode stimulus identity over long time scales. Auditory fear conditioning introduces biases in the frequency of specific operations mediating increased associations of sensory stimuli and improved sound encoding. The ongoing recombination of neuronal ensembles provides a mechanism for the integration of novel stimulus information by associative learning paradigms.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Differential modular dynamics in marmoset cortex during conscious and unconscious states
Dominic Standage
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Yuki Hori; Ravi S. Menon; Stefan Everling; Jason P. Gallivan

Consciousness is the state of wakefulness and awareness characterised by the ability to sense and respond to stimuli. In recent years, our understanding of the mechanisms underlying consciousness has been greatly improved by the study of unconsciousness with general anaesthetics. While much of this work has focused on the cellular effects of anaesthesia, several recent studies have used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to investigate whole-brain, network-level changes linked to these cellular effects. The dynamics of whole-brain states have been shown to differ between periods of consciousness and unconsciousness, with a smaller repertoire of brain states observed during unconsciousness, and fewer transitions between these states (Barttfeld et al, PNAS, 2015). These whole-brain analyses have been invaluable for characterising the systems-level bases of consciousness, providing evidence for theoretical accounts of conscious experience. This approach, however, does not consider the modular configurations (and reconfigurations) that constitute these whole-brain states, and that have been linked to cognition (Bassett et al, PNAS, 2011; Braun et al, PNAS, 2015). We quantified these modular dynamics during wakeful rest and anaesthesia-induced unconsciousness, using resting state fMRI with the common marmoset (Callithrix jacchus; Hori et al, Cereb Cortex, 2020). We found that the awake condition was characterised by more coordinated reconfiguration of a smaller number of modules, and by greater stability among whole-brain networks derived from these modules. Conversely, the anaesthetised condition was characterised by the more haphazard reconfiguration of a larger number of modules and a decrease in network integrity. Our findings are consistent with the hypothesis that unconsciousness results from the fragmentation of whole-brain networks, and that the coordinated reconfiguration of modular structure is a marker of cognitive engagement in the conscious state.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Spiking Time-Dependent Plasticity implements self-organized resonances
Pau Vilimelis Aceituno
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Pau Vilimelis Aceituno, ETH Zürich

Neural populations exposed to a certain stimulus learn to represent it better. However, the process that leads local, self-organized rules to do so is unclear. We address the question of how can a neural periodic input be learned and use the Differential Hebbian Learning framework, coupled with a homeostatic mechanism to derive two self-consistency equations that lead to increased responses to the same stimulus. Although all our simulations are done with simple Leaky-Integrate and Fire neurons and standard Spiking Time Dependent Plasticity learning rules,
our results can be easily interpreted in terms of rates and population codes.
This talk is mostly theoretical, but during the interactive part I would like to discuss biological predictions and neurorobotic implementations.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Transcriptomic contributions to the cytoarchitectonic parcellation of the human cerebral cortex.
Leana King
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Leana King, Helen Wills Neuroscience Institute, University of California Berkeley, Berkeley, California; Jesse Gomez, Princeton Neuroscience Institute, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ; Zonglei Zhen,Beijing Key Laboratory of Applied Experimental Psychology, Beijing Normal University, Beijing, China, Faculty of Psychology, Beijing Normal University, Beijing, China; Kevin S. Weiner, Helen Wills Neuroscience Institute, University of California Berkeley, Berkeley, California, Psychology Department, University of California Berkeley, Berkeley, California.

Abstract:
Transcriptomic contributions to the functional and anatomical parcellation of the human cerebral cortex has become a major interest in systems neuroscience in the last decade. Recent research shows that active transcription of a small set of genes contributes to large-scale gradients and functional hierarchies in the human cerebral cortex (1,2). The combination of our previous findings has shown that different sets of genes contribute to the positioning of cortical areas within functional hierarchies (2) and the organization of functional maps within each cortical area (3). Here, we tested if either set of genes previously identified better explained the recent identification of over 88 cytoarchitectonic areas (4). Using a data-driven approach, we show that the genes previously identified to explain the functional organization of the visual processing hierarchy in human cortex better explains the arealization of these 88 cytoarchitectonic areas than the genes explaining functional maps within each visual area. Importantly, follow-up analyses show that an additional set of genes contribute to the cytoarchitectonic parcellation of the human cerebral cortex beyond those genes contributing to the parcellation of the human visual processing hierarchy. These results support a novel hypothesis that there is a nested spatial relationship among transcriptomic, anatomical, and functional parcellations of the human cerebral cortex at the level of maps (mm; areal), gradients and hierarchies (cm; within lobes), and networks (several cm; across lobes). We conclude by showing that a microanatomical substrate supporting this hypothesis across spatial scales is cell density.
References:
1. Burt JB, Demirtaş M, Eckner WJ, Navejar NM, Ji JL, Martin WJ, et al. Hierarchy of transcriptomic specialization across human cortex captured by structural neuroimaging topography. Nat Neurosci. 2018. 21(9): 1251–1259.
2. Gomez J, Zhen Z, Weiner KS. Human visual cortex is organized along two genetically opposed hierarchical gradients with unique developmental and evolutionary origins. PLoS Biology. 2019. 17(7). e3000362.
3. Zhen, Z. Gomez, J., & Weiner, K. S. Opposing transcriptomic gradients explain orthogonal maps in human visual areas. bioRxiv. 2019.
4. Amunts K, Mohlberg H, Bludau S, Zilles K. Julich-Brain: A 3D probabilistic atlas of the human brain's cytoarchitecture. Science. 2020. 369(6506): 988-992.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Mechanism of Temporal Interference stimulation using in-vitro and in silico model of hippocampal gamma oscillation
Zeinab Esmaeilpour
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Greg Kronberg, City college of New York; Davide Reato,Champalimaud Centre for the Unknown, Neuroscience Program, Lisbon, Portuga; lucas C parra, city college of New York; Marom Bikson, city college of New York

It has been suggested that transcranial electrical stimulation using Temporal Interferential (TI) stimulation can be leveraged in neuromodulation of deep brain regions where the two high-frequency (kHz) electric fields intersect, and form Amplitude-Modulated waveform with low beating frequency (tens of Hz). However, superficial regions are exposed to higher magnitude but unmodulated sine waveform with a steady amplitude. The mechanisms through which CNS could be sensitive to Amplitude-Modulated with kHz carrier frequency but not unmodulated sinusoidal waveform is not yet understood. Explaining the cellular mechanism of Amplitude-Modulated high-frequency stimulation is thus of interest in developing rational optimized stimulation strategies. The effect of Amplitude-Modulated high-frequency electric fields on ongoing network activity was evaluated in carbachol-induced gamma oscillation in CA3a region of rat hippocampal slices. Extracellular local field potentials were analyzed before, during and after 2 s of stimulation. We tested unmodulated sine waveforms with low frequency (i.e. 5 Hz), kHz frequency (i.e. 1 and 2 kHz) and 5 Hz Amplitude-Modulated waveforms with 0.1, 1, and 2 kHz carrier frequencies. A validated MRI-derived head model predicted both peak electric fields in the cortex and depth of Amplitude-Modulation at deep regions during TI. We further developed a computational model of excitatory/inhibitory neuronal network with conductance-based synaptic interactions to explain the experimental results. Both experiment and model confirmed the hypothesis that spatial selectivity of temporal interference stimulation depends on the phasic modulation of neural oscillations only in deep brain regions. Adaptation mechanism (e.g. GABAb) enhanced sensitivity to amplitude modulated waveform in contrast to unmodulated kHz and produced selectivity in modulating gamma oscillation. Selection of carrier frequency strongly affected sensitivity to amplitude modulation stimulation. The TI sensitivity (current required at the scalp) depends on the active neuronal membrane time-constant approaching the kHz carrier frequency.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
NeuroGraphMatch
Ali Saad-Eldin (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Benjamin D. Pedigo, Johns Hopkins University; Youngser Park, Johns Hopkins University; Carey E. Priebe, Johns Hopkins University; Joshua T. Vogelstein, Johns Hopkins University

A network is defined as a set of nodes connected by a set of edges. In neuroscience, the structure of the brain (connectome) can be modeled as a network, where neurons or regions of interest are thought of as nodes, and the connections between these regions are thought of as edges. Through the use of functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) as well as diffusion tensor imaging (DTI), one can estimate the presence of “nodes” and “edges”in the brain, thus representing it as a graph. Additional advancements in methodologies involving electron microscopy have allowed for the ability to capture information on individual neurons and synapses. This has made the use of network statistics important in the study of brains. Specifically, the graph matching algorithm (also known as the quadratic assignment problem) seeks to quantify the underlying similarity between two networks, determining an alignment of nodes between them. This analysis can be utilized to quantify similarities in inter- and intra-species connectomes, or to predict homologous neuron pairs across brain hemispheres. Through the use of available and simulated data, we will demonstrate the efficacy of our Fast Approximate Quadratic assignment algorithm (FAQ) Python implementation (now in SciPy and graspologic), and showcase it’s applications in the fields of computational neuroscience and, more broadly, combinatorial optimization.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
New ways to analyze and visualize large-scale network activity in sea slugs with single-neuron, single-spike resolution
Viral Mistry
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jeffrey Brown, RFUMS; Evan Hill, RFUMS; William Frost, RFUMS

Despite an ever-growing body of research elucidating how neural networks produce behavior, the contributions of specific neurons within those networks are often poorly understood. In particular, achieving both the temporal and spatial resolution in activity recordings of neuronal populations required to develop detailed bottom-up insights about how behavior is generated has proven to be a challenge for network neuroscience. Simple nervous systems, like those of gastropod mollusks, comprise relatively few, large, mostly superficial and individually identifiable neurons. This enables both electrophysiological and optical recordings with single-neuron, single-spike specificity over significant portions of those nervous systems, allowing for more thorough neuroethological investigation. Here, we discuss several computational tools we have recently developed to visualize and animate optical data collected in the brains of gastropod mollusks as a part of a BRAIN Initiative project taking a multi-dimensional approach to understanding how networks produce behavior. Large-scale optical recordings are obtained of motor programs of interest, using a photodiode array imaging at 1,600 samples/s and a fast-absorbance voltage-sensitive dye. These signals are then blind source separated into individual neuronal activity traces using independent component analysis. A custom algorithm maps the individual neuronal signals onto their source neurons in the recorded brain region, and then animates these maps to generate audiovisual “playbacks” of network activity with high spatiotemporal resolution. Through the use of a previously developed unsupervised community detection algorithm, we can also derive the functional neuronal ensembles operating during behavioral programs. Together, these tools constitute an ultra-fast workflow that provides same-day insights about both single-cell activity and network organization in recorded brain regions. This approach is well-suited to exploring network function in little studied, nontransgenic species, such as we are currently doing with the nudibranch Berghia stephanieae.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The Shallow Brain
Eric Wong
 
Abstract
 
We present here a model for the core computational architecture that supports cognitive processes in the brain. We base our model on three premises: 1) The brain represents abstractions as groups of active neurons, here referred to as attractors. 2) Most learning is implemented by creating associations between abstractions, exemplified by classical conditioning or learning the many incremental associations we are taught in our first few decades of life that impress into our brains the distilled accumulated intelligence of our species. 3) Any combination of attractors can serve as either input or output for a given association. Together these suggest that the architecture of the brain is primarily an unstructured network, where new attractors can be created as new abstractions are learned, and associated with other attractors. The well-established STDP mechanism has been shown to support both the construction and association of attractors from an initially random network.
Such a network may account for aspects of cognition that are composed of explicit associations between identifiable abstractions, but likely does not support the unconscious, automatic, or intuitive processing that implement implicit thought. We hypothesize that the associative network of attractors is embedded in (and derives from) a background of randomly connected neurons, and that the action of the associative network can train this background network to implement implicit thought by exciting the desired output attractors and connecting them by STDP to active neurons in the background network, much as in reservoir learning. If this process is repeated using an incremental learning curriculum, the background network can develop elements that are functionally hierarchical, despite a lack of initial structure.
We note that the architecture described here is amenable to single-shot learning, and because it does not propagate signals for synaptic changes through the network, likely insensitive to catastrophic forgetting.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Optimal control of approach-avoidance dynamics
Harrison Ritz (He/Him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Amitai Shenhav; Benjamin Hayden; Seng Bum Yoo

Animals must continuously adjust their behavior to pursue potential rewards (e.g., chasing prey) while evading potential threats (e.g., avoiding predators). To behave optimally, animals must also use their knowledge about the dynamics of their environment (e.g., a predators’ agility) to guide their actions. The current experiment seeks to develop a computational framework for understanding this goal pursuit.

Computational models of approach-avoid behaviors have been largely limited to describing simplified economic choices, without providing a clear understanding of how continuous actions are controlled across time. Our approach leverages engineering algorithms from Optimal Control Theory, a framework also used in computational models of online motor control. These models are inherently well-suited for describing the continuous dynamics of natural behavior, while being far less computationally demanding than model-based planning over discretized states and actions.

In the current project, we sought to understand how rhesus macaques (Macaca mulatta) played a dynamic predator-prey computer game. Monkeys controlled an avatar with a joystick, chasing a prey avatar to gain juice and evading a predator avatar to avoid a timeout. We used Inverse Optimal Control to infer the valuation of prey capture and predator avoidance that best explained monkeys' actions under a standard optimal control algorithm (iLQR). Our model predicted the monkeys’ full trajectories well above chance, including in held-out trials. The model’s inferred values on prey and predator were also significantly correlated with the amount of reward and punishment at stake, reflecting the animals’ understanding of the task.

Optimal control theory offers rational process models for translating appetitive and aversive goals into extended behaviors, while maintaining computational feasibility. These models make testable predictions about the representations necessary for control and provide a normative baseline against which to compare alternative accounts, catalyzing our understanding of how animals pursue their goals.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Temporal graphs reveal the subset of spikes informative of visual stimulus
Maayan Levy
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jeff Kaihao Guo, University of Chicago; Jason N. MacLean, University of Chicago

Which spikes give rise to a percept is a key question in neuroscience. Yet, spiking activity varies from trial to trial despite conditions being ostensibly identical, making identification of the information conveying spikes difficult. One approach is to use functional connectivity, i.e. the pairwise statistical dependency between neurons and then identify how these functional connections dynamically manifest, summarized as a temporal graph (TG). We used 2-photon calcium imaging to study populations of pyramidal neurons in mouse primary visual cortex in response to 12 directions of drifting gratings and inferred spikes from resultant fluorescence. We then computed a functional connectivity matrix (FN) for each of the 12 directions as lagged mutual information between each pair of neurons over the full time course of stimulus presentation - i.e. the ‘static’ FN for each direction. Next we intersected the static FN with the spiking activity to build a TG: a tensor summarizing which spikes are an expression of functional connectivity. We find that these TGs are sparse and their density profiles are correlated in trials of the same direction. We further parse TGs according to four edge types, based on similarity between different grating directions. We find that a specific subnetwork, capturing interactions that are strong for one stimulus and weak for similar stimuli, is sparse with strong weights and displays a balance in feedforward and recurrent spiking patterns. Decoding only from spikes that are a manifestation of this subgraph yields better performance, as compared to decoding from raw spiking activity and from other subgraphs that capture fully unique or fully shared edges between directions. Our results demonstrate that despite trial-to-trial variability, the time evolution of spikes in response to visual stimuli follows a predictable trajectory and a specific subset of the spikes are needed to successfully decode information about direction.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Influence of the BDNF Val66Met Polymorphism on Modulation of Functional Brain Networks
Vicente Alba Suarez (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Vicente Alba Suarez, York University; Katherine M. Newman, York University; Caitlin Mullin, York University; Georg R. Zoidl, York University, Mark Halko, Harvard Medical School; Gary R. Turner, York University; & W. Dale Stevens, York University

Human brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) is an important protein responsible for the development and maintenance of neurons. Polymorphisms (i.e., genetic variations) of the BDNF protein have been implicated in overall reduction of functional connectivity (FC) within and between large-scale functional brain networks. Specifically, the well studied Val66Met BDNF polymorphism has been shown to impact connectivity of the default mode network (DMN), a group of brain regions critically involved in internally focused cognition. Furthermore, this polymorphism of BDNF protein has been shown to influence the effectiveness of non-invasive brain stimulation (NIBS) techniques, such as repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS). This presents a potential problem in using NIBS to modulate FC of brain networks in experimental and clinical settings (e.g., treatment of depression). We used resting-state functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) in combination with intermittent and continuous theta burst rTMS in young adults to evaluate the influence of the Val66Met polymorphism of BDNF on baseline FC of large-scale intrinsic functional networks, and the ability to modulate within and between-network FC using NIBS. The rTMS target stimulation site selected was the left inferior parietal lobule (IPL), a core node of the DMN, and was identified individually for a Val homozygote and a Met homozygote through functional task fMRI data. Resting-state fMRI data were collected before and after administering rTMS to the IPL. Results showed a reduction in baseline FC for a Met homozygote compared to a Val homozygote, both within the DMN and between the DMN and other large-scale brain networks. Furthermore, we found the ability to modulate within and between-network FC through rTMS was improved for a Val homozygote compared to a Met homozygote. These findings suggest that differences at the cellular level can influence differences in large-scale brain networks that impact the efficacy of rTMS methods according to individuals’ genotype.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Blaming blunders on the brain: can indifferent choices be driven by range adaptation or synaptic plasticity?
Jules BROCHARD (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jean Daunizeau, Institut du Cerveau et de la Moelle Épinière

Computational investigations of learning and decision making suggestthat systematic deviations to adaptive behavior may be the incidental outcome of biological constraints imposed on neural informationprocessing. In particular, recent studies indicate that range adaptation, i.e.,the mechanism by which neurons dynamically tune their output firing properties to match the changing statistics of their inputs, may drive plastic changes in the brain’s decision system that induce systematic deviations to rationality. Here, we ask whether behaviorally-relevant neural information processing may be distorted by other incidental, hard-wired,biological constraints, in particular: Hebbian plasticity. One of our main contributionsis to propose a simple computational method for identifying (and comparing) the neural signature of such biological mechanisms or constraints. Using ANNs (i.e., artificial neural network models) and RSA (i.e.,representational similarity analysis), we compare the neural signatures of two types of hard-wired biological mechanisms/constraints: namely, range adaptation and Hebbian plasticity. We apply the approach totwo different open fMRI datasets acquired when people make decisions under risk. In both cases, we show that although peoples' apparentindifferent choicesarewell explainedby biologically-constrained ANNs, choice data alone does not discriminate between range adaptation and Hebbian plasticity. However, RSA shows that neural activity patterns in bilateral Striatum and Amygdala are more compatible withHebbian plasticity. Finally, the strength of evidence forHebbian plasticity in these structures predicts inter-individual differences in choice inconsistency.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Recurrent Neural Networks reveal distinct signal flow in mouse visual cortex following expectation violations
Akul Gupta
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Farzaneh Najafi

A prominent theory in neuroscience has been the predictive coding theory, where top-down inputs provide predictions, which are compared with the bottom-up sensory inputs. Predictions are subsequently updated if they deviate from the actual sensory inputs (Rao & Ballard, 1999). To investigate the neural circuit mechanisms that underlie predictive coding, we need to study brain area interactions while animal’s predictions are violated. To this end, we used Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN’s) to analyze cortical layer and area interactions during a visual task, which involved expectation violations.

In brief, Multiplane Mesoscopes were used to simultaneously image 4 cortical depths of 2 visual areas (V1 and LM), while mice performed an image-change detection task. Three mouse lines, which were tagged for excitatory and two inhibitory subpopulations (VIP and SST), were used in our study. The behavioral task involved repeated and regular presentation of images (expected events), as well as the following two unexpected events: 1) infrequent and random omissions of the visual stimulus; 2) presentation of a novel image set after several days of training with a different (familiar) image set.

We fit the activity of units in an RNN model to the activity of individual neurons (Andalman et al., 2019) to study how unexpected events modify signal flow between cortical layers and areas. By comparing the weight distributions of RNN units, we demonstrate that functional connectivity between visual areas and layers changes following the presentation of novel images. Furthermore, functional connectivity was differentially modified for excitatory and inhibitory cell types.

Overall, our results demonstrate the use of RNN’s to investigate the cortical circuitries that underlie the representation and updating of prediction signals.
Interactive talk
Watch now
No evidence for entrainment: endogenous gamma oscillations and rhythmic flicker responses coexist in visual cortex
Katharina Duecker
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tjerk P Gutteling, Centre for Human Brain Health, School of Psychology, University of Birmingham; Christoph S Herrmann, Experimental Psychology Lab, Department of Psychology, European Medical School, Cluster of Excellence “Hearing for All”, Carl von Ossietzky University, Oldenburg, Germany; Ole Jensen, Centre for Human Brain Health, School of Psychology, University of Birmingham

Oscillatory brain activity in response to rhythmically presented stimuli is widely utilised in neurocognitive research to investigate visual perception. It has been suggested that endogenous neuronal oscillations can synchronise to rhythmic stimulation, a phenomenon widely termed entrainment.
Motivated by the plethora of studies showing the involvement of neuronal gamma oscillations (~30-100 Hz) in cognition, we aimed to study to what extent photic stimulation at frequencies >50 Hz drives ongoing gamma oscillations in the human brain. To this end, we systematically investigated oscillatory responses to a rhythmic flicker in absence and presence of endogenous gamma oscillations using magnetoencephalography (MEG). Utilising a high-frequency projector, we superimposed the photic stimulation, with frequencies ranging from 52 to 90 Hz, onto an invisible circular patch and moving grating stimuli known to reliably induce gamma oscillations, respectively. Power and phase-locking were found to decrease approximately linearly with increasing flicker frequency; with no amplification at individually preferred frequencies, suggesting that the visual system did not resonate within the stimulation range. Unexpectedly, this was also the case when gamma oscillations were induced. Moreover, the rhythmic stimulation did not appear to modulate the frequency or phase of the gamma oscillations. Rather, the results indicate a co-existence of both responses, with the sources of the flicker response and the gamma oscillations peaking at significantly different locations in visual cortex. As there was no modulation of endogenous oscillations by visual stimulation, our findings challenge the notion that the phenomenon of neuronal entrainment generalises to gamma oscillations.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Statistical tools for nanoscale connectomics: clustering neurons in the Drosophila larva brain and other applications
Benjamin Pedigo
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Benjamin D. Pedigo, Johns Hopkins University; Michael Winding, University of Cambridge/MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology; Ali Saad-Eldin, Johns Hopkins University; Tingshan Liu, Johns Hopkins University; Albert Cardona, University of Cambridge/MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology; Marta Zlatic, University of Cambridge/MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology; Carey E. Priebe, Johns Hopkins University; Joshua T. Vogelstein, Johns Hopkins University

Connectomics (the study of neural wiring) is a relatively new discipline in neuroscience. Complete circuit mapping at the synaptic scale (nanoscale) has the potential to inform wide ranging questions in neuroscience, such as understanding how circuit architecture leads to activity, or how genetics or disease affect neural architecture. Recent technological advances are enabling connectomics datasets to scale into the tens or hundreds of thousands of neurons and millions of synapses. Increasingly, learning from and comparing such large connectome datasets will require techniques for statistical learning on network data. Here we describe several examples of such statistical techniques on the Drosophila larva connectome.
