For example, we present methodology for clustering and model fitting on the connectome, and show that statistical models of networks can be used to inform the clustering process. We show that the connectivity-based clustering is sensible in terms of known cell types, but also suggests new groupings of neurons for investigation. Then, we briefly touch on other statistical techniques and how they can be applied to connectomes. These methods will enable automated analyses of connectomes at scale (such as classifying cells into types based on their connectivity), but also serve as a basis for future work on comparing connectomes across individual, taxa, or disease state, for example. We provide implementations of all of these methods via an open-source Python package, graspologic. For discussion in this interactive session, we also ask the community what analysis techniques will be the most important to develop as the field moves forward.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Whole-brain imaging of Danionella Translucida with oblique plane microscopy
Maximilian Hoffmann
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Maximilian Hoffmann, Einstein Center for Neurosciences, NeuroCure Cluster of Excellence, Charité Universitätsmedizin, Berlin, Germany ; Jörg Heninnger,Einstein Center for Neurosciences, NeuroCure Cluster of Excellence, Charité Universitätsmedizin, Berlin, Germany; Benjamin Judkewitz,Einstein Center for Neurosciences, NeuroCure Cluster of Excellence, Charité Universitätsmedizin, Berlin, Germany;

Because the fish Danionella translucida remains small and transparent even in adulthood, it is potentially possible to optically interrogate neuronal networks at single-cell resolution across an entire adult brain. However a suitable microscopy technique, which has a field of view encompassing the whole brain and permits to record at least at the speed on the order of the decay time of Calcium indicators, is lacking.
Here we present a novel microscope, which fulfils these criteria. By introducing a new solution for the central re-imaging geometry of oblique plane microscopy we extend the family of these microscopy techniques to larger field of views. We are therefore able to record from a volume of 2600 µm x 1000 µm x 850 µm at 1Hz, while maintaining an optical resolution below the size of a single cell. We use this technique to persistently record neural activity of a neural population distributed throughout the whole brain of Danionella translucida.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Approaching Artificial Intelligence as an Embodied Developmental Process
Jesse Parent
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Bradly Alicea, OpenWorm Foundation, Orthogonal Research and Education Lab; Rishabh Chakrabarty, Manipal Academy Of Higher Education, Orthogonal Research & Education Lab; Akshara Gopi, Manipal Academy Of Higher Education, Orthogonal Research & Education Lab; Anson Lim, Western Michigan University, Orthogonal Research & Education Lab; Furkan Özçelik, Brain and Cognition Research Center in Toulouse, Orthogonal Research & Education Lab

In this submission, we will lay out an argument for building artificial intelligence (AI) based on biological development. A developmental AI consists of three components: an embodied input/output network, a critical period for information acquisition and connectivity, and a network topology that expands over time according to the principles of contingency and developmental freedom. Developmental contingency restricts the developmental neural network to an increasingly limited set of possible trajectories. While contingency results in earlier developmental events (cell differentiation) to constrain the range of possibilities for future developmental events (formation of a network motif), developmental freedom is the tendency for information and representations in particular to take advantage of a stable underlying topology. This contributes to an artificial brain that acts as a generative network with a further capacity for behavioral complexity.

We will demonstrate examples for each of these points using developmental Braitenberg Vehicles (dBVs) as the subject of thought experiments. These thought experiments will take the form of a contingency analysis of a typical dBV input/output network topology. This analysis shows how embodiment developmental agents provide three potentially powerful mechanisms for the emergence of adaptive intelligent systems. First, the presence of an embodied input/output network can act to structure input data. Secondly, the existence of a critical period embedded within the developmental process acts to structure association-building through network complexity. Finally, developmental freedom results from the placement of the critical period within a sequence of events defining the biological developmental process, which in turn can enhance both information acquisition and network structure. In conclusion, we will discuss potential benchmarks and future advances in the developmental approach, including the application of epigenetic landscapes to characterize the formation of a neural network topology.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The Sense of Joint Agency in Sensorimotor Interaction
Cecilia De Vicariis
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Vinil T. Chackochan, Bournemoth University; Vittorio Sanguineti, University of Genoa

Computational models have provided important contributions to unveiling the mechanisms underlying individual action and the sense of self agency – the subjective feeling of being in control of our own actions. The development of computational models is even more necessary to understand the mechanisms underlying joint actions and the subjective experiences of control which emerge during this kind of situations.
Understanding the partner and choosing mutually satisfactory strategies are key components in joint action and in the development of the sense of joint agency. The development of a partner representation is incorporated in the process of state estimation and, with the body predictions, determines the selection of the control strategies. Game theory - the study of strategic interaction of self-interested agents – constitutes a natural extension of optimal control when multiple agents are involved.
Here we propose a modular computational architecture, which integrates the classical motor control theories - optimal estimation and optimal control - and extends them to reconcile the sense of self and joint agency during interactions.
Models and simulations based on optimal estimation and game theory provide insights regarding what we represent of a partner, which strategies we adopt and how these strategies evolve with time and training during joint action. They also provide a conceptual basis for extending the notion of self agency to that of joint agency.
The sense of agency is described in probabilistic terms, as a dynamic decision process, which continuously evaluates the assumptions underlying each observer-controller pair of the proposed modular architecture. Agency relates to reasoning about ourselves: our role in the action, the perceived features of our body and environment, presence of additional partners or opponents; their actions and intentions. During movements, the sense of agency gates each control signal thus providing the basis for optimal action selection.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Top-down and bottom-up information flow in visually responsive neural populations: a Granger causality analysis on high-frequency broadband amplitude from intracranial electrodes.
Guillaume Corlouer
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Guillaume Corlouer, Sackler center for consciousness science and Department of Informatics, University of Sussex, Falmer,Brighton, BN1 9QJ, UK; Yitzhak Norman, Department of Neurobiology, Weizmann Institute of Science, 76100, Rehovot, Israel; Rafael Malach; Department of Neurobiology, Weizmann Institute of Science, 76100, Rehovot, Israel, CIFAR Program on Brain, Mind, and Consciousness, Toronto, Ontario, Canada; Lionel Barnett, Sackler center for consciousness science and Department of Informatics, University of Sussex, Falmer,Brighton, BN1 9QJ, UK; Anil Seth, Sackler center for consciousness science and Department of Informatics, University of Sussex, Falmer,Brighton, BN1 9QJ, UK, CIFAR Program on Brain, Mind, and Consciousness, Toronto, Ontario, Canada; Ashesh D. Mehta, Department of Neurosurgery, Donald and Barbara Zucker School of Medicine at Hofstra/Northwell, and Feinstein Institute for Medical Research, Manhasset, NY, 11030, USA

How does information flow among visually-responsive neural populations along the visual cortex hierarchy? We address this question by estimating transfer entropy from state-space Granger causality modeling on intracranial EEG (iEEG) data. In an exploratory analysis, we conduct pairwise and groupwise conditional Granger causality on a high-frequency broadband envelope of iEEG signals recorded from 10 epileptic patients. The high-frequency broadband envelope has been shown to be highly correlated with local neural population firing rates, and so is a relevant biomarker of local neural activity. We model information flow between visually responsive populations in three distincts conditions: a resting state condition, a place stimulus presentation and a face stimulus presentation. In each of these conditions we examine the magnitudes of top-down and bottom-up information flow between visually responsive neural populations in both higher and lower areas of the occipito-temporal cortical hierarchy. Signals are treated as multivariate, multiple-trial time series, for which we show that state space modeling yields stable models from which Granger causality can be inferred - a difficult challenge given the non-stationarity of the signals involved. From these state-space models, we first infer groupwise conditional Granger causality between visually responsive functional groups of channels, to model information flow between functional regions along the occipito-temporal hierarchy. We then run a pairwise-conditional Granger causality analysis between individual visually responsive channels in these groups, to further explore modes of information transfer in local neural populations between and within visually responsive sites. The aim of this exploratory study is to motivate hypotheses about distinct modes of top-down and bottom-up information flow between face and non-face selective regions of the visual cortex.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Mentation rate during resting state fMRI and trait depressive rumination: Is there a difference between depressed and never-depressed individuals? (A CAN-BIND-4 Analysis)
Scott Squires
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Julie Tseng, Queen's University; Mojdeh Zamayadi, Baycrest Health Sciences Centre; Stefanie Hassel, University of Calgary; Stephen Strother, Baycrest Health Sciences Centre; Glenda MacQueen, University of Calgary; Sidney Kennedy, St. Michael's Hospital; Roumen Milev, Queen's University; Kate Harkness, Queen's University; Jordan Poppenk, Queen's University

Trait depressive rumination (DR) is the tendency to dwell on the causes, meanings, and consequences of distressing feelings, and is a major risk factor for depressive and other psychiatric disorders. DR is usually assessed with the Response Styles Questionnaire, which has two subscales: Brooding measures the tendency to passively compare one's situation with an unachieved standard, while Reflection measures the tendency to engage in cognitive problem solving to alleviate feelings of distress. A conceptually related construct to DR is mentation rate (MR), or the number of discrete thoughts that one has over time. Little is known about how DR is represented in resting state brain activity measured via functional MRI (RS-fMRI) or if people who frequently ruminate also tend to have a higher MR or lower MR. In this analysis, a novel fMRI processing technique was used to objectively assess individuals’ MR based on the rate of simultaneous whole-brain network activity transitions (Tseng & Poppenk, 2020). This technique was useful for studying DR because it prevented metacognition about one’s DR from biasing the assessment of MR (e.g. via self-report).

Archival RSQ and RS-fMRI data from 88 depressed and 63 never-depressed adults, collected as part of the Canadian Biomarker Integration Network for Depression: Stress and Reward in Anhedonia (CAN-BIND-4: SARA) study, were used to assess DR and network transition rate (TR; a metric of MR), respectively. Multiple linear regression was used to evaluate the RSQ-TR association, controlling for age and sex: Brooding, but not Reflection, was associated with a slower resting TR, independent of depression status. This evidence suggests that individuals who report a greater tendency to brood in response to negative feelings also have a smaller number of discrete thoughts during rest, which may provide some explanation for why brooding thoughts tend to be characterized by repetitive thinking and dwelling.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Biologically Plausible Fast and Statistical Sequence Learning with RNNs
Huzi Cheng
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Huzi Cheng, Indiana University Bloomington; Joshua William Brown, , Indiana University Bloomington;

Two dilemmas exist on sequence learning in brains and artificial RNNs. The first is the nature and function of well-known reverse replay in the hippocampus, which is crucial to memory consolidation and sequence learning. Different models have been proposed regarding replay, while how replays support learning remains unclear. Neural activities in existing models are usually limited to “one-hot” representations, i.e., only one neuron (or geometrically clustered neurons) is transiently active during the replay period. This prevents flexible high dimensional sequence learning. Second, the main training algorithm used for RNNs, Backpropagation through time (BPTT), is thought to be biologically implausible, since it requires cached storage of hidden and input layer activity across multiple time steps.

We propose here how a reverse replay RNN may act as a fast learning teacher (i.e. the hippocampus), which provides information to statistically train an RNN (i.e. memory consolidation in cortex).

To demonstrate this, we developed a gated RNN (fast learning) and a mutually coupled RNN (slow, statistical learning). The fast RNN forms stable line attractors in the neural state space (not one-hot). It utilizes oscillations to facilitate fast, stable sequence learning and arbitrarily bidirectional replay on random sequence patterns. The slow RNN consists of two neuron groups with mutual excitatory/inhibitory connections. With different E/I balance levels and the help of reversed inputs, this competition determines the network running direction, generating either forward or backward replays. These replays may train the slow RNN with the power of BPTT but with only local connectivity and plasticity rules, and no requirement to cache neural activities of previous time steps.

The coupled fast and slow RNNs may not only provide an alternative mechanism of biologically plausible sequence learning but also suggest how hippocampus and cortex produce memory consolidation.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
The color of the flash attenuates its mislocalization in the flash-jump illusion
Harpreet Saini (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Heather Jordan, York University; Mazyar Fallah, York University

Recent studies have demonstrated the modulatory role of task-irrelevant color on higher-level cognitive tasks involving response inhibition. In this study, we investigated whether color also affects visual perception earlier in the visual processing hierarchy, using the flash-jump illusion. In this illusion when an apparent motion stimulus, i.e. a rectangular bar appearing at different locations along a trajectory, changes color at a single position, observers perceive this color change as occurring farther along the trajectory of motion. This mislocalization error has been shown to be dependent on responses in area V4, an intermediate stage in the ventral visual stream. Our results demonstrated that the color of the flash modulated the magnitude of the flash-jump effect such that participants reported less of a shift, i.e. a more veridical flash location, for both red and blue flashes, as compared to green and yellow. This pattern of color effects was present for both accuracy and precision in localizing the flash. Given that neural correlates of the flash jump effect are found in area V4, our findings suggest that color-dependent modulations of perceptual processes can occur as early as the intermediate stages of visual processing. Since the color of the flash affected its localization, these color modulations must be inherent and automatic in visual processing.
Keynote Event
Watch now
Impact of developmental dysfunction of parvalbumin interneurons on neural circuit function
Renata Brito 		Keynote Event
Watch now
Michael Long
Michael Long 		Keynote Event
Watch now
The social brain: Interacting networks enabling the understanding of others
Philipp Kanske 		Keynote Event
Watch now
Chasing the light: Mechanistically informed
Maneesh Sahani
Traditional talk
Watch now
Manipulating a Whip: Motor Control beyond Reach?
Marta Russo
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Aleksei Krotov, Northeastern University; Hillary Hoyt, Northeastern University; Mahdiar Edraki, Northeastern University; Reza Razavian, Northeastern University; Moses Nah, MIT; Neville Hogan, MIT; Dagmar Sternad, Northeastern University

Over the past decades much of motor neuroscience research has focused on unconstrained reach-like movements under highly controlled conditions. While this may yield insights into the role of internal models and optimal feedback control strategies, it is challenging to extrapolate this understanding to more advanced tasks such as interacting with objects that have internal dynamics. Using the extreme example of manipulating a bullwhip, this study asked how humans can achieve dexterity in manipulating the wave dynamics of the whip's infinite number of degrees of freedom.
16 participants attempted to hit a target with the 1.60m-long whip either in discrete style, with pauses between throws of the whip, or in rhythmic style, where the whip never came to rest between throws. Performance was quantified by success rate, error and variability of error. All measures showed better performance in the discrete style, but performance showed improvement only in the rhythmic style. Hand trajectories in state space and speed profiles indicated similar patterns for both styles. In particular, the tangential speed of the hand revealed two principal submovements in both styles, identifying two movement phases: preparatory phase and throwing phase. The preparatory phase was significantly longer and peak speed significantly higher in the discrete style. Comparison of the whip motion showed smoother unfolding in the rhythmic style, indicating smoother energy propagation along the whip.
Taken together these findings indicate that having more time in the discrete style to set proper initial conditions allows for a better performance. However, the features found in the rhythmic style suggest other mechanisms might be engaged. Based on observations of a two-peaked hand speed profile, we suggest that humans may represent control of this prodigiously complex dynamic object in terms of the parameters of primitive actions – submovements – that are used for interactive control.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Assessing Limitations of Three-Factor Hebbian Learning Relative to Deep Reinforcement Learning
Jordan Lei
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Joshua Gold, University of Pennsylvania; Konrad Kording, University of Pennsylvania; Blake Richards, McGill University; Vijay Balasubramanian, University of Pennsylvania

Three-Factor Hebbian Learning (also known as Reward-Modulated Hebbian Learning) is an important framework for neuroscientists because it provides a biologically relevant framework for modeling learning in the brain. However, the effectiveness of Three-Factor Learning, which specifies that synaptic plasticity is driven only by presynaptic activity, postsynaptic activity, and a global neuromodulator, is limited. By contrast, Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) provides more computationally powerful learning rules that typically use an additional factor related to the influence of the synapse or neuron towards the action taken by the agent. However, the biological relevance of these rules is less well understood. The primary goal of this project is to better understand the specific network and task conditions that cause Three-Factor Learning agents to fail, and the specific features of DRL algorithms that can overcome these problems and thus could potentially have relevance to learning in the brain.

We consider four primary challenges that the brain must overcome to learn effectively. The first is adding uncertainty to the time of stimulus onset on each trial, which is typically used in real-world learning tasks but less often in simulations. The second is adding multiple stimulus dimensions and changing which one is relevant for learning at a given time. The third is network complexity, including simply moving from a simple linear network that is used in many simple modeling exercises to a multi-layer network needed to solve more complex problems. The fourth is additional forms of plasticity, such as a perceptual learning-like mechanism that can affect the input to the network, that must interact synergistically with other learning in the network to produce appropriate outputs. Preliminary results suggest that each of these challenges are overcome more effectively by DRL algorithms than Three-Factor Hebbian rules, implying a potential role for those algorithms in the brain.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Motor cortical control of vocal behavior in neotropical singing mice
Arkarup Banerjee
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Michael Long, NYU;

Using sounds for social interactions is common across many taxa. Humans engaged in conversation, for example, take rapid turns to go back and forth. This ability to act upon sensory information to generate a desired motor output is a fundamental feature of animal behavior. How the brain enables such flexible sensorimotor transformations, for example during vocal interactions, is a central question in neuroscience. Seeking a rodent model to fill this niche, we are investigating neural mechanisms of vocal interaction in Alston’s singing mouse (Scotinomys teguina) – a neotropical rodent native to the cloud forests of Central America. We discovered sub-second temporal coordination of advertisement songs (counter-singing) between males of this species – a behavior that requires the rapid modification of motor outputs in response to auditory cues. We leveraged this natural behavior to probe the neural mechanisms that generate and allow fast and flexible vocal communication. Using causal manipulations, we recently showed that an orofacial motor cortical area (OMC) in this rodent is required for vocal interactions. Subsequently, in electrophysiological recordings, I find neurons in OMC that track initiation, termination and relative timing of songs. Interestingly, persistent neural dynamics during song progression stretches or compresses on every trial to match the total song duration. These results demonstrate robust cortical control of vocal timing in a rodent and questions the current dogma that motor cortical control of vocal output is evolutionarily restricted to the primate lineage.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Central neural circuits supporting olfactory navigation in walking Drosophila
Andrew Matheson (He/Him/His)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Andrew MM Matheson, Neuroscience Institute, New York University Langone Medical Center; Timothy A Currier, Neuroscience Institute, New York University Langone Medical Center; Aaron J Lanz, Neuroscience Institute, New York University Langone Medical Center; Angela M Licata, Neuroscience Institute, New York University Langone Medical Center, Katherine I Nagel, Neuroscience Institute, New York University Langone Medical Center

All organisms must navigate to find food and resources. For many organisms this requires navigating in a turbulent chemical environment, where odour cues alone are insufficient to locate food sources. A commonly used algorithm in such environments is to surge upwind during odour, and cast crosswind at odour offset. Critically, this algorithm depends on the integration of odour information with wind direction cues. Previously, our lab developed a high-throughput behavioural paradigm for walking Drosophila, where an attractive odour elicits two motor programs: an upwind run during odour, and search behaviour at odour offset. Here, we used this paradigm to identify central circuits that translate sensory stimuli into navigation behaviours.

To identify neurons involved in olfactory motor program generation, we took an optogenetic approach. Beginning at the olfactory periphery, we first showed that activation of orco+ olfactory receptor neurons produces both upwind runs and offset search. We next activated output neurons in higher order olfactory areas, the lateral horn and mushroom body (LHONs and MBONs), and found subsets of these also produce the complete olfactory navigation motor program of upwind runs and offset search. Using 2-photon imaging and a 5 direction wind-odour manifold, we found these LHONs and MBONs encode odour in a non-directional manner, indicating that odour and wind direction signals must be integrated downstream.

To identify downstream targets of navigation-promoting LHONs and MBONs, we used trans-synaptic tracing. We found that downstream neurons targeted the fan-shaped body (FSB), a region implicated in navigation. We performed an activation screen of the FSB and identified both input neurons and local/output neurons that generate upwind navigation when activated. Several groups of input neurons responded to odour in a non-directional manner, while at least one group of local neurons showed some direction-selective odour responses. Connectomic analysis suggests these local neuron receive input both from olfactory FSB inputs and from wind-direction selective ventral P-FNs (Currier et al. 2020). Local FSB neurons may represent a site where appetitive odour and wind direction information are integrated to drive navigation behaviours. This work will make possible a mechanistic understanding of the circuit basis of olfactory navigation.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The SNARE regulator Complexin 3 is a target of the cone circadian clock
Jacob Bhoi (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Zhijing Zhang, The University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Houston, TX; Christophe P. Ribelayga, The University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston, Houston, TX

Almost all living organisms have evolved rhythms of behavior and physiology to allow them to occupy temporal niches. One such rhythm is a circadian rhythm which allows organisms to preemptively adapt to changes in environment conditions driven by the daily light/dark cycle. Rhythms are generated by cell autonomous molecular clocks which drive rhythmic cell processes. BMAL1 is a core component of the mammalian circadian clockwork. Removal of BMAL1 from the retina significantly affects visual information processing in both rod and cone pathways. To identify potential pathways and/or molecules through which BMAL1 alters signal transmission at the cone pedicle, we performed an RNA‐seq differential expression analysis between cone‐specific Bmal1 knockout cones (cone‐Bmal1−/−) and wild‐type (WT) cones. We found 88 genes differentially expressed. Among these, Complexin3 (Cplx3), a SNARE regulator at ribbon synapses, was downregulated fivefold in the mutant cones. The purpose of this work was to determine whether BMAL1 and/or the cone clock controls CPLX3 protein expression at cone pedicles. We found that CPLX3 expression level was decreased twofold in cone‐Bmal1−/− cones. Furthermore, CPLX3 expression was downregulated at night compared to the day in WT cones but remained constitutively low in mutant cones both day and night. The transcript and protein expression levels of Cplx4—the other complexin expressed in cones—were similar in WT and mutant cones; in WT cones, CPLX4 protein level did not change with the time of day. In silico analysis revealed four potential BMAL1:CLOCK binding sites upstream from exon one of Cplx3 and none upstream of exon one of Cplx4. Our results suggest that CPLX3 expression is regulated at the transcriptional level by the cone clock. The modulation of CPLX3 may be a mechanism by which the clock controls the cone synaptic transfer function to second‐order cells and thereby impacts retinal signal processing during the day/night cycle.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Synaptopathy in Frontotemporal Dementia: investigating the pathogenic role of mutant CHMP2B
Rebekah Smikle
 
Abstract
 
Frontotemporal dementia is the second most common form of early-onset dementia and senile neurodegenerative disease. One rare subtype is caused by a mutation in the gene CHMP2B. CHMP2B is a subunit of the endosomal sorting complexes required for transport (ESCRT) and CHMP2B mutation causes defects in certain protein degradation pathways. The ESCRT pathway is involved in degradation of synaptic vesicle proteins, and preliminary data by E. Clayton and S. Schorge demonstrates that several synaptic proteins accumulate in brains of aged mutant CHMP2B mice compared to age-matched controls. Synaptic vesicle protein accumulation would inevitably cause synaptic dysfunction, an effect not well studied in frontotemporal dementia. This project aimed to characterise this probable ‘synapto-pathogenic’ feature of CHMP2B-frontotemporal dementia, by investigating the neuronal subcellular localisation of mutant CHMP2B protein and examining the relative synaptic vesicle protein levels at early postnatal stages. Using immunofluorescence microscopy in mouse cortical neurons transfected with mutant CHMP2B, we found that mutant CHMP2B forms puncta which co-localise with presynaptic marker SV2. Wildtype CHMP2B shows diffuse staining, but also co-localises with SV2. Cycloheximide chase and subsequent western blot were conducted to inhibit protein synthesis in protein lysates and isolate levels of the synaptic vesicle proteins synapsin, synaptophysin and SV2 remaining after protein degradation. While no significant difference was found between mutant lysates and wildtype controls, a surprising trend of increased protein accumulation in wildtype and decreased protein accumulation in mutant samples was observed. Interestingly, an SV2 isoform not observed in wildtype samples accumulated in mutant samples. These findings demonstrate that mutant CHMP2B is localised to the presynaptic terminal, but point to the need for further investigation of its mechanism of action, including isoform-specific protein degradation. Understanding the pathogenic agency of mutant CHMP2B at the synapse will be useful for identifying therapeutic targets in CHMP2B-frontotemporal dementia.
Traditional talk
Watch now
A Double-Layer Multi-Resolution Classification Model for Decoding Spatio-Temporal Patterns of Spikes
Xiwei She
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Dong Song; Theodore Berger

To study how information are encoded in neural signals, we build a double-layer multi-resolution classification model for decoding specific behavior information from single-trial spatio-temporal patterns of spikes. The model can take hippocampal spiking activities as input signals and memory-related variables as output signals. In the first layer, to avoid overfitting caused by small sample size and the very high dimensional input and output signals, L1-regularized b-spline logistic regression classifiers are used to reduce dimensionality and yield sparse model estimation. A wide range of temporal resolutions of neural signals are included by using multiple classifiers with different numbers of b-spline knots. Each classifier serves a base-learner to classify spatio-temporal patterns with a given temporal resolution. A bootstrap aggregating strategy is used to further reduce estimation variances of these classifiers. In the second layer, another L1-regularized logistic classifier takes outputs of first-layer classifiers as inputs to generate the final output prediction. This classifier serves as a meta-learner that combines multiple temporal resolutions to classify the spatio-temporal patterns of spikes. We test the proposed decoding modeling method with both synthetic data and experimental data recorded from rats and human subjects performing memory-dependent behavioral tasks. Results show that this method can effectively avoid overfitting and yield accurate prediction of memory labels. The double-layer multi-resolution classifier consistently outperforms the best single-layer single-resolution classifier by extracting and utilizing multi-resolution spatio-temporal features of spike patterns in classification. The proposed model can be used not only to predict memory contents, but also has the potential to be used to design optimal spatio-temporal patterns for eliciting specific memories in the hippocampus, and thus have important implications to the development of hippocampal memory prostheses.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Altered dynamic architecture of functional connectivity for predicting recovery of consciousness in behaviorally unresponsive patients
Charlotte Maschke (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Stefanie Blain-Moraes, School of Physical and Occupational Therapy, McGill University Montreal

The brain is an inherently dynamic and time-varying organ, whose functionality is based on patterns of spatially and temporally differentiated activity. In individuals with disorders of consciousness (DOC), the dynamic properties of functional connectivity of their brain networks are altered. Accurate assessment of level of consciousness in unresponsive patients and their potential to recover requires further understanding of the dynamic architecture of functional connectivity. In this study, we investigate the diagnostic and prognostic value of dynamic properties of functional connectivity in individuals in an unresponsive or minimally responsive state. Time-resolved functional connectivity was estimated from high-density EEG using the weighted phase lag index (wPLI). The spatial-temporal organization of wPLI connectivity was assessed with a K-means clustering analysis and compared between 1) healthy adults; 2) DOC patients who recovered consciousness; 3) DOC patients who remained unresponsive; and 4) patients showing cognitive-motor dissociation. The robustness of the results was further evaluated using a hidden Markov model. We demonstrate that the dynamic organization of functional connectivity varies widely in DOC patients, and that these patterns differs from those which are observed in healthy adults. We demonstrate that the degree of preserved dynamic organization of time-resolved functional connectivity distinguishes unresponsive patients according to their state of consciousness and potential to recover consciousness. Our findings provide evidence for altered spatial-temporal patterns and dynamic properties of functional connectivity in unresponsive individuals. The maintenance of the brains inherently dynamic and time-variable organization contains valuable information for the accurate assessment of an individual's level of consciousness and the potential to recover consciousness.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Transsaccadic integration of object orientation vs. identity in human cortex: An fMRI paradigm
Bianca Baltaretu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Bianca R. Baltaretu [Centre for Vision Research, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Vision, Science to Applications (VISTA) program, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Department of Biology, York University, Toronto, ON, CA]; W. Dale Stevens [Centre for Vision Research, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Vision, Science to Applications (VISTA) program, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Department of Psychology, York University, Toronto, ON, CA]; Erez Freud [Centre for Vision Research, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Vision, Science to Applications (VISTA) program, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Department of Psychology, York University, Toronto, ON, CA]; J. Douglas Crawford [Centre for Vision Research, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Vision, Science to Applications (VISTA) program, York University, Toronto, ON, CA; Departments of Biology, Psychology, Kinesiology & Neuroscience Diploma Program, York University, Toronto, ON, CA];

Recently, Dunkley et al. (Cortex, 2016) showed modulations in parietal cortex (i.e., supramarginal gyrus, SMG) for transsaccadic changes in object. However, this result did not generalize to other features, such as spatial frequency (Baltaretu et al., J Vis, 2016). We hypothesized that the fundamental difference between these results was the detection of transsaccadic changes in object orientation vs. identity. To test this, we used a double-dissociation fMRI task. Participants fixated a small cross 15.4° left or right of centre, where an object was subsequently presented (rectangle, barrel-shaped, or hourglass-shaped), oriented at ±45° from vertical. After this, the fixation cross either remained in the same position (Fixation condition) or shifted to the other side (Saccade condition). Then, either the same object would appear with the opposite orientation (Orientation change condition) or one of the other two objects would appear at the same orientation (Identity change condition). Button press was used to indicate whether object identity or orientation had changed. Results indicate that cortical modulations were larger for saccades (than fixations) when orientation changed in medial early occipital regions (e.g., V1) extending into later occipitotemporal regions. Activation for changes in identity were larger for saccades (than fixations) for identity change in regions similar to those for orientation change, but also in medial parietal regions (e.g., precuneus and superior parietal lobule). When looking for a feature (Orientation > Identity) change specifically in cortical regions showing a Saccade > Fixation preference, we found this activation within medial occipital/occipitotemporal cortex extending toward the border with parietal regions as well. These preliminary results suggest that differences in object features that occur across saccades also appear at the cortical level (largely within medial occipital cortex, extending both towards parietal and temporal cortex). Further controls will be applied to confirm that these results are task- and feature-specific.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Human control of complex objects: Stochastic optimal feedback control and beyond
Reza Razavian
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Rashida Nayeem, Northeastern University; Mohsen Sadeghi, Northeastern University; Salah Bazzi, Northeastern University; Dagmar Sternad, Northeastern University;

For several decades, goal-directed reaching in the horizontal plane has served as testbed to gain insight into human control and adaptation of movements. A prominent model that has successfully accounted for a variety of observations is stochastic optimal feedback control that minimizes muscular effort and kinematic accuracy given signal-dependent noise. This body of research simplified the movement to free pointing tasks, excluding any real-world interactions with objects and the environment. Our research extends the sensorimotor challenge and examines ‘reaching’ while transporting a non-rigid object, such as carrying a cup of coffee. Safe control of such underactuated objects need to predict, preempt or compensate for self-generated perturbations of the liquid that presents forces acting back onto the hand.
In our experiment, participants transported a semicircular cup with a heavy ball rolling inside (simulating the sloshing coffee) in a virtual environment, interfaced with a robotic manipulandum. They moved the cup-and-ball on a horizontal line to a target box. Due to the internal dynamics, the cup trajectory significantly deviates from a bell-shape velocity profile common in unconstrained movements. It also deviates from the two-peaked profile that is predicted by an effort-minimizing optimal controller that minimally intervenes with forces generated by the rolling ball. To reproduce the observed cup velocity profile (which has small positive acceleration in the middle), two modifications of the optimal feedback controller were needed: First, hand impedance accounts for the participants’ compliant behavior when facing perturbations (included as a linear spring/damper at the cup). Second, the controller seeks to regulate the zero-force trajectory of the spring/damper with maximal smoothness. As long as the object dynamics is simple, as for a rigid object, both the original and the modified control models result in bell-shaped velocity profiles. However, when coping with interaction forces from the object, the dynamically-informed smoothness criterion is superior as it penalizes changes in cup velocity. These findings show that to gain insight into human control, we need to go beyond the highly simplified tasks to gain insights into human behavior with real-life challenges.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Differences between representations shaped by supervised and unsupervised learning rules
Ada Duan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Matthias Hennig

How the brain adjusts the synapses of individual neurons to support learning is an essential question in neuroscience. Backpropagation is the current most efficient solution for this problem in deep neural networks, and may be approximated by the brain to some extent. On the other hand, unsupervised learning rules like various forms of Hebbian learning are experimentally well supported, and are critical both during circuit development and learning from sensory information without supervision signals. The combination of supervised and unsupervised learning rules has therefore the potential to produce plasticity mechanisms that are both biologically plausible and can exploit their advantages. Here we study a learning rule combining backpropagation of gradients and an unsupervised Hebbian rule with competition between neurons, in a network receiving natural images as stimuli. The backpropagation objective is the image classification accuracy, while Hebbian learning causes emergence of typical visual receptive fields such as edge detectors, as well as less structured, random-looking kernels. Results suggest while combined learning has similar classification performance with backpropagation alone, changes due to backpropagation may be small compared to changes of unsupervised learning. Structured receptive fields shaped by unsupervised learning result in a sparser contribution of neurons to correct prediction. When initialised from both random and structured kernels, random kernels tend to get more changes during backpropagation. Though unsupervised learned kernels seem to be slightly hindering the efficiency of backpropagation, they can better support transfer learning between classes. These suggest that top-down influences on early sensory receptive fields may generally be weak and experimentally hard to detect. The work is a first step in studying how to combine supervised and unsupervised learning rules to bring out respective advantages as well as learn in a more biologically plausible manner.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Functional Representation of Vocal Musculature in the Motor Cortex of Mice
César Vargas (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Elena Waidmann, The Rockefeller University; Erich D. Jarvis, The Rockefeller University and Howard Hughes Medical Institute

Vocalizations are a dynamic and complex behavior that can be innate or learned. Vocal learners, animals that learn to imitate or modify vocalizations, use top-down input from the forebrain to provide fine motor control over vocal musculature. These forebrain circuits coordinate sub-cortical networks during, and after, learning to precisely execute these learned behaviors. Currently, we do not have genetically tractable mammalian models for speech and vocal learning. However, behavioral and anatomical findings from our lab and others’ have shown that the ultrasonic song system of mice exhibits rudimentary features consistent with advanced features of vocal learners, including multisyllabic structure that varies with social context, and a small pool of cortical neurons in posteromedial M1 that projects directly to vocal motor neurons in the brainstem. To test if these M1 neurons can functionally activate vocal muscles, and possibly provide fine motor coordination, we used intracortical microstimulation (ICMS) paired with electromyography (EMG) from vocal muscles in the larynx of anesthetized mice. We use latency from stimulation to EMG response to estimate the number of synapses between the cortex and the muscles, with shorter latencies meaning there are fewer neurons in the circuit (i.e. more direct connectivity). Using this approach, we found a representation of laryngeal musculature in posteromedial M1, consistent with our anatomical tracing, but also a second representation in anterolateral M1. The two regions have distinct latency and stimulation thresholds from one another. The anterolateral region, corresponding to orofacial motor cortex (OFC), has shorter latencies-to-response from stimulation and lower current injection thresholds. Conversely, the posteromedial region has longer latencies and higher thresholds. These two representations possibly underlie different functions of the laryngeal musculature in different behaviors, such as voluntary swallowing, breathing, or vocalizing. These results are the first characterization of the functional representations of laryngeal musculature in the rodent motor cortex.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Distinct Cluster of Dopaminergic Input Neurons is necessary to establish larval aversive memory
Denise Weber
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Lukas Körner; Andreas S. Thum

The ability to learn from past events and apply them to future situations can determine life and death of an organism. In 1985, Tully and Quinn showed that even an inconspicuous organism such as adult Drosophila is able to learn situational information and develop memory. Since then, much has been done in this field and Drosophila has been established as a generally valid model organism for learning and memory. In particular, the Drosophila larva offers unexpected advantages: firstly, the availability and robustness of the larvae for behavioral experiments; secondly, the anatomical simplicity of the larval central nervous system, which consists of only about 10,000 neurons; furthermore, the almost unlimited variety of genetic tools which make it possible to activate or silence individual neurons. All advantages - together with the latest publication of the connectome – make the larva a popular object of choice in neurogenetics. Above all, the insect mushroom body (MB) is a central unit when it comes to sensory input, processing, and behavioral output. It has been shown that the MB consists of eleven compartments, all of which have a limited number of specific neuronal inputs (MBINs) and outputs (MBONs) - these MBINs can be either dopaminergic (DAN), octopaminergic (OAN), or of unknown identity. Here, we analyzed different mushroom body input neurons to test their significance in salt-dependent aversive classical olfactory conditioning by using the Split-GAL4-UAS system to ablate MBINs at cellular resolution. Our results reveal that an aversive salt-dependent memory is not formed by a single input neuron, rather by an integral network of input neurons in the vertical lobe of the mushroom body.
Traditional talk
Watch now
The Nuclear GAPDH-HMGB cascade in cortical microglia regulates cognitive flexibility
Adriana Ramos
 
Abstract
 
Glyceraldehyde dehydrogenase (GAPDH) is a key enzyme in glycolysis. Beyond its fundamental role in metabolism, GAPDH can get post-translationally modified in response to cellular stressors and subsequently translocate to nuclei to exert transcriptional control [the nuclear GAPDH (N-GAPDH) cascade]. We hypothesized that this cascade might play a critical role linking stress and behavior.

In this study, we discovered a novel mechanism that controls the response of microglia to stress through the N-GAPDH cascade and regulates animal adaptive behavior. Specifically, activation of the N-GAPDH cascade solely in cortical microglia and cognitive inflexibility were observed in a Lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-treated mouse model. Such cognitive deficits were blocked through pharmacological treatment or microglia-specific genetic intervention targeting the initial steps of the N-GAPDH cascade. To understand how the N-GAPDH cascade in microglia causes the cognitive deficits, we performed a ChIP-Seq analysis against N-GAPDH using ex-vivo microglia from the LPS-treated mice. We found upregulation of High-mobility group-box (HMGB) that can be secreted from microglia and binds to N-Methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptors on glutamatergic neurons, causing their hyperactivation which turns to cognitive deficits. In summary, this study defined a new mechanism of microglia-neuron interaction though which stress-activated immune cells regulates neural system via a key metabolic molecule, GAPDH.

On-going studies: The ChIP-Seq analysis further revealed that the N-GAPDH cascade transcriptionally regulated the expression of GAPDH by itself and controlled proteostasis in microglia in a cell autonomous manner. The relevance of the N-GAPDH cascade in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (in particular monocytes) is under study in order to find possible molecular based biomarkers to predict behavioral inflexibility in the clinic. Among those candidates, we found autofluorescence reflects the activation of the N-GAPDH cascade in preclinical studies. Using a cohort of patients with schizophrenia and healthy controls we found cellular autofluorescence in blood cells negatively correlates with behavioral flexibility.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Maintenance of refined visual receptive fields through BDNF-TrkB signaling depends on presynaptic GABA levels, not postsynaptic GABAA receptors or the scaffolding proteins gephyrin and PSD-95.
Parag Juvale
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
David B. Mudd, Neuroscience Institute, Georgia State University, Atlanta, GA USA; Nitheyaa Shree, Neuroscience Institute, Georgia State University, Atlanta, GA USA; Sarah L. Pallas, Molecular and Cellular Biology Graduate Program, University of Massachusetts Amherst, MA USA, Neuroscience Institute, Georgia State University, Atlanta, GA USA.

The development of visual response properties is thought to require early sensory experience, but our previous work showed that visual experience is not necessary, and spontaneous activity is sufficient for visual receptive fields (RFs) in superior colliculus (SC) or visual cortex (V1) to refine. Instead, juvenile visual experience is necessary only to maintain RF size in adulthood via a BDNF-TrkB dependent mechanism that preserves lateral inhibition. RF expansion significantly hampers visual processing ability of dark reared (DR) hamsters, and treatment with a TrkB agonist during a critical period rescues it. In this study, we investigated whether postsynaptic changes could underlie RF expansion in SC and V1 of DR adults. Dark rearing could interfere with the maturation of GABAA receptor (GABAAR) subunit composition, resulting in a higher α2/α1 (immature/mature) subunit ratio, compared to light reared hamsters. The α5/α1 (extrasynaptic/synaptic) GABAAR subunit ratio in DR adults might be higher than normal, resulting in lower phasic inhibition. Alternatively, dark rearing could reduce gephyrin localization at the synapse, reducing the stability of the synaptic GABAA receptors and consequently, the overall inhibitory effect of GABA. Lastly, dark rearing could also result in reduced synaptic accumulation of the scaffold protein, postsynaptic density-95 (PSD-95), resulting in reduced synaptic anchoring of NMDA receptors (NMDARs) and AMPA receptors (AMPARs), potentially affecting long-term potentiation. Using western blotting, we found no significant differences between DR and normal animals in SC or V1 for the synaptic GABAAR subunits, or the scaffolding proteins anchoring the GABAA or glutamate receptors at the synapse. Our results rule out several alternative explanations for the loss of GABAAR function identified by our earlier work, and support reductions in presynaptic GABA rather than postsynaptic alterations as the primary explanation for the loss of RF stability in DR animals.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
A Sparse Multiscale Nonlinear Autoregressive Model for Seizure Prediction
Pen-Ning Yu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Dong Song, University of Southern California

Objectives: Accurate seizure prediction is highly desirable for medical interventions such as responsive electrical stimulation. We aim to develop a classification model that can predict seizures by identifying preictal states, i.e., the precursor of a seizure, based on multi-channel intracranial EEG (iEEG) signals.
Approach: A two-level sparse multiscale classification model is developed to classify interictal and preictal states from iEEG data. In the first level, short time-scale linear dynamical features are extracted as autoregressive (AR) model coefficients; Long time-scale linear and nonlinear dynamical features are extracted as Laguerre-Volterra autoregressive (LVAR) model coefficients; Root-mean-square error (RMSE) of model prediction is used as a feature representing model unpredictability. In the second level, all features are fed into a sparse classifier to discriminate the iEEG data between interictal and preictal states.
Main results: The two-level model can accurately classify seizure states using iEEG data recorded from ten canine and human subjects. Adding long time-scale and nonlinear features significantly improves model performance compared with the conventional AR modeling approach. There is a high degree of variability in the types of features contributing to seizure prediction across different subjects.
Significance: This study suggests that seizure generation may involve distinct linear/nonlinear dynamical processes caused by different underlying neurobiological mechanisms. It is necessary to build patient-specific classification models with a wide range of dynamical features.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Functional connectivity between right frontoparietal and visual networks is linked to visual processing speed
Adriana Ruiz-Rizzo
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Svenja Küchenhoff, LMU Munich; Christian Sorg, TU Munich; Sebastian Schneider, TU Munich; Oliver Kohl, LMU Munich; Hermann J. Müller, LMU Munich; Kathrin Finke, Jena University Hospital

The neural theory of visual attention (TVA) proposes that visual processing speed depends on the coordinated activity between frontoparietal and occipital brain areas. Previous research has shown that the coordinated activity (i.e., functional connectivity, FC) between the cingulo-opercular network (COn) and the right-frontoparietal network (RFPn) is linked to individual visual processing speed. However, evidence for a link between visual processing speed and the inter-FC of COn and RFPn with visual networks is still lacking. Forty-eight healthy human adult participants underwent resting-state (rs-)fMRI and performed a whole-report psychophysical task. To obtain inter-FC, we analyzed rs-fMRI data within the entire frequency range possible for our data (i.e., 0.01-0.4 Hz) to avoid discarding meaningful neural information. Following previous approaches, we examined the data in separate frequency bins (Hz): Slow-5 (0.01-0.027), Slow-4 (0.027-0.073), Slow-3 (0.073-0.198), and Slow-2 (0.198-0.4). We used the mathematical framework of TVA to estimate an individual, latent-level visual processing speed parameter. We found that the inter-FC between RFPn and visual networks was negatively associated with visual processing speed in Slow-5 and Slow-2, with no corresponding significant association for the inter-FC between COn and visual networks. These results provide first empirical evidence for an association of inter-FC at rest between RFPn and visual networks with the visual processing speed parameter. These findings suggest a direct influence on occipital regions from the right frontoparietal, but not frontoinsular, regions, to support visual processing speed.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Home-Cage Environmental Refinements and Colony Conditions Influence Rats' Depression- and Anxiety-Related Behaviours
Samantha Irwin
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Janet L. Menard, Queen's University; Jasmin Katz, University of Toronto

As the welfare of research animals’ garners rising attention, modest changes to standard housing conditions, known as ‘environmental refinements’, are increasingly employed to promote animals’ well-being. However, little consideration has been paid to whether such efforts truly improve animal welfare or lead to substantive changes in animal behaviour. The study at hand attempts to empirically validate whether providing rats with minor forms of refinements in their home-cage improves their wellbeing as indexed by anxiety-and depression-like behaviour. Rats (n = 12) in the refined condition were housed in cages that contained various refinements and compared to standard housed rats (n = 12) without access to any home-cage refinements. After one month of habituating to home-cage conditions, rats were tested in a battery of well-validated paradigms of anxiety- and depression-like behaviour including the Elevated Plus Maze, Novelty-Induced Suppression of Feeding (NSFT), Shock Probe Burying, and Sucrose Preference Tests (SPT). There were no significant between-group differences in rats’ behavioural profiles save the NSFT and SPT. Here, rats in the refined housing condition demonstrated heightened anxiety- and depression-like behaviour, which contradicted the prediction that refinements would improve behavioural indices of wellbeing. Notably, animals in both housing conditions displayed unusually high levels of anxiety-like behaviours across all behavioural assessments. These findings raise the possibility that the combination of refinements provided and/or other home-cage and colony variables can contribute to heightened stress, anxiety- and depression-like behaviour in laboratory animals. Beyond implications for animal welfare, disruptions to behavioural profiles pose a considerable challenge for neuroscientific researchers employing animal models as a means to study the brain and behaviour. As such, the impact of home-cage refinements on laboratory animals’ well-being and behavioural profiles requires further clarification.

Keywords: animal welfare, housing conditions, environmental refinements, anxiety, depression
Traditional talk
Watch now
Merging control strategies for the manipulation of complex objects
Mohsen Sadeghi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Dagmar Sternad

Skilful object manipulation often combines different movement elements to achieve specific task goals. When swirling a glass of wine, the primary goal of control is to bring the wine (internal degree of freedom) into a rhythmic circular motion, whereas when bringing the glass of wine to the mouth, the main goal is to translate the glass itself. Smooth transition of control goals, from rhythmic to discrete, or from internal to external degrees of freedom, exemplifies the remarkable dexterity in manipulation, yet remains hardly explored.
This study developed a novel paradigm to examine how humans combine such control goals when manipulating an object with internal dynamics, akin to swirling a glass of wine. Subjects grasped the handle of a custom-designed cup with a ball rolling inside, and rhythmically "swirled" the ball close to the rim, while remaining within a specified "home position". An audible cue signalled subjects to translate the cup in a reach-like movement to a target position. Such discrete translation could interrupt the ball rotation or cause the ball to fall out. Subjects were instructed to keep the ball rotation as steady as possible during and after the reach. Dependent measures were the amplitude and frequency of ball rotation and their deviation/error from a perfect circular motion, the ball phase when initiating the translation, and the duration of the translation.
With practice, subjects achieved smooth transitions between rhythmic (ball) and discrete (cup) movements by jointly modulating the ball phase at translation initiation, and the duration of the translation. These findings suggest that the motor system learns to merge the control goals by integrating the discrete cup movement into the rhythmic cycle of the ball rotation. The observed behaviour is discussed in the context of optimal control theory and dynamic primitives for the control of complex actions.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Identifying learning rules from neural network observables
Aran Nayebi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sanjana Srivastava, Stanford University; Surya Ganguli, Stanford University; Daniel Yamins, Stanford University

The brain modifies its synaptic strengths during learning in order to better adapt to its environment.
However, the underlying plasticity rules that govern learning are unknown.
Many proposals have been suggested, including Hebbian mechanisms, explicit error backpropagation, and a variety of alternatives.
It is an open question as to what specific experimental measurements would need to be made to determine whether any given learning rule is operative in a real biological systems.
In this work, we take a "virtual experimental" approach to this problem.
Simulating idealized neuroscience experiments with artificial neural networks, we generate a large-scale dataset of learning trajectories of aggregate statistics measured in a variety of neural network architectures, loss functions, learning rule hyperparameters, and parameter initializations.
We then take a discriminative approach, training linear and simple non-linear classifiers to identify learning rules from features based on these observables.
We show that different classes of learning rules can be separated solely on the basis of aggregate statistics of the weights, activations, or instantaneous layer-wise activity changes, and that these results generalize to limited access to the trajectory and held-out architectures and learning curricula.
We identify the statistics of each observable that are most relevant for rule identification, finding that statistics from network activities across training are more robust to unit undersampling and measurement noise than those obtained from the synaptic strengths.
Our results suggest that activation patterns, available from electrophysiological recordings of post-synaptic activities on the order of several hundred units, frequently measured at wider intervals over the course of learning, may provide a good basis on which to identify learning rules.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Temporal regularity is an essential social cue in mouse vocal communication
Catherine Perrodin (she/her)
 
Abstract
 
Animals navigating the real world continuously face large amounts of complex sensory information. One of the strategies used by the brain to perceptually compress multidimensional input is to selectively extract the features relevant for behaviour and survival. Like humans and many other mammals, mice communicate using acoustically complex vocal sequences. However, little is known about what acoustic information listeners monitor and use from these sensory streams during social interactions.
Here, we utilized female mice’s natural behavioural response to male courtships songs to identify the relevant acoustic dimensions used by listeners in their social decisions. Using playbacks of intact and acoustically manipulated songs in an ethologically-relevant assay, we evaluated the behavioural relevance of several candidate acoustic features in mouse communication.
We found that female listeners were highly sensitive to disruptions of song temporal regularity and preferentially approached playbacks of intact male songs over rhythmically irregular versions of the songs. In contrast, female behaviour was invariant to manipulations affecting the global structure of the song, such as randomized sequential organization and song temporal reversal. Similarly, manipulating the local spectro-temporal structure of individual syllables, such as phase-scrambling or pure tone approximation, did not influence female behaviour to male song playback.
Our findings highlight temporal regularity in vocal sequences as a key acoustic cue extracted by listeners during natural vocal-directed behaviour. By identifying which acoustic dimensions in vocal sequences are behaviourally-relevant, respectively less informative, to listeners, this work frames ongoing electrophysiological investigations into the neuronal substrates supporting the perception of vocal sequences.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Temporal dynamics in Drosophila taste coding influence synaptic plasticity
Anita Devineni
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Julia U. Deere, Columbia University; Bei Sun, Columbia University; Richard Axel, Columbia University

The taste system ensures that animals consume nutritious foods and avoid ingesting toxins. Taste also modulates responses to other stimuli; for example, animals learn to avoid cues that are associated with bitter taste. The timing of neural activity is a key feature of neural encoding in many systems, but few studies have investigated the temporal dynamics of taste responses. Using calcium imaging, we found that Drosophila taste sensory neurons show striking differences in their response dynamics. Most classes of taste neurons show a sustained response throughout the stimulus presentation that rapidly diminishes upon stimulus removal. However, some bitter-sensing neurons show strong, transient responses at both the onset and offset of the stimulus. Moreover, with repeated bitter stimulation the onset response rapidly habituates while the offset response remains strong.

We observed the same bitter response dynamics in a set of downstream neurons, the PPL1 dopaminergic neurons (DANs). PPL1 DANs innervate the mushroom body, the learning and memory center of the fly brain, and mediate aversive olfactory learning. Studies have shown that PPL1 DANs are activated by aversive stimuli and drive learning by inducing synaptic depression at synapses onto mushroom body output neurons. Unexpectedly, we found that repeatedly pairing odor with bitter taste induced synaptic potentiation, not depression, at these synapses. However, synaptic depression could be induced by pairing odor with bitter removal. By combining calcium imaging with optogenetic stimulation to mimic PPL1 DAN activity, we found that these unexpected plasticity effects could be explained by the combination of two factors: 1) intrinsic timing rules that govern mushroom body plasticity, and 2) the dominance of the bitter offset response during repeated bitter exposure. These results demonstrate the importance of taste response dynamics and reveal unexpected complexity in how dopaminergic modulation drives plasticity in the primary learning center of the fly.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The neuroprotective role of orphan nuclear receptor NR5A2/LRH-1 against oxidative stress
Katerina Dimitropoulou (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ismini Rozani, Center for Basic Research, Biomedical Research Foundation of the Academy of Athens; Efstathia Tetringa, Center for Basic Research, Biomedical Research Foundation of the Academy of Athens; Dimitrios Gkikas, Center for Basic Research, Biomedical Research Foundation of the Academy of Athens; Matina Tsampoula, Center for Basic Research, Biomedical Research Foundation of the Academy of Athens; Panagiotis K. Politis, Center for Basic Research, Biomedical Research Foundation of the Academy of Athens

Oxidative stress is a major underlying factor that is a key player in the initiation and/or progression of various fatal neurodegenerative diseases and other brain-related neuropathological conditions. Up to this date there is no established therapy or pharmaceutical strategy to tackle this mutifactorial condition within the context of neurodegeneration, thus identification of new molecular pathways with neuroprotective action against oxidative stress-induced apoptosis may be proven essential for novel therapeutic approaches. To this end, we identify orphan nuclear receptor NR5A2 as a critical protective factor in neuronal cells against H2O2, a well-established oxidative stress model. More specifically, we provide evidence that adenoviral-mediated overexpression of NR5A2 significantly decreases apoptosis and promotes survival of H2O2-treated SH-SY5Y cells and ex vivo cultured murine cortical neurons. Most importantly, dilauroyl-phosphatidylcholine (DLPC), an efficient, FDA-approved pharmacological agonist of NR5A2, is sufficient to recapitulate its neuroprotective action in primary neuronal cells. In an attempt to unravel the molecular mechanism of NR5A2 neuroprotective function, we identify key anti-apoptotic genes, such as Bcl-xl and Bcl-2, as well as genes regulating cellular response to oxidative stress, such Sod2 and Nrf2, as potential downstream targets. Future analyses will include ChIP and transcriptional assays to test the direct binding of NR5A2 on these targets. Collectively, our observations render NR5A2 as a critical neuroprotective factor and promising drug target for brain-related diseases.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Disrupted Organelle Dynamics in Autophago-lysosomal Pathway in the Drosophila Models of C9-ALS In Vivo
Hyun Sung
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Thomas E. Lloyd, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by preferential death of motor neurons leading to muscle weakness and atrophy. Although the majority of ALS cases are sporadic, a G4C2 hexanucleotide repeat expansion (HRE) in C9orf72 is the most common inherited cause of ALS (C9-ALS). Since ALS displays selective vulnerability of motor neurons with cytoplasmic protein accumulation, we hypothesize that changes in intracellular organelle dynamics relevant to protein degradation pathway by G4C2 HRE may be a critical factor in C9-ALS motor neuronal degeneration. Here, we imaged Drosophila motor neurons expressing 30 G4C2 repeats (30R), and investigated the axonal transport of multiple organelles and endoplasmic reticulum (ER) dynamics. We found that 30R expression reduces the number of axonal autophagosomes (APs), while it causes local accumulation of late endosomes (LEs) and lysosomes in motor axons. Interestingly, 30R expression led to a marked reduction in AP number within motor neuron synaptic boutons, and this deficit was not restored by neuronal excitation with TrpA1. However, the remaining APs in C9-ALS motor neurons underwent normal maturation and development to amphisomes upon successful fusion with LEs during their secure retrograde transport. Since axonal transport of mitochondria was not affected by 30R expression, we hypothesized that the impaired axonal transport specific to the auto-lysosomal pathway is not because of global disruption in axonal transport. Instead, we found the converted ER structure and impaired ER dynamics in 30R motor neurons by showing rigid ER knots and ER tubule discontinuities. Collectively, our results indicate that pathogenic repeats of G4C2 hexanucleotide impair auto-lysosomal pathway by affecting intracellular organelle dynamics, and suggest an important role of ER integrity in axonal transport relevant to auto-lysosomal function for neuronal proteostasis.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Validation of a Convolutional Neural Network Model for Spike Transformation Using a Generalized Functional Additive Model
Bryan Moore
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Dong Song, University of Southern California

Identification of causal relationships of neural activity is one of the most important problems in neuroscience and neural engineering. Past work has shown that cognitive processes such as memory formation rely on transformations of spatio-temporal patterns of spikes across different neural populations. Such transformations are highly nonlinear dynamical, and cannot be captured by basic linear models. Convolutional neural networks (CNN) can capture complex nonlinearity and abstract low-level and high-level features in natural images via the use of deep layers of nonlinear activation functions. It thus holds the promise of modeling complex neural spike transformations underlying cognitive processes.
We treat spatio-temporal patterns of past input spikes as binary images and use a CNN to predict spiking in a single output neuron in a binary classification task. We generate synthetic data using a generalized functional additive model (GFAM) with multiple neurophysiologically inspired functions (kernels) and a probit link function that is passed to a threshold to produce a binary neural time series representing spikes. A sliding window generates binary training images from this time series that are passed to a CNN with multiple layers of convolution with filters convolving over the time domain to capture temporal nonlinearity. The CNN is able to achieve a high correlation between the predicted probability of spiking in the output neuron and the true probability of spiking in the output neuron for the data generated with a generalized functional additive model. The CNN is also able to recover the ground truth kernels used to generate the probability of spiking in the output neuron during synthetic data generation. Based on the CNN's validation via a GFAM, our current work includes validation of our approach with non-linear models using data generated with more complex nonlinear kernels.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Bipolar disorder alter topology and synchronizability of functional brain network
Fatemeh Akrami
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Fatemeh Akrami, Iran University of Medical Science, Tehran, Iran, Iranian NeuroWave Lab, Isfahan, Iran; Amirhossein Ghaderi,department of psychology, University of Calgary, Canada ,Iranian NeuroWave Lab, Isfahan, Iran

Bipolar disorders (BD) is characterized by different functional changing in the brain. It adversely affect human behaviour, speech, and cognition. Furthermore, due to this disorders, people tend to make a decisions which may lead to negative consequences. The question then arises is what does happen in the brain in BD condition? Since the brain is known as a synchronized dynamic network, it is possible that any abnormality changes this synchronizability. In this study, we apply graph theory analysis to compare the organization of the functional brain networks between BD and normal control individual. The participants in this study consists of twenty- one individuals in BD conditions and the same number in the normal group. We tested the brains rhythms (derived from source localized EEG data) in the resting- state eye open (rsEO) condition. Graph theory analysis reveal that there are significant differences in theta wavelength in clustering coefficient (p=0.05; mean (BD)= 0.1283, SD= 0.0625; mean (control)= 0.0944, Std= 0.0526), global efficiency (p=0.04; mean (BD)= 0.1511, Std= 0.0645; mean (control)= 0.1140, Std= 0.0567), and second smallest eigen value (p=0.04; mean (BD)= -2.5115, Std= 1.0928; mean (control)= -1.9448, Std= 0.7094) between two groups. These results indicate that BD alter topology and synchronizability of functional brain network, particularly in theta wavelength.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Spontaneous shifts of arousal state shape behavior in perceptual decision-making
Ella Podvalny
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ella Podvalny; Leana E. King; Biyu J. He

Arousal levels perpetually rise and fall to control behavior. While extreme arousal states clearly indicate behavioral extremes, from sleep to escape from danger, little is known about the behavioral relevance of intermediate arousal levels fluctuating spontaneously in waking humans. Here, we simultaneously monitored magnetoencephalography and pupil size in healthy volunteers (N=24) at rest and during a perceptual decision-making task with long inter-trial intervals. We first identified how the two commonly used markers of arousal - pupil size and spectral power of brain activity – relate to one another at rest, and then show how prestimulus fluctuations in these markers shape subsequent perceptual decisions. We found that spontaneously varying pupil size correlates with power of brain activity in all frequency bands and in all large-scale cortical networks. Prestimulus pupil size correlates with subsequent shifts in detection bias (c) and sensitivity (d’), which was fully explained by large-scale spectral power variation. When dissociated from pupil-linked state, delta power of dorsal attention and default networks predicts bias and alpha power of visual network predicts sensitivity. Spontaneous pupil constriction and dilation events correlate with large-scale brain activity as well, but not with behavior. Our results illuminate the large-scale electrophysiological neural correlates of pupil-linked arousal and show the effects of arousal states on human perceptual decision-making.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Single circuit in V1 capable of switching contexts during movement usingVIP population as a switch
Doris Voina
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Stefano Recanatesi; Brian Hu; Eric Shea-Brown; Stefan Mihalas

As animals adapt to their environments, their brains are tasked with processing stimuli in different sensory contexts. This suggests that neural architectures have evolved to respond flexibly to a range of stimulus conditions and statistics. As the number of possible contexts is virtually infinite, making parallel circuits for each context unfeasible, a crucial question is what architectures permit implementation of multiple related computations within a single circuit. Here, we address this question in the specific case of the circuitry of the visual system, focusing on the role of distinct cell types in context integration of visual scenes. We show that a population of inhibitory neurons, the VIP cells, can enable such context integration — defined as the integration of feedforward and surround information across visual space — in two different contexts, in which the viewer is static vs. moving. Moreover, the VIP population is efficient, requiring only a relatively small number of neurons to switch contexts. Our findings shed light on a minimally complex architecture that is capable of switching between two naturalistic contexts using few switching units.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Predicting Age In 8-To-24-Month-Olds Using Resting-State Functional Connectivity Mri
Omid Kardan (he/him/his)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Omid Kardan, University of Chicago; Sydney Kaplan, Washington University in St. Louis School of Medicine; Muriah D. Wheelock, Washington University in St. Louis School of Medicine; Dominique Meyer, Washington University in St. Louis School of Medicine; Adam T. Eggebrecht, Washington University in St. Louis School of Medicine; Lucille A.
