Moore, Oregon Health & Science University; Eric Earl, Oregon Health & Science University; Eric Feczko, University of Minnesota; Óscar Miranda-Domínguez, University of Minnesota; Kathy Snider, Oregon Health & Science University; Alice Graham, Oregon Health & Science University; Marc G. Berman, University of Chicago; Sooyeon Sung, University of Minnesota; Kamil Uğurbil, University of Minnesota; Essa Yacoub, University of Minnesota; Jed T. Elison, University of Minnesota; Christopher D. Smyser, Washington University in St. Louis School of Medicine; Damien A. Fair, University of Minnesota; Monica D. Rosenberg, University of Chicago

Resting-state functional connectivity (rsFC) measured with functional MRI has been used to predict phenotypes such as chronological age and clinical diagnoses in typically and atypically developing adults and children. However, its utility for predicting phenotypes in infants and toddlers is less well-characterized. Here, we use fMRI data from the Baby Connectome Project sample to predict the age of 110 infants and toddlers age 8-24 months old using data collected during natural sleep. Successful prediction could provide initial evidence that rsFC in infancy is reliable and informative of chronological age, and thus potentially predictive of other measures of interest in this group such as language or motor development with age. Using 10-fold cross-validation, we trained and tested support vector regression (SVR) models to predict age-at-scan using whole-brain rsFC constructed from 333 cortical parcels. Models successfully predicted novel infants’ age with ±4.1 months error and predictive R2=0.32. To characterize the anatomy of predictive networks, we grouped connections into 11 infant-specific or 12 adult-defined canonical resting-state functional networks (e.g., the default mode network). We found that connections between regions of the same networks—i.e., within-network connections—predicted age as well as or better than the full functional connectome (RMSE=±4 months error and R2=0.35 for within-infant-network connections). Furthermore, control analyses confirmed that results are not driven by head motion. Looking ahead, the current findings can help characterize changes in functional brain organization across development and inform work predicting measures of cognitive development in infants.
Interactive talk
Watch now
pyAFQ: Automated Fiber Quantification, in Python
John Kruper
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ariel Rokem, University of Washington Department of Psychology

The white matter contains the long-range connections that form brain networks. Diffusion weighted MRI (dMRI) is an in vivo, non-invasive measurement that characterizes brain tissue and indicates the trajectory of these connections. This data can be used to detect, characterize, and monitor brain diseases. Additionally, brain connections change during learning and could help account for individual differences in cognition. To perform this analysis at scale, methods for delineation of the major tracts are needed. Automated Fiber Quantification in Python (pyAFQ; https://github.com/yeatmanlab/pyAFQ) is a python package that automates this process. Given dMRI data that has undergone standard preprocessing, pyAFQ will automatically perform computational tractography, delineate and segment the major tracts based on individual-level anatomical constraints, and extract the diffusion measurements along those tracks (e.g., fractional anisotropy and mean diffusivity). We call this entire process tractometry.

To demonstrate the use of these methods, we compared tract profiles generated by pyAFQ to the original, matlab-based AFQ software. They are in close agreement and have similar test-retest intersubject reliability. We ran pyAFQ on test-retest data from the human connectome project (HCP) and compared different tractography and segmentation models and methods in this dataset. For comparison, we ran pyAFQ on clinical-grade data.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Influence of ageing and chronic stroke on postural control, muscle-tendon mechanics, and soleus muscle responses to proprioceptive stimuli during standing
Robyn Mildren
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Mildren RL, Johns Hopkins University; Pollock CL, University of British Columbia; Lim SB, University of British Columbia; Schmidt ME, University of British Columbia; Eschelmuller G, University of British Columbia; Carpenter MG, University of British Columbia; Blouin J-S, University of British Columbia; Inglis J.T., University of British Columbia

Proprioceptive sensory information from the lower limbs plays a critical role in the control of posture and balance, and changes in proprioceptive pathways with healthy ageing and following a stroke may contribute to impaired balance and falls. Here, we aimed to examine how healthy ageing and chronic stroke influence the frequency characteristics of the soleus muscle response to proprioceptive stimuli during standing. We also aimed to examine whether there are relationships between soleus responses, postural control, and muscle-tendon mechanics. We applied a continuous noisy vibration to the right or left Achilles tendon and examined responses in soleus surface EMG in a sample of 54 healthy adults across a broad age range (20–54 years) and 8 adults with chronic hemiparetic stroke. Our results showed the soleus response frequency bandwidth became progressively narrower with age, and soleus response gain was lower in older relative to young adults across a bandwidth of ~28–54 Hz. Across the age range, the amplitude of the soleus response was negatively correlated with age. We found minimal age-related differences in mechanical admittance of the muscle-tendon unit, suggesting this did not mediate the changes in soleus responses. Participants with chronic stroke had lower anteroposterior centre of pressure amplitude and frequency on the affected side, which suggests they relied more upon the less-affected limb for balance control. In addition, participants who showed an asymmetry in soleus responses characterized by larger responses on the affected side tended to have lower mechanical admittance at frequencies beyond ~20 Hz, as well as poorer motor recovery assessed with the Fugle-Meyer scale. The age-related changes in soleus responses to proprioceptive stimuli reflect progressive changes in muscle spindle morphology and stretch sensitivity, meanwhile, changes post-stroke may be related to altered muscle-tendon mechanics and postural control strategies.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Flexible modulation of navigational processing in association cortices as a function of task context
Andrew Alexander
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
A.S. Alexander; J.C. Tung; L.E. Shelley; A.M. Conner; G.W. Chapman; M.E. Hasselmo; D.A. Nitz;

Animals engage in a variety of navigational behaviors that require different regimes of behavioral control and different temporal scales of predictive coding. In the wild, rats readily switch between foraging and more complex behaviors such as chase, wherein they pursue other rats or small prey (Calhoun, 1963). These behaviors require vastly different tracking of multiple behaviorally-significant variables including self-motion state. It is unknown whether changes in behavioral context flexibly modulate the encoding of these variables. To explore this possibility, we compared self-motion processing in multisensory association cortices while rats performed alternating blocks of free foraging and visual target pursuit. Rats learned the pursuit task and demonstrated predictive processing by anticipating target trajectories and intercepting them. Relative to free exploration, pursuit sessions yielded greater proportions of parietal and retrosplenial cortex neurons with reliable sensitivity to self-motion. Pursuit self-motion correlates possessed enhanced signal-to-noise ratios, as a consequence of multiplicative gain modulation, which led to greater decoding accuracy of self-motion state over extended temporal windows of behavior. Finally, many self-motion sensitive neurons conjunctively tracked the position of the visual target relative to the animal in egocentric coordinates providing a potential mechanism for the observed gain changes to self-motion signals. We conclude that association cortex ensembles multiplex navigation-relevant variables in a dynamic manner to enhance behaviorally-relevant computations as a consequence of task demands.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Attention differentially modulates multiunit activity in the LGN and V1 of macaque monkeys
Shraddha Shah
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Shraddha Shah, Neuroscience Graduate Program, University of Rochester Medical Center; Marc Mancarella, Department of Neuroscience, University of Rochester School of Medicine; Jacqueline R. Hembrook-Short, Physiology & Neurobiology Department, Geisel School of Medicine at Dartmouth; Vanessa L. Mock, Ernest J. Del Monte Institute for Neuroscience, University of Rochester School of Medicine; Farran Briggs, Department of Neuroscience, University of Rochester School of Medicine, Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, University of Rochester, Center for Visual Science, University of Rochester

Attention promotes the selection of behaviorally relevant sensory signals. Attention effects, such as gain modulation of neuronal firing rate, are observed in all visual brain areas, including the visual thalamus (McAlonan et al., 2008; Maunsell, 2015). However, magnitudes of attentional gain modulations within and across visual brain areas differ depending on neuronal types, task, measurement, neuronal feature selectivity, etc. Diversity of attention effects across visual brain areas could suggest that attention effects depend on the functional architecture of a given area. To test this possibility, we evaluated attentional gain modulation in visual areas with distinct functional architectures using an aggregate measure of neuronal activity, multiunit firing rate. We recorded from the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) and primary visual cortex (V1) in macaque monkeys performing a contrast change detection task requiring covert shifts of visual spatial attention. Because multiunit activity reflects pooled signals from neurons embedded in the local functional architecture, we tested specific predictions about the dependence of attentional modulation of multiunit firing rates on functional architecture. We found evidence for unique relationships between multiunit activity and functional architecture in the LGN and V1. Effects were mostly consistent across different thresholds used to sort multiunits and temporal analysis windows. Consistent with single unit measures, attentional modulation of multiunits depended on whether multiunits were tuned to task-relevant visual features. Together these findings suggest that attentional modulation of multiunit activity in visual areas must be considered within the context of the underlying functional architecture.

 Interactive talk
Watch now
Searching for a neuromarker of spatial attention bias in school-aged children
NaYeon Kim (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Patricia Hoyos, Princeton University; Sabine Kastner, Princeton University

Visuo-spatial attention is a fundamental cognitive function that enables us to navigate visual environments efficiently. We recently found that children at ages 6-8 exhibit a preference for the left-hand side of space over the right-hand side when allocating attention. Such leftward attention biases in children gradually diminished with increasing age (manuscript under review). In adults, a subject’s spatial bias indicates an asymmetry in attentional weights generated within the dorsal fronto-parietal attention network (also known as Dorsal Attention Network) to direct attention to the contralateral side (Szczepanski & Kastner, 2013). Thus, leftward biases in children may indicate a hemispheric asymmetry in the developing attention network, which gradually achieves a more balanced control of spatial attention as a function of age. To explore this possibility, we first searched for a neuromarker of attention biases in children by building a functional connectivity-based predictive model (Shen et al., 2017) with a priori regions of interest. We measured spatial biases using a landmark task in school-aged children (age 6-12; N = 37) and collected functional MRI data while children were watching a short movie clip. We identified topographic areas in the frontal and parietal cortices by using a probabilistic atlas (Wang et al., 2015), such as Frontal Eye Fields (FEF) and subregions along the Intraparietal Sulcus (IPS). We were able to build a model that successfully predicted each child’s spatial bias from connectivity patterns across the fronto-parietal areas. Using a whole-brain parcellation scheme (Schaefer et al., 2018), we found that spatial biases were predicted specifically from this attention network, but not from other networks. Future work using this predictive modeling approach to examine the development of the attention network will be discussed. Our study provides a lens to better understand the link between attention behavior and the fronto-parietal attention network in typical and atypical development.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Deep Learning for Brain MRI Reconstruction: Expanding the U-Net
Makarand Parigi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Abhinav Saksena, University of Michigan; Yun Jiang, University of Michigan

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) has been used to investigate the structure and function of the brain and central nervous system (Kangarlu et al.). However, obtaining MR images of the brain often takes several minutes, which could be prohibitively long for studying neuronal activities in the brain. This process has been sped up by applying conventional reconstruction methods, such as parallel imaging and compressed sensing (Jaspan et al., Golay et al.). However, these methods are limited in accelerating MRI scans. Thus, developing an effective reconstruction method to further accelerate brain MRIs would help neuroscience researchers observe neuronal processes in a noninvasive manner. This could also result in more data that may support computational modeling of brain structure and function.
In this study, we investigate machine learning, in particular deep learning in reconstructing MR images. One prominent deep learning model is the U-Net (Ronneberger et al.) which transforms a noisy image into a clearer image, ideally suitable for use by neuroscientists and radiologists. However, most MRI machines today acquire data with multiple coils simultaneously, and the conventional U-Net does not take into account information from multiple coils; it operates once the data from multiple coils have been combined into a single image. This may mean a loss of valuable information for imaging reconstruction. We are experimenting with extending the U-Net to account for the additional information from multiple coils. We train these U-Net variations on the fastMRI dataset, a large corpus with brain MRI data (Zbontar et al.). In this talk, we describe the various models, examine preliminary results, and outline future directions.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Efferent and afferent estimates of hand location do not optimally integrate
Maria Ayala
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Marius 't Hart, Denise Henriques

The central nervous system (CNS) can rely on at least two sources of information in order to localize limb position in the absence of vision: (1) proprioceptive afferents from receptors in the limb, and (2) an efference copy of the motor command used by the cerebellum to generate a prediction of sensory consequences. To produce a reliable, single estimate about the location of the limb, these two sources of information could be optimally integrated using Bayesian integration, or maximum likelihood estimation (MLE). While some work has been done to investigate whether the CNS optimally combines visual and proprioceptive cues, less is known for the integration of non-sensory signals for limb estimates (i.e. efferent signals) given the difficulty of isolating them from the ever-present proprioceptive afferent signals. Here, we use our new paradigm to isolate efferent-based estimates of hand position from proprioception, by having over 200 healthy participants, both younger and older adults (55+), localize their hand after actively reaching in a self-chosen direction (active localization), or after being passively moved by a robotic manipulandum (passive localization). We then investigated if estimates of hand location based on both efferent and afferent signals (active localization) are more precise than those based only on proprioception (passive localization). According to the MLE rule, or other straightforward Bayesian mechanisms, variance should be lower in the localization condition where two signals are combined (active localization; prediction and proprioception) and higher with only a single source of information (passive localization; proprioception only), but we found no evidence in support of this. Further, we looked at whether weaker proprioceptive priors lead to greater learning-induced shifts in hand localization as would be predicted by Bayesian (optimal) inference. But we did not find that noisier, highly variable estimates were more susceptible to larger proprioceptive recalibration following adaptation to a perturbation suggesting a non-Bayesian mechanism for integration. Together, these findings make it less likely that the CNS uses optimal integration to combine efferent-based predicted sensory consequences and proprioceptive afferents when estimating and updating the final limb position.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Learning a Path-Integrating Circuit of the Drosophila Central Complex
Panteleimon Vafeidis
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Pantelis Vafidis, Computation and Neural Systems, Division of Biology and Biological Engineering, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, United States; Tiziano D'Albis, Institute for Theoretical Biology, Department of Biology, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, Berlin, Germany; David Owald, Institute of Neurophysiology, Charite – Universitatsmedizin Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Richard Kempter, Institute for Theoretical Biology, Department of Biology, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, Berlin, Germany;

Head direction cells are neurons that respond selectively to a specific head orientation in space. They are organized in a recurrent network, where the current head orientation is represented by a localized bump of neuronal activity. Path integration in the context of head direction cells is moving this bump of activity around the network respecting the animal's current head orientation, while using only self-motion cues. The one-dimensional ring attractor has been a popular approach to model the network of head direction cells, and one of the most long-lived attractor network models in Computational Neuroscience. Furthermore, this model has recently received experimental support in the fly's head direction system. However, it remains to date unclear how a path integrating circuit of head direction cells could self-organize through synaptic plasticity. Previous models showed circuits that either needed parameter tuning after training, or used biologically implausible learning rules.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Learning and attention increase neuronal response selectivity in mouse primary visual cortex through distinct mechanisms
Adil Khan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jasper Poort; Katharina Wilmes; Antonin Blot; Angus Chadwick; Maneesh Sahani; Claudia Clopath; Thomas Mrsic-Flogel; Sonja Hofer

Response selectivity of cortical neurons can increase for behaviorally relevant stimuli across days as animals learn a novel stimulus-reward association, and across seconds when animals transiently attend to sensory stimuli. While both phenomena can act on the same cortical circuit, it is unknown whether they rely on the same mechanisms. We imaged activity of the same neuronal populations in primary visual cortex as mice learned a visual discrimination task and subsequently performed an attentional switching task. Selectivity changes due to learning and attention were largely uncorrelated at the single-cell level. Selectivity increases after learning were mainly due to selective suppression of responses to one of the task relevant stimuli but relied on both selective enhancement and suppression during attention. Furthermore, learning and attention differentially affected interactions between excitatory and different inhibitory cell classes. Circuit modelling revealed that cell class specific top-down inputs best explained attention modulation, while reorganization of local functional connectivity accounts for specific learning related changes. These results suggest that distinct mechanisms underlie increased discriminability of relevant sensory stimuli across longer and shorter time scales.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Functional connectivity measured during movie watching, but not rest, predicts social function in children and adolescents
Taylor Chamberlain
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Taylor A. Chamberlain, University of Chicago; Monica D. Rosenberg, University of Chicago

Whole-brain functional connectivity has become an increasingly popular method for relating individual differences in behavior to brain function. Functional connectivity-based models predict a variety of abilities and behaviors, including sustained attention function (Rosenberg et al., 2016) and personality dimensions (Hsu et al., 2018). Traditionally, functional connectivity research has utilized resting-state scans, thought to provide a relatively “neutral” context. However, recent work suggests that rest may not be an ideal state for studying individual differences (Finn et al., 2017). In fact, models built on functional connectivity data observed during movie-watching outperform those built on rest data in predicting cognitive and emotional phenotypes in adults (Finn et al., 2020). Here, we test whether this finding generalizes to a developmental population. Our sample consisted of 266 individuals ages 6-17, from the Healthy Brain Network Biobank (Alexander et al., 2017). We calculated individual-level functional connectomes from four fMRI scans: two resting-state scans and two scans obtained while participants watched emotionally evocative video clips. To define a summary measure of social function, we applied principal component (PC) analysis to scores on questionnaires related to social behavior (e.g., Social Responsiveness Scale) using data from Healthy Brain Network participants without usable fMRI data. Scores on the first PC, which explained 78% of the variance in the behavior-only sample, were generated for each participant in the fMRI sample. Connectome-based predictive models (Shen et al., 2017) trained and tested with 10-fold cross-validation predicted social PC scores from movie-watching, but not resting-state, data. This pattern of results was robust to effects of age, head motion, and scan duration, such that models based on movie—but not rest—data predicted social PC scores from less than three minutes of data. Thus, fMRI functional connectivity data collected during naturalistic movie viewing, rather than during rest, may best predict social function in development.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Multidimensional analysis and detection of informative features in diffusion MRI measurements of human white matter
Adam Richie-Halford
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jason Yeatman, Stanford University; Noah Simon, University of Washington; Ariel Rokem, University of Washington

Tractometry uses diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (dMRI) to quantify tissue properties along the trajectories of white matter connections (Yeatman et al. 2012). Tractometry results are usually analyzed using mass univariate approaches, computed separately for each point along tracts (Colby et al. 2012), akin to fMRI voxel-wise analysis. Alternatively, an a priori hypothesis is used, where tissue properties are computed for a specific tract of interest. In the present work, we introduce a method based on the Sparse Group Lasso (SGL; Simon et al., 2013) that selects informative features by enforcing sparsity, both at the level of individual tracts and across the entire set of tracts, thereby recovering the minimal set of anatomical features to make accurate predictions. Our method presents a significant departure from previous analysis of tractometry data: rather than providing p-values for each individual location in the brain, the statistical accuracy of this method focuses on the accuracy of the predictions of phenotypic data.

We validated our approach in both regression and classification settings. An example dataset for classification contained data from 24 patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and 24 matched controls (Sarica et al. 2017). An example dataset for regression contained data from 76 healthy subjects, ranging between 6 years and 50 years of age and a validation dataset contained 641 healthy subjects from the Cam-CAN dataset. In the classification setting, we demonstrate that this method competes with previous results without the need for a priori feature engineering. Moreover, it automatically identifies well-known features of the disease. In the regression setting, the data can be used to accurately predict "brain age". Thus, this multivariate approach both (a) achieves high cross-validated accuracy for precision medicine applications of dMRI data and (b) identifies relevant features of brain anatomy to further our neuroscientific understanding of clinical disorders.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Frequency-Dependent Force Direction Elucidates Neural Control of Balance
Kaymie Shiozawa
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kaymie Shiozawa, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Jongwoo Lee, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Marta Russo, Departments of Biology, Electrical and Computer Engineering, Physics, Northeastern University; Dagmar Sternad, Departments of Biology, Electrical and Computer Engineering, Physics, Northeastern University; Neville Hogan, Departments of Mechanical Engineering and Brain and Cognitive Sciences, Massachusetts Institute of Technology

Balance is an unstable task that requires control of translational and rotational motions. Humans use foot-ground interaction force, characterized by direction, point of application, and magnitude, to manage body accelerations. Previous work identified a point of intersection of foot-ground interaction forces that exhibited consistent frequency-dependent behavior across multiple subjects. To test whether this frequency-dependent behavior provided a distinctive signature of neural control or was a necessary consequence of biomechanics, this study simulated quiet standing and compared the results with human subject data. If a standing human was modeled as a single inverted pendulum, no controller could reproduce the experimentally observed frequency-dependence of the intersection point. The simplest competent model that approximated a standing human was a double inverted pendulum with torque-actuated ankle and hip joints. It was stabilized by a linear feedback controller based on position and velocity errors of each joint. Numerous controller parameter sets could stabilize this model and produce a change in vertical position of the intersection point with increasing frequency; the observed decrease in height appears to reflect a biomechanical constraint. However, a controller that best reproduced the results observed in human standing used minimal effort and more ankle torque than hip torque. These observations imply that human subjects employed a neural strategy that prioritizes the use of the ankle torque and minimizes overall control effort to balance.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Biomimetic stimulation improves accuracy of vestibular prosthesis-evoked vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) responses
Kantapon Pum Wiboonsaksakul (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Dale C Roberts, Johns Hopkins University; Charles C Della Santina, Johns Hopkins University; Kathleen E Cullen, Johns Hopkins University

The vestibular system is crucial for maintaining visual stability via the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR). Accordingly, patients with bilateral vestibulopathy suffer debilitating oscillopsia and dizziness. To improve patients’ quality of life, one emerging approach is a prosthesis that senses head rotation and transforms the movement into vestibular afferent stimulation, substituting for the damaged periphery. Though such devices can partially restore VOR function, current approaches do not represent the specific high-pass dynamics by which actual vestibular afferents encode head motion. We hypothesized that a more biomimetic design would improve performance. To test this, we incorporated afferent-like dynamics into our vestibular prosthesis. Two rhesus monkeys with bilateral vestibular hypofunction were implanted with unilateral prosthesis (targeting horizontal canal afferents). At 7 rotation frequencies (0.2 – 20 Hz), we recorded the VOR eye movements evoked by 5 different mappings: 1) no dynamics (constant gain and no phase lead), 2) regular afferent-like dynamics, 3) irregular afferent-like dynamics, 4) the combination of the two, and 5) very high-pass irregular dynamics. The gain and phase of the evoked VOR response were then analyzed. All 4 afferent-like mappings yielded constant gains up to ~5 Hz while the gains remained constant only up to 1 Hz without the afferent-like dynamics. The phase of the 4 biomimetic mappings was more compensatory (temporally precise) across a range of frequencies. In contrast, the mapping without dynamics did not maintain accurate timing and showed increasing phase lag as a function of frequency, consistent with an uncompensated fixed delay. Overall, our results show that a mapping that mimics regular afferents best maintains the VOR gain and compensatory phase response across frequencies. Further, our results have a direct clinical significance, providing support for a more biomimetic approach to improve prosthesis performance and, in turn, functional outcomes of patients with bilateral vestibulopathy.
Traditional talk
Watch now
The Influence of Individually Ventilated Cage Conditions on Rats’ Anxiety-Related Behaviours
Emma Littler
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Emma Littler, Queen's University; Jessica MacKay, Queen's University; Janet Menard, Queen's University

In recent years, many animal research facilities have transitioned from using traditional open-top cages (OTCs) to using individually ventilated cages (IVCs) to house rodent colonies. Although the use of IVCs has clear benefits, there have been unanticipated drawbacks. Some research has suggested that IVCs may lead to increased rodent stress levels, however, the exact cause for this increase remains unknown. One cage-condition that is unique to IVCs, and may be responsible for increasing stress levels, is the air pressure environment inside the cage. IVCs can be operated under negative or positive pressure, however, little is known about how air pressure might influence behaviour. The social housing of rodents in OTCs is known to buffer rodents’ responses to stress, and is a well-validated phenomenon termed “social buffering”. At present, it is unknown if this phenomenon carries over to rodents housed in IVCs, and if this “social buffering” response is dependent on the type of air pressure. Rats were randomly assigned to single- or paired-housing in IVCs under negative or positive pressure. Five weeks after housing assignment, rats’ anxiety-like behaviour was measured in the elevated plus maze (EPM), and their brain tissue was processed to examine oxytocin-immunoreactivity (OT-ir) in the hypothalamus. The anxiety-reducing effects of pair-housing were only evident in rats housed under positive pressure. Although there were no differences in the number of OT-ir cells in the paraventricular nucleus (PVN) of the hypothalamus between single- and pair-housed animals, a higher number of OT-ir cells in the PVN was significantly correlated with decreased anxiety-like behaviour. These findings suggest that IVCs may be altering well-validated behavioural profiles in rodents, and this may be in part due to the unique cage-conditions that IVCs present. As such, this research aims to improve the welfare of laboratory rodents by refining and improving their housing conditions.
Traditional talk
Watch now
TRPA1 mediates cold nociception in Drosophila melanogaster larvae
Mariana Holguin-Lopez
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
J.M. Lechter, Georgia State University; N. J. Himmel, Georgia State University; A. Sakurai, Georgia State University; D. N. Cox, Georgia State University.

Nociception is the process by which an organism detects potentially harmful stimuli, driving behavioral responses that minimize incipient damage and promote organismal survival. Nociception relies on specialized channel receptors to detect these stimuli. Thermal nociception is responsible for the detection of noxious thermal stimuli at either extreme. Transient receptor potential (TRP) channels play a crucial role in thermal nociception. However, there is little knowledge regarding how they mechanistically function in the regulation of noxious cold detection. TRPA1 is a polymodal channel that is conserved among vertebrates and invertebrates. Human TRPA1 has been implicated in mediating cold nociception, though its functional role in this process remains poorly understood. In Drosophila larvae, TRPA1 has been identified in polymodal nociceptive neurons in which it mediates chemical, high heat, and mechanical nociception. Recent neurogenomic analyses have identified TRPA1 expression in cold nociceptive sensory neurons (Class III; CIII), which suggests the possibility that this channel is also involved in the mediation of noxious cold detection. We have employed neurogenetic and behavioral techniques to dissect the role of TRPA1 in this process.
Whole animal TRPA1 mutants displayed a decrease in the characteristic contractile behavior in response to noxious cold temperatures; this was also observed in CIII-specific TRPA1 knockdown larvae. The requirement for TRPA1 was observed to be isoform specific. Optogenetic and behavioral analyses attested that TRPA1 is required for stimulus transduction rather than for action potential propagation. These findings provide insights into the underlying mechanism of cold detection while also raising questions regarding the polymodality and evolutionary role of TRPA1 channels. A better understanding of how the nociceptive phenomenon works could provide information that will aid in the development of better treatments for neuropathies, such as allodynia and hyperalgesia.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Distinctive signatures of information seeking during changes of mind in controllable environments
Marion Rouault
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Marion Rouault, Department of Cognitive Studies, Ecole Normale Superieure de Paris, France; Aurélien Weiss, Department of Cognitive Studies, Ecole Normale Superieure de Paris, France; Jun Seok Lee, Department of Cognitive Studies, Ecole Normale Superieure de Paris, France; Jules Bouté, Department of Cognitive Studies, Ecole Normale Superieure de Paris, France; Jan Drugowitsch, Department of Neurobiology, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA 02115, USA; Valérian Chambon, Department of Cognitive Studies, Ecole Normale Superieure de Paris, France; Valentin Wyart, Department of Cognitive Studies, Ecole Normale Superieure de Paris, France

The ability to flexibly adjust our confidence and change our mind in light of new information is a hallmark of human cognition. Using perceptual decision-making as a model system, previous work has focused on situations in which participants are observers adapting their decisions to incoming evidence. However, in many real-life settings, subjects exert active control over their environment when sampling information for decision-making. Here, we examined how being in control over evidence sampling influenced changes of mind and the associated confidence, as compared to uncontrollable environments. Across five variants of the same experiment (N=113 human participants), we found that changes of mind required more evidence against current beliefs in controllable environments. These changes of mind were also associated with reduced confidence, but were more likely to be confirmed on the next trial. Computational modelling revealed that in controllable environments, more stable beliefs, rather than a reduced sensitivity to evidence explained these differences. At the neurophysiological level, changes of mind in controllable environments were associated with a stronger involvement of a dorsal attentional network in MEG, and were followed by an increased pupil-linked arousal during decision evaluation. Together these findings characterise specific signatures of human information seeking in controllable environments.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
A circuit-based theory of the impact of cortical state on information flow
Matt Getz (he/his)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Chengcheng Huang, University of Pittsburgh; Brent Doiron, University of Chicago

Cortical state changes such as attention or arousal are a frequent topic of study as they allow for the inference of relationships between changes in cortical activity and behavior. Intuition for these links has been derived from how response properties often subject to cortical state modulation, like tuning and correlated variability, relate to information flow. However, despite the widespread use of these results in unpacking experimental observations, it remains to fully consider how modulation of cortical state affects stimulus processing. To this end we look at the effect of cortical state on information flow in cortical circuit models and find that linear Fisher information does not change with cortical state if the operating regime of cortex is well-described by a linear response function. This is because any state-dependent changes in response gain are canceled by changes in population variability. We show that if one restricts a decoder to a subset of a cortical population, information within the subpopulation can increase through modulation of cortical state. One clear example is that of excitatory and inhibitory cells in a network: only excitatory cells project along the cortical hierarchy, and are thereby the only targets of interest to a downstream decoder. Surprisingly, we find that only those cells which are not accessible to the decoder can modulate how information flow changes within the decoded population. Our theory additionally reveals a parametrically simplified and intuitive framework for analyzing the effects of modulation on information processing, thereby adding valuable insight into a widespread phenomenon across cortical networks.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Comparing decision-making across social, emotional, and perceptual tasks
Iris Vilares
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Nathan Torunsky

Every day we are making decisions that have associated uncertainty. They range from the perceptual, sensorimotor ones (e.g. grabbing a cup of coffee) to high-level, social ones (should I trust this person?). However, while considerable research has been done within each domain, how the decision-making at the perceptual/sensorimotor level relates to decisions at higher levels is still largely unknown. Furthermore, existing research suggests that, for certain psychiatric disorders, there may be decision-making differences already at a perceptual level (e.g. autism; schizophrenia). However, the extent to which this happens in different conditions and pre-clinical traits is still not well understood. My research combines perceptual, sensorimotor, emotional and social decision-making to better understand the connection (or lack thereof) between these different decision-making levels. In addition, we analyze how decision-making at different levels is affected by psychiatric conditions and personality traits. In our more recent, pre-registered study, we analyzed people’s behavior in a perceptual task (dot-motion), an emotion recognition task (the Reading the Mind in the Eyes test, RMET), and a social decision-making task (trust game), in a Midwest community sample (Minnesota State Fair goers, n = 123). We found no correlation between participants' performance across tasks. However, we found a strong positive correlation of decision confidence across tasks: participants more confident in their responses in a perceptual task also tended to be more confident in their responses on the emotion-recognition task and social task. Furthermore, reported confidence across tasks correlated negatively with participant’s alexithymia scores (a subclinical trait characterized by low emotional awareness). Altogether, our results suggest that confidence in one’s decisions is a personality trait that spans different types of decisions, and that it may be related to the degree of emotional awareness one has.
Traditional talk
Watch now
The Influence of Social Housing and Housing Air Pressure on Rats’ Anxiety-Related Behaviour
Alex Prosserman
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Janet Menard; Samantha Irwin; Emma Littler

Research facilities are increasingly adopting individually ventilated cages (IVCs), a standardized caging system to improve rodents’ wellbeing. IVCs may alter well-characterized displays of rodent behaviour, which poses a unique concern for psychological research. It was not previously known if IVCs alter the anxiety reducing effects of social-housing in rats. Thus, this study examined whether social-housing produced anxiety reducing effects on Long-Evans rats housed in IVCs, as indexed by their behaviour in a Modified Novelty-Induced Suppression of Feeding Test (NSFT) and the density of their oxytocin-labelled cells in the hypothalamus. This study further investigated whether maintaining the IVCs under positive or negative air pressure influenced the rats’ behavioural and neuroanatomical outcomes. It was predicted that single-housing and positive air pressure would increase the rats’ latencies to initiate snack consumption in the NSFT and reduce the density of their oxytocin-labelled cells in the hypothalamus, suggesting increased anxiety-like behaviour. Surprisingly, there was no evidence that social housing influenced the rats’ latencies to initiate snack consumption across the habituation or test trials. However, there was a marked and unexpected main effect of air pressure such that the rats housed under negative air pressure took longer to bite the palatable snack than those housed under positive air pressure. Finally, single-housed rats under positive air pressure displayed more oxytocin-labelled cells in the PaPo of the hypothalamus. These results suggest that IVCs can alter the well-characterized anxiety reducing effect of social housing in laboratory rodents, and might influence other well-characterized displays of rodent behaviour.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Neural Circuitry of Water Seeking in Drosophila
Dan Landayan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Dan Landayan, Stanford; Jennifer Zhou, UC Merced; Brian Wang, UC Merced; Fred Wolf, UC Merced

Thirst is an evolutionarily ancient motivational state that is hard-wired and critical for survival. How thirst circuits in the brain coordinate the appropriate goal-directed behavior, and how it can do so in the presence of opposing behavioral states such as hunger, is not well understood. We show that a persistent state of thirst is evoked by the precise activation and inactivation of overlapping central brain neuronal circuit elements in Drosophila. In a neuronal activation screen, we identified a subset of glutamatergic neurons that evoke robust thirst-related behaviors, including water seeking and intake; we named these neurons Durstig, the German for thirsty.These central brain neurons function downstream of sensory input and internal osmotic sensors to drive seeking to either open orin accessible water.Importantly, activation of Durstig neurons overrides food seeking in water replete but hungry flies. Thus, neural circuit elements that regulate hunger and thirst are tightly integrated. These studies provide an entry point for mapping the fundamental homeostatic thirst neurons and the hierarchical wiring of neural circuits that encode opposing motivational states.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Within and across domain effects of choice-induced bias
Wojciech Zajkowski
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Wojciech Zajkowski, Cardiff University; Jiaxiang Zhang, Cardiff University

Recent evidence suggests choices influence evaluation, giving rise to choice-induced confirmation bias. It is however unknown whether this phenomenon is constrained to the domain of choice, or spans across domains, allowing a decision to influence evaluation of unrelated item-specific information.
Here, we intermix value-based and perceptual choices and evaluations of a set of appetitive stimuli to study both within and across domain effects of choices on value estimation. In a set of 5 experiments (4 preregistered, total of 425 participants) we find strong and consistent evidence for both within and across domain effects of choice induced bias in both domains. This means perceptual choices influenced subjective appetitive value, and value-based choices influenced perceived size.
The effect is stronger for value-based estimations, and for domain-congruent choices. The bias is driven to a greater extent by devaluing rejected items, is specific to endogenous (self-generated) choices, and cannot be explained by positive evidence bias. Our generative model of choice-driven value fluctuation reveals that only within-domain effects are long lasting.
These findings reveal that the act of free choice influences the estimation of both choice-relevant and irrelevant attributes of the chosen item, providing further insight into how choices shape internal values.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
A detailed computational model of thalamic and cortical microcircuits based on inference in a generative vision model
Dileep George
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Miguel Lázaro-Gredilla, Wolfgang Lehrach, Antoine Dedieu, Guangyao Zhou

Understanding the information processing roles of cortical circuits is an outstanding problem in neuroscience and artificial intelligence. Theory-driven efforts will be required to tease apart the functional logic of cortical circuits from the vast amounts of experimental data on cortical connectivity and physiology. Although the theoretical setting of Bayesian inference has been suggested as a framework for understanding cortical computation, making precise and falsifiable biological mappings need models that tackle the challenge of real world tasks. Based on a recent generative model, Recursive Cortical Networks, that demonstrated excellent performance on visual task benchmarks, we derive a family of anatomically instantiated and functional cortical circuit models. Efficient inference and generalization guided the representational choices in the original computational model. The cortical circuit model is derived by systematically comparing the computational requirements of this model with known anatomical constraints. The derived model suggests precise functional roles for the feed-forward, feedback, and lateral connections observed in different laminae and columns, assigns a computational role for the path through the thalamus, predicts the interactions between blobs and inter-blobs, and offers an algorithmic explanation for the innate inter-laminar connectivity between clonal neurons within a cortical column. The model also explains several visual phenomena, including the subjective contour effect, and neon-color spreading effect, with circuit-level precision. Our work paves a new path forward in understanding the logic of cortical and thalamic circuits.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Discrete and continuous dynamics of neural state space during decision making
Jun Ye
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sunandha Srikanth, Department of Biological Sciences, Institution: University of California, San Diego; Tanvi Ranjan, School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University; Frances S. Cho, Dept. of Neurology, University of California San Francisco; Jun Ye, NMA

Perceptual decision-making tasks involve transforming continuous sensory inputs into discrete decisions and continuous actions (Parr & Friston, 2018). This transformation occurs across a large network of brain areas. In mice performing such a task, neurons encoding choice are localized in forebrain and midbrain regions, while neurons encoding action initiation are distributed across the brain (Steinmetz et al. 2019). Whether the representation of brain-wide neural activity during such a transformation evolves in a continuous or discrete manner remains unclear (VanRullen & Koch, 2003). Hidden Markov models (HMM) can be used to assess neural dynamics when latent neural states are assumed to be discrete. Here, we compare this approach with that describing smooth evolution of states by decoding behavior following either HMM, or independent component analysis (ICA) using data collected by Steinmetz et al (2019).
Discrete state representation via HMM had similar decoding accuracy when decoding visual stimulus (present or not) compared to that obtained via continuous state via ICA. In contrast, continuous representation yielded greater accuracy in decoding action (go vs no-go) compared to discretized state reduction. Across sessions, discretized states mapped onto different behavioral epochs, potentially due to differences in the brain regions sampled, how individual mice approach the task, or between-day variability of a given mouse. We used a generalized linear model (GLM) to refine the discrete state representation in light of this variability. Coupling of neural spiking rate to behavior was used as a proxy for neurons’ contribution to behavior. We use insights from the GLM to refine the comparison of discrete and continuous models for decoding behavior. These results suggest a quick/almost instant change in neural dynamics in response to visual stimulus and a slow changing dynamics, when leading to action.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Evidence of Social Buffering in Rats Housed in Individually Ventilated Cages (IVCs)
Benjamin Streatch (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Benjamin Streatch; Samantha Irwin; Emma Littler; Janet Menard, Queen's University Department of Psychology

Rodent research facilities are increasingly adopting the use of individually ventilated cages (IVCs), despite initial evidence that these hermetically sealed housing units might be inherently stressful. As well, maintaining IVCs under positive air pressure could be more stressful than negative air pressure, in that the former (but not the latter) completely isolates rodents from the smells and sounds of other conspecifics in the colony. We asked if social housing, known to buffer rats’ responses to acute and/or chronic stress, serves a similar, protective role when rodents are housed in IVCs, and further, whether “social buffering” depends on the type of air pressure adopted. Rats were randomly assigned to either single- or paired-housing in each of the two air pressure conditions. After eight weeks in their respective housing condition, rats were tested in the shock-probe burying test, and then their brain tissue was processed to determine oxytocin-immunoreactivity (OT-ir) in the hypothalamus. Independent of air pressure, single-housed rats displayed marked reductions in probe burying relative to pair-housed rats. Given that chronic stress reduces active coping responses, including shock-probe burying, it might be the case that chronic stress-related outcomes linked to IVCs can be buffered by social housing. Our OT findings partially support this, in that the number of OT-ir cells was reduced in the posterior parvocellular region of the PVN of single-housed rats, but only if they were housed under negative air pressure. This suggests that these effects of air pressure condition were buffered by social housing. These findings inform efforts to improve housing conditions for animals used in research.

Acknowledgements: Research Supported by NSERC

 Traditional talk
Watch now
Neural mechanisms underlying temperature-driven host seeking by a skin-penetrating human-parasitic nematode
Astra Bryant (she, her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Felicitas Ruiz, UCLA; Elissa Hallem, UCLA

Skin-penetrating parasitic nematodes are a major source of “diseases of disadvantage,” infecting approximately 1 billion people. Their life cycle includes an infective third-larval (iL3) stage that searches for hosts in a poorly understood process involving thermal cues. We measured temperature-driven behaviors in multiple parasitic-nematode species, including the human-parasitic threadworm Strongyloides stercoralis. We found that mammalian-parasitic iL3s are highly sensitive to thermal gradients. At temperatures above their cultivation temperature, iL3s display robust attraction to mammalian body temperatures (37°C). Temperature-driven responses are dominant in multisensory contexts; when below host body temperature, iL3s prioritize temperature-driven behaviors over chemosensory attraction to host odors.

We leveraged the genetic similarities between S. stercoralis and the free-living model nematode Caenorhabditis elegans to investigate mechanisms underlying temperature-driven host seeking. For C. elegans, thermotaxis behaviors within their physiological temperature range (~15-25°C) depend on the Ce-tax-4 gene, which encodes a cyclic nucleotide-gated channel subunit. We showed that targeted mutagenesis of Ss-tax-4 abolishes iL3 heat seeking, suggesting this behavior is generated through adaptations of conserved molecular cascades. In C. elegans, AFD sensory neurons provide the primary thermosensory drive for thermotaxis navigation. We genetically identified the S. stercoralis AFD neurons, and found that inducible silencing of these neurons suppresses iL3 heat seeking. Thus, AFD’s thermosensory role is conserved between S. stercoralis and C. elegans despite species-specific differences in thermal preference, behavior, and AFD dendritic structure. Using genetically encoded calcium sensors, we found that temperature-driven responses in Ss-AFD are distinct from those in Ce-AFD. Furthermore, at least two Ss-AFD-specific receptor guanylate cyclases confer sensitivity to temperature ranges that include mammalian body temperatures, compared to only one in C. elegans. Thus, altered thermal encoding in primary thermosensory neurons likely contributes to parasite-specific behaviors. Together, our results provide insight into the behavioral strategies, neural circuits, and molecular mechanisms that allow skin-penetrating nematodes to target hosts.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Systematic biases in rare-event inferences
Tahra Eissa
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Josh Gold, University of Pennsylvania; Kresimir Josic, University of Houston; Zachary Kilpatrick, University of Colorado Boulder

When choosing between different options we often rely on information of non-uniform frequency and quality. For example, when evidence for one option is rare, these observations are of high quality, while evidence that may be abundant is often less convincing. Moreover, the information available to an observer is often limited, restricting the amount of high-quality evidence that may be obtained. How do human observers make decisions in situations with asymmetric evidence quality, especially when the amount of evidence is limited? Recruiting over 200 subjects from crowdsourcing platform Amazon Mechanical Turk, we consider how humans approach these decisions with a task in which subjects observe a sequence of red/blue balls drawn with replacement from one of two jars with known ratios of ball colors. Subjects must infer which of the two equally probable jars the balls were drawn from. When both jars have ball ratios that favor the same color (one ball color is rare), subjects show a strong bias toward the jar with the more extreme ratio, even when evidence came from the higher-fraction jar. Notably, these biases are predicted by an ideal Bayesian observer. However, many human observers show an enhanced bias in line with a Bayesian but not optimal approach. We have attributed this enhancement to subjects underweighing the information gained by a rare ball observation along with an overall preference for the more extreme response. We confirmed these results using model-free information theory metrics that showed a drop-off in the effective use of task information as subjects deviated from the ideal observer. Thus, our study yields new quantitative insights into rare-event inference, which is relevant to both real-world problems (like predicting stock-market crashes) and common laboratory tasks (like inferring rare state changes in dynamic environments).
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Constrained brain volume in an efficient coding model explains the fraction of excitatory and inhibitory neurons in sensory cortices
Arish Alreja
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ilya Nemenman, Emory University; Christopher Rozell, Georgia Institute of Technology

The number of neurons in mammalian cortex varies by multiple orders of magnitude across different species. In contrast, the ratio of excitatory to inhibitory neurons (E:I ratio) varies in a much smaller range, from 3:1 to 9:1 and remains roughly constant for different sensory areas within a species. Despite this structure being important for understanding the function of neural circuits, the reason for this consistency is not yet understood. While recent models of vision based on the efficient coding hypothesis show that increasing the number of both excitatory and inhibitory cells improves stimulus representation, the two cannot increase simultaneously due to constraints on brain volume. In this work, we implement an efficient coding model of vision under a volume (i.e., total number of neurons) constraint while varying the E:I ratio. We show that the performance of the model is optimal at biologically observed E:I ratios under several metrics. We argue that this happens due to trade-offs between the computational accuracy and the representation capacity for natural stimuli. Further, we make experimentally testable predictions that 1) the optimal E:I ratio should be higher for species with a higher sparsity in the neural activity and 2) the character of inhibitory synaptic distributions and firing rates should change depending on E:I ratio. Our findings, which are supported by our new preliminary analyses of publicly available data, provide the first quantitative and testable hypothesis based on optimal coding models for the distribution of neural types in the mammalian sensory cortices.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Economic Choices with Simultaneous or Sequential Offers Rely on the Same Neural Circuit Mechanism
Weikang Shi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Weikang Shi, Washington University in St. Louis; Sebastien Ballesta, Washington University in St. Louis; Camillo Padoa-Schioppa, Washington University in St. Louis

Economic choices entail assigning values to the available options; a decision is then made by comparing values. Studies in which monkeys chose between two juices identified in the orbitofrontal cortex (OFC) different groups of cells encoding the value of individual options (offer value), the binary choice outcome (chosen juice) and the chosen value. These variables capture both the input and the output of the choice process, suggesting that these groups of neurons constitute the building blocks of a decision circuit. Experimental and theoretical results support this hypothesis. However, current notions emerged from studies where offers were presented simultaneously; conversely, it was suggested that choices between goods offered (or attended) sequentially rely on different mechanisms. Ballesta et al. recently examined OFC activity during economic decisions under sequential offers. They found different groups of cells seemingly analogous to those identified under simultaneous offers: group1 cells encoded the value of one particular juice whenever that juice was offered; group2 cells encoded the value of the juice currently offered and, subsequently, the chosen value; group3 cells encoded in a binary way the juice type present on the monitor and, subsequently, the chosen juice. Here we directly examined the relation between these cell groups and those previously identified under simultaneous offers. Monkeys performed economic decisions alternating between the two task modalities in a trial-by-trial way. Our results indicate that decisions under sequential offers and under simultaneous offers rely on the same neural circuit.
Keynote Event
Watch now
Minisymposium on Connectomics: a new era of dissemination and discovery (Chair: Sebastian Seung)
 
Abstract
 
Over the past fifteen years, the field of connectomics has developed in three overlapping stages. The first two have focused on the technical challenges of data collection and automated reconstruction. Now the third and most exciting stage is picking up speed. This symposium will describe connectomic resources that are being disseminated now, and the discoveries that they are enabling.

Chair:
Sebastian Seung (Princeton University)

Talks:
- "FlyWire: online community for whole-brain connectomics"
Mala Murthy (Princeton University)

- A connectome-based neural network model of the Drosophila visual system
Srini Turaga (HHMI Janelia Research Campus)

- Neural coding and dynamics from a brainstem wiring diagram
Mark Goldman (University of California, Davis)

- A surprising new function of oligodendrocyte precursor cells
JoAnn Buchanan (Allen Brain Institute)

- The mind of a mouse
Jeff Lichtman (Harvard University)

Exploring the CellF
Guy Benary
Traditional talk
Watch now
An ROI-based fMRI Study of Schizophrenia for Identification of Affected Brain Regions
Indranath Chatterjee
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Lea Baumgärtner, Hochschule der Medien, University of Applied Science, Stuttgart - 70569, Germany;

Schizophrenia, a severe psychological disorder, is very prevalent in the world. The research on schizophrenia using machine learning techniques and neuroimaging is an active area of study. The functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) helps to identify the brain activity in voxels, consisting of measured changes in blood-oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) signals over time. Based on the fMRI data of 34 schizophrenia patients and 34 healthy controls, we performed a Region of Interest (ROI) study on the identified brain regions for studying hundreds of literature over the last 30 years. Besides, we parcellate the brain into four levels of hierarchy, Hemisphere, Gyrus, Lobes, and Cell type (Broadmann Areas). We applied statistical feature selection techniques, such as t-test and Pearson's Correlation on the preprocessed data to identify the significant regions in each level. The selected features were used for training several machine learning classifiers to analyze the prediction performance of affected brain regions. As for the machine learning approach, we used various classifiers such as K-nearest Neighbor, Naive Bayes, Decision Tree, Random Forest, Support Vector Machines, and Extreme Learning Machines. We achieved the highest classification accuracy of around 84 % on the Pearson's correlation selected Lobe's data, 84 % on the Broadmann areas' data, and similarly 81 % on the Gyrus data and Hemisphere data. Furthermore, we performed backtracking of the statistically significant selected features and visualized them better to understand the affected brain areas in schizophrenia patients. The reviewed papers depicted region-wise changes in schizophrenia confirm our findings. With the result of our work, we examined the previous research conclusions on an ROI-based approach. Also, we found some affected brain regions, which were never reported before in the literature on schizophrenia. These new findings may open up a possible way of understanding schizophrenia patients' brains from different perspectives.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Hierarchical stochastic block modeling in the Drosophila connectome
Tingshan Liu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tingshan Liu, Johns Hopkins University; Benjamin D. Pedigo, Johns Hopkins University; Thomas L. Athey, Johns Hopkins University; Joshua T. Vogelstein, Johns Hopkins University

A connectome describes functional interactions or structural connections between regions of interest in the brain. The Drosophila connectome has been studied extensively in the literature and modeled as a complex network to understand the relationship between brain functionality and animal behavior. Similar to human connectomes, Drosophila connectomes also exhibit modular structure despite their relatively small sizes where cluster-like regions in the brain can be further divided into subclusters based on functional or structural similarity. Built upon an automatic Gaussian mixture modeling technique, we introduce a hierarchical stochastic blockmodel clustering algorithm which recursively clusters a network to obtain sub-clusters that can be approximated as stochastic blockmodels. We demonstrate the hierarchical structure of the mushroom body of Drosophila connectomes revealed by the proposed algorithm.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Altered amygdala functional connectivity across Schizo-Bipolar spectrum and facial emotion recognition
Jiaxu Han
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Victoria Okuneye, The University of Chicago; Sarah Keedy, The University of Chicago

Research purpose: Previous research has consistently reported facial emotion recognition deficits across the schizo-bipolar spectrum. Though its neural mechanism is still not well understood, there is evidence suggested altered functional activity in the amygdala in schizophrenia-spectrum disorders during facial emotion tasks. The current study aims to compare the amygdala resting-state functional connectivity between patients across the schizo-bipolar spectrum and healthy controls as well as its correlation to the behavioral performance of a dynamic facial emotion recognition task (DARE). Method: Subjects were selected from a multi-site study (BSNIP) and they completed the DARE task and a resting-state fMRI scan. After removing scans with poor quality and excessive motion, the current study included a total of 346 subjects (healthy control: 126; schizophrenia: 84; schizoaffective disorder: 104; bipolar disorder with psychosis: 32). Amygdala was chosen as a region of interest (ROI) given its role in emotion processing, as well as reported changes in this region in the schizophrenia population in previous research. Age, gender, motion, and scanner sites were included as predictors of no interests. Results: Compared to healthy controls, there was a significantly (p-FWE<0.01) decreased functional connectivity to the right amygdala in the right insula and right planum polare in the patient group. Additionally, there was a significantly (p-FWE<0.01) decreased functional connectivity to the left amygdala in the left and right insula, right planum polare, and right supramarginal gyrus in patients compared to controls. However, amygdala functional connectivity was not significantly correlated with the overall facial emotion recognition accuracy in the DARE task.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Atypical Development of Working Memory of Biological Motion in Autism Spectrum Disorder and Its Relation to Core Autistic Symptoms
Linlin Gong
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Linlin Gong, School of Psychological and Cognitive Sciences, Peking University, Beijing, China; Yiyang Cai, School of Psychological and Cognitive Sciences, Peking University, Beijing, China; Dong Guo, Department of Psychology and Behavioral Sciences, Zhejiang University, Xixi Campus, Hang Zhou, China; Yajie Liu, School of Psychological and Cognitive Sciences, Peking University, Beijing, China;Shaolin Zeng, Zaifeng Gao, Department of Psychology and Behavioral Sciences, Zhejiang University, Xixi Campus, Hang Zhou, China;Kunlin Wei, School of Psychological and Cognitive Sciences, Peking University, Beijing, China

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder whose core symptoms include impaired social interaction and interpersonal communication. Elucidating their developmental trajectory of social information processing is important for advancing theories of etiology and intervention of ASD. While previous research has charted the development of joint attention and theory of mind, the development of perception of biological motion (BM) among children with ASD is still understudied. By viewing point-light displays of human movements, typically-developed (TD) people is capable of inferring others’ identity, gender or emotion with ease. Our recent study has found that working memory of BM (WM-BM) develops rapidly around age 4 and 5 among TD children. Here we examine whether children with ASD has similar critical development of BM. We tested WM-BM as well as that of inverted biological motion (WM-IBM) among children with and without ASD aged between 4 and 6 yrs. For TD children, both WM-BM and WM-IBM capacity increased steadily between age 4 and 6. Children with ASD had similar performance as TD children at age 4 and 5 but lagged behind at age 6. For them, only WM-IBM but not WM-BM capacity increased with age, highlighting a specific slow-down in development of social information processing. Importantly, we found that the WM-BM capacity correlated with the severity of core symptoms of autism among children with ASD, suggesting that our working memory test based on BM is a good indicator of social development in this population. Since the preference for BM stimuli is reduced among high-risk autism infants as early as 8-month old, our results suggest that early deviation in preference and perception of social stimuli would lead to impaired high-level cognition (i.e., WM here) of related stimuli years later, a developmental path that might be shared by various social-cognitive abilities among individuals with ASD.
Traditional talk
Watch now
The Parameter Mapping Relationship between LIF Model and Artificial Neuron Model
Lu Sijia
 
Abstract
 
Brain science and cognitive neuroscience have always been considered one of the important sources of inspiration to machine learning algorithms. Although the performance of artificial neural networks (ANNs) can reach the human level on many specific tasks, the strong dependence on labeled data and uninterpretability have been hindering its development. In this regard, many methods were proposed, including the spiking neural networks(SNNs), which are considered to be the third generation of neural network.

As a brain-inspired network, SNNs has the information transmission mechanism, the processing mechanism closer to the brain, and the lower energy consumption. In recent years, in addition to Hebbian learning mechanism, a supervised learning algorithm using backward propagation has also been proved. However, it does not exceed the effect of ANNs in practical application, especially in the field of target detection and target recognition. Our main objectives are as follows: 1. Establish a connection mechanism between ANNs and SNNs, analyze the differences between the two networks, and narrow the gap between the two networks in practical applications; 2. Extend the local unsupervised learning mechanism to the multi-layer network learning mechanism, and establish a deep network structure; 3. Solve the problem of 'vanishing forward-spike propagation' in deep spiking neural networks. we believe that analyzing the relationship between Leaky Integrate-and-fire (LIF) and artificical neuron model (AN), the basic units of SNNs and ANNs, is the key to solve problems. A parameter mapping is given between LIF and AN, which is verified both theoretically and by simulation analyses for various cases, from a single neuron to a three-layer neural network.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Novel Function of Brain Tissue-Specific MicroRNA-124 in Regulating Mesodermal Cell Fate
Kalin Konrad
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Santiago Suarez, University of Delaware; Jia L. Song, University of Delaware

MicroRNA-124 (miR-124) has a highly conserved role in regulating the intricate balance between proliferation and differentiation during neurogenesis. The objective of this proposal is to investigate the novel role this neuron-specific microRNA (miR-124) in regulating mesodermal cell specification as well as its conserved function during neurogenesis. Our lab uses the sea urchin as a model due to its high fecundity, well-documented gene regulatory networks (GRN), and the fact that it contains a single miR-124, making it a simplified model to incorporate miR-124’s function into the GRN. MiR-124 has been observed in an array of species to directly suppress Notch to promote the neuronal linage. In sea urchin, Notch signaling is important for neurogenesis later in development while its earlier function is to modulate the specification of the mesoderm. We bioinformatically identified one or more potential miR-124 binding sites of Notch, Nodal, Ese (blastocoelar specific transcription factor), and Gcm (pigment cell specific transcription factor). The sea urchin Delta/Notch signaling pathway initiates specification of mesodermally-derived blastocoelar and pigment cells and later Nodal signaling ensures proper segregation of these cells to perform immune functions. We have determined that miR-124 directly suppresses Nodal, Notch, and blastcoelar specific transcription factor Ese to mediate proper specification and development of these immune cells. More recently we aim to reveal the molecular mechanism by which miR-124 impacts neurogenesis. We have observed that when we inhibit miR-124 that there is a significant decrease in mature neurons as well as an overall decrease in levels of serotonin expressing neurons. This decrease in specified neurons in miR-124 knockdown embryos as also resulted in slower-moving larval behavior. Due to our results and literature I predict that miR-124 directly inhibits Notch to mediate neurogenesis. I propose to test this by using a modified oligo designed to flank the binding site of miR-124 identified within Notch. By removing miR-124 suppression of Notch I will be able to determine if this proposed mechanism explains the overall decreased specified neurons in my miR-124 knockdown embryos. Our results have revealed a vital role of miR-124 in mesodermal cell specification, in addition to testing its conserved function in promoting neural differentiation in sea urchin.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Long non-coding RNA – Transcription factor regulatory networks in mammalian neural stem cells
Elpinickie Ninou
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Artemis Michail, Panagiotis Politis

With the advent of new generation technologies, a growing list of formerly unknown regulatory RNA species have come into spotlight. Among them, long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) have been found to control stem cell pluripotency, carcinogenesis, development and function of several tissues and organs. Although thousands of lncRNAs are expressed in adult mammalian brain in a highly patterned and specific manner, they remain poorly characterized and their roles in brain development have not yet been studied.
To tackle this question, we initially performed RNA-Seq analysis in the developing nervous system of mouse embryo. Based on this analysis, we identified many lncRNAs highly expressed in neural cells. We focused on lncRNAs, which are transcribed from genomic loci in close proximity with protein coding genes, encoding for critical transcription factors (TFs) in brain development. We hypothesized that these lncRNAs may be implicated in the regulation of neighboring TF genes.
To this end, we characterized the changes in the expression profiles of a number of lncRNAs-TF pairs during development of mouse brain. In this study, we further focused on the functional role of lncRNA TCONS_00034309 in the differentiation of neural stem cells and its relation to Tbr2 transcription factor by in vitro and in vivo overexpression and knock-down studies, using CRISPR-dCas9-KRAB Effector System.
To conclude, our data suggest critical roles for this lncRNA in neuronal differentiation and astrogliogenesis during brain development. Our study provides insights into the involvement of lncRNAs in organogenesis and shows how lncRNAs and protein-coding genes form regulatory networks with important functions in neural stem cells.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Embryonic Neuronal Activity in the Circuit Assembly of the Mouse Piriform Cortex
David Wang
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
David C. Wang, Stanford University Department of Biology; Jun Ding, Stanford School of Medicine Neurosurgery and Neurology; Liqun Luo, Stanford University Department of Biology

Throughout development, neuronal activity plays a vital role in the assembly of neuronal circuits. While this has been explored in many afferent sensory circuits, the role of activity in shaping recurrent intracortical networks remains largely unexplored. The mouse piriform cortex is an interesting region to study this as it contains highly recurrently connected neuronal assemblies which respond to different olfactory stimuli. While the time and mechanism of the development of these assemblies is unclear, there is much evidence suggesting neonatal mice have olfactory learning capability at birth and require olfaction to survive. Given the potential ethological importance of these assemblies in early development, the perinatal maturation of these assemblies may elucidate principles of activity-dependent formation of recurrent intracortical circuits.

Using genetic techniques to label active neurons in the developing mouse brain, I found that the piriform cortex is one of the only cerebral cortical regions that is robustly active in late embryogenesis. I propose this embryonic neuronal activity may shape piriform assembly maturation in utero, which may in turn facilitate neonatal olfactory learning and behavior. One possible mechanism is that synchronized in utero activity of piriform neurons may strengthen assembly connectivity through Hebbian plasticity, and well-connected assemblies may promote robust pattern completion to facilitate neonatal olfactory learning. To explore this, I am probing the role of these embryonically labeled piriform neurons with immediate-early gene labeling and neonatal behavior, and the physiological connectivity of assemblies with optogenetics and whole-cell recordings in acute neonatal brain slices.
Keynote Event
Watch now
Dissecting neuronal diversity of the cerebral cortex in development and disease
Simona Lodato
Traditional talk
Watch now
A Biophysically Inspired Learning Algorithm for Deep Neural Networks
Arash Ash
 
Abstract
 
Backpropagation (BP) of global error has been the only way to learn artificial deep neural networks efficiently. However, BP in the traditional form is not biologically plausible since the feedback path requires symmetric weights of feedforward. Inspired by the Hebbian plasticity idea of learning synaptic weights from neuronal activities, we propose a novel learning algorithm called Feedback Propagation (FP) that uses a feedback network learned by the changes in the local activations.
