We show that this results in a local negative feedback loop that produces credit assignments in the global gradient direction. We trained deep, fully connected, and convolutional models on MNIST and CIFAR image recognition datasets with BP and FP algorithms and compared the performances and the learned representations. The results show that FP achieves similar generalization error as BP on fully connected models. However, the convolutional models did not learn as well using the FP algorithm.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The effects of cognitive and mechanical restrictions on modular neuromuscular control in younger and older adults during beam walking
Andréia Costa
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Andrew Sawers, Department of Kinesiology, College of Applied Health Sciences, The University of Illinois at Chicago, USA; Tibor Hortobágyi, Center for Human Movement Sciences, University Medical Center Groningen, The Netherlands; Renato Moraes, School of Physical Education and Sport of Ribeirão Preto, University of São Paulo, Brazil

The manipulation of cognitive and mechanical restrictions affects performance and spatiotemporal parameters of gait. However, it is unclear if such restrictions also influence neuromuscular control of gait or whether age mediates their effect. Hence, we examined the effects of cognitive task and changes in arms position during beam walking in younger and older adults. Younger (YA, 23.8±3.2y, n=17) and older adults (OA, 69±3.9y, n=14) walked along a 6-cm wide beam (2-cm high, 4-m long), with free and chest folded arms, with and without a cognitive task (serial subtraction by 3). We used non-negative matrix factorization to extract muscle synergies from surface EMG recordings of 13 leg and trunk muscles. Differences in modular control complexity were assessed by comparing the number of muscle synergies (nsyn) and the variability accounted for by a single muscle synergy (VAF-1). The number of significantly active muscles per synergy (Wmus) and the sum of significantly active muscles per synergy (Wsum) were also compared to assess muscle coactivity and modular control efficiency. Addition of the cognitive task increased Wmus (without: 3.9±1.2, with: 4.4±1.3, p=0.047), only in YA, indicating increased coactivity in the presence of the subtractions in this group. On the other hand, restricting arm motion increased VAF-1 (folded: 74.5±3.7%, free: 73.2±4.2%, p=0.018), just in OA, suggesting less complexity of modular control with arms folded within older adults. Age was responsible for differences in nsyn (YA:7.0±1.3, OA:6.1±1.2, p=0.038), VAF-1 (YA:68.9±5.6%, OA:73.9±4.0%, p=0.004) and Wsum (YA: 2.1±0.5, OA: 2.5±0.7, p=0.034), implying less complexity and efficiency in modular control in OA. In conclusion, cognitive and mechanical restrictions affected neuromuscular control differently based on age, changing coactivity and complexity in YA and OA respectively. Older adults still exhibited a modular control strategy that was less complex and efficient than younger adults. FUNDING: FAPESP/Brazil (Grants 2018/18081-0 and 2019/00387-9).
 Interactive talk
Watch now
The impact of short-term motor imagery training on the brain
Wang Youhao
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Youhao Wang

Background: in recent years, the combined application of motor imagery and brain computer interface (BCI) technology has attracted extensive attention and obtained good research results in the field of neural rehabilitation. However, this BCI-based motor imagery therapy with real-time neural feedback has not been deeply explored. This paper will analyze the brain changes before and after the motor imagery training mission in a short time from the two perspectives of brain ERD attenuation and ERP connectivity.
Method: The subjects were trained with or without visual feedback. Firstly, we analyze the changes of EEG signal attenuation during motor imagery based on brain ERD phenomenon in a short period of time. Then we introduce the connectivity index of brain network based on graph theory, and discuss the influence of motor imagery training with or without neural feedback on the brain in three scales (single node scale, regional scale and whole brain scale).
Results: we found that the attenuation of EEG signal increased before and after motor imagery training whether or not nerve feedback was introduced. In the analysis of brain network, we found that the group with neural feedback has more obvious connectivity attenuation than the group without feedback.
Conclusion: we discussed the influence of BCI motor imagery with or without nerve feedback on brain from two aspects of ERD attenuation degree and ERP connectivity change. The results showed that the changes of indexes in the group with nerve feedback were more obvious and had more uniform trend attributes. This provides a good reference for the follow-up research.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The response to background motion: characteristics of a hand stabilization mechanism
Emily Crowe
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Emily M. Crowe, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam; Jeroen B. J. Smeets, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam; Eli Brenner, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam

When making goal-directed movements towards a target, our hand deviates from its path in the direction of sudden background motion. We introduce the Hand Stabilization Hypothesis to explain this ‘manual following response’. This hypothesis suggests that any abrupt background motion near the desired endpoint of one’s action is attributed to that point having moved relative to oneself. This leads to the hand following any motion within that relevant region to stabilize the ongoing movement. In six experiments, we accumulate evidence in support of this hypothesis. Participants were asked to intercept a moving target when it reached a certain area and, at a fixed moment during the hand’s interceptive action, background structures started to move either leftward or rightward. We determined the response of the hand by subtracting its velocity when the background moved leftward from its velocity when the background moved rightward. The participants’ hand responded to background motion even if the majority of background structures remained static or if background structures were only briefly visible. Thus, the response cannot be driven by judgments of self-motion based on the instantaneous optic flow within the relevant part of the background. The response was most sensitive to motion close to where the target was to be hit, both in the visual field and in depth. Even motion of only three small dots in that area was sufficient to elicit a response. Together these experiments characterise the fast and simple hand stabilization mechanism that is likely to be relevant for the control of an ongoing hand movement in a dynamic environment.
Traditional talk
Watch now
A Theoretical Framework for Target Propagation
Alexander Meulemans
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Francesco S. Carzaniga; Johan A.K. Suykens; João Sacramento; Benjamin F. Grewe

The success of deep learning, a brain-inspired form of AI, has sparked interest in understanding how the brain could similarly learn across multiple layers of neurons. However, the majority of biologically-plausible learning algorithms have not yet reached the performance of backpropagation (BP), nor are they built on strong theoretical foundations. Here, we analyze target propagation (TP), a popular but not yet fully understood alternative to BP, from the standpoint of mathematical optimization. Our theory shows that TP is closely related to Gauss-Newton optimization and thus substantially differs from BP. Furthermore, our analysis reveals a fundamental limitation of difference target propagation (DTP), a well-known variant of TP, in the realistic scenario of non-invertible neural networks. We provide a first solution to this problem through a novel reconstruction loss that improves feedback weight training, while simultaneously introducing architectural flexibility by allowing for direct feedback connections from the output to each hidden layer. Our theory is corroborated by experimental results that show significant improvements in performance and in the alignment of forward weight updates with loss gradients, compared to DTP.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Task-specificity and neural adaptations after balance learning in healthy young adults
Lisanne Bakker
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
T. Nandi, Nuffield Department of Clinical Neurosciences, University of Oxford, United Kingdom; C.J.C. Lamoth, University of Groningen, University Medical Center Groningen, the Netherlands; T. Hortobágyi, University of Groningen, University Medical Center Groningen, the Netherlands

Introduction: Only 30 minutes of balance skill training lead to significant improvements in behavioral and neuromuscular outcome measures. However, it is unclear if such a rapidly acquired skill is also retained and transferred to other untrained balance tasks. Therefore, the purpose of this study was to examine the effects of a single balance training on balance skill acquisition, retention, and transferability and to examine the underlying neural plasticity by intermuscular coherence and transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS).
Methods: Healthy young adults (n=36, age 20.9, 18M) were randomly assigned to learn balancing on a wobble board (BAL), cycle while seated (CYC) or sit and rest (CON) for 20 minutes. Before, immediately and ~7 days after the exercise session, we assessed performance of the trained and several untrained balance tasks. Potential underlying neural mechanisms were examined by intermuscular coherence of lower extremity muscles and by TMS.
Results: BAL improved balance performance in the trained task by 338.9% (±257.2, effect size [d]=1.94), while CT (21.5% ±70.3, d=0.07) and NC (25.8% ± 85.3, d=0.05) did not. BAL retained the acquired skill after a 1-week-long off-line, no-training period (256.0% ±165.5). No changes occurred in 12 measures of untrained balance outcomes, 8 measures of intermuscular coherence, and in 4 TMS measures of supra-spinal plasticity (all p>0.05).
Conclusions: A single unstable balance-board training session but not cycling or rest improved the trained balance skill by margins observed in long term studies without transfer to other balancing skills or changes in neural plasticity. Future studies will examine in more detail and by additional methods the neuromechanical mechanisms and the time course underlying the remarkable level of specificity of learning a balance skill.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Task classification from pre-stimulus functional connectivity on EEG-data
Timofey Adamovich
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Timofey Adamovich, Psychological Institute of Russian Academy of Education; Ilia Zaharov, Psychological Institute of Russian Academy of Education; Anna Tabueva, Psychological Institute of Russian Academy of Education

Execution of cognitive tasks is associated with a task-specific pattern of the brain functional connectivity. However, much less attention is been drawn to pre-stimulus preparatory processes. Previously, the brain preparation topology was shown on fMRI-data, we aimed to replicate this result and distinguish pre-stimulus reconfiguration of brain functional network on EEG-data. During EEG recording 76 participants were asked to identify the correctness of stimuli, belonging to one of three types: sentence in the native language, algebraic equations and simple addition. 2 seconds before each stimulus, the cue was shown. Functional connectivity in this interval was estimated in sensor space via the imaginary part of coherency and graph was constructed from the 25% of strongest connections. Multiclass sparse logistic regression was used as the classifier on 5 global (median path length, assortativity degree, average clustering coefficient, global and local efficiency) and 5 local measures (degree, rich-club coefficient, clustering coefficient, betweenness centrality k-core index) and with Leave-one-out as the train-test split. We were not able to correctly classified pre-stimulus functional connectivity with accuracy ranging from 31% to 38% for the different frequency bands. This result might reflect several drawbacks in our analysis. First, the topological resolution of 64-channel EEG might be inadequate for the extraction of differences between stimuli. Second, issues with the graph construction, poor choice of synchronization measure or threshold of the strongest connections. Third, target differences could hide in the temporal dynamics of network reconfiguration, which is completely obscured by averaging across the whole pre-stimulus time window. We also want to point out that similar classification applied to participants shows accuracy from 61% to 90%, thus emphasizing the importance of individual differences in functional connectivity studies.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
On the necessity of recurrent processing during object recognition: it depends on the need for scene segmentation
Noor Seijdel
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jessica Loke, University of Amsterdam; Ron van de Klundert; Matthew van der Meer; Eva Quispel; Simon van Gaal, University of Amsterdam; Edward H.F. de Haan, University of Amsterdam; H. Steven Scholte, University of Amsterdam;

While feed-forward activity may suffice for recognizing objects in sparse scenes, additional visual operations that aid object recognition might be needed for more complex scenes. One such additional operation is figure-ground segmentation; extracting the relevant features and locations of the target object while ignoring irrelevant features. In this study of 60 participants, we show objects on backgrounds of increasing complexity to investigate whether recurrent computations are increasingly important for segmenting objects from more complex backgrounds. Three lines of evidence show that recurrent processing is critical for recognition of objects embedded in complex scenes. First, behavioral results indicated a greater reduction in performance after masking objects presented on more complex backgrounds; with the degree of impairment increasing with increasing background complexity. Second, electroencephalography (EEG) measurements showed clear differences in the evoked response potentials (ERPs) between conditions around 200ms - a time point beyond feed-forward activity and object decoding based on the EEG signal indicated later decoding onsets for objects embedded in more complex backgrounds. Third, Deep Convolutional Neural Network performance confirmed this interpretation; feed-forward and less deep networks showed a higher degree of impairment in recognition for objects in complex backgrounds compared to recurrent and deeper networks. Together, these results support the notion that recurrent computations drive figure-ground segmentation of objects in complex scenes.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Surrogate gradients as a link between connectivity and computational function in spiking neural networks
Friedemann Zenke
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Friedemann Zenke, Friedrich Miescher Institute

The brain relies on intricately connected spiking neural networks to solve complex information processing tasks. To understand the principles of this processing, models are indispensable. However, modeling spiking neural networks that mimic a similar computational complexity in-silico has remained challenging due to a lack of theoretical understanding of how neuronal connectivity translates into network-level function. In deep learning, gradient-based algorithms established this link by optimizing objective functions. However, gradient-based methods usually fail in spiking neural networks due to the non-differential nature of spiking neuron models, which precludes gradient computation.
Surrogate gradient learning has emerged as a versatile solution to this problem, allowing us to build functional multi-layer and recurrent spiking neural networks capable of solving diverse computational tasks. Here, I will first motivate and introduce surrogate gradient learning and illustrate how biologically plausible voltage-based three-factor learning rules emerge naturally within this framework. Second, I will showcase the flexibility and remarkable robustness of surrogate gradients on several spike-based information processing problems. Finally, I will show how surrogate gradients allow training spiking neural networks implemented in dedicated neuromorphic hardware, thereby enabling unprecedented processing speed and power-efficiency.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The strategy of learning a new visuomotor skill and the underlying neural mechanisms are age-dependent
Margot Bootsma
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Simone R. Caljouw, University Medical Center Groningen; Menno P. Veldman, KU Leuven; Natasha M. Maurits, University Medical Center Groningen; John C. Rothwell, University College London; Tibor Hortobágyi, University Medical Center Groningen

Motor learning is accompanied by experience-dependent neural plasticity of motor-related areas in the brain. Oscillatory brain activity in the alpha and beta frequency bands has been identified as a possible neural marker of this process. Although an age-specific increase in desynchronization of alpha and beta power during movement is frequently reported, if and how old age affects functional reorganization after a period of motor practice is incompletely understood. Therefore, the aim of the current study was to determine the effects of age on task-related brain activation before and after motor skill acquisition and at 24-h retention of a mirror star tracing task. We used electroencephalography (EEG) to assess task-related power (TR-Power) in the alpha (8-12 Hz) and beta (12-30 Hz) frequency bands before, immediately after and 24-h after motor practice of a mirror star tracing task in younger (N=36, age=21.1±1.3yr) and older (N=36, age=70.4±4.1yr) adults. While both speed and accuracy of the motor task improved directly after practice in both age groups, younger adults only consolidated improvements in speed, whereas older adults only consolidated improvements in accuracy. In younger adults, task-related power was observed in the hemisphere contralateral to the practicing right hand, while older adults showed a more bilateral activation pattern. There was an increase in task-related alpha and beta desynchronization immediately, but not 24h after practice, indicative of early neural plasticity. Interestingly, this change in desynchronization after practice was larger for older compared to younger adults. Together, these results indicate that both the strategy for learning a mirror star tracing task as well as the underlying neural mechanisms are age-dependent.
Interactive talk
Watch now
A Gaussian Noise Neural Channel Modulated the Functional Connectivity
Qiang Li
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Qiang Li, University of Valencia;

Information transfer among brain regions is the fundamental intelligence computing in the primate brain. The local and global topology connectivity among functional brain regions directly driven human cognitive behaviors. The real neural signal includes the real neural firing and neural self-noise. Neural self-noise non-regular firing or synchronization will cause severe neuron disease and it also plays a very important role in the functional connectivity. Therefore, how the neural self-noise affect the information flow among brain regions? Firstly, Phase Locking Value(PLV) can investigate task-induced neural synchronization from the EEG signal [1]. Secondly, Shannon’s information theory and its extensions framework can be used to quantitative the maximum information capacity in the noise neural channel. The basic idea is 1) simulation: the fake neural signal (EEG) produced by setting certain time points, number of subjects, and number trials with neural self-noise. The amplitude of neural signals can be changed according to given parameters. 2) Phase Locking Value (PLV) measured among brain regions with setting different parameters of time series. 3) redundancy measured among brain regions with Total Correlation (TC)/Multivariate Mutual Information. [2] 4) Compared different measure results and check how the neural self-noise affects the information flow in the brain. The result shown 1) neural-self noise directly affect functional connectivity among brain regions (increase neuron self-noise will reduce PLV and TC) 2) TC has stronger statistical power than PLV in the quantitative functional connectivity

Appendix:
The Matlab demo used in this short research can get from here: https://github.com/sinodanish/NeuroMatch3.0

References:
[1] Lachaux, Jean‐Philippe, et al. “Measuring phase synchrony in brain signals.” Human brain mapping 8.4 (1999): 194-208.
[2] Watanabe, S. Information theoretical analysis of multivariate correlation.IBM Journal of research anddevelopment1960,4, 66–82.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Electrophysiology of Affordances
Karthik Mahesh Varadarajan
 
Abstract
 
Affordances, in scientific literature have largely been treated either as psychophysical action schema or as visual percept abstractions. The neurobiology of affordances is not well-understood. In this paper, we attempt to explain the neurobiology of affordances through a simplified observational model, defined in terms of electrophysiology. In particular, we analyze affordances using cerebral electrophysiology measurements, namely electroencephalography (EEG) and arm muscular electrophysiology measurements, namely electromyography (EMG). Fourier and Wavelet based analysis of EEG measurements from 5 participants during 12 affordance executions across three modes - observational, simulated and ego-execution demonstrate two key effects. Firstly, these sensorimotor EEG affordance codes are distinct and uniquely discriminant across the affordance categories. Secondly, the affordance codes show a high-degree of similarity across the three execution modes, indicating the role of mirror neuronal behavior in affordance processing in the brain. On the other hand, EMG measurements across 33 different grasp affordance executions (as defined by KTH grasp taxonomy), show a high degree of overlap, especially across precision pinch grasp types. This indicates that EMG based motor codes may be insufficient in modeling sensorimotor affordance codes and the wider diversity of EEG codes is likely to be necessary in successful characterization.
Traditional talk
Watch now
A GRAB sensor for spatially resolved endocannabinoid dynamics in vitro and in vivo
Ao Dong
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ao Dong, Peking University; Kaikai He, Peking University; Barna Dudok, Stanford University; Jordan S Farrell, Stanford University; Wuqiang Guan, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory; Daniel J Liput, National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism; Henry L Puhl, National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism; Ruyi Cai, Peking University; Jiali Duan, Peking University; David M Lovinger, National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism; Bo Li, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory; Ivan Soltesz, Stanford University; Yulong Li, Peking University

Endocannabinoids (eCBs) are retrograde lipid neuromodulators involved in many physiologically important processes, yet their release and dynamics in the brain remains largely unknown, in part due to lack of probes capable of reporting eCBs with sufficient spatiotemporal resolution. Here, we developed a new G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) Activation Based eCB sensor GRABeCB2.0 using the human CB1 receptor fused with a circular permutated EGFP (cpEGFP). GRABeCB2.0 exhibits ~second kinetics and robust fluorescence increase in response to eCBs (ΔF/F0 ~800% to 2-AG; ~550% to AEA in neurons), and does not elicit detectable G protein and arrestin coupling. Using GRABeCB2.0, we detected evoked eCB dynamics in both cultured neurons and acute mouse brain slices. Interestingly, we also observed spontaneous compartmental eCB transients that spread ~11 μm in culture neurons, suggesting constraint local eCB signaling. By expressing GRABeCB2.0 in vivo, we readily observed foot-shock elicited and running triggered eCB transients in mouse amygdala and hippocampus respectively. Lastly, using GRABeCB2.0 in a seizure model, we observed a spreading eCB wave following a calcium wave in mouse hippocampus. In summary, GRABeCB2.0 is a powerful new probe to resolve eCB release and dynamics under physiological and pathological conditions.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Body silhouettes as features in visual search: evidence from spatially-global attention modulation in visual cortex
Sushrut Thorat
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Marius V. Peelen, Donders Institute for Brain, Cognition and Behaviour, Radboud University, Nijmegen, The Netherlands.

Visual search for objects in cluttered scenes is guided by top-down attention, allowing observers to efficiently select goal-relevant information from incoming visual input. When search is for low-level features, such as orientation, color, or motion direction, this attentional selection modulates visual processing across the visual field, even at spatially-unattended and task-irrelevant locations. Recent behavioral and neuroimaging studies have provided evidence that similar spatially-global selection mechanisms may exist for highly-familiar object categories such as faces. Similar to low-level features, faces are selectively represented in the visual system. In the present fMRI study, we reveal spatially-global modulation for another selectively-represented object category: human bodies. Participants were cued to search for one of six object categories in two vertically-aligned images. Crucially, two additional, horizontally-aligned, images were simultaneously presented but were never task-relevant across three experimental sessions. Analyses locked to the objects presented in these task-irrelevant images revealed that responses evoked by body silhouettes were strongly modulated by the participants’ top-down attentional set, becoming more body-selective when participants searched for bodies in the task-relevant images. These effects were observed both in univariate analyses of body-selective cortex and in multivariate analyses of high-level visual cortex. Finally, we found that this modulation reflected response gain rather than a generic bias induced by the cues. These findings provide evidence for a spatially-global selection mechanism for human bodies, linking this modulation to body-selective representations in high-level visual cortex.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Combining hierarchical latent-mixture and evidence accumulation-based models of cognition with fMRI data
Percy Mistry
 
Abstract
 
We show how the functional resolution of mapping neural circuit features to distinct cognitive and behavioral components of decision-making process can be improved, by combining hierarchical latent-mixture and evidence-accumulation based models with neural (fMRI) data. These models are implemented within a Bayesian inference framework. Theory based and structural assumptions are used to develop evidence accumulation models whose parameters are hierarchically governed by cognitive subsystems, such as performance monitoring, belief updating, error-feedback, and executive control. Such models explicitly account for the temporal dynamics and learning associated with repeated decision making. They dissociate between different potential cognitive processes and strategies that may be used on a trial-by-trial basis, and account for the hierarchical process of strategy switching. The hierarchical cognitive processes and subsystems are characterized by cognitive parameters that potentially capture and mediate the relationship between neural (fMRI) and behavioral data. Such neuro-cognitive modeling allows us to differentiate between theories, provide insights into the developmental maturation of brain networks, and improve the identification of differential brain feature characteristics associated with different cognitive processes in clinical and neuro-diverse populations. Applications include identifying the joint neural and behavioral basis of individual differences in mathematical decision making, response inhibition, and perceptual decision making tasks.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
The role of habitual behaviour in the corticostriatal pathway in a mouse model of Parkinson disease.
Josefa Zaldivar
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Zaldivar-Diez, J, (1) Centro Integral de Neurociencias A.C. (CINAC); Hernandez, LF, (1); Obeso, JA (1); Roeper, J (2) Institute of Neurophysiology, Goethe University Frankfurt

The cardinal motor features of Parkinson disease (PD) typically, but often ignored, have a focal onset (Vidaihet, M. et al; 1994). However, the prevailing current Braak hypothesis about the beginning of PD fails to explain this important, focal and somatotopic pattern. Increased corticostriatal activity onto the caudal putamen leads to the perfect scenario for increased levels of α-synuclein to become toxic upon axonal dopaminergic endings (Foffani, G and Obeso, JA; 2018). It is noteworthy that corticostriatal stress in humans might be facilitated/mediated by continuous engagement in automatic/habitual motor performance giving rise to damage of dopaminergic axons in the motor striatum (Hernández, LF. et al; 2015; 2019).

The goal of this project is to unveil the pathological role that habitual behaviour could have in the corticostriatal circuit in a mouse model of PD. To achieve this goal C57BL/6N mice will be used to anatomically define the cortico-striatal circuit of the paw. Then, α-synuclein pre-formed fibrils will be stereotactically injected in this area of the cortex to determine its uptake by dopaminergic striatal terminals. Finally, the role of cortical stress performed by enhanced automatic/habitual behaviour will be studied in these α-synuclein injected mice analysing the electrophysiological activity at the striatal level while animals perform a high demanding automatic/habitual task (FR4 lever press task).

We will describe the results obtained in the anatomical characterization of the corticostriatal circuit of the paw region in C57BL/6N mice.
Traditional talk
Watch now
A family of sensitive and specific genetically-encoded GRAB sensors for spy on neuropeptides dynamics
Huan Wang
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tongrui Qian, Peking University; Ling Wu, Peking University; Zimo ZhangRen, Peking University; Yulong Li, Peking University

Neuropeptides are key signaling molecules in endocrine and nervous system, regulating virtually all physiological processes, ranging from food ingestion, sleep & circadian rhythm, to pain sensation and social behaviors. To understand their important functions in vivo, it is critical to be able to monitor neuropeptide dynamics with selectivity, sensitivity and good spatiotemporal resolution. One major hindrance to the above goal is the lack of direct, sensitive and non-invasive probes to report these bioactive peptides in vivo. Here, by tapping into GPCRs for human neuropeptides, we developed a toolbox of GRAB (GPCR activation based) sensors for neuropeptide Y (NPY), vasopressin/oxytocin, somatostatin (SST), corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), neurotensin (NT), cholecystokinin (CCK), vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), substance P and for Drosophila neuropeptides allatostatin A (AstA) and allatostatin C (AstC). These fluorescent sensors utilize native GPCR ligand binding pockets as neuropeptide sensing modules and circular-permutated GFPs as optical reporters. We have developed sensors with ultra-good selectivity for neuropeptides, with nano molecular affinity, up-to 1500% dF/F fluorescence increase upon cognate ligand application. In addition, these GRAB sensors have minimal downstream G protein coupling, or arrestin coupling, compared to their original GPCR scaffolds. We are validating these peptide sensors in slice & in vivo and extend the sensor development strategy to cover more neuropeptides in human body. The further development of these sensors and their deployment will likely significantly enhance our understanding of neuropeptide function and regulation in physiological and pathophysiological conditions.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Recognition memory for highly similar visual stimuli: when novelty is not new
Richárd Reichardt
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Bertalan Polner; Péter Simor

Novelty in cognitive neuroscience is often taken for granted: anything that the researcher describes as novel should elicit similar neurocognitive responses in the participants. For example, novel stimuli are expected to elicit neural activation in the hippocampus and are also expected to be recognized with a higher probability in a memory test. The experimental results however reveal a more complex picture. It seems that not all novel stimuli are processed in the same manner by the human brain, instead the difference of a stimulus from already seen stimuli determines the neurocognitive responses ascribed to novelty. It follows from this idea, that the more different a stimulus is from a given set of stimuli, the more likely it is to be recognized later. We aimed to test this hypothesis with a unique task, in which the participants are first familiarized with patterned visual stimuli. Next, they have to distinguish these familiar items from similar novel stimuli, and finally their memory is tested for the familiar and novel stimuli alike. The stimuli are algorithmically generated, and the degree of difference across the stimuli is controlled and quantified. Our results show that the more different a stimulus is from the familiars the more likely it is that a participant correctly recognized it, while highly similar stimuli were often confused with the familiars. This result supports the idea that novelty as a category is not necessarily meaningful in cognitive psychological experiments, instead the difference from other stimuli, or unexpectedness should be assessed. This is in line with the basic idea of predictive coding that unexpected information should be prioritized in neurocognitive processing. Our results thus support the idea that predictive coding is universally utilized in the brain, as memory systems also seem to employ this information processing strategy.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Computation noise promotes cognitive resilience to adverse conditions in humans and recurrent networks
Valentin Wyart
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Charles Findling, École Normale Supérieure

Random noise in information processing systems is widely seen as detrimental to function. But despite the large trial-to-trial variability of neural activity, humans show a remarkable adaptability to unexpected adverse events during goal-directed behavior. The origin of this cognitive ability, described as constitutive of general intelligence, is still disputed. In this talk, I will show that implementing computation noise in recurrent neural networks boosts their cognitive resilience to a variety of adverse events entirely unseen during training, in a way that strikingly resembles human cognition in similar conditions. In contrast to neural networks featuring exact computations, noisy networks and humans acquire behavioral hallmarks of Bayesian inference in a ‘zero-shot’ fashion – without prior experience with conditions that require these computations for maximizing rewards. These findings suggest that human intelligence may ride on computation noise to promote near-optimal behavior in adverse conditions without any engineered cognitive sophistication.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Proposal to use neuromorphic architecture to emulate neurological disease progression or neurotoxicity
Thomas Ehmer
 
Abstract
 
This is combining topics A and E - and is supposed to be not a real scientific talk but rather an open discussion about the roadmap to achieve a novel instrument which is using multi-scale (bottom up / top down) inputs to emulate ("in mimicko") two things. 1) disease progression and effect of drug to slow the progression - and 2) long-term neurotoxicity side effects.
Topic1: the progression of neurological disease - over a very long range (computing 1h emulation - resulting in 10 years "real life progression) for a speedup of 100k (e.g. using Spinnaker)). What is needed is a collaboration from neuroanatomists, pharmaceutics, neuromorphic modelling, neurology medical expertise, behavior modelling as well as a deep understanding of the mechanism of action for both the disease as well as the potential treatment. E.g. monitoring the onset of blurry vision in MS - and delay of this onset by drugs.
Topic2: using the same mechanism to emulate potential long term neurotoxic effects which accumulate over time given "drug exposure". This is more speculative.
The challenge is mapping neuroanatomic details to the emulation - as well as precise mapping of the biochemistry - including blood-brain barrier.
Traditional talk
Watch now
A series of genetically encoded GRAB sensors for measuring serotonin dynamics in vivo
Jinxia Wan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jinxia Wan, State Key Laboratory of Membrane Biology, Peking University School of Life Sciences, Beijing 100871, China; Fei Deng, State Key Laboratory of Membrane Biology, Peking University School of Life Sciences, Beijing 100871, China; Hui Dong, State Key Laboratory of Membrane Biology, Peking University School of Life Sciences, Beijing 100871, China; Guochuan Li, State Key Laboratory of Membrane Biology, Peking University School of Life Sciences, Beijing 100871, China; Wanling Peng, Institute of Neuroscience, State Key Laboratory of Neuroscience, CAS Center for Excellence in Brain Science and Intelligence Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai 200031, China; Xuelin Li, State Key Laboratory of Membrane Biology, Peking University School of Life Sciences, Beijing 100871, China; Tongrui Qian, State Key Laboratory of Membrane Biology, Peking University School of Life Sciences, Beijing 100871, China; Kun Song, Institute of Neuroscience, State Key Laboratory of Neuroscience, CAS Center for Excellence in Brain Science and Intelligence Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai 200031, China; Jianzhi Zeng, Peking-Tsinghua Center for Life Sciences, Academy for Advanced Interdisciplinary Studies, Peking University, Beijing 100871, China; Miao Jing, Chinese Institute for Brain Research, Beijing 102206, China; Min Xu, Institute of Neuroscience, State Key Laboratory of Neuroscience, CAS Center for Excellence in Brain Science and Intelligence Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai 200031, China; Yulong Li, State Key Laboratory of Membrane Biology, Peking University School of Life Sciences, Beijing 100871, China;

Serotonin (also called 5-HT) is an important monoamine neuromodulator, critical for regulation of sleep, appetite control as well as learning and memory. Malfunction of 5-HT system also involved in depression, addiction, compulsivity and other neurological disorders. One major obstacle to understand the physiological regulation of 5-HT is lack of sensitive methods to decipher the dynamics of 5-HT non-invasively with good cell specificity and high spatiotemporal resolution, especially in vivo. Here, we developed a series of genetically-encoded 5-HT sensors by coupling cpEGFP or cpmApple with 5-HT receptors. Upon 5-HT binding, the chimeric receptor changes its conformation which leads to a subsequent fluorescent signal increase from the embedded cpEGFP or cpmApple , therefore reporting 5-HT. We named this kind of sensors “the GPCR Activation Based sensors for 5-HT, short for GRAB5-HT. With iterative engineering, we developed a series of GRAB5-HT sensors with high specificity and sensitivity. Furthermore, we demonstrated GRAB5-HT sensors could be applied in multiple organisms, including Drosophila, mice and monkey for reliable detection of 5-HT in vivo. Thus, this tool would enhance our understanding of complex neuromodulation both in health and in diseases.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Limits of perception and richness of behaviour: Dissociating implicit and explicit representations of visual ensembles
Sabrina Hansmann-Roth
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sabrina Hansmann-Roth, Icelandic Vision Lab, School of Health Sciences, University of Iceland, Reykjavík, Iceland; Árni Kristjánsson, Icelandic Vision Lab, School of Health Sciences, University of Iceland, Reykjavík, Iceland; David Whitney, Department of Psychology, The University of California, Berkeley, CA, USA; Andrey Chetverikov, Donders Institute for Brain, Cognition, and Behavior, Radboud University, Nijmegen, The Netherlands

All natural scenes contain elements, for example the leaves on a tree, that share visual features such as shape, texture, and colour. How are these ensembles represented in the visual system? During the last decade, studies have suggested that the visual system encodes summary statistics (e.g., mean and variance) of ensembles to save resources and bypass the bottlenecks of attention and working memory. Claims have even been made that representing visual information as summary statistics is what determines the richness and limitations of our conscious experience. In this study we show that such explicit reports severely underestimate the richness of visual representations. In a set of behavioural experiments our observers searched for an odd-one-out target among heterogeneous distractors and their memory of distractor characteristics was tested using explicit or implicit measures. Observers could explicitly distinguish distractor sets with different mean and variance, but not differently shaped probability distributions. In contrast, our implicit assessment revealed the encoding of mean, variance, and even distribution shape. Furthermore, explicit measures had common noise sources that distinguished them from implicit measures. This shows that the visual system does not reduce information about visual features to summary statistics, but instead that explicit decisions about summary statistics are limited, as if they were based on small samples from an otherwise fully encoded probabilistic representation of visual features. This discovery has implications for the understanding of how information is stored in the visual system and how it is accessed for decision making, suggesting that perception for action can be less limited than visual awareness. Our results provide new insights into the nature of representations of visual information and invite speculation about whether different types of information from encoded feature distributions are available to different visual streams in the brain that may serve different functions.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Pre-training RNNs on ecologically relevant tasks explains rats suboptimal behavior in a simple categorization task
Manuel Molano-Mazón
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Manuel Molano-Mazon, IDIBAPS, Barcelona, Spain; Daniel Duque-Doncos, IDIBAPS, Barcelona, Spain; Guangyu Robert Yang, Center for Theoretical Neuroscience, Columbia University, New York, USA; Jaime de la Rocha, IDIBAPS, Barcelona, Spain;

In order to make optimal decisions in real-world environments it is fundamental to take into account recent stimuli and the actions made in response to them, together with the outcomes of those actions. A recent study (Hermoso-Mendizabal et al.) has shown that rats are able to leverage the information contained in the trial history of a perceptual two-alternative forced choice (2AFC) task that includes serial correlations in the trial sequence. However, rats only used this trial history information after correct trials and failed to do so after error trials, when they temporarily followed a strategy only based on the current stimulus. Here we use RNNs to investigate whether this reset strategy reflects an adaptive mechanism or alternatively reveals fundamental limits in the capacity of simple neural circuits to perform counterfactual inference.
We trained Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) in the same 2AFC task used for rats and found that the networks, like the rats, learned to leverage the sequence partial predictability to increase their categorization accuracy after correct trials. However, RNNS also used this predictability after error trials departing from the reset strategy of the rats and resembling the behavior of an optimal agent that can perform counterfactual inference.
We hypothesize that the discrepancy between the rats and RNNs behavior is due to the fact that networks are fully optimizing their performance in the 2AFC task whereas the brain of rats has been shaped by evolution in order to optimize their performance in more ecological environments. As a consequence, although rats manage to perform well in the task, they are not able to fully adapt their behavior to it. We show that by pre-training the RNNs in the same task but using a number of choices larger than two, they exhibit the reset strategy displayed by the rats, which is close to an optimal behavior in a more complex environment with multiple options.
Our results suggest that seemingly sub-optimal behaviors in laboratory tasks (e.g. the reset strategy) can be a byproduct of the adaptation to more complex environments. Furthermore, our work demonstrates the usefulness of pre-training artificial neural networks in ecologically plausible environments before testing them on the task of interest.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Motor and cognitive real-life habits in Parkinson’s disease
Pasqualina Guida
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Mariana H.G. Monje, CINAC Hospital Universitario HM Puerta del Sur Móstoles Madrid, Spain; José Ángel Obeso, CINAC Hospital Universitario HM Puerta del Sur Móstoles Madrid, CIBERNED Madrid Spain; Ignacio Obeso, CINAC Hospital Universitario HM Puerta del Sur Móstoles Madrid, CIBERNED Madrid Spain

Humans can simultaneously and easily shift between automatic/habitual to voluntary/goal-directed modes of behavioural control. Habits (stimulus-response) allows us to perform well-practiced tasks with minimal or no conscious effort. In Parkinson disease (PD), there is a differential loss of dopamine (DA) along the caudal sensorimotor putamen initially transferring to more rostral regions as the disease progresses. The sensoriomotor putamen is primarily implicated in habitual control of behaviour therefore possibly explaining some motor deficits in PD such as arm swinging, walking and writing.
Our aim was to to investigate with a more ecological approach whether early dopaminergic cell loss in PD (a) alters real-life motor habits and (b) if as well cognitive real-life habits are impaired in PD compared to controls.
We measured habitual behaviour in 14 early PD patients and 14 HC during performance of a natural habitual motor (handwriting, one of the most well-learned and automatic tasks) and cognitive tasks (Go/noGo Associations Tasks GNAT on implicit prejudice). Tasks were developed to differentiate between habitual and goal directed components. In the writing task, we collected data from the most automatic (e.g. signature, Spanish) to more goal-directed conditions (e.g. Polish, Greek). In the GNAT, we used four kind of stimuli to create four possible Go conditions: two congruent and two incongruent associated to familiar and unfamiliar associations.
In the natural habitual motor task (handwriting), PD patients showed reduced automatism in the execution of habitual conditions (Spanish and signature writing) compared to controls. However, in the cognitive habitual task, results reveal similar habitual responses in both groups, showing faster responses for congruent conditions than incongruent ones.
Our results suggest larger differences in the motor domain in real-life habits whereas the cognitive one remains unaffected in early PD, indicative of specific deficient use of motor habits in PD.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Fully reproducible EEG analyses with EEGLAB and LIMO EEG
Cyril Pernet
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Cyril Pernet, University of Edinburgh, Ramon Martinez-Cancino, Dung Truong, Scott Makeig & Arnaud Delorme, University of California San Diego

Reproducibility is a cornerstone of scientific communication without which one cannot build upon each other's work. Because modern human brain imaging relies on many integrated steps with a variety of possible algorithms, it has however become impossible to report every detail of a data processing workflow. In response to this analytical complexity, community recommendations are to share data analysis pipelines (scripts that implement workflows). Here we show that this can easily be done using EEGLAB and tools built around it. BIDS tools allow importing all the necessary information and create a study from EEG-Brain Imaging Data Structure compliant data. From there preprocessing can be carried out in only a few steps using EEGLAB and statistical analyses performed using the LIMO EEG plug-in. Using Wakeman and Henson (Wakeman & Henson, 2015) face dataset, we illustrate how to prepare data and build different statistical models, a standard factorial design (faces * repetition) and a more modern trial based regression approach for the stimulus repetition effect, all in a few reproducible command lines.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Long-lasting effects of starvation experience on fly activity and place preference
Deepthi Mahishi
 
Abstract
 
Animal behavior and actions are demonstrably governed by sensory stimulation and internal states like hunger. Depending on starvation levels, priorities shift between diverse energy-expensive activities and foraging/feeding. Flies are known to execute efficient path integration strategies during foraging. However, the long-term activity pattern for both hungry and satiated flies in conditions of foraging remain to be better understood. Similarly, little is known about how chronic contact chemosensory stimulation affects locomotion. To address these questions, we have developed a novel, simplistic fly activity tracking setup – the Panopticon. Our assay allows recording of walking behavior, of several flies in parallel, each surrounded by a uniform substrate layer. Individual animals are placed for >24 h in agarose-coated sectors of a 3D-printed Petri dish inset. We employ Fiji-based video tracking, followed by a custom-built MATLAB analysis framework, which allows multifaceted assessment of fly activity patterns, including representation of walking trails and location probability as a function of time.
Interactive talk
Watch now
SpikeInterface, a unified framework for spike sorting
Matthias Hennig
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Alessio P Buccino, Department of Biosystems Science and Engineering, ETH Zurich, Switzerland; Cole L Hurwitz, School of Informatics, University of Edinburgh, United Kingdom; Jeremy Magland, Flatiron Institute, New York City, NY, United States; Samuel Garcia, Centre de Recherche en Neuroscience de Lyon, CNRS, Lyon, France; Joshua H Siegle, Allen Institute for Brain Science, Seattle, WA, United States; Roger Hurwitz, Independent Researcher, Portland, Oregon, USA; Matthias H Hennig, School of Informatics, University of Edinburgh, United Kingdom

Given the importance of understanding single-neuron activity, much development has been directed towards improving the performance and automation of spike sorting. These developments, however, introduce new challenges, such as file format incompatibility and reduced interoperability, that hinder benchmarking and preclude reproducible analysis. To address these limitations, we developed SpikeInterface, a Python framework designed to unify preexisting spike sorting technologies into a single codebase and to standardize extracellular data file operations. With a few lines of code and regardless of the underlying data format, researchers can: run, compare, and benchmark most modern spike sorting algorithms; pre-process, post-process, and visualize extracellular datasets; validate, curate, and export sorting outputs; and more. In this paper, we provide an overview of SpikeInterface and, with applications to both real and simulated extracellular datasets, demonstrate how it can improve the accessibility, reliability, and reproducibility of spike sorting in preparation for the widespread use of large-scale electrophysiology.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Machine Learning Framework for Fully Automatic Quality Control of Registrations in Big Data brain MRI
Sudhakar Tummala
 
Abstract
 
In analysis of brain structural magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data, rigid and affine registration of individual subject’s brain to a reference brain is a vital step in pre-processing stage. In general, the registered images could be checked manually or semi-manually for quality of alignment. However, this visual quality control becomes a tedious process when we deal with big data MRI processing containing thousands of images. Therefore, there is a strong need to fully automate this quality checking process. Hence, I propose to develop and deploy different machine learning (ML) classifiers for quality checking of both rigid and affine registrations.
Firstly, the cost functions such as normalized cross-correlation, normalized mutual information and correlation ratio are computed by comparing the subject’s registration to the template with the template. These cost values are computed locally at a 3x3x3 volume of interest (VOI) and further moving this VOI with a stride of 3. Final cost value is the average of cost values obtained in each VOI. Further, these are also the features used for training different ML classifiers including linear discriminant analysis, support vector machine, kNN, random forest, Gaussian naive bayes. These ML classifiers are 5-fold cross validated on a subset of T1-weighted MRI data from autism brain imaging data exchange (ABIDE I) consisting of 220 images. These images were rigidly and affinely transformed to the template by using the FSL interface in Nipype. Further, 220 incorrectly registered images were generated by changing the values in transformation matrices and then applying these modified matrices to register the image to the template.
All ML classifiers achieved a testing accuracy of 99.9 % for both rigid and affine registrations. Eventually, these trained ML models could be deployed for automatic quality checking of image registrations involving big data there by eliminating the need for manual intervention.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Replication of two computational models of locomotion of Caenorhabditis elegans in Brian 2
Ivan Estevez
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Francisco J. Valverde-Albacete, Carlos III University of Madrid; Carmen Peláez-Moreno, Carlos III University of Madrid

The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans has a simple nervous structure yet displays complex behaviours
mediated by a sensation-action loop. We report on replicating two experiments based on two different
models of the locomotion neural circuits of C. elegans [1, 2].

Both articles present point-neuron models that consider the graded nature of the electrical activity
in C. elegans, as opposed to spiking-neuron models—yet both are different. In the first case a
non-dimensional model is used for a small subnetwork in which the values of free parameters are
found by applying constraints with a genetic algorithm. The second model is based on physiological
parameters for cells and synapses, therefore no optimization is needed and almost the complete
connectome of C. elegans is simulated—279 out of 302 neurons. The replications are performed in the
simulating platform Brian 2, which is available as a Python module and is different from the
original methods used.

We were able to verify the main hypothesis proposed by each article. In the first case, the
production of intrinsic network oscillations by central pattern generators (CPGs) along the ventral
nerve cord of the worm. In the second, the existence of a bifurcation in the model state-space
produced by a constant sensory input that creates oscillatory behaviour. Nevertheless, we were
unable to replicate exact quantitative results for the first model, and obtained contradictory
results when performing neural ablations on the second network model. The source code generated, and
data used are made publicly available in code repositories [3].

[1] E. O. Olivares, E. J. Izquierdo and R. D. Beer, 'Potential role of a ventral nerve cord central
pattern generator in forward and backward locomotion in Caenorhabditis elegans', Network
Neuroscience, vol. 2, no. 3, pp. 323-343, 2018. DOI: 10.1162/netn_a_00036.

[2] J. Kunert, E. Shlizerman and J. N. Kutz, 'Low-dimensional functionality of complex network
dynamics: Neurosensory integration in the Caenorhabditis elegans connectome', Phys. Rev. E, vol. 89,
p. 052805, 5 May 2014. DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevE.89.052805.

[3] https://github.com/ivan-ea/celegans_brian2_replications
Interactive talk
Watch now
GIN-tonic: collaboration in research made easy
Julien Colomb
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Achilleas Koutsou, Thorsten Arendt, Deepti Mittal, Keisuke Sehara,  Rike-Benjamin Schuppner, Thomas Wachtler, Matthew Larkum, Julien Colomb

Computer scientists have seen their collaboration highly facilitated by the use of GitHub-like platforms. Their work could not be done without the use of issues, pull requests and merges, not any more. However, we have been waiting for a "GitHub for science" tool for a decade. Indeed, the technology needed to deal with research data specificities makes the repository administration very complex and time consuming, and requires relatively high computer skills.

We have developed a toolkit to bring the power of GitHub to the researchers. Behind the scene, we are using advanced technologies: git-annex deals with large files; git modules brings access rights and publication at the sub-folder levels; gogs brings the github-like collaboration tool, and the tonic application (in go) facilitates and automates complex administrative tasks (like the creation of the research repo). Last but not least, we also worked on a folder structure template to facilitate and promote file sharing, reproducible research and research data management.

Similar to the beverage, gin-tonic was tricky to prepare, but now you can relax and enjoy it. Once installed, you only need to save your digital files at a right place and double-click synchronization files from time to time: then you get access to all advanced features via your internet browser. In addition, it is a free open source software and works as a data backup system.

Gin-tonic stands for: GitHub for neuroscience - templates and other necessary tools for git control
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Comprehensive map of human brain lipidome
Maria Osetrova (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Anna Tkachev, Skolkovo Institute of Science and Technology; Elena Stekolschikova, Skolkovo Institute of Science and Technology; Aleksandra Mitina, Skolkovo Institute of Science and Technology; Olga Efimova, Skolkovo Institute of Science and Technology; Ekaterina Khrameeva Skolkovo Institute of Science and Technology; Philipp Khaitovich Skolkovo Institute of Science and Technology;

The lipid composition of brain anatomical structures remains poorly understood, particularly in humans and closely related non-human primates. In addition, lipids are often assumed to be exclusively structural elements of the brain, and their functionality remains poorly studied on the scale of the whole brain. In our work, we describe the generation and analysis of a lipidome atlas of the healthy adult human brain.
Analysis of the lipid composition of 75 regions of the brain of 4 healthy individuals using high-performance liquid chromatography combined with mass spectrometry resulted in 3573 high-quality peaks, as well as a subset of 503 manually annotated lipid species covering 20 lipid classes. A comparison of lipid data with the structural and functional MRI of the brain revealed groups of lipids associated with the white and the gray matter of the brain, as well as a group of function-associated lipids.
Statistically significant differences in the behavior of different lipids species in different areas of the brain, discovered in this work, can be associated with cytoarchitectural diversity. Moreover, similarities to the functional architecture of the brain make lipids a potential target for the diagnosis of mental disorders.
Thus, comparative analysis of the lipid composition of the brain of patients with schizophrenia showed that the greatest changes occur in the lipids associated with the white matter of the brain, as well as lipids associated with the functional activity of the brain.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Altered hippocampal neural dynamics in a rodent model of chronic stress
Anupratap Tomar
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Denis Polygalov,Laboratory for Circuit & Behavioral Physiology, RIKEN Center for Brain Science, 2-1 Hirosawa, Wako-shi, Saitama, Japan 351-0021; Sumantra Chattarji, National Centre for Biological Sciences, Bellary Road, Bangalore, 560065, India; Thomas J. McHugh, Laboratory for Circuit & Behavioral Physiology, RIKEN Center for Brain Science, 2-1 Hirosawa, Wako-shi, Saitama, Japan 351-0021

Adverse effects of chronic stress include anxiety, depression, and learning and memory deficits. Some of these deficits are mediated by stress-induced impaired hippocampal functionality at multiple levels of neural organization including dendritic shrinkage and neurogenesis and impaired synaptic plasticity. In agreement, studies in awake behaving rodents have reported that chronic stress alters place cell activity and disrupts global remapping which is the generation of distinct representations (place maps) across different surroundings. Surprisingly, it is not known if and how chronic stress alters hippocampal information processing during offline behaviour states, including quiet wakefulness/sleep, during which information consolidation takes place during sharp-wave ripples (SPW-Rs or ripples), high frequency (100-200 Hz) oscillatory events in the CA1 region.
Here, we employed tetrode recordings in mice and subjected them to chronic immobilization stress (CIS), a well-established rodent model of chronic stress and assessed pyramidal cell activity and SPW-Rs in the dorsal CA1 of the hippocampus. Contrary to our expectations, we noticed a net decrease in pyramidal cell activity during the first exposure to a stress compared to the prior quiet wakefulness/sleep state. We also noticed lower firing rates and decreased participation by pyramidal cells during SPW-Rs, though pyramidal cell co-activity was enhanced during stress exposure. Interestingly, after repeated exposure to same stress, some of these stress-phenotypes were noticed during the rest-state on the last day of CIS, when no overt stress was delivered. These data indicate that repeated exposure to stress alters hippocampal neural dynamics and that disrupted ripple-spike interactions may underlie the impaired learning observed in chronically stressed subjects.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Just-in-time computations by non-normal attractor dynamics in the prefrontal cortex
Jake Stroud
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jake P. Stroud, University of Cambridge; Kei Watanabe, Osaka University; Takafumi Suzuki, National Institute of Communication and Information Technology Osaka; Mark G. Stokes, University of Oxford; Mate Lengyel, University of Cambridge and Central European University Budapest

Prefrontal cortex plays a central role in working memory maintenance. However, both the neural circuit mechanisms supporting this role and the precise computational objective underlying those mechanisms remain unknown. There have been two distinct proposals for what circuit dynamics may underlie memory maintenance: attractor dynamics giving rise to stable (persistent) activities, or feed-forward dynamics resulting in sequential (time varying) activities. Here, we analyze multiple datasets recorded in monkeys performing memory-guided saccade tasks across multiple task epochs. We show that neither of the previously proposed dynamical regimes alone accounts for experimentally observed neural activities, which instead display a rich combination of both sequential and stable dynamical motifs. Specifically, we found strongly dynamic transitions and hence sequential neural activity between different task epochs, together with stable activity during the delay epoch. We propose a novel unifying model that explains these puzzling findings. Our model combines two dynamical regimes that have hitherto been studied in isolation: non-normal feed-forward and attractor dynamics. Critically, in our model, optimal stimulus inputs are orthogonal to stable activity patterns, naturally producing strongly sequential stimulus-to-delay activity followed by stable delay activity, as seen in experiments. To understand the computational function of these dynamics, we trained recurrent neural networks for different objectives: to produce target activities at the time of the response, or throughout the delay period, or “just-in-time” (before the response, at the end of the delay period). Using these objectives, we respectively recovered either of the classical dynamics (sequential and stable), or their combination as observed in data. These results also generalised to neural responses recorded in a task involving distractor stimuli. In summary, our results identify a new class of non-normal attractor network dynamics, unifying sequential and stable motifs, and suggest that they serve a new functional objective: just-in-time computation.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Altered brain function and structure in people with carpal tunnel syndrome: systematic review and meta-analysis of structural and functional magnetic resonance imaging
Mohamed Sobeeh
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Amira Benmelouka, Faculty of Medicine, University of Algiers, Algeria;Global Medical Research Initiative (GMRI); Eslam Metwally, Al-azhar Faculty of Medicine, Cairo, Egypt;Global Medical Research Initiative (GMRI); Mohammed Jawad, Faculty of Medicine, Alexandria University, Alexandria, Egypt;Global Medical Research Initiative (GMRI); Ahmed Mohammed, Faculty of Medicine, Alexandria University, Alexandria, Egypt;Global Medical Research Initiative (GMRI); Sara Nasr, Faculty of Medicine, Alexandria University;Global Medical Research Initiative (GMRI); Ghidaa El-helw, Faculty of Medicine, Beni Suef University, Egypt;Global Medical Research Initiative (GMRI); Mohamed Doheim, Faculty of Medicine, Alexandria University, Alexandria, Egypt;Global Medical Research Initiative (GMRI).

Study Design: Systematic review and meta-analysis.
Objective: The aim of this systematic review/meta-analysis was to appraise and summarize the literature about magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) outcomes in people with carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) to identify the altered brain structure and function compared to healthy controls (HC).
Background: CTS represents the most common nerve entrapment neuropathy in the arm associated with an altered nociceptive system peripherally and centrally.
Methods: Two reviewers screened studies for eligibility by title and abstract then by reading the full text. This systematic review/meta-analysis used PRISMA guidelines to report the outcomes. Five databases were searched for relevant literature (Embase, Web of Science, Scopus, PubMed, and Cochrane). Studies comparing MRI and fMRI findings in people with chronic CTS (present for at least 3 months) and HC through the following parameters: 1) Interdigit cortical representation distance, 2) cluster size of digit representation on somatosensory cortex. Newcastle-Ottawa quality assessment scale was used for risk of bias assessment. When possible, the results from different studies were pooled and meta-analysis was done using standardized mean difference (SMD) as effect size measures based on random effect model.
Results: There was a significant reduction of interdigit cortical separation distance of index-middle and index-little fingers in the CTS (SMD=-0.878, 95%CI (-1.27, -0.48), P-value=0.00) and (SMD=-0.84, 95%CI (-1.26, -0.42), P-value=0.00) respectively. Moreover, middle-little fingers interdigit separation showed no significant difference.
Conclusion: In CTS, cluster size of index, middle and little fingers representation in the primary somatosensory cortex showed significant blurring as evident by increased their cluster size as well as reduction of interdigit cortical separation distance between both index-middle and index-little fingers. Altered cortical morphology and function proved the central mechanisms might be involved in CTS providing a base for future treatment strategies.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Modelling Appetitive-Disinhibition in Modified Stop-Signal Task—A Computational model of Associative Memory initiated Going (Disinhibition) System
Nilosmita Banerjee
 
Abstract
 
Background: Studies employing modified Stop-signal tasks (MSST) have demonstrated that response-inhibition, a key executive-function, severely impairs in appetitive environments. These studies demonstrate that presence of appetitive-cues results in disinhibited response and slow-stopping latencies (i.e., Stop-Signal Reaction-Times or SSRT’s). Theoretical-frameworks propose that retrieval of appetitive-cue–approach/going-response associations (developed during appetitive-conditioning) from ones associative-memory traces, biases the inhibitory-system such that it produces approach/going (i.e., disinhibited-response) post exposure to appetitive-cues.
Aims: The aim of the current study was to develop a computational model of response-disinhibition i.e., a going-system. In developing this model, we introduced a new free-parameter ‘λ’ which instantiated associative-memory recall. We augmented λ to the Interactive Race Model (IRM) of action suppression to model the interaction between the associative-memory (i.e., λ) and inhibitory-system (i.e., IRM) with an aim to simulate disinhibited-responses (indicated by slow SSRT’s) observed in MSST studies.
Methods: We tested three model types which differed in how λ affected go-process and stop-process in IRM formalism. In the first model (Associative-Memory Interactive Disinhibition-Model–AMI) the λ parameters affected the mutual inhibitory-interaction between go-process and stop-process. In the second model (Associative-Memory Race Disinhibition-Model–AMR) λ parameters affected the mean growth-rate of go-process and stop-process. In the final model (Associative- Memory Interactive Race Disinhibition-Model–AMIR) λ parameters affected both mean growth-rate and mutual inhibitory-interaction between go-process and stop-process simultaneously.
Results: The modelling results indicated that out of the three models, only the first model–AMI, produced slow SSRT’s observed in appetitive-cue conditions in MSST studies.
Conclusion: The current study validated the theoretical propositions that associative-memory and inhibitory-system interact with each other in producing appetitive-cue initiated disinhibition. It specifically highlighted that associative-memory affects the mutual inhibitory-interaction (between go-process and stop-process) aspect of the inhibitory-system in giving rise to appetitive-cue initiated disinhibited-responses observed in MSST studies.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Pluralistic Approach to Decoding Motor Activity from Different Brain Regions
Rishika Mohanta
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Prakriti Nayak, King’s College London; Narotam Singh, JSS Academy of Higher Education and Research, Mysuru; Vaibhav Sharma, Netaji Subhas University of Technology, Delhi

There exists a high degree of correlation and redundancy in the activity of neural populations across different regions of the brain; motor function is a result of such activities, coordinated over various regions. This project explored different approaches to decode activity from motor implicated regions in rodents using spike and population activity. The data, sourced from the Steinmetz dataset, was cleaned to consider recordings only from the motor related areas, while focussing on the the open loop condition - data between stimulus onset and go-cue - to avoid representations of stimulus movement. In order to identify whether neuronal spike activity accurately predicted motor function, general linear modelling (GLM) was used to decode the motor output (assumed from the wheel output) from the neural spike data from randomly sampled neurons (50) and trials (100) in different brain regions. This was implemented using cross-validated ridge regression. The length of the temporal kernel, or the spiking history required for optimal decoding, can vary from region to region; therefore, different kernel sizes, between 50ms to 250ms, were evaluated to choose the optimal kernel size for the analyses. Parallely, Gaussian-process factor analysis (GPFA) was implemented to compute the latent dimensions in the spiking population activity, followed by ridge regression to reconstruct the motor output and linear discriminant analysis (LDA) to classify directional (left, right, or none) motor output in the lower dimensional space. It was concluded from the results that while spikes from different brain areas roughly predict the motor output to different degrees, the latent neural modes of these regions do not separate the output equally.
Traditional talk
Watch now
NMDA receptors promote hippocampal sharp-wave ripples and the associated co-activity of CA1 pyramidal cells.
Tim Howe
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Anthony J. Blockeel; Hannah Taylor; Matt Jones; Maxim Bazenhov; Paola Malerba

Hippocampal sharp-wave ripples (SWRs) support the reactivation of memory representations, relaying information to neocortex during “offline” and sleep-dependent memory consolidation. While blockade of NMDA receptors (NMDAR) is known to affect both learning and subsequent consolidation, the specific contributions of NMDAR activation to SWR-associated activity remain unclear. Here, we combine biophysical modeling with in vivo local field potential (LFP) and unit recording to quantify changes in SWR dynamics following inactivation of NMDAR. In a biophysical model of CA3-CA1 SWR activity, we find that NMDAR removal leads to reduced SWR density, but spares SWR properties such as duration, cell recruitment and ripple frequency. These predictions are confirmed by experiments in which NMDAR-mediated transmission in rats was inhibited using 3 different NMDAR antagonists, while recording dorsal CA1 LFP. In the model, loss of NMDAR-mediated conductances also induced a reduction in the proportion of cell pairs that co-activate significantly above chance across multiple events. Again, this prediction is corroborated by dorsal CA1 single-unit recordings, where the NMDAR blocker ketamine disrupted correlated spiking during SWR.
Our results are consistent with a framework in which NMDA receptors both promote activation of SWR events and organize SWR-associated spiking content. This suggests that, while SWR are short-lived events emerging in fast excitatory-inhibitory networks, slower network components including NMDAR-mediated currents contribute to ripple density and promote consistency in the spiking content across ripples, underpinning mechanisms for fine-tuning of memory consolidation processes.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Linking single neurons to collective dynamics in the mouse brain during a perceptual decision-making task
Morteza Moazami
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Elaheh Imani, ; Alireza Hashemi,;

Across the cortical hierarchy, single neurons are characterized by differences in the extent to which they can sustain their firing rate over time (i.e. their "intrinsic timescale"). Previous studies have demonstrated that neurons in a given brain region mostly exhibit either short or long intrinsic timescales. In this study, we sought to identify populations of neurons that accumulate information over different timescales in the mouse brain, and to characterize their functions in the context of a visual discrimination task. Thus, we separately examined the neural population dynamics of neurons with long or short intrinsic timescales across different brain regions. More specifically, we looked at the decoding performance of these neural populations, aligned to different task variables (stimulus onset, movement and choice probability). Taken together, our population level findings support the hypothesis that long intrinsic timescale neurons encode abstract variables related to decision formation. Furthermore, we evaluated the time constants of individual neurons at different epochs during the task, and found that many neurons exhibited multiple timescales in their response. These timescales were consistently longer after the animal formed its decision (e.g. during wheel movement), and the longest timescales were observed in frontal regions and in the thalamus. Finally, we also found a significant correlation between the functions primarily subserved by individual neurons, and their intrinsic timescales. In summary, our findings support the idea that long intrinsic timescale neurons, which appear at different levels of the cortical hierarchy, are primarily involved in computing the time integral of sensory signals.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Endocannabinoid System as an alternative way for neuropathic pain treatment
João Gustavo dos Anjos Morais Oliveira
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Cláudio Henrique Cavalcanti Teixeira, Escola Bahiana de Medicina e Saúde Pública; Cristiana Bello Dultra Nogueira, Escola Bahiana de Medicina e Saúde Pública; Lucca Oliveira Soares Pinto, Escola Bahiana de Medicina e Saúde Pública

Neuropathic pain is a debilitating condition, which can occur in both the central and peripheral nervous system lesions. Its cost could amount to as much as $160 billion annually in the United States. The magnitude of the cost is associated with scarce effective treatment for this condition. Research made with the Endocannabinoid System are raising its potentiality to be an alternative way for the treatment of this condition. That fact based the production of this review, with systematic reviews and reviews searched via PubMed.
Clinical evidence has suggested cannabis-based medical extracts may be helpful as an adjuvant treatment for some patients with neuropathic pain symptoms, especially the activation of CB1 receptors by Δ9-Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC). However, side effects related to the activation of CB1 receptors could be harmful, as CB1 is expressed in higher function areas in the central nervous system, representing a threat specially for individuals with a history of neuropsychiatric conditions. Local injection of cannabinoids has shown effectiveness as CB1 receptors are present in peripheral tissue. It has been demonstr ated that oromucosal spray containing equal mixture of THC and Cannabidiol (CBD) induced significant antinociceptive effects in patients with peripheral neuropathic pain and has also suggested the capacity of CDB to reduce THC’s psychotic effects. Furthermore, smoked cannabis has presented better results as a second-line treatment, as it has presented a dose-dependent anti-nociceptive effect capable of attenuating neuropathic pain. The inhibition of endocannabinoids degrading enzymes can lead up to elevated levels of these substances where their actions can produce analgesia. This strategy represents an alternative to the global activation of CB1 receptors, which is associated with adverse effects.
