Even though the results are promising, the evidence is not strong enough for its disseminated use. There are gaps to be filled, for example the lack of natural versus synthetic compounds comparison.
Traditional talk
Watch now
A phase code for human amygdala-hippocampal theta-gamma interplay determines emotional memory formation
Manuela Costa
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Diego Lozano-Soldevilla, Laboratory for Clinical Neuroscience, Center for Biomedical Technology, University Politécnica de Madrid, Madrid, Spain; Antonio Gil-Nagel, Epilepsy Unit, Department of Neurology, Hospital Ruber Internacional, Madrid, Spain; Rafael Toledano, Epilepsy Unit, Department of Neurology, Hospital Ruber Internacional, Madrid, Spain; Carina Oehrn, Department of Neurology, University Hospital of Giessen and Marburg, Baldingerstrasse, 35043 Marburg, Germany, Center for Mind, Brain and Behavior (CMBB), Philipps-University Marburg, Marburg, Germany; Mar Yebra, Laboratory for Clinical Neuroscience, Center for Biomedical Technology, University Politécnica de Madrid, Madrid, Spain; Costantino Mendez-Bertolo, Laboratory for Clinical Neuroscience, Center for Biomedical Technology, University Politécnica de Madrid, Madrid, Spain; Johannes Sarnthein, Neurosurgery Department, University Hospital and University of Zurich, Zurich, Switzerland; Nikolai Axmacher, Department of Neuropsychology, Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience, Faculty of Psychology, Ruhr University Bochum, Universitaetsstrasse, 150, 44801 Bochum, Germany; Stephan Moratti, Department of Experimental Psychology, Complutense University of Madrid, Spain; Bryan A. Strange, Laboratory for Clinical Neuroscience, Center for Biomedical Technology, University Politécnica de Madrid, Madrid, Spain, Department of Neuroimaging, Reina Sofia Centre for Alzheimer's Research, Madrid, Spain.

Communication between the amygdala and the hippocampus has been proposed to
support emotional, relative to neutral, memory. However, it is still unknown how these
two structures interact during successful encoding of unpleasant information. We used
direct intracranial recordings from 15 patients with medication-resistant epilepsy while
they encoded (day 1) and later retrieved (after 24 h, day 2) unpleasant and neutral
complex scenes from the IAPS database. All patients had intracranial depth electrodes
implanted into the amygdala and 8 patients also in the ipsilateral hippocampus.
Investigating the oscillatory responses associated with the subsequent memory of
scenes, we found that successful emotional memory formation produced in the
amygdala (n=8) a local broadband gamma activity (80-135 Hz) starting at around
400ms. By contrast, at around 500ms hippocampal (n=8) gamma responses (50-75 Hz)
were associated with successful encoding of both unpleasant and neutral scenes. We
further found theta oscillations in the amygdala influencing in a unidirectional way
hippocampus theta responses to emotional stimuli. Importantly, during successful
encoding of unpleasant scenes, the hippocampus gamma activity coupled to the
amygdala theta in a specific manner. We indeed found that the coupling occurred with a
consistent phase difference of ~1.67 radians during successful and unsuccessful
encoding of unpleasant scenes. Finally, using amplitude envelope cross-correlation as a
proxy of synchrony strength between the amygdala and the hippocampus we found
transient broadband gamma (60-120 Hz) connectivity. The amygdala gamma also leads
the hippocampus gamma during successful encoding of unpleasant scenes.
Our results show a unique phase code for negative memory formation in humans and
demonstrate that the amygdala facilitates memory encoding in the hippocampus within
a unique time window of ~37ms on which hippocampal gamma amplitude peaks have
to occur to form successfully emotional memories.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Is the Kiki-Bouba effect specific to pronounceable words?
Ananya Passi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
SP Arun, Indian Institute of Science Bangalore

INTRODUCTION. Across cultures, people associate spiky shapes to the word “Kiki” and rounded shapes to the word “Bouba”. What causes this highly systematic shape-sound association? One possibility is that our mouth forms an angular shape while uttering the word “Kiki” and circular shape while saying “Bouba”. Alternatively, objects with sharp edges produce high-pitched (“Kiki”-like) sounds while those with rounded edges produce low-pitched (“Bouba”-like) sounds. Repeated cross-modal experiences could enable learning this association. Here, we investigated the reason behind this effect using a series of behavioral experiments.

METHODS. We conducted four online behavioral experiments using Google Forms. Ten spiky and ten rounded shapes were created. In Experiments 1 & 2, subjects had to associate each shape to a Kiki-like or Bouba-like word. In Experiment 3 & 4, multiple audio clips were played and subjects had to associate them with either a spiky or a rounded shape. The audio clips were either (1) pronounceable Kiki & Bouba words; (2) the same words but reversed in time so that they were no longer pronouncable, but contained the same sound frequencies; (3) pure tones matched to the mean frequency of the Kiki and Bouba words; and (4) Sounds produced by natural objects when struck.

RESULTS. In the shape-validation experiment, 80% of the subjects associated spiky shapes with Kiki-like words and rounded shapes with Bouba-like words. In Experiments 3 & 4, subjects associated Bouba-like words with rounded shapes (~85%), Kiki-like words with spiky shapes(~60%), reversed Bouba words with rounded shapes (~85%), reversed Kiki words with spiky shapes (~55%), metal clanks with spiky shapes (~90%) and pillow hits with rounded shapes (~55%). There was a strong positive correlation between mean frequency of sound and the Kiki-ness of the word.

CONCLUSIONS. We conclude that the Kiki-Bouba effect reflects a robust association between shapes and sound frequency irrespective of whether the sounds can be pronounced.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Disrupted experience-dependent place cell coding in rats heterozygous for the calcium channel gene Cacna1c
Ed Morrell
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jeremy Hall, Cardiff University; Lawrence S Wilkinson, Cardiff University; Matt W. Jones, University of Bristol

Genome-wide association studies reveal that variants of CACNA1C, a gene encoding the α1 pore-forming subunit of the L-Type calcium channel, confer risk for psychiatric disorders across diagnostic categories. Heterozygosity for this gene in rodents has been associated with hippocampal synaptic plasticity deficits and related cognitive impairment. What is not yet known however, is how synaptic deficits disrupt neuronal and network activity to compromise behavioural function. We sought to bridge this gap by quantifying place-cell dynamics in Cacna1c heterozygous (Cacna1c+/-) rats.
We recorded dorsal CA1 single unit and local field potential activity in adult Cacna1c+/- rats during free exploration of familiar and novel environments, and during rest. Place-fields were normal in a novel environment yet enlarged on a linear track in Cacna1c+/- rats, with an associated reduction of place-cell spatial information. During rest, despite intact sharp-wave ripple oscillations, Cacna1c+/- rats exhibited overexcitation of place-cells during ripples. In contrast, cross-correlated activity between place-cell pairs during ripples was markedly impaired. In addition, a loss of correlation between spike-timing and place-field distance between cell pairs during ripples was observed during the rest period following free exploration in Cacna1c+/- rats, indicating an impairment in ripple-associated reactivation of spatial codes.
These results point towards a deficit in the consolidation of spatial memory in Cacna1c+/- rats, possibly arising due to impairments in schaffer-collateral plasticity. Such deficits may underlie Cacna1c-associated behavioural impairments, highlighting a potential mechanism underlying cognitive dysfunction in psychiatric disease.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Intracerebral recordings study of the spatiotemporal dynamics of human exogenous attention
Tal Seidel Malkinson (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Dimitri J Bayle; Alexia Bourgeois; Katia Lehongre; Vincent Navarro; Claude Adam; Jacobo D Sitt; Paolo Bartolomeo

Our attention is automatically captured by salient events, a process called exogenous attention orienting. We explored the neural basis of two exogenous attention related effects: response time facilitation (RT facilitation) and inhibition of return (IOR). How fast we respond to a stimulus depends on whether it appears in a previously attended location, for example if a target-stimulus was preceded or not by an exogenous cue. However, this cueing effect changes according to the cue-to-target delay: short delays lead to faster responses in cued locations (RT Facilitation), while delays that are only slightly longer inverse this pattern and lead to faster responses to uncued locations (IOR). A method with high temporal resolution is required to study the neural correlates of these fast and dynamic processes. Here, data were recorded from 28 epileptic patients implanted with depth electrodes as a part of their medical treatment (1407 contacts), providing a unique opportunity to directly measure human neurophysiology with excellent spatio-temporal resolution. Patients performed the Posner paradigm with peripheral cues, while their neural responses were recorded. We studied the neural activity through a data-driven clustering approach, to reveal the spatiotemporal patterns of target-related activity. We identified specific neural clusters showing segregated cue and target related responses when the delay was long, but an integrated response to cue and target when the delay was short. Clusters varied in their sensitivity to the stimulus location, stimulus identity (cue or target) and response latency. These clusters may contribute to the computations underlying exogenous attention related effects.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Emotion and Working Memory Circuits Examined via Inhibition Tasks in Prefrontal Cortex: An fNIRS Study
Ece Zeynep Karakulak
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kubra Kadak, Istanbul Medipol University; Lutfu Hanoglu, Istanbul Medipol University

Emotion is a wide hub involving limbic system and neocortical structures and shares a part of functional network with cognition. Neuropsychological studies have shown that emotion and cognition processes are both appearent in the prefrontal cortex. Although they are overlapping seperate functions, recent neuroimaging studies present a wide literature on mutual or adjacent brain areas host these feaures. In this study, we aimed to show whether inhibition processes are shared on PFC during event related emotional and color-word Stroop tasks. We collected fNIRS data from prefrontal regions of 5 healthy young people without any neuropsychiatric conditions. Emotional Stroop task presented via happy and sad faces with congruent and incongruent words in the middle of the picture. In color-word Stroop task, we used color words painted in red, yellow, green and blue. We requested from participants to tap 1 for congruent and 2 for incongruent trials. All analyzing processes applied using NIRSLAB. fNIRS data are filtered, averaged and then contrasted in a binary model in which incongruent trials are main sets and congruent trials are substracted properties for SPM. We observed right dorsolateral prefrontal area is the most differentiated region regarding oxyhemoglobin concentration change during both inhibition tasks when right dorsomedial prefrontal and left inferior frontal areas are additionally distinguished in emotional Stroop task. The present data indicates that there is shared cortical networks especially on right PFC during emotional and cognitive conflict monitoring while emotional processing also requires medial-frontal structures. Further research studies should consider fNIRS as a comprehensive method for assessing higher cognitive functions.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Experience replay supports non-local learning
Yunzhe Liu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Marcelo Matter, Princeton University; Tim Behrens, University of Oxford; Nathaniel Daw, Princeton University; Ray Dolan, University College London

To make effective decisions we need to consider the relationship between actions and outcomes. However, there are often substantial gaps between them in both space and time. The biological mechanism capable of spanning those gaps remains unknown. One promising, albeit hypothetical, mechanism involves neural replay of non-local experience. Using a novel task, that segregates direct from indirect learning, combined with magnetoencephalography (MEG), we probed the role of neural replay in non-local learning in humans. Following reward receipt, we found significant backward replay of non-local experience, with a 160 msec state-to-state time lag, and this replay facilitated learning of action values. This backward replay, combined with behavioural evidence of non-local learning, was more pronounced in experiences that were of greater benefit for future behavior, as predicted by theories of prioritization. These findings establish rationally targeted non-local replay as a neural mechanism for solving complex credit assignment problems during learning.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Studying the role of the large neutral-amino acid transporter Slc7a5 in autism spectrum disorder and microcephaly
Lisa Knaus
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Bernadette Basilico; Nicole Amberg; LIl Andersen; Thomas Ruelicke; Simon Hippenmeyer; Gaia Novarino

The solute carrier transporter 7a5 (SLC7A5), a large neutral amino acid transporter, has a crucial role in maintaining branched chain amino acid (BCAA) levels in the brain. We have identified several patients harboring a homozygous missense mutation in the SLC7A5 gene, who are on the autism spectrum (ASD) and present with motor deficits and microcephaly. In mice, a deletion of Slc7a5 from the blood brain barrier (BBB) endothelial cells causes decreased levels of BCAAs in the brain, altered cap-dependent translation and severe behavioral abnormalities including sociability and gait defects.
Now, aiming to dissect the molecular mechanisms underlying the microcephalic phenotype of the patients, we have generated a conditional knock-out mouse line (cKO) of Slc7a5 specifically targeting neuroprogenitor cells of the developing cortex and hippocampus.
These cKO mice present with a microcephalic brain, thereby recapitulating the patient’s phenotype. We have found that the severe reduction of cortical thickness is caused by increased apoptotic activity within the postnatal cortex. Interestingly, these elevated rates of cell death co-occur with an endogenous wave of neuronal apoptosis within a specific developmental time window. This apoptotic program has been shown to be regulated by the activity levels of cortical pyramidal neurons and is crucial for postnatal network refinement. We now aim to elucidate potential contributions of Slc7a5 to this critical process, thereby focusing on a cell type-specific role of the transporter during this neurodevelopmental time window.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Predictive processing by Purkinje cells in the anterior vermis during active versus passive self-motion
Omid Zobeiri
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kathleen Cullen

The ability to distinguish between self-generated (reafference) vs. externally-applied
(exafference) sensory signals is fundamental for ensuring accurate motor control. This is
particularly evident in the context of the vestibular system, in which the same neurons that
receive afferent input also mediate vestibulo-spinal reflexes (VSR). Notably, while VSRs are
essential for postural stability, they can be counterproductive during active motion. Previous
studies by our group have shown that VSR neurons selectively code passive head movements.
Although, the cerebellum is hypothesized to play a role in vestibular reafference suppression,
the exact underlying neural mechanism is unknown. Accordingly, here we recorded from
Purkinje cells in the anterior vermis of the vestibular cerebellum in rhesus monkeys during
passive and active motion. We first recorded neuronal responses to vestibular-only and neck
proprioceptive-only passive stimulation. Simple spike activity encoded both stimuli in a direction-
dependent manner. We then passively applied both vestibular and proprioceptive stimuli
simultaneously (i.e., passive head-on-body rotations) and found that Purkinje cells linearly
integrated these two inputs. However, comparison of neuronal responses to active and passive
head-on-body motion revealed a marked response attenuation for active head motion (~70%,
p<0.01). Accordingly, we next tested whether motor inputs to the Purkinje cells might mediate
the suppression observed during active movements. Most cells receive and encode motor
signals, yet a linear model could not explain response attenuation during active movements.
Finally, we compared the climbing fiber inputs to the Purkinje cells for passive vs. active head
movements and found that the probability of a complex spike firing increased (~60%, p<0.01)
immediately following (~20ms) the onset of passive but not active head movements, suggesting
that complex spikes detect externally-applied versus self-generated vestibular inputs. Taken
together, these results provide new insights into the cerebellar computations performed to
suppress the sensory consequences of self-generated movement to ensure postural stability.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Characterization and analysis of visual processing in humans using fMRI data and machine learning techniques
Vittor Pereira
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Giulia Zanon de Castro, Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais (grid.8430.f); Frederico Gadelha Guimarães, Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais (grid.8430.f); Anthony Randal McIntosh, Rotman Research Institute - Baycrest Centre - University of Toronto (grid.17063.33)

Recent studies suggest that shape and surface characteristics of objects appear to be encoded in the ventral visual cortex. With this idea, this work aims to get insights into the human visual system from the analysis of the public experimental database VIM-1. The dataset consists of displaying images to subjects, with neuronal activity being measured using fMRI. In order to find clusters inherent to the responses to visual stimuli, we use the k-means algorithm. We could (i) find groups of voxels that have similar brain activity, also cohesive in anatomy; (ii) obtain groups of images that provide similar brain activations. Anatomical group locations are related to the locations of the main visual information processing pathways in the brain, the ventral and dorsal pathways. Finally, using the Mann-Whitney U test, we found a statistically significant difference between the density of the image edges and the level of neuronal activity in groups of images with opposite activations. Additionally, from the F test (ANOVA), we found a correlation between the edge density and the activation level in a cluster, which comprises most of the V1 area.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Pitfalls in quantifying exploration in reward-based motor learning
Nina van Mastrigt
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
K. van der Kooij, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam; J.B.J. Smeets, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam

Movements are variable. It is unclear how much different variability sources contribute to this variability and how these contributions can be quantified. These questions are especially of interest in studying reward-based motor learning, where people are thought to add exploratory variability to their inevitable motor noise to discover which movements lead to reward. Whether variability promotes or hampers learning is however controversial. To clarify this relation between variability and learning, it is important to separate variability caused by exploration from motor noise.

We developed the additional trial-to-trial change (ATTC) method for quantifying exploration as the additive variability following non-rewarded movements over variability following rewarded movements. Here, we aimed to validate the ATTC method by simulating learning using existing models of reward-based motor learning. This is important because we developed the method in a random reward paradigm, in which participants cannot use the feedback to improve their performance. Furthermore, learning contributes to trial-to-trial changes in behavior in a systematic, rather than random, manner, and may hence influence the quantification of exploration. We calculated the similarity between input exploration and exploration estimated from model behavior, for four models and their parameters.

The fairly simple rationale behind the ATTC method is that exploration is higher following reward absence, which is a key feature of all models, too. Nevertheless, similarity is sensitive to the ratio of input motor noise and exploration, and exploration is generally underestimated.

Our results reveal two important pitfalls in quantifying exploration based on trial-to-trial changes. Firstly, performance-dependent reward causes considerable correlations in samples of motor noise, thereby affecting estimates of exploration depending on the ratio of the learners’ exploration and motor noise. Secondly, using trial-to-trial changes to quantify exploration results in an underestimation of exploration since the exploration relative to which the change is calculated is unstable.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Emergent Sequential Task Learning Facilitates Convergence in Recurrent Neural Networks
Thijs van der Plas
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sanjay Manohar, University of Oxford; Tim Vogels, IST Vienna;

Neuronal networks can learn to maintain stimulus information in order to solve working memory tasks. Here, tasks are defined by their loss function that is optimised to solve the task. Loss functions can vary in difficulty, and various machine learning strategies have been developed to catalyse learning, such as drop-out, adaptive learning rates and various gradient descent methods. But these are all technical improvements of the involved algorithms, and do not inform us of how animal learning might be improved. Instead, we have identified a different, non-trivial strategy to improve learning, by adding a second, easier task to the loss function. Our original task requires a recurrent neural network to report the trial type at the end of each trial, by accumulating information throughout the trial. This is a difficult task to learn, and networks often fail to converge. This changes when an additional component is added to the loss function that requires networks to make short-term predictions throughout the trial, thus informing them of the trial structure. Networks emerge to learn to solve the second task first, thereby changing the functional profile of their neurons, after which they also learn to minimise the first component of the loss function. This unsupervised, sequential learning behaviour provides a new perspective on task optimisation. It shows that networks can decompose a loss function and learn its parts in an optimal sequence. This principle could potentially be applied to other difficult tasks, arguing that they may be solved by using additional, easier tasks, serving as a warm start to the network.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
TASER (Temporally Adaptive SourcE Reconstruction)
Ryan Timms
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ryan C. Timms, University of Oxford; Andrew J. Quinn, University of Oxford; Alexander Skates, University of Oxford; Cameron J. Higgins, University of Oxford; Usama Pervaiz, University of Oxford; Evan J. Roberts, University of Oxford; James Bonaiuto, Institut des Sciences Cognitives Marc Jeannerod; Stephen M. Smith, University of Oxford; Matthew J. Brookes, University of Nottingham; Gareth R. Barnes, University College London; and Mark W. Woolrich, University of Oxford

Source reconstruction is a ubiquitous yet complex and critical pre-processing step in MEG and EEG analysis. Existing approaches have enjoyed great success, but nearly always assume stationarity in the source space covariance, a constraint which confounds the accuracy of source localisation (Barratt et al., 2018). Here we present TASER (Temporally Adaptive SourcE Reconstruction), a fully unsupervised algorithm which learns time-point specific reconstruction weights to build source space images. Specifically, we infer regularised time-varying data and noise covariance matrices at the same temporal resolution of the data. This is achieved by employing a stochastic gradient variational Bayesian inference framework, featuring gated recurrent unit neural networks. We show in simulation that TASER improves upon conventional static (minimum norm and beamformer) estimates in 3 out of 4 criteria. Applying the algorithm to real data, we show that TASER is able to uncover task-relevant physiological dynamics in an unsupervised fashion, negating the need to manually segregate data into different trial conditions. By automatically accounting for differences in covariance between timepoints, we replicate the findings of Barratt et al. (2018) and map the post movement beta rebound of digits 1 and 5 in motor cortex using MEG data, demonstrating the increase in spatial resolution over conventional static approaches to source reconstruction. This new unsupervised technique has exciting potential applications to datasets where there is little to no pre-supposed task structure e.g. during the resting state.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Transcriptomic Analysis of the brains of Symptomatic and Asymptomatic Alzheimer’s Patients
Varun Ullanat
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ryna S

Asymptomatic Alzheimer’s diseases (Asym-AD) is a condition where patients have intact cognition but neuropathology similar to Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Studying the genome-wide expression of transcripts in Asym-AD brains could help us understand the molecular mechanisms that play a role in the onset of AD. Microarray expression counts from the entorhinal, temporal, cerebellum and frontal regions of the brain is taken for AD, Asym-AD and Normal (control) patients collected from the GEO database. The gene expression of the three conditions are compared as three different cases: AD versus Asym-AD, AD versus control and Asym-AD versus control. All analysis was done using the R software. Differential gene expression (DGE) and Co-expression is first done to analyse the abnormalities in the transcriptome. Overrepresentation analysis (ORA) and Gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) is done to find out the significant pathways and modules. Finally, protein-protein interaction networks are constructed to identify potential network hubs for targeting. Neuronal pathways including postsynaptic signal transduction, transmission across synapses and release of neurotransmitters were affected in all cases, and some interesting pathways such as Innate immunity and Neutrophil degranulation was found to be altered in the Asymptomatic AD versus control case. This could suggest an immunological basis for the Asymptomatic AD as a cause or direct side effect of AD neuropathology.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Temporal expectation of probabilistic rhythms
Keith Doelling
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
M. Florencia Assaneo, Instituto de Neurobiologia, UNAM; Luc Arnal, Institut Pasteur; David Poeppel, New York University

The environment surrounding the human brain is full of rhythm and temporal regularities which can be extracted to improve perception and ultimately survival. Many studies have suggested that neural oscillations may be a candidate mechanism for processing and predicting such rhythms particularly in the auditory domain. However, such studies are often limited by a narrowing scope, studying only perfectly isochronous rhythms that are unlikely to be found in the natural world (cf. speech). How might such an oscillatory mechanism behave in a more probabilistic rhythmic environment? We designed a behavioral experiment to study how humans make predictions under these more ambiguous conditions. Participants listen to a train of tones drawn from gaussian distribution around perfect isochrony and report whether the final tone is early or late relative to their expectation. We found that the method for calculation of temporal expectation depends critically on the stimulus rate (from 1 Hz – 4 Hz). We compared our behavioral results with two models of temporal prediction at different levels of explanation: a Wilson-Cowan model of oscillatory behavior from a neural perspective and an ideal observer Bayesian model. Our analysis studies the potential (if any) for oscillatory behavior to be used as a mechanism for a rhythmic prior in the Bayesian sense even under uncertain rhythmic scenarios
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Emergent decision-making behaviour and rhythm generation in a computational model of the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus
Duncan MacGregor
 
Abstract
 
Neurons of the ventro-medial nucleus (VMN) of the hypothalamus play an essential role in energy homeostasis, possibly implementing decision making between different motivational states. Analysis of spike interval histograms of extracellular recordings of these cells identifies several distinct types based on firing pattern, including varied features such as doublets, long refractory periods, and oscillations in excitability, in particular a distinct 3Hz oscillation. We have been using integrate-and-fire based modelling in an attempt to determine whether these variations are more likely based on varied intrinsic electrophysiological properties, or may be a result of network interactions. Some cell types can be matched by single neuron models. The more complex types appear to require a network. A homogeneous network of random synaptically connected model neurons with long duration hyperpolarising after-potential (HAP), was able to reproduce some of the more complex cell types, including rhythm generating behaviour. Adding a depolarising afterpotential to the neurons, the network could also reproduce bistable behaviour that might underlie decision making mechanisms. However the homogeneous network could not match the oscillatory cells, which do not show the long HAP necessary to generate the rhythm. The solution was to use a network population of two distinct cell types, one with a short HAP and the other with a long HAP. The slow HAP cells synchronise to produce a 3Hz rhythm. This forms a network input signal to the fast HAP cells, producing firing that closely, and consistently, matches recorded oscillatory cells.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Head direction cells: the three-dimensional neuronal compass
Jean Laurens
 
Abstract
 
Here we show that head direction (HD) cells in mice encode a 3D neural compass. We recorded the responses of HD cells in the Anterior Thalamus, Cingulum fiber bundle and Retrosplenial Cortex of mice across the entire range of 3D head orientations. The 3D responses of HD cells can be decomposed into a 1D azimuth component that encodes head orientation in the horizontal plane, and a 2D pitch/roll component that encodes head orientation relative to vertical. The azimuth component is visually anchored, whereas the vertical component is anchored to gravity. Individual cells may encode azimuth, gravity or both; and the probability of encoding azimuth (~50%) and gravity (~66%) are independent. Furthermore, in those cells that encode both, the responses azimuth and gravity superimpose multiplicatively. We propose a conceptual framework of 3D orientation encoding in the HD system which is compatible with previous finding in bats, primates and rodents.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The gradient of population receptive field stimulus-dependence in ventral visual cortex
Garikoitz Lerma-Usabiaga
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Garikoitz Lerma-Usabiaga; Rosemary Le; Chen Gafni; Michal Ben-Shachar; Brian Wandell

Regions of ventral occipito-temporal (VOT) visual cortex are more responsive to written words than other categories of visual stimuli. We refer to these regions as the VOT reading circuitry (VOTRC). The population receptive field (pRF) of a voxel is the portion of the visual field in which stimuli evoke a response. The pRFs of voxels in the VOTRC are stimulus-dependent (Le et al., 2017). Measured with word stimuli, the pRF centers are mainly confined to the central visual field (with a clear contralateral bias); measured with checkerboard stimuli, the pRF centers span a wider range of locations, extending to the periphery. To understand this stimulus dependence, we analyzed pRFs in visual field-maps (V1-3, hV4, VO1) whose signals are the likely inputs to the VOTRC. We measured pRFs in 34 subjects (20 only English; 14 Hebrew/English) using the moving bar paradigm with several types of contrast patterns within the bar (checkerboards, English and Hebrew words of different sizes, false fonts). We found that stimulus dependence emerges gradually along the visual field map hierarchy. The stimulus dependence is small in visual areas V1 and V2, becoming more pronounced in V3, hV4, and VO-1. The pRF center can be expressed in Cartesian [x,y] or Polar [eccentricity,angle] coordinates. The largest variation in stimulus dependence is the eccentricity of the pRF center; the angle remains relatively constant. Given that the pRF position is stimulus dependent, it may be important to use the relevant stimulus when using pRFs to model the visual components of different tasks. With an interest in reading development, it seems best to use word stimuli in a legible orthography. Establishing pRF properties using such stimuli in good readers may help understand the visual reading circuitry and provide a baseline for comparing responses in poor readers.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Computational principles of motor adaptation
Barbara Feulner
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Barbara Feulner, Imperial College London; Matthew G. Perich, Mount Sinai; Lee E. Miller, Northwestern University; Raeed H. Chowdhury, University of Pittsburgh; Juan Álvaro Gallego, Imperial College London; Claudia Clopath, Imperial College London

Animals, including humans, have a remarkable ability to adapt movements to changing external conditions. Despite advances in understanding motor adaptation at the behavioural level, disentangling the underlying neural mechanisms remains challenging. Dorsal premotor (PMd) and primary motor (M1) cortex are the main cortical areas involved in movement planning and execution, and neural activity changes within these two areas are believed to underlie motor adaptation. However, it remains unknown whether changes in neural activity emerge due to synaptic changes within the motor cortices or through altered inputs to them. As there are currently no experimental methods to directly measure synaptic strength in vivo, answering this question must rely on indirect evidence from neural recordings, obtained through correlation or more sophisticated inference analyses. Yet, the extent to which synaptic changes can be detected with these measures remains unclear. We used a new approach to investigate the role of synaptic changes in PMd and M1 for motor adaptation. Instead of trying to infer weight changes from experimental data, lacking ground truth knowledge, we implemented a recurrent neural network architecture that solved motor adaptation tasks through changing its connectivity. This allowed us to 1) measure task-related connectivity changes, 2) compare ground truth weight changes to the results of common inference methods and 3) compare resulting activity changes to experimental data. Using this approach, we found that two commonly studied motor adaptation paradigms – force-field adaptation and visuo-motor rotation – require only small changes in network activity and underlying connectivity to counteract the perturbations. Furthermore, matching experimental observations, the correlation structure among network units was highly preserved, which is usually interpreted as stable synaptic connectivity. Thus, experimentally observed activity changes in PMd and M1 during motor adaptation could potentially arise from small, but effective, synaptic weight changes in PMd and M1.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Equilibrium Propagation for Complete Directed Neural Networks
Matilde Tristany Farinha
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Matilde Tristany Farinha, INESC-ID Dept. of Mathematics, IST, University of Lisbon, Portugal; Sérgio Pequito, Dept. of Industrial and Systems Engineering, RPI, Troy (NY), USA; Pedro A. Santos, INESC-ID Dept. of Mathematics, IST, University of Lisbon, Portugal; Mário A. T. Figueiredo, Instituto de Telecomunicações, IST, University of Lisbon, Portugal;

Artificial neural networks, one of the most successful approaches to supervised learning, were originally inspired by their biological counterparts. However, the most successful learning algorithm for artificial neural networks, backpropagation, is considered biologically implausible. We contribute to the topic of biologically plausible neuronal learning by building upon and extending the equilibrium propagation learning framework. Specifically, we introduce: a new neuronal dynamics and learning rule for arbitrary network architectures; a sparsity-inducing method able to prune irrelevant connections; a dynamical-systems characterization of the models, using Lyapunov theory.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Framework for Information Theoretical analysis of Electrophysiological data and Statistics (FRITES)
Etienne Combrisson
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Etienne Combrisson, Institut de Neurosciences de la Timone, UMR 7289, Aix Marseille Université, CNRS, 13385 Marseille, France; Michele Allegra, Institut de Neurosciences de la Timone, UMR 7289, Aix Marseille Université, CNRS, 13385 Marseille, France; Ruggero Basanisi, Institut de Neurosciences de la Timone, UMR 7289, Aix Marseille Université, CNRS, 13385 Marseille, France; Robin A.A Ince, Institute of Neuroscience and Psychology, University of Glasgow, Glasgow, UK; Bruno L. Giordano, Institut de Neurosciences de la Timone, UMR 7289, Aix Marseille Université, CNRS, 13385 Marseille, France; Andrea Brovelli, Institut de Neurosciences de la Timone, UMR 7289, Aix Marseille Université, CNRS, 13385 Marseille, France;

We present analysis pipelines that aim at characterising the dynamics of cortico-cortical interactions underlying cognitive brain networks. Our hierarchical Functional Connectivity (FC) approach is able to isolate first regions whose linear correlation and mutual information (i.e., the total interdependence between neural signals) increases transiently or statically in relation to task conditions, then parses the relative direction of this influence using covariance-based Granger causality methods. Covariance-based Granger causality measures are particularly suited, because they are computationally simple to estimate, provide an intuitive link between directed and undirected FC measures and can be used on short neural signals (e.g., single-trials) and large networks (e.g., hundreds of brain areas). The workflows are applied to human source-level high-gamma activity (HGA) estimated from MEG data (Brovelli et al, JNeurosci 2015; JNeurosci 2017). The workflows exploit an anatomical atlas named MarsAtlas (Auzias et al, Human Brain Mapp 2016), and provide single-trial and ROI-based estimates of HGA time courses. Statistical analysis searching for task-related modulations in FC and group-level inference is performed using gaussian copula mutual information approaches combined with cluster-based statistics and permutation tests. The end results are time-resolved and task-related information routing patterns characterising the dynamics of cognitive brain networks.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Transthyretin and Alzheimer’s disease: Systematic review
Arjumand Faruqi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Ahmad Ozair

Introduction:
Prealbumin or transthyretin (TTR), a protein, is found in various tissues, including the brain. [1]
Studies have found a conflicting role of TTR in Alzheimer’s Disease (AD). [1-3]
No systematic review, the highest quality of evidence, currently exists on this. Only narrative reviews exist.

Material and methods:
1. We conducted the systematic review as per the PRISMA checklist and flowchart
We conducted a search on PUBMED/ MEDLINE database on 15th June 2020.
2. We used the search function: ((transthyretin) OR (prealbumin)) AND (Alzheimer's disease)
3. We found 95 eligible studies after the three steps of screening.
Identification: Records identified through database searching (PUBMED) (n=346). Additional records identified through other sources (n=0). Duplicate Removal: Records after duplicates removed (n=346).
Screening:
Records screened (n = 346), Records excluded (n=184).
Full-text articles assessed for eligibility (n =162). Full-text articles excluded, with reasons (n=67).
Included- Studies included in qualitative synthesis (n=95).

Results:
Majority of studies find that TTR has an overall neuroprotective role in AD.
TTR has been found to clear Amyloid-beta (Aβ) peptide molecules and inhibit Aβ aggregation.
TTR is found to influence A-beta levels in a gender-specific manner, its action influenced by testosterone and estradiol.
There is enough evidence to suggest that TTR in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) comes from 3 sources: (1) synthesis by neurons, (2) synthesis by choroid plexus; and (3) serum TTR also diffuses into the CSF.
Studies done in CSF report that TTR levels in CSF are significantly decreased in AD.
In CSF of patients with AD, abundant oxidized iOS forms of TTR are detected.
Studies done in serum also find that TTR levels inversely correlate with disease progression. Serum TTR levels are found to be lowered in AD patients.
Serum levels of TTR have been found to be a good biomarker for AD for diagnostics.

Discussion:
We could not perform quantitative synthesis due to lack of large observational or interventional studies in clinical practice.
We only searched the PUBMED/MEDLINE database, and did not utilise SCOPUS or EMBASE.

References:
1. Pate KM, Murphy RM. Cerebrospinal Fluid Proteins as Regulators of Beta-amyloid Aggregation and Toxicity. Isr J Chem. 2017;57(7-8):602-612. doi:10.1002/ijch.201600078
2. P, Russo C. Human brain amyloidoses. Nephrol Dial Transplant. 1998;13 S7:33-40.
3. Chodobski A, Szmydynger-Chodobska J. Choroid plexus: target for polypeptides and site of their synthesis. Microsc Res Tech. 2001;52(1):65-82.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Differential effect of auditory and visual associative cues on perceptual inference
Zsófia Pálffy
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Bertalan Polner PhD, Department of Cognitive Science, Budapest University of Technology and Economics; Kinga Farkas MD PhD, Department of Psychiatry and Psychotherapy, Semmelweis University

Background: It is a widely held assumption that the brain performs perceptual inference by combining sensory information with prior expectations, all being weighted by their uncertainty. It has been shown that priors influencing perception of ambiguous stimuli can be manipulated with associative learning. Here, we investigate the differential effect of auditory vs. visual associative cues on visual motion perception and we also examine the reliability of individual differences.

Methods: Healthy individuals (N=29; 14 men, age[SD]=26.6[5.5]) performed a perceptual inference task twice with a one-week delay. They indicated the perceived direction of illusory motion of dot pairs (640 trials). A visuo-acoustic cue preceded the target stimulus and probabilistically predicted the direction of the motion. In 30% of the trials, motion direction was ambiguous, and in half of these trials, the auditory and the visual dimension of the cue predicted opposing directions. Cue-stimulus contingency could change every 40 trials.

Results: Responses were slower to ambiguous, relative to non-ambiguous stimuli. The impact of associative learning on perceptual decisions was evidenced by slower responses to less predictable, relative to more predictable non-ambiguous stimuli and by the increased rate of cue-congruent decisions on ambiguous trials. Importantly, when the visual and the auditory dimensions of the cue predicted conflicting directions of motion on ambiguous trials, participants made more decisions congruent with the prediction of the acoustic dimension. Furthermore, all the above effects had substantial inter-individual variability which showed high test-retest reliability (rs > 0.6).

Discussion: Overall, priors based on auditory information seem to have a stronger weight during the perception of illusory visual motion, although the data suggests large and stable differences in perceptual learning and/or decision making. Computational modelling combined with neuroimaging could allow testing hypotheses regarding the potential mechanisms causing these behavioral effects (e.g. characteristics of visual vs. auditory processing, attention and uncertainty).
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Learning compositional sequences with multiple time scales through a hierarchical network of spiking neurons
Amadeus Maes
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Mauricio Barahona;Claudia Clopath

Sequential behaviour is often compositional and organised across multiple time scales: a set of individual elements developing on short time scales (motifs) are combined to form longer functional sequences (syntax). Such organisation leads to a natural hierarchy that can be used advantageously for learning, since the motifs and the syntax can be acquired independently. Despite mounting experimental evidence for hierarchical structures in neuroscience, models for temporal learning based on neuronal networks have mostly focused on serial methods. Here, we introduce a network model of spiking neurons with a hierarchical organisation aimed at sequence learning on multiple time scales. Using biophysically motivated neuron dynamics and local plasticity rules, the model can learn motifs and syntax independently. Furthermore, the model can relearn sequences efficiently and store multiple sequences. Compared to serial learning, the hierarchical model displays faster learning, more flexible relearning, increased capacity, and higher robustness to perturbations. The hierarchical model redistributes the variability: it achieves high motif fidelity at the cost of higher variability in the between-motif timings.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Multi-modal representation of self-motion in the retrosplenial cortex
Sepiedeh Keshavarzi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Edward F Bracey, Sainsbury Wellcome Centre, UCL; Dario Campagner, Sainsbury Wellcome Centre, UCL; Adam L Tyson, Sainsbury Wellcome Centre, UCL; Stephen C Lenzi, Sainsbury Wellcome Centre, UCL; Tiago Branco, Sainsbury Wellcome Centre, UCL; Troy W Margrie, Sainsbury Wellcome Centre, UCL

Successful navigation depends on animals’ ability to reliably track their orientation and heading direction. The internal representation of such directional sense requires angular head velocity (AHV) information. However, despite numerous studies on head direction, place, and grid cells, little is known about the computations underlying AHV signalling, and in particular, how this is achieved in higher order cortical regions in the mammalian brain. Using high-density single-unit recordings, we describe the activity of AHV neurons in the retrosplenial cortex (RSP) of mice exploring a large arena, and in response to vestibular and visual motion stimuli under controlled head-fixed conditions. We find that many AHV neurons display similar tuning properties during active (freely moving) and passive motion (head-fixed rotations in yaw), and combine vestibular and visual inputs to increase the gain and signal-to-noise ratio of angular velocity coding during navigation. Further, using a novel go/no-go task and computational methods, we demonstrate that vestibular-visual combination increases the perceptual accuracy of own velocity, and the fidelity of its representation by RSP neuronal ensembles. These findings provide novel insights into cortical computations underlying representation of self-motion during navigation.

 Traditional talk
Watch now
Decoding visual colour from scalp electroencephalography measurements
Jasper Hajonides
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jasper Hajonides; Anna Christina Nobre; Freek van Ede; Mark Stokes

Recent advances have made it possible to decode various aspects of visually presented stimuli from patterns of scalp EEG measurements. As of recently, such multivariate methods have been commonly used to decode visual-spatial features such as location, orientation, or spatial frequency. In the current study, we show that it is also possible to track visual colour processing by using Linear Discriminant Analysis. Building on other recent demonstrations, we show that colour decoding: (1) reflects sensory qualities (as opposed to, for example, verbal labelling) with a prominent contribution from posterior electrodes contralateral to the stimulus, (2) conforms to a parametric coding space, (3) is influenced by luminance offsets but driven by chromaticity differences between stimuli (4) is possible in multi-item displays, and (5) is comparable in magnitude to the decoding of visual stimulus orientation. Through subsampling our data, we also provide an estimate of the approximate number of trials and participants required for robust decoding. Colour decoding opens a relevant new dimension in which to track visual processing using scalp EEG measurements, while bypassing potential confounds associated with decoding approaches that focus on spatial features.
Traditional talk
Watch now
The influence of target reward on motor planning and online motor decision
Antoine De Comite
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Frederic Crevecoeur, Université catholique de Louvain; Philippe Lefèvre, Université catholique de Louvain

The central nervous system uses sophisticated strategies to plan and execute upper limb reaching movements. Motor planning involves the selection of a goal amongst multiple options that is biased by factors such as the biomechanical cost or the expected gains of the potential movements. Likewise, motor execution is influenced by parameters such as reward, which invigorates reaching movements in a way that is coherent with robust optimal feedback control models. To date, the effect of costs and rewards on planning and control has been studied separately, and it remains unknown whether and how target selection may be influenced by reward following disturbances during ongoing actions. To address this question, we designed an experiment in which we sought to determine whether the distribution of rewards amongst three potential options (either all targets had the same reward or the lateral targets had smaller reward) had an influence on motor planning and execution in presence of unexpected mechanical perturbations. We observed a decrease of the online change in target goal when the lateral targets had smaller rewards, for all mechanical perturbation levels. Interestingly we observed, when all the targets had the same reward, a negative correlation between the EMG activity of muscles and the propensity to switch target online: higher activity correlated with smaller change propensity. In order to confirm this effect, we designed a similar second experiment in which a leftward background load was applied through some trials to pre-excite the muscles. Remarkably, we observed that the application of the leftward background load decreased the frequency of switch toward the leftward target at all perturbation levels. In all, our study revealed that multiple mechanisms underlie reward-dependent planning and control of movement: a robust control strategy that leverages gain-scaling and a more flexible control strategy that enables rapid and online target changes.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Using a Sparse RNN for dynamic binary classification
Denis Turcu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Larry Abbott, Zuckerman Mind Brain and Behavior Institute, Columbia Unicersity, New York, NY

Feedforward network models performing classification tasks rely on highly convergent output units that collect the information passed on by preceding layers. Although convergent output-unit like neurons may exist in some biological neural circuits, notably the cerebellum, neocortical circuits do not exhibit any obvious candidates for this role, instead they are highly recurrent. We investigated whether a sparsely connected recurrent network could perform classification in a distributed manner without ever bringing all of the relevant information to a single convergence unit (for an alternative approach see Kushnir, Fusi; 2018).

Our model is based on a sparse RNN that performs the classification dynamically. Specifically, the interconnections of the RNN are trained to resonantly amplify the magnitude of responses to some external inputs but not others. The amplified and non-amplified responses then form the basis for binary classification. In this arrangement, the minimum number of synapses per neuron required to reach maximum memory capacity scales only logarithmically with network size. Despite highly sparse connectivity, learned strong recurrent connections allow input information to flow to every neuron of the RNN, providing the basis for the distributed computation. Furthermore, training allows the model to act as an evidence accumulator. The accumulator robustly maintains its decision for significant periods of time after the input is turned off, although the undriven network stops accumulating information. We studied different training methods and found that back-propagation through time yields the best results. Our model is robust to various types of noise and works with different activation and loss functions, although certain of these are optimal. In addition, the RNN can be constructed with a split “excitation–inhibition” architecture with little reduction in performance.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Surprisingly little evidence for task- or belief-dependent signals in macaque V1
Richard Lange
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Camille Gomez-Laberge, Harvard Medical School; Ariana Sherdil, Harvard Medical School; Richard Born, Harvard Medical School; Ralf Haefner, University of Rochester

We set out to test two general predictions of how approximate Bayesian inference may manifest in sensory neural activity: that choice probabilities and noise correlations contain significant feedback components reflecting variability in posterior beliefs about a category. Specifically, a general prediction of optimal Bayesian learning and inference is excess choice-related variability in the direction of neural sensitivity, f’ (Lange & Haefner 2020). We trained two macaque monkeys to switch between two coarse orientation discrimination tasks while we recorded simultaneously from dozens of V1 units using planar 10x10 multi-electrode arrays. This is a rich dataset, including neural data recorded over the course of learning and while monkeys randomly switched discrimination tasks, cued at the start of each trial. Despite our original goal of extending previous experimental results on purported feedback both in choice probabilities and in noise correlations (Cohen & Newsome 2008, Nienborg & Cumming 2014, Rabinowitz et al 2015, Haefner et al 2016, Bondy et al 2018), we failed to find both main effects. Our experiment design and analysis pipeline include numerous stages designed to reduce possible confounds, such as the selection of neurons with diverse tuning properties, automatic outlier detection, spike detection designed to minimize spurious coincident spikes across channels, and regression methods that account for both pseudo-replication and measurement error. We were also able to recover post-mortem histology from these animals and thus assign each electrode on the array to a cortical layer. Our results on choice probabilities are consistent with Jasper et al (2019), who similarly used electrode arrays in V1. We invite further discussion of possible methodological or theoretical failures both on our part and on the part of earlier studies. Alternatively, we may conclude that choice-related signals in V1 are weaker or contain different structure than previously thought.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Energy landscape analysis of EEG of Alzheimer’s patients reveals alterations of state transitions dynamics
Dominik Klepl (He/his)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Fei He, Coventry University

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is one of the most common neurodegenerative diseases with around 30 million patients worldwide. Accessible and non-invasive methods of diagnosing and characterising AD are therefore desirable. Electroencephalography (EEG) fulfils these criteria and is often used when studying AD. Several features derived from EEG were shown to be able to predict AD with high accuracies, e.g. signal complexity and synchronisation. However, the dynamics of how the brain transitions between stable states have not been properly studied in case of AD and EEG data. Energy landscape analysis is a method that can be used to quantify these dynamics. This work presents the first application of this method to both AD and EEG. Energy landscape assigns energy value to each possible state, i.e. pattern of activations. The energy is inversely proportional to probability of occurrence. Therefore, high energy states have low probability of occurrence. Studying the features of energy landscapes of 20 AD patients and their healthy age-matched counterparts, significant differences were found. The dynamics of AD patients’ EEG were showed to oscillate between more stable states. Moreover, the pathways used for transitions between stable states in AD patients were found to be longer. Finally, we show that features derived from energy landscapes can potentially be used for predicting AD with high accuracy. The results reported in this work suggest that brains of AD patients adapt to the damage and death of neurons by finding novel albeit suboptimal pathways for transitioning between stable states.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Flexibility and Predictions in Autism: Findings from EEG, behavior, and machine learning classification
Seydanur Tikir
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Seydanur Tikir, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, United States of America; Michael J. Crosse, X, the Moonshot Factory, Mountain View, CA, United States of America; Dylan Festa, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, United States of America; Jonathan Vacher, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, United States of America; Ruben Coen-Cagli, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, United States of America; Sophie Molholm, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY, United States of America;

In stable and predictable environments, the brain generates expectations with high confidence, whereas in unstable environments, this confidence is lowered. Thus, the brain not only makes predictions, but also assigns an expected error rate based on environmental statistics. Individuals with autism resist even trivial changes in everyday life, which is a major phenotype of autism. We hypothesize that their ability to flexibly tune the confidence of their predictions based on changes in the stimulus statistics is impaired. To assess the use of environmental statistics in updating predictions, adults with (N=21) and without (N=20) autism performed a task in which they responded to the completion of a pattern of three sequentially presented shapes. Across blocks of ~120 pattern initiations, the probability of pattern completion varied between 100%, 86%, 66%, and 33%. The ability to infer a change in the probability of pattern completion was assessed with reaction time and high-density electroencephalography (EEG), with a particular focus on CNV and P300 components in the analyses of evoked brain potentials. The modulation of P300 and CNV as a function of stimulus probability was significantly diminished in the autism group. Further, a linear classifier trained to discriminate between individuals with autism and controls based on average brain responses to target trials (at all electrodes and time points) revealed successful classification (~80% accuracy) when all probability conditions are given as input. We also presented a passive auditory oddball paradigm in which the probability of deviant tones was 4%, 8%, or 16% in different blocks. Preliminary analyses of the mismatch negativity (MMN) component suggest that the brain is able to preattentively calculate stimulus statistics in autism. Taken together, these data might indicate that the specific problem with predictive processing in autism is not in registering environmental statistics, but in applying the statistics to making predictions.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Preferential transmission via cortical resonance
Chris Lewis
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Chris Lewis, University of Zurich; Jianguang Ni, Ernst Strüngmann Institute; Thomas Wunderle, Ernst Strüngmann Institute; Patrick Jendritza, Ernst Strüngmann Institute; Andreea Lazar, Ernst Strüngmann Institute; Ilka Diester, Ernst Strüngmann Institute; Pascal Fries, Ernst Strüngmann Institute

Synchronization has been implicated in neuronal communication, but causal evidence remains indirect. We used optogenetics to emulate synaptic inputs to cat visual cortex and measured spike output. Channelrhodopsin 2 generated currents through the somato-dendritic membranes of excitatory neurons under precise temporal control. Constant excitation was transformed into strong synchronization in the gamma-band, revealing the well-known cortical resonance. Ramp stimulation demonstrated that the resonant frequency varied (30-60 Hz) with excitatory input strength, and Gaussian excitation exhibited hysteresis of power and frequency. Crucially, white-noise sequences enabled a causal analysis of network transmission, establishing preferential transmission of input components that are coherent to the resonance. Models composed of recurrently coupled excitatory and inhibitory units uncovered a crucial role of feedback inhibition and suggest that hysteresis can arise from the non-inactivating M-current. The presented approach provides a means to investigate resonance properties of local circuits and how these properties transform input and shape transmission.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Sensory versus culturally shaped expectations in the neural processing of music
David R. Quiroga-Martinez
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Marina Kliuchko, Technical University of Denmark; Niels Chr. Hansen, Aarhus Institute of Advanced Studies & Center for Music in the Brain, Aarhus University, Denmark; Andreas Højlund, Center for Functionally Integrative Neuroscience, Aarhus University, Denmark; Marcus Pearce, School of Electronic Engineering and Computer Science, Queen Mary University of London, UK; Elvira Brattico, Center for Music in the Brain, Aarhus University; Peter Vuust, Center for Music in the Brain, Aarhus University

When listening to music, we constantly attempt to predict the sounds that will follow. For example, quite often we end up humming, singing along or tapping our foot to the beat, and find pleasure in listening to pieces we know very well. However, the nature and brain basis of musical predictions or expectations remain poorly understood. Concretely, we do not know the extent to which these expectations arise from adaptation to the sensory properties of sounds or from a more cognitive and culturally shaped learning of the statistics of musical pieces and styles. In this presentation, I will address this issue by showing MEG data and modeling work in which the neural correlates of melodic expectations are investigated. I will show comparisons between the performance of a cognitive model of music statistical learning (IDyOM) and simpler metrics of acoustic similarity between tones (e.g. pitch distance, cosine similarity) in predicting neural responses to sounds. For this, an encoding model based on regularized linear regression was used. Preliminary results show that, across listening conditions, datasets and types of listeners, acoustic similarity models outperform cognitive models, thus suggesting a prominent role of sensory expectations in shaping neural responses to musical sounds. Potential neuronal mechanisms will be discussed, as well as the relationship of our findings with behavioral studies suggesting a preponderance of cognitive over sensory expectations during music listening.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Inductive Biases of Neural Population Codes
Blake Bordelon
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Cengiz Pehlevan, Harvard University

The ability to learn a pattern from a small number of examples is a central component of intelligence. Understanding how and why the brain can learn in such a sample efficient manner remains an open problem for neuroscience and artificial intelligence. In this work, we study how the structure of neural population codes influences the number of sampled stimuli required to learn an accurate linear readout. We find that sample efficient learning requires a population level inductive bias determined by the structure of the inner-product kernel, which measures the similarity of neural responses to two different input stimuli. We demonstrate that the eigendecomposition of the kernel provides information about the strength of the inductive bias as well as the compatibility of the population code with certain tasks. In a model of online learning, trial to trial variability (neural noise) can either facilitate or prevent rapid learning depending on the geometry of responses. We apply our theory of generalization to experimental population responses of mouse V1 neurons, showing how they have a good inductive bias for low frequency orientation discrimination tasks but do not possess an appropriate inductive bias to efficiently discriminate semantic categories of objects from linear readout.
Interactive talk
Watch now
The Effect of Task on Object Processing revealed by EEG decoding
Ken Yip
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Leo Y.T. Cheung, The Chinese University of Hong Kong; Vince S.H. Ngan, The Chinese University of Hong Kong; Yetta Kwailing Wong, The Chinese University of Hong Kong; Alan C.-N. Wong, The Chinese University of Hong Kong

At which phase(s) does task demand affect object processing? Previous studies showed that task demand affects object representations in higher-level visual areas but not so much in earlier areas. There are, however, limitations in those studies concerning the relatively weak manipulation of task due to the use of familiar real-life objects, and/or the low temporal resolution in brain activation measures such as fMRI. In the current study, observers categorized images of artificial objects in one of two orthogonal dimensions, shape and texture. Electroencephalogram (EEG), a technique with higher temporal resolution, and multivariate pattern analysis (MVPA) were employed to reveal object processing across time under different task demands. Results showed that object processing along the task-relevant dimension was enhanced starting from a relatively late time (~230ms after image onset), within the time range of the event-related potential (ERP) components N170 and N250. The findings are consistent with the view that task exerts an effect on object processing at the later phases of processing in the ventral visual pathway.


 Traditional talk
Watch now
Dendritic Activity in Area CA3 of the Mouse Hippocampus
Jason Moore
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jason Moore, New York University Langone Medical Center; Maya Hopkins, New York University Langone Medical Center; Shannon Rashid, New York University Langone Medical Center; Jayeeta Basu, New York University Langone Medical Center

Hippocampal “place cells” are tuned to locations in an environment, much as sensory cortices encode features of their respective modalities. Hippocampal cells also exhibit the phenomenon of remapping, in which a cell codes for different positions in different environments, or different positions in the same environment, when task demands change. Remapping occurs on fast timescales, so typical plasticity mechanisms cannot completely explain this behavior.
Recent studies implicate dendritic spikes in predicting the formation of stable place fields. However, due to technical and analytical limitations, in vivo studies of hippocampal dendritic activity have largely been confined to basal or proximal apical dendrites. To address these issues, our lab has developed an experimental paradigm in which the basal dendrites, cell bodies, and apical dendrites of pyramidal neurons in area CA3 are imaged in the same focal plane. We imaged calcium activity, reported by GCaMP6f or GCaMP7b, simultaneously in pyramidal cell bodies and dendrites while head-fixed mice ran for water rewards on a treadmill track.
To interpret this data, we developed an automated algorithm to identify dendritic and somatic regions of interest (ROIs) from the calcium signal. The algorithm matches manually-labeled datasets and identifies many more dendritic segments than a human expert. The algorithm is easily applied to detecting ROIs from various interneuron populations as well as axonal data, and runs faster than real-time on a standard desktop computer, with very few free parameters to tune.
When we analyzed the compartment-specific tuning of neurons, we discovered an interesting feature that the dendrites of a neuron may be tuned to completely different locations than their sister dendrites or their parent soma. Furthermore, the internal routing of information, - which dendrites are highly correlated with the soma, - was often changed during remapping. These results suggest that dendrites may enable a neuron to hold multiple pieces of information, and a subset of that information is routed to the soma, perhaps in a context-dependent manner.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Effects of Anti-Hebbian learning on the synchronization and structure of directed networks with pure and hybrid inhibitory and excitatory couplings
Abolfazl Ziaeemehr
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Abolfazl Ziaeemehr, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences; Mir Mohammad Ebrahimi, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences; Mina Zarei, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences

The interplay between structure and dynamics of the complex networks has been vigorously investigated in recent years. It has been shown that directed acyclic graphs are optimal structures for the synchronization of identical oscillators. However, feedback loops are required for noise-resistant synchronization of non-identical oscillators. On the other hand, the interaction structures of many real networks vary over time according to their dynamics. Here we employ a rewiring strategy based on an anti-Hebbian learning rule to modulate the structure of directed networks of Kuramoto oscillators. The results show that the anti-Hebbian learning rule leads to the global synchronization of the networks. Indeed, information flow is created from the nodes with average frequencies to the nodes with low or high frequencies in the emerged optimal structure, where the nodes with average frequencies are engaged only in the feed-forward loops, but the nodes with low and high frequencies are mostly joined together with the feedback loops. Similar results were also found in the Hybrid Excitatory-Inhibitory networks of oscillators. In the previous studies, the balance between neural excitation and inhibition has been shown to be crucial for brain computations. Here, we found that excitatory and inhibitory in-degrees of each oscillator are approximately balanced in the evolved network.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Enhancing classification of autism spectrum disorder using resting-state fMRI with machine learning approach and dimensionlity reduction
Anis Zahedifard
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Seyedeh Parisa Dajkhosh,Amirkabir University of Technology, Mehrnaz Hosseinzadeh, Fasa University of Medical Sciences,Yousef Ghanbari,University of Tehran

Autism spectrum disorder is a condition related to brain development that impacts how a person perceives and socializes with others. Early diagnosis of autism disorder involves in-depth behavioral observation and testing, which can be time consuming, expensive, and affected by clinician diagnostic bias. Early diagnosis of ASD using non-behavioral measurements can lead to improved outcomes for children with ASD. We developed algorithms to classify ASD based on publicly available brain-imaging datasets (ABIDE), including brain scans from people with and without ASD diagnosis. Using a multilayer perceptron neural network, we classified preprocessed data from 200 regions of interest (atlas of craddock 200) into binary categories of ASD positive or negative. To overcome overfitting of the training dataset, we used a novel approach to determine the most relevant subset of the preprocessed data. This led to a significant increase in our held-out testing accuracy. Our results indicate that brain imaging data alone, without any behavioral assessments, can be used to classify ASD diagnosis using dimensionality reduction and machine learning techniques. This has the potential to improve early diagnosis of ASD.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
EDEN: A high-usability, high-performance, general-purpose neural simulator
Sotirios Panagiotou
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Harry Sidiropoulos, Erasmus University Medical Center; George Smaragdos, Erasmus University Medical Center; Mario Negrello, Erasmus University Medical Center; Dimitrios Soudris, National Technical University of Athens; Christos Strydis, Erasmus University Medical Center

In-silico neuroscience is an important tool to define the conceptual models of neural networks, to deeply explore the emerging features of these models, and to guide subsequent in-vitro and in-vivo experiments.
We present EDEN, a novel neural simulator that can run all types of neural network models in the NeuroML v2.0 specification, and drastically reduces the required simulation time.
There is no model-specific programming required to run the models.
EDEN also performs full validation of the NeuroML models in use, and explains the causes of possible errors.
The simulator setup is integrated with the Python and Docker infrastructure. This way, EDEN can be effortlessly deployed on interactive Python notebooks, for a single person or a whole class.
Simulations are automatically further sped up with multi-core execution within a single PC, or throughout HPC clusters.
This way, even larger and more detailed models can be investigated in a practical timeframe.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Investigating memory accuracy and diversity of generative replay in a predictive coding neural network
Yihe Lu (Yee-Hur)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Tamás Földes, Cardiff University; Penelope Lewis, Cardiff University

Human memory replay is crucial for memory consolidation and knowledge integration. Similarly, replay can be deployed in an artificial neural network (ANN) to overcome the catastrophic forgetting problem in continual learning. For decades, experience replay (ER) has been applied; an ANN revisits exact old episodes whenever learning a new one. However, ER is not biologically plausible, because it requires an external memory storage with an increasing capacity to stock all old episodes (Kali and Dayan, 2004, Nat. Neurosci.). More recently, generative replay (GR) has been proposed for ANNs capable of predictive coding (PC). When such an ANN learns a new episode, it is simultaneously trained with self-generated samples. Despite the efficiency and the biological plausibility of GR, we were concerned about its effectiveness and robustness, and we investigated the quality of GR in restricted Boltzmann machines (RBMs), typically trained by contrastive divergence, a PC-like algorithm. We found the replay quality poor in terms of both accuracy and diversity. The individual replays were unidentifiable as any learned episodes by basic similarity measurements. Assorting them by Bayesian classifiers, we found stronger memories were replayed more frequently than weaker ones. Surprisingly, we still managed to replicate the success of an RBM’s continual learning by GR (Mocanu et al., 2016, ArXiv). Our results agree with the claim by van de Ven et al. (2020, Nat. Commun.) that replays with low quality is good enough for preserving past memory traces. We further considered a scenario of GR with relatively small numbers of replays. We found that an RBM could not guarantee all past memories to be replayed even once when learning a new episode, which tended to cause catastrophic forgetting of weaker memories. We argue that the amount of replay is a major constraint of the memory capacity for an ANN in continual learning.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Autoantibodies in Traumatic Brain Injury : An update
Oumaima Outani
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Oumaima Outani

Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is the most recognized subtype of injury that affects the central nervous system (CNS). TBI is a leading cause of death and morbidity worldwide.
An important area of TBI research is the TBI-induced cascade of inflammatory and pathophysiological events and the resulting autoantibodies especially that literature have confirmed its role as a precursor in many neuropsychiatric disorders such as chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), Alzheimer’s disease (AD), Parkinson’s disease (PD) and Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
These autoantibodies could have a prospective role as potential biomarkers indicating the corresponding pathophysiological mechanisms following the injury.
Putative biomarkers that have been documented in experimental TBI and then in patients post-TBI
cover many processes including injury to neuronal cell bodies, demyelination, astro-glial injury, and axonal injury . Some of these identified markers include Protein (S100B), Glia Calcium-Binding, Myelin Basic Protein (MBP), and neurofilament proteins.
However, translating from experimental applicability to bedside clinical practice remains challenging. It is also essential to mention that therapeutic interventions modulatin B cells could be of therapeutic potential.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Distinct higher-order representations of natural sounds in human and ferret auditory cortex
Agnès Landemard
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Célian Bimbard, UCL Institute of Ophthalmology ; Charlie Demené, Physics For Medecine; Shihab Shamma, Laboratoire des Systèmes Perceptifs; Sam Norman-Haigneré, Zuckerman Institute for Mind Brain Behavior ; Yves Boubenec, Laboratoire des Systèmes Perceptifs

Little is known about how neural representations of natural sounds differ across species. For example, speech and music play a unique role in human hearing, yet it is unclear how their cortical representations differ between humans and other animals. In a previous study, we found that humans showed selectivity for natural vs. spectrotemporally-matched synthetic speech and music in non-primary regions, that both cannot be explained by lower-level modulation statistics, and do not yet reflect explicit semantic knowledge. Here, we addressed the question of whether such higher-order selectivity is present in other species.
