Precisely, we measured cortical responses in ferrets to the same set of natural and synthetic sounds previously tested in humans, as well as natural and synthetic ferret vocalizations, using functional Ultrasound imaging, a newly developed wide-field imaging technique. We found that tuning for spectrotemporal modulations present in both natural and synthetic sounds was similar between humans and ferrets, and could be quantitatively predicted across species, consistent with prior findings. But unlike humans, ferret responses to natural and synthetic sounds were similar throughout primary and non-primary auditory cortex even when comparing natural and synthetic ferret vocalizations; and the small differences that were present in ferrets were weak and spatially scattered. This finding reveals that auditory representations in humans and ferrets diverge sharply at late stages of cortical processing, potentially driven by higher-order processing demands in speech and music.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Learning orthogonalizes visual cortical population codes
Samuel W. Failor
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Samuel W. Failor, University College London; Matteo Carandini, University College London; Kenneth D. Harris, University College London

A body of work argues that learning results in an increased representation of behaviorally relevant stimuli in cortex; however, understanding how learning changes population codes requires simultaneously recording large neural populations. To clarify the effects of learning in primary visual cortex (V1), we recorded from thousands of neurons in V1 in response to passive drifting gratings before and after training on a novel orientation comparison task.

In the task, two gratings were presented simultaneously, each one of three orientations (45°, 68°, and 90°). Mice were rewarded for choosing 45° or rejecting 90°. Thus, 45° and 90° informed what action the mouse should take while 68° was a distractor.

Task training affected orientation tuning curves in unexpected ways: a reduction in the number of neurons preferring the informative orientations (45° and 90°), asymmetric tuning curves, and suppression of responses to both informative orientations, most notably for weakly tuned neurons.

These multifarious effects on tuning curves could be explained by a simple principle: sparsening of the population for informative orientations. This increase in population sparseness orthogonalized the population codes for informative stimuli to each other and to all other orientations (i.e., increased the angle between the population rate vectors).

To elucidate the possible biological mechanism underlying these learning effects, we developed a simple computational model, in which a top-down “importance signal” modulated neuronal F-I curves. This model, which does not necessitate Hebbian-like plasticity, could successfully recapitulate the myriad impacts of learning on single-cell tuning curves by increasing population sparseness through F-I curve modulation.

Our results show that learning sparsifies the representation of informative task stimuli in the brain, orthogonalizes their population codes, and may improve their differentiation by downstream regions of the brain.

 Interactive talk
Watch now
What is the potential of decoding?: A time course comparison between ERP and machine learning classification analyses
Ryan O'Donnell
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Brad Wyble, Pennsylvania State University

Neural decoding is a popular method in cognitive research. With decoding, neural data from individual trials or batches are categorized by a statistical classifier (e.g. support vector machines, SVM, or deep neural networks). However, neural decoding analyses stand in contrast to traditional event related potential (ERP) analyses, which average EEG data across same-condition trials to enhance voltage signals related to a particular experimental manipulation. This study set out to assess the differences in the timecourse of voltage signals obtained via task-based ERP versus the information gain obtained via item-based neural decoding analyses. To do so, participants completed two target identification tasks (targets could be a face or body) under different visual presentations (Single vs RSVP presentation), which have previously been shown to elicit latency differences in target-related ERP components like the P3 (Craston, Wyble & Bowman, 2006). Recorded data was analyzed using conventional ERP techniques as well as machine learning classification techniques (in this case, a linear SVM trained to classify face from body trials within presentation format). The two analyses provided different conclusions about the influences of presentation format on cognitive processes, with ERP replicating the previously observed differences in P3 amplitudes and latencies whereas machine learning demonstrated no substantial differences in classification accuracy or latency between formats. Overall, these results highlight the importance of comparing ERP and decoding analysis techniques in EEG. If decoding is driven by the voltage signals present in ERPs, one might have assumed that differences in ERP latencies would be reflected in the temporal profile of classification. However, this was not true. The failure to find a clear correspondence between condition differences in the timecourse of ERPs and decoding profiles suggests that classifiers are finding statistical regularities in target-related scalp voltages that are not scaling with traditional task-based ERPs measures.
Traditional talk
Watch now
The role of Kv2 and Nav1.6 in Adaptive Firing in Place Fields within the CA1 region of the Hippocampus: A Computational and Experimental Approach
Carol Upchurch
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Crescent Combe, Department of Neuroscience, Christopher Knowlton, Department of Cell Biology and Anatomy, Sonia Gasparini, Department of Neuroscience, Carmen Canavier, Department of Cell Biology and Anatomy

Objective: The hippocampus is an area of the brain important in learning and spatial navigation. Within the hippocampal CA1 region, some pyramidal cells function as place cells, firing preferentially when an animal is in an area of its environment, its place field. As an animal enters its place field, the sensory input creates a bump in excitatory synaptic input, that decreases as an animal leaves the place field. We simulate this as a triangular current ramp applied to the soma or proximal dendrites (~200 μm from the soma). In a familiar place field, CA1 pyramidal cells fire more on the up ramp than down ramp, even though the ramp is symmetric. This phenomenon, adaptation, is more pronounced in the dendrites. Spike height also significantly decreases in the dendrites. Slow inactivation of the voltage gated sodium channel increases with distance from the soma along the apical dendrite. Our objective is to model this inactivation as a possible mechanism behind adaptation and decrease in spike height in the dendrites.

Methods: We inserted a five state Markov model of Nav1.6 into an existing multicompartmental model implemented in NEURON. We calibrated this model to fit the time, voltage and spatial dependencies of slow inactivation according to the literature and data from our experimental collaborators. We later updated this model with the addition of the voltage gated potassium channel Kv2.

Results: After inserting the Markov model into the existing multicompartmental model, our simulation results included doublets that were inconsistent with our experimental results, until the addition of Kv2. In line with this prediction, blocking Kv2 produced doublets in our experimental ramps. With the addition of Kv2 and the Nav1.6 Markov model, the model successfully simulates adaptive firing, which is more pronounced in the dendrites, and decreased spike height in the dendrites.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Biological learning of local motion detectors
Tiberiu Tesileanu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Alexander Genkin, NYU; Dmitri Chklovskii, Flatiron Institute

Motion detectors in the brain are typically localized, using correlations between light intensities at nearby locations in combination with a small temporal delay. If motion is global, however, in the sense that the same transformation is applied uniformly across the entire field of view, locations arbitrarily far apart can in principle be used for motion detection. One explanation for why this does not happen in the brain is that it would require long-distance connections that would be prohibitively expensive. Here we suggest that, in fact, a normative model that posits that the brain is adapted to natural visual statistics is sufficient to lead to localized interactions, even without considering the costs of long-range connections. Our model further provides a biologically plausible mechanism that can be used to learn the connectivity pattern for local motion detectors. We adapt a method initially designed for learning infinitesimal generators for global motion, and show that, when the training data contains localized patterns and/or localized motion, the learned generators naturally cluster into groups involving small sets of nearby pixels. Our proposed learning algorithm is based on non-negative similarity matching, a normative approach that allows us to use an objective function to derive a biologically plausible circuit that solves the task.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Mapping the building blocks of face processing in individuals with and without autism using microstate analysis
Rianne Haartsen
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Luke Mason, Birkbeck University of London United Kingdom; Pilar Garces, Roche Pharma Research and Early Development Basel Switzerland; Anna Gui, Birkbeck University of London United Kingdom; Tony Charman, King’s College London United Kingdom & South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation United Kingdom; Mark H. Johnson, Birkbeck University of London & University of Cambridge United Kingdom; Emily J.H. Jones, Birkbeck University of London United Kingdom; the EU-AIMS LEAP team

Face processing undergoes significant changes during early development. Difficulties in facial processing and variability in neural processing of faces are common in individuals with autism across development. It remains unknown whether this individual variability in face processing between individuals with and without autism is better explained by qualitative differences in the involvement of different neural processing pathways or by quantitative differences in the neural processing of similar neural pathways.
In this study, we investigated spatial and temporal characteristics of face processing using electroencephalography in children with and without autism (N’s = 53 and 40), adolescents with and without autism (N’s = 79 and 68), and adults with and without autism (N’s = 90 and 74) from the Longitudinal European Autism Project. We applied multi-channel data-driven analyses to the event-related responses to upright and inverted faces (modulating configural face processing) and tested for qualitative differences in scalp topography with topographic analyses of variance and for quantitative differences in strength of these topographies with global field power comparisons. Next, we extracted distinct spatiotemporal microstates to examine neural timings for responses to faces for the different orientations and diagnostic groups.
The neurotypical groups displayed distinct temporal and topographic profiles with different strengths for the upright and inverted faces. Topography and strength of the scalp profiles showed subtle differences between individuals with and without autism in the adolescents, but not in the children and adults. The microstate approach revealed quantitative differences between diagnostic groups during the early temporal stages of face processing, and qualitative differences between diagnostic groups during the later temporal stages of face processing across all age groups.
Our findings demonstrate the importance of multi-channel spatiotemporal analytic approaches in investigating neural responses in neurodevelopmental disorders. Alterations emerging at early stages of development in autism may result in compensatory processes later in development.
Traditional talk
Watch now
A system-theoretic approach to synaptic scaling
Saeed Aljaberi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Saeed Aljaberi, Adriano Bellotti, Fulvio Forni, Timothy O’Leary (University of Cambridge)

A closed-loop biophysical model of synaptic scaling is proposed and analyzed using tools from control theory:
- We show that the system is stable and converges to a unique parameter-dependent equilibrium, which means that the neuron’s averaged activity is regulated to the desired level (homeostasis).
- We also show the system is robust to parametric uncertainties, such as trafficking rates, degradation, and neurite size or length. This is done using classical feedback control approaches based on transfer functions and Nyquist stability criterion.
- We discuss the modeling of synaptic scaling, developing a comparison between coarse and fine models. We use the $H_{\infty}$ norm to capture the worst case error between the two models. Our findings show that the coarse model provides a good fit and captures the qualitative behavior of the complex fine model.
Based on these findings, we map complex topologies of real morphologies to coarse/reduced models and we show how to use these reduced models to predict the behavior of real neuronal morphologies without the need of computationally expensive simulations.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
A computational examination of the two-streams hypothesis: which pathway needs a longer memory?
Abolfazl Alipour
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
John Beggs, Indiana University Bloomington; Joshua Brown, Indiana University Bloomington; Thomas James, Brown Indiana University Bloomington;

The two visual streams hypothesis is a robust framework that has inspired many studies in the past three decades. One of the well-studied claims of this hypothesis is the idea that the dorsal visual pathway is involved in visually guided motor behavior, and it is operating with a short memory. Conversely, this hypothesis claims that the ventral visual pathway is involved in object classification, and it works using a long-term memory. In this study, we tested these claims by training identical recurrent neural networks to either perform viewpoint-invariant object classification (a task attributed to dorsal stream) or orientation classification (a task attributed to dorsal stream) and measured how much they rely on their memory in each task. Using a modified leaky-integrator echo state recurrent network, we found that object classification requires a longer memory compared to orientation classification. However, when we used long-short-term memory (LSTM) networks, we observed that object classification requires longer memory only in larger datasets. Accordingly, our results suggest that having a longer memory is advantageous in performing ventral stream’s tasks more than their dorsal counterparts, as was originally suggested by the two-streams hypothesis.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Cognitive Impairment and Rehabilitation in Alzheimer’s Disease
Dorothy Martha Scordilis
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Theodoros Angelopoulos, Dorothy Martha Scordilis, Christos Tsagkaris

A wealth of evidence emphasizes on the link between Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and cognitive impairment (CI). CI is generally accepted as a decline in memory, learning capacity, concentration, or decision-making, leading to functional impairment. The role of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) as a predictive factor of AD and the CI linked to the establishment and progression of AD have been discussed in the context of epidemiology, genetics, pathophysiology, pathology, and clinical practice. AD-associated CI has been also addressed as a source of socioeconomic burden urging for the development of therapeutic interventions. Cognitive rehabilitation (CR) is a complementary non-pharmaceutical treatment for AD consisting of cognitive stimulation and training methods. Based on the neuronal plasticity concept, CR aims at increasing AD patients’ functional status and retarding their mental decline. Although the method has encouraging results in several studies, there is still controversy as far as its efficacy is concerned and further research ought to be conducted before incorporating CR in AD’s treatment plan globally. CR drawbacks should be addressed and counteracted in this context, while the current CR approach may be ameliorated through errorless learning techniques.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Sensory thalamus, speech, and predictive coding
Katharina von Kriegstein
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Glad Mihai, TU Dresden; Stefan Kiebel, TU Dresden; Robert Trampel, MPI-CBS Leipzig; Alejandro Tabas, TU Dresden

The auditory (medial geniculate body, MGB) and visual (lateral geniculate nucleus, LGN) thalami are key structures of sensory processing in the human brain. Several studies in humans indicate that task-related modulation of MGB and LGN is critical for auditory and visual speech recognition and is reduced in developmental dyslexia. These findings might be explained in a predictive coding framework, where predictions generated in cerebral cortex are used to optimise the processing of auditory and visual speech in sensory thalami. However, to date it is unclear whether responses in sensory thalami and other subcortical sensory pathway nuclei can be explained by predictive coding or habituation to stimulus statistics. In a novel study, we used ultra-high resolution functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) at 7 Tesla to adjudicate between these two possibilities in the human subcortical auditory pathway. To elicit prediction error, we introduced frequency variations in pure tone sequences and abstract rules that manipulated the predictability of the tones orthogonally to the stimulus statistics. Our results show that predictability entailed in abstract rules drive mesoscopic responses to tones in the medial geniculate bodies and the inferior colliculi of the human auditory pathway. The results provide first unambiguous evidence of predictive coding in a subcortical sensory pathway – a mechanism that might be used during auditory and visual speech recognition.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Stable representational similarity despite drifting population activity in a network model of noisy representation learning
Shanshan Qin
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Shanshan Qin, Harvard University; Cengiz Pehlevan, Harvard University

Stable neural representations are generally associated with robust behavior and physiological functions. However, recent experiments have shown that neural population codes in many brain areas continuously change even when the animals have learned and stably perform their tasks. This representational ``drift'' naturally leads to questions about its causes, dynamics and functions. To address these questions, we consider a basic and biologically-plausible model of representation learning, the Hebbian/anti-Hebbian network, and hypothesize that drifting representation is due to noisy synaptic updates and turnover. We find that while the receptive fields of individual neurons change significantly over time, representational similarity of population codes is stable over time, providing a substrate for robust downstream readout by a Hebbian neuron. We investigate the dynamics of the drift, and find that the drift speed can be quantified by a rotational diffusion constant, which is determined by the learning rate, noise level and upstream input statistics. Our model accounts for many of the recent observed experimental observations in hippocampus and cortices related to sensorimotor tasks.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
P3 component differences between conditions and fluid intelligence effect in 3-stimuli Oddball task
Ingrida Antonova
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Patrycja Dzianok, Nencki Institute of Experimental Biology of Polish Academy of Science; Jakub Wojciechowski, Bioimaging Research Center, World Hearing Center of Institute of Physiology and Pathology of Hearing; Jacek Rogala, Nencki Institute of Experimental Biology of Polish Academy of Science; Joanna Dreszer, Centre for Modern Interdisciplinary Technologies Nicolaus Copernicus University; Ewa Kublik, Nencki Institute of Experimental Biology of Polish Academy of Science 1

Oddball task is one of the most popular tasks to study cognitive processing.
In this study, we aimed to investigate spatio-temporal dynamics of stimulus processing using three-stimuli visual Oddball task. We were interested, if target activates any additional networks / stages of information processing or all steps are the same but differ in temporal dynamics.
We recruited 41 healthy participants and registered high-density 128 active channels EEG. ERP-microstate analysis was applied in order to investigate spatio-temporal dynamics of information processing.
ERP-microstate analysis revealed that both deviant and target stimuli recruited an additional process which was not present in standard condition. This process was represented by later P3-associated microstate with more central positivity. In contrast, the earlier P3-microstate with more parietal positivity was common between three conditions. Although steps of information processing were similar between deviant and target conditions but conditions differed significantly in temporal dynamics of P3-associated later microstate: it had significantly longer duration and higher amplitude for target compared to deviant stimulus.
Moreover, when we divided our participants into three groups based on their fluid intelligence scores: Low, Medium, High, microstate analysis revealed significant group effect. We observed that the group with lowest scores had significantly higher amplitude of earlier P3-microstate compared to groups with higher scores.
To conclude, earlier P3 component represents a common information processing stage for all conditions while the later P3 component represents additional cognitive processes crucial for target discrimination from a distractor. Interestingly, the common P3 component differentiated group of subjects with lowest fluid intelligence scores from the two groups with higher scores possibly indicating that subjects with lower scores had to apply more effort to perform the task.
[Supported by National Science Centre, Poland, grant UMO-2016/20/W/NZ4/00354]
 Traditional talk
Watch now
A multi-modal fitting procedure to construct biophysically detailed multicompartment neuronal models
Alessio Buccino
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Alessio Paolo Buccino, ETH Zurich; Tanguy Damart, Blue Brain Project, EPFL; Darshan Mandge, Blue Brain Project, EPFL; Werner Van Geit, Blue Brain Project, EPFL; Henry Markram, Blue Brain Project, EPFL; Andreas Hierlemann, ETH Zurich;

In computational neuroscience, multicompartment models are among the biophysically most realistic representations of single neurons.
Constructing such models usually involves the use of the patch-clamp technique to record somatic voltage signals under different experimental conditions. The experimental data are then used to fit the many parameters of the model. While patching of the soma is the gold-standard approach to build multicompartment models, several studies have also evidenced a richness of dynamics in dendritic and axonal sections. Recording from the soma alone makes it hard to observe and correctly parameterize the activity of non-somatic compartments.

In order to provide a richer set of data as input to multicompartment models, we investigate here the combination of somatic patch-clamp recordings with recordings of high-density microelectrode arrays (HD-MEAs). HD-MEAs enable to observe extracellular potentials and neural activity at subcellular resolution. We hypothesize that HD-MEAs may provide a valid alternative to conducting multiple simultaneous patch recordings.

To test this hypothesis, we built ground-truth samples from an available L5b cell model (Hay 2011), which was developed with multiple patch recordings (one somatic patch and two patches on the apical dendrites), and which is capable of reproducing properties of active dendrites. To do so, we extended the BluePyOpt software to use LFPy to simulate intra- and extracellular signals. We extracted features from both, simulated somatic voltage traces and extracellular action potentials. The extracted features were used to find an optimal set of parameters using a genetic algorithm approach.

In this in-silico study, we show that using a combination of patch-clamp and extracellular features allows for finding a much better fit of the dendritic parameters than the use of somatic features alone. This multimodal fitting strategy potentially yields a set of better constrained and more accurate multicompartment models.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Synchronization of adaptive networks of Sakaguchi-Kuramoto oscillators
Mina Zarei
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Erfan Deris, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences; Mina Zarei, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences; Nahid Azimi, Institute for Advanced Studies in Basic Sciences;

Sakaguchi-Kuramoto model is a generalization of the well-known Kuramoto model including a phase-lag or frustration parameter. In this work we study the structure and synchronization dynamics of adaptive networks of Sakaguchi-Kuramoto oscillators based on Hebbian and anti-Hebbian learning rules. We show that following anti-Hebbian learning the structure of network is gradually evolved such that the global synchronization is enhanced. On the other hand, Hebbian learning leads to the local synchronization and clustering structure of the network. Moreover, in the presence of frustration the connectivity patterns of the oscillators changes asymmetrically with respect to the mean frequency of the oscillators. In other words, the connectivity patterns of the oscillators with high and low natural frequencies would be different in the evolved networks. Previous studies have also shown that oscillators on the human connectome follow a hierarchy of timescales, i.e. highly connected regions have low natural frequencies and peripheral regions have high natural frequencies. In addition, we found that the value of the frustration parameter affects the size and the number of the clusters in the networks that are evolved based on the Hebbian learning rule.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Global Brain Volume is Associated with General Psychopathology in Children
Leighton Durham (she/her/hers)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
E. Leighton Durham, Vanderbilt University; Hee Jung Jeong, Vanderbilt University; Tyler M. Moore, University of Pennsylvania; Randolph M. Dupont, Vanderbilt University; Carlos Cardenas-Iniguez, University of Chicago; Zaixu Cui, University of Pennsylvania; Farrah E. Stone, Vanderbilt University; Marc G. Berman, University of Chicago; Benjamin B. Lahey, University of Chicago; Antonia N. Kaczkurkin, Vanderbilt University

Childhood is important for the onset of psychopathology and for brain development. Psychopathology is characterized by considerable comorbidity, which is mirrored in its underlying neural correlates. Both common and dissociable variations in brain volume have been found across multiple mental disorders in adult and youth samples. However, the majority of related research has used samples with broad age ranges, which may obscure developmental differences. The present study examined associations between regional gray matter volumes (GMV) and dimensional psychopathology in a large sample (N = 9,608) of children (9-10 years) collected as part of the Adolescent Brain and Cognitive Development (ABCD) Study. A bifactor model identified four dimensions of psychopathology: a general factor, which reflects common variance across disorders, as well as three subfactors measuring specific internalizing, conduct, and ADHD symptoms. Brain volume was acquired using 3T MRI. Results from SEM analyses demonstrate nearly global inverse associations between regional GMVs and the general psychopathology and conduct factors, with significant associations for the ADHD factor as well (p-values ≤ .048, FDR-corrected). Sensitivity analyses including total GMV and intracranial volume as covariates further support this global effect, as region-specific results became non-significant, with the exception of the bilateral hippocampus. Sensitivity analyses controlling for income, parent’s level of education, and medication use as additional covariates yielded largely convergent results. Together, these results suggest that smaller brain volume is a common risk factor for psychopathology across disorders, and possibly for conduct and ADHD symptoms in particular.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
A convolutional neural-network model of the human inner-hair-cell and auditory-nerve-fiber complex
Fotios Drakopoulos
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Deepak Baby, Ghent University, Sarah Verhulst, Ghent University

Analytical descriptions of inner-hair-cell (IHC) and auditory-nerve-fiber (ANF) processing have evolved
over the years, with IHC transduction models shifting from simplified low-pass filters to detailed
conductance models which include basolateral outward K+ currents. State-of-the-art models of the IHC-
ANF synapse complex describe the vibrations of the IHC stereocilia based on the mechanical drive to the
IHC and model ANF spikes or instantaneous firing rates as resulting from the depletion and
replenishment of different neurotransmitter stores. While such sensory models have progressed to
accurately capture the nonlinear and dynamic properties of the neuronal processes associated with
hearing, they typically comprise mechanistic descriptions and coupled sets of ordinary differential
equations, rendering these models slow to compute.
Here, we present a hybrid computational neuroscience - deep neural network (DNN) framework which
simulates auditory IHC-ANF processing, to offer a fast and differentiable model which can be used in
large-scale neuronal network models. Based on a state-of-the-art biophysical model of the auditory
periphery (including human cochlear mechanics, IHC and ANF processing), we trained several
convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures to learn the computations performed by the IHC-ANF
complex (CoNNear IHC-ANF ). We determined the hyperparameters in these architectures (different layers,
filter lengths, input and context windows, activation functions) on the basis of well-known single-unit
IHC and ANF properties derived from experimental neuroscience studies. The model was trained using
an acoustic speech corpus, and its performance evaluated using basic acoustic stimuli which were not
included in the training set.
The final CoNNear IHC-ANF model offers a 70-fold speed-up factor on a CPU and a 280-fold factor on a GPU
when compared to the analytical IHC-ANF model processing computations. When connected to a DNN-
based cochlear model, preferably CoNNear cochlea , population responses (e.g. CAP, ABR wave-I) can be
simulated across a large number of cochlear tonotopic locations, and be used for backpropagation
purposes. Our auditory periphery framework can be applied for the development of large-scale neural-
network circuits aimed to advance our knowledge of unknown neuronal systems such as the brainstem
and subcortical pathways, or the human auditory cortex.

Work supported by European Research Council ERC-StG-678120 (RobSpear)
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Towards a computational model of sleep-dependent memory consolidation for associative memories
Tamas Foldes
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Yihe Lu, Penny Lewis

Recent reviews suggest complex picture underlying the sleep-dependent memory consolidation effect across many associative memory tasks, finding strong task-dependency and variability in study design thus limiting overall generalizability (Lerner & Gluck, 2019). Whilst there are multiple theories proposed to explain sleeps role in forming optimal schemas and there are many computational models related to memory consolidation (Rennó-Costa, da Silva, Blanco, & Ribeiro, 2019) there appears to be a gap between the two approaches in their target areas of interest and explanatory scope; most models being too complex or too abstract to guide human sleep and memory research. In addition, there is a lack of testable computational accounts addressing sleeps role in forming predictive codes (Hinton et al, 1995; Hobson & Friston, 2012) in behaviourally well studied tasks.

We propose an abstract, neurally-plausible connectionist model of sleep-dependent memory processing of hippocampal generalization to show that offline generative replay provides sufficient conditions for the sleep effect to emerge in indirect association tasks (Ketz, Morkonda & O’Reilly, 2013; Kumaran & McClelland, 2012; Ellenbogen, 2007). We argue that autoencoders provide an ideal framework to study retrieval-based inferential mechanism as well as long-term memory generalization related to sleep-dependent memory consolidation and inform a predictive coding account of the sleep effect.

Neural, cogntive and cultural foundations of navigaiton ability
Hugo Spiers
 
Abstract
 
Some people are very good at navigating, others find it a significant challenge. What determines whether someone will succeed or fail to navigate successfully? This talk will briefly explore what might make someone a good navigator looking at demographics, cultural background and brain structure and function. Data from the mobile app video game Sea Hero Quest project will be presented revealing world-wide patterns in navigation ability of 3.9 million people and the potential for tracking subtle cognitive markers for Alzheimer’s disease.

Alternative splicing choices for synaptic strength
Andrea Gomez

Better together: Let’s improve the culture in neuroscience
 
Abstract
 
Neuroscience is a wonderful field, full of excitement, mutual support, and learning from one another. However, the interactions we are having do not always feel positive. People are being bullied, some exploit their privilege, some are being talked down as stereotypes are used. This session is to hear from a number of people how it sometimes does not feel good. And which changes we should make as a field to neuroscience (starting with NMC) move forward productively while being whole more inclusive, positive, and fun.

- Yiota Poirazi, PhD (Institute of Molecular Biology and Biotechnology of the Foundation for Research and Technology Hellas)

Watch now
Sensitivity versus criterion mechanisms underlying the attentional blink
Swagata Halder
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Dr.Sridharan Devarajan, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore

Attention enables us to select behaviorally relevant, stimuli for enhanced sensory processing and decision-making. We investigate neural mechanisms of the “attentional blink”: the impaired ability to select the second (T2) of two targets, when it occurs within close temporal proximity (200-500 ms) of the first (T1).

Does attentional blink affect the selection of T2 for enhanced sensory processing (sensitivity, d’), for decision-making (criterion, c) or both? Specifically, does it affect d’ and c associated with detecting T2, with discriminating its features, or both? We addressed all of these questions using a single, novel psychophysical task with concomitant EEG (electroencephalography) recordings in 23 human participants.

Two target stimuli (Gabor gratings) embedded in a stream of plaid distractors appeared in a 10-Hz rapid serial visual presentation (RSVP) paradigm. On each trial, subjects discriminated the orientation of a T1 stimulus (cardinal/diagonal) with a 2-AFC (two-alternative forced-choice) response. They also indicated the presence, as well as the orientation of a T2 stimulus with a 3-AFC response (clockwise/counterclockwise of vertical, or absent). We developed a novel, multidimensional signal detection model to analyze subjects’ multialternative behavioral choices; the model quantified d’ and c for both detection and discrimination of T2 stimuli.

Significant reductions in both detection and discrimination d’ parameters were observed during the blink. On the other hand, the blink produced virtually no effect on either detection or discrimination criteria. Event-related potentials, including the visual P2 over occipital electrodes and P3b over parietal electrodes modulated in amplitude in a manner that closely resembled detection d’ changes.

Our study introduces a novel task and framework to investigate behavioral and neural mechanisms underlying the attentional blink, and suggests that selection deficits associated with attentional blink may reflect d’ rather than criterion mechanisms.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Striatal D1 collaterals to the GPe act as a second direct pathway to regulate motor coordination
Marie Labouesse
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Marie A. Labouesse, Columbia University; Joseph Villarin, Columbia University; Arturo Torres, Columbia University; Xiaoiao Sun, Columbia University; Fernanda de Carvalho, Columbia University; Sherry Lam, NIH/NIDA; Jordi Bonaventura, NIH/NIDA, Michael Michaelides, NIH/NIDA; Savio Chan, Northwestern University; Ofer Yizhar, Weizmann Institute of Science; Christoph Kellendonk, Columbia University

In the classical model of the basal ganglia two segregated and functionally opposing pathways arise from the striatum to regulate motor control. Direct pathway striatal projection neurons (dSPNs) expressing dopamine D1 receptors (D1R) project monosynaptically to the substantia nigra (SNr) to promote movement while indirect pathway SPNs (iSPNs) expressing D2R project monosynaptically to the globus pallidus externus (GPe) to oppose movement. Recent functional studies, however, reveal that during native movements both pathways are activated. Moreover, anatomical and physiological studies have put into question the organization of the basal ganglia. For instance, we and others have shown that a large fraction of dSPNs possess axon collaterals within the GPe. These “bridging” collaterals are plastic in the adult animal and regulated by D2Rs and neuronal activity. These findings, though indirect, suggested an important role of dSPN bridging collaterals in regulating the balance of the direct and indirect pathway and motor function. Here, we used a combination of genetic targeting, calcium in vivo imaging, dSPN terminal-specific manipulations and behavioral tracking (DeepLabCut) to determine the role of dSPN bridging collaterals in motor function. We found that dSPN bridging collaterals were activated during specific movements in the rotarod. dSPN terminal inhibition also decreased locomotion and impaired rotarod performance. Recent physiology work shows that dSPNs preferentially target the non-canonical, striatal-backprojecting, arkypallidal Npas1 neurons in the GPe. We here found that stimulation of dSPNs inhibited Npas1 neurons in awake behaving mice. Finally, we found that Npas1 stimulation recapitulated the effects of dSPN inhibition by decreasing locomotion and rotarod function. We propose a model by which dSPN bridging collaterals support movement via inhibition of Npas1 neurons in the GPe. Thus, direct pathway GPe terminals act in concert with the canonical terminals in the SNr by inhibiting a potential stop signal going back to the striatum.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
BrainGlobe: a Python ecosystem for computational (neuro)anatomy
Luigi Petrucco
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Federico Claudi; Adam L. Tyson; Tiago Branco; Troy W. Margrie; Ruben Portugues

Neuroscientists routinely perform experiments aimed at recording or manipulating neural activity, uncovering physiological processes underlying brain function or elucidating aspects of brain anatomy. Understanding how the brain generates behaviour ultimately depends on merging the results of these experiments into a unified picture of brain anatomy and function. We present BrainGlobe, a new initiative aimed at developing common Python tools for computational neuroanatomy, and its core package, the BrainGlobe atlas API (BG-AtlasAPI).
While digital high-resolution 3d atlases have been produced for several model organisms, the effective use of these atlases depends on the availability of an application programming interface (API) that enables researchers to develop software to access and query atlas data. Some atlases come with an API, but these are generally specific for individual atlases, and this hinders the development and adoption of open-source neuroanatomy software. BG-AtlasAPI overcomes this problem by providing a minimal Python interface to download and interact with atlases for the most common model organisms in systems neuroscience. BG-AtlasAPI is a small and extensible package that allows developers to develop software agnostic to the atlas and species, increasing adoption and interoperability of packages in neuroscience.
Finally, we showcase the usage of BG-AtlasAPI in other Python projects (for cell detection, atlas registration and visualisation) developed within the BrainGlobe ecosystem, to illustrate how it provides easy interoperability and support for brain atlases from different species.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Autonomic Dysfunction in Parkinson’s Disease: An Application of Machine Learning for Clinical Diagnosis
Ajay Peddada
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Olivier Darbin, University of South Alabama

Background: Parkinson’s Disease (PD) is a progressive neurological disorder characterized by cardinal motor symptoms including tremor, rigidity, and slowness of movement. Today, diagnosis relies on the presence of motor symptoms when predominant lesions have already occurred peripherally and centrally. However, nonmotor symptoms such as autonomic dysfunction appear prior to motor symptoms and have the potential to serve as biomarkers for prodromal PD. The goal of the current study is to assess autonomic dysfunction as a possible biomarker in patients with Parkinson’s Disease.

Methods: We measured subjective autonomic symptoms as well as heart rate variability and blood pressure in patients with PD and healthy subjects. The clinical data was analyzed to discriminate between the parkinsonian and healthy state using a suite of machine learning algorithms. The relative importance of different biomarkers was extracted to determine which features of autonomic dysfunction are most predictive of PD.

Results: Machine learning algorithms attained high accuracy (F1 > 0.80) in classifying between PD and control subjects. Nonlinear features of heart rate variability were the most important features, including Approximate Entropy and the Hurst Exponent. Statistical analysis confirmed significantly lower levels of entropy in patients with PD. PCA achieved lower accuracy (76%) in comparison to the machine learning ensemble. PCA showed that Hurst Exponent and High Frequency spectral power were positively correlated with the parkinsonian state, while Median Instantaneous Frequency and Entropy were negatively correlated with the parkinsonian state.

Conclusions: Machine learning analysis revealed that autonomic dysfunction was highly predictive of PD. The high-ranking performance of nonlinear features suggests that autonomic control is more complex than antagonistic interactions between sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems. Additionally, the effective performance of nonlinear features suggests their utility as biomarkers for early stage PD.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Remembering what happened when: Emergence and stability of context-specific hippocampal sequences encoding odors and time
Jiannis Taxidis
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jiannis Taxidis, UCLA; Peyman Golshani, UCLA

How does the brain keep track of events we need to remember as well as the intervals between them? A recent model of hippocampal function posits that hippocampal networks generate spiking sequences to encode important sensory stimuli (external world) and place or time between them (internal representations) forming memory maps of spatiotemporally related experiences. But does it use one or multiple encoding strategies to combine external and internal representations? Do sensory and time representations share the same stability adaptability or learning-dynamics? Using two-photon calcium imaging in vivo in CA1 of head-fixed mice, we tracked the activity of thousands of cells across days, while mice learned and performed an olfactory delayed non-match-to-sample task requiring working memory. We observed ‘odor-cells’, encoding specific olfactory stimuli, followed by ‘time-cells’ encoding delay timepoints after a specific odor. Despite forming continuous spiking sequences, the two neuronal groups exhibited strikingly different properties. Odor-cells retained stable fields when the delay or odor presentation was extended as well as across days, whereas time fields were highly unstable and readily remapped in both cases. During learning, the number of odor-cells remained fixed while time-cells increased as performance improved. This increase was learning-related since it did not occur in naïve mice passively exposed to the same task trials. Finally, cells did not spike randomly before they acquired their field or after they lost it. A cell’s activity progressively converged to its field and then diverged from it over days. Odor-cells acquired a stable field earlier and for longer than time-cells. Therefore, the hippocampus can generate and sustain both stable representations of external cues as well as flexible temporal-codes with distinct learning-dynamics. This crucial combination of stability and flexibility allows hippocampal circuits to link fixed elements of the external world despite their changing temporal relationships, to construct memory-maps of related experiences.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) increases social behaviour and bursting activity in medial prefrontal cortex neurons.
Athanasios Markopoulos (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Dr. Antonio Inserra, McGill University; Dr. Danilo De Gregorio, McGill University; Prof. Gabriella Gobbi, McGill University.

Social behaviour (SB) encompasses a plethora of complex interactions among individuals. The medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) exerts a pivotal role in the modulation of SB in mammals since mPFC dysregulation has been demonstrated to be involved in the pathogenesis of impaired SB phenotypes. In the past 15 years, psychedelic drugs have been investigated as potential therapeutics in psychiatry. Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) in humans has been shown, in clinical settings, to produce feelings of happiness, trust, closeness to others, and enhanced emotional empathy. Despite these positive results, the ability of LSD to modulate SB has not been investigated, and the neuronal mechanisms underlying LSD's behavioural effects remain elusive. Here, we dissected the ability of acute and repeated LSD to exert prosocial effects and to modulate neuronal activity of the mPFC in mice. We found that repeated (30ug/kg per day, for 7 days), but not acute LSD treatment significantly increased the time spent interacting with an intruder mouse in the Direct Social Interaction Test. Similarly, repeated LSD treatment increased sociability and the preference for social novelty in mice subjected to the Three-Chambers Sociability Test. These behavioural results are paralleled with our electrophysiological findings. Using in-vivo extracellular single-unit recordings, we found that acute LSD treatment had no significant effect on the spontaneous firing nor the bursting activity of mPFC neurons, but repeated LSD treatment significantly increased the bursting activity of these neurons. Ultimately, our results demonstrate the ability of LSD to produce pro-social effects that are coupled with an increase in mPFC neuronal bursting activity.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Temporal dynamics of neuronal responses in human visual cortex
Iris Groen
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Giovanni Piantoni, University Medical Center Utrecht; Stephanie Montenegro, New York University School of Medicine; Adeen Flinker, New York University School of Medicine; Sasha Devore, New York University School of Medicine; Orrin Devinsky, New York University School of Medicine; Werner Doyle, New York University School of Medicine; Nick Ramsey, University Medical Center Utrecht; Natalia Petridou, University Medical Center Utrecht; Jonathan Winawer, New York University

Cortical responses to visual stimuli exhibit complex temporal dynamics, including sub-additive temporal summation, adaptation, and slower dynamics for suboptimal stimuli. Multiple computational models have been proposed to account for these dynamics in several measurement domains, including single-cell recordings, psychophysics, and fMRI. It is challenging to compare these models because of differences in model form, test stimuli, and instrument. Here we present a new dataset that is well-suited to compare neural models of temporal dynamics. The dataset is from electrocorticographic (ECoG) recordings of human visual cortex, which measures cortical population responses with high spatial and temporal precision. The stimuli were large, static contrast patterns that varied systematically in contrast and duration for single-pulse trials, and in inter-stimulus interval (ISI) for paired-pulse trials. Time-varying broadband responses were computed using the power envelope of the band-pass filtered voltage time course (50-170 Hz) recorded from 126 electrodes in total across eleven epilepsy patients, covering earlier (V1-V3) and higher-order (LO, TO, IPS) retinotopic maps. In all visual regions, the ECoG broadband responses show several non-linear features: peak response amplitude saturates with high contrast and long stimulus durations; response latency decreases with increasing contrast; and the response to a second stimulus is suppressed for short ISIs and recovers for longer ISIs. These non-linear response features were well predicted by a model consisting of a small set of canonical neuronal operations: linear filtering, rectification, exponentiation, and delayed normalization. These results demonstrate that a simple computational model captures a wide range of temporal and contrast-dependent neuronal dynamics at millisecond resolution. Finally, we present a software repository that implements models of temporal dynamics in a modular fashion, enabling the comparison of many models fit to the same ECoG data and analyzed with the same methods.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Travel Direction as a Fundamental Component of Human Navigation
You (Lilian) Cheng (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sam Ling, Boston University; Chantal Stern, Boston University; Andrew Huang, University of California, Santa Barbara; Elizabeth Chrastil, University of California, Irvine

In daily life, one’s travel direction is typically correlated with head direction, but from first principles, these two factors can offer different spatial information. Although head direction has been found to be a crucial part of human navigation, it is unclear whether travel direction plays a primary role in navigation. To test this, we adopted a visual motion adaptation paradigm, which allowed probes for selectivity of travel direction. To do so, we first adapted people to visual self-motion in one direction in a virtual hallway, and then tested people during a series of visual back and forth movements, toward and away, from the initial travel direction. In both phases, the head direction was reversed occasionally to be dissociated from the travel direction, precluding optic flow from contributing to any observed adaptation effects. We then asked subjects to report their net travel direction, measuring psychometric functions for perceived travel direction, under conditions of adaptation and no-adaptation. We found high-level motion aftereffects of travel direction, suggesting that travel direction is a fundamental component of human navigation. Interestingly, subjects had a higher frequency of reporting net travel toward the adapted direction, indicating that the aftereffect is opposite to the traditional motion aftereffect. The same aftereffect was found after controlling for response biases. We propose that the travel direction system is composed of separate sensory inputs and feed-forward high-level motion processing pathways, which may overlap or interact with the head direction system.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Efficacy of pyruvate and tempol treatment in traumatic brain injury rat model
Alexandra Latyshkova (she, her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Anton Malkov, Institute of Theoretical and Experimental Biophysics

Efficacy of pyruvate and tempol treatment in traumatic brain injury rat model

Patients with traumatic brain injury are at risk of developing hyperexcitability. Our study is aimed at exploring new ways to mitigate the effects of the brain damage. The results show that pyruvate and tempol application can alleviate the symptoms in rat models.
To evaluate the influence of the treatment we measured local field potential in the CA1 region of the hippocampus in rats exposed to brain injury and performed a set of behavioural tests.
Pyruvate and tempol administered orally during the first days after the injury are shown to significantly reduce neurological malfunctions and slightly lessen sensory-motor impairment. Tempol also improves exploratory behaviour and lowers the level of anxiety in rats with injury.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Is attention modulating alpha oscillatory activity focally for task-related locations or globally also to task-irrelevant locations?
Mattia Pietrelli (he/him/his)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Pietrelli, M., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison; Samaha, J., University of California, Santa Cruz; Postle, BR., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison

Research on endogenous attention suggests that spatial and temporal expectations influence the processing of visual stimuli in part by hijacking ongoing alpha-band oscillatory activity in brain areas involved in visual perception. However, it is not known if this top-down modulation of alpha is selective for the circuits that represent the focus of spatial attention, or if it is also deployed for the active control of processing at non-target locations. To answer this question, we manipulated spatial and temporal predictability during a Posner-style visual discrimination task, in which, within a block, stimuli could only appear in two of the four cardinal locations (i.e., only left-right target locations during some blocks, only top-bottom targets during others). This allowed us to distinguish “ignored” locations (i.e., not cued on a particular trial) from “irrelevant” ones (never cued during a particular block). We used inverted encoding modelling to generate topographic filters to isolate the alpha oscillatory activity associated with each of the four target locations. Behavioral results showed an influence of spatial expectations on both discrimination performance and eye-movement patterns, with hints of a weaker influence of temporal expectations. In addition to the standard pattern of “alpha desynchronization” at the locus of attention, the EEG results revealed no difference in the effects of spatial or temporal expectations on the alpha-band dynamics associated with ignored versus irrelevant locations. These results do not find evidence that alpha-band dynamics are differently controlled for ignored versus irrelevant locations, but instead suggest that they reflect a more global phenomenon that covers all representations of visual space outside the focus of attention.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Optogenetic activation of the inhibitory nigro-collicular pathway evokes paradoxical contralateral orienting movement in mice.
Claudio Villalobos Dintrans
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Michelle Basso, Department of Psychiatry and Biobehavioral Sciences, David Geffen School of Medicine, UCLA

The current model for controlling movement initiation proposes that the basal ganglia (BG) plays a permissive role in the generation of movements through the modulation of the amount of inhibition on BG target structures such as the superior colliculus (SC), a key structure involved in orienting control. One of the outputs of the BG, the substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr), contains GABAergic neurons that primarily project to the ipsilateral SC. The current model suggests that the removal of SNr inhibition, combined with excitatory drive from the cerebral cortex to the SC, produces contralateral orienting movements. This model of action is often referred to as the rate model, where the rate of inhibitory spiking of the SNr onto target structures is what determines the initiation of movement; high rates and inhibition results in no movement, while low rates and less inhibition produces movement. We tested this hypothesis by controlling the rate of SNr activity into the SC using optogenetics. Contrary to the model predictions, optogenetic activation of the SNr terminals into the SC of mice evoked, rather than prevented, contralateral movement. To determine how orienting movements may result from the activation of inhibitory terminals, we performed a series of slice experiments and found that the same optogenetic stimulation that evoked contralateral movements in vivo evoked post-inhibitory rebound depolarization and spiking in the SC output neurons. Only high frequency stimulation evoked contralateral movements in vivo and triggered rebound spiking in vitro. The latency of orienting movements relative to the pulse stimulation in vivo was comparable to the latency of rebound spiking in vitro. These results challenge the current dogma regarding the role of the nigro-collicular pathway in the initiation of orienting movements and may provide new understanding on the progression and pathophysiology of movement disorders associated with the function of the BG.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Automatic model descriptions in a neural network simulator
Marcel Stimberg (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Vigneswaran C, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai

Computational neuroscience simulations are often written as scripts that make use of a neural simulator package. The details of a model implemented in such a script might not be obvious to a reader not familiar with the simulator. When a researcher presents such a model in a publication, they will therefore rather describe it with text and equations. Creating such a description, however, is error-prone, since it is up to the researcher to make sure that it accurately presents the simulated model. We therefore propose that it would be very useful if the simulator itself could generate a model description automatically. Here we present a prototype of such a system for the Brian simulator. It is built on the same framework that powers Brian's code generation process and is therefore guaranteed to give results that are consistent with the actual simulation. The new model description framework provides a basic exporter that generates a machine-readable representation which abstracts away all the details of Brian's internal representations and takes care of more subtle issues such as the meaning of referred constants and the order of variable assignments. This exporter is meant to be used as a base for other types of exporters. As a proof of concept, we show an export to the Markdown format, providing a human-readable description of a model. Such a description can be useful to exchange with other researchers that are not familiar with the Brian simulator, as a basis for a model description shared as part of a publication or website, or simply as a means for debugging a model. Finally, we discuss the limitations of such descriptions and the possibility of annotating it with additional semantic information derived from the model.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Dopamine and excessive behaviours: impulse control disorders in Parkinson disease
Ignacio Obeso Martin
 
Abstract
 
Dopamine mediates a wide range of reward processes and when dysfunctional, excessive behaviours may be encountered. Under dopaminergic treatments, Parkinson´s disease (PD) patients may develop impulse control disorders (ICDs) resulting in excessive behaviours towards appetitive items, hence representing an optimal human model to study addiction. The wide spectrum of excessive approach tendencies towards appetitive options include primary and secondary rewards such as binge eating, hypersexuality, pathological gambling or compulsive shopping. In addition, the neurocognitive profile of ICD is marked by preference of immediate gratification and lack of adaptation to negative outcomes paralleled by enhanced signalling of the mesocortical valuation system. To date, the precise behavioural and neural changes involved in ICD are unclear. More precisely, is unclear whether ICD is a deficit of impulsive choice or impulsive actions that cannot override excessive desire of appetitive items. Here, evidence will be presented to put forward the field on one specific ICD (i.e. hypersexuality) in choice behaviour and action impulsivity (using fMRI and computational modelling). Ultimately, preliminary findings may support a transfer towards clinical consequences that will impact ICD with neuromodulation techniques. Our findings give rise to a new neurocognitive and imaging profile on one ICD subtype to open new research avenues and bridge our findings into clinical contexts.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Parallel pathways of odor processing in the lateral entorhinal cortex
Sebastian Bitzenhofer
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Sebastian H. Bitzenhofer, Center for Neural Circuits and Behavior, Department of Neuroscience, School of Medicine, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, California, USA; Jeffry S. Isaacson, Center for Neural Circuits and Behavior, Department of Neuroscience, School of Medicine, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, California, USA

Layer II principal cells in lateral entorhinal cortex (LEC) receive olfactory sensory input from the olfactory bulb and piriform cortex and relay this information to the hippocampus. Distinct types of layer II cells direct information via two parallel pathways: fan cells send direct projections to the dentate gyrus and pyramidal cells project to CA1. However, little is known about the role of the LEC in the processing of odor information. Here we use acute optogenetic silencing in head-fixed mice performing two-alternative-forced-choice (2AFC) tasks to show that the LEC is necessary for rapid (<300 ms of odor inhalation) discrimination of odor identity and intensity. Consistent with these rapid behavioral responses, simultaneous silicon probe recordings in the awake state from the LEC and hippocampus reveal that virtually all olfactory-evoked activity occurs in a brief time window coupled to odor inhalation. Using brain slice recordings, we show that direct input from the olfactory bulb preferentially targets LEC fan cells, whereas input from the piriform cortex equally targets fan and pyramidal cells. This results in faster onset of odor evoked activity and more selective responses in fan cells, as well as better odor discrimination at the population level.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Socializing reduces distress-associated behavior in mice
Saba Shokat Fadaei (She, Her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Haohan Wei, New York University ; Ayo Adewakun, New York University ; Robert C. Froemke , New York University School of Medicine ; Jhimmy Talbot, New York University; Dan Littman, New York University

Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) induced neuroinflammation is a shared symptom for most neurodegenerative diseases. One of the harmful outcomes of presence of LPS in the brain is the cognitive impairment which is a result of a downstream inflammatory responses that had been initiated in the gut.
In animal models these cognitive impairments include lethargy, arched or curled body posture, inactivity, and reduced consumption. Socialization in animals is positively correlated with physical and mental, learning, and reduced mortality. The main goal of this study is to investigate if socialization through co-housing has a direct therapeutic effect on LPS induced neuroinflammation.
We utilized an LPS-induced endotoxemia model for our experiments. A total of 24 mice C57/BL6 mice were divided into two groups: socially isolated mice or co-housed mice.
Continuous seventy-two hours recording sessions were performed and videos were analyzed and scored. We found that co-housing mice not only reduced the recovery time but also decreased the duration of exhibition of the sickness behavior. Analysis showed that the single-housed mice displays sickness behavior, including extended hunched posture, for about thirty-five minutes following the LPS injection, while the co-house mice only spent twelve minutes displaying sickness behavior. In addition, there was a significant weigh loss in the LPS injected mice. Motion tracking analysis revealed that socially isolated LPS injected mice remained stationary for hours compared to co-housed mice.
In conclusion, our findings show that co-housing mice post endotoxemia endotoxemia demonstrate therapeutic which could be further exploited for translational studies.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Accumulation of Salient Perceptual Events Predicts Human Subjective Time
Maxine Sherman (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Zafeirios Fountas, Wellcome Centre for Human Neuroimaging, University College London, London, UK; Anil K. Seth, Sackler Centre for Consciousness Science, University of Sussex, UK; Warrick Roseboom, Sackler Centre for Consciousness Science, University of Sussex, UK

Human experience of time exhibits systematic, context-dependent deviations from objective clock time. For example, time is experienced differently at work than on holiday. However, leading explanations of time perception are not well-equipped to explain these deviations. We propose that salient changes in sensory dynamics are the units from which we construct our subjective estimates of duration, such that epochs will feel longer when they contain more salient events. We tested this idea in a human model-based neuroimaging experiment with a fully pre-registered analysis pipeline(osf.io/ce9tp). Forty participants watched naturalistic, silent videos and estimated their duration while fMRI was acquired. We extracted moment-to-moment changes in visual cortex BOLD dynamics (“events”), and using computational modelling we show that accumulated events in visual cortex predicted duration biases reflecting human experience of time. We were unable to predict subjective time from two control regions irrelevant for perceptual classification of our silent videos - auditory and somatosensory cortex - despite being able to predict ‘clock time’ from all three areas. Therefore, we show that trial-by-trial subjective duration judgements can be reconstructed purely from human BOLD activity reflecting perceptual classification of the content for which time is being judged. Our results reveal that human subjective time is based on information arising during the processing of our dynamic sensory environment, providing a computational basis for an end-to-end account of time perception.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Role of Path Information in Visual Perception of Joint Stiffness 
Aaron West (he/him/his)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Aaron Michael West Jr., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Meghan Huber, Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, University of Massachusetts Amherst; Neville Hogan, Department of Mechanical Engineering and the Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences, Massachusetts Institute of Technology

Humans have an astonishing ability to extract hidden information from the movement of others. In previous work, subjects observed the motion of a simulated stick-figure, two-link planar arm and estimated its stiffness. Fundamentally, stiffness is the relation between force and displacement. Given that subjects were unable to physically interact with the simulated arm, they were forced to make their estimates solely based on observed kinematic information. Remarkably, subjects were able to correctly correlate their stiffness estimates with changes in the simulated stiffness, despite lack of force information. We posit that subjects were only able to do this because the controller used to produce the simulated arm’s movement, composed of oscillatory motions driving mechanical impedances, resembled the controller humans use to produce their own movement. However, it is still unknown how this controller is encoded in the nervous system, and consequently, what motion features subjects used to determine their stiffness rating. Human motion exhibits systematic velocity-curvature patterns, and these patterns play an important role in perceiving and interpreting motion. Thus, we hypothesized that manipulating the velocity profile should affect subjects’ ability to estimate stiffness. To test this, we changed the velocity profile of the simulated two-link planar arm while keeping the simulated endpoint paths the same. Even with manipulated velocity signals, subjects were still able to estimate changes in simulated joint stiffness with the same level of accuracy observed in the original experiment. These results suggest that path information predominates over temporal information when humans use visual observation to estimate stiffness.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Spinal-Mediated Kappa Opioid Receptor Antinociception is Blunted in a Mouse Model of Multiple Sclerosis
Caylin Chadwick
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Caylin I. Chadwick, Neuroscience & Mental Health Institute, University of Alberta, Canada; Bradley J. Kerr, Anesthesiology & Pain Medicine, University of Alberta, Canada; Anna M.W. Taylor, Pharmacology, University of Alberta, Canada

Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a debilitating disease in which inflammation and autoimmune reactions result in demyelination within the central nervous system (CNS). Chronic pain is commonly experienced with MS, and changes in the kappa opioid system have been described in several models of chronic pain. This project aims to characterize changes in kappa opioid receptor (KOR) analgesia and expression in a mouse model of MS.

To accomplish this, male and female C57Bl/6 mice were induced with experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), which models the inflammation, autoimmunity, and demyelination that occurs in human MS. At the first sign of disease presentation, systemic injection of KOR agonist U50,488H (1.6 mg/kg and 30 mg/kg, i.p.) evoked equipotent analgesic responses in EAE and control mice. However, local administration of U50,488H into the spinal cord (10 ug, i.t.) was significantly less analgesic in EAE mice. To explore this disparity, KOR mRNA and protein expression was measured in various CNS regions associated with pain using fluorescent in situ hybridization and western blot, respectively. In the spinal cord, KOR mRNA and protein levels were significantly reduced in EAE mice. No changes were detected in KOR protein levels in the amygdala and the claustrum; however, there was a significant increase in the expression of KOR protein in the nucleus accumbens of EAE mice.

Overall, this data suggests that systemic KOR agonism is effective at eliciting analgesia in a mouse model of MS. We posit that reductions in KOR expression in the spinal cord are compensated by increases in supraspinal KOR expression to maintain analgesic potential, especially in the nucleus accumbens.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Neural Mechanisms of Object-based Attention: Decoding EEG Alpha When Anticipating Faces, Scenes, and Tools
Sean Noah
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Travis Powell, UC Davis; Natalia Khodayari, Johns Hopkins; Diana Olivan, UC Davis; Mingzhou Ding, University of Florida; Ron Mangun, UC Davis

Attentional selection mechanisms in visual cortex involve changes in oscillatory neural activity in the electroencephalography (EEG) alpha band (8–12 Hz), with decreased alpha indicating focal enhancement of cortical activity and increased alpha indicating suppression of cortical activity. This pattern has been observed for spatial selective attention and attention to visual stimulus features such as color and motion. We investigated whether attention to categories of objects involves similar alpha-mediated changes in focal cortical excitability. In experiment 1, 20 volunteers (8 males; 12 females) were cued (80% predictive) on a trial-by-trial basis to anticipate different objects (faces, scenes, or tools). Support vector machine decoding of alpha power patterns revealed that late (>500 ms latency) in the cue-to-target foreperiod, EEG alpha differed with the to-be-attended object category, whereas patterns of the theta, beta, and gamma frequency bands were not systematically different across object conditions. In experiment 2, to control for the possibility that decoding of the physical features of cues led to our results, 25 participants (9 males; 16 females) performed a similar task as experiment 1, but with cues that were nonpredictive of the subsequently presented object category. Alpha decoding was now only significant in the early (<200 ms) foreperiod. In experiment 3, to control for the possibility that task set differences between the different object categories led to our experiment 1 results, 12 participants (5 males; 7 females) performed a predictive cuing task where the discrimination task for different objects was identical across object categories. The results replicated experiment 1. Together, these findings support the hypothesis that the neural mechanisms of visual selective attention involve focal cortical changes in alpha power not only for simple spatial and feature attention, but also for high-level object-based selection in humans.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Dopamine circuits driving the transition to habit
Priscilla Ambrosi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Priscilla Ambrosi, Northwestern University; Talia N. Lerner, Northwestern University

Habits decrease the burden of decision-making by establishing stimulus-response associations that guide
automatic behavior. While this automaticity can improve task performance, it can also lead to
compulsive behaviors seen in substance abuse and obsessive-compulsive disorder. To understand how
initially reward-driven behaviors develop into reward-independent habits, I am investigating a putative
circuit underlying habit formation in mice. Specifically, I am testing the existence of a circuit long
hypothesized to connect the dorsomedial striatum (DMS; required for reward-driven learning) to the
dorsolateral striatum (DLS; required for habit formation). The hypothesis, built from previous anatomical
data, is that DMS neurons indirectly activate DLS-projecting dopamine cells via inhibition of the
substantia nigra pars reticulata (SNr). To test this hypothesis, I am using optogenetics coupled with ex
vivo electrophysiology and in vivo fiber photometry. First, I am characterizing the circuit connecting DMS
to DLS-projecting dopamine cells ex vivo using retrograde labeling, viral-mediated gene delivery, transsynaptic
tracing, and intersectional genetics. Second, I am testing whether DMS activation leads to
dopamine release in DLS in vivo. Finally, I will compare the activity and connectivity of DLS-projecting
dopamine neurons before and after habit training. My ex vivo data is the first functional evidence for a
polysynaptic DMS-SNr-SNc-DLS circuit. Surprisingly, however, my in vivo data suggests that DMS
activation alone is not sufficient to increase dopamine release in DLS. My work will not only help answer
a fundamental question in neuroscience – what is the mechanism of habit formation? – but also provide a
foundation for future translational studies.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Autopilot: a distributed vision for the extravagant complexity of naturalistic neuroscience experiments
Jonny Saunders
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Michael Wehr

To understand the brain, it is increasingly clear that neuroscientists need to study it in its natural context of complex, contingent, and open-ended behavior. Naturalistic experiments invite neuroscientists to imagine beyond the constraints of their traditional rigs, but dreams of observing neural activity in multiple unrestrained animals in complex, hardware-dense environments are rudely grounded by technical complexity. Neuroscientists are intrepid, used to cobbling together the many mutually unintelligible components their experimental apparatuses require, but idiosyncratic builds are costly to re-develop and place hard limits on experimental replication. Autopilot is a Python framework for behavioral neuroscience that tackles problems of technical scale by distributing experiments over swarms of networked computers, principally Raspberry Pis. Rather than relying on an ecosystem of system-specific components, Autopilot provides the infrastructure to integrate your existing hardware or to use the many inexpensive peripherals available to the Raspberry Pi. Its distributed design allows effectively arbitrary numbers of hardware components to be coordinated in an experiment -- just add more computers. We attempted to blur the line between using and developing Autopilot: rather than writing scripts that "sit on top of" a fixed library, users are encouraged to be playful with its core components and write their experiments "within" it. Our vision is to nudge heroic reinventions of the wheel towards a shared, communally developed library of hardware controllers and experimental prototypes. Autopilot balances flexibility with reproducibility by separating an experiment's design from the particularities of its implementation. Data produced by Autopilot are clean and exhaustive at the time of collection, allowing direct replication of an experiment from a single file. In sum we built Autopilot to give neuroscientists the freedom to design the hare-brainedly complex experiments needed to study the behaving brain in a framework that encourages communally-developed and reproducible science. I will be presenting Autopilot's motivation, design, and recent work like the integration of DeepLabCut-Live -- and if lab access and instrumentation permits, a demonstration of the experiments we're designing with it now.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Neurophysiological Correlates of Dual Tasking in People with Parkinson’s Disease and Freezing of Gait
John Butler
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
John S. Butler, School of Mathematical Sciences, Technological University Dublin, Kevin Street, Dublin, Ireland; Conor Fearon,Trinity Centre for Bioengineering, Trinity College, The University of Dublin, Dublin 2, Ireland; Saskia M. Waechter, Trinity Centre for Bioengineering, Trinity College, The University of Dublin, Dublin 2, Ireland; Isabelle Killane, School of Mechanical and Design Engineering, Technological University Dublin, Kevin Street, Dublin, Ireland; Simon P. Kelly, 6School of Electrical & Electronic Engineering, University College Dublin, Dublin 4, Ireland; Richard B. Reilly,Trinity Centre for Bioengineering, Trinity College, The University of Dublin, Dublin 2, Ireland; & Timothy Lynch, Dublin Neurological Institute at the Mater Misericordiae University Hospital, Dublin 7, Ireland

Objective: Freezing of gait in people with Parkinson’s disease (PwP) is associated with executive dysfunction and motor preparation deficits.
