We have recently shown that electrophysiological markers of motor preparation, rather than decision-making, differentiate PwP with freezing of gait (FOG+) and without (FOG-) while sitting. To examine the effect of locomotion on these results, we measured behavioural and electrophysiological responses in PwP with and without FOG during a target response time task while sitting (single-task) and stepping-in-place (dual-task).
Methods: Behavioural and electroencephalographic data were acquired from 18 PwP (eight FOG+) and seven young controls performing the task while sitting and stepping in place.
Results: FOG+ had slower response times while stepping compared with sitting. However, response times were significantly faster while stepping compared with sitting for controls. Electrophysiological responses showed no difference in decision-making potentials (Centroparietal Positivity) between groups or conditions but there were differences in neurophysiological markers of response inhibition (N2) and motor preparation (Lateralized Readiness Potential, LRP) in FOG+ while performing a dual-task.
Conclusion: This suggests that the addition of a second complex motor task (stepping-in-place) impacts automatic allocation of resources in FOG+, resulting in delayed response times. The impact of locomotion on the generation of the N2 and LRP potentials, particularly in freezers, indirectly implies that these functions compete with locomotion for resources.
Significance: In the setting of multiple complex tasks or cognitive impairment, severe motor dysfunction may result, leading to freezing of gait.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Metabolic state dependence of olfactory cortex flavor representation during binge eating in rodents
Hung Lo (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Anke Schönherr, Charité; Marion Rivalan, Humboldt University of Berlin; Katharina Stumpenhorst, Humboldt University of Berlin; York Winter, Humboldt University of Berlin; Dietmar Schmitz, Charité; Friedrich Johenning, Charité

Energy homeostasis is achieved by the complex regulatory network that involves a feedback circuit between dietary intake behavior and nutritional state. The uncoupling of dietary intake and nutritional state results in overeating. Hedonic overeating can escalate into binge eating, a heritable trait associated with binge eating disorder and bulimia. One factor that modulates this feedback loop is the sensory perception of flavors. Olfaction is a critical element of flavor perception and greatly influences the qualitative and hedonic evaluation of food items. Patients with olfactory chemosensory deficits commonly report a reduced appreciation of food items. Current evidence suggests that upon fasting, the olfactory system is necessary for triggering fasting-induced overeating. However, it is unclear how adaptations related to binge eating are reflected by the olfactory flavor responses.

To understand the relationship between olfactory perception and binging, we developed an overeating behavioral paradigm that repeatedly delivers hedonic food (flavored milk) to mice. Implementing this with a head-mount miniaturized microscope allows us to measure neural responses upon overeating in the olfactory cortex (piriform cortex) in freely moving mice. We found that during a binge eating bout, the majority (~90%) of excitatory piriform neurons are suppressed. Whether this implies the involvement of inhibitory neurons during binging and/or whether the flavor representation adapts during the escalation of binging are the next steps of our examination.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Differential acute behavioral responses to (±)-DOI injected in a novel or familiar environment
Merima Sabanovic
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
David Bannerman, University of Oxford; Mark Walton, University of Oxford; Jason Lerch, University of Oxford; Vladyslav Vyazovskiy, University of Oxford

Serotonergic psychedelics induce profound changes at multiple levels of neuroplasticity that putatively aid lasting remission from a wide spectrum of neuropsychiatric disorders. In humans, heightened neuroplasticity was linked to heightened environmental sensitivity of acute and long-term psychedelic effects to both emotional/mental and physical context in which the treatment occurs, but such non-pharmacological factors of psychedelic response have been largely overlooked in animal models that remain crucial for discoveries on mechanisms of drug action.

Familiarity is one of the main environmental factors emphasized in clinical settings. In this study, we investigated whether familiarity of the environmental context during administration of psychedelic (±)-DOI would modulate measures of psychedelic effects in mice – head-twitch (HTR) and ear-scratch (ESR) responses – as well as any changes in locomotive exploration and interaction with novel objects. To do this, one group of wild-type C57BL/6J male mice was habituated to the injection context extensively prior to testing whereas the context was novel for the second group.

2mg/kg (±)-DOI induced a locomotor suppression regardless of injection context, but ESR to 2mg/kg (±)-DOI was higher in the non-habituated than in habituated animals, with a similar trend observable for HTR. Additionally, 2mg/kg (±)-DOI reduced novel object interaction in habituated animals, hypothetically signalling a cognitive shift from external processing of the environment to internal processing of emotional states and mind-generated stimuli. In non-habituated animals, vehicle control group had lower object interaction than habituated controls, likely due to attention competition for exploring both the novel environment and the novel objects, but (±)-DOI did not induce further drops in interaction times.

To the best of our knowledge, this study was the first attempt of investigating the effect of familiarity of the drug injection environment in mice on both the acute behavioural responses to a psychedelic drug and on the accompanying changes in exploration. A subsequent ex vivo imaging study will also be a first attempt to look at environmental effects on brain structure.

In my presentation I will also outline our future studies investigating whether (±)-DOI can influence structural brain plasticity and cognitive plasticity, referring to an increased capability for flexible cognitive change, in the long-term, after the drug has cleared the system.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Body Part- and Location-Selectivity Surrounding hMT in BOLD Responses to Naturalistic Stimuli
Matthew Shinkle
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Matthew W. Shinkle, Mark D. Lescroart

Information about body pose is critical for social communication and human interaction. In this work, we aim to clarify the extent to which potentially multiple regions of lateral occipitotemporal cortex (LOTC) encode information about the locations of body parts. To this end we applied voxel-wise modeling to BOLD responses for five participants across three diverse naturalistic stimulus sets: static natural images, natural movie clips, and computer-rendered scenes. From each stimulus set we used a deep neural network (OpenPose) to extract the locations and identities of different body parts. We then applied regularized linear regression to these features to estimate the relationship between each body feature and the BOLD responses of individual voxels. We validated our regression model by calculating prediction accuracies at each voxel. In addition to FFA, OFA, and pSTS, our model accurately predicted BOLD responses in voxels surrounding hMT, confirming body part selectivity in these regions. Variance partitioning incorporating motion energy features and binary ‘building present’ and ‘human present’ labels revealed unique variance explained by our body model in these regions, suggesting our prediction performance in these voxels is not merely due to naturalistic stimulus confounds. Finally, we contrasted voxel-wise model weights corresponding to different body features to measure differences in tuning based on body part identity and visual field location. This analysis revealed patchy selectivity for hands compared to faces around hMT and selectivity for the contralateral visual field throughout LOTC, particularly near the Lateral Occipital Sulcus. These results argue for an anatomically-circumscribed model of body-selectivity in LOTC and lend support to previous reports positing the existence of multiple sub-regions of EBA.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Stability and Control of Walking at Various Speed-Slope Combinations
Aya Alwan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Manoj Srinivasan, The Ohio State University; Nidhi Seethapathi, University of Pennsylvania

Walking on sloped surfaces is a common part of navigating our streets and buildings. Understanding sloped walking is especially important because slopes are common as an alternative to stairs for people with disabilities. Persons with lower-limb disability are not able to adjust their gait to walk on slopes without direct neural control (Rábago et al. 2016). While past work has explored the differences in biomechanics between sloped and level ground walking (Pickle et al. 2016), there is very little work in understanding gait stability and control in walking on slopes. Here, we investigate how the foot placement control strategies used on level ground walking (Wang and Srinivasan, 2014) are modulated when walking on a slope. Using human subject experiments and computer simulations, we investigate how deviations in the center of mass states occurring due to small intrinsic perturbations, are corrected using foot placement during sloped walking. We collected kinematic data on healthy humans while walking on an inclined-treadmill during ascent for several speed-slope combinations. We fit linear models between hip states at mid-stance and the next foot position to infer control strategies of sloped walking. Furthermore, we simulated a walking controller using experimentally obtained linear coefficients on a computational point-mass telescoping leg model. The linear models and computer simulations show what aspects of the controller are preserved (foot placement control) and what aspects change (push-off or power stroke) as humans walk stably up a range of slopes. These findings will inform control of prosthetic limbs by providing a human-derived controller that is stable on both level-ground and slopes.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Methyl Jasmonate attenuated lipopoysaccharide-induced depressive-like behaviour in mice
Adaeze Adebesin
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Solomon Umukoro* , University of Ibadan, Ibadan, Oyo State; Olusegun Adeoluwa, Afe Babalola University, Ekiti State; Anthony Eduviere, Delta State University, Abraka, Delta State.

Depression is a recurrent neuropsychiatric disorder that affects millions of individuals worldwide and impact negatively on the patients' social functions and quality of life. Studies have shown that i.p injection of lipopoysaccharide (LPS) induces depressive-like behavior in rodents via induction of oxidative stress and neuroinflammation. Methyl jasmonate (MJ), an isolated compound from jasmine plant has gained reputation in aromatherapy for treatment of depression, nervousness and memory deficits. This study was designed to evaluate the effects of MJ on LPS-induced depressive-like behavior in mice. Mice were given MJ (5-20 mg/kg), imipramine (10 mg/kg) or vehicle (10 mL/kg) intraperitoneally for 7 consecutive days. On day 7, treatment was carried out 30 min prior to i.p injection of LPS (0.8 mg/kg). Twenty four hours after LPS administration, tail suspension, forced swim and sucrose preference tests were carried out. Thereafter, serum corticosterone levels were determined using ELISA. The levels of malondialdehyde (MDA), glutathione (GSH) and TNF alpha were determined in brain tissue homogenates. LPS significantly increased immobility time in the tail suspension and forced swim tests when compared with vehicle (p < 0.05), which indicates depressive-like syndromes. However, the increased immobility time was significantly reduced by MJ (5-20 mg/kg) when compared with LPS-treated group. LPS administration also altered the levels of MDA, GSH, corticosterone and TNF alpha in mice, which was significantly reversed by MJ. These findings suggest that attenuation of LPS-induced depressive-like behavior by MJ may be related to suppression of oxidative stress and release of TNF alpha.

Keywords: Methyl Jasmonate, Lipopolysaccharide, Malondialdehyde levels, Glutathione concentration, tail suspension test, Forced swim test.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Adult-born Neurons Inhibit Developmentally-born Neurons
Alyssa Ash
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Elena Regele-Blasco; Erin Chahley; Desiree Seib; Jason Snyder, UBC

Recent reports indicate that lateral inhibition plays a powerful role in selecting which dentate gyrus (DG) neurons are recruited during memory formation. This raises the question of whether developmentally-born and adult-born DG neurons have distinct roles for inhibition, particularly in vivo when neuronal ensembles are selected during memory encoding. To address this we combined chemogenetics and immunohistochemistry for BrdU+Fos to silence and measure activity in developmentally and adult-born neurons as rats learned a spatial water maze task. Specifically, retrovirus was injected into the DG of male rats at 6 weeks of age to express the inhibitory DREADD receptor, HM4Di, in neurons born in adulthood. The same rats were also injected with BrdU to label developmentally or adult-born neurons. At 10 weeks of age rats were injected with either the HM4Di agonist CNO or vehicle, then trained in the water maze. We found that silencing a subset of adult-born neurons (aged 4 weeks) increased activity levels in the developmentally-born neuron population. However, silencing adult-born neurons did not affect activation in other adult-born neurons within the DG, suggesting limited interaction amongst the adult-born population. As well, we have examined activation of interneurons (PV+ and SST+) within each treatment group to determine if silencing neurons at different ages impacts downstream activity in inhibitory interneurons. Our recent findings implicate PV+ interneurons in the modulatory subcircuit between neuron populations within the DG.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Metabolic syndrome effect on olfactory function, memory and neurodegenerative processes in rats
Pedro Clavel
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Bryan V. Phillips-Farfán, Instituto Nacional de Pediatría

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative condition characterized by progressive cognitive decline. The main symptom is memory loss but clinical evidence shows that olfactory dysfunction can occur years before any cognitive symptoms. Metabolic syndrome (MS) is an important risk factor for AD development. Experimental research has shown that insulin resistance and oxidative stress (a core MS dysfunction) promote the amyloidogenic pathway, leading to the development of neuritic plaques characteristic of AD. Whether these alterations participate on olfactory dysfunction is still unknown. We evaluated olfactory and memory function, explored insulin pathway activation, amyloid precursor protein (APP) expression, lipid peroxidation and neurodegenerative processes in the olfactory bulb and hippocampus using an MS model induced by a high carbohydrate diet. We found olfactory dysfunction in rats that ate a high carbohydrate diet, but interestingly memory appeared to be better in this group Systemic hyperinsulinemia hyper-activated the insulin pathway and APP was downregulated in the hippocampus. Nonetheless, these effects were not observed in the olfactory bulb, as insulin activation and APP expression remained unchanged. Malondialdehyde, a lipid peroxidation marker, was decreased in the hippocampus and unchanged in the olfactory bulb. We did not find neurodegeneration in these tissues. These results provide novel information about olfactory function in a model of MS induced by high carbohydrate. We propose that insulin resistance showed a differential effect in the hippocampus and olfactory bulb, which could account for the results.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Terpsichore in Isolation: A study on the Correlation between Online Dancing and Telehealth during COVID-19 Pandemic on People with Parkinson's Disease
Katayoun Ghanai
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Joseph FX Desouza, Centre for Vision Research, Psychology, Interdisciplinary graduate studies, VISTA, York University, CAPnet, Toronto, Canada; Michael Coghlan, Music Department, AMPD, York University, Toronto, Canada

Terpsichore, one of the nine Muses and the Goddess of the dance, is known for playing her lyre and leading the dance. My interest in the lyre was enhanced upon learning of the “healing” properties” of David’s lyre as presented in the Old Testament. A new window opens and the concept of art serving a function betony mere enjoyment becomes as magical as the mythology itself. “Dancing with Parkinson’s” expands the participants perception of music and dance within the studio and occurs in more than 25 countries all over the world. Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a degenerative neurological disorder with no known cure and no disease modifying treatments. The rising tide of 60,000 Americans with PD per year presents a huge challenge for society for affected individuals, medical professional and care givers. The disease demands intense patient care while negatively impacting quality of life on all those involved. Our group conducts research on the impact of dance upon individuals diagnosed with PD since 2013 (Bearss, Desouza, 2017). Weekly dance classes for people with PD, a dance choreographer, and a pianist have been occurring for seven years. We sample all people’s data through multimodal brain imaging scans, behaviour analysis, clinical tests and self-reported questionnaires. Results indicate promising positive effects of participating in dance (Bearss et al 2017; DeSouza and Bearss, 2018; Ciantar et al 2019). The Covid-19 Pandemic diminished the possibility of continuing the classes although the program administrators tried to maintain the spirit of this long running program via online sessions. No additional tests can be run on studying the effects of virtual dance classes on the participants’ brains but collecting data through online questionnaires can help studying the correlation between on-line dancing and telehealth. The desire of patients for continuing the online delivery is a definite sign of some benefits.
References
Bearss, K., Mcdonald, K., Bar, R., & DeSouza, J. (2017). Improvements in balance and gait speed after a 12 week dance intervention for Parkinson’s disease. Advances in Integrative Medicine, 4(1), 10-13. doi:http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.aimed.2017.02.002  
Ciantar, S., Bearss, K., Bar, R., Levkov, G., & DeSouza, J. (2019). Investigating Affective and Motor Improvements with Dance in Parkinson’s Disease. Biorxiv,
Katayoun Ghanai
PhD3 Music, Neuroscience Graduate Diploma, York University, Canada
Centre for Vision Research, Psychology, Interdisciplinary graduate studies, VISTA, York
University, CAPnet, Toronto, Canada
Michael Coghlan
Department of Music, AMPD, York University, Toronto, Canada
doi:https://doi.org/10.1101/665711  
DeSouza, J., & Bearss, K. (2018). Progression of Parkinson’s disease symptoms halted using dance over 3-years as assessed with MDS-UPDRS. Neuroscience Meeting Planner. San Diego: Society for Neuroscience Abstracts. Online, doi:https://abstractsonline.com/pp8/#!/4649/presentation/22209  
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Application of human kinematic parameters for measuring motion performance in mice
Michael Mykins
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Michael Mykins1, Department of Biochemistry and Cellular and Molecular Biology, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37996; Billy Lau1, Department of Biochemistry and Cellular and Molecular Biology, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37996; Eric Espinoza-Wade2, Department of Mechanical Engineering, California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo, CA 93407; Keerthi Krishnan1, Department of Biochemistry and Cellular and Molecular Biology, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN 37996

In the field of human rehabilitation and neural repair, gross motor function is characterized by changes in kinematic parameters that measure the difficulty/smoothness of a motion. While kinematic parameters such as peaks and jerk are well established in assessing motor efficiency in humans and non-human primate models, they have not been validated in rodent models. Traditionally, motor function in mice is qualitatively assessed by observation and there is a need for a standard to quantify motor function. Validation of these parameters for analyzing motor function would provide a new perspective for quantitating individual variation in motor learning and execution for mouse models of motor related disorders. We sought to answer if these known kinematic parameters in humans could predict individual variation in motor efficiency in mice during the single pellet-grasping assay. Mice were food restricted to increase motivation to reach for a high reward food pellet and were recorded for 10 minutes a day for 4 days while attempting to retrieve the pellet. Individual reaches were manually tracked using Tracker Motion Analysis Software to extract time position data to derive peaks and jerk. Peaks of failed reaches decreased significantly with progressive training and were comparable to peaks of successful reaches, suggesting that peaks may be a predictive measure of motion efficiency in mice. Jerk may not be a sensitive enough measure to quantify motor performance in mice during the single pellet-grasping assay. The observation that the number of peaks decreases with motor training is consistent with previous studies in humans. Thus, peaks serve as a quantitative measure for studying learning and execution of fine motor skills in mice.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Role of interneurons in populations’ neural coding and network properties in auditory cortex
Melanie Tobin (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
M. Tobin, UPenn; K Wood, UPenn; J Stiso, UPenn; D Bassett, UPenn; M N Geffen UPenn;

Cortical neuronal networks are comprised of multiple types of excitatory and inhibitory neurons, which
perform specific computations. In the auditory cortex (AC), excitatory neurons receive the sound input and
transmit the processed signal to other areas, whereas the inhibitory neurons dynamically help shape the
response of the excitatory neurons. In the last decade, we have learned specific functions of distinct
inhibitory neurons, yet how different interneuron subpopulations affect network dynamics remains
unexplored. To establish the role of different interneuron subpopulations within the cortical network, we
stimulated specific interneuron subpopulations, while imaging the network responses to sounds in the AC.
We monitored the activity of populations of hundreds of neurons using two-photon calcium imaging and
simultaneously increased the activity of a subpopulation of interneurons using optogenetic stimulation. We
focused on VIP and SOM inhibitory neurons, which have previously been found to shape cortical responses
in a context-dependent fashion (Natan et al, 2015; Pi et al, 2013). Response of neurons activated by sound
were enhanced when VIPs were activated but reduced upon activation of SOMs. Using Non-Negative Matrix Factorization, we identify subgraphs of neurons with increased connectivity when the activity of VIP or SOM interneurons is increased and describe their network properties. Our results suggest that the differential role of inhibitory neuron types on cortical activity extends from affecting not just single neuron responses, but also cortical function at the network level.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
An implantable kinematic headplate for sub-micron skull positioning in mice
Su Jin Kim
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Su Jin Kim, Boston University Neurophotonics Center;Benjamin B. Scott, Boston University Center for Systems Neuroscience

Head immobilization is widely used in neuroscience studies to facilitate sensory stimulus control, behavioral monitoring, and neurophysiological recordings. Head-fixation strategies that combine mechanical stability and repeatable positioning over time or across instruments are particularly important for cellular resolution imaging or manipulation experiments. Headplates using kinematic coupling principles have been developed for precise micron-scale stability and position repeatability in rats (Scott et al. 2013, Rich et al. 2018). Here, we sought to extend this technology to a system small enough to be worn by mice (weighing <2 grams) and capable of submicron registration accuracy. To achieve these goals, we designed a headplate and clamp based on the Maxwell kinematic coupling system. The clamp was an anodized aluminum mount with three vee grooves, oriented at 120 degrees relative to each other. The headplate was a stainless steel triangle with three half spheres at the triangular vertices. Neodymium magnets attached to the clamp were used to provide the clamp force. We assessed the registration accuracy of the system using super resolution two-photon imaging of fluorescent microspheres (1μm diameter) fixed to the headplate following repeated attachments of the headplate. In initial experiments, registration accuracy (root mean square displacement) was 1.35μm in x, 1.42μm in y, and 0.28μm in z. Surgically implanted mice tolerated the headplate well and behaved normally. Scanning electron microscopy of the half spheres revealed mesoscale ridges and grooves in the metal surface. We replaced the stainless steel half spheres with precision ruby spheres. This improved repositioning accuracy to 0.17μm in x, 0.32μm in y, and 0.21μm in z. We anticipate that our system may facilitate experiments in mice where high precision and stability are required, such as imaging experiments using voluntary head restraint, time-lapse developmental studies, and registration of the same subject across multiple instruments.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Attitudes as Emergent Products of Associative Evaluations, Metacognitive Assessment, and Self-Report: A Computational Approach
Izabelė Jonušaitė
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Han van der Maas, Department of Psychology, University of Amsterdam; Casper Hesp, Department of Psychology, University of Amsterdam

Attitudinal dynamics have been described by dual-process theorists as having two distinct patterns—implicit and explicit. However, the interaction and blending of the two have been poorly understood. There is empirical and theoretical research on the circumstances under which these processes dissociate and align, yet a principled account of their interaction has not been proposed. In this paper, we present a computational model that formalizes the interaction between implicit and explicit attitudinal dynamics, and generates predictions of experimental explicit attitude measurement data based on these dynamics. We employ the Attitudinal Entropy framework by Dalege et al. (2016, 2018) to simulate implicit attitudes. To incorporate dynamics of explicit attitude formation and report, we expand the model by translating it into Bayesian terms, and use the Active Inference framework (Friston, 2010; Friston et al., 2017) to build a higher-level, (minimally) metacognitive module that assesses the real-time implicit level dynamics, stores memory of past assessments and directs self-report. Bidirectional communication among the modules allows to reproduce a variety of empirical phenomena related to self-report. Firstly, we simulate forced choice self-report for various settings that modulate explicit-implicit interactions, showing attitude strengthening effects under functional metacognition but not when metacognitive assessment is overconfident. Secondly, we simulate what happens on the implicit and explicit attitude levels when a person is forced to give a specific report (e.g., due to social pressure). The model sheds light on cognitive mechanisms underlying self-report and lays a foundation for a computational analysis of heterogeneous cognitive processes that combine to produce emergent attitudinal phenomena.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Functional brain network for perisaccadic visual processing: evidence from high resolution EEG and graph theory analysis
Amirhossein Ghaderi
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Amirhossein Ghaderi, Centre for Vision Research, York University, and Vision Science to Applications (VISTA) Program, York University, Toronto, ON, Canada; Matthias Niemeier, 3Department of Psychology, University of Toronto Scarborough, Toronto, ON, Canada; John Douglas Crawford, Centre for Vision Research, York University, and Vision Science to Applications (VISTA) Program, York University, Toronto, ON, Canada

The cortical network involved in the perisaccadic visual processing is still poorly understood and debates remain to find how brain can integrate the information from two visual fields (i.e. pre- and post- saccadic fixation points). Here, we constructed functional brain networks from Electroencephalography (EEG) data in the perisaccadic interval. Then, we evaluated the topological and spectral properties of the perisaccadic network. EEG was recorded via 64 channels in two behavioral conditions (fixation and saccade). Participants (N=21) were pre-cued with a series 1-3 grids (three horizontal lines, 10° by 10°) located 5° below the central fixation-point. In the saccade condition, saccades (recorded by Electrooculography) were cued by a sudden shift of the fixation-point to 10° left/right. 100ms later, a stimulus (three vertical lines; same size/location) was briefly presented (for 70ms). Saccades were occurred after the stimulus presentation. Fixation condition was identical, except the fixation-point remained in the centre. LORETA source localization was performed on the 200ms period following the saccade cue, or the equivalent time during fixation trials. Lagged coherences were calculated between all pairs of 84 Brodmann areas. Graph theory analysis (GTA) was implemented to find clustering coefficient (C), global efficiency (E), energy (H), entropy (S). Nonparametric permutation test showed higher values for C, E, H, and S in all frequency bands for the saccade task (relative to the fixation task). These results suggest that the segregation, integration, synchronizability, and complexity of brain network were simultaneously enhanced during the perisaccadic interval (in comparison to the fixation). The increased network properties can suggest a mechanism for high-level information processing (that is related to increased entropy in the network) and high-speed information propagation (that is associated with higher energy, clustering coefficient, and efficiency in the network) during the perisaccadic interval.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Translating time from temporal variation in transcription and structure in humans and chimpanzees
Christne Charvet
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Christine Charvet, Delaware State University

How the unique capacities of human cognition arose in evolution is a question of enduring interest. It is still unclear which developmental programs are responsible for the emergence of the human brain. The inability to determine corresponding ages between humans and apes has hampered progress in detecting developmental programs leading to the emergence of the human brain. I harness temporal variation in anatomical, behavioral, and transcriptional variation to determine corresponding ages from fetal to postnatal development and aging, between humans and chimpanzees. This multi-dimensional approach results in 137 corresponding time points across the lifespan, from embryonic day 44 to ~55 years of age, in humans and their equivalent ages in chimpanzees. I used these data to test whether developmental programs, such as the timeline of prefrontal cortex maturation, previously claimed to differ between humans and chimpanzees, do so once variation in developmental schedules is controlled for. I compared the maturation of frontal cortex projections from structural magnetic resonance (MR) scans and from temporal variation in the expression of genes used to track long-range projecting neurons (i.e., supragranular-enirhced genes) in chimpanzees and humans. Contrary to what has been suggested, the timetable of prefrontal cortex maturation is not unusually extended in humans. This dataset, which is the largest with which to determine corresponding ages across humans and chimpanzees, provides a rigorous approach to control for variation in developmental schedules and to identify developmental programs responsible for unique features of the human brain.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Adult-born hippocampal neurons undergo extended development and are morphologically distinct from neonatally-born neurons
Jason Snyder
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
John Darby Cole, University of British Columbia; Delane Espinueva, University of British Columbia; Désirée R. Seib, University of British Columbia; Alyssa M. Ash, University of British Columbia; Matthew B. Cooke, University of British Columbia; Shaina P. Cahill, University of British Columbia; Timothy O’Leary, University of British Columbia; Sharon S. Kwan, University of British Columbia; Jason S. Snyder

During immature stages, adult-born neurons pass through critical periods for survival and plasticity. It is generally assumed that by 2 months of age adult-born neurons are mature and equivalent to the broader neuronal population, raising questions of how they might contribute to hippocampal function in old age when neurogenesis has declined. However, few have examined adult-born neurons beyond the critical period, or directly compared them to neurons born in infancy. Here, we used a retrovirus to visualize functionally-relevant morphological features of 2- to 24-week-old adult-born neurons in male rats. From 2-7 weeks neurons grew and attained a relatively mature phenotype. However, several features of 7-week-old neurons suggested a later wave of growth: these neurons had larger nuclei, thicker dendrites and more dendritic filopodia than all other groups. Indeed, between 7-24 weeks, adult-born neurons gained additional dendritic branches, grew a 2nd primary dendrite, acquired more mushroom spines and had enlarged mossy fiber presynaptic terminals. Compared to neonatally-born neurons, old adult-born neurons had greater spine density, larger presynaptic terminals, and more putative efferent filopodial contacts onto inhibitory neurons. By integrating rates of cell birth and growth across the lifespan, we estimate that adult neurogenesis ultimately produces half of the cells and the majority of spines in the dentate gyrus. Critically, protracted development contributes to the plasticity of the hippocampus through to the end of life, even after cell production declines. Persistent differences from neonatally-born neurons may additionally endow adult-born neurons with unique functions even after they have matured.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Differential gene expression by RNA-seq during Alzheimer’s disease-like progression in the Drosophila melanogaster model
Letícia Batista
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jéssica Regina da Costa Silva, UFU; Patrícia Tieme Fujimura, UFU; Letícia Leandro Batista, UFU; Serena Mares Malta, UFU; Romualdo Morandi Filho, UFU; Aline Gomes de Souza, UFU; Ana Paula Mendes Silva, UFU; Luiza Diniz Ferreira Borges, UFU; Victor Alexandre Félix Bastos, UFU; Jamile Fernanda Silva Cossolin, UFV; José Eduardo Serrão, UFV; Ana Maria Bonetti, UFU; Luiz Carlos Oliveira Júnior, UFU; Carlos Ueira-Vieira, UFU

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is characterized by progressive, irreversible loss of memory and cognitive function. It is know that its pathogenesis is multifactorial, despite not well elucidated. Drosophila melanogaster is an ideal model organism to dissect molecular pathways, here used to dissect the differential gene expression during AD’s progression due to the amylodoigenic pathway using RNA-seq. A total of 1388 genes were found as differentially expressed both as AD progressed and in control flies. The main pathways related to those genes were evaluated using fly genes and human orthologs, linking genomic and higher order functional information. We identified alterations in pathways related to metabolism, ribosomal pathways, proteasome pathways and immune system. Some of those genes were validated by qPCR and in vivo knockdown. The identification of molecular pathway similarities between the transgenic Alzheimer-like fly model identified in this work and its human orthologs may provides new insights for the use of this fly in screening novel anti-AD drugs.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Using topological data analysis to investigate the relationship between population gut microbiome and Parkinson's Disease
Eva Lymberopoulos (she/her/hers)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Nikhil Sharma, UCL Institute of Neurology

Neurological disorders are the leading global cause of disability, and Parkinson’s Disease (PD) is the fastest growing of them. Thus, finding disease-modifying treatments for this debilitating disorder is becoming ever more pressing. Increasing evidence from animal and human studies points to a central role of gut dysbiosis in contributing to PD pathology, a potential target for novel therapies. However, standard analyses cannot consider the complexity and non-linearity of the gut microbiome, likely missing many subtle relationships. This study is the first to use indirect association with PD on a population gut microbiome dataset, and additionally the first to use Topological Data Analysis (TDA) to analyse an association of the microbiome with disease. For this, countries in a large, open-access microbiome dataset (sample size N=1151) were grouped based on Years Lived with Disease (YLD). The study used TDA to analyse the network structure of the microbiome data and associate it with these disease groups (High or Low YLDs) and other host factors through network enrichment stratification. We found that the PD groups were associated with distinct clusters of the microbiome network, a pattern that covaried with certain phyla. Specifically, the High YLD group was associated with Bacteroidetes, while the Low YLD group was associated with Firmicutes, but also Proteobacteria and Actinobacteria. The latter two are hypothesised to relate to a lower burden of PD through their complex inverse relationship with Firmicutes, which are thought to be neuroprotective. Thus, TDA is a fruitful tool for microbiome analysis and has extended previous findings. Importantly, the study supports the microbiome as a promising candidate target for scalable novel intervention therapies, such as pre-, pro-, or antibiotics, among others. In the future, we aim to replicate these findings in other large datasets and combine the novel methodology with machine learning.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Action imitation via trajectory-based or posture-based planning
Erica Barhorst-Cates
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Mitchell W Isaacs, Moss Rehabilitation Research Institute; Laurel J Buxbaum, Moss Rehabilitation Research Institute; Aaron L Wong, Moss Rehabilitation Research Institute

Movement imitation is a significant daily activity involved in social interaction and motor learning. Although imitation remains poorly understood, recent research suggests that it may be achieved in two distinct ways. In posture-based imitation, movements reproduce how the body should look and feel, and are sensitive to the relative positioning of body parts. In trajectory imitation, movements mimic the spatiotemporal motion path of the end effector. We hypothesized that people can imitate via either mechanism. If true, we would expect to see a switch cost when individuals change from one mechanism to the other. To test this, twenty-five healthy young adults performed a sequential multitasking imitation task. Participants were first instructed to pay attention to the limb postures or the hand path of a video-recorded model. They next performed an intervening motor task that was neutral, congruent, or incongruent with the instructed imitation type. Finally, participants imitated the modeled movement. Spatiotemporal imitation accuracy was greatest after a neutral intervening task, and worst after posture matching. When the primary task involved imitating trajectories, we observed a switch cost: movements following the posture-matching intervening task were less consistent with baseline (neutral) performance, suggesting performance was disrupted by the incongruence. Incongruent primary and intervening tasks also reduced cross-subject consistency. Such effects were not observed when imitating limb postures. In summary, we observed a partial dissociation between posture matching and trajectory imitation as a result of instructions and intervening tasks that is nevertheless consistent with the existence of two computationally distinct imitation mechanisms.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Distinct synaptic plasticity mechanisms determine the diversity of cortical neuronal responses during behavior
Badr Albanna (he/him/his)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Michele N Insanally, University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Department of Otolaryngology, Pittsburgh, PA; Brian DePasquale, Princeton University, Princeton Neuroscience Institute, Princeton, NJ; Saba Fadaei, New York University, Skirball Institute of Biomolecular Medicine, New York, NY; Trisha Gupta, New York University, Skirball Institute of Biomolecular Medicine, New York, NY; Madeline Albanese, Fordham University, Department of Natural Sciences, New York, NY; Kanaka Rajan, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, Department of Neuroscience and Friedman Brain Institute, New York, NY; Robert C Froemke, New York University, Skirball Institute of Biomolecular Medicine and Center for Neural Science, New York, NY;

Spike trains recorded from the cortex of behaving animals can be complex, highly variable from trial-to-trial, and therefore challenging to interpret. A fraction of recorded cells typically exhibit trial-averaged responses with obvious task-related features and can be considered ‘classically-responsive’, such as pure tone frequency tuning in the auditory cortex. However, a substantial number of cells (including cells in primary sensory cortex) do not appear to fire in a task-related manner and are often neglected from analysis (Olshausen & Field 2006). Even classically-responsive cells lose their stimulus representation during task-engagement without impairing behavioral performance (Otazu et al., 2009). These results suggest that non-classically responsive cells may play an underappreciated role in sensory processing and cognition. Recently, we showed that non-classically responsive cells recorded from auditory cortex and frontal cortex contained hidden task-relevant information while animals performed a frequency recognition task at levels comparable to responsive cells using a novel single-trial spike-timing-based analysis (Insanally et al., 2019). However, the synaptic origins and potential contribution of these cells to network function remain unknown. To address this, we developed a novel class of spiking recurrent neural network models that incorporate both spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP; Bi and Poo, 1998; Vogels et al., 2011; D’amour and Froemke, 2015) and FORCE learning (Sussillo and Abbott, 2009; Nicola and Clopath, 2017) to perform an auditory-guided task. We find that (1) this model recapitulates the surprising number of non-classically responsive cells seen in vivo and (2) distinct STDP mechanisms alter single-unit response profiles with heterosynaptic plasticity playing a key role. Finally, our model also makes strong predictions about the synaptic origins of classically and non-classically responsive neurons which we can compare to in vivo whole-cell recordings taken from the auditory cortex of behaving animals.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Oxytocin and embryonic diapause
Jessica Minder
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Moses Chao; Robert Froemke

We have examined prenatal oxytocin receptor expression in the mouse embryo, detecting the oxytocin receptor as early as embryonic day four, during the blastocyst stage. This is the developmental stage where blastocysts begin implantation into the uterine endothelium, an event critical for successful pregnancy. Interestingly, rodents- like most if not all mammals- undergo a phenomenon called diapause, in which the timeframe that the embryo implants is delayed during a maternal state unfavorable for pregnancy, such as while nursing a previous litter (Fenelon et al., 2014). Embryonic diapause is thought to occur by making the uterus non-receptive to implantation in a manner regulated by the hypothalamic neuroendocrine axis, but the underlying mechanism is unknown (Renfree and Shaw, 2000). Lactation requires the neuropeptide oxytocin, raising circulating levels of oxytocin that can permeate down to the embryo, perhaps via maternal-fetal signaling (Stouffer and Hennebold, 2014).

We hypothesize that oxytocin, released in response to the sensory stimulus of a suckling pup, might act to initiate diapause in mice. In support of this, we have recapitulated a developmental delay in vitro using a cell culture model of blastocyst implantation (Bedzhov et al., 2014), in which the time for mouse blastocysts to implant is delayed by 12 hours in the presence of oxytocin, as compared to saline-treated blastocysts (p-value:0.0087). Using patch-clamp electrophysiology, we have elucidated that oxytocin may be functioning to signal entry into diapause within the embryo by reducing the overall conductance of the mouse blastocyst to initiate developmental pausing until conditions are favorable for pregnancy progression.

In addition to examining diapause in vitro, we are using chemo- and opto- genetics to activate oxytocin neurons in the hypothalamus of mothers in the absence of the nursing to ask if oxytocin release is sufficient for diapause induction. Furthering our understanding of the uterine conditions favorable for allowing blastocyst implantation and the mechanisms by which the mouse blastocyst integrates cues from its surroundings to dictate developmental timelines has major implications for neuroendocrine signaling, developmental biology, and reproductive medicine.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Knowledge-centric metacognitive approach for solving tasks
Arun Kumar
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Paul Schrater, schrater@umn.edu, University of Minnesota Twin Cities;

People exhibit general intelligence behaviors in solving a variety of tasks flexibly by reusing and applying high level knowledge acquired over a period of time. But artificial agents lack generalist behaviors. We argue that general intelligence in artificial agents requires a knowledge-centric meta-cognitive approach. Meta-reasoning about next actions and possible next states is more than resource allocation and memory look-up, it allows people to direct their learning and interactions with world objects in a reusable way. Core to our proposed approach is the ability of finding natural decompositions in environments to understand and exploit structured knowledge representations. Our proposal is based on three main principles for solving complex tasks flexibly - natural decomposition and abstractions, interactions and composition of interactions. World environments are composed of entities and categorized by the types of those entities, in essence, they are knowledge graphs of underlying objects and their relationships. To solve tasks, the meta-cognitive process of the agent formulates a graph traversal path of which entities it needs to interact with locally and then solve tasks by composition of these interactions along the traversal path. Therefore, integrating these principles provides us levers and connect points to induce flexibility into the agents’ behaviors. The proposed meta-cognitive approach captures the essence of generalist behaviors and has promise to act as an enabler for artificial general intelligence with implications across domains.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Odor identification in novel olfactory environments is selectively impaired in a mouse model of autism
Gonzalo Otazu
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Yan Li, Mitchell Swerdloff, Tianyu She, Asiyah Rahman, Naveen Sharma, Reema Shah, Michael Castellano, Daniel Mogel, Jason Wu, Asim Ahmed, James San Miguel, Jared Cohn, Nikesh Shah, Gonzalo H Otazu

Aversion to novel stimuli in autism affects quality of life. We developed a behavioral paradigm to study the effect of novel background odors on odor discrimination in mouse models of autism. We trained wild type mice to discriminate target odors in known background odors. When tested, mice could discriminate known targets in novel background odors, a task similar to the visual CAPTCHA used to distinguish humans from computers. Using glomerular imaging data, we showed that WT mice used an algorithm that required less training data than a linear classifier or nearest neighbor classifier. The Cntnap2-/- mouse model of autism matched wild type mice performance in the presence of known backgrounds, but performance fell almost to chance levels in the presence of novel backgrounds. Wild-type mice use a robust algorithm for detecting odors in novel environments and this computation is selectively affected in a mouse model of autism.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The role of delayed maturation of GABA-A receptor function in schizophrenia
Kyla Gaeul Lee (she/her)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kyla Gaeul Lee, Schulich School of Medicine and Dentistry, Western University; Raj Rajakumar, Schulich School of Medicine and Dentistry, Western University

Unlike positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia, cognitive abnormalities of this disorder are manifested very early and are present in the prodromal period in preadolescent children. An imbalance in excitatory/inhibitory transmission in the prefrontal cortex (PFC) unrelated to synaptic pruning may underlie this preadolescent manifestation of cognitive deficits. In the normal brain, GABA binding to GABA-A receptors causes depolarization during early development then becomes hyperpolarizing owing to the changes in KCC2 and NKCC1 expression and function. Interestingly, premature ablation of the subplate (SP) layer of the developing visual cortex resulted in delayed upregulation of KCC2 causing a continued depolarizing effect of GABA in the cerebral cortex. Our laboratory described that neonatal ablation of the SP layer of the PFC in rat results in multiple behavioral and neuropathological abnormalities relevant to schizophrenia. In order to study the effects of a delayed GABA functional switch on cognitive function and PFC pathology of schizophrenia, we sought to ablate the SP layer of the developing PFC in postnatal day 1-old rats. Lesioned and sham-operated pups were sacrificed at different time points between P5 and 3 months, and coronal sections through the PFC were processed for immunohistochemical labeling of GAD67, parvalbumin, KCC2, and NKCC1.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Delayed maturation of input plasticity at lateral perforant path synapses onto adult-born dentate granule neurons.
Nicholas Vyleta
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jason Snyder, University of British Columbia

In the mammalian brain, the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus uniquely generates new neurons throughout the lifetime of the animal. Adult-born granule cells undergo a period of maturation during which their membranes are more excitable and inputs from medial perforant path neurons can more easily induce long-term potentiation of synaptic responses. This previously described “critical window” exists between approximately four- and six-weeks of cell age. Whether signaling from the other major cortical input to the dentate gyrus—the lateral perforant path—undergoes the same timecourse of maturation remains unknown. We measured synaptic responses to lateral perforant path stimulation on adult-born granule cells between three- and thirty-weeks old. Surprisingly, we find that long-term potentiation of synaptic responses matures over an extended timecourse, with a peak at around 15-weeks of cell age. Cells between 4- and 6- weeks of age are more likely to experience long-term depression of lateral perforant path inputs than are older cells. We find that facilitation of transmitter release increases over a similar timecourse as long-term potentiation, and that the magnitude of the reduction of facilitation after induction of long-term potentiation predicts the magnitude of that potentiation. These data suggest that an increase in presynaptic release probability at lateral perforant path synapses is the major mechanism of long-term potentiation, and that this plasticity is more prominent at inputs onto older neurons.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Application of Neuroinformatics Pipeline to Gene-environment Interaction in Neurodegenerative Disease
Shauna Overgaard
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Shauna Overgaard, University of Minnesota; Gyorgy Simon, University of Minnesota; Laël Gatewood, University of Minnesota; Weihua Guan, University of Minnesota; Prashanthi Vemuri, Mayo Clinic

Background
The presence of the ϵ4 allele of the Apolipoprotein (APOE4) increases the risk of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and is associated with earlier onset of Alzheimer’s disease pathology. The theory of cognitive reserve suggests the existence of a resilience mechanism in the face of neuropathology. A mechanistic relation of cognitive reserve to gray matter density has been implicated where damage to the observable brain is found in the absence of cognitive impairment. The aim of this work was to build neuroinformatics tools to understand the complex interplay between APOE4, resilience, and pathologies.
Methods
Objective 1 of this work was to test whether the effect of cognitive reserve on gray matter density differs by APOE4 genotype. The overall capacity for integrative processing may be associated with cognitive reserve; this was evaluated using a core construct from graph theory called global efficiency. Objective 2 of this work was to test whether a higher cognitive reserve is associated with higher global efficiency. The input of APOE4 status may serve different roles and affect the manner in which the system runs. Objective 3 of this work was to test whether APOE4 carriers as compared to non-carriers demonstrate differences in network recruitment, contributions of global efficiency to functioning. The specific neurophysiological mechanisms that facilitate the effective integration of experience and the development of neuroprotective intellectual abilities are unclear.
Conclusion
The work presented draws on the methodological strengths of health informatics, biostatistics, and neuroscience, to 1) develop a neuroinformatics pipeline for the replicable collection, manipulation, and analysis of data to produce meaningful and verifiable information, and 2) employ this pipeline to evaluate the potential impact of specific allele carriership on what is recognized as a resilience mechanism for the rest of the population.
Traditional talk
Watch now
Reductions in Parkinson’s Disease symptoms and alpha rhythm modulations as a result of multinetwork learning to music over 3-years.
Karolina Bearss
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Joseph F. X. DeSouza

Parkinson’s Disease (PD) has a fast progression of motor dysfunction within the first 5 years with annual rates of decline of 5.2 to 8.9 points on the MDS-Unified Parkinson’s Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS). We aimed to extend research on the short-term benefits of Dance for PD and determine improvements over 3 years while participating in weekly classes. We collected EEG, mood (PANAS-X), cognitive (MMSE, PD-NMS & MDS-UPDRS Parts I, II & IV) and motor (MDS-UPDRS Part III) assessments with the goal to examine a continuous PD long-term program that can serve to compliment traditional medical treatments and examine whether disease progression is modified. We conducted two studies: (1) examined the short-term benefits of dance (N=17) and (2) measured PD symptom progression over a 3-year period (N=32). Our results indicated that rsEEG global alpha power was highest after a single dance class in comparison to before, F(1,26) = 6.928, p < .025, η2 = .210. Individuals with PD participating in 3-yrs of dance showed no progression of motor symptoms across time (p=0.817). Further no impairment was shown for daily living (p=0.329), motor experiences of daily living (p=0.540) and for non-motor complications (p=0.390). To examine disease progression directly in our cohort, we matched data from Parkinson’s Progression Markers Initiative as our non-dance PD comparison group (PD-MJFF-Com). A significant Group (PD-Dancers and PD-MJFF-Com) by Days interaction showed that PD who train in dance have less motor impairment (M=18.75) than PD-MJFF-Com who do not dance (M=24.61) and over time (p< 0.05). As expected, and in stark contrast to our PD-Dancers the PD-MJFF-Com showed motor impairment (UPDRS III) across time (p< 0.01). UPDRS I and II showed disease progression of PD over time (p<0.005), and (p<0.01), whereas UPDRS IV showed no progression (p= 0.365) over the same 2-year period. Thus, multinetwork training to music is effective at slowing motor and non-motor PD symptoms.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Dissecting learning and generalization of a continuous motor skill using a customized videogame
David Huberdeau
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Adrian M. Haith, Johns Hopkins University; John W. Krakauer, Johns Hopkins University

How humans learn continuous motor skills, like a tennis serve, is a topic of great interest but remains controversial. One theory is that continuous movements in humans are made up of a sequence of discrete movement primitives. Movement primitives become sequenced into chunks that are then executed more efficiently. One prediction from the chunking model is that learning is sequence-specific, i.e. learning of one sequence of movements does not benefit the performance of a different sequence. We sought to test the chunking model by comparing the movement kinematics of continuous movements that were either well practiced or unpracticed. Human participants learned a continuous-movement skill that was implemented in a custom-built videogame. The game recorded participants’ movements as they learned to drive a virtual car along a narrow and winding track (the training track) by tilting a tablet computer using both wrists. To test for generalization, participants navigated a new track, the probe track, in a block of trials on their final day of participation. The probe track was the mirror-image of the training track, and so was matched for difficulty. Under the chunking model, performance on the probe track should have worsened compared to the training track. However, movement kinematics on the probe track matched those recorded on the training track, revealing that participants fully generalized. Performance, however, as measured by task success (remaining within the track boundaries) was worse for the probe track. Performance may transiently worsen compared to an individual’s average performance due to lapses, and an analysis of kinematics prior to task failure indicated that failures occurred in the same way on both tracks, while the frequency of lapses was higher on the probe. These findings are more consistent with learning a general control policy based on visited states rather than a chunked movement sequence.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Lateralized Short-Term and Long-Term Plasticity of Somatostatin-Positive Interneurons in Female Mouse Auditory Cortex
Soomin Song (He, Him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Robert C. Froemke, NYU

There are multiple forms of synaptic plasticity, and distinct inputs onto the same postsynaptic neuron can have qualitatively different learning rules (Maheux et al. 2015). There is growing evidence that cortical inhibitory synapses are highly plastic, including differences in cell-type-specific GABAergic inputs onto layer 2/3 pyramidal neurons (Chiu et al. Neuron 2018). In the auditory cortex, we have found that an unusual left-lateralized form of short-term inhibitory depression might help enable longer-term changes to both excitation and inhibition for enhanced responses to pup calls in maternal mice (Marlin et al. Nature 2015, Schiavo et al. Nature 2020).

Here we examined short-term and spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) of different inhibitory inputs onto layer 2/3 pyramidal neurons of adult mouse auditory cortex in slices. STDP is a method for inducing input-specific and long-term modifications of synaptic strength, where short-term plasticity reflects the dynamic synaptic strength based on recent history. These mechanisms might underlie the synchronization of stimulus-evoked inhibitory input during development (Dorrn et al. Nature 2010, Field et al. Neuron 2020) and after conditioning or maternal experience.

We utilized isolated expression of channelrhodopsin-2 in various GABAergic interneurons to selectively activate these inputs. Somatostatin interneurons are distinct physiologically, expressing STDP (169% potentiated current, n = 11, p < 0.05) as compared to PV, VIP and Layer-1 interneurons. Somatostatin also demonstrate differential depression to repetitive stimulation (df = 3, F = 3.26, p < 0.05), depending on hemisphere, as compared to PV. Our data suggest somatostatin interneurons are critical for laterality in the auditory cortex.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Social Transmission of Maternal Behaviors through Observation
Naomi Lopez Caraballo
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Naomi Lopez Caraballo; Robert Froemke

Oxytocin is a peptide hormone important for maternal physiology and social behaviors (Jurek & Neumann Physiol Rev 2018). One behavior influenced by central oxytocin signaling in rodents is pup retrieval (Marlin et al. Nature 2015; Scott et al. Nature 2015). When mouse pups are out of the nest, they emit vocalizations that prompt dams to fetch the pup back to the nest. Virgin females do not initially retrieve pups, but can learn to retrieve after several days of co-housing with an experienced mother and pups in a manner that may involve visual observational learning of dams interacting with the nest and pups (Carcea et al. BioRxiv 2019).
To explore what aspects of maternal behavior are socially transmitted, we showed audio-visual movies to head-fixed awake virgins that initially did not retrieve. It allows us to manipulate the sensory stimuli presented to the virgins and further explore experience-related effects on behavior and neural activity. Our data (n=11) shows that virgins can learn to retrieve in the virtual setup, while virgins presented with dark background did not learn to retrieve (n=14). Alternatively, virgins presented with videos of maternal mistakes (out of the nest retrievals; n=4) or non-maternal behaviors (video of conspecific; n=8) lead to decreased performance. This setup is an essential step towards understanding which visual stimuli are informative for retrieval learning. It will allow us to manipulate sensorial experience, and employ electrophysiological and optogenetical techniques to further explore the role of oxytocin on social behavior.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Representing Altruism in Multi-agent Theory of Minds
Claire Yang
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Joe Blanchard, University of Minnesota; Paul Schrater, University of Minnesota

Research on multi-agent theory of minds assumes that each agent is motivated by the maximization of either their own utility, or their team's collective utility. There is a significant gap in our understanding of how to represent perceived unselfish behavior in social interactions with multiple people and objectives. We address this gap by utilizing a multi-agent theory of minds framework and three-player stag hunt game to simulate a situation where social cooperation can only be inferred from other agent's actions. In addition to normal game actions, each agent has actions that allow them to advertise and elicit social preferences. Agents can declare their altruistic intentions towards any other agent, without committing to altruistic gameplay. To elicit social preferences, each agent has the ability to make any other agent play the dictator game. The dictator game allows the agents to signal whether they are purely self-interested, or actually altruistic at a cost to the agent. Preliminary results without the dictator game show that higher level agents are more likely to declare altruism, and that an agent's altruistic declarations had a notable effect on the inferred teams and the other agents' following actions. We aim to utilize this environment to conduct experiments with depressed and nondepressed participants, in order to better understand how depression affects the perception of social cooperation and altruism.
Interactive talk
Watch now
Microstimulation and optogenetics: A combined stimulation strategy
Hector Baez
 
Abstract
 
It has been well studied that intracortical microstimulation is sufficient to drive action potential generation in cortical neurons of awake behaving animals. However, in certain sensory regions of the brain, microstimulation is difficult to implement due to the overlap of functional regions covered by the spreading electrical current. In the primary somatosensory cortex for example, neurons representing features of tactile perception such as motion or texture are intermixed in functional circuits at the cellular level. Therefore, microstimulation of these regions can lead to the activation of multiple feature-encoding neurons simultaneously, which limits the ability of microstimulation to drive functional haptic perception. In contrast to ICMS, optogenetics is a technique capable of driving units with single-cell precision for both activation (channelrhodopsin) and inactivation (halorhodopsin). Optogenetics however requires direct exposure to light and therefore is limited in spatial depth and reach. The goal of this project is to reduce the ambiguity of artificial sensations by implementing a combined strategy of microstimulation and optogenetics to selectively silence cells activated by microstimulation using a biologically constrained model. A biologically constrained computational model was constructed in MATLab to analyze the population responses to electrical and optogenetic stimuli. The individual current and luminous intensity contributions are summated and included in a Poisson spiking model to determine neural activation. To test our predictions, we first analyzed how a single optoelectrode affects the neural sets within the population. This analysis was expanded to include the interaction of multiple optoelectrodes within the subspace to achieve a desired stimulation pattern. A particle swarm optimization algorithm was utilized to locate optimal stimulus combinations resulting in the best SNR for motion representation.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
An Attempt at Co-Clinical Trials of Autism in Mice and Humans
Zsuzsi Lindenmaier, she/her
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Adrienne Kinman; Tiffany Chien; Kaitlyn Easson; Monique Stuvie; Darren Fernandes; Eric Chater-Diehl; Michelle Siu; Darci Butcher; Jacob Ellegood; Rosanna Weksberg; Jane Foster; Evdokia Anagnostou; Jason P. Lerch

Despite promise in animal models, novel therapeutics consistently fail in clinical trials of autism. Due to the heterogeneous nature of autism, treatment will likely only ameliorate symptoms in a subset of patients. There is a need to simultaneously test promising new compounds while understanding and predicting which patients will respond to each therapy. To determine what might contribute to response susceptibility, we propose the implementation of co-clinical trials in autism. In co-clinical trials, novel compounds, with established safety profiles, are simultaneously tested in mouse models of autism as well as in Phase 2 trials in humans with autism. A high-throughput protocol for mouse models of autism is discussed, which encompasses chronic treatment over development, multiple magnetic resonance imaging time-points, and behavioural tests before, during, and after treatment. Human subjects also follow an extensive phenotyping protocol, including behavioural testing, as well as genetics and imaging assessments. This multi-modal, multi-species approach is designed to be a rigorous method of assessing treatment effect, with the intention of stratification by response susceptibility. The considerations of the co-clinical trials is discussed, focusing on the trials and tribulations of the model, as well as lessons-learned. The hope is to introduce the concept of co-clinical trials to the field of autism, creating a shift in our current approach to the treatment of the disorder.
Keynote Event
Watch now
Social transmission of maternal behavior
Ioana Carcea
Keynote Event
Watch now
Panel on Neuroscience as Visual Art
 
Abstract
 
Neuroscience has a long history of collaboration with the visual arts. Dating back to Santiago Ramón y Cajal, visual arts have impacted the discovery process in neuroscience both through technique development (e.g., staining techniques derived from photography) and through artistic drawings that gave our first detailed insights into the form and function of neurons. Today, visual arts remains a medium that communicates both the details and the beauty of the brain and it's parts. This panel of visual artists using neuroscience as their inspiration will discuss their approach to developing and creating their art, as well as the role visual arts can play in science and science communication.

Moderator:
Chris Rozell (Georgia Institute of Technology)

Panelists:
- Kathleen Childress (https://hkcdesigns.wordpress.com/)

- Michele Banks (https://www.artologica.net/)

- Kathleen Sluka (https://www.kathleenslukaart.com/)

- Christine Liu (https://twophotonart.com/)

- Greg Dunn (www.gregadunn.com)
 Keynote Event

Neuromodulatory landscapes of the basal ganglia: Oxytocin and dopamine
Yevgenia Kozorovitskiy
Interactive talk
Watch now
Modeling of behavioral tasks for data sharing using state machines
Pamela Baker
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Pamela Baker, Allen Institute for Brain Science; Lydia Ng, Allen Institute for Brain Science

Rigorous descriptions of experimental methods are critical for reproducing protocols, comparing different studies, performing data analyses, and building accurate computational models to predict and explain results. Behavioral tasks are a critical component of many neurophysiology studies, but published task descriptions vary greatly in the amount of information they convey about task structure and logic, and this lack of standardization can make task descriptions difficult to interpret and insufficient to reproduce the methods and analyses.
Our goal is to build a schema for representation of behavioral tasks that is machine-readable and uses existing standards and formats for specification; facilitates comparison of task structure and logic; permits task emulation for testing and debugging of experimental designs; and captures the essential metadata for performing relevant data analyses. This schema will be used to extend the NWB:N data standard (http://www.nwb.org) for storing task descriptions and metadata.
Our approach was to model tasks as finite state machines (FSMs). Many types of tasks can be modeled by FSMs, and many common software packages for designing and executing tasks for neurophysiology studies use an FSM framework. We used MagicDraw, a commercial systems engineering software package that includes a freeware version, to build executable task models. MagicDraw was chosen because it allows for the graphical design of state machines for task logic, enables task emulation with model outputs for later analyses, and uses existing UML standards for building and exporting FSM descriptions.
We have developed a set of task models in MagicDraw that cover the most common task designs for rodent neurophysiology. We will demo some of these models and present the results of simulations. We will discuss what FSM task models can and can’t capture, and hope to stimulate discussion of essential metadata for behavioral task description and sharing, and to discuss features to include in task representations that would be most useful for facilitating sharing in the community.
Funding to L. Ng: NIH R24 MH116922-02
 Traditional talk
Watch now
The influence of active removal from working memory on serial dependence
Jiangang Shan
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Jiangang Shan, University of Wisconsin-Madison; Bradley R. Postle, University of Wisconsin-Madison

Flexible control of the contents of working memory (WM), necessary for many aspects of behavior, includes the ability to remove no-longer-relevant information. Although simply withdrawing attention is one likely mechanism, many empirical results suggest that it is possible to actively remove information from working memory. We tested evidence for a specific mechanism for active removal: modulating the gain of the sensory channels that encode the stimulus-specific features (Lorenc et al., 2020; an efficient coding mechanism (c.f., Fritsche et al., 2020)). Subjects performed paired doublets of trials, the first being multi-item WM with retrocuing and updating, the second being 1-item delayed recall, with measures of serial dependence of the latter on various items from the former as the primary dependent variable of interest. The first trial of each doublet presented two sample Gabor patches, followed by a retrocue that implicitly designated the uncued item as an irrelevant memory item (IMI). Next a third item was presented, and finally memory for either the cued or the third item was tested. The critical manipulation was whether or not the third item was presented at the same location at which the IMI has appeared, with overlap between the two expected to prompt the active removal of the IMI from WM, whereas nonoverlap might require nothing more than the withdrawal of attention. Results indicated that whereas the IMI exerted the attractive bias on 1-item delayed recall in the no-overlap condition (consistent with a withdrawal of attention), but a repulsive bias in the overlap condition. Because repulsive serial dependence effects have been attributed to an efficient encoding mechanism (Fritsche et al., 2020), this result suggested the active removal of information from WM could be implemented by modulating the gain of the sensory channels that encode the features of IMI.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Reconciling functional differences in populations of neurons recorded with two-photon imaging and electrophysiology
Josh Siegle (he/him)
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Peter Ledochowitsch, Allen Institute; Xiaoxuan Jia, Allen Institute; Daniel Millman, Allen Institute; Gabriel K. Ocker, Allen Institute; Shiella Caldejon, Allen Institute; Linzy Casal, Allen Institute; Andrew Cho, Allen Institute; Daniel J. Denman, CU Anschutz; Séverine Durand, Allen Institute; Peter A. Groblewski, Allen Institute; Greggory Heller, Allen Institute; India Kato, Allen Institute; Sara Kivikas, Allen Institute; Jerome Lecoq, Allen Institute; Chelsea Nayan, Allen Institute; Kiet Ngo, Allen Institute; Philip R. Nicovich, Allen Institute; Kat R. North, Allen Institute; Tamina K. Ramirez, Allen Institute; Jackie Swapp, Allen Institute; Xana Waughman, Allen Institute; Ali Williford, Allen Institute; Shawn R. Olsen, Allen Institute; Christof Koch, Allen Institute; Michael A. Buice, Allen Institute; Saskia E.J. de Vries, Allen Institute

Extracellular electrophysiology and two-photon calcium imaging are widely used methods for measuring physiological activity with single-cell resolution across large populations of neurons in the brain. While these two modalities have distinct advantages and disadvantages, neither provides complete, unbiased information about the underlying neural population. Here, we compare evoked responses in visual cortex recorded in awake mice under highly standardized conditions using either imaging or electrophysiology. Across all stimulus conditions tested, we observe a larger fraction of responsive neurons in electrophysiology and higher stimulus selectivity in calcium imaging. This work explores which data transformations are most useful for explaining these modality-specific discrepancies. We show that the higher selectivity in imaging can be partially reconciled by applying a spikes-to-calcium forward model to the electrophysiology data. However, the forward model could not reconcile differences in responsiveness without sub-selecting neurons based on event rate or level of signal contamination. This suggests that differences in responsiveness more likely reflect neuronal sampling bias or cluster-merging artifacts during spike sorting of electrophysiological recordings, rather than flaws in event detection from fluorescence time series. This work establishes the dominant impacts of the two modalities’ respective biases on a set of functional metrics that are fundamental for characterizing sensory-evoked responses.
 Interactive talk
Watch now
Retinal waves prime visual motion detection by simulating future optic flow
Xinxin Ge
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Xinxin Ge, UCSF (formerly at Yale); Kathy Zhang, Yale; Ali Hamodi, Yale; Alex Gribizis, Max Plank Florida Institute for Neuroscience; Aude Martinez Sabino, University of Technology of Compiègne

The ability to perceive and respond to environmental stimuli emerges in the absence of sensory experience. Spontaneous retinal activity prior to eye-opening guides the refinement of retinotopy and eye-specific segregation, but its role in the development of higher order visual response properties remains unclear. Here, we describe a transient developmental window during which the spatial propagation of spontaneous retinal waves resembles the optic flow pattern generated by forward self-motion. We show that wave directionality requires the same circuit components that form the adult direction-selective retinal circuit and that chronic disruption of wave directionality alters the development of direction-selective responses of superior colliculus neurons. These data demonstrate how the developing visual system patterns spontaneous activity to simulate ethologically relevant features of the external world to instruct self-organization.
 Traditional talk
Watch now
Paired Stimulation in the Human Limbic System Induced Functional Connectivity Changes Consistent with Spike-Timing-Dependent Plasticity
Jasmine Zhou
 
Coauthors, Abstract
 
Kira Evitts, University of Washington; Samantha Sun, University of Washington; Ankit Khambhati, University of California, San Francisco; Kristin Sellers, University of California, San Francisco; Edward Chang, University of California, San Francisco; Azadeh Yazdan-Shahmorad, Washington National Primate Research Center, University of Washington, and University of California, San Francisco

Many neurological disorders can be attributed to abnormal neural dynamics at the network level, which arise from anomalous neural connectivity. As a result, spatially and temporally specific brain stimulation protocols can be designed to take advantage of our brain’s natural plasticity, reorganize selected neural connections, and serve as a potential therapy for various brain disorders.
